column2: Lonely Planet’s  “Traveller’s Guide to Making a Difference Around the World” lists a set of tough questions that you should answer before signing up for a volunteer program.
This Indian Ocean resort, perched on the spine of Kiwayu Island, off the coast of Kenya, is pure Gilligan’s Island, a stick and twine arrangement jutting out from the bush.
Long the modest cousin of Forest Hills, its refined neighbor to the east, Rego Park has lately been buoyed by upwardly mobile immigrants.
Amsterdam is angling to become Europe’s creative capital, and it’s doing so without even inhaling.
Things are getting confusing out there in Genderville.

At present, the U.S. defense budget accounts for approximately half of total global defense spending, while the U.S. armed forces employ about 1.68 million uniformed members. By comparison, the State Department employs about 6,000 foreign service officers, while the U.S. Agency for International Development has about 2,000. In other words, the Department of Defense is about 210 times larger than USAID and State combined -- there are substantially more people employed as musicians in Defense bands than in the entire foreign service.

BREW--Norma (Atlas), of New York City, New York died peacefully on July 6, 2007 at the age of 85. Born on April 1, 1922, Norma lived her entire life in New York City. She began working for the New York Times in 1947, where she remained for over 40 years. During this time, she met and married one of the editors, Thomas Brew. He passed away in 1974. A devoted patron of the arts and theatre, Norma corresponded with many actors, musicians, and dancers worldwide, often traveling abroad to attend their performances. She was loved by all whose lives she so gracefully touched. Norma will be remembered for her eloquent writing, her charming sense of humor, and her sincere devotion to her friends. She will be deeply missed by her friends and family. Services were private. Donations in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

To the Editor: In his review of Michael J. Behe's ''Edge of Evolution'' (July 1), Richard Dawkins writes of a certain breed of dog derived from its lupine ancestor, ''a heavyset, thick-coated wolf, strong enough to carry a cask of brandy, that thrives in Alpine passes and might be named after one of them, the St. Bernard.''

WHEN Josh Fatoullah graduated from Great Neck North High a few years ago and went off to freshman year at Florida State, his parents were sure he was gone for good. ''I said, 'He'll never live here again,' '' recalled his father, Ron, a lawyer. Ron Fatoullah was 17 when his own father died of a heart attack, and this made him very emotional about Josh's departure.
To the Editor:

IN the pitch-black din of the Whale Inside Dark Restaurant in Beijing, a table of 30 diners was getting rowdy. ''I'm touching your head!'' said one, like a mischievous child. ''Who just said that?'' another replied. The disembodied voices floated across the boisterous 90-plus-seat restaurant, but no one could see who was talking, except for the waiters, who were outfitted with military-grade night-vision goggles. In a new twist on conceptual dining, restaurants are turning off the lights to focus attention on the food. The trend seems to have started in Zurich and has since spawned permutations all over the world, with diners donning blindfolds, sitting in unlit rooms and, lately, being served by waiters in night-vision goggles. The idea is that by depriving one sense (sight), other senses are heightened.
To the Editor:
To the Editor:
To the Editor:

To the Editor: I find it off-putting that Richard Dawkins was selected to review Michael Behe's new book, even though I favor Dawkins's position on intelligent design. Is it surprising that Dawkins's review would be concerned only with discrediting Behe? Hardly: their public rivalry dictated the review's content before the book was even published. Dawkins's criticism was not only predictable, it was -- literally -- also a page taken from his own book, ''The God Delusion'' (Page 130). What intelligent design would have allowed the editors to go ahead with this assignment? Can your readers expect Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to review Rushdie's new book? Hyperbole aside, this review offered nothing that I could not get from reading Dawkins, and prevented a meaningful glimpse of an alternative viewpoint.

In France, Bernard-Henri Lévy is famous for his impeccably tailored open-necked shirts, the glamorous company he keeps, and a string of 30 books on subjects ranging from European intellectuals' misguided dalliance with Marxism (''Barbarism With a Human Face'') to the legacy of Jean-Paul Sartre (''Sarte: The Philosopher of the 20th Century'') to post-9/11 Islamic radicalism (''Who Killed Daniel Pearl?''). Over here, he's better known as the guy who traveled from the Baseball Hall of Fame to evangelical megachurches to Las Vegas lap-dance parlors researching his book ''American Vertigo: Traveling America in the Footsteps of Tocqueville,'' which earned him a spot on the Times best-seller list (and, in these pages, a memorable trip to the woodshed courtesy of Garrison Keillor). This week, Lévy takes the measure of the newly elected French president, Nicolas Sarkozy. Sarkozy's candidacy divided France's left-leaning intelligentsia, with a number of Lévy's fellow ''new philosophers'' -- as the anti-Communist thinkers who came of age in the 1970s are known -- declaring their support. But despite sympathy with Sarkozy's foreign policy and ''anti-anti-American'' outlook, Lévy could not endorse the tough-talking conservative. In his review of Sarkozy's book ''Testimony,'' which begins on Page 8, he explains why The Editors

To the Editor: Re ''Gavel to Gavel (to Gavel to Gavel) Coverage'' by Alessandra Stanley [July 8]:

MORTGAGE bankers and brokers say they encourage borrowers to shop around before committing to a loan, but that does not stop many of them with ending every introductory phone call with the question: Do you want to lock in the rate?

BEAULIEU--Rick J., age 56, joined his beloved soulmate, Deborah in heaven on July 18. We will miss his charismatic charm. Rick was a successful ad executive in New York for over 20 years. Visitation Monday, funeral Tuesday, Chicago, IL. Services by Beverly Ridge Funeral Home 773-779-4411.

Jaimie Epstein's words hit home with this online dater (On Language, July 8). My sister has urged me to give some of these grammar-challenged guys a chance. Since her husband, a prince among men, still clings to his Southern expression ''might-could,'' I accept her advice, which brings me to the next step: the phone call. It's then that I'm really turned off, between the ''I go'' instead of ''I said'' and the dreaded ''upspeak,'' ending every statement with a question.

Brian Butterfield, the third-base coach for the Toronto Blue Jays, has a dream. He wants to work for two professional teams in different sports, meaning he would keep his job with the Blue Jays and secure a position as a player evaluator for the New England Patriots. ''Deion Sanders and Bo Jackson did it as players,'' Butterfield said. ''Why couldn't I do it? I could be a scout. They wouldn't have to pay me much.''
SCHNEEWEISS--Pauline (nee Goldfine) June 2, 1913 -July 22, 1996. Rivie, I love you forever. Sam
To the Editor:

BARTELS--Irvin, July 13, 2007 at age 83 in Miami, FL, after a long illness. Husband of Connie, father of Nannette and Donald (Andrea), grandfather of Corinne (Scott) and Rebecca. He is also survived by his sister Clarice. WWII veteran, he served in France and Germany. Graduate of Brooklyn College. Bart, as he was known to his friends, formerly worked as a Purchasing Manager in the Electronics field. In addition, he was a talented photographer, involved in Community Theater and later an integral part of the Weston, Connecticut Shakespeare Play Reading Group. His sunny, optimistic disposition spread happiness to those around him. During his last few years he took great joy in the beauty of the semi-tropical South Florida climate. A memorial service will be held Sunday August 5th at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation of Miami.

Ellen Kathleen Bradford and Todd Allen McIntosh were married yesterday at Holy Name Cathedral in Chicago. The Rev. Daniel G. Mayall, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. Mrs. McIntosh, 32, is an associate in the insurance and financial services group of Sidley Austin, the Chicago law firm. She graduated summa cum laude from Clemson and received a law degree from Harvard.

PATTY HEWES frightens Glenn Close. No wonder: Hewes is an ice-eyed trial lawyer and serpentine liar who disdains white-collar violence in favor of open sadism. She never settles for $100 million, in other words, when she can put everyone through hell for a nickel more.

TAKING A STROLL ON NUNGWI BEACH, JAN. 18, 2007 Fabian Colley, 32, a coal miner and farmhand from Mudgee, New South Wales, Australia, with Brooke Bliss, 29, a teacher: ''We'd just done two weeks in Egypt and five weeks elsewhere in Africa, traveling with, like, 10 and then 20 people. So it was nice leaving to go to Zanzibar on our own. That morning we were actually walking to get a taxi to the other side of the island -- where we were getting married the next day. It was a beautiful, intimate marriage service, just us and a couple people from the resort for witnesses. And then you had the long white beach and the palms and the ocean. For us, it was just about us, so we could enjoy the moment instead of having a big wedding and worrying about everyone else having a good time. This was more of a thing for me and Brooke.'' As told to Austin Considine
To the Editor:

STATE lawmakers have taken a lot of grief for what they failed to accomplish before adjourning last month. But New Yorkers should celebrate at least one piece of legislative inaction: a bill that would forbid lawsuits against arbitration service providers. That measure remains in committee, and we can only hope it stays there.

It is naïve to assume that the only shoplifting going on in that fancy-food shop is taking place in view of the security cameras (The Ethicist, July 8). Instead of billing only for those items that were caught on tape, why not add a few additional items that were ''missed'' by the cameras. This would put the shoplifter in an awkward position. How could he confront the shop owner? What would he say? ''I only stole the macadamia nuts; I never touched the caviar!'' He will get the message loud and clear: Busted. Hoisted on his own petard.
To the Editor:
Tom Carvel's body will remain buried at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, despite efforts by his niece to exhume it so it can be examined for foul play.

To the Editor: ''Solar Power Captures Imagination, Not Money'' (''The Energy Challenge'' series, front page, July 16) reminds me of a lecture I heard in the mid-70s by Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court.

KOHANSKI--Dorothy Dellar, died July 17, 2007 at her home in Columbia, MD. Born May 15, 1921 in Spokane, WA, the former Marine Corps Reserve Sergeant, educator and genealogist was wife of the late Dr. Alexander S. Kohanski and mother of the late Aaron Kohanski. She is survived by two sons and their wives: Dan Kohanski and Jean Marcucci, Ron Kohanski and Leslie Pick; and five grandchildren: Michael, Samson, Anna, Alexander and Emma.

The ROCK THE BELLS festival on Randalls Island might seem like a 10-year-old memory, because the headliners are Rage Against the Machine and Wu-Tang Clan, who toured together in 1997. It was a weird double bill back then: Wu-Tang played its trademark desultory, tricksterish set in a state of high flux -- it was hard to tell who was onstage, who was missing, who was just along for the ride -- while Rage Against the Machine fans pawed and snorted and stamped the ground. Then, when Rage appeared, at the first power chord, kaboom: frat-boy hell, or heaven, depending on your taste. Wu-Tang has never quite gone away, while Rage Against the Machine officially broke up, then re-formed. But the rest of the touring festival's lineup puts their pairing of the two headliners in a context that unites them. This is an alternative festival for rock fans and old hip-hop heads, nostalgic mostly for the late '90s, with a little mid-'80s thrown in as well; it includes the Roots, Mos Def, Cypress Hill, Mr. Lif, Rakim, EPMD, Erykah Badu and Public Enemy. Saturday and next Sunday, starting at noon, Randalls Island, tickemaster.com, rockthebells.net; $83.

Now he has founded his own company, BAD BOYS OF DANCE, an all-male ensemble which makes its debut at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival on Thursday. You have a system that is taxed to the limit. This is what happens when spare capacity is eroded.

When you picture a youth hostel, images of Birkenstock-shod backpackers sleeping on ripped sofas may come to mind. No longer. Now there are designer hostels, aimed at ''flashpackers,'' who want cheap, but contemporary, lodging. In London, YHA (www.yha.org.uk), which operates more than 200 hostels in England and Wales, recently spent £1.7 million renovating its Earls Court Hostel (right). Not only does the hostel now have a cafe serving cappuccinos and lattes, it has a lounge with a flat-screen TV, a courtyard garden and Wi-Fi and dial-up Internet connections. Double, twin-bedded rooms start at £57 a night ($117 at $2.05 to £1), while those willing to sleep in one of the two communal 10-bed, single-sex rooms need pay only £17.20.

Thank you for Akiko Busch's beautiful poem to the Hudson River (July 8). The Hudson brings serenity and inspires awe in all seasons, from the February EagleFest, when crowds at Charles Point in Peekskill gather to watch eagles sitting on the ice floes, to sultry summer evenings, when strollers walk a mile out into the Hudson on the Piermont pier.
The New York State Health Department will appeal a judge's ruling that temporarily blocks the closing of Community Hospital in Dobbs Ferry, a department spokeswoman said last week.

To the Editor: I could not agree with Karen Houppert more (''Final Period,'' Op-Ed, July 17). I am quite surprised that a perfectly normal process of womanhood can be phased out by a birth control pill, Lybrel.

To the Editor:
The eldest children in families tend to develop higher I.Q.'s than their siblings, researchers are reporting.
To the Editor:

Gary Rosen (July 8) complains that he's ''tired of the sanctimony and alarmism that surround the subject'' of global warming. His essay was well timed to appear the day after the seven-continent ''Live Earth'' benefit concerts organized by the high priest of sanctimonious alarmism, Al Gore. After the communal affirmations of Saturday's global celebration, a cold bath of Sunday morning sobriety is just what we need. ''The current debate would benefit from less emotion and more calculation,'' Rosen says. Fine. By all means, let us debate the best course of action. But let us remember that all the rational deliberation (Rosen's choice of ''calculation'' is telling) in the world will fail to lead to action unless people are motivated to act, and motivation is powered by emotion.
To the Editor:

ISRAELSSON--Bo Hampus, of Greenwich, CT passed away on July 10, 2007 at the age of 74. Born in Gothenburg and raised in Halmstad, Sweden, he earned a Master of Political Science and a Ph.D. in Statistics at the University of Lund before beginning his business career as M.D. of Asbrink & Co in Malmoe, Sweden. From 1967 to 1970 he served as Swedish Trade Commissioner to Canada, thereafter as President for various Swedish and American subsidiaries in Canada, Austria, Sweden, and the US. In 1984 he was appointed President of the Swedish Trade Council, headquartered in Stockholm. In 1991 he returned to the US as a management consultant and an adjunct professor at the University of Connecticut. Bo enjoyed family, friends, golf, hunting and the piano. He is survived by his wife Karin of 51 years, daughters Monica Mattar and Lena Evans (husband Roger), sons Johan (wife Amy) and Peter (wife Janani Nathan), and his nine grandchildren, as well as by his brother Mats (wife Barbro). Memorial services will be held on July 23 at 2 pm at the Church of Sweden in NY, 5 East 48th Street, and on August 20 in Falsterbo, Sweden. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Moffitt Cancer Center Foundation, 12902 Magnolia Drive, UTC FOUND, Tampa, FL 33612 (www.moffitt.usf.edu) are welcome.
To the Editor:

The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 14,000 for the first time on Thursday, only to fall back on Friday. Friday's losses pulled the major market averages into negative territory for the week. On Friday, the Dow dropped by nearly 150 points, afterGoogle and Caterpillar announced earnings for the second quarter that failed to meet Wall Street's expectations.

Roger Cohen (July 8) fails to note any political skills Tzipi Livni has displayed or might possess, required of a leader of a nation at war. In fact, his article suggests, by describing her past reluctance to try to seize the brass ring of the prime minister's office -- in effect, a politician whose most risky move is gunning the engine at an intersection when the light turns yellow -- that she lacks them.
To the Editor:

JAFFE--Richard, died on July 14. He was kind-hearted, sweet, and a good, decent human being. He spoke and listened to everyone with equal regard, whether discussing last night's ball game with a cab driver or questioning Senator Joe Lieberman at the JCC. He was an avid sports fan, amateur tennis champion, and devoted bridge player. As a lifelong reader of this newspaper, he enjoyed debating politics. He worked in New York's Diamond District, beginning at his grandfather's jewelry business, A. Jaffe & Son, and retiring from Harry Winston. His wife, daughter Susan, son Howard and family and friends will cherish all the good memories he leaves behind. Family visitation will be held at home July 29, 3-5 pm.

Ms. Lynn, 37, is keeping her name. She is a senior editor at Zagat Survey in New York and the author of a novel, ''Now You See It'' (Simon & Schuster, 2004). She graduated from Dartmouth and received a Master of Fine Arts in fiction writing from New York University.

Cinemax may not have the most high-minded reputation, but under its ''Reel Life'' banner it's one of the steadiest exhibitors of serious documentaries. This Thursday it presents the television premiere of ''THE BLOOD OF YINGZHOU DISTRICT'' (7 p.m.), the winner of this year's Oscar for best documentary short. Ruby Yang's film tracks the lives of Chinese children who have been orphaned because their parents sold their blood and died of AIDS. Four years ago Cinemax presented another documentary about AIDS in China, the unforgettable ''To Live Is Better Than to Die,'' as grim and unadorned a depiction of disease, poverty and death as you're ever likely to see on American television, and ''Yingzhou District'' plays like a sequel, following the children victimized by the blood-selling crisis into the next sad chapter of their lives.

JONES--Geoffrey Mont gomery Talbot, died peacefully July 20th in New York City after a gallant fight with brain cancer. Born in 1919 in Newport, RI, he was a resident of New York City for many years. Upon graduating from Princeton in 1942, he served in the US Army and overseas with the OSS, receiving two battlefield promotions to Major. His decorations include: the US Legion of Merit; the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Cluster; the Purple Heart; the Order of the British Empire; Officer of the French Legion of Honor; three Croix de Guerre; the Danish Medal for Freedom; the Donovan Medal; and the Italian Order of Merit, Commendatore. He retired as President of the Veterans of OSS in 2001. He was President of the Donovan Memorial Foundation. He is survived by his son, Kiley C. T. Jones of New York City. Memorial service at a date to be announced.

The article describes the Irgun as ''Zionist guerrillas who used what would today be called terrorist methods to blast the British out of Palestine.'' In fact, today the Irgun would not be considered terrorist. After all, if members of Al Qaeda, who routinely slaughter Iraqis by the hundreds, are ''insurgents,'' and Hamas, which has done the same in Israel, is made up of ''militants,'' it is unlikely the Irgun, which focused primarily on British forces and which was loath to kill civilians, would be considered terrorist. But given the rampant double standards that bedevil Israel, who knows?
To the Editor:

Predeceased by her husband, Oscar Sachs, she is survived by daughters Nikki Sachs, Barbara Sachs, and Devorah Verburg - Sachs; and six grandchildren, Aaron, Jesse, Zachary, Noah, Joshua and Zoe. I laughed out loud as I read Marion Winik's Lives column (July 8). I am the 46-year-old mother of two boys (19 and 15) and a 4-year-old girl (had her at 41). I have heard the ''it will keep you young'' comment many times. If enduring a nursery-school interview on the same day your son's fake ID is confiscated by campus police, all while suffering from hot flashes, guarantees youth, then Winik and I will both live well into our hundreds. Thanks for revealing our secret plan for eternal youth.

The Somerset County Park Commission, which was sharply criticized in a county report two weeks ago for poor management and fiscal practices, agreed Thursday to tighten its spending and give more oversight of its operations to county officials.
To the Editor:

DANBURY--Tom, 71, retired co-founder of Survey Sampling International (SSI), passed away on July 11 in Kansas City, Missouri. Mr. Danbury is credited with a number of innovations for the marketing research industry and co-founded the first commercial sampling company in 1977 with Beverly Weiman. Prior to founding SSI, Mr. Danbury was Director of Marketing Research at Donnelley's Marketing Information Center (1972-1977). He was VP and Associate Research Director at Foote, Cone and Belding (1966-1972). Mr. Danbury was a faculty member at the Communications Research Center, Michigan State University (1961 -1966). Mr. Danbury was born April 29, 1936, in King City, Missouri. He received his Journalism degree from the University of Missouri-Columbia. Mr. Danbury married Rosalie A. John in 1959. They were residents of Mamaroneck, NY from 1966-1969 and Westport, CT from 1969-1992. Since his retirement, Mr. Danbury and his wife lived in Kilauea, HI. Mr. Danbury is survived by his wife Rosalie; sons, Jim and his wife Diane, John and his wife Elizabeth, and Peter; four grandchildren; and brothers, Donald, Robert and Charles Danbury. Memorial contributions may be made to The Carter Center by visiting (cartercenter.org) or Care (care.org). Online condolences may be made at www.mem.com.

While Brazilians celebrate the fact that the Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro was named one of the new seven wonders of the world on July 7, Unesco, which awards World Heritage status to historic sites and then helps countries protect them, is worried about the ramifications of the contest. ''We believe there is a risk that these sites will become tourist attractions like Disneyland,'' said Sue Williams, a Unesco spokeswoman, adding, ''The campaign seemed quite commercially driven and another way to lure in more tourist dollars.''
MANN--Nathan. Geoffrey Beene Inc. mourns the loss of our longtime friend and colleague Mr. Nathan Mann. Our sincere sympathy goes to the Mann family.

To the Editor: Niall Ferguson, with whom I have differed repeatedly over his defense of imperialism, needlessly tries to start a fight between Paul Collier and me in his review of Collier's ''Bottom Billion'' (July 1). I applaud Collier's excellent new book and thank him for including kind references to my own work therein. The very idea of the poverty trap as being critical in Africa, a concept at the core of ''The Bottom Billion,'' has likewise been a core theme of my own writings on Africa, indeed a central theme of my book ''The End of Poverty.'' The notion of different factors contributing to the poverty trap is also a theme common to both our research efforts. For my part, I have worked hard to introduce in the academic literature and policy discussions the idea that poverty is involved in vicious circles related to violence, natural resources, landlockedness and other geographic factors, and poor governance.

To the Editor: One can agree or disagree with the criticism of Clarence Thomas both in Orlando Peterson's review of ''Supreme Discomfort'' (June 17) and in the book itself. However, as a resident of Savannah, I object to the disservice done to the low-income but quite safe and respectable community of Pin Point, Ga., by calling it ''a scene of rural desolation,'' ''black life in the rural South at its bleakest'' and ''this sociological nightmare.'' By the way, the crab factory is long gone, but it provided a living for some when few other opportunities were available. The owner kept it operating as long as possible for the sake of the employees, but eventually succumbed to economics. I am sure the good citizens of Pin Point feel fortunate in comparison with residents of the ghettos of large cities, especially in the North.

McDONALD--Yong Ash. She fought her illness with great strength and dignity. We have always admired her kindness, warmth, optimism and consideration for others. Our deepest condolences to her husband, Mayor Jack McDonald of Palm Beach, FL, who treated her with great love and tenderness. We will miss her, and mourn her untimely passing. Barbara and Michael Ditzian Lorinda and Peter Ezersky Gloria and Philip Levin

Tzipi Livni's understanding that Israel rose from the ashes of the Holocaust and her awareness of that responsibility for coming generations should prepare her for the challenges she faces. Her roots within a family that felt like outsiders can provide a useful perspective. Her Mossad training and love of her country sound promising. Israel is lucky to have someone like her on the rise.
To the Editor:

If the four conservative justices on the Supreme Court insist on using the First Amendment to dismantle McCain-Feingold because ''giving money is a form of speech,'' then I suppose they won't object to my exercising my First Amendment right to refrain from giving tax dollars to the government for its ill-conceived and immoral war in Iraq (Jeffrey Rosen, July 8).
To the Editor:

Despite the criticism President Bush has received over his Iraq War policies, isn't it interesting that stock markets have been booming since early 2003, when Saddam was overthrown and the president signed his supply-side tax cuts into law? NOTTINGHAM--Robinson Kendall, Jr, age 46, on July 18, 2007 in the company of his parents at their home in Washington, DC. Resident of Lake Worth, FL and Washington, DC. Caused by melanoma cancer. Founded a residential real estate firm in 1998 in Washington, DC and expanded it to Palm Beach County, FL in 2004 after practicing law in New York and Washington, DC for 12 years, including seven years as a prosecutor in the U.S. Justice Department's Criminal Division. Graduate of the University of Virginia School of Law (1986), Wesleyan University (1983), and Newark Academy (1979) in Livingston, NJ. Dedicated friend and generous philanthropist. Served as tutor, board member and major fundraiser for Good Shepherd Ministries, Inc., providing tutoring and mentoring to at-risk children in Washington, DC. Survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. R. Kendall Nottingham of Washington, DC and Palm Beach, FL; brother, Charles D. Nottingham of Fredericksburg, VA; sister-in-law, Catherine C. Nottingham of Fredericksburg, VA; two nephews, Garner L. Nottingham and Charles S. Nottingham of Fredericksburg, VA; and many devoted friends. The family will receive friends at a visitation to be held at Gawlers Funeral Home 5130 Wisconsin Ave., NW, Washington, DC on Monday July 23 from 12:00 noon until 2:00pm. I don't suppose that Tzipi Livni would be willing to extend a hand to any leader of Hamas and say: ''You are a terrorist: my father was a terrorist, and I am proud of him. We used terrorism when it served our purposes, and then we retired and entered politics. I urge you to do the same. Together we need to discuss the needs of both our peoples.'' No, I don't imagine that Livni would do that. She wants ''the West'' to ''tell Hamas . . . that it must not only recognize Israel's right to exist but also 'the right of Israel to exist as a Jewish state.' '' Every Israeli I have known in the past 60 years has known what Palestinians ''should do,'' but no one has effectively persuaded them.

Last Thursday, Virgin America, the new Burlingame, Calif.-based airline that bills itself as the ''next generation low-fare carrier,'' started selling tickets for flights from San Francisco to New York and Los Angeles, which begin on Aug. 8, and to Washington and Las Vegas, which begin in September and October, respectively. The company, whose fleet currently has 10 Airbus 320-class planes, hopes to expand its service to up to 30 cities within five years. The first-class cabin features white leather seating with a massage function, shown above, while the main cabin has perks like mood-lighting and plugs for portable electronic devices (www.virginamerica.com). ... At three Peninsula Hotels -- in New York, Hong Kong and Bangkok -- guests who stay for one night in a suite will get a second night free. ''The Suite Life'' is valid through Sept. 15; nightly suite rates start at $460 for Bangkok, $876 for Hong Kong and $1,600 for New York (www.peninsula.com). ... Liberty Science Center in New Jersey reopened last week after having closed for 22 months and over $100 million worth of renovations. The center now has 85,000 square feet dedicated to exhibition space -- including six new exhibition areas -- and a learning and teaching center. The redesigned gift shop has a roof made of soil and growing plants, and a new wing houses the museum's signature exhibition, ''Skyscraper! Achievement and Impact,'' in an 11,000-square-foot gallery. The exhibition includes cut-away views of buildings and hands-on activities like conducting wind tunnel tests on buildings designed by participants. Other exhibitions include ''Eat and Be Eaten,'' which explores the predator-prey cycle, and I Explore, which is geared toward teaching younger children (2 to 6 years old) about body awareness. The museum, located in Liberty State Park, is accessible via the PATH train and a light-rail transfer, or via ferry or water taxi and a light-rail transfer (www.lsc.org).

DAVIDSON--Laura Agnes. Renowned haiku poet L.A. Davidson died July 18, 2007 two weeks before her 90th birthday. In 2003 Vincent Tripi wrote ''L.A. Davidson is one of the most honored and respected American haiku poets. She exemplifies, at its highest level, the poetic ideal of servitude to beauty and the truth.'' Best known for ''The Shape of the Tree New York New York,'' ''Jamaica Moments'' and ''Bird Song More and More,'' she was active in haiku since the founding of the Haiku Society of America 1968. Family and friends will miss her gumption, good heart, great cookies and moments of exquisite poetry. Cremation private. Memorial donations to Haiku Society of America, 31 Seal Island Road, Bristol, RI 02809-5186.

On the Road in Portugal To the Editor: Lest your readers get discouraged about driving in Portugal because of Sarah Wildman's remarks in her article ''Portugal's Hidden 'Dream Places''' (July 8), I want to report much more favorable driving experiences from my trip to northern Portugal last October. Because my wife and I were staying at Solar da Rede, I drove on roads (for over a week) from Lisbon to north of Porto and didn't feel any need for G.P.S. help. The autostradas were particularly good, primarily because a lot of E.U. money has been flowing to Portugal for infrastructural improvements. Many secondary roads are winding, but the scenery is spectacular.

WENTZ--Sidney F., 75, on Wednesday, July, 18, 2007. Sidney F. Wentz of Hobe Sound, FL, Little Compton, RI, and Florham Park, NJ, passed away at Massachusetts General Hospital after a short illness. He is survived by his wife, Barbara, son Eric, daughters Jennifer Rich and Robin Chisholm, and six grandchildren. Born on March 27, 1932 in Dallas, TX, Sidney grew up in Cleveland, OH, graduated from Princeton University with a B.A. in 1954, served in the Navy from 1954-1957, and graduated from Harvard Law School in 1960. From 1960-1965, Sidney was an attorney at White & Case, NYC, and a corporate attorney for AT&T from 1965-1967. Commencing in 1967, he held several positions with Crum and Forster, an insurance holding company, retiring as Chairman and CEO in 1988. He served as Chairman of the Board of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation from 1989-1999. He also served on the Board of Directors for several companies including Ace Limited Insurance Company and Castle Energy Corporation. In addition, he served as a Trustee for Morristown Memorial Hospital, Drew University, and the Hobe Sound Community Chest. Services will be held Friday, August 3, at 2:00pm, at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, RI. Donations can be made in his name to the Hobe Sound Community Chest, Inc., P.O. Box 511, Hobe Sound, FL, 33475, or to Massachusetts General Hospital, Development Office, 165 Cambridge Street, Suite 600, Boston, MA, 02114 (please specify Gastrointestinal Cancer Center). To sign the online guestbook please visit www.potter funeralservice.com

ELDRIDGE--Douglas H., 1916-2007. Douglas Hilton Eldridge died July 19th, 2007 at his home. He was born in central Montana on April 12th, 1916. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from the University of Washington with a bachelors degree in economics in 1937 and a masters in business in 1941. He began his lifelong work in public finance with the Washington State Tax Commission in 1939. Joining the United States Navy on December 9th, 1942, he served in Naval Intelligence as a Japanese Language officer. Among other commendations, he received the Presidential Unit Citation awarded to the Assault Troops of the Fifth Amphibious Corps in the Battle of Iwo Jima. Completing his Ph.D. in 1949, he joined the Tax Analysis Staff of the United States Treasury in Washington, D.C. In 1953 and 1954 he worked on the staff of Senator Ralph Flanders of Vermont. Returning to the Treasury, he continued to work in the taxation and public finance area rising to Chief of the Tax Analysis Staff. During his period in Washington, he authored articles and reviews in the Journal of Political Economy and other publications. In 1962 he became a professor of economics at Claremont Mens College and the Claremont Graduate Schools. His appointment as Executive Director of the National Bureau of Economic Research was announced in the New York Times in August 23rd, 1965. He retired from the National Bureau as Executive Secretary in 1978. He married Clara E. Young on June 8th, 1940. They traveled the world and had a long and devoted life together. They raised three children, Douglas A. Eldridge of Albany, NY, Edith Marie Eldridge (died 1971) and Maurice Paul Eldridge of Boston, MA. A member of the American Economic Association, the National Association of Business Economists, the National Tax Association, the Tax Institute of American, Beta Gamma Sigma and the Lincoln Institute for Land Policy, he served on the Board of Directors of the Lincoln Foundation. Douglas H. Eldridge reflected the strength and stoicism of his origins in Depression era Montana. He was a public servant foremost. He is survived by his wife and sons, their spouses, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 225 Michigan Avenue, Floor 17, Chicago, IL 60601. Funeral service will be private.

MASTERS--Esther Shady, of New York, NY, died peacefully at her home in Manhattan on Thursday, July 19, 2007. She was 100 years old. Born Esther Shaderowfsky, she grew up in Brooklyn, attended Erasmus Hall and worked as a buyer for Bonwit Teller. She was married for 48 years to A. Edward Masters, an attorney in solo practice, until his death in 1980. A New Yorker to the core, she was fully engaged with life in the city until her final illness. An avid theater-goer and dancer, she regularly attended performances with the Manhattan Theater Guild, ate out at fine restaurants and shopped enthusiastically until well into her late 90s. She is survived by two sons, Jon J. Masters of New York, NY, and Kim J. Masters of Fort Mill, SC; five grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. The funeral services will be private. The family will receive condolence calls Sunday afternoon, July 22nd.

An entry in the Manhattan section of Residential Sales Around the Region last Sunday about the sale of a studio apartment at 211 East 53rd Street was published in error. The sale closed on March 2, 2005; it was not a recent sale.

An article in Sunday Styles last week about Ronald Boyer, a former actor in pornographic movies who has expressed the desire to be an Episcopal priest, referred incorrectly to his progress toward that goal. He has been confirmed in the church; he is not working toward ordination as a priest or undergoing training to be a deacon. The article also referred incorrectly to efforts by Mr. Boyer to establish a ministry among sex workers. He discussed the plan with the vicar of his church; he did not meet with the secondranking official of the Episcopal Diocese of Los Angeles, Bishop Suffragan Chester L. Talton.

Maria Sharapova has been told that she will not be considered for the Russian Fed Cup team that will face Italy in the final in September. That decision, by the Russian Fed Cup captain Shamil Tarpishchev, could affect her chances of playing in the 2008 Beijing Olympics.A shoulder injury forced Sharapova to pull out of the semifinal last week against the United States, once again delaying her Fed Cup debut.''I feel it would be incorrect to invite Sharapova to play against Italy as we reached the final without her,'' Tarpishchev said.According to the rules of the Russian federation, only those players who perform on the country's teams in Davis Cup or Fed Cup can be considered for Olympic selection.

CNN has been providing frenzied coverage in the hours leading up to its broadcast of the YouTube debate, calling it a ground-breaking moment in politics and providing the same wall-to-wall coverage that it grants major news developments. The cable network is even conducting a "countdown" to the debate's 7 p.m. start in the lower right corner of the screen, as if it were a space launch or New Year's Eve.

CHARLESTON, S.C. -- One of the more interesting things to watch for in tonight's CNN/YouTube presidential debate is whether the quality of the questions from regular viewers are better - more insightful, more probing, more off-beat - than questions the candidates have encountered this year from panels of print and television journalists.

The poisoning of a former KGB agent in London further unraveled into a political dispute last week, with Moscow continuing to refuse to extradite the man British law enforcement has identified as the main suspect in the case. By the end of the week, both countries had announced tit-for-tat expulsions of each other's diplomats, and said they would tighten visa requirements on government officials. For now, it seems, the case is being tried in public statements from the British and Russian governments - and in the court of public opinion.
A rendering of the mobile pavilion designed by Zaha Hadid. (Courtesy of Zaha Hadid Architects)
Reading about Markus Winkelhock leading the first (and perhaps final) lap of his Formula One career, I couldn't help thinking of two things.

Teachers tell me constantly that practice is the best strategy to master a new language. But that can be humiliating when your French has a nasal twang that prompts native speakers to regard you like a Martian.

"Here's a crude generalization: after the sixties, intellect and patriotism went separate ways, to the detriment of both. This mutual hostility made intellectuals less responsible and soldiers less thoughtful," writes George Packer at The New Yorker's Interesting Times blog.
While we continued to refine the plans to cut costs, we also addressed a looming issue: How the heck we were going to pay for construction.
A few minutes ago, Grant Achatz, the chef of Alinea in Chicago, released this statement through his publicist:

CHARLESTON, S.C. - There was a collision here today, right downtown in Waterfront Park, when John Edwards and Joe Biden turned up at the same photo opportunity hours before tonight's Democratic presidential debate.

For most of the history of Western civilization, there hardly was any such thing as a former king. Their reigns generally lasted until they died, peaceably or otherwise, and it was axiomatic that if you wanted to depose one, you'd better kill him; merely lock him up or chase him away, and a lot of people would go on regarding him, not you, as the rightful monarch, causing no end of ensuing bother.

American support for the initial invasion of Iraq has risen somewhat as the White House has continued to ask the public to reserve judgment about the war until General David Petraeus files his report in the fall.
Paul Krugman responds to readers' comments on his July 20 column, "The French Connections."

Any loyal reader of The Caucus knows how fond we are of campaign music. So we are delighted to present this audio report today by Jack Cushman of the Washington Bureau that looks at the state of politics and music, past and present.

"Self-hate, in the Jewish context, is assailed by traditionalists, quantified by sociologists, catalogued by hobbyists, ribbed by comedians, feared by parents," writes Bradley Burston at Haaretz.com. "It is also underrated."

Idealab, the original Internet incubator, never made it to the public markets. The company, which hatched successful start-ups such as Citysearch and flameouts such as eToys, called off its proposed initial public offering in 2000, as Silicon Valley was feeling the painful downside of the dot-com bubble.
In his Web column today, Patrick Healy writes:

Last week, one of Rome's daily newspapers, Il Messaggero, ran an article about some of the bizarre questions put to "060606," the city of Rome's information hotline that's active 24-hours a day, 365 days a year. Besides requests for mamma's recipe for spaghetti all'amatriciana (a bacon and tomato sauce typical of the Lazio region), call center workers had plenty of stories for the Messagero reporter: the concerned citizen who phoned in to report a "suspicious looking pigeon" during the bird flu scare; the motorist who called to find out whether zero is an odd or an even number, during a day where traffic was limited to odd number license plates. In fact, calling 060606 is extremely useful if you live in Rome and are forced to navigate the capital's bureaucratic intricacies on a regular basis. It also provides information on other sundry questions, like where to pick up a parked car that's been towed away, or where to bring a pigeon with a broken wing (the bird center next to the zoo, as it happens). But tourists may find it useful, too (though for information on exhibitions and museum hours and other similar queries, callers are rerouted to a tourist information line - 06 82059127 - which operates daily from 9 AM to 7:30 PM). If you're calling from a fixed dial phone, the calls cost the local rate. If you're calling from a cellphone the costs depend on your carrier's charges.

On "Meet the Press" yesterday, Sen. Russ Feingold renewed his Quixotic call for Congress to censure President Bush. Yet again, the rally cry was greeted by a resounding thud. Ed Morrissey at Captain's Quarters feels that even as symbolism, censure is pointless. "It would carry no weight nor force any change in policy," writes Morrissey. "It amounts to little more than a temper tantrum and is at least arguably inappropriate in terms of the Constitutional separation of powers. Congress uses censure to punish its own members, not members of other branches. It has only been used once against a president -- in 1834 against Andrew Jackson -- and the succeeding Congress vacated it."

We've written at length about how faltering debt markets could damp the buyout boom of recent years. Now come signs that the disappearance of easy credit may be felt in another kind of corporate transaction: stock buybacks.

American Standard said Monday that it would sell its bath and kitchen products business to Bain Capital for $1.76 billion in cash, separating itself from one of the biggest makers of faucets and sinks.

A fresh report that Tellabs may be the target of a takeover offer has rekindled speculation about deal-making in the telecommunications industry. Shares of Tellabs, which makes telecom equipment, jumped nearly 7 percent to a 52-week high Monday after TheStreet.com wrote that a joint venture between Nokia and Siemens might offer $7 billion for Tellabs.

Offsetting carbon emissions has been all the rage these past months. If you're an individual with a guilty conscience or if your company needs to burnish its environmentally friendly image, it's easy to purchase a credit or offset.

Prominent Russian writer and Nobel Prize winner Alexander Solzhenitsyn on Russia’s turbulent history, Putin’s version of democracy and his attitude to life and death. SPIEGEL: Alexander Isayevich, when we came in we found you at work. It seems that even at the age of 88 you still feel this need to work, even though your health doesn’t allow you to walk around your home. What do you derive your strength from? Solzhenitsyn: I have always had that inner drive, since my birth. And I have always devoted myself gladly to work -- to work and to the struggle.

Once the Yankees acquired Jose Molina from the Angels on Saturday, my first thought was how they had dramatically improved themselves at the backup catcher position. Wil Nieves is a nice guy with some defensive abilities, but Molina is a nice guy who is also a much more talented reserve catcher.
Pete Wells, the editor of the Dining In/Dining Out section, is answering questions July 23-27.
Flooding disrupted life in parts of England, Texas and Asia.
It has been a busy month for Marc Andreessen, the Silicon Valley entrepreneur who helped create Netscape in the 1990s.
A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

Here's a photograph (right) that makes me smile. It comes from a book that makes me smile, too - John T. Edge's revised and expanded edition of "Southern Belly: The Ultimate Food Lover's Companion to the South."
The leveraged loan market seems to be in danger of seizing up -- largely because the investors who buy the paper issued by Collateralized Debt Obligations -- are suddenly unwilling to do so.

As foreign governments continue to take over companies in key industries, the European Union has agreed to let its members institute so-called golden shares to prevent further buyouts. Peter Mandelson, the body's trade commissioner, said over the weekend that the maneuver would not necessarily be protectionist if it protected key domestic industries.
I wrote a an article about what the US was doing wrong on broadband, "Digital Robber Barons?", back in 2002.

Teleflex, which makes a wide range of products for industrial use, said Monday it would buy Arrow International, a medical device manufacturer, for $2 billion. The deal would make medical technology into Teleflex's largest source of revenue and profits, Teleflex said in a press release.

The Democratic presidential candidates and their aides have likely been spending a lot of time lately combing through videos on YouTube's Web site in preparation for tonight's first-ever CNN/YouTube presidential debate in Charleston, S.C. The candidates will have to respond to several dozen of the 2,989 homemade question videos that users submitted.

The author and Tufts associate professor Daniel W. Drezner is less than pleased with a new Financial Times/Harris poll that found that most residents of wealthy countries, "regardless of how liberal their economic traditions" do not feel that "opening economies to freer trade is beneficial to poor and rich countries alike." Much of this animosity, the poll found, stems from the belief that globalization is directly related to rising income inequality.

Facebook has been rumored to be for sale for a long time, yet no deal has been signed. Why? According to one of the social networking site's backers, it's because potential suitors are lowballing offers.

Transocean, the world's largest offshore driller, has agreed to buy a smaller rival, GlobalSantaFe. Though the transaction was described in Monday's announcement as a "merger of equals," the combined company will be known as Transocean and use that company's ticker symbol, RIG. Transocean's chief executive, Robert Long, will continue in that role after the deal.
After two years of rapid-fire deal making, private equity firms are finding it harder to get the job done.

Hedge fund managers are not short on chutzpah, as a rule. But it takes a special kind of cheek to ask investors at this very tender moment in the housing market for $750 million to fund a new company specializing in subprime residential mortgage loans.

Under Jeffrey Immelt, General Electric has changed its tune on several things, like cleaning up a massive pollution site along the Hudson River. But is the massive conglomerate -- which makes jet engines, loans and the TV show "Heroes" -- ready to break itself up in order to save, well, itself?

The jittery credit markets made investors sweat this week as the country's biggest banks reported second-quarter earnings. But Wall Street's message was served up like a cold glass of lemonade: Relax, we'll work through this even as we put away more money to cover future loan losses.

United Rentals, the nation's biggest construction-equipment rental company, said it had agreed to be bought by Cerberus Capital Management for $6.6 billion, including debt. Cerberus will pay $34.50 in cash for each share of United Rentals, the company said.

In an effort to open up the field for trading shares in private placements, Merrill Lynch, Lehman Brothers, Morgan Stanley and Citigroup are developing their own electronic trading platform, The Financial Times reported.
With the clock ticking toward the August congressional recess, lawmakers will be scrambling over this week and next to try to chalk up some legislative accomplishments before departing for a month.

Even as "Transformers" has proven one of the breakout hits of the summer, could Paramount Pictures still lose the studio that made it and other blockbusters? Tensions between the Viacom-owned studio and DreamWorks, the star-studded boutique it bought almost two years ago for $1.53 billion, have been anything but secret.

The jockeying for Italy's Berenice Fondo Uffici continued Monday with Merrill Lynch again raising its bid for the company, which owns about 50 office buildings from Milan to Palermo. Merrill's improved offer is 774 euros ($1,070) a share compared with its previous bid of 770 euros, which was trumped by a Goldman Sachs offer of 771 euros on July 18.

WuXi PharmaTech is planning to make public a proposed $200 million share offering in the United States this week. Bloomberg News said that Credit Suisse and J.P. Morgan Chase are arranging the share sale by China's largest drug-research contractor, citing individuals it did not identify.

TomTom has agreed to buy a digital-mapping company Tele Atlas for about 2 billion euros ($2.77 billion) in cash. The acquisition will allow TomTom, the world's largest maker of navigation devices for cars, to deliver real-time updates on routes to its more than 10 million products, the companies said.
Hypo Real Estate Holding will acquire Depfa Bank for 5.7 billion euros ($7.9 billion) to form the biggest real estate financing company in Germany.
Mol, Hungary's biggest refiner, has denied a report in a Polish newspaper that the company is considering a merger with Poland's PKN Orlen to avoid a takeover by Austria's OMV.

The Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan sold about 11 percent of its stake in a Canadian oil and natural-gas producer, Nexen, to rebalance its portfolio. The sale raised 219.4 million Canadian dollars ($210 million), Bloomberg News reported.

With the Blackstone Group's shares taking a beating on Wall Street, investors are feeling anger at the chief executive, Stephen A. Schwarzman, and are hoping he will do something to raise the flagging stock, The New York Post reported over the weekend.

Barclays is considering its options for recovering $400 million it invested in the a now worthless Bear Stearns hedge fund. Those options are either a negotiated settlement or litigation, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Nearly six decades after George Orwell wrote "Nineteen Eighty-Four," the question of rewriting history, or at least history textbooks, regularly finds its way into the headlines.

After backing out of a bid for its rival, the EMI Group, last week, the Warner Music Group may now be circling the music publishing arm of Britain's Chrysalis. Reuters cited reports in The Observer and in The Financial Mail that said the division might be worth 90 million to 100 million pounds ($185 million to $206 million) but that it could fetch as much as 180 million pounds.
Should Delta Two, an investment firm based in Qatar, be successful in its 10.4 billion pound ($21.4 billion) takeover bid for Britain's J Sainsbury, it already has a new chairman lined up.
The Carlyle Group has hired Peter Nachtwey as its chief financial officer and managing director in what The Financial Times called a first step toward an initial public offering.

A study by Morgan Stanley has warned that current jitters on the global credit markets may spread to equity markets, The Telegraph reported Monday. The study said stock market corrections occur six months after the cost of debt rises, suggesting is that the current rally in equities on Wall Street and in Europe could be more fragile than it looks.

Amp'd Mobile, a venture capital-backed cellphone service provider hurt by rapid growth and a deadbeat youth market, could close its doors as early as Monday after a bankruptcy court hearing on its inability to pay its network lease.

Resolution and Friends Provident, two British insurance companies, were in discussions on Sunday to combine and create a company with a market value of about 8.3 billion pounds ($17.1 billion), The New York Times said citing a person with knowledge of the talks.

Pret A Manger, a British sandwich chain, may drop plans for an initial public offering now that several private equity firms have expressed interest in a deal, Reuters said, citing a report in the Financial Mail.

The No. 3 executive at the clothing giant Jones Apparel Group, who has overseen its biggest brands like Jones New York, Anne Klein New York and Nine West, has stepped down, The New York Times said citing people with knowledge of the matter.

As it assembles at the Boston Hilton on Monday to consider selling Dow Jones & Company and its main prize, The Wall Street Journal, to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, the controlling Bancroft clan faces some stark choices.

Barclays has raised its bid for ABN Amro to 67.5 billion euros ($93 billion) and included some cash. The new offer was helped along by investments in Barclays of up to 13.4 billion euros from the China Development Bank and a Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings.
Voters in Turkey went to the polls on Sunday in a pivotal election seen by many as a referendum on the secular Turkish state.

Dubai Aerospace Enterprise has its sights set on Auckland International Airport. In a takeover bid made Monday, Dubai Aerospace is seeking to acquire a 51 percent to 60 percent stake in New Zealand's busiest airport.
The Southern Utes have become an energy powerhouse and a model for other resource-based American Indian tribes. But not everyone is pleased about their ascendancy.
Pythons that have been kept as pets and released are an ecological nightmare in Everglades National Park.
There is nothing like a little regulatory scrutiny to get Internet companies talking about privacy, even if some of their words ring somewhat hollow.

Nationally, spending on veterinary care is expected to reach $9.8 billion in 2007, up from $7.2 billion five years ago, according to the American Pet Products Manufacturers Association. A survey released by the group last month found that 47 percent of dog owners say their pet sleeps in a family member's bed.
Mohammad Zahir Shah, Afghanistan’s former king, died on Monday at 92. He ruled Afghanistan from 1933 until he was deposed by his cousin and exiled in 1973.
A few days before closing forever, a West Village piano bar and cabaret was filled with longtime patrons and music lovers belting out old favorites.

The unseeded Czech Radek Stepanek upset the tournament favorite James Blake, 7-6 (7), 5-7, 6-2, to clinch his second ATP title at the Los Angeles Classic yesterday. Stepanek broke the second-seeded Blake twice in the final set to seal victory in 2 hours 20 minutes at the Los Angeles Tennis Center. Stepanek took a medical timeout late in the match to have treatment on his left hamstring.
Facing an unusual series of video-recorded questions, the eight Democratic presidential candidates sparred over race, gay marriage, Darfur and troops in Iraq.
Pythons that have been kept as pets and released are an ecological nightmare in Everglades National Park.
Of all the factors blocking the economic revival of New Orleans, the shattered health care system may be the most important.
Hoping to win approval for their merger, the satellite radio companies announced plans to let consumers choose the programs in their subscription package.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer suspended one top aide and reassigned another after the attorney general accused his staff of using the New York State Police for political purposes.
The bombs exploded within 15 minutes of each other in the relatively calm district of Karrada.
The Taliban had threatened to kill 23 South Korean hostages unless an equal number of Taliban fighters were released.
Floods caused misery, cut essential services and forced evacuations in widely spaced parts of the globe today.
The announcement follows Ms. Brown’s disclosure on “Weekend Today” on Saturday that she was leaving and pregnant.
The killings of hundreds of political activists that have blotted the record of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo’s administration.
Mohammad Zahir Shah returned to Kabul from exile in 2002. He had been deposed in 1973 after a 40-year reign.
There are many questions about what the former British prime minister can achieve as special envoy.

A 10-year-old boy was shot in the arm last night on the Lower East Side, the police said. The shooting, outside the Samuel Gompers Houses on Pitt Street, took place about 10 p.m. No arrests had been made, and the the circumstances were under investigation. The boy, taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, was listed in stable condition.

Rafael Nadal dropped serve three times and had to sweep five straight games to win the Mercedes Cup with a 6-4, 7-5 victory over Stanislas Wawrinka yesterday in Stuttgart, Germany.The top-seeded Nadal had not dropped serve in the tournament, but had to rally from 5-2 down in the second set to claim his sixth title this year and his 93rd victory in 94 matches on clay.Nadal is 23-5 in career finals, the highest winning percentage in the Open era.

The unseeded Czech Radek Stepanek upset the tournament favorite, James Blake, 7-6 (7), 5-7, 6-2, to clinch his second ATP title at the Los Angeles Classic yesterday. Stepanek broke the second-seeded Blake twice in the final set to seal victory in 2 hours 20 minutes at the Los Angeles Tennis Center. Stepanek took a medical timeout late in the match to have treatment on his left hamstring.

Mauro Zárate scored the winning goal in the 86th minute yesterday as Argentina triumphed in the FIFA Under-20 World Cup for the sixth time, rallying to beat the Czech Republic, 2-1, in Toronto.The game appeared to be heading for extra time until Zárate cut in from the left and beat goalkeeper Radek Petr at the near post with a fierce shot from the edge of the penalty area.

Scott Dixon escaped a first-lap accident and hung near the leaders before taking over to win the inaugural Honda Indy 200 yesterday in Lexington, Ohio, for his third consecutive victory.Dixon, sixth in qualifying, took the lead for good on Lap 77 of the 85-lap race when Dario Franchitti took a delayed pit stop. Dixon was never threatened to the finish, earning his ninth IndyCar Series win. After wins at Watkins Glen and Nashville the past two weekends, he tied the series mark for consecutive victories set by Kenny Brack (1998) and tied by Dan Wheldon (2005).

Sébastien Bourdais won for the first time in four races and regained control of the Champ Car title chase, running away with the Grand Prix of Edmonton. The 28-year-old Bourdais, seeking an unprecedented fourth straight series title, heads for next week’s race in San Jose, Calif., 20 points ahead of Robert Doornbos.

The top seed, Anna Chakvetadze of Russia, won her third WTA Tour title of the year as she breezed past Akiko Morigami of Japan, 6-1, 6-3, in the Cincinnati Open final yesterday.The 20-year-old Chakvetadze claimed the first set in 26 minutes, then overcame an 0-2 start to win the second.

The world championship leader, Casey Stoner of Australia, led from start to finish and claimed his sixth MotoGP win this season yesterday at the United States Grand Prix at Laguna Seca Raceway in Monterey, Calif.Stoner, 21, who was the pole-sitter and won all three practice sessions on the 11th stop on the 18-race circuit, was never challenged and came home well in front on his Ducati in 44 minutes 20.325 seconds.

The Belmont Stakes winner Rags to Riches missed another scheduled workout yesterday, this time because she did not “feel quite right” on the track at Belmont Park, her exercise rider, Lauren Robson, said. The trainer Todd Pletcher said that Rags to Riches, his star 3-year-old filly, was examined and that “she was fine.” The scheduled five-furlong breeze was cut short by Robson. Rags to Riches missed a workout last week with an elevated temperature. She was then pulled out of consideration for Saturday’s $300,000 Coaching Club American Oaks, which was won by her stablemate Octave.

A woman was stabbed multiple times with a box cutter inside a church yesterday morning, the police said. The stabbing occurred at Trinity Baptist Church at 218 Passaic Street shortly before 11:30 a.m. Theresa Whitfield, 38, was cut in the face, neck and body, the police said. Another woman, Yolanda Cooper, 40, was arrested. Charges against her included aggravated assault and possession of a weapon, the police said. The motive was under investigation. Ms. Whitfield was in fair condition last night at Hackensack University Medical Center. The pastor of the church is the Rev. Jonathan Whitfield. The police would not comment about the victim’s relationship to Mr. Whitfield or Ms. Cooper.

A music review on Thursday about Os Mutantes, at the Lincoln Center Festival, misstated the day of the concert. It was Tuesday, not Wednesday. The review also misidentified the guitar soloist on the Beatles’ recording of “While My Guitar Gently Weeps” in a comparison of the solos of Sérgio Dias Baptista of Os Mutantes to the solo on that recording. It was Eric Clapton, not George Harrison.

An article on Sunday about the challenges facing John Edwards’s presidential campaign in Iowa misstated the position taken by Tom Vilsack, the former governor of Iowa, during the 2004 Democratic caucuses there. Mr. Vilsack was neutral; he did not support Mr. Edwards. (Mr. Vilsack’s wife, Christie, endorsed John Kerry.) The article also gave the incorrect surname in some copies for a professor at Drake University who said the Edwards campaign cannot survive a second- or third-place finish in Iowa in 2008. He is Dennis J. Goldford, not Goldfarb.

An article on July 12 about bombings of natural gas pipelines in Mexico misstated the name of the state that is home to Salamanca, one of the cities supplied by the pipelines. It is Guanajuato; there is no “Guatemala State.” The article also misstated the year for the founding of the Popular Revolutionary Army, the rebel group that claimed responsibility for the bombings. It was formed in 1994, not 1996.
An operation in New Haven that resulted in dozens of arrests was not a raid, according to the secretary of homeland security.
Con Edison must present a plan for removing asbestos from a crater caused by last week’s steam pipe explosion before underground repairs can proceed.
Copeland’s, which has served soul food in Harlem for five decades, has fallen victim to gentrification.

Mauro Zárate scored the winning goal in the 86th minute yesterday as Argentina triumphed in the FIFA Under-20 World Cup for the sixth time, rallying to beat the Czech Republic, 2-1, in Toronto.The game appeared to be heading for extra time until Zárate cut in from the left and beat goalkeeper Radek Petr at the near post with a fierce shot from the edge of the penalty area.

The world championship leader Casey Stoner of Australia led from start to finish and claimed his sixth MotoGP win this season yesterday at the United States Grand Prix at Laguna Seca Raceway in Monterey, Calif.Stoner, 21, who was the pole-sitter and won all three practice sessions on the 11th stop on the 18-race circuit, was never challenged and came home well in front on his Ducati in 44 minutes 20.325 seconds.

Bernard Hopkins told everyone who would listen that he had a foolproof plan for getting inside Winky Wright’s vaunted defense.On Saturday night, the 42-year-old Hopkins ended Wright’s seven-and-a-half-year, 13-bout unbeaten streak with a unanimous decision in their 170-pound matchup at the Mandalay Bay Events Center in Las Vegas.Hopkins (48-4-1,32 knockouts) landed his biggest blow when he opened a gash over Wright’s left eye with a head butt in the third round. Hopkins spent the night picking at it while Wright (51-4-1) scrambled and counterpunched, his face showing frustration and fatigue as the fight slipped away.Hopkins abandoned retirement for a shot at the 35-year-old Wright, who had not lost since December 1999.

Rafael Nadal dropped serve three times and had to sweep five straight games to win the Mercedes Cup with a 6-4, 7-5 victory over Stanislas Wawrinka yesterday in Stuttgart, Germany.The top-seeded Nadal had not dropped serve in the tournament, but had to rally from 5-2 down in the second set to claim his sixth title this year and his 93rd victory in 94 matches on clay.Nadal is 23-5 in career finals, the highest winning percentage in the Open era.
tennis.

Sébastien Bourdais won for the first time in four races and regained control of the Champ Car title chase, running away with the Grand Prix of Edmonton. The 28-year-old Bourdais, seeking an unprecedented fourth straight series title, heads for next week’s race in San Jose, Calif., 20 points ahead of Robert Doornbos.

Fernando Alonso, the two-time defending Formula One champion, outdueled Felipe Massa on a slippery track yesterday, passing him late in the race to win the European Grand Prix at the Nürburgring in Germany. Alonso moved 2 points behind the leader, Lewis Hamilton, in the standings. Hamilton, a rookie, was ninth, finishing out of the top three for the first time in 10 races.

The American Joe Ogilvie won the $4 million U.S. Bank Championship yesterday after shooting a three-under-par 67 in the final round to finish at 14-under 266.It was Ogilvie’s first PGA Tour victory and his 230th event.Ogilvie was tied for the lead at 11 under with Tim Clark through 15 holes in the final round. But a long-distance eagle on the par-4 No. 16 and a birdie on No. 18 allowed him to secure the win at the Brown Deer Park Golf Course in Milwaukee.Ogilvie finished with four birdies and overcame three bogeys en route to capturing the $720,000 first-place purse.

Scott Dixon escaped a first-lap accident and hung near the leaders before taking over to win the inaugural Honda Indy 200 yesterday in Lexington, Ohio, for his third consecutive victory.Dixon, sixth in qualifying, took the lead for good on Lap 77 of the 85-lap race when Dario Franchitti took a delayed pit stop. Dixon was never threatened to the finish, earning his ninth IndyCar Series win. After wins at Watkins Glen and Nashville the past two weekends, he tied the series mark for consecutive victories set by Kenny Brack (1998) and tied by Dan Wheldon (2005).

The top seed Anna Chakvetadze of Russia won her third WTA Tour title of the year as she breezed past Akiko Morigami of Japan, 6-1, 6-3, in the Cincinnati Open final yesterday.The 20-year-old Chakvetadze claimed the first set in 26 minutes, then overcame an 0-2 start to win the second.
House Democrats have drafted a plan that calls for major changes in Medicare and promises to intensify the battle with the White House over health care.
Stephen E. Abraham, a decorated reserve Army intelligence officer, may have played a key role in the Supreme Court’s reversal of its stance on Guantánamo Bay prisoners.

Two men were shot, one fatally, in Brownsville yesterday morning, the police said. The shooting occurred in front of 420 Watkins Street shortly after 5 a.m., the police said. A man approached two other men and opened fire, striking one in the head and the other in the torso. The first victim, age 24, was pronounced dead at the scene, and the second, age 32, was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was in stable condition yesterday, the police said. The victims’ names were not released, and the investigation is continuing, the police said.

Five people sustained minor injuries yesterday when an amusement park ride malfunctioned in Ocean City, the police said. The people, who were taken to Shore Memorial Hospital, were riding the Canyon Falls Log Flume at Gillian’s Wonderland Pier on the Boardwalk, the police said. The ride will remain closed during an investigation by the State Department of Community Affairs. Telephone calls to the amusement park were not returned yesterday.

A 24-year-old man was shot to death yesterday morning in Fort Greene in what the police described as a traffic dispute. The shooting occurred shortly before 4 a.m. in front of 330 Hudson Walk, within the Ingersoll Houses, the police said. The man, Edwin Roman, was with a friend when another car cut him off, said Mr. Roman’s mother, Iris Rullan. An argument ensued, and the driver grabbed a chain Mr. Roman was wearing and drove off, Ms. Rullan said. “My son followed him,” she said. “They both got out of the cars, and they argued, and he shot him.” The gunman fled, and there were no arrests. A police spokeswoman said she could not corroborate Ms. Rullan’s account.

A small plane crashed in the backyard of a northern New Jersey home yesterday morning, the state police reported. Two people were in the plane when it crashed about 9:30 a.m., but neither was injured, said Sgt. Stephen Jones of the state police. Alison Duquette, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration, said the plane was a Cessna 172 that had taken off from an airport in Caldwell.

A man who grabbed onto his friend’s car to stop her from driving was killed after he fell off the car and was run over, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The man, Louis Wiederer, 26, was holding onto Jesenia Vega’s car around 9 p.m. on Saturday as she drove off, the police said. Mr. Wiederer lost his grip on the car and fell under it. The car stopped nearby, the police said, but Mr. Wiederer, of Westbury, was dead. Ms. Vega, 27, was arrested at the scene and was charged with driving while intoxicated. She was arraigned yesterday and pleaded not guilty.

An 8-year-old girl was shot in the shoulder as she sat on her porch yesterday morning with her family, the Newark police said. The girl, whom officials did not name, was sitting on the porch when a white car drove up and someone began shooting. The girl was taken to Newark Beth Israel Medical Center; her injuries were not considered life-threatening. The police did not believe the gunman was aiming at the girl.

An article on Sunday about the challenges facing John Edwards's presidential campaign in Iowa misstated the position taken by Tom Vilsack, the former governor of Iowa, during the 2004 Democratic caucuses there. Mr. Vilsack was neutral; he did not support Mr. Edwards. (Mr. Vilsack's wife, Christie, endorsed John Kerry.) The article also gave the incorrect surname in some copies for a professor at Drake University who said the Edwards campaign cannot survive a second- or third-place finish in Iowa in 2008. He is Dennis J. Goldford, not Goldfarb.
