PACHUCKI--Philip J., of Syosset, NY, passed away on July 20, 2007 after a year-long illness. Philip was a loving husband to his wife of 38 years, Eleanor, and a beloved father of a daughter, Lauren of Nashville, TN. He will be sorely missed but his memory is a blessing to all who knew and loved him. Philip was a noted figure in the world of New York construction management. He retired as a vicepresident from AMEC (formerly Morse Diesel). His projects included a major renovation of the New York Stock Exchange, a seven year long undertaking in which he managed all aspects of the job ranging from architecture to mechanics. Other renowned projects included the Pan Am Building, the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum, Stern School of Business at NYU, Baruch College, Booth Memorial Hospital, New York Presbyterian Hospital, St. Vincent's Hospital, and the Jewish Community Services Center, among many others. The family will receive their friends at Beney Funeral Home, 79 Berry Hill Road, Syosset, NY on Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9. A funeral mass will be held at St. Edward Confessor Church, 205 Jackson Avenue, Syosset, NY on Wednesday at 9:45. The family wishes to extend a special thanks to Dr. Zoe Goldberg and the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for their compassionate care. Donations may be made in his memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center or to the Lustgarten Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research.

Take 390,500 oil barrels, pile them horizontally 500 feet high in the desert of the United Arab Emirates, and what have you got? Another project of the artist Christo and his wife, Jeanne-Claude, Agence France-Presse reported. ''The Emirates is very keen to see this project realized,'' Christo said in St.-Paul de Vence, France, at a presentation of models and drawings for the monument. The idea for the pyramid, with a flat summit, dates to the 1960s, the artists said, but two earlier attempts to erect it, in Texas and the Netherlands, went nowhere. Unlike previous ephemeral projects, like the wrapping of the Reichstag in 1995 and the saffron ''Gates'' in Central Park in 2005, the so-called Mastaba project, in orange-yellow and about two-thirds the height of the Eiffel Tower, would not be dismantled. ''Arab states are less susceptible to provisional works and change,'' Christo said. And unlike previous projects, financed by the artists' selling of models and drawings, this one, if it comes to fruition, would be paid for by Abu Dhabi. Meanwhile Christo and Jean-Claude are planning to conclude nine years of planning by covering about six miles of the Arkansas River in Colorado with clear fabric in the installation ''Over the River'' for two weeks in July and August 2011.Citing health concerns, the conductor James Levine, below, music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, has withdrawn from his appearances this summer at the Verbier Festival in Switzerland, where he was to have led the opening concert Friday and the Mozart Requiem yesterday, PlaybillArts.com reported. ''My doctors have strongly advised me not to travel but to stay calm and collect my energies,'' he said in a statement released by the festival. Bernadette Horgan, a spokeswoman for the Boston Symphony Orchestra, said Mr. Levine remains at Tanglewood, working with students and planning to conduct all his scheduled concerts there before taking the ensemble on a European tour from Aug. 26 through Sept. 7.

To the Editor: ''When 3 Really Is a Crowd,'' by Elizabeth Marquardt (Op-Ed, July 16), raises alarms about the well-being of children who have more than two parents, while the think tank for which she works, the Institute for American Values, also warns of the dangers of single-parent households.

An article on July 12 about bombings of natural gas pipelines in Mexico misstated the name of the state that is home to Salamanca, one of the cities supplied by the pipelines. It is Guanajuato; there is no ''Guatemala State.'' The article also misstated the year for the founding of the Popular Revolutionary Army, the rebel group that claimed responsibility for the bombings. It was formed in 1994, not 1996. The article also misidentified the group that kidnapped the businessman Alfredo Harp Helú, one of at least three executives kidnapped in an effort to raise money for rebel causes. It was carried out by the Revolutionary Workers Party-People's Union -- not by the Popular Revolutionary Army, which later merged with the union.

The choreographer Mark Morris received the 2007 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award in ceremonies Saturday at the Page Auditorium at Duke University in Durham, N.C. The $35,000 award was created in 1981 to honor modern dance choreographers who have made an indelible contribution to the art form. The citation, in part, praised Mr. Morris as an artist ''whose imagination transforms a traditional musical score into a gold mine of new possibilities, whose incorrigible wit gives his dances such original humor, and whose vision and profound belief in the power of dance is apparent in his many accomplishments.'' Mr. Morris, 50, who formed the Mark Morris Dance Group in 1980, received the prize from Mike Ross, director of the Krannert Center for the Performing Arts at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

The Rolling Stones earned $5.4 million when they gave a private concert last week for 500 guests in Barcelona, Spain, Agence France-Presse reported. Citing the British music magazine NME, the news agency said that the party at the Catalan National Art Museum had been organized by Deutsche Bank. Mick Jagger told the audience: ''Thank you for having us. The best part is it's coming out of your bonuses.'' The Stones are currently touring Europe.

A music review on Thursday about Os Mutantes, at the Lincoln Center Festival, misstated the day of the concert. It was Tuesday, not Wednesday. The review also misidentified the guitar soloist on the Beatles' recording of ''While My Guitar Gently Weeps'' in a comparison of the solos of Sérgio Dias Baptista of Os Mutantes to the solo on that recording. It was Eric Clapton, not George Harrison.

Barry Bonds plopped down on a green couch in the clubhouse, put his San Francisco Giants teammate Matt Morris in a headlock and playfully kissed him twice. Those were Bonds's most strenuous actions Sunday. He and his chase for home run supremacy took the day off. A few minutes after Bonds joked with Morris, he had the entire couch to himself. Bonds stretched out and watched the British Open or snoozed. He did not join the Giants for stretching exercises or batting practice.

ROSENBAUM--Irving. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Howard A. Stecker, Senior Rabbi Hon. Richard Kestenbaum, President ROSENBAUM--Irving M., of Great Neck, and Sparta, NJ. Former Chairman of S.E. Nichols, Inc. on July 21 at age 86. Born in Dresden, Germany, he served his adopted country and the cause of freedom during WWII in the 3rd Infantry Division and the US 7th Army (European Theater). His searing experiences in Europe before and during the war inspired a lifetime of service to humanity and especially to the Jewish people. He was the beloved husband of the late Hanni (nee Schein); loving father of Eli, Daniel, and Michael; adoring grandfather of Karina and Alissa; cherished brother of the late Dr. Salo Rosenbaum; and the beloved companion of Ruth Hockley. Services today, 12 Noon, at the ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opposide the LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations are encouraged to the American Friends of the Open University of Israel.

Tammy Faye Bakker, the diminutive and elaborately coiffed gospel singer who, with her first husband, Jim Bakker, built a commercial empire around television evangelism only to see it collapse in sex and money scandals, died Friday at her home near Kansas City, Mo. She was 65. Her death was reported on her Web site and by her booking agent, Joe Spotts, The Associated Press said. She had been suffering from colon cancer, which had spread to her lungs.

BANCROFT FAMILY GATHERING As it assembles at the Boston Hilton to consider selling Dow Jones & Company and its main prize, The Wall Street Journal, to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, the controlling Bancroft clan faces some stark math. But money will not be the only issue on the table as family members consider their century-old legacy. While the bulk of speculation, anticipation and hand-wringing over Rupert Murdoch's potential purchase of Dow Jones has focused on The Wall Street Journal, a smaller media property has quietly chugged along, successful and unprotected. Despite all the hoopla surrounding the YouTube debate on CNN last night, the debate did not draw as big an audience as the debate on CNN in New Hampshire in June.
Against a backdrop of mortar fire, families in Baghdad play at Abu Niwas Gardens, finding a dangerous solution to coping in the 120-degree heat.

For a campaign that claims not to be a campaign, there was a lot of political maneuvering among Fred Thompson's staff today, perhaps signaling an impending shift in the former senator's strategy to work toward the Republican nomination for the presidency.

At some Italian restaurants they're called cichetti. At a new Italian restaurant near Madison Square Park they called stuzzichini. And at an even newer Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village they're being called piccolini.

GEORGETOWN, S.C. - Former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina continued one of the lines of attack he made at Monday night's debate today, challenging his Democratic opponents to support an increase in the minimum wage to $9.50 an hour.

So, other than YouTube, who won the debate last night? Scanning the blogosphere, it seems that if not everyone found something to like about everyone, at least someone found something to like about each one. "Hillary Rodham Clinton's dominating CNN/YouTube debate performance tonight flipped the script on America. Or it should have," says Douglas Burns at Iowa Independent. "No longer should the question be: Can a woman be president? With her fourth in a series of crushing Democratic debate performances, the question everyone in America should be asking themselves: What have we been missing by eliminating more than half our population from the application process for this job since the late 18th century?"
Animal rights activists move from the margin to the mainstream. Kim Severson visits the Farm Sanctuary's bed and breakfast.
N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern compares the investigation of a former referee to a 2005 case of a German soccer referee.

A moment from last night's debate has burst into a full-blown dispute today between Senator Hillary Clinton and Senator Barack Obama, the two leading Democratic presidential candidates. It is their first public wrangling.

A further reminder of The Decline of Soda emerged today with a study hitting the top of most e-mailed lists drawing a link to heart disease. Dr. Ramachandran S. Vasan, the lead author, said no causal link was established, a point emphasized by one interest group. Rather, "consuming sweet sodas changes dietary patterns or that soda was simply a marker for participants' poor eating habits," said Mr. Vasan, according to The Los Angeles Times. And it didn't matter if the sweetness came from corn syrup or Aspartame.

Commissioner Bud Selig, who has been a close friend of Hank Aaron for nearly 50 years, said that he would make a decision about attending Barry Bonds's pursuit of Aaron's career home run at an "appropriate time."
Commissioner David Stern held a news conference to confront the scandal facing his league.
Readers respond to David Brooks's July 24 column, "A Reality-Based Economy."
In today's truck market, size sells. In fact, the bigger a pickup is, the better it seems to be selling.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s August debate among the Democratic candidates has generated so much interest that the labor federation has decided to hold the event at Soldier Field, rather than McCormick Place.
So, how's the new Harry Potter book selling?
Next week, the Frugal Traveler is driving to Wyoming, Montana and Idaho. He needs your help. Do you know a cheap motel, a great place to eat or a must-see attraction? Share your tips with Matt here.

Beazer Homes USA said Monday afternoon that a previously disclosed informal inquiry by federal regulators has been raised to a formal investigation into possible violations of federal securities laws. In a regulatory filing, Beazer said that last Friday it has received a formal order from the Securities and Exchange Commission to determine whether anyone or any entity related to Beazer has broken securities laws.

This summer, private equity reached a public-relations tipping point. In a relatively short time, it seemed that politicians, labor unions and part of the American public turned on the men and women -- mostly men -- who run buyout firms. Their supposed crimes? Greed. Too much wealth. Too many tax dodges.

UGO, a nine-year-old network of Web sites that made it through the Internet downturn without collapsing or being acquired, has found a buyer. It is Hearst, the privately held media conglomerate, which told Crain's New York Business that UGO will be the first major acquisition for its interactive-media unit.

The classic target for a buyout firm like the Blackstone Group has a beaten-down stock price, low levels of debt and a solid business. Daniel Gross, offering up an apparently tongue-in-cheek proposal on Slate.com, suggests that Blackstone itself would fit the bill.
After more than eight years in jail in Libya, six medical workers charged with infecting children with H.I.V. were pardoned by Bulgaria's president Tuesday.
O.K., presidential politics entered the YouTube era last night, and everybody has an opinion -- ­ not about the candidates, of course, but about the format.

Last weekend, I had to fly to California for a speaking engagement-right smack in the middle of a book deadline. I was panicked. All those hours sitting in traffic getting to and from the airports without Internet access-wasted. And what if I couldn't find wireless Internet service in the airport waiting lounges or the speaking venue? More hours wasted. No chapters would be turned in, no PDFs sent in for proofreading, and the book would not make its deadline.
Every once in a while, I kick myself that I wasn't an early subscriber to McSweeney's Quarterly Concern, the literary magazine Dave Eggers founded in 1998.

To watch Bear Grylls on his program "Man vs. Wild" is to be in a constant state of disbelief -- over how he is able to escape a tiger shark attack; eat the biggest maggot you've ever seen; build a complicated raft out of bamboo and leaves; and basically, well, survive in really dire situations, with a sense of humor and an uncanny knack for delivering live commentary as he performs his feats.

When Procter & Gamble bought Gillette for $57 billion, it picked up a lot more than just razors: The deal gave it Duracell batteries and Braun, whose products include coffeemakers and blenders. Less than two years later, Wall Street is wondering whether it may be time for P&G, a giant of the consumer products business, to tidy up a bit.
That old saying is not, to my knowledge, in any investor relations manual.

Ryerson, a steel services company that has been under pressure from shareholder activists to sell itself, agreed Tuesday to a buyout by Platinum Equity for about $1 billion. Platinum will pay $34.50 a share, below the company's closing stock price Monday of $34.96 but 15 percent higher than its price on Feb. 13, before it said it was considering a sale.
If you're going to criticize the performance of a news organization, you at a minimum need to get your facts right.

The Princeton Review, purveyor of test preparation materials and classes, said on Tuesday that it would receive a $60 million infusion from Bain Capital Ventures and Prides Capital. That investment will take the form of preferred stock, which can then be converted into common stock at $6 a share and will accrue a six percent dividend for the next four years.

The Carlyle Group isn't just the largest buyout firm in Washington. It is also a training ground for many private-equity professionals who go on to set up shop in the region, which, while not on a par with New York, has become a buyout hub in its own right.
Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below. - The Editors

The comparisons to River Phoenix and Judy Garland ring truer by the day. Lindsay Lohan, the 21-year-old actress, has been arrested again for driving under the influence and cocaine possession, TMZ.com first reported and others confirmed. In May, she was arrested for D.U.I. after she crashed her Mercedes on Sunset Boulevard, a charge that sent her to rehab. Sharon Waxman's words in The Times following that incident still seem to apply:
Word arrived the other day that an American publisher would, at long last, issue a book of Clive James's poetry in this country.
Japan’s Nikkei average fell to its lowest in six weeks on a tumble in U.S. Stocks and a stronger yen.

As many states continue to jockey for early dates in the presidential nomination process, most American voters would like to establish a single national primary day, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll.

It was a night of firsts. For two hours in Charleston, S.C., all eight Democratic presidential candidates fielded questions in their first "official" debate of the 2008 election. The event, hosted by CNN and YouTube, was also the first to blend the online video-sharing platform with presidential politics.

Behind the happy news in Sofia, Bulgaria, this morning of the freedom of five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor was a complicated, murky deal worked out among representatives of Libya, Bulgaria, France, the European Union and even Qatar. Here's the breakdown so far.

Yesterday we were told that Mohammad Zahir Shah, the last (so far as we know) king of Afghanistan, died in Kabul, and most obituaries paint him as a well-meaning if ineffectual old man. James S. Robbins at National Review Online sees him as something altogether different - a model, of the Platonic sort:

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has long been known as a sharp-elbowed player in private equity, one that fights to get its deals done. But its recent tactics may be causing blowback from Wall Street at a crucial moment for the buyout firm, Reuters reports.
Images from “Condensation,” five video works by Chen Chieh-Jen at the Asia Society.

Your vote is private, yet large campaign donations are anything but, especially if you are a bold-faced name in a world more glittering than that of politics. Based on Federal Election Commission filings, here is where some of the United States' rich and/or famous threw their support in the second quarter:
Transocean's proposed acquisition of GlobalSantaFe will create a giant in the offshore drilling industry -- and could spur more deals.
In the war to win ABN Amro, Barclays unveiled a new weapon on Monday: investments from two Asian governments and news that could make its stock leap. But will that be enough to secure victory?

AOL is planning to bulk up its ad offerings with a deal for Tacoda, an online ad firm that uses behavioral targeting to track Web users' habits, The New York Post reported. The deal, which could be announced as early as Tuesday, will see AOL pay between $200 million and $300 million.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel's cabinet has approved a plan to sell a 25 percent stake in Deutsche Bahn, the rail operator, Reuters reported Tuesday citing a government source.

In the latest debt deal to hit a snag, underwriters put off a sale of $3.1 billion in loans that would pay for the leveraged buyout of General Motors' Allison Transmission unit, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Images of the British sculptor's work.

The $2 billion deal by Teleflex, a maker of a wide range of industrial products, to buy Arrow International may face opposition from one of the medical device maker's largest shareholders, the Robert L. McNeil Jr. 1983 Trust.

The Italian government is feeling a little more inclusive following the collapse of the auction for Alitalia last week when the last bidders pulled out. Now, Italy is happy to sell Alitalia to anyone willing to turn the money-losing national airline around - no matter whether the new owners are "Eskimos or Chinese," an Italian government minister said Monday.

Hedge funds had their second-best fund-raising quarter, attracting $58.7 billion globally from investors, even as losses in subprime-mortgage loans forced managers including Bear Stearns to close funds.
Basis Capital Fund Management, an Australian hedge fund manager, has hired the Blackstone Group to help it limit losses after being hurt by the rout in the subprime mortgage market.

In a fresh sign of China's financial strength, a leap in the shares of the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China on Monday made it the world's biggest bank by market capitalization, overtaking Citigroup.
Twango, a media-sharing Web site founded by five former Microsoft employees, announced Monday that it had been acquired by the cell phone giant Nokia. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.
Shares of American Airlines parent AMR rose more than 7 percent on Monday amid persistent talk in the stock options market about a possible takeover of the company.

Venture capital financing grew 8 percent to $7.4 billion in the second quarter, with medical device companies taking the spotlight as the fastest growing sector, according to a report released Monday. Medical device start-ups walked away with $1 billion, a 58 percent increase over the year-ago period, the report issued by Ernst & Young and Dow Jones VentureOne said.
An NASD arbitration panel ordered Merrill Lynch to pay an Iranian former broker $1.6 million, saying a branch complex director at the firm set him up to be fired after learning of his ethnicity.
For his next act, Christopher Gardner, whose rags-to-riches tale inspired the film "The Pursuit of Happyness," is starting a private equity fund that will invest solely in South Africa.
Silicon Valley has a new deep-pocketed commercial real estate investor on the block.

Monday's announcement by Barclays that it had raised its offer for ABN Amro following a cash infusion from the China Development Bank and Temasek Holdings of Singapore was just the latest development in a takeover battle that has had more twists and turns than an Alpine pass.

Hoping to persuade skeptical regulators to approve their proposed merger, the nation's two satellite radio companies announced detailed plans Monday to give consumers the ability to choose the programs that make up their subscription package.
The success of four start-up carriers that offer all-business class flights has some of the major airlines considering competing services of their own, notes The New York Times.

The radio broadcaster Cumulus Media said Monday that it had agreed to a $1.3 billion buyout led by its chief executive and Merrill Lynch, reviving expectations of further deals in an industry struggling with weaker advertising.

Dan's Papers - a free weekly newspaper whose quirky coverage of the Hamptons is required reading for the rich, the famous and those who wish they were - has been sold to the Brown Publishing Company, a family-owned firm that boasts more than 80 newspapers, mainly in Ohio.
A look at a former church in Umbria that was turned into a vacation home.

The Hartford Financial Services Group paid $115 million to settle accusations that it allowed illegal trading in some mutual funds, the company and the Connecticut attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, announced on Monday.

In their last meeting before an expected vote on selling to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, the family that controls Dow Jones & Company, owner of The Wall Street Journal, heard arguments for and against the deal yesterday from family members and advisers.
Homes on the market in Ridgefield, Conn., Santa Fe, N.M., and Honolulu.
“Prison Town, USA,” a smartly constructed documentary tonight on the PBS series “P.O.V.,” explores the “after” debate in Susanville, a small city in Northern California.

It may be easier to buy that Swiss chalet of your dreams soon---but it's not going to get any cheaper. Or at least that's what some experts are predicting, now that Switzerland has decided to revoke Lex Koller, the controversial law restricting foreign ownership of Swiss property.
Fashion designers get the Wright perspective. Photographed at the newly restored Hollyhock House in Los Angeles.

Several studies have found that up to 40 percent of people have some degree of anxiety about flying. An anxiety or panic attack is often acutely physical, marked by sweating, numbness in the hands and feet, and a pounding heart, leading sufferers to think they are having a heart attack.

Some mixed emotions here at Kauffman Stadium tonight. The Yankees won, 9-2, their ninth victory in 11 games. But as he spoke about it after the game, Roger Clemens made clear he had other thoughts on his mind.
A federal appeals court struck down a Bush administration rule that loosened the work hours of truck drivers.
Instead of units’ holding individual services as casualties occurred in Iraq and Afghanistan, the base may decide to hold a collective service once a month.
Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender, issued a pessimistic outlook of the housing market, helping to ignite a sell-off in the stock market.
A plurality of Africans are optimistic about their future, according to a poll conducted in 10 sub-Saharan nations.
A new global opinion poll finds that people in developing countries are broadly more satisfied with their lives than five years ago.
The online retailer announced today that its second-quarter net income increased more than threefold, with revenue up 35 percent.
A day after CNN announced that it was hiring Campbell Brown to replace one of its prime-time hosts, Ms. Zahn confirmed that she was leaving the channel.
With the Severn, Thames, and other rivers already at full capacity, and more rain on the way, severe flood warnings remained in effect for many parts of the country.
The president argued today that an Al Qaeda-affiliated group in Iraq is linked tightly to the central Al Qaeda leadership.
Older people are discovering the joys (and risks) of franchising.
The authorities said the two men invaded a suburban home and killed the wife and two daughters of a prominent Connecticut endocrinologist.
His  innovative straight-talk approach to psychotherapy made him one of the most influential and provocative figures in modern psychology.
One of the most wanted Taliban militants in Pakistan killed himself when troops raided a hideout, government officials said.
N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern denied allegations that the league knew earlier of a referee’s betting activities.
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales denied today that he had pressured former Attorney General John Ashcroft to re-authorize domestic surveillance.
The telephone company solidly beat Wall Street’s forecasts as wireless data use soared, but its initial report on iPhone signups sent Apple’s shares down sharply.
Tony Blair made the comment during a maiden visit in his new role as the envoy of the Middle East Quartet.
Envoys from the two countries squared off over American allegations that Iran has increased the flow of aid to Iraqi militias.
After more than eight years in jail in Libya, six medical workers charged with infecting children with H.I.V. were pardoned.

Cécilia Sarkozy, the French first lady, is in Libya trying to persuade Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to free five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor convicted of having deliberately infected children with H.I.V.

A 40-year-old off-duty police officer and his 18-year-old companion were found shot to death in the officer’s Bronx apartment yesterday afternoon in what is being investigated as a possible murder-suicide, the police said. The woman’s body was found in the officer’s bed with gunshot wounds to the head and torso. The officer, Fred Maselli, was found shot in the head on the floor of the apartment, at 3611 Henry Hudson Parkway West. A gun was found near his body, the police said. Officer Maselli was a seven-year veteran of the force who worked at the 34th Precinct, the police said. Eddie Fishbaum, a neighbor, said that Officer Maselli was the father of two. The woman was identified by family members as Shirley Fontanez of Washington Heights, the mother of a 3-year-old girl. Ms. Fontanez’s mother, Maria Espinoza, 40, said that the couple had been dating for more than two years. Friends said Ms. Fontanez often complained that Mr. Maselli was threatening and abusive. “I was like, ‘Why are you still with this guy?’ ” said Monica Pinedu, a friend. She said that Ms. Fontanez responded, “Because he will kill me.”.
The Yankees gave Roger Clemens a 4-0 lead in the second inning and he protected it, allowing four hits and striking out three in seven strong innings.

Rags to Riches, the first filly in 102 years to win the Belmont Stakes, was examined by Dr. Steve Allday at Belmont Park yesterday, a day after being pulled up at the start of a scheduled five-furlong workout. The trainer Todd Pletcher reported that she seemed to be in good condition, but that a complete physical was needed to determine whether she would run next month in the Alabama Stakes at Saratoga.Rags to Riches will be sent to the University of Pennsylvania’s New Bolton Center in Kennett Square, Pa., for more tests.
The decision comes as a major blow to Wyeth, based in Madison, N.J., which hopes to market the drug as the first nonhormonal treatment for menopausal symptoms.

A German financier, Hypo Real Estate, agreed to buy Depfa Bank of Dublin in a cash and stock transaction that values the business at $7.9 billion, the companies said. Hypo Real Estate, which is based in Munich, said it would pay Depfa shareholders 6.80 euros ($9.38) a share in cash and 0.189 new share. That is the equivalent of 16.14 euros ($22.27) a share, a 17 percent premium over Depfa’s closing price on Friday. Depfa, which specializes in public-sector finance, will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Hypo but keep its name, headquarters and brand identity. Hypo Real Estate said the acquisition would create one of the world’s leading providers of financing for commercial real estate, the public sector and infrastructure projects.

TomTom, Europe’s largest maker of car navigation systems, said it would buy a digital mapping company, Tele Atlas, for about $2.8 billion to form a bulwark against larger competitors and help it map the best possible routes as users need them. TomTom said it would pay 21.25 euros ($29.33) a share for Tele Atlas, a 28 percent premium to the company’s closing price on Friday. The deal would combine Europe’s two smaller, high-growth rivals against the dominant players in the navigation device and mapping markets. TomTom, based in Amsterdam, relies on the data that Tele Atlas gathers to present the maps for its displays. Tele Atlas, based in Den Bosch, the Netherlands, has been increasing sales quickly but was unprofitable until recently, and relies on TomTom for about a third of its revenue.

The Indian drug maker Dr. Reddy’s Laboratories posted a 30.5 percent increase in first-quarter net profit on strong demand for cheaper generic drugs as countries look to cut health care costs. Although the result fell short of analysts’ forecasts, the chief executive, G. V. Prasad, said he expected broad-based growth ahead. “We remain confident about our performance. This year it will be all-round secular growth, traditional businesses are showing good potential. There could be mix of organic and inorganic growth,” Mr. Prasad said. Dr. Reddy’s said net profit for the April-June quarter rose to 1.8 billion rupees ($45.3 million) from 1.4 billion rupees a year earlier. Revenue fell to 12.02 billion rupees ($296 million) from 14.05 billion rupees a year ago.

Singapore’s inflation in June accelerated to the highest in a year as holiday travel became more expensive and car prices increased. The consumer price index rose 1.3 percent from a year earlier, after gaining 1 percent in May, the department of statistics said. Rising wages and expanding payrolls, amid Singapore’s longest economic expansion since 1991, have encouraged consumers to spend. Inflation pressures are likely to intensify after the government this month increased its tax on goods and services and the island’s biggest power company raised electricity rates for the third quarter.

Dubai’s government, using wealth generated by a three-year rally in crude oil, agreed to buy a controlling stake in the Auckland International Airport, New Zealand’s busiest, for as much as 2.6 billion New Zealand dollars ($2.1 billion). Auckland Airport directors recommended the offer, which was made by Dubai Aerospace Enterprises and was worth up to 3.80 New Zealand dollars a share. Under the takeover proposal, a new company will be formed to buy the Auckland Airport. Existing shareholders will be offered 2.34 New Zealand dollars in cash plus shares in the new company, each with an associated convertible loan note. The so-called stapled securities are valued at 1.39 New Zealand dollars each.

Frank Thomas homered twice to raise his total to 503 and pull to one behind Eddie Murray for 20th place as the Toronto Blue Jays sent Johan Santana to a rare second-half loss, beating the visiting Minnesota Twins, 6-4, last night.
Sobering expectations — foreshadowed on Sunday when management announced lower prices — weighed on the company’s already drooping stock.
In his first major league start since being found to have a treatable form of lymphoma last year, Jon Lester made a dramatic and effective return to the Boston Red Sox’ rotation.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about the search for victims of a Brazilian airliner crash in São Paulo misstated the circumstances of the crash. The airliner, TAM Flight 3054, skidded off a short slippery runway and hit an office building and gas station; it did not collide with another aircraft in midair. As the article noted, a Brazilian airliner collided in midair with an American corporate jet last September, killing 154.

An article on Friday about the six-nation talks aimed at disarming North Korea of its nuclear weapons misstated the name of the agency that serves as the United Nations nuclear monitor. It is the International Atomic Energy Agency, not Association.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about the private library collections of several business executives referred incorrectly to the Accreditation Council for Graduate Medical Education, whose chief executive, David Leach, commented on his collection of the works of Aristotle. The accreditation council is an independent, nonprofit organization; it is no longer a division of the American Medical Association. (The two separated in 2003.) The article also included a quotation from Shelly Lazarus, chairwoman and chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather, that misstated the title of a book in her collection. It is “How Doctors Think” by Dr. Jerome Groopman — not “How to Think Like a Doctor.”.
Corrections: For the Record

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Friday of Kenji Miyamoto, the longtime leader of postwar Japan’s Communist Party, rendered incorrectly the name of the American general in charge of the Allied occupation, who barred Mr. Miyamoto and 23 other party members from public service just before the outbreak of the Korean War. He was Gen. Douglas MacArthur; he had no middle name and did not use the initial A (or other initials often ascribed to him, including B, C and S). The error most recently appeared on June 29 in an obituary of Kiichi Miyazawa, Japan’s prime minister in the 1990’s. Five articles in 2005 included the “A” (on May 29, June 20, June 28, July 29 and Aug. 26), and the “A” has been used in 19 other articles since 1987.

An article on June 14 about the resignation of the senior instructional official in the New York City public schools misspelled the given name of a member of the New York State Board of Regents who said she was concerned about rapid turnover in this position. (The error was repeated in an article on July 18 about the release of data showing how the city schools would use an influx of state money.) The regent is Merryl H. Tisch, not Meryl.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about efforts by Wall Street banks to reassure investors that the financial industry is strong rendered incorrectly a word in a quotation from Kenneth D. Lewis, chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, who commented on consumer spending. He said, “As long as you have employment and wages growing, you are going to have a relatively healthy consumer.” He did not say “unemployment.”.
Yankees first base coach Tony Peña’s son, Tony Peña Jr., started at shortstop and batted ninth for the Kansas City Royals on Monday.

NEWARK, July 23 — At his arraignment in federal court Monday, former Mayor Sharpe James pleaded not guilty to corruption charges and then listened as one of his lawyers defended himself against allegations that it would be a conflict of interest if he remained part of Mr. James’s defense team.
Dan Rattiner, the founder, president, publisher and editor in chief of Dan’s Papers, will stay on indefinitely.
Police suspect that a man arrested for on Monday is the “mad hatter” who has robbed 18 New Jersey banks over the past year.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer suspended one top aide and reassigned another after the attorney general accused his staff of using the New York State Police for political purposes.
The Democratic presidential candidates often lapsed into their talking points, and there was little actual debate.

European Union nations agreed to start planning for a possible 3,000-member peacekeeping mission to Chad to help provide security for tens of thousands of refugees fleeing the conflict in neighboring Darfur, Sudan. European Union foreign ministers said such a mission would require United Nations support, cooperation with neighboring countries and “a clearly defined exit strategy.” The operation would be intended to complement the planned 26,000-member African Union-United Nations peacekeeping force. Of the 2.5 million people displaced by the four-year conflict, some 230,000 have fled into Chad, and more than 170,000 Chadians have also been displaced, the United Nations says.

The United Nations asked the Netherlands to be the host of a new international tribunal to try the suspected killers of the former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri, a United Nations spokeswoman said. The Dutch government, although responding positively, wants its concerns addressed first, a spokesman said. They include an understanding of the tribunal laws, its financing, security for witnesses and tribunal staff, and a commitment from another country where convicts would serve their sentences.

Lawyers for the former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega asked a Miami court to block his extradition to France, arguing that under the Geneva Conventions he was entitled to be repatriated to Panama.
About 10,000 people fled Mogadishu last week alone, and the exodus continues, the United Nations said.

A heat wave that has hit Romania in the past week has killed at least 18 people and caused hundreds to collapse in the street, authorities said. Temperatures are expected to hover above 100 in the south and east for the next two days, and reach 108 in some areas. Most of the deaths were caused by dehydration, Heath Minister Eugen Nicolaescu said.

Access to drugs to fight H.I.V. and AIDS in developing countries has improved recently, but new infections still vastly outpace treatment efforts, health officials said Monday. Three years ago, fewer than 300,000 people in the developing world were receiving antiretroviral drugs; last year, 2.2 million people did, Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the United States National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, said at an AIDS conference in Sydney. “However, for every one person that you put in therapy, six new people get infected,” he said.

Flash floods and landslides inundated villages, destroyed bridges and roads, and sent thousands fleeing their homes in central Indonesia, officials said. At least 39 people were killed, dozens are still missing and rescuers are only starting to reach isolated areas, said Brig. Gen. Badrodin Haiti, a Sulawesi Island police chief. Torrential rains have been falling for days and there are reports of six feet of water in some villages.

At least nine Tamil Tiger guerrillas and a civilian were killed in fresh violence in Sri Lanka, the military and the rebels said. Government forces shot dead four rebels in the Jaffna peninsula on Monday, the military said. The rebels said they lost five men in a battle with security forces elsewhere. And gunmen shot and killed a local employee of the Danish Refugee Council near the town of Jaffna, for which the military blamed the rebels.

The leader of Hezbollah, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, said his militia’s rockets could reach all of Israel, including Tel Aviv. Mr. Nasrallah has previously said that the group could have fired on Tel Aviv in its war with Israel last summer. In an interview with the satellite TV network Al Jazeera, he said the war did not diminish Hezbollah’s capacity. “We could absolutely reach any corner and any point in occupied Palestine,” he said, using Hezbollah’s term for Israel. An Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman, Mark Regev, called Hezbollah’s rearmament “a direct and grave violation” of the Security Council resolution that ended the war.

China’s intelligence services are gathering information on foreigners who might protest and spoil the nation’s moment in the spotlight during the 2008 Beijing Olympics. Spy agencies and research organizations compiling lists of potentially troublesome groups are looking beyond the usual suspects, human rights groups, at evangelical Christians demanding religious freedom, Darfur advocates wanting Beijing to use its oil-buying leverage with Sudan to end the strife there, and environmental campaigners angry about global warming, security experts and a consultant familiar with the effort said.
A man described by neighbors as a retired factory worker shot three people to death and wounded two others before killing himself, the authorities said.
Traffic deaths in the United States fell to their lowest total in five years in 2006, a federal safety official said.
The government warned consumers and retailers to take urgent action to rid their shelves of more than 90 products, including chili sauce, corned beef hash and dog food.
A Chinese couple regained legal custody of their 8-year-old daughter after a seven-year fight to win her back from what was supposed to be temporary foster care.
Scores of gay and lesbian couples lined up to register as domestic partners as a new state law took effect.
A spacewalking astronaut, Clayton C. Anderson, discarded a camera mounting and an ammonia tank weighing more than half a ton at the International Space Station.
A giant dust storm enveloping NASA’s Mars rover Opportunity appears to have eased slightly over the weekend, allowing the rover to recharge its batteries a little.
The minimum wage rises 70 cents to $5.85 an hour today, the first increase in a decade.

Paul Broun, a Republican who has never held public office, was certified as the winner of a special election to fill the seat in the House of Representatives vacated by Charlie Norwood, a Republican who died in February.
Over the next several days, the Bancroft family members will tell their lawyers where they stand on selling Dow Jones & Company, and the lawyers will tally the results.
Defense lawyers at the terrorism trial of Jose Padilla challenged the accuracy of some translations and interpretations used by prosecutors.
Steve Barr’s organization has founded 10 charter high schools and has won approval to open 10 more.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
The American command in Baghdad has prepared a detailed classified plan that calls for restoring security in local areas by the summer of 2008.
Multinational corporations are once again resorting to complex strategies to shelter profits in tax havens.
Of all the factors blocking the revival of New Orleans, the shattered health care system may be the most important.
In a poll, 42 percent of Americans said that taking military action in Iraq was the right thing to do.
American Express said yesterday that record spending had fueled a 12 percent jump in profit.
The ruling by a federal judge in Syracuse, however, did not answer whether firms must label newsletters and e-mail messages to clients as advertising.
As F.B.I. officials, the news media and fans pore over video footage of games refereed by Tim Donaghy, a game between the Bulls and the Warriors in February could attract attention.

Detroit signed forward Antonio McDyess to a two-year contract extension yesterday. McDyess, 32, overcame knee injuries to play in a career-high 82 games in each of the past two seasons with the Pistons. He has one season left on his current deal. He averaged 8.1 points, 6 rebounds and 21 minutes last season, making 53 percent of his shots.

Troy Polamalu, the Pittsburgh Steelers’ star safety, signed a four-year contract extension yesterday worth $30.19 million, making him the highest-paid player in team history and one of the N.F.L.’s top-paid defensive backs. The deal guarantees that the Steelers can keep him through the 2011 season, when he will be 30.Polamalu, an All-Pro safety in 2005, was set to make $1,088,000 and $1,722,000 in bonuses this season. His extension kicks in next season and will pay him $15,375,000 during the 2008-11 seasons in guaranteed money and roster bonuses, which are automatically paid as long as he is on the team.

Forward Chris Simon, who is still serving an N.H.L.-record 25-game suspension for hitting the Rangers’ Ryan Hollweg with a stick last season, re-signed with the Islanders. Simon agreed to a one-year deal worth $475,000.Simon, 35, missed the final 15 regular-season games and all 5 games of the Islanders’ first-round playoff loss to Buffalo. The last five games of his suspension carry to next season. He had 10 goals and 17 assists in 67 games last season.

The Nascar driver Carl Edwards was released early yesterday from an Omaha hospital after being injured Sunday night in a dirt track race in nearby Greenwood, Neb., a hospital spokeswoman said.Details of the injury were not immediately available. Edwards’s younger brother, Kenny Edwards, told The Omaha World-Herald it could be a dislocated thumb, caught in the steering wheel during a crash.

The Boston Bruins obtained center Carl Soderberg from the St. Louis Blues for goalie Hannu Toivonen yesterday.on Monday. Toivonen, who spent parts of the last two seasons with the Bruins, became expendable when Boston obtained goalie Manny Fernandez from Minnesota on June 30.

Cleveland center LeCharles Bentley, a two-time Pro Bowler, was cleared to return to the playing field, another major step in his comeback from a knee injury. He was cleared by Dr. Russell Warren, the Giants’ team physician, who performed two operations on Bentley.Bentley tore the patellar tendon in his left knee on the first play of training camp last season with the Browns. The injury was complicated by a staph infection, which Bentley said became so severe that it nearly killed him; doctors considered amputation.Bentley said he planned to be back in Cleveland on Thursday to report for training camp.

The free-agent swingman Morris Peterson signed with the Hornets, joining New Orleans after playing the first seven years of his career with Toronto. He averaged 8.9 points and 3.3 rebounds in 71 games last season.

The Rangers promoted Jim Schoenfeld to assistant general manager. He replaces Don Maloney, who became general manager of the Phoenix Coyotes last month. Schoenfeld will remain the general manager of the Hartford Wolf Pack, the Rangers’ American Hockey League affiliate, a position he has held for four seasons.He will no longer coach the Wolf Pack; Ken Gernander was hired to replace him. Schoenfeld will be the assistant general manager for player personnel; Cameron Hope will serve as assistant general manager for hockey administration.“Our organizational philosophy is to build within, and Jim’s keen eye for talent at every level has proven successful in building our organization,” Glen Sather, the Rangers’ president and general manager, said in a statement.

REGISTERED TRAVELER UPDATE The Registered Travel program continues to emerge — slowly. Verified Identity Pass, which runs Clear, the first version of the program to be in operation, said it would open and market a Clear lane at La Guardia Airport in New York in a partnership with AirTran Airways. Clear, which began operating at the airport in Orlando, Fla., two years ago, also has lanes at Kennedy International Airport and at Newark Liberty International Airport, and at airports in Indianapolis, Cincinnati and San Jose, Calif. It plans to open at the Albany airport next month. Steven Brill, the chief executive, said that Clear has 55,000 members (at $99.95 a year). He said he believed membership would reach 100,000 by September. In an interview last March, Mr. Brill said he expected that Clear could have 200,000 to 400,000 members by the end of the year.

A former Navy sailor charged with disclosing secret information about Navy ships and how to attack them also discussed attacking military personnel, prosecutors said.

The owner of a meat rendering plant in the Ironbound section of Newark was indicted yesterday on charges of polluting the air and water, state officials said. The owner, Seymour Berkowitz, 72, of Allendale, faces up to five years in state prison and fines. The plant, on Bay Avenue, processed more than a million pounds of meat waste a week, which was stored outside on the ground in all weather, state officials said.

New York City Transit plans to order 620 new subway cars at a cost of $1.2 billion, officials said yesterday. The purchase was approved by a board committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which oversees the transit agency. The cars are to replace older cars that are more prone to break down. The order represents the second phase of a major car contract signed in 2002 with two manufacturers, Kawasaki and Alstom. That contract called for an initial order of 660 cars, the first of which went into service last year. The new order costs about $100 million more than originally budgeted.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and 85 staff members returned to their City Hall quarters in Lower Manhattan yesterday after the premises underwent two weeks of renovation. During the work, the mayor and his staff worked out of emergency management headquarters in Brooklyn. The work, which cost $627,000, included new wiring, phones, desks and carpeting and expanded air-conditioning ducts.

A deadly fish virus spreading through upstate New York has been detected in three new locations and for the first time has been found in rainbow trout, one of the state’s top game fish, state scientists said yesterday. The disease, viral hemorrhagic septicemia, was found in fish from the Little Salmon River in Oswego County and the Seneca-Cayuga Canal, as well as an isolated farm pond in Niagara County, the Department of Environmental Conservation said. The virus causes internal bleeding in fish, but poses no risk to humans.

10 P.M. (FX) DAMAGES What price success? That’s the question at the stony heart of this new dramatic series, which follows Ellen Parsons (Rose Byrne), an ambitious first-year associate at a high-profile law firm. She is about to be thrown to the wolves, and the sharpest fangs may just belong to her mentor, Patty Hewes (Glenn Close, above right), the nation’s most revered — and reviled — litigator. Patty likes to defend the little people. But whether she’s on the side of justice is another story. Tate Donovan plays Tom Shayes, her trusted senior associate. Ted Danson (above left) is Arthur Frobisher, a ruthless billionaire chief executive, whom Patty is out to destroy. And Zeljko Ivanek is Ray Fiske, Frobisher’s lawyer, who’s got a little ammunition of his own. Let the bloodletting begin.

MESHBERG--Lev , of New York City and Carrara, Italy passed away suddenly on Tuesday, July 17 after suffering a heart attack. He was born in Odessa, Ukraine in 1933. Lev Meshberg was an artist whose works were widely exhibited and purchased by numerous museums and private collectors all over the world. He received formal training at the Odessa College of Fine Art. Upon graduation from college in 1958 he joined the Union of Artists. In 1973 he, his wife and their son Andrew emmigrated to the US. For many years Lev Meshberg was represented by the Franklin Bowles Galleries in New York and San Francisco. He is survived by his son Andrew Meshberg. His principal students were John Currin, Andrew Meshberg and Leon Lumelsky. Memorial services will be held at Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820, tel: (203)655-6127 on July 27 from 11:00 AM to 2:00 PM.

GREAVES--Geoffrey , 64 of Huddersfield, England and New York City died July 8, 2007. He will be missed by Sandra Greaves, daughter Gillian Greaves and all those whose lives he touched. May he rest in peace.

SITZMAN--Peter Jared , 38 of Sparta, New Jersey and previously of Lexington, Massachusetts died suddenly July 19, 2007 of a massive allergic reaction triggered by bee stings. He leaves his loving parents, Gloria and Dr. Steven Sitzman; brother Michael R. Sitzman; aunts and uncles: Dr. Matthew Gromet and Phyllis Schultz of Charlotte, North Carolina; Rosalind and Dr. Martin Stark of Reston, Virginia; and Leslie Sussman of Atlanta, Georgia. Pete was a favorite among his cousins: Melanie and Steven Glick and son Noah; Dan Gromet; Andrew Stark and Rebecca Gordon; AJ and Heather Sussman and son Andrew; and Nancy Effros and son Johnnie. Peter graduated from Williston North Hampton in 1987 and received his BA from the University of Rochester in 1991. He earned his MFA from Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, Virginia. Pete was a freelance high-end photo retoucher for the pharmaceutical industry. His ready smile, infectious laugh, and warm, loving manner will be sorely missed. Graveside ceremony and burial was held Sunday July 22nd at Mount Ararat Cemetery, East Farmingdale, New York. A memorial service will be held at Temple Isaiah, Lexington, Massachusetts at 1pm Tuesday July 24th. In lieu of flowers please make a donation in Peter's honor to an animal shelter of your choice.

RONAYNE--John A. , of Pearl River, NY passed away on July 20, 2007. Jack was born on March 14, 1916 in the Bronx, NY. He was a graduate of Fordham University and Fordham Law. He served in the US Army during WWII, retiring from the Army Reserves in 1976 with a rank of Lt. Colonel. He was an Inspector with the New York City Police Department retiring in 1961. Jack was Asst. Dean at Fordham Law School and Professor at Brooklyn Law School for over thirty years. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Alice; his children, Nancy, Peter and Donna, Jay and Mavis; five grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Services were held by WymanFisher Funeral Home, Inc., 100 Franklin Ave., Pearl River, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be held 10am Tuesday at St. Aedan's R.C. Church, Pearl River, NY. Burial will follow at St. Anthony's Cemetery, Nanuet, NY. RONAYNE--John A. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of a beloved colleage and esteemed teacher, Professor Emeritus John A. Ronayne. He joined the faculty in 1966, following a distinguished career in law enforcement. Over the course of four decades, he touched the lives of thousands of students, lawyers, and friends. Although his presence will be missed, his legacy will be enduring. We extend our deepest sympathy to his entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of The Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

WEISS--Sidney , of Lido Beach, NY, on July 23. Beloved husband of the late Ruth, cherished father of Joan and Jonathan (Linda), loving grandfather of Melissa and Wendy, loving brother of Harold. Love you madly and miss you forever. Services 11:30am Wednesday at Boulevard Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY 516295-3100.

NELKIN--Myron . An extraordinary man. Devoted, loving and proud husband, father and grandfather. Our hearts go out to Barbara, Mindy, Henry, Cathy, Rachel, John, Jimmy and Robbie. We are grateful to have known him. Louise and Bob Hersh and family. NELKIN--Myron, beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted and loving father of Henry, Mindy and Cathy. Adoring grandfather of Rachel, John, James and Robert. Private graveside service at 11am on Wednesday at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont followed by a memorial service at the Garden City Hotel. Shiva to be observed Wednesday and Thursday from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm.

Nearly six months before the first primary votes are cast, the contrast between the presidential fields of the two parties is stark and, historically speaking, quite surprising. There is still time for things to change, but among Democrats, the situation has been remarkably consistent for months, Democratic strategists and some polls say. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York is establishing herself as the Democrat to beat. Senator Barack Obama of Illinois is building a broad and, it appears, enthusiastic network as he challenges Mrs. Clinton. Former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina is struggling in states like South Carolina, Democrats say, as he bets his chips on Iowa, but is staying on the radar screen by setting out policy positions and striking a more aggressive stance.

As many states continue to jockey for early dates in the presidential nomination process, most American voters would like to establish a single national primary day, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll. Nearly three-quarters of the registered voters polled said they would prefer one nationwide day of contests to select each party's presidential nominee, although Republicans are slightly less inclined than Democrats and independents to support such a change in the long-established system of separately scheduled state primaries and caucuses.

FEINS--Claire K., of Yonkers, NY and then Stamford, CT on July 21, 2007. Born in the Bronx in 1918, first of four siblings, Claire graduated from Wadleigh High School, class of 1934 and went onto Hunter College. She was the first woman in her family to attend or graduate from college, receiving a BA in 1938 and an MA in History from Columbia in 1939. While at Columbia, she met Daniel M. Feins; they were married in 1941 and were inseparable until Dan's death in 1990. Claire was a committed and caring Social Studies teacher in the NYC Public Schools for over 30 years, teaching first at Dodge Vocational High School and then at Christopher Columbus High School in the Bronx. She also was a lecturer at Hunter College in the evening program, teaching students preparing for US citizenship. Claire and Dan traveled widely throughout the US and to Europe, the Mideast, South America and China. In retirement, they were avid Elderhoster participants. Claire loved art and art history, music, and theater. She was also a longtime active member of the Central Westchester Chapter of Brandeis U. Nation Women's Committee (BUNWC). Claire is survived by two devoted daughters; Judith Feins of Bellmont, MA and Roberta Feins of Seattle, WA; by their husbands (Bruce Bell and Bill Ross), and by two grandsons David and Jon Bell-Feins. Donations may be made to the American Parkinson's Disease Association, to BUNWC, or to Temple Emmanuel in Yonkers. Funeral services from the George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle at 1 PM today, 914632-0324 with interment to follow in the Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson.

NUSSBAUM--Ruth . The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its distinguished member, mother of our member Alan Nussbaum. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Steve Graber, President
SALZER--William M. March 22, 1917-July 24, 1977. Forever loved. Elizabeth

ROSENBAUM--Irving M . The Yeshiva University family expresses sorrow on the passing of a longtime friend who was a founding member of Wurzweiler School of Social Work Board of Governors. Deeply devoted to the Jewish community, Mr. Rosenbaum and his late wife, Hanni, established the Irving M. and Hanni Rosenbaum YU Aliyah Incentive Fund to assist alumni of YU schools who have made aliyah. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his sons, Eli, Daniel, and Michael; his granddaughters, Karina and Alissa; and to his companion, Ruth Hockley. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. NEW STRATEGIES TO AVOID TAXES Drug companies and other multinational corporations are once again resorting to complex strategies, many of them legal, to shelter billions of dollars in profits in international tax havens -- lowering their tax bills by about $50 billion a year, according to their financial statements and independent tax experts. ANOTHER LOSS FOR NEW ORLEANS Before Hurricane Katrina, health care was the biggest private employer in New Orleans, paying much higher wages than hotels or stores. But there are now 16,800 fewer medical jobs than before the storm and two-thirds fewer hospital beds in New Orleans. [A1.]

RADER--Matthew Sam , died peacefully on July 14th, 2007 at home. Matthew was born March 10th, 1950 in New York City where he spent most of his life. He received a Bachelor's degree from the University of Wisconsin, Madison and a Master's degree in Criminal Justice from the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York. In 1990, Matt married the love of his life, Lynne Ossa Rader, mother of Amber, and although she predeceased him, he never stopped loving or speaking of her. Matt worked most of his life as a psychiatric Social Worker on Staten Island and in Brooklyn. Social Work was a natural extension of Matt's love and wisdom. Everyone who knew him, especially young people, benefited enormously from his deep well of caring--he was simply never too busy to talk, or to help. Forced to retire because of his deteriorating health, Matt spent the last several years actively involved in causes in support of human dignity, particularly the AIDS Hotline and Gods Love We Deliver. Although very ill, he continued his volunteer work for God's Love until just weeks before his death. His is survived by Joseph, the nurturer he considered his son, his daughters Amber and Cassie, and her mother Nancy, his nieces Rachael and Emily, nephew Jacob, his brother Frank and sister-in-law Rae, and many friends. A memorial in celebration Matt's life will be held on Saturday, July 28th at 2:30 P.M at the 92nd Street Y (corner of 92nd Street and Lexington Avenue). Contributions may be made to God's Love or Hospice of New York.
HOGARTY--Gerard W. , 7/24/91. We continue to celebrate the joy of your life. Love, Mother, Tim, Family and Friends

A 40-year-old off-duty police officer and a 19-year-old woman were found shot to death in the officer's Bronx apartment yesterday afternoon in what is being investigated as a possible murder-suicide, the police said. The woman's body was found in the officer's bed with gunshot wounds to the head and torso. The officer, Fred Maselli, was found shot in the head on the floor of the apartment, at 3611 Henry Hudson Parkway West. A gun was found near his body. Officer Maselli was a seven-year veteran of the force who worked at the 34th Precinct, the police said. Eddie Fishbaum, a neighbor, said that Officer Maselli and the woman had recently been dating.
THOMSON--Evelyne H. , 90, formerly of Manhasset, LI, on July 17th. Beloved wife of the late Samuel G. Thomson, mother of Jeanne and Gary, loving grandmother and great-grandmother.

Fred D. Thompson has never denied that he was quite the man about town before his marriage to his second wife, Jeri Kehn Thompson, in 2002. For those who wonder about how he was viewed by the women he dated, the country music singer Lorrie Morgan may have some answers. She dated Mr. Thompson around the time he was elected to the Senate in 1994, after he had divorced his first wife. ''Fred is an extremely generous man,'' Ms. Morgan wrote, with George Vecsey, a sports columnist for The New York Times, in her out-of-print 1997 memoir, ''Forever Yours, Faithfully.'' ''He wined and dined me and brought me presents.''

Jeffrey Swartz, Chair, Board of Directors Rabbi David Shapiro, Rosh Yeshiva

INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Classified Military PlanSees U.S. in Iraq Till 2009 The American command has prepared a detailed, classified plan that foresees a significant American role in Iraq for the next two years. The plan calls for restoring security in Baghdad and other local areas by the summer of 2008 and establishing ''sustainable security'' on a nationwide basis by the summer of 2009, according to American officials. ROSENSWEIG--Dorothy L. , 98, on July 23, 2007. Wife of the late David of the New York Philharmonic Society. Beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother.

MALLAN--Thomas Andrew , 73, founder and Chairman of the Board (Emeritus), of Main Steel Polishing Company, Inc., died July 19, 2007. Tom began his career in the metals industry with the G.A. Feld Company in 1954. In 1956, he turned an idea into a business when he founded Main Steel Polishing in the Bronx, NY. Although the company started with just one sheet polisher, Toms integrity, leadership and forward thinking moved Main Steel from a single location to the company's position today as the largest independent toll processor in North America, with ten facilities. The company celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2006. Born in Mt. Vernon, NY in 1934, Tom moved with his family to Marfa, TX in 1946 where he lived until graduating from high school. He returned to his roots in New York and graduated from the New York Military Academy in 1953. He also attended the Stockbridge School of Agriculture at the University of Massachusetts. Although Tom focused on his business, he believed in giving back and was an active participant in a number of organizations. He played an active role in the Metals Service Center Institute (MSCI) and received their prestigious Presidents Award in 2006. He also started the Toll Processing group for the Fabricators and Manufacturers Association (FMA) and was a member of their Board. Tom was also a strong supporter of the Association of Women in the Metal Industries (AWMI). Tom was a 32nd Degree Mason, a Shriner, a member of St. Georges-by-the-River Church in Rumson, NJ and belonged to many business and social associations. In addition to his wife Linda, Tom leaves a daughter Tracey Kane and her husband Bill, a daughter Margaret Mallan, a son Thomas Mallan, Jr. and fiance Amanda Lucas, and two grandchildren Lt. Kimberly Kane, US Army and Spc. Christopher Kane, US Army as well as a large, loving, extended family. The funeral was held at St. Georges bythe-River Episcopal Church, Rumson, NJ on 11:00 am on Monday, July 23, 2007. In lieu of flowers, donations in Tom's memory can be made to any of the following organizations: St. Georges-by-theRiver Episcopal Church, 7 Lincoln Ave., Rumson, NJ 07760; The FMA Scholarship Program, FMA Foundation, 833 Featherstone Rd., Rockford, IL 61107; Westchester Masonic Lodge Scholarship, 54 Main St., Tarrytown, NY 10591; the American Heart Association, or the Visiting Nurse Association.

MEISTER--Bertram, M.D. We think of you, miss you, and love you every day. Arlene, Lynn and Barbara.
BENENSON--Edward . It's been two long years. Remembered with much love. Gladys, Lisa and Amy

BISHOP--Gordon , 60, son of the late Edward and Sylvia Levin Bishop, died on Saturday July 21, surrounded by family and friends. Loving husband of the late Raden Ayu Nanies Siti Achadia Suryodiprodjo of Jojakarta, Java, devoted father of Naomi-Melati Bishop of NY, NY and cherished brother to Warren Bishop of LA, CA, Jane Bishop Shalam of Old Westbury, NY and Stuart Bishop of St. Paul, Minn. Gordon was a charismatic, passionate and talented poet, artist, mentor, Indonesian cultural specialist, businessman, journalist and political activist. Born in Manhattan, educated at Trinity School, Johns Hopkins, U.C. Berkeley and the Actors School of Compagnie Renaud-Barrault, Paris, France. Gordon lived a storied life to the fullest. He leaves a remarkable legacy of artistic endeavor and political activism in both the U.S. and Indonesia. His on-line Indonesia news service, Joyo News Service, has won international journalism awards and his poetry has been published in literary journals and anthologies. Gordon's magnanimous spirit, courage, sense of humor, flamboyance and larger - than - life character helped him to celebrate life and seek beauty even when faced with terrible tragedy and physical suffering. Gordon's exuberant, inspirational legacy will never cease to exist and has left an indelible mark on everyone he met. A funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel at 76 St. and Amsterdam, on Tuesday, July 24th at 11:45 am.

MEYERS--Stuart John , June 26, 1925-July 22, 2007. Beloved son of David and Florence Meyers, died peacefully at his home after a prolonged illness with his long time companion, Barbara Meredith, at his side. Stuart was best known as the Publisher of American Bicyclist and was considered one of the worlds leading authorities on the bicycle industry. He is survived by his brother, Warren B. Meyers, and will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed by his many friends.

Ron Miller, a former songwriter for Motown Records who wrote a string of pop standards, including ''For Once in My Life'' and ''Heaven Help Us All,'' died yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Santa Monica. Mr. Miller, who had been ill with lung cancer and emphysema, died of a heart attack, his daughter Lisa Dawn Miller-Hackett said.

At a campaign event in New Hampshire today, Mitt Romney took aim at the leading Democratic presidential hopefuls, saying that if one of them were elected, America should get ready for "a sharp left turn," according to a dispatch from the Associated Press.

There seems to be a new wave in the contrarian crossfire of television news on the subject of celebrity misdeeds. Jack Cafferty, the vinegary commentator on CNN and alumni of a legendary "Live at Five" team, was the latest example in a protest against the Lindsay Lohan news, right.

Obesity often is described as a modern-day epidemic, but only now have scientists found evidence that it spreads from person to person. After studying the social connections and body composition of nearly 12,000 people participating in the Framingham Heart Study over three decades, researchers at Harvard Medical School found that subjects were at greatly increased risk of becoming obese if they had friends who were themselves obese.

So the other, or at least next, shoe has dropped in the Alberto Gonzales hearings, with the House Judiciary Committee voting "to seek contempt of Congress citations against Joshua B. Bolten, the president's chief of staff, and Harriet E. Miers, the former White House counsel." A former committee chairman, James Sensenbrenner, Republican of Wisconsin, threw cold water on the announcement, according the Associated Press, "saying that a civil lawsuit in federal court would be less perilous for the balance of power between the executive and legislative branches than a constitutional battle over contempt" -- "I think that the White House is going to win an argument in court over the contempt matter," Sensenbrenner told the panel.

A reader, Victoria McCoy, wondered why I didn't call Arthur Sulzberger, Jr., the publisher of The New York Times and chairman of its parent company, Mr. Sulzberger on second reference. It occurred to me that others may wonder why I never use Mr., Mrs., Ms. or other honorifics, when The Times always does.

Bankers for Kohlberg Kravis Roberts pulled the sale of 5 billion pounds ($10.3 billion) in senior loans meant to finance the buyout of Alliance Boots, a person with knowledge of the matter told DealBook Wednesday. The eight banks responsible for the offering will keep the debt on their books for now, this person said.

A major tsunami drill along Thailand's Andaman Coast revealed flaws in the warning system that's been set up in the aftermath of the 2004 disaster, The Associated Press reported. Not everyone heard the alarms, and the ones that did heard too late. Officials had solutions for both problems -- more alarms and better software.

Thousands of soccer fans filled the streets of Baghdad after the Iraqi team's victory in the Asian Cup semifinals, but bombings marred the celebrations.

A computer programmer/blogger brings word via Boing Boing that Thailand has unblocked YouTube again, more than three months after several videos posted on the site were deemed insulting to the king, a high crime in that country. Google, the owner of YouTube, agreed to block access to those three videos itself, but not to others cited by the Thai government.

Wednesday was a busy day if you happened to be a presidential candidate "surrogate" -- one of those individuals who the campaigns dispatch from time to time to speak for or vouch for the candidate on one issue or another.

Sardar Biglari, chairman of The Lion Fund, is speaking out against IHOP's proposed acquisition of the restaurant chain Applebee's. In a news release, he cites unusual stock moves -- IHOP's share price has surged since the $1.9 billion deal was announced last week, whereas a buyer's stock often declines -- as evidence that the sale price is too low.

A rising tide, they say, lifts all boats. And law firms are no exception: recent years have bestowed a bounty upon the legal profession as work for mergers and acquisitions, leveraged buyouts and hedge-fund deals has surged. Profits per partner are rising because firms can charge clients more per hour. Lawyers at New York firms are making record salaries even as many of them grouse that they should be making more.

Why have private equity firms been winning so many auctions? Peter J. Solomon, whose eponymous boutique investment bank focuses on the retail industry, suggests that the playing field has been tilted in their favor by the bankers that companies hire to run the sale process.
"Lost and Found" is an animated valentine to my favorite early animators.

At the Summer North American Bridge Championships here on Tuesday night, the winners of the Truscott/USPC Senior Swiss Teams were Geoffrey Brod of Avon, Conn.; Richard DeMartino of Riverside, Conn.; Pat McDevitt of Brookline, Mass.; and John Stiefel of Wethersfield, Conn.

As your usual host here at Screens takes a well-deserved week off, allow me to pose a question: Financial contributions aside, has the Internet reinvented/radicalized/renewed our interest in political campaigns? We got the Hillcast, a hot-off-the-digital-presses "Sopranos" parody (also courtesy of Senator Clinton), what seems like just about every minute of the Obama campaign and some truly hypnotizing performance art from Mike Gravel (it's so nutty, it makes you wonder if he should spend more time seeking arts grants than campaign contributions).
An excursion to Canada in search of history and lore. By Hope Larson. Part of Summerscapes, an occasional series on the rites of summer.
The latest enforcement action from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission shows just how aggressive that regulator is. Not very.
Nobody really likes to pay taxes -- and that may apply just as much to the environmentally minded as to anyone else.
