Falcons’ quarterback Michael Vick and three defendants pleaded not guilty in federal court and were released without bond.
An envoy from South Korea flew to Afghanistan to negotiate the release of the remaining 22 hostages.
Alex Rodriguez’s 499th career home run broke open a tight game and helped the Yankees cut their deficit in the A.L. East to 6 ½ games behind the Boston Red Sox.

Hundreds of Manhattan residents were evacuated from their homes last night when a retaining wall at a controversial construction site on the Upper West Side gave way, the police and a spokeswoman for the Buildings Department said.

A man shot a 14-year-old girl in the ankle last evening after an argument in the street, the police said. The girl, whose name was not released, was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where she was in stable condition last night. The police said that the girl was sitting on a stoop on Pitman Avenue in Wakefield when a white Dodge Magnum pulled up around 5:30 p.m. The man, who was driving the car, started a conversation that turned into an argument, at which point he pulled out a gun and shot the girl in the ankle, the police said.

Hundreds of Manhattan residents were evacuated when a retaining wall at a construction site on the Upper West Side gave way last night, the police and a spokeswoman for the Buildings Department said. No serious injuries were reported. The wall’s collapse took place in the Park West Village complex, near the intersection of 97th Street and Columbus Avenue, at a retail-residential complex that will house a Whole Foods supermarket. The Fire Department evacuated people from apartments in an adjacent building at 784 Columbus Avenue to a nearby school while the management company spent several hours shoring up the wall.
In the Philadelphia suburbs where Tim Donaghy grew up, there seems to be only muted sympathy for a man who was described by many as having an abrasive, confrontational personality.
Baseball immortality is one start away after Tom Glavine pitched six innings in the Mets’ victory Wednesday night against the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Brent Sutter, who has been the Devils’ head coach for less than two weeks, said Wednesday that he had hired four assistant coaches that have either coached or played for the Devils.
Since he was recalled from the minors on July 12, Lastings Milledge has driven in a team-high 11 runs, and — until Tuesday night — done nothing to spark the controversy.
Documents indicate that Congressional leaders were briefed about terrorist surveillance, contradicting testimony by Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales.

An article on July 17 about deliberations by the United Nations Security Council over the future of Kosovo, the breakaway Serbian province, misstated the percentage of Serbs in Kosovo’s population of approximately 1.9 million. It is 6 percent, not 10 percent.
Chipmaker KLA-Tencor settled with the S.E.C. on charges that it had concealed more than $200 million in compensation through options backdating.
Prostate cancer is less likely to relapse in men who are treated by more experienced surgeons, according to a new study.
The trade surplus surged in June as a weaker yen and higher overseas demand for electronics and cars helped exports rise at the fastest pace in five months.
A British insurer, Resolution, said that it would buy a rival, Friends Provident, in an all-stock deal that would create one of Britain’s largest life insurers.
Surging sales of Nintendo’s Wii and DS video game systems lifted the company’s quarterly profit fivefold, prompting the Japanese game maker to raise its annual earnings forecast 40 percent.
The truck maker Volvo posted an unexpected decline in second-quarter profit and forecast more weakness in the United States, setting off a 9 percent decline in its share price.

South Korea’s economy grew sharply in the second quarter, expanding at its fastest rate in a year, fueled by strong output of semiconductors, ships and automobiles, the Bank of Korea said. Gross domestic product expanded 4.9 percent in the three months ended June 30 from the second quarter last year, the central bank said. That was up from the 4 percent rate in the first quarter and the highest since growth of 5.1 percent in the second quarter last year. Compared with the previous quarter, the economy grew 1.7 percent. The manufacturing sector grew 3.6 percent in the second quarter, rebounding from a contraction of 0.9 percent in the first quarter. South Korea’s exports grew 5.2 percent, up from the first quarter’s 2.7 percent expansion.
Top-seeded Andy Roddick took another step toward his fourth final in five years at the Indianapolis Tennis Championships.
Tennis.

Patrick Kane, an 18-year-old forward who was the first pick over all in last month’s N.H.L. entry draft, has signed a three-year contract with the Chicago Blackhawks, the team announced yesterday. The 5-foot-10, 160-pound Kane led the Ontario Hockey League in scoring last season with 62 goals and 83 assists with the London Knights.

The Carolina Hurricanes star Eric Staal and his brother, Jordan Staal of the Pittsburgh Penguins, were arrested and charged for misdemeanor disorderly conduct and obstructing the legal process charges at Eric Staal’s bachelor party. The Cook County (Minn.) Sheriff’s Office said the brothers were among 14 arrested last weekend after authorities received several complaints about “screaming, yelling and playing loud music” at the resort in northeastern Minnesota.
Second-seeded Mikhail Youzhny and third-seeded Juan Carlos Ferrero lost their second-round matches at the Austrian Open in Kitzbühel.

The Swiss syndicate Alinghi announced yesterday that it would defend its America’s Cup trophy in Valencia, Spain, where it won the final last month. Alinghi’s owner, Ernesto Bertarelli, announced Team New Zealand as the fourth challenger accepted for the next race — after South Africa’s Shosholoza, Team Origin of Britain and Desafio Español from Spain, the challenger of record.

Softball finally got going yesterday at the Pan Am Games in Rio de Janeiro after two days of delays because of weather and stadium problems. The world champion United States won twice, first beating Brazil, 7-0, on a combined no-hitter from Jennie Finch, who struck out 11 in four innings, and Alicia Hollowell, who fanned three in the fifth before the game was called by the mercy rule. In a 4-0 victory over Colombia, the American team also got no-hit pitching and a combined 17 strikeouts from Monica Abbott and Jennie Ritter.

Subtle Aly caught I Promise at the wire yesterday to win the $100,000-added Schuylerville Stakes for 2-year-old fillies on opening day at Saratoga Race Course. Ridden by Edgar Prado, Subtle Aly, a chestnut filly, ran six furlongs in 1 minute 11.06 seconds.

Environmentalists were assessing damage to land and seawater in suburban Vancouver as a cleanup of oil sprayed from a ruptured pipeline continued. An excavator working on a sewer line on Tuesday broke the pipeline, sending a plume of crude oil about 60 to 100 feet into the air until the system was shut down 25 minutes later. Eight homes in Burnaby were heavily coated by the oil and remained evacuated. Several oil-saturated streets remained closed. Storm sewers caused some oil to enter Burrard Inlet, although light winds and the rapid placement of containment barriers limited its spread. The Canadian Transportation Safety Board is investigating. The pipeline is owned by Kinder Morgan Energy Partners of Houston.

Pratibha Patil was inaugurated as India’s first female president, a move that has been praised as a boost for women in a country where they often face rampant discrimination. Her limousine was escorted through the streets of New Delhi by a company of soldiers riding horses, and she took the oath of office in Parliament. A 72-year-old lawyer and governor of northwestern Rajasthan, she was chosen for the largely ceremonial post by the governing Congress Party and elected by national and state lawmakers last week.
Increased attacks on truck convoys are hampering the half-billion-dollar effort to feed two million people affected by the conflict in Darfur, the World Food Program said.

Russia will not complete the nuclear power plant it is building for Iran until late next year, a year behind schedule, the official Russian news agency RIA Novosti reported, quoting the director of a subcontracting company of the state nuclear power company Atomstroyexport. The director, Ivan Istomin of Energoprogress, said suppliers had “lost faith” in the Bushehr power plant, Iran’s first nuclear power plant, because of payment disputes with Iran. The United States and other Western countries have repeatedly objected to Russia’s involvement in the plant, warning that Iran could apply the technology to nuclear weapons. In recent months, Russia has displayed its own wariness.

A ferocious heat wave kept its grip on much of southern Europe. Officials across the region said the heat had played a part in the deaths of dozens of people, mostly the elderly. The temperature in Athens reached 113 degrees, as power failures added to the misery, leaving parts of Greece, along with Albania, Macedonia, Montenegro and Kosovo, without electricity for hours. Dozens of forest fires burned across the region. Along the Gargano Peninsula in southern Italy, thousands of tourists, vacationers and residents who had been forced to the sea by fires and rescued by boat began returning to their hotels and homes, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. Cooler weather is expected this week.
Second quarter profits declined at the military contractor General Dynamics due to one-time charges, but its private jet and combat equipment divisions helped boost core earnings.

About 150 Santas from around the world gathered near Copenhagen for their annual convention. They discussed whether the Yule should be celebrated more on Christmas Eve or Christmas Day. They also called for tax exemptions on Christmas presents.
Casualties from land mines used by guerrilla organizations in Colombia have climbed sharply in recent years, with civilians suffering increasingly.
Raising tolls carries the risk of political suicide. But what if drivers say they are willing to pay more to get through the region’s bridges and tunnels faster?
Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials need to assure riders that they have scoured all available pockets for cash before they increase fares in New York.
A Washington, D.C., cab driver who admitted he had attended training camps in Pakistan was sentenced to 15 years in prison.
A fraternity president was charged with making a terrorist threat after a note was found that threatened a “murderous rampage” similar to the shootings at Virginia Tech.
Summer rain has begun to replenish Lake Okeechobee in the heart of the Everglades after an 18-month dry spell led to severe water restrictions, officials said.
Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agents raided 10 medical marijuana clinics in Los Angles County.
The Hungarian cinematographer fell in love with the American landscape on a cross-country bus ride and then gave visual shape to seminal films like “Easy Rider.”
Democratic leaders have lowered their sights on cutting subsidies in part to protect rural freshman lawmakers who may be vulnerable in 2008.
With Shinzo Abe’s future as prime minister hanging by a thread, politicians from his own party are distancing themselves for their own survival.
After a 13-inning game on Tuesday night, Barry Bonds was not in the starting lineup for Wednesday night’s game against Atlanta, prolonging a home run chase that had already stalled.
Hidden cards and risk-taking behavior like bluffing have made poker a difficult challenge for software designers. But as with chess and checkers, the computers are catching up.

A Washington paramedic who admitted that he attended terrorism training camps in Pakistan in 2002 was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 15 years in prison. The man, Mahmud Faruq Brent, 32, pleaded guilty in April to conspiring to help a terrorist organization, the Pakistani group Lashkar-e-Taiba. He had been portrayed as eager to serve the terrorist group even if it meant attacking the United States, but his lawyer, Hassen ibn Abdellah, called him a hard-working family man who might have been “naïve, young, impressionable” when he went to the terror training camp.

A City Council aide who was fired after threatening the “assassination” of a councilman was escorted by police officers and security guards from the Council chamber yesterday after she defied an order to leave. Viola Plummer, who had been chief of staff to Councilman Charles Barron, briefly stood her ground before leaving the chamber with Mr. Barron at her side in a show of support. The episode was the latest chapter in a racially charged matter that began when lawmakers voted on May 30 to block an effort to name four blocks of a Brooklyn street after the late black activist Sonny Carson. After the vote, Ms. Plummer declared that Councilman Leroy G. Comrie Jr., a black Queens Democrat who had abstained, would never become Queens borough president, and threatened him in vulgar terms with assassination. Ms. Plummer, who is black, insists the threat was aimed at Mr. Comrie’s political career, not his life. But the remark drew a strong rebuke from Speaker Christine C. Quinn, who first suspended, then fired Ms. Plummer after she refused to sign a pledge promising to conduct herself appropriately. Ms. Plummer has filed a lawsuit challenging her dismissal.

A former police officer was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to two to six years in prison for killing a pedestrian while driving drunk on the Queensboro Bridge last year. The former officer, Brandon Colon, 31, pleaded guilty on June 4 to second-degree manslaughter in the death of Julio Ortega-Moncada, 31, on March 28, 2006. Mr. Colon was off duty at the time. A felony complaint said he had a blood alcohol level of nearly 0.14 percent (the legal limit is 0.08 percent). In court yesterday, Mr. Colon apologized to Mr. Ortega-Moncada’s family. “I can never escape what happened,” he said.
The results exceeded analysts’ expectations as the company reported strong sales of iPods and Macintosh computers, as well as the sale of 270,000 iPhones.

A man suspected of being the “mad hatter,” who has committed 18 bank robberies while wearing distinctive hats, was indicted yesterday on one count of bank robbery, federal prosecutors said. The man, James G. Madison, 50, of Maplewood, was charged with robbing a Bank of America branch in Union on Sunday, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney for New Jersey. Mr. Madison is a suspect in 17 other robberies. While in custody on Monday, Mr. Madison told reporters that he was innocent and that the arrest was a matter of mistaken identity. He was ordered held without bail, prosecutors said. Compiled by John Sullivan.

An 8-year-old boy playing in the surf at the Newark Avenue beach drowned on Tuesday night after being swept up in a rip current, the authorities said yesterday. The boy, Trevon Taylor, was wading in waist-high water near a jetty when he was swept into deep water about 8:30 p.m., according to a family friend who had taken him to the beach with other children. More than 40 lifeguards formed a chain in the surf and found the boy about 30 yards offshore. He was pronounced dead at Jersey Shore University Medical Center, the police said.

Lt. Gov. David A. Paterson has been given a clean bill of health after tests at Mount Sinai Hospital. Mr. Paterson, left, underwent the tests following his release from a Buffalo hospital, where he was taken after fainting during a flight to Buffalo on Tuesday morning. Mr. Paterson had an angiogram at Mount Sinai, and doctors said he was in excellent health and could resume his normal schedule after a few days of rest.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission agreed yesterday to review an application to extend the license of the Indian Point nuclear reactors for 20 years. The state attorney general, the environmental group Riverkeeper and others had argued that the application was inaccurate or incomplete and should not be accepted for consideration, but the agency said it was sufficient. The decision gives opponents 60 days to request a hearing. Licenses on the two operating units expire in 2013 and 2015. The review of the application is likely to take nearly three years.

The 10-block area that was closed after last week’s explosion of a steam pipe on 41st Street at Lexington Avenue has for the most part been reopened, the city’s Office of Emergency Management said yesterday. The area, known as the frozen zone, has been reduced to the streets near the blast: 41st Street between Park and Third Avenues and Lexington Avenue between 40th and 42nd Streets. Of 11 buildings closed after the explosion, 8 have been cleaned and reopened, city officials said. Con Edison is working to repair the broken steam pipe and will repave the damaged street, city officials said.

The New York Civil Liberties Union has filed a public records request asking the Police Department to turn over computerized data on stop-and-frisk activities so it can analyze the role that race plays in such street stops. Asked if the department would comply, its spokesman, Paul J. Browne, pointed out that the department had already turned over reports on its raw data to the City Council, as required by law. The reports showed a fivefold increase in the number of stop-and-frisks from 2002 to last year, with more than half of them involving black residents. The civil liberties group wants to analyze each of the 508,540 street stops last year, as well as those from the first half of this year. The department commissioned the RAND Corporation, a nonprofit organization, to conduct an independent assessment of the stops, Mr. Browne said. He added, “In terms of race, the data showed that stops were consistent proportionately with descriptions provided by victims of violent crime.” The Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said yesterday that the Council expected the police to provide the data to citizens and that if they did not, the Council would “take appropriate action.”.
The Hearst Corporation is suing the federal government to reveal the names of dozens of current and former major league baseball players who may have been provided performance-enhancing drugs.
A public increasingly jaded about the damages from the Iraq war should demand the commander in chief face up to the sufferings of his returning troops.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York vowed to fight any State Senate inquiry into his administration’s internal operations.
Presidential candidates’ use of jets shows how some campaigns have reaped benefits from supporters by using corporate jets at costs lower than chartering a plane.
Some school officials and even some parents were left scratching their heads over what practical effect the bill would have.
Congress must not capitulate in the White House’s attempt to rob it of its constitutional powers.
President Vladimir V. Putin announced the move in response to plans by the United States to build missile defense sites and deploy troops in Central Europe.
Joshua Komisarjevsky, a suspect in the brutal invasion of a home in Cheshire, Conn.,  is part of a family whose members have been accomplished in the arts and in business.
Profits dropped 94 percent in the second quarter at ConocoPhillips due to charges related to its Venezuelan assets, where it has abandoned its heavy oil projects.
The report, by an independent body, places a large share of the blame for the failures on the government overseers at the U.S. aid agency.
A huge explosion and fire hit a major gas pipeline in northwest Russia early Thursday, but there were no reports of casualties, and officials said gas exports were not affected.
Bankers have been unable to raise all of the money needed for the buyout of the Chrysler Group by a private-equity firm, but officials say the deal remains on track.
Shaun White, who won a snowboarding gold in Turin, is committed to becoming an equal level snowboarder and skateboarder.
Hall of Fame third baseman George Brett, who planned to visit with Alex Rodriguez while the Yankees were in town, said recently that he would pick Rodriguez to start a franchise.
Anheuser-Busch said that its second quarter profit rose, helped by higher prices, increased productivity and strong sales of imported brands like Tsingtao and Corona.
Despite an 11 percent rise in profits at WellPoint, the largest U.S. health insurer by enrollment, shares fell after the company reported a drop in membership from the first quarter.
Jeff Gaspin will become the C.O.O. of NBC’s Universal Television Group, giving him responsibility for the company’s TV business outside of the NBC network.
For officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the expected surplus could become a major obstacle to convincing straphangers and politicians of the necessity of a fare and toll increase.
With one big inning, the Toronto Blue Jays swept aside the Minnesota Twins.
The only homeless shelter in New York just for veterans will close in August for renovations, then reopen with a little more than half its current number of beds.
Arkansas Coach Houston Nutt’s tumultuous off-season was filled with salacious rumors about his personal life and charges of betrayal to recruits.
The U.S. aircraft-maker posted its largest quarterly profit in nearly four years on the strength of its airplane business.
Democrats agreed to compromises in the legislation, prompting concerns over the effectiveness of some of the promised security enhancements.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,631 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
Looking for the “Hottest Mom in America,” Medicis Pharmaceutical introduced a multimedia campaign  to market its cosmetic wrinkle filler to middle-income women.
The Taliban shot dead one of their 23 South Korean hostages after complaining that the government had not responded positively to their demands.
The tools in the swindle included tiny video cameras, earpiece radio receivers devised to be undetectable and laptop computers.
The field for the second annual NYC Half-Marathon got stronger with the addition of three elite athletes from Kenya and South Africa.
Today, many of the nation’s largest foundations regard disclosing and analyzing their failures as bordering on a moral obligation.
A new report is a rebuttal of assertions by detainee advocates that the American naval station at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, is filled with hapless innocents.
The commanding general at Fort Lewis, Wash., rescinded a plan for a once-a-month collective memorial service rather than individual ones for slain soldiers.
The Texas power company TXU Corporation urged shareholders to vote for its planned takeover by a private equity group, despite the objection of its largest shareholder.
Joseph L. Bruno, Albany’s top Republican, made his first public appearance since the release of a report showing that aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer had conspired to plant damaging news about Mr. Bruno.
Continued declines in advertising revenue pushed down operating profit at the New York Times Company, but second-quarter earnings were up on the sale of its television stations.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York made an appearance at the annual conference for the Urban League, which has become a required stop for presidential aspirants.
GlaxoSmithKline reported a 1.4 percent rise in net profits despite a drop in revenue and troubles surrounding it’s diabetes drug Avandia.
The House Judiciary Committee voted along party lines to hold President Bush’s chief of staff and the former White House counsel in contempt of Congress.
The Walt Disney Company said it would ban cigarettes from being shown in its family films and would discourage it in other films.
The unidentified corpses were apparently the latest victims in Iraq’s sectarian warfare.
The arraignment kept up the prosecution’s rapid pace in a shooting that took place little more than two weeks ago.
The House voted overwhelmingly to bar permanent U.S. military installations in Iraq as lawmakers readied for yet another clash over a demand to withdraw troops.
The move came after President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva had assured Brazilians that he had ordered changes in the country’s flawed civil aviation system.
Two Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor that they wanted to move on with their lives but were still too shaken after more than eight years in a Libyan prison.
Faced with scaling back his program to a noncompetitive level, Bobby Ginn merged with Dale Earnhardt Inc. to form a four-car team.
Concerns about product safety and workplace conditions have driven Mattel to become a role model for how to do business prudently in China.
The three-time Pro Bowl running back Priest Holmes will report to the Kansas City Chiefs’ camp Saturday, 21 months after he was knocked out of football by a devastating hit.

SYRACUSE, July 25 — A procession of girls from the Onondaga Nation, an Indian tribe south of here, are testifying this week against a former music teacher accused of furtively molesting them as they sat on his lap while movies were shown to the class.
The former president and C.O.O. of SafeNet, a maker of network security products, was indicted on securities fraud charges in connection with the backdating of employee stock options.
Strong demand for Internet-enabled cellphones helped raise profits at the mobile chipmaker.
After reworking his contract last year at the Jets’ request, the left guard expected the team to return the favor.
A verdant ribbon of land at the north end of City Hall Park will reopen after being out of use for seven years.
Mercedes’s earnings were up 74 percent, beating expectations, despite a dip in unit sales.
A preliminary autopsy report showed a burst blood vessel in his neck killed Mike Coolbaugh, the Tulsa Drillers hitting coach, when he was hit by a batted ball Sunday.
Colgate-Palmolive said that second-quarter profits improved thanks to cost cutting measures and increased market share due to record advertising spending.

There will hardly be any summer break for 30 high-achieving and low-income students in New Jersey who are participating in a new program aimed at eventually getting them into the nation’s best colleges.
The home builder Pulte Homes reported a second-quarter loss after taking charges related to lower land values and job cuts.
The company’s chief executive said he anticipates closing the transaction in the fourth quarter, following F.C.C. approval.
Chen Liangyu has been stripped of his membership in Parliament, signaling that he will probably be charged with crimes soon.
The Blackburn Challenge is a 20-mile rowing-and-paddling race around Cape Ann, Mass., a rocky peninsula an hour north of Boston.
The number of West Nile virus cases in the United States is nearly four times what it was a year ago, meaning that an epidemic may be in store, researchers report.
Northeastern Pennsylvania is a longtime Yankees stronghold and considering its proximity to New York, it’s only natural that the Yankees’ Class AAA team would end up in Scranton.
Color pages are five times more profitable for Xerox than black-and-white prints.
San Francisco’s Taxicab Commission voted to keep the Dark Lord’s favorite number — 666 — affixed to an allegedly cursed cab.
East Timor, a country with few natural resources and only marginal geographical advantages, shows signs of a growing Chinese presence as China courts its neighbors.
The foreign ministers of Egypt and Jordan held joint meetings with Israeli leaders on Wednesday, their first as envoys of the Arab League.
NASA has lost $94 million in office equipment, looking the other way as employees claim missing laptops are lost in space, according to a report.
Stocks were up on Wednesday on strong earnings reports, but investors are worried about deteriorating lending conditions.
An agreement would allow emergency food aid into a conflict-ridden area that the Ethiopian military has been blockading for several weeks.
A divided S.E.C. issued two dramatically different proposals on how and whether shareholders can nominate corporate directors.
Prime Minister Gordon Brown said his government would establish a highly visible border police force to patrol airports and seaports.
A growing group of recent college graduates are bypassing regular employment to become franchisees.
Ohio’s domestic violence laws do not conflict with its ban on same-sex marriage, the State Supreme Court ruled.
Ulrich Mühe was a popular German actor who won acclaim as a tormented Stasi officer in cold-war East Germany in the Oscar-winning film “The Lives of Others.”
The National Association of Realtors reported that existing homes sales fell to the slowest pace since November 2002, a decline that was twice what had been expected.
Bill Flemming, one of the original announcers on ABC’s “Wide World of Sports,” was also known for his Olympics, college football and golf broadcasts.
The method most frequently employed to bring the Supreme Court to heel has been increasing or decreasing its membership.
David Beckham’s arrival on our shores is uniting those who worship the global game of soccer and those who can’t stand it.
Exploring Brooklyn.
Federal regulators charged the collapsed hedge fund Amaranth Advisors and its former chief energy trader with trying to manipulate natural gas markets last year.
Manhattan.
Whether they are for or against the bulldozing of the old walled garden at Hadspen House in England, everyone in British gardening seems to have an opinion about it.
A Russian-born builder specializes in buying, renovating and flipping choice single-family Upper East Side town houses.
Lindsay Lohan denies using drugs, “Lost,” but returning, millions bid for memoir of Keith Richards and more culture news.
After 32 years, Soho Rep will move completely from Off Off Broadway to Off Broadway status for the coming season.
Dates, cast and theater have been set for Aaron Sorkin’s new play about the legal battle over the invention of the television.

This fall Drew Carey will take over “The Price Is Right” for Bob Barker, who retired in June at 83 after 35 years on the job.

Last week will surely go down as one of the worst in recent sports history. In the span of a few days, scandal shook our three most popular sports leagues to their foundations.

Charles H. Ferguson is a political scientist, turned author, turned Sundance-prize-winning filmmaker his first time behind the camera with “No End in Sight.”

“Nick Cannon’s Star Camp” follows a group of young would-be pop stars being handpicked by Mr. Cannon and put through a boot camp to form a group and learn what it takes to make it in the music business.
It’s astonishing how much the White Stripes, who played their first show at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday, have achieved through pure stubbornness.
Baron Ullens is to announce on Thursday the details of his plans for one of the largest contemporary art spaces in China.

The centuries-old art of Beijing Opera encountered the century-old art of Western modern dance on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, when the Lincoln Center Festival presented Shen Wei Dance Arts.
Starting next week members of the union that represents the carpenters, electricians, props workers and sound technicians on Broadway will be reporting to work without a contract.
An article on July 12 about mattresses misspelled the given name of the United States sales manager for Hastens, a Swedish manufacturer. He is Erik Svensson, not Erick.
My new dog chewed up a chair and is eyeing the sofa — what can I do?

Six decades after his altar-boy childhood and subsequent loss of faith, Peter  O’Toole portrays the 16th-century pope Paul III in Showtime’s series “The Tudors,” which returns for its second season next spring.
The case in Parma is one of several against former executives and others accused of contributing to the alleged fraud that concealed Parmalat’s mounting debt.
The German company will sell its auto parts division to the tire maker Continental for $15.6 billion and will acquire Dade Behring Holdings, a maker of medical diagnostic products, for $7 billion.
The CW network is not home to many hot television shows, but that may change in the fall with the introduction of a series full of fire — and brimstone — and laughs.
Who in the West knows much of the dance and music of Mongolia? Or that its dances aren’t like those of anywhere else? Or that its singing is, by any standard, phenomenal?
People can turn from casual house admirers to near-obsessives, or house stalkers, who may stop and stare longingly, snap photos, talk to neighbors and track property records.

Mark McGwire will be conspicuously absent from the stage at this weekend’s Hall of Fame ceremony, penalized for his suspected steroid use by the baseball writers who select the inductees. That makes us ask: Should Hall of Fame voters treat Barry Bonds the same way when he become eligible?.

Seve Ballesteros finished second in the British Open when he was 19, a wiry lad who played golf with an artistic abandon unseen before or since. From that morning in 1976 when he burst onto the scene at Royal Birkdale, until the afternoon last week when he announced his retirement at Carnoustie with little fanfare, Ballesteros strode through life with a regal bearing -- impetuous, fiercely proud, supernally gifted. He was to Europe what Arnold Palmer was to America -- golf’s leading man, equal parts macho and charisma. For 20 years, he carried the European Tour on his back, winning three British Opens, two Masters and 87 tournaments worldwide. Europe owes much of its Ryder Cup success to his fiery leadership. His magical hands still could lay open a 2-iron to make it work like a sand wedge, but his arthritic back, riddled with pain, has ended his spectacular run at age 50.

Athletes with Type-1 diabetes no longer need to stay on the sidelines. As The Times reports today, small and instantaneous blood monitors and new companies that help manage the illness are allowing some doctors to bless intense exercise for patients willing to diligently watch blood-sugar levels during their workouts. Even endurance athletes with Type-1 diabetes, like Missy Foy, a professional ultra-distance runner, are competing at the highest levels of their sport.

If you’re looking for a new and challenging backpacking trip in the Northeast, consider the Grafton Loop Trail, a 42-mile path in the White Mountains of western Maine designed specially for multi-day excursions. The eastern leg of the loop opened in 2003, but the final piece of the puzzle, a 17.5-mile stretch on the west side of Route 26 near the town of Bethel, wasn’t accessible to hikers until late last month. Fit backpackers can bag the rugged and hilly terrain in three to five days, says Andrew Norkin, the director of trails for the Appalachian Mountain Club, and will summit several peaks that offer splendid views of the region. Several sources of potable water and eight campsites, available free on a first-come, first-served basis, are spread along the trail. No permits are necessary, and you’ll get a chance to test your mettle on the Appalachian Trail; the Grafton Loop shares eight miles of terrain with the storied route.
When a series starts off as excitingly as John Twelve Hawks’s Fourth Realm Trilogy did, readers are apt to cut the author’s next installments a little slack.
The book series has the voice of a young reader, and that  is troubling to some grammarians and parents.
A neighborhood in transition: Can laid-back and brand-name coexist?
For the first time, four generations — those who lived through World War II, Baby Boomers, Generation X and Generation Y — are together in the workplace.

7 P.M. (Cinemax) THE BLOOD OF YINGZHOU DISTRICT Starting tonight Cinemax will present all four of this year’s Academy Award-nominated documentary shorts on consecutive Thursdays, beginning with the winner. Thomas Lennon and Ruby Yang’s “Blood” follows a year in the life of orphans in the Yingzhou District in Anhui Province, China, who were ostracized by family and community, and even left to fend for themselves, because their parents had contracted AIDS from selling their blood and in some cases infected their children.

Frederick Wessler always took photographs, even when he was a foley artist (the one who puts the sounds in) for film and television. But don't confuse the vivid computer-generated prints of domestic objects and scenes he began making after he retired -- a Stillson wrench, above; a Wellfleet, Mass., front door at high noon; the narrow hall of his Chelsea tenement apartment building -- with photographs. Mr. Wessler, 62, uses three-dimensional modeling and rendering software to build, light and give texture and color to his images. He's drawn to things that have a history, like his father's wrench, which he remembers from his childhood and which he found recently while cleaning out his parents' house. ''You try to bring out that ineffable quality that is lurking somewhere in an object,'' Mr. Wessler said, describing how he tweaked the wrench's bruises and chipped paint, amplifying them in the computer to create, as he described it, the illusion of verisimilitude. ''If my pictures work, you should get a sense that something has happened or is about to happen,'' he said. Prints range from $250 to $500. Information: www.wessler3d.com. PENELOPE GREEN

CURRAN--Catherine Gamble. Born Beijing, China 1926. Died August 18, 2007 at her home in Manhattan. A philanthropist and patron of the arts and education, she graduated from Riverdale Country School and Mount Holyoke College and lived in India, London, England, Manhattan and Harbor Point, Michigan. As President of the Sidney Gamble Foundation for China Studies she oversaw a collection of early photographs of China taken by her father, co-curating the exhibition which toured the US and China and is now archived at Duke University. She was a Trustee of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Princeton - in - Asia, Young Concert Artists, and the Little Traverse Conservancy of Northern Michigan, and also served on the Boards of Mount Holyoke College, the New York City Ballet, the National Dance Institute, the American Federation of Arts, the American Friends of Covent Garden and the Royal Ballet. She was a Fellow of the Frick Collection, the Morgan Library, and the Royal Society of Arts, London, and a member of the visiting Committee to the Department of Drawings and Prints of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and of the Drawings Committee of the Morgan Library. She was on the Advisory Councils of the National Dance Institute and the School of American Ballet. Mrs. Curran was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club and the Little Harbor Club. She will be deeply missed by her children, Constance (Roemer) McPhee of New York and Peter (Bonni) Curran of Ketchum, Idaho, and her grandchildren Michael McPhee and Jessica and Cody Curran. In lieu of flowers please consider a donation to one of the organizations mentioned above.

NELKIN--Myron. My heart goes out to Myron's family at this very sad time. Muriel Israel NELKIN--Myron: 1700 apartments, and every one of them was built with your heart and soul. Over fifty years of providing housing on Long Island, you set the standard for the industry and raised the bar for everyone. Having worked for you is something we will always treasure. We never felt like employees; you made us feel like family. You were the captain of our ship and a father figure to us all. To have known you was a gift, to have worked for you an honor. The management and staff of Fairhaven Properties NELKIN--Myron. A loving husband, father, and grandfather, a visionary real estate developer, a friend and mentor to his employees, a generous supporter of a variety of charitable causes, and an avid golfer in his spare time, Myron Nelkin passed away on Sunday, July 22, at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. Born in Brooklyn on January 5, 1925, Mr. Nelkin was a student at Boys High in Brooklyn and graduated from Columbia University with a degree in business in 1946. With his father, Harry L. Nelkin, DDS, he began his working life building homes in Queens and Long Island. He founded three companies, Fairhaven Properties, Nelkin Construction Corp., and Central Management, and built all of Long Island's Fairhaven apartment complexes and the Woodbury Gardens senior residence. What Mr. Nelkin considered his crowning achievement was the rebuilding of The Garden City Hotel on the site of the storied original, where Charles Lindbergh slept in 1927 on the night before his trans-Atlantic flight. The completely new construction opened in 1983 on 21 acres in the heart of Garden City. Lavishly landscaped and decorated, lively and bright, the acclaimed establishment maintains a sense of its place in the history of Long Island, as Mr. Nelkin wished. When in New York, he called the penthouse suite his home. Mr. Nelkin generously supported the Helen Keller Home for the Blind, the North ShoreLong Island Jewish Health System, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Family Services of Nassau County, Christa House, the Hart Foundation for Parkinson's Research, and the Tilles Center, as well as Jewish philanthropies and causes. He is survived by his wife, Barbara (nee Norinsberg); his children, Henry L. Nelkin, Mindy Nelkin, and Cathy Nelkin-Miller and her husband, Charles Miller; his grandchildren, Rachel, John, and James Schwartz and Robert Miller; and his brother and sister-inlaw, William and Trudi Nelkin. A private interment was held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont. The family is sitting shiva at the hotel on Wednesday and Thursday, July 25 and July 26 from 2-4PM and 79PM. NELKIN--Myron. A man of great kindness, generosity and wisdom. Garden City will always be in his debt for his vision and creativity. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Barbara, daughters Mindy and Cathy, son Henry and grandchildren. Mary and Bob Krener NELKIN--Myron: We were so very proud to have been named your first ever Executive Committee. Representing The Garden City Hotel is not a job; it is our pleasure and greatest honor. We will always try to set the same standards for the staff that you set for us. We will help to carry on your legacy and continue to strive to be Long Island's finest hotel. You will always be our leader. You will be remembered every day, and your heart and soul will continue to be the driving force of this operation. The Executive Committee of The Garden City Hotel

SUNDIATA--Sekou. The New School notes with great sadness the death on July 18 of poet Sekou Sundiata, a writing professor at Eugene Lang College The New School for Liberal Arts and an artist of considerable renown. His most recent work, the 51st (dream) state, challenged facile notions of race, freedom, citizenship and ''Americanness'' through storytelling, readings, stand-up comedy, and poetry blended with music and video. He had a profound influence on many young poets and performance artists, and will be deeply missed. Philip Scaturro, Chairman of the Board Bob Kerrey, President Ben Lee, Provost Jonathan Veitch, Dean of Eugene Lang College The New School of Liberal Arts and The New School community

COLE--Lee R. (New York, NY) -August 17, 2007, in the care of the staff at Brigham and Women's Hospital and surrounded by his family, following a long illness bravely borne Lee R., beloved husband of Suzanne. Sadly missed by his daughters Bethany and Jennifer (Haughey), his sons Kristian and Justin, son-in-law Brian, daughters-in-law Dana and Carol, his grandchildren Zachary, Madison, Orla, Eoghan, Conall and Wallace Lee, extended family and friends. Family flowers only; donations if desired to Dana Farber Hospital, Lymphoma Research, Suite D1B30, Attn; Amy Emmert, 44 Binney St., Boston, Ma., 02115 or The Center for Lymphoma Research, Wiell Cornell Medical College, Starr 340, 520 East 70th St., NY, NY, 10021, Lee R. Cole Memorial Fund, Attn: Dr. John Leonard. Prior to his recent retirement, Lee R. Cole was Managing Director and Co-Head of Equity Linked Organization with UBS. Previously, he had been a Managing Director and Cohead of U. S. Equity Linked Capital markets at Credit Suisse First Boston. From 1997 to October 2000 he was Co-head of Convertible Securities with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Prior to that, Mr. Cole spent almost 20 years at Merrill Lynch as head of Global Convertible Origination He was perhaps most famous for his development of Liquid Yield Option Notes (LYONs), zero-coupon, convertible, callable and putable bonds. A chart on Sunday with an article about efforts by states to balance dog owners' rights with safety referred imprecisely to the 12 states that prohibit local governments from banning specific breeds. Despite those statewide statutes, several local governments in some states do indeed have laws against specific breeds. (In at least one case, the local law was passed before the state's ban took effect; in other cases the local governments have passed laws as a way to challenge their state's statute.)

A front-page article on Tuesday about a report that said aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York improperly used the State Police to gather information about State Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, a political rival, included incorrect information from the governor's office about the duties of an aide, William Howard. (The error also appeared in a chart in some copies.) Mr. Howard was assistant -- not deputy -- secretary for homeland security, not for public safety. The article also gave an incorrect title in some copies for Rex Smith of The Times Union of Albany, which first published articles on Mr. Bruno's use of State Police helicopters to travel to political fund-raisers in New York. Mr. Smith is the editor, not the publisher. Also, a picture in some copies of Governor Spitzer with Preston L. Felton, the acting superintendent of the State Police, carried an erroneous credit in some copies. It was by Nathaniel Brooks for The New York Times, not Mike Groll of The Associated Press.

An enthusiastic and much loved teacher of English Literature at Columbia for 45 years, he devoted himself to his edition of Samuel Johnson's ''Lives of the Poets,'' forthcoming in the Yale Edition of the Works of Samuel Johnson, of which he was also General Editor. Many people loved him, and we will miss him. Donations may be sent to the Pancreatic Cancer Research Fund, 161 Fort Washington Ave., NY, NY 10032-3784, c/o Dr. Chabot, checks payable to Columbia University.

(Jieldé lamps sell for $250 to $1,100; the Loft series fixtures shown above are $902 each.) Those who can't wait until September can order now, by sending an e-mail to jielde@notonqueen.com. The New York Times Company said today that its second-quarter operating profit fell because of weakness in newspaper advertising but that net income doubled because of a gain from the sale of its television stations. Highlighting the challenge faced by the entire newspaper industry as ad dollars shift away from newspapers to the Internet, the company also said it plans to cut operating costs by $230 million over the next two years.

WEINTZ--Elisabeth Brewer ''Betsy'', 77, of Riverside, CT, died unexpectedly of an apparent heart attack August 22, 2007, while summering at her family home on Islesboro, Maine. Born March 26, 1930, in New York City, Betsy was the daughter of Warren Brewer and Elizabeth Miller Hunt. Betsy had a lifelong commitment to community service. She was a current member of the Leadership Council of the Harvard School of Public Health. Her most recent support led to the founding of the Harvard Humanitarian Initiative, a research and academic center devoted to advancing humanitarian practice, government and international policy in the protection of the world's most vulnerable people and the training of the next generation of humanitarian leaders. She devoted over 36 years to Greenwich Hospital as a volunteer in the emergency room. She also served as Chair of Emergency Room Volunteers, was on the Hospital Disaster Team and was a board member of the Executive Comittee of the Greenwich Hospital Auxiliary. She served as president of the Old Greenwich Riverside Community Center for several years and was a trustee of the Greenwich Library. She served as board member of the Greenwich Adult & Continuing Education and the Community Cooperative Nursery School. She served on the Greenwich Arts Council, Junior League of Greenwich, and was on the PTA for Riverside Elementary School, Eastern Junior High School, Greenwich High School, and Brunswick School. Betsy loved to sing with the Blue Hill Troupe Ltd. and with the Greenwich Choral Society. What she loved even more was being with her family. Her love of the sea, sailing down the Intercoastal Waterway with her parents, crewing for her husband on Long Island Sound, and boating on Penobscot Bay with her grandchildren were some of her cherished times. She loved to travel, but mostly only with or where there was family. If Betsy could have, she would have saved every puppy in the window. There was never a moment in her life where there wasn't at least one dog by her side. She's survived by Rocky. Betsy was the first female ocean marine underwriter of the Insurance Company of North America, in Philadelphia. She later worked as the Administrative Assistant for the President and Chairman of the Board of American Sugar Refining Company in New York. She attended Rippowam Elementary School in Bedford, NY, Friends School of Wilmington, Delaware, Chapin School, NY, NY, and graduated in 1950 from Briarcliff College. In addition to her husband of 513/4 years, J. Fred Weintz, Jr., a retired partner of Goldman Sachs & Co., she is survived by her brothers Warren Brewer, Jr. of Cambridge, MA, and Roger Conant Brewer of Indialantic, FL; her daughters Elizabeth Weintz ''Beppie'' Cerf of Falmouth, ME, Polly Weintz Sanna of Cos Cob, CT, her sons Dr. Eric Cortelyou Weintz of Menlo Park, CA and Karl Frederick Weintz of Boston, MA; and her grandchildren Elisabeth Brewer ''Brett'' Cerf, Robert Frederick ''Rick'' Cerf, Warren Barrett ''Bart'' Cerf, Jonathan Cortelyou ''Jake'' Cerf, Lucy Hamlin Sanna, Cortney Curtis Weintz, and Bryce Cortelyou Weintz. She was predeceased by their first born son, Frederick Cortelyou ''Rickie'' Weintz, who died in infancy in 1962. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, August 29, at 11am at Christ Church, 126 E. Putnam Ave., Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830, 203-863-3000; Harvard Humanitarian Initiative, 8 Story Street, 2nd Floor, Cambridge, MA 02138, 617384-5661; Islesboro Islands Trust, PO Box 182, Islesboro, ME 04848, 207-734-6907; or a charity of your choice.

SULLIVAN--John Thielen. Lawyer, Chairman of the Executive Committee, First Investors, died Friday, August 17, peacefully at home in Mill River, MA. He was 75. Mr. Sullivan died after a brief bout of prostate cancer. Born in Detroit, Michigan, the son of Cora Mae (Solma) and Charles Morris Sullivan, he was raised in Toledo, Ohio. He graduated from The University of Notre Dame and Yale University Law School. His legal career began at Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, and continued at the SEC Enforcement Division where he soon served as Chief of the Wall Street Branch. After three years at Cole & Dietz, he became a partner at Hawkins, Delafield & Wood, where his practice revolved around securities law and international banking. He served as Chairman of the firm's Management Committee from 1981 until his retirement from the partnership in 1986. His association with First Investors began in 1968 when he represented Glenn Head and David Grayson in their purchase of the company. He served as outside counsel, on the Board of First Investors Consolidated Corporation, and ultimately on the Boards of most of the F.I. companies. He stepped in as President for a year following the death of David Grayson in 1994. History, philosophy and religion were his passions, as well as riding his horse. His first wife was Pamela Wylie, who died untimely in 1969. Loving and beloved husband of 22 years to Anne (McClelland) and tender, attentive father of Charles. He is also survived by nephews Patrick Robie, Jason St. John Robie and Michael Robie and nieces Martha Thorsrud and Margaret Shiple, their spouses and children. He was predeceased by his sister, Mary Sullivan Robie. A funeral was held Saturday, August 18 in Mill River, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The American Cancer Society, toll-free: 1-800-227-2345, or mailed to Memorial Processing Center, P.O. Box 7, East Syracuse, NY, 13057-0007. Please include Mr. Sullivan's and family address P.O. Box 313, Mill River, MA 01244

Len Brackett, a designer and builder outside Nevada City, Calif., has been making elaborate Japanese-style homes since 1977, shortly after completing a five-year apprenticeship with a Kyoto temple carpenter. Recently, he began producing a miniature version that he calls his ''gin-and-tonic bus stop'' -- a 6-by-10-foot pagoda he devised on impulse, he said, so he could ''sit, look at the garden, and have a gin and tonic.'' (After a friend likened it to a bus stop, the nickname stuck.) ''The shop work took just over a week,'' added Mr. Brackett, 60, above, ''and then it took two days to assemble.'' The structure, above, also known as the Summer House, is made of three types of wood -- sugar pine, incense cedar and Port Orford cedar -- and has the same complex joinery, above right and top, as Mr. Brackett's larger houses. ''In terms of quality, there is no difference between this and the houses I charge $2 million to design and build,'' he said, although this one costs $19,000, plus shipping (it comes in two crates). ''It's a pure architectural form -- there are no utilities, no planning expenses and no permitting, which is how I am able to make it so cheaply.''

BORDEAUX-GROULT-Pierre, died in his 92nd year on Wednesday, August 22nd at the American Hospital in Paris. He was born on March 21, 1916 and was educated in France and in England, receiving degrees from l'Ecole des Hautes Etudes Commerciales and Oxford University. In World War II, he served with the Free French Forces in Africa and, subsequently, with the French Forces in Germany. He was awarded the Croix de Guerre and the Bronze Star. Later, he held a number of positions with the Mouvement Europeen, becoming Treasurer in 1958. He was also the Founding President of the Comite d'Action pour l'Union Europeenne, a founder of l'Association pour la Concorde Civile et la Fraternite dans les Balkans and a founder of the French food company, Tipiak, S.A. He was an Officier de la Legion d'Honneur, Chevalier des Palmes Academiques and Officer of Merit of the Republic of Germany. He is survived by his wife Calixte, four children, Robert, Daphne, Elisabeth-Charlotte, Marie-Brunhilde and two stepchildren, Henry Mortimer and Victoria de Navacelle and seven grand and step-grandchildren. His first wife, Elise, his son Richard and his grandson Thomas predeceased him. He will be laid to rest at the Chateau de Moncley, his wife's ancestral home.

A picture caption in The Arts on Saturday with the continuation of a music review about ''Siegfried'' and ''Götterdämmerung,'' at the Lincoln Center Festival, misidentified the characters in the foreground. They are the Rhinemaidens, not the Norns (the daughters of Erda, the earth goddess).

SILANO--Louis. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of PB mourn the passing of Louis G. Silano, Senior Vice President and Technical Director for Structures. Lou passed away on July 24, at the age of 80. He served on many notable bridges and tunnels in the United States; his engineering acumen was recognized by the American Society of Civil Engineers, which honored him with its Lifetime Achievement Award in Design in 2005. Lou served in the US Coast Guard during WWII and held both bachelor's and master's degrees in civil engineering from Columbia University. He joined PB in 1951 and retired in January 2007 after 55 years as the longest-serving employee in PB's history. He was truly one of a kind and his passing leaves a void that no one can fill. We extend our sympathies to Lou's wife, Jacqueline, and to his entire family. Thomas J. O'Neill, Chairman and CEO PB

The Archizoom chair ($1,525), below, a re-issue of a 1979 original, is an unusually inviting piece for the Italian design association of the same name that created it. Archizoom, which formed in Florence in 1966, was known for its antidesign stance and the exhibitions of radical architecture its members took part in, in Italy in the late '60s and at MoMA in 1972. The group's most famous piece was the uncomfortable-looking 1968 Mies armchair and footrest, which had a chrome frame and a latex sling, and poked fun at functionalism. The decidedly comfy Archizoom is chrome with hand-stitched leather in black or Russian Red, below; a swivel-base version is also available. At M2L, 215 East 58th Street (Third Avenue), (800) 319-8222 or m2lcollection.com. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

An article in Business Day yesterday about the introduction of an environmentally themed credit card by General Electric included incorrect information from the company about the amount of carbon emissions that a typical consumer is responsible for each year. It is 10 metric tons of carbon, not 10,000 metric tons.

REVASCH--David. Passed away in the early morning hours of August 23rd at the age of 71. Born in Rabat, Morocco, his Manhattan-based International Law practice took him to France, Africa, Switzerland, Belgium, England, Italy, Israel and Russia. David was regularly sought out for advice and counsel. Where others caused problems, David solved them, and provided a sense of safety and security to all those around him. He was the rock of his family and his untimely passing leaves behind a huge void in all our hearts. David had a zest for life, a joke for every occasion, and a style that was all his own. He cut a dashing figure in his signature fedora, cigar, and bowtie. And his law office was lavishly filled with rare and unique artworks, many of which were collected as gifts from people he helped around the world. A profoundly spiritual man, with complete and utter faith in God, he davvened daily at the Chabad of Midtown Manhattan, was a member of Orach Chaim, and supported countless shuls throughout his many travels. Following a memorial service in New York on August 23, David was laid to rest in the esteemed Ponovich cemetery in B'nei Brak, Israel just moments before Shabbos August 24, alongside his father Asher and mother Aliza. He is survived by wife Jane, daughter Abigail, son-in-law Eric, and grandson Ezekiel (four months), as well as sisters Margalit, Ruti, Shoshana, Devorah, and brothers Yossi, Shalom and Shmuel. We will hold him in our hearts forever. He gave us joy words cannot express. REVASCH--David. A kind, brilliant and generous friend to all who knew him. He was a giant of a man with a beautiful smile and always giving great advice to all of us in need of a trustworthy friend. David, rest in Zion. Shalom. Murray A. Wilson REVASCH--David. Dearest daddy, the bond we shared was truly the most cherished and special bond a father and daughter can have. The only comfort I take is that you passed away as you lived: swiftly, and with a first class trip to heaven, just in time for Shabbos with the angels. I will love you always. Abigail

A ''What's On Tonight'' television listing on Tuesday about ''Into Alaska With Jeff Corwin,'' on the Travel Channel, referred incorrectly to Alaska. It was the 49th state admitted to the union -- not the 50th, which was Hawaii.

BRAWER--Charlotte, 91, died comfortably on July 20, 2007, in Cambridge, MA, after living for many years in Manhattan. She was the widow of Henry I. Brawer of Paterson, NJ, and was later married to Jack Kaplowitz of Passaic, NJ, from whom she was subsequently divorced. She was a mother and grandmother, and for many years, a stepmother. As a saleswoman for First Investors Corp., she was among the first women to enter the world of finance and one of the first to sell mutual funds. She was active in fund raising for Planned Parenthood. a member of the board of the NY Society for Ethical Culture and an enthusiastic member of QUEST, a community for lifelong learning. She will be remembered for her strength, intelligence, and generosity. A memorial service will be held at the NY Society for Ethical Culture at a future date.

FARBER--Lillian. Beloved mother, cherished life-partner, devoted sister, aunt, sister - in - law, mother - in - law, grandmother and dear friend, Lillian Farber died on July 23rd, 2007, just two weeks shy of her 87th birthday. She possessed a world-class mind. A passionate lifelong reader, who absorbed the printed word at a speed frightening to anyone who saw her read a page, she was a mesmerizing conversationalist insightful, curious, perceptive, and devilish with a self-deprecating wit. She was also a beauty, and a dynamo. Social justice and politics energized her: in the mid-1950's, while raising four children, she spearheaded a campaign to strengthen the Democratic Party in Westchester County by running twice as the Democratic candidate for a seat on the town council of Greenburgh, then a heavily Republican enclave. She helped lead a successful fight to integrate the Hartsdale public schools, was an activist in the League of Women Voters, and a leader in the Brandeis National Women's Committee, a group dedicated to raising funds for the young university's libraries. Having graduated from NYU in three years, she went back to school in the mid-1960's, obtaining a Master's degree from Sarah Lawrence College in sociology in 1966, becoming director of the college's Upward Bound program (an intensive academic program for inner-city high school students), and then Dean of Student Services. In the mid-1970's, Lillian moved to Newfane, Vermont. There, she was vice president of Zone VI Studios, a manufacturer of photographic equipment. While helping to build and run the company, she found time to devote herself to local political campaigns in Vermont, to serve on the Vermont Council of the Arts, to chair the board of the Moore Free Library in Newfane, to officiate at civil unions and marriages as a justice of the peace, and, finally, to serve on the board of trustees of Marlboro College, an institution whose humanistic values she cherished. With a sense of adventure and mission, Lillian took on the role of chair of the Marlboro trustees' finance committee. She was fearless approaching potential donors, and unfailingly persuasive. Three Marlboro presidents, as well as members of the faculty and staff, counted on her for her counsel and foresight. She joined the board of trustees in 1982, served four years as chair in the 1990's, and became a member emeritus in May 2005. Lillian had an artists eye for photography: she built a distinguished collection that included works of Fred Picker, Paul Strand, Eugene Atget, Edward Weston, Alfred Steiglitz, Dorothea Lange, and Paul Caponigro, among others. In 2006, she donated the collection to Marlboro College. Her beloved son, Robert, who predeceased her, was a noted painter. Sister of the late Natalie Steinbock, she is survived by her life-partner, Bern Friedelson; children Lindy Linder, Peggy Farber, and Felicia and Charles Gervais; a sister, Florence Isbell; four grandchildren, Liza and Luke Linder and Benjamin and Samuel Jacoff; beloved nieces, nephew, and brothers-in-law; and dear ones, Susan Friedelson and Lori Schreiner. In lieu of flowers, donations to Marlboro College and the A.C.L.U.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about performances of Shakespeare in the suburbs misidentified the stage manager for Trilogy Repertory Company's production of ''The Taming of the Shrew'' in Basking Ridge, N.J. He is Jared Forsythe -- not Christian Winans, who played Pedant, as the article noted. Also, a picture caption misstated the profession of Hank Barre, one of the actors, in some copies. He is a financial adviser, not a drama coach.

HANSEN--Stephen C., passed away peacefully at 67 on August 21st. Mr. Hansen recently retired from his position as Chairman and CEO of Dollar Bank, which recently became the largest, free-standing mutual bank in the country. He led the institution to unprecedented growth and diversity over 34 years, while maintaining the banks mutuality and independence to benefit its customers and communities. Mr. Hansen was born and raised in New York City and graduated from The Buckley School, St. Paul's School, Princeton University, and the University of Virginia School of Law. He began his career as a member of the New York Bar but soon determined to become more involved in the social and economic aspects of our country. Prior to moving to Pittsburgh and Dollar Bank, he was one of the youngest elected members to the New York State legislator, representing the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He followed this with positions as advisor to the U.S. Secretary of HUD, Special Assistant to the Under Secretary of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and Special Assistant to the Chairman of the FDIC. Mr. Hansen was heavily involved in the community through his participation on numerous boards, including the Cleveland Federal Reserve, the Carnegie Institute, and Pittsburgh's public broadcasting (WQED). He was Chairman of the Board for the American Respiratory Alliance and the Regional Industrial Development Corporation (RIDC) of Western Pennsylvania. Stephen is survived by his wife Ethel Olmsted Hansen, son Lee C. Hansen, daughter-inlaw Gretchen W. Hansen, two grandchildren Victoria A. and William L. Hansen, two nephews William P. Taft and Timothy E. Taft, and his aunt Barbara C. Emeny. Stephen will be interred in a family plot in Locust Valley, NY. A Memorial service will be held at the Fox Chapel Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh on Tuesday, August 28th at 11:00am and will be followed by a gathering for friends and family. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Boy and Girls Club of Western Pennsylvania, 5432 Butler Street, Pittsburgh, PA 15201-3096, (412) 782-5710

A front-page article on Sunday about the racial politics of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican presidential candidate, during his tenure as mayor of New York referred incorrectly in some copies to the object that white police officers used to sodomize a black man, Abner Louima, in a station house bathroom in 1997. It was a broomstick, not a toilet plunger. The article also gave an incorrect spelling at one point for the surname of a historian at Cooper Union who said Mr. Giuliani believed that crime was ''about behavior, not race.'' He is Fred Siegel, not Siegal. The article also referred incorrectly in some copies to Mr. Giuliani's approval rating of 7 percent among blacks after the shooting death of Patrick Dorismond, an unarmed black security guard killed by the police. That statistic was recorded in April 2000, not at year's end.

At the American Contract Bridge League's Summer North American Bridge Championships, the Von Zedtwitz Life Master Pairs title was won on Sunday by Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., and Zia Mahmood of New York. Surprisingly for someone who has won five world championships and numerous national titles, this was Martel's first three-day national pair victory. Martel and Zia finished one board ahead of Renee Mancuso of Los Angeles and Howard Weinstein of Sarasota, Fla. Third were Fred Stewart of Bloomington, N.Y., and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif. To win a big pair event requires good play and some luck. The winners were fortunate to get such a great result from the diagramed deal, but in part they earned their top.

LIPTON--Sidney. HIP Health Plan of New York and its Boards of Directors are deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Sidney Lipton, 93, devoted medical director of the Bay Ridge Medical Center in Brooklyn for more than 30 years. Dr. Lipton, who died on Thursday, August 23, was universally revered by colleagues and patients. A board-certified general surgeon and the winner of numerous awards, Dr. Lipton was chosen as an outstanding physician by Maimonides Hospital, where he served as an attending physician. A graduate of Columbia College and the NY Medical College, Dr. Lipton did his training at Beth Israel Hospital. He was extensively published in the field of general surgery and medical issues. Dr. Lipton was married for 45 years and is survived by his beloved wife, Greta; two daughters, Lynne Levitsky, M.D., and Barbara Chargaff; a son, A. Paul Bogaty, and five grandchildren and five greatgrandchildren. Two children, Diana Lipton, M.D., and Nina Bogaty, Ph.D., predeceased Dr. Lipton. Interment will be at Beth David Cemetery. Visiting hours at the Lipton home will take place on Monday, August 27 through Wednesday, August 29, 5-10 pm. Anthony L. Watson Chairman and C.E.O. HIP Health Plan of New York LIPTON--Sidney, M.D. The medical staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Sidney Lipton. Dr. Lipton was associated with the department of surgery at Maimonides for over 50 years. He was an eminent surgeon who helped make the department what it is today. He was a teacher par excellence. Dr. Lipton will be sorely missed by all his colleagues, patients and friends. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. W. Wexelman M.D., Pres S. Farber M.D., Pres Elect H. Wasserman M.D., Sect'y E. Fitzpatrick M.D., Treas LIPTON--Sidney, M.D. The Department of Surgery at Maimonides Medical Center, Brooklyn, New York, mourns the death of our dear friend, Dr. Sidney Lipton. He will be remembered as one of the founding surgeons of the Department. For generations, he mentored young surgeons and attendings and was a source of wisdom and inspiration to us all. He will always be remembered for his wry smile, his sense of humor, his energy and enthusiasm and most of all for his love and compassion for his patients. May he rest in peace.

The Shelburne Museum in Vermont, known for its 18th- and 19th-century folk art and 19th-century American paintings, is branching out into contemporary design. Those traveling north in the summer or fall may want to see ''Going Green: 20 Eco-Friendly Designs for a Healthier Life,'' a show of sustainable housewares and furnishings like the vine-and-steel Spoon lounge chair, above, that starts today. Other exhibitions on view include ''Chandelirious! The Dazzling World of Contemporary Chandeliers,'' ''Contemporary Vermont Quilts'' and ''Out of This World: Shaker Design Past, Present and Future.'' It is open through Oct. 28, on Route 7 in Shelburne, Vt. (seven miles south of Burlington). Information: (802) 985-3346 or shelburnemuseum.org.

WINOGRAD--Teddi. Born in 1919 and died peacefully August 21st, 2007, in her home in Beverly Hills, where she hosted the Great Mind Series featuring progressive luminaries. Adored by her children Marcy and Barry, by her wonderful grandchildren Ben, Gina, and Rachel, by her brother Ron, by her son-in-law Buddy, and by many friends.
