Peace activist Blase Bonpane will lead the services at Hillside Memorial Park, 6001 Centinela Ave., Los Angeles, 90045, on Sunday,August 26, 1 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the USC Andrus Gerontology Center, 3715 McClintock, Room 110, Los Angeles, California, 90089; Progressive Democrats of America, 4045 East Palm Lane Suite 4, Phoenix, AZ 85008; Palisadians for Peace, 934 Las Pulgas, Pacific Palisades, 90272.

A brief article in Science Times on Tuesday about a study of nurse-to-patient ratios in intensive care units misidentified the journal in which the research appeared. It was Critical Care -- not Critical Care Medicine, a competing journal.

MICHELSON--Ann R. (nee Richard). 99 years young. Beloved wife of Ben, beloved mother and mother-in-law to Allen and Roseann Michelson, Elinor and Morton Shaevel, grandmother to Brian, Lonni, Andrew, Karen and Holly, William, Amy, Robert, great-grandmother to Naomi, Gabriella, Benjamin and Lewis. She will be remembered with love.

SHAIR--Hortense Spitz. After a Long Battle at home with Alzheimer's, Horty made it to her 83rd Birthday on August 2. She quietly gave up 22 days later. Her beloved husband David was at her bedside, holding her hand to the last minute, just shy of their 60th anniversary on October 18th. Hortense went straight from High School to a job as a receptionist at the Neiman Marcus Buying office in New York. The ''Job'' became a lifetime career. 57 years later she retired in 1999 as the Director of the office. Executives throughout the organization learned to turn to Horty to help solve a wide variety of questions and problems. The late Stanley Marcus penned a six-paragraph letter when he learned of her impending departure. ''There are not many people in big or little organizations who have been so successful in administering a position and at the same time meeting the varied demands, requests and hopes of so many individuals.'' She cherished her many opportunities to assist him. A broad smile and a generous disposition were her trademarks. Too busy to have children, Horty filled the gap with nieces and nephews, and their offspring, plus numerous friends and business acquaintances. Sister Leah provided Bob and Wendy, who in turn brought forth grandnephew Lee. He called Hortense ''Aunt Hotty'' and achieved star status very early. Brother Morty produced David, Bill, Joyce and Susie and more grand nieces and nephews. Many personal and business friends are still at hand -Irene and Jerry and their children, also Gloria, Bill B. and his offspring, Ellie and children, Donald and Fran, Addie and Eddie, and celebrities Alvin Colt and Jerry Sorbara. Our Faithful aides Nicole, Prudence and Grace who helped her resist that terrible disease. David is hanging in tearfully, content that he could keep his darling by his side to the last second. We had a great time together! No flowers please. Contributions to The Alzheimer's Association would be worthy! Horty died as she lived, with dignity. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery on Thursday, October 18, at 2pm.

JOHNSON--Ernest ''Skip'', 64, of NYC and East Hampton. Retired Vice President, Bank of NY. MBA Wharton. Penn Club Charter Member. Mourned by family and devoted partner, Donald Bernstein. Memorial Service, Thursday, August 9, 2pm, All Souls Unitarian Society, 1157 Lexington Ave.

WEINER--Daniel Lee, M.D., 75, on July 2. He practiced plastic surgery in New York for more than 40 years. He served for many years as a Board member and Director of Medical Programs for the International Rescue Committee (IRC). In his last decade he co-founded two organizations that provided training and other assistance to medical professionals in Eastern Europe and other regions. His survivors, who treasure his memory, include three children, Rachel, Michael, and David, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held July 27, at 3:00, at the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, 15 W. 86th St., in New York. Donations in his memory may be made to the IRC, 122 E. 42nd St., New York 10168-1289.

SIGMUND--Moses, of New York, Florida and Randolph, Vermont, loving husband, father and grandfather, passed away on July 21, 2007 at his home in Vermont. He was born on September 11, 1907, the son of Moritz and Gazela Moses. Mr. Moses grew up and attended public school in New York, graduating from Brooklyn Law School in 1930. He was admitted to the bar in 1931 and practiced law continuously in New York for the next 75 years. He retired at the age of 98. His loyalty, generosity and dedication were reciprocated by his clients, to whom he acted not only as attorney, but also confidante, advisor and friend. Growing up, Mr. Moses was an enthusiastic stickball player, and played in and coached a variety of local baseball teams. In later years, he became an avid golfer and fisherman, and was a longtime member of Dellwood Country Club. On April 20, 1943, Mr. Moses married Elizabeth, who predeceased him on April 20, 2007. Survivors include his sister, Esther Moses, his daughter and son-in-law, Karen and Karl Miller, his grandchildren, Caitlin Miller and Aaron Moses Miller, his nephew Martin Friedman and wife Marilyn, and numerous other nephews and nieces.

KATZ--Jerome. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of our dedicated benefactor. Our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier, Michael Weisbrod, President Martin Berman, Chairman Seymour Siegel, Treasurer

GOODMAN--Carolyn. In spired by your extraordinary example of transforming grief for the benefit of others, we honor you, our dear, witty and beautiful friend, by continuing to fill our lives with love and generosity. The Fox Family

TURRELL--Richard H., Sr., 82, a retired senior vice president of Fiduciary Trust Company International of New York, died at his home in Tequesta, Florida, on August 22, 2007. Prior to residing in Tequesta, he lived with his family in Short Hills, New Jersey. Born on April 9, 1925, in Kingston, Pennsylvania, Mr. Turrell entered Cornell University in 1943 until drafted into the army, where he served with the U.S. Army Signal Corps in the Pacific Theatre from 1943 until 1946. Upon his return from service, Mr. Turrell attended Washington and Lee University, and he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and received a Bachelor of Science degree in Commerce in 1949. He was a member of Phi Delta Theta. Mr. Turrell began his business career with the Delaware, Lackawana & Western Coal Company in 1949 and was assistant secretary of Blue Coal Corp. in New York City from 1953 to 1958. He began a distinguished career in finance in 1958 when he joined Auchincloss, Parker & Redpath, a New York brokerage firm, as a registered representative. Mr. Turrell joined Fiduciary Trust in 1961 as a portfolio manager and was elected vice president in 1965, senior vice-president in 1968, and senior vice president and secretary in 1971. He served as secretary of the company for 13 years. After his retirement in 1994, he continued to serve as an advisor to many family trusts. Mr. Turrell had a lifelong interest in education. Long active in the affairs of Washington and Lee University, he served a term as president of the Alumni Association and was named a distinguished alumnus in 1986. He also served as president of his Class of 1943 at the Lawrenceville School. In 1980 Mr. Turrell was elected to the Board of Monmouth College and served as treasurer until 1988 and he was elected vice chairman of the Board. He became chairman in 1989 and served in that capacity until 1992. He received an Honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Monmouth in 1995. In recognition of his long service to the University, in 2007 he was named a Life Trustee Emeritus. He was also a member of the Board of Overseers of Simons Rock of Bard College, Great Barrington, Massachusetts, from 1968 through 1993. Active in community and civic affairs, Mr. Turrell served as a trustee of the Childrens Specialized Hospital Foundation, Mountainside, New Jersey, from 1989 to 1995 and was currently on the Board of Directors of Advocates for the Rights of the Challenged (ARC) in Martin County, Florida. In addition, he was an officer and director of the Kiwanis Club of Palm Beach and later its President in 2006. From 1973 to 1978 he was chairman of the Millburn/ Short Hills (New Jersey) Republican Committee and was currently active in Republican affairs in Martin County. Mr. Turrell was a member of Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, where he was named a governor in 1977. He was also a member of the Capitol Hill Club in Washington, D.C., and the Turtle Creek Club, Tequesta, Florida. He was a Mason at Irem Temple AAONMS and amember of the First Presbyterian Church of Tequesta, Florida. He was married to Sally Wolfe for 52 years, who died February 2007. He is survived by a son Richard, his wife Cynthia and their children Lauren and Brian of Hillsborough New Jersey, also a son David in Tequesta, Florida. A son Douglas predeceased him in 1993. Two brothers Henry and Edwin of Wyalusing, PA survive him. Memorial services will be held at Christ Church in Short Hills, Short Hills, New Jersey on September 21 at 11am and in Tequesta, Florida at the First Presbyterian Church on October 27 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, the family would sincerely appreciate memorial contributions to either ARC of Martin County, 2001 South Kanner Highway, Stuart, Florida, or Childrens Specialized Hospital Foundation, 150 New Providence Road, Mountainside, New Jersey 07092.

Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the University of Michigan Business School. ZANKEL--Robert Thomas. Tommy's untimely death is a tragic loss for us, and for all those who knew and loved him. Our hearts break for everyone in his family, for Sarah, and the many friends of all ages who will miss and mourn him. We will always cherish the wonderful and joyous memories of happy and sunny days. Mona and Carleton Dukess ZANKEL--Thomas. Iridian Asset Management LLC mourns the loss of Tom Zankel. Tom has been our colleague and friend for over 11 years and he will be profoundly missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with Tom's family and fiance. David L. Cohen Harold J. Levy Co-Chief Executive Officers ZANKEL--Thomas. The Society of Illustrators wishes to extend our deepest condolences to the Zankel family. ZANKEL--Tommy. My heart cries for Tommy and his brothers after hearing of Tommy's death. The 25th installment of ''Now That's What I Call Music!'' vaulted to No. 1 on the Billboard chart this week with sales of 223,000 copies in its debut, Nielsen SoundScan reported. Carrying hits from Justin Timberlake and Carrie Underwood, among others, it is the 12th album in the compilation series, including the last four, to reach the top of the chart. News was also made in the No. 5 spot, where ''Coco'' (Universal Republic), the debut album of Colbie Caillat, who was discovered on MySpace, chalked up 51,000 sales in its first week. In between came Miley Cyrus's double-disc Disney set, ''Hannah Montana 2 (Soundtrack)/Meet Miley Cyrus,'' rising one notch this week to No. 2 on sales of 113,000 copies. T.I.'s ''T.I. vs. T.I.P.'' (Grand Hustle/Atlantic), which led the chart the previous two weeks, dipped to third place with 94,000 sales. The soundtrack to ''Hairspray,'' buoyed by the opening of the film, climbed to 4th place from 20th on sales of 72,000, a 95 percent increase.

GROSSMAN--Charles. Forest City mourns the passing of Charlie Grossman. Charlie, Managing Director of ING Clarion Partners, was a leader in the industry, a true professional and an extraordinary gentleman. He will be missed by his friends at Forest City Ratner Companies and Forest City Enterprises.

THE differences between men and women have long fueled bad jokes and self-help books, but recently they have spurred something less obvious: a wave of female-specific camping gear. Women's sleeping bags are particularly popular. Sales almost doubled from 2004 to 2006, according to the Leisure Trends Group, a market-research company. ''Before, if you bought a piece of gear that was for a woman, it was a downsized men's version and was painted pink,'' said Kristine Carey, the brand manager for Sierra Designs. These days, some makers offer substantial differences that they assume women want: more insulation for cold feet, wider hip space and less room in the shoulders for drafts. But women taller than 5-foot-9, beware: bags for women tend to be shorter than unisex ones.

I've been out car shopping, which is always a mind-expanding experience, and I laughed softly to myself when last night's salesman said to me (proudly) that he had previously been a mortician. How do you go from the dead to a V-8, and what face do you put on for the world? Of course the car I desire is not the one I probably should have. The car I desire is a Mustang GT. The Shelby is OUT of the question. My son is duly shocked that Mom wants a hot car. It's a question, I know, of image. I think he equates the Mustang with spoiled prep schoolers. Frankly, I just like the soothing rumble it makes as I blow into Food Town. I recognize the tug of an unplayed (or underplayed) dream much more than an image thing. And on that note, at the height of the American summer, I offer y'all my favorite peach pie recipe

While many political junkies feel that foreign policy is perhaps Hillary Clinton's Achilles heel with Democratic primary voters, she seems to have decided to make it the centerpiece of her attacks on Barack Obama. The Times reports that the latest salvoes "stemmed from their answers at a debate Monday involving the circumstances under which each as president might meet with leaders of Syria, Cuba and Venezuela, but it has broadened into a debate over whether the nation needs experience or a fresh approach on the world stage."

A federal judge on Friday sentenced Qwest Communications' former chief executive, Joseph P. Nacchio, to six years in prison for his insider-trading conviction. Judge Edward Nottingham of United States District Court also ordered Mr. Nacchio to forfeit $52 million in assets he gained in illegal stock sales, imposed a maximum $19 million fine and ordered him to serve two years' probation after serving his sentence.

Sowood Capital Management, a $3 billion hedge fund that invests in stocks and bonds, is down 10 percent for the year, battered by credit markets that have hedge funds, their investors and their lenders on edge, The New York Times reported. The fund was started in 2004 by Jeffrey B. Larson and Stuart Porter, both of whom worked for the Harvard Management Company, the university's massive endowment.

It has already become a Wall Street mantra: Thursday's stock-market slump was driven in part by the widespread belief -- or perhaps "panic" is a better word -- that tightening credit markets will put a stop to the leveraged-buyout boom. The New York Times and DealBook quoted Richard Bernstein, Merrill Lynch's chief investment strategist, saying that the "rationing of credit means equity investors should discontinue their speculation regarding takeovers and L.B.O.s." The Wall Street Journal declared that the takeover boom, which had been an "important underpinning to the market," might now be "losing its power."

Magnus Carlsen of Norway and Alexander Onischuk of the United States are tied for the lead with three points after four rounds of the Biel International Chess Festival in Switzerland. While not considered one of the elite tournaments on the calendar (like Linares or Corus), Biel is still quite strong and this year has attracted four of the world's top 20 players, including Teimour Radjabov, No. 9, Alexander Grischuk, No. 14, Carlsen, No. 17, and Judit Polgar, No. 19. Only one of the 10 players, Yannick Pelletier, the host country's representative, is not among the top 100.

Thomas H. Lee Partners said on Friday that it was suing Mayer Brown Rowe & Maw over the law firm's role in the Refco fraud case. The private equity firm said in documents that Mayer Brown misled it over the state of Refco, formerly one of the world's biggest commodities firms.

Medtronic, a maker of medical devices, said Friday that it would buy Kyphon for $3.9 billion to expand its spinal treatment business. Its offer of $71 a share in cash represented a 32 percent premium to Kyphon's closing stock price Thursday.

Cadbury Schweppes, the world's largest confectionery company, said it is extending the deadline for selling its United States beverages unit, becoming one of the first companies to delay a deal because of "extreme volatility" in debt markets.

Seven For All Mankind, the seven-year-old Los Angeles denim company that helped usher in the era of $200 designer jeans, was sold Thursday to the VF Corporation for $775 million.

Owens Corning Sales said Friday it is buying Saint-Gobain's glass reinforcement and composites division for $640 million. The deal involves 20 plants, including 12 glass fiber reinforcement facilities, six fabrics plants and two plants that produce both reinforcements and fabrics and includes a specialty fabrics business that supports weaving and knitting operations of glass fiber.

Nordstrom said Thursday that it had agreed to sell its Faconnable brand to the M1 Group, a family-owned company based in Lebanon, for $210 million to focus on its main business, high-end department stores. As part of the agreement with M1, Nordstrom said it would continue to buy Faconnable merchandise for at least the next three years and will still offer the label in its stores.

Bank of America said on Thursday it asked a Manhattan federal judge to dismiss its lawsuit against ABN Amro seeking to block the Dutch bank from trying to sell its LaSalle Bank unit to other buyers.

Whole Foods Market is expected to report a decline in third-quarter profit next week, as acquisition worries, concerns about growth momentum, and news of its chief executive's anonymous postings on Internet chat forums weigh on the natural-foods grocer.

On the heels of its aQuantive purchase, Microsoft on Thursday announced it has bought AdECN, a company that is a technology platform for buying and selling display advertising. Santander, Spain's largest bank, posted a 39 percent increase in first-half profit, helped by the sale of its stake in an Italian bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, and cost controls. A Suffolk police vehicle crashed head-on with a car driven by a Long Island man on Wednesday night in Mount Sinai, killing the man, the Suffolk police said last night. Officer Robert Falisi received a call about 9:45 p.m. that motorcycles were speeding in the Miller Place area, and he saw some of the motorcycles going west in nearby Mount Sinai, the police said. Officer Falisi, who activated his lights to pursue them, crashed into a 1993 Ford Mustang at the intersection of Route 347 and Hallock Avenue. The Mustang’s driver, Gabriel Bergianti, 27, of Port Jefferson, was taken to Mather Memorial Hospital, where he was declared dead. Officer Falisi was taken to St. Charles Hospital for cuts and other minor injuries. He was treated and released. The police are investigating.

The carrier also said it had invested heavily this quarter in improving its operations, as it reported a 13.6 percent drop in second-quarter earnings.
Strong overseas demand helped offset high energy costs, leading the chemical maker to a better-than-expected second quarter.
Raytheon said Thursdaythat second-quarter net profit rose sharply, helped by a one-time gain from the sale of its aircraft unit and strong revenue from its missiles and military electronics units.
The 3M Company said it saw strong second-quarter performances across all its businesses.
Federal regulators said Thursday the failed hedge fund Amaranth Advisors and two traders accused of manipulation of natural gas markets face $291 million in penalties.

A front-page article yesterday about coming films from Hollywood that raise questions about the Iraq war erroneously attributed an award to Paul Haggis, the writer and director of a new Iraq-related film, “In the Valley of Elah.” Although Mr. Haggis, who shared two Oscars for “Crash,” was nominated for an Oscar for the screenplay of “Million Dollar Baby,” he did not win.
James Blake needed only 66 minutes to beat Ricardo Mello, 6-4, 6-2, and advance to the quarterfinals of the Indianapolis Tennis Championships.
Jolanda Ceplak of Slovenia, the 800-meter indoor world record holder, has been suspended after testing positive for the blood-booster EPO.
Ante Razov had a goal and an assist in Chivas USA’s 2-0 victory against the Red Bulls on Thursday night.

Plentiful rain throughout Texas the past year led weather officials to declare an end to drought conditions across the state for the first time in at least a decade. “We’ve gotten so much rain this year we’ve pretty much made up for the past few years’ drought conditions in several areas of the state,” said John Nielsen-Gammon, the state’s climatologist. Only isolated areas in the northern Panhandle, far West Texas and along the eastern margins of the state are still below normal, Mr. Nielsen-Gammon said. Heavy rains have caused flooding in several parts of the state since mid-June. At least 16 people have died, and property damage has been widespread. Numerous rivers remain at or above flood level.

A trail of pennies from a burning taxi cab led the authorities to the home of a teenager, who is charged in the killing of the cab’s driver. The driver, Jagit Singh, had been working the night shift on July 10 when a caller reported seeing a cab in flames and rolling backward down a street around 2:30 a.m., Detective Eleanor R. Broggi, of the King County Sheriff’s Office, wrote in an affidavit. Mr. Singh was found dead with two gunshots to the back of his head. Nearby, a trail of pennies led up the driveway of a home, Detective Broggi wrote. The teenager, Earnest L. Collins, 18, lived at the home, near Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, and a search turned up clothing with burn marks, investigators said. Mr. Collins was arrested in Chicago on Monday and is charged with murder.
Santander, the largest bank in Spain, posted a 39 percent increase in first-half profit, helped by the sale of its stake in an Italian bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, and cost controls.

Problems at Airbus, including the cost of redesigning the midrange A350 jet and the delayed A380 superjumbo aircraft, caused second-quarter profits at the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company to slump 85 percent, the company said.

Canon, the world’s biggest maker of digital cameras, said second-quarter profit rose 17 percent as a weaker yen increased the value of earnings from its EOS and PowerShot models and its multifunction photocopiers.
AstraZeneca said it would more than double previously planned job cuts as it reported that quarterly profit fell 12.5 percent.

Two people were killed and four others were injured in an explosion at the company that developed SpaceShipOne, the first privately financed human spacecraft. Roberto Figueroa, a spokesman for the Kern County fire department, said a hazardous materials team was investigating the cause of the explosion at Scaled Composites, the Mojave, Calif., company founded by Burt Rutan, a renowned aircraft designer. Mr. Rutan, above, said the explosion at the test facility involved nitrous oxide, which is used in the engine for SpaceShipOne and in SpaceShipTwo, the successor craft being designed for Virgin Galactic, Sir Richard Branson’s space tourism venture. Mr. Rutan was not at the site when the blast occurred, and said he was rushing back to his company. “It’s not a good day,” he said. “This looks like the equivalent of the Apollo 1 fire here.”.

Three white former Milwaukee police officers were convicted of beating a biracial man outside a party in October 2004 and violating his civil rights, but a suspended officer was acquitted in the case. Federal prosecutors said the four were part of a group of off-duty officers who beat the man, Frank Jude Jr., left, in October 2004 outside a housewarming party for one of the officers. The jury, which included one black man, convicted the three former officers, Jon Bartlett, 35, Daniel Masarik, 27, and Andrew Spengler, 28, of violating Mr. Jude’s civil rights and conspiring to assault him while acting as officers. Each faces up to 20 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. The other officer, Ryan Packard, 27, was acquitted of both charges.

Port clerks and their employers at the Ports of Long Beach and Los Angeles, the nation’s largest port complex, tentatively agreed on a new contract. The deal, between shippers and terminal operators and the Office Clerical Unit, Local 63, of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union came after an impasse in talks was declared late Tuesday. Under the tentative deal, the workers will receive a wage increase of 7 percent over the three-year contract. The employers also agreed to pay $3.4 million toward establishing a trust fund to manage the employees’ health and welfare and pensions plans. The 15,000-member International Longshore and Warehouse Union had indicated that longshoremen would honor picket lines if the roughly 750 clerical workers went on strike. The move could have effectively stopped the loading and unloading of cargo at the ports.

The State Supreme Court ruled that cities can no longer seize automobiles whose drivers are arrested for allegedly buying drugs or soliciting prostitutes. The ruling overturns the laws of more than two dozen cities that allowed police to seize an automobile immediately after the driver’s arrest. The 4-to-3 ruling said only state law can mete out punishment for drug and prostitution offenses and that without authorization from the California Legislature, cities cannot pass seizure ordinances that are harsher than state and federal laws. Mark Clausen, a lawyer, whose suit against the City of Stockton led to the ruling, has filed several related lawsuits throughout the state on behalf of taxpayers who allege the seizure laws are unconstitutional.

Michael B. Nifong, the former Durham County district attorney, acknowledged that “there is no credible evidence” that three Duke lacrosse players committed any of the crimes he accused them of more than a year ago, offering for the first time a complete and unqualified apology. “We all need to heal,” Mr. Nifong said. “It is my hope we can start this process today.” Mr. Nifong’s apology came as a judge began considering whether to hold him in criminal contempt of court for his handling of the case, which began in the spring of 2006. The judge, W. Osmond Smith III of Superior Court, has already concluded there is probable cause to believe Mr. Nifong “willfully and intentionally made false statements of material fact” to the court during a hearing last fall. Mr. Nifong could face up to 30 days in jail.

A top deputy to the disgraced former state comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, and his successor resigned his post on Tuesday, but a spokesman said the move was unrelated to an ongoing investigation of the comptroller’s office.

A man suspected of sexually assaulting three women since mid-June in the East Village and Lower East Side was arrested Wednesday after the boyfriend of one victim spotted the suspect and dialed 911, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Asuncion Jesus-Garcia, 20, of Manhattan, is facing charges of sex abuse, attempted rape, robbery and other charges in the attacks, which took place on June 12, July 7 and July 13, all around 4 a.m., the police said. Investigators are trying to determine whether the man is responsible for other similar assaults, the police said, notably that of a 20-year-old woman on July 19 in the East Village. In the July 13 case, the victim’s boyfriend interrupted the attack by breaking a window to get into a hallway where it was occurring, but the suspect ran past him, said Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly. At 1 p.m. Wednesday, the boyfriend saw the same man at 10th Street and Avenue A, said Mr. Kelly. Officers arrived within minutes and arrested Mr. Jesus-Garcia, who works in a restaurant at First Avenue and East 11th Street, the police said.
The double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius, who wants to race in the Olympics, will work with track and field’s world governing body to ensure that he does not have an unfair advantage.

New York City and the police captains union announced a tentative agreement yesterday that would increase pay by 37 percent over eight years and bring the maximum base salary for the Police Department’s top officers to $141,933 at the end of the contract, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The $65 million deal, which is retroactive to November 2003 and runs through March 2012, is the longest labor contract the city has ever negotiated, the mayor said, and breaks an impasse that appeared headed for arbitration. The deal must still be approved by the roughly 700 members of the Captains Endowment Association, which includes captains, inspectors, deputy chiefs and police surgeons. Mr. Bloomberg said the deal comports with the terms set in recent contract agreements with firefighters and police sergeants. It could also help set the terms in arbitration talks with the largest police union, the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association.

A man who stopped to help the driver of a crashed car near the Long Island Expressway temporarily lost his vehicle yesterday when the other driver leaped into it and sped away, the Suffolk County police said. About 1 a.m., the police spotted a stolen 2007 Chevrolet Corvette speeding on the expressway; the vehicle rear-ended another car near Exit 59, then left the expressway and flipped over near Exit 53. James Scarabino, 30, of Lake Ronkonkoma, who was driving by, stopped to help, but the Corvette’s driver pushed him aside, jumped into Mr. Scarabino’s 1994 Chrysler LHS and drove away, the police said. Mr. Scarabino’s car was found later at a gas station on Route 25 and East Deer Park Road in Huntington, the police said. The other driver was still at large last night, the police said.

A state workers union leader who once dated Gov. Jon S. Corzine can participate in a court argument on whether e-mail messages between her and Mr. Corzine should be made public, a judge ruled yesterday. Tom Wilson, the head of the state Republican Party, wanted to see if the messages show whether the relationship between Mr. Corzine, a Democrat, and the union leader, Carla Katz, affected recent state contract talks. Mr. Wilson had argued that Ms. Katz has no privacy rights regarding the communications, but yesterday, Judge Paul Innes of State Supreme Court ruled that Ms. Katz can intervene in a lawsuit that Mr. Wilson filed seeking the release of the messages.

An appeals court yesterday threw out a $10.75 million judgment against the city in a case involving a man who was paralyzed from the waist down after being shot by a city police officer in 1988. The man, Darryl Barnes, was awarded $51 million after a 2003 trial; the amount was later reduced by the judge to $10.75 million. But yesterday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled that the trial judge had improperly excused Mr. Barnes from testifying because he was mentally disabled, even though he had been found competent at an earlier hearing. Instead, the court allowed pretrial testimony from Mr. Barnes to be read. The court ruled that this deprived the city of its right to cross-examine him. Mr. Barnes’s lawyer, Robert M. Simels, said yesterday that he would appeal.
Ready’s Image gave the trainer Todd Pletcher his first stakes victory of the meet when he captured the Sanford Stakes by four lengths at Saratoga Race Course.

A pilot program to begin this fall will pay youths nearing the end of foster care up to $2,000 for saving up to $1,000 and completing certain financial training, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. The $1 million program is intended to ease the transition from foster care at 21 and will create individual development accounts at Citibank. Participants could begin making contributions as early as 16 and could use the accumulated savings plus the 2-to-1 matching funds for housing, education or vocational training. The program, supported by both public and private money, is modeled on similar efforts in other cities and is to run for five years and serve 450 youths.

A military report has concluded that flares dropped by a National Guard pilot at an altitude that was too low and when conditions were dry were to blame for a fire that destroyed more than 17,000 acres of Pine Barrens in May, the Air Force announced yesterday. The report, by a military accident review board, also found that dry conditions around the Warren Grove Gunnery Range in Little Egg Harbor Township had not been adequately communicated to everyone involved in the aircraft training exercise. The May 15 fire destroyed four homes and damaged 37. Two serious injuries were reported. The military has promised to reimburse those affected by the fire; about 2,000 people have filed claims.
Nick Faldo shot a three-under-par 68 for a share of the first-round lead at the Senior British Open at Muirfield in Gullane, Scotland.
Pat Hurst and Brittany Lincicome of the United States and Eun-hee Ji of South Korea each shot a six-under-par 66 to share the lead after the first round of the Evian Masters.
A son of Philadelphia Eagles Coach Andy Reid has opted to go to trial on drug and weapons charges, while another pleaded guilty to drug offenses.

The lawyer for former Mayor Philip A. Giordano asked a federal judge yesterday to reduce the 37-year prison sentence he received after a 2003 conviction in connection with the sexual abuse of two young girls. Judge Alan H. Nevas of Federal District Court did not rule on the request, although he harshly noted that Mr. Giordano had inflicted lasting trauma on the girls. Mr. Giordano, who served three terms in office, was convicted of violating the girls’ civil rights by paying a prostitute to bring them to him for sexual encounters when they were 8 and 10. He faces resentencing because federal sentencing guidelines have been made advisory rather than mandatory.

For the second time this month, the restaurateur Jean-Georges Vongerichten, left, has been sued over workers’ wages and the division of tips. The allegations, in a lawsuit filed yesterday in Federal District Court, involve Mr. Vongerichten’s flagship restaurant, Jean-Georges, at 1 Columbus Circle, as well as Spice Market, on West 13th Street near Ninth Avenue, and Perry Street, near Washington Street. Like the earlier lawsuit, filed on July 9 by workers from Mr. Vongerichten’s V Steakhouse, which closed in 2005, the lawsuit says the restaurants improperly divided tips among managers as well as workers. It also says the workers were paid less than the minimum wage. Calls to Mr. Vongerichten’s office were not returned yesterday.
The N.F.L. denied a request by the suspended cornerback Pacman Jones to join the Tennessee Titans in training camp.
Robert Mueller’s testimony about an argument over an N.S.A. program was a blow to the attorney general.
Giants players will report to training camp on Friday carrying many more questions and far less swagger than they toted last season.
A workshop for low-income students teaches them that their life experiences can be as powerful as stellar grades.
The presidential candidate would use the money to provide tax-free savings accounts and expanded tax credits for lower-income workers.
A judge presiding over a lawsuit said he would rule Friday whether to reveal the names of major league baseball players implicated in performance-enhancing drugs in government documents.
The plan would help India build a nuclear fuel repository and find alternative sources of nuclear fuel.
VF’s acquisitions of Seven for All Mankind and Lucy Activewear for a combined $885 million are intended to add new contemporary labels to brands including Wrangler and The North Face.
The two leading Democratic presidential candidates are openly criticizing each other for the first time, stretching the exercise out all week.

President Vladimir V. Putin signed amendments to a law on extremism that would bolster measures officials have used to ban literature and put pressure on opposition politicians. The amendments expand the definition of extremism to include, among other things, hooliganism that is committed for political or ideological reasons, according to the Kremlin Web site, a formulation critics say will allow the authorities to impose long prison sentences on people engaged in civil disobedience.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, the 72-year-old former Panamanian Army general and dictator, appeared in court in Miami to fight a plan to extradite him to France.
The government has donated $2.5 million of Zambian-grown maize that will feed hundreds of thousands of needy Zambians through September.

An explosion at a weapons depot in the north killed at least 15 soldiers and wounded 50 others, the official news agency SANA reported. It said that the blast could be heard for miles and was a result of a heat wave that has gripped the country and that the authorities had dismissed the possibility of sabotage.

Msgr. Georg Gänswein, Pope Benedict XVI’s secretary and close adviser, warned of the Islamization of Europe and stressed the need for the Continent’s Christian roots not to be ignored. In comments released in advance of an interview to be published today in the German weekly Süeddeutsche Magazin, he said: “Attempts to Islamize the West cannot be denied. The danger for the identity of Europe that is connected with it should not be ignored out of a wrongly understood respectfulness.” He also defended a speech Benedict gave last year linking Islam and violence, saying it was an attempt by the pope to “act against a certain naïveté.”.

A London jury convicted Bachan Athwal, a 70-year-old grandmother of 16, of arranging the murder of her daughter-in-law because she was having an affair and wanted a divorce. Mrs. Athwal, left, faces life in prison in the killing of Surjit Athwal, 27. Her 43-year-old son, whom Surjit married when she was 16, was also convicted. All lived in West London. Prosecutors said that after Mrs. Athwal learned Surjit was having an affair with a co-worker, they went on a trip to a family wedding in India in 1998; Surjit never returned. Prosecutors said Mrs. Athwal later boasted that she had arranged for her brother to strangle Surjit and throw her body into a river. Prosecutors described Mrs. Athwal as the dominant figure in her large Sikh family and said she considered Surjit’s affair a disgrace. Last week, a London judge gave life sentences to the father and uncle of a 20-year-old Kurdish woman who was killed in 2006 because the men disapproved of her boyfriend.
Four rare mountain gorillas, a silverback male and three females, were shot dead in the Virunga National Park on Sunday.

Military talks between generals of the two Koreas to ease tensions on the cold war’s last frontier broke down in acrimony over a nautical border set more than a half century ago. The North called the three-day meeting pointless. “We’ve come to a conclusion that we don’t need these fruitless talks any more,” said Lt. Gen. Kim Yong-chol, the head of the North Korean delegation.

The police in France detained three suspected members of the Basque paramilitary group ETA, and Spain’s Interior Ministry identified one as the group’s suspected logistics chief, Juan Cruz Maiza Artola, left. “Everyone can understand that an organization that loses the head of its logistical operations has suffered a heavy loss, and for that reason I have to say this has been a very important operation,” said the Spanish interior minister, Alfredo Pérez Rubalcaba. A total of 22 ETA suspects have been arrested since June 5, the ministry said.

Leszek Wojcik, a bus driver in Slupsk, has been fired for sending 38,000 text messages on his company cellphone in a losing effort to win a contest jackpot, a spokesman said. He ran up a tab of $34,000 with his text messages while trying to win $36,000. He told a television station that he wanted to buy a second car with his possible winnings. “Now I’m without work,” he said.

Taking his message of fare increases and a dire financial outlook directly to straphangers yesterday morning, Elliot G. Sander, the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, passed out leaflets on a subway platform at Grand Central Terminal.
Bush administration officials are expressing increasing anger at what they say has been Saudi Arabia’s counterproductive role in the Iraq war.
New tools are allowing people with minimal skills to do what only professional mapmakers were able to do before.
BMW is opening a lavish, cathedral-like showroom in Munich to showcase its history and to deliver vehicles, bathed in a spotlight and rotating on a turntable, to their new owners.
The case could be another setback for gene therapy, a field with a troubled history and numerous treatment failures.
A federal jury found that Drummond, an Alabama-based coal company, was not liable for the deaths of three union leaders at its mine near La Loma, Colombia, in 2001.
By 2010, Rose H. Harvey intends that as many as 300 underachieving New York City schoolyards will morph into vibrant outdoor playgrounds.
The rationing of credit led investors Thursday to erase the takeover premiums that had propped up share prices for dozens of companies that had been considered buyout targets.
More than a dozen current and former lawmakers are under scrutiny in cases involving their work on Capitol Hill.
Amgen beat Wall Street expectations despite reporting slow revenue growth, while Bristol-Myers Squibb raised its 2007 outlook.
The European Court of Human Rights issued an unusually harsh rebuke of the Russian government on Thursday.

In a surprise move, the ailing clothing giant picked Glenn Murphy, the former head of Canada’s largest drugstore chain, as its new C.E.O., despite promises it would find a seasoned clothing executive.
New home sales fell in June by 6.6 percent, the largest amount in five months, a decline that was more than triple what had been expected.
The largest bottler of Coca-Cola drinks posted beat Wall Street expectations in the second quarter, despite a 20 percent fall in net income.
A family softball game was a welcome break for Barry Bonds, mainly because he did not have to hit — or think about hitting.

The caseworkers, immigration lawyers and resettlement specialists at the International Rescue Committee spend their days helping refugees flee their troubled homes and make their way to the United States.
The question facing investors now is whether the market is just having a bad week or starting to turn the corner toward a bearish slump.
The burglary victims said they were told that their cases were linked to a home invasion that ended in the murder of a doctor’s wife and her two daughters in Cheshire, Conn.
The lofty expectations at Southern California come more from the defensive side, a change for a program that has built its recent reputation on flashy offensive players.
It remains a mystery how the pilots of a small jet chose the wrong runway moments before a crash that killed 49 people, federal investigators said Thursday.
Steve Spurrier is entering his third season as the coach at South Carolina, and his belief that the Gamecocks could become a force in the SEC is nearing a collision with reality.
A meeting intended to help develop a strategy for settling the growing crisis of Iraqi refugees stopped short of proposing any concrete solutions.
The program is similar to others adopted by several states that are trying to address the fallout from the aggressive home loans made during the recent housing boom.
Investigators reported “ ‘heavy use of alcohol’ by astronauts” within 12 hours of flying.
Several residents said the collapse of a retaining wall on the Upper West Side brought their frustrations with the site to a boiling point.
Arlen Specter is something of a serial breaker of the unspoken rules aboard Air Force One.
The results were in contrast with those of Royal Dutch Shell, which reported a strong jump in quarterly earnings.
A veterans’ hospital in Pittsburgh has significantly reduced the number of patients who develop deadly drug-resistant infections, long a problem in the U.S.
At some children's birthday parties, instead of gifts, guests are being asked to donate to a charity of the child’s choice.
Some Wall Street tycoons who tangled with Gov. Eliot Spitzer appeared to savor his current troubles in Albany.
The automaker reported its first quarterly profit in two years, although it continued its money-losing streak in its core market of North America.
Hideki Matsui, who came into Thursday’s game on an 11-for-24 tear, said he was not ready to call this his best month as a Yankee.
The Senate Finance Committee approved a set of measures intended to give the U.S. additional tools to pressure China and other countries accused of manipulating the value of their currencies.
The attack occurred hours after an American military official claimed “significant success” for recent security operations in Baghdad and Diyala Province.
The European Commission has accused the world’s largest chipmaker of using illegal rebates in its fight against rival Advanced Micro Devices.
D. R. Horton and Beazer Homes USA, two large home builders, saw losses in the last quarter and predicted more tough times to come.
No families should have to choose between putting food on the table or accepting a collect call from a loved one behind bars.
Avandia leads to an increased risk of heart attacks and is particularly dangerous to patients who take insulin, according to a report by federal drug reviewers.
Voters are watching to see if lawmakers have the guts to own up to their scandalous weakness for pandering to bundle-bearing lobbyists.
Strong digital camera sales and the success of “Spider-Man 3” helped offset losses from the PlayStation 3 game console.
A Pennsylvania ruling strikes a major blow against local attempts to crack down on illegal immigration.
The Philadelphia Phillies lost more than a game.
Alex Rodriguez could become the first major league player ever to hit his 500th home run twice.
Responding to decay in the subprime mortgage industry, Wells Fargo said it would stop lending to risky borrowers through brokers, but will continue to offer subprime loans.
A judge on ordered the federal government to pay damages to four men who it framed for a murder they did not commit.
The State Supreme Court upheld the right of homeowners’ associations to restrict the posting of political signs and other forms of constitutionally protected speech.
Mr. Skrobek was the premier postwar artisan of the figurines that have graced millions of mantels around the world for nearly three-quarters of a century.
Driven by concerns that are as much political as they are environmental, the company will offer a hybrid version of its Cayenne sport utility vehicle by the end of the decade.
Raanan A. Agus, head of Goldman’s equity proprietary trading desk, is starting a hedge fund, but with a twist. His fund will be inside Goldman Sachs itself.
Mr. Tabori was an internationally known playwright whose work sounded the depths of the refugee experience.
Johnson & Johnson is trying to revive the market for teeth-whitening products with a new product and advertising campaign.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,635 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Dr. Boyse did some of the earliest studies of the body’s system for recognizing and fighting off disease organisms and other foreign substances.
Skip Prosser led Wake Forest to its first basketball top ranking three seasons ago.
Mainstream investors are starting to show interest in firms that make and distribute pornographic entertainment and sexually related products and services.
Adrian Chip, a valuable racehorse taking aim at the $1.5 million Hambletonian at the Meadowlands, could not come from anyplace more humble.
Human Rights Watch called for the immediate closing of emergency centers set up last year to deal with a wave of illegal migrants in the Spanish Canary Islands.
The largest cable television provider in the U.S. saw a 28 percent increase in second-quarter profits, fueled by an increase in customers.
Muhammad Dahlan  was trusted by Israel and the United States and some saw him as a potential successor to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas.
The former supervisor of a military insider who criticized hearings at Guantánamo Bay said that the man’s view was “of a very narrow piece of the process.”
This year, for the first time, it was Fidel Castro’s younger brother, Raúl, the acting president, who gave the annual revolutionary speech at the anniversary celebration.
The German state-owned lender WestLB ousted its chief executive, Thomas Fischer, after 243 million euros ($334 million) of first-half trading losses.
The nation’s third largest health insurer saw a 16 percent rise in second-quarter earnings, beating Wall Street expectations.
The national mood in South Korea reached its lowest point and the Taliban threatened to kill more hostages if its demands were not met.
Eritrea has covertly shipped arms to insurgents in Somalia in an effort to torpedo Somalia’s fledgling government, a new United Nations report says.
A new bill allows prisoners in New York to suspend their Medicaid coverage while incarcerated, then have it immediately reinstated once they are released.
The shortfall was revealed when the state complied with a request to complete calculations required by a new accounting rule for state and local governments.
A recent survey showed that a majority of Brazilians feel the country’s natural riches could provoke a foreign invasion and many distrusted environmental groups.
A retired three-star general may be demoted for his role in the investigation of  Cpl. Pat Tillman’s death from American fire in Afghanistan.
Wolfgang Bernhard will become Chrysler’s chairman after the automaker is purchased by Cerberus Capital Management.
The struggle over a proposal for a huge coal-fired power plant on a Navajo reservation is a homegrown version of the global debate on climate change.
Executives said they would add Internet services to Microsoft’s desktop applications to respond to the growing threat posed by rivals like Google.
An infected lawyer who  set off an international health scare is no longer contagious, according to officials at the National Jewish Medical and Research Center.
Falcons’ quarterback Michael Vick and three defendants pleaded not guilty in federal court and were released without bond.

An Op-Ed article on July 17, about a new birth control pill that suppresses periods, incorrectly described premenstrual dysphoric disorder. It refers to severe irritability, tension and depression before periods, not to debilitating periods.
When faced with a betting scandal, a sports league usually hardens its anti-gambling stance. But that doesn’t work.

To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Wolfgang Bernhard will assume the post after the automaker is purchased by Cerberus Capital Management.
Christine Ebersole, Beth Leavel and Rosie O’Donnell will all star in productions during City Center’s 15th Encores! season.

Flipping her hair dramatically while wearing a long red trench coat and high heels, Beyoncé tripped and fell face-down on a flight of stairs while performing her song “Ring the Alarm” at a concert on Tuesday in Orlando, Fla., The Associated Press reported. But she rapidly regained her footing, reclaimed her microphone and went on with the show. Amateur videos of the mishap had nearly 900,000 hits on YouTube by yesterday morning.

CNN’s Democratic presidential debate in South Carolina on Monday, featuring questions submitted by YouTube users, may have broken new ground as a format for political debate, but it proved less remarkable as a ratings draw. The debate, from 7 to 9 p.m. and moderated by Anderson Cooper, attracted fewer viewers (2.6 million), Nielsen Media Research reported, than CNN’s more traditional Democratic debate in New Hampshire on June 3 (2.8 million). In the demographic of adults 18 to 34, the network did see a modest increase, averaging 407,000 viewers this round compared with 368,000 on June 3.

Fox once again outpaced its competitors Wednesday night in the ratings, as its latest installment of “So You Think You Can Dance” delivered 7.7 million viewers from 8 p.m. to 9:30, Nielsen estimated. Following it, Fox’s “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” (7.4 million) finished second in its half hour in total viewers behind CBS’s repeat of “Criminal Minds” (7.6 million). Fox’s karaoke-theme game show did remain No. 1 in its time period among adults 18 to 49, but by only the thinnest of margins ahead of the last 30 minutes of NBC’s “Last Comic Standing” (6.3 million). At 10 NBC’s “Dateline: To Catch a Predator” (7.2 million) finished on top in the 18-to-49 set, but CBS’s “CSI: NY” drew the most viewers in the hour (8 million). Over all CBS, ABC and NBC ended the night in a close race for second place behind Fox. In the 18-to-49 demographic, however, NBC earned a solid No. 2 ranking ahead of third-place ABC, whose “American Inventor” drew 6.1 million viewers from 9 to 11.

The French government has withdrawn its opposition to school screenings of the Romanian film about back-street abortions that won the Palme d’Or at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, Agence France-Presse reported. Three weeks ago the government advised against plans to show the film, Cristian Mungiu’s “4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days,” featuring Laura Vasiliu, left, saying it was too “hard” for youngsters, but it reversed course after the national film classification board declared “4 Months” suitable for all ages. It follows the ordeal of two university students as one tries to help the other obtain an illegal abortion.

Productions from the United States and Britain, including movies by Kenneth Branagh, below, Wes Anderson, Brian De Palma, Peter Greenaway, Paul Haggis, Todd Haynes, Ang Lee and Ken Loach, dominate the lineup of 22 films in the competing at the 75th anniversary Venice film festival, Variety.com reported. Continental Europe and Asia are also represented in the event, running from Aug. 29 through Sept. 8, but English-language films occupy half the slots in the contest. Marco Mueller, the director of the festival, said, “American films and films from Great Britain are still spawned by diverse and dynamic production structures that allow them to take the most risks and be continuously innovative.”.

Plácido Arango, a businessman and arts patron, was appointed yesterday the president of the board of the Prado in Madrid. Boos and jeers mingled with polite applause greeted 29-year-old Katharina Wagner, great-granddaughter of Richard Wagner, when the curtain fell on her new production of his “Meistersinger von Nürnberg” on the opening night of the 96th Bayreuth Festival in Germany on Wednesday, Agence France-Presse reported. With an audience that included Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, near right with Ms. Wagner, and José Manuel Barroso, president of the European Commission, the audience welcomed the first two acts with friendly applause, but it expressed outrage after the third and final act featured nudity. Ms. Wagner’s directing debut took place in the context of a struggle for control of the festival among branches of the Wagner clan. Wolfgang Wagner, 87, the composer’s grandson and festival director, wants Ms. Wagner, his daughter by his second marriage, to take over when he steps down.

TRAUBE--Beverly Anderson, a veteran Broadway talent agent whose clients were a who's who of the stage, died last Saturday evening at her home in Queens. She was 77. Her 50-year career made her one of New York's longest running independent agents. She helped launch the careers of Alan Alda, Bernadette Peters, Elliot Gould, Morgan Fairchild, Donna Mills, Gil Gerard and Pia Zadora. Her late husband, Leonard Traube, passed away in 2003. She is survived by two sons, publicist Frederic Traube, president and owner of Pro Sports Music Marketing, a Virginia-based music and sports marketing agency, his wife Lana; and Michael Traube, a New York based artist. A viewing and memorial service will be held June 27 in New York City at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. A memorial will also be held in Los Angeles on July 23.

PRIOR--Rev. Eugene. The Alumni Association of Loyola School notes with profound sorrow the passing of Fr. Eugene J. Prior, S.J. Advocate, guide, spiritual leader, and friend, Fr. Prior was the heart of the Loyola family. Present and presiding at alumni weddings, baptisms, and funerals, Fr. Prior accompanied the Loyola community from 1949 until 1952 and again from 1962 until his death. He was and always will be ''terrific.'' Gerard Herrling, President, Loyola Alumni Association Board Stephen Katsouros, S.J., President, Loyola School PRIOR--Rev. Eugene J., S.J., died on July 24, 2007. Fr. Prior, the son of the late Eugene and Elizabeth Prior and brother of the late Thomas ''Happy'' Prior, was born in the Bronx in 1924 and attended Fordham Prep and Fordham University. He entered the Society of Jesus in February, 1943, and was ordained a priest in June, 1955. Fr. Prior taught at Regis High School and The Loyola School. In 1962 he became a Spiritual Director for Students at The Loyola School and subsequently served as Headmaster, Dean of Students and, since 2001, Vice President for Alumni and External Affairs. Friends may call Sunday, July 29, 2-9pm and Monday, July 30, 2-5pm at The Loyola School Alumni Gymnasium at Park Ave and E. 83rd St. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday at 7pm, at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Park Ave at 84th. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Fr. Eugene Prior Scholarship Fund at The Loyola School will be gratefully accepted. PRIOR--Rev. Eugene. NELKIN--Myron. A loving husband, father, and grandfather, a visionary real estate developer, a friend and mentor to his employees, a generous supporter of a variety of charitable causes, and an avid golfer in his spare time, Myron Nelkin passed away on Sunday, July 22, at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. Born in Brooklyn on January 5, 1925, Mr. Nelkin was a student at Boys High in Brooklyn and graduated from Columbia University with a degree in business in 1946. With his father, Harry L. Nelkin, DDS, he began his working life building homes in Queens and Long Island. He founded three companies, Fairhaven Properties, Nelkin Construction Corp., and Central Management, and built all of Long Island's Fairhaven apartment complexes and the Woodbury Gardens senior residence. What Mr. Nelkin considered his crowning achievement was the rebuilding of The Garden City Hotel on the site of the storied original, where Charles Lindbergh slept in 1927 on the night before his trans-Atlantic flight. The completely new construction opened in 1983 on 21 acres in the heart of Garden City. Lavishly landscaped and decorated, lively and bright, the acclaimed establishment maintains a sense of its place in the history of Long Island, as Mr. Nelkin wished. When in New York, he called the penthouse suite his home. Mr. Nelkin generously supported the Helen Keller Home for the Blind, the North ShoreLong Island Jewish Health System, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Family Services of Nassau County, Christa House, the Hart Foundation for Parkinson's Research, and the Tilles Center, as well as Jewish philanthropies and causes. He is survived by his wife, Barbara (nee Norinsberg); his children, Henry L. Nelkin, Mindy Nelkin, and Cathy Nelkin-Miller and her husband, Charles Miller; his grandchildren, Rachel, John, and James Schwartz and Robert Miller; and his brother and sister-inlaw, William and Trudi Nelkin. A private interment was held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont. NELKIN--Myron. Our heartfelt sympathy to Barbara and her beautiful family. May their cherished memories live in their hearts forever. Maxine and Skip Pines NELKIN--Myron. My darling husband, I miss you already. The children and I are heartbroken. Thank you for providing us with a life full of wonderful, loving memories and for being our hero. Our love for you will live on, and you will live in our hearts and souls forever. Kisses and hugs, Barbara

KREEK--Louis Francis, Jr., died on July 23 in Akron, OH, at age 78. He was born in Washington, DC, and graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Chemical Engineering and George Washington University Law School. For 30 years he was a patent attorney at Merck Pharmaceuticals, the patent firm of Kenyon and Kenyon in New York City, Exxon Company in Elizabeth, NJ, and ICI in Wilmington, DE. In 1985, he moved to Akron, OH, to join the patent firm of Oldham and Oldham, working there until retirement. His wife Gwendolyn Scheopfle Kreek died in 2006 after a long illness. He was active in local and national Alumni Association fund raising for MIT; President of the Delaware Valley MIT Club from 1978-1980, and was later President of the Akron area MIT Club. Active in the Kiwanis Club in Akron, he was Lieutenant General of his local chapter for two years. In July 2007, he received the Past International President's Award from the Kiwanis Club at a luncheon honoring his outstanding service to the organization. He is survived by his sister, Mary Jeanne Kreek, MD, Professor and Head of Laboratory at The Rockefeller University (and her husband Robert A. Schaefer, MD), his nephew, Robert A. Schaefer, Jr., JD (and his wife, Heather Fain Schaefer), all of New York City, and his niece, Esperance Anne Kreek Schaefer, MD, MPH, of Boston, MA. The funeral will be held Saturday, July 28 at the UCC Church-Kent, OH. Memorial gifts may be made to Akron City Hospital-Summa's Palliative Care and Hospice Fund or The United Church of Christ-Kent, OH.

'MONGOLIA: MUSIC, DANCE & BALLAD' If it's happened once, it's happened a million times: Cornered at some hideous cocktail party, you dodge the topic as long as you can, only to be forced, at last, into admitting your ignorance of Mongolian dance. No? Hasn't happened yet? Just you wait; in a city of cultural know-it-alls, no chink in the knowledge body armor is too small to be exploited. Thankfully, the Lincoln Center Festival has anticipated your needs with the North American premiere of ''Mongolia: Music, Dance & Ballad.'' This 90-minute concert, under the artistic direction of the French ethnomusicologist Alain Desjacques, offers a crash course in biyelgee, the traditional pastoral dances of the Qoton and Bayad people. Typically performed by men in the limited space offered by a yurt, these solo dances center on the upper body and incorporate an everyday gestural language based on various nomadic activities. A two-stringed fiddle called a khuur is the only accompaniment, but the rest of the performance combines a host of fascinating-sounding instruments (including the tsuur, or Mongolian vertical lute) and singing techniques, like the vocal art of khoomii, in which multiple tones are produced simultaneously. Bring your notebook and then head to the next available cocktail party. (Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m., with a 2 p.m. matinee tomorrow, Clark Studio Theater in the Rose Building at Lincoln Center, 165 West 65th Street, 212-721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $40.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

'THE SILENT CITY: NEW YORK IN THE MOVIES, 1898-1928' ''In New York and other big cities,'' Buster Keaton wrote in his autobiography, ''crowds will always hamper your work.'' Especially if you're a big star, as Keaton was in 1928, the year he made ''The Cameraman,'' above, his last great feature and his first movie for MGM. Elaborate plans to film on location were scrapped when he was mobbed on city streets, and most of the movie was shot in Hollywood, but no matter: it makes a lovely start to Film Forum's series ''The Silent City: New York in the Movies, 1898-1928,'' on Monday nights through Aug. 27. All the Keaton poetry is here in this tale of a tintype photographer whose desire to impress a girl, Sally (Marceline Day), leads him to great feats and disasters as a newsreel cameraman. There's Keaton the actor (watch how he nestles his head onto Sally's shoulder, a picture of bliss); Keaton the physical marvel (running to catch up with a bus, he leaps, lands neatly with legs outstretched on a fender and resumes his chat with Sally); Keaton the accidental avant-gardist (the film he shoots for the newsreel company suggests the experimentation of Dziga Vertov's ''Man With a Movie Camera,'' a Soviet masterpiece of 1929); and, everywhere, Keaton the virtuoso (his solitary baseball game in an empty Yankee Stadium is just one example). Signing with MGM, Keaton later said, was ''the worst mistake of my career.'' It meant scripts, schedules, regimentation; after this film he would never again work in the free, improvisatory way that was so essential to his genius. If ''The Cameraman'' is for the ages, ''Speedy,'' the 1928 Harold Lloyd vehicle sharing Monday's double bill, is beautifully of its age, the Jazz Age, which perhaps found its purest physical expression in New York. Lloyd's Speedy, a cabbie in a hurry, races up and down city streets, at one point picking up Babe Ruth, in a nifty cameo. ''Gee, Babe,'' Speedy says, ''you've done more for baseball than cheese did for Switzerland.'' (Mondays through Aug. 27, Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, 212-727-8110, filmforum.com; $10.50.) RACHEL SALTZ

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the search for a particle known as the Higgs boson misstated part of the name of a particle detector at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory. It is the Collider Detector at Fermilab, not the Collider Detector Facility. Also, a picture caption incorrectly described the piece of equipment shown. It is the Compact Muon Solenoid, a particle detector built on the Large Hadron Collider, not the magnet core of the collider.

Your affection, success, and esteem for others are a small number of your impressive traits. The Kalick Family

Fox once again outpaced its competitors Wednesday night in the ratings, as its latest installment of ''So You Think You Can Dance'' delivered 7.7 million viewers from 8 p.m. to 9:30, Nielsen estimated. Following it, Fox's ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' (7.4 million) finished second in its half hour in total viewers behind CBS's repeat of ''Criminal Minds'' (7.6 million). Fox's karaoke-theme game show did remain No. 1 in its time period among adults 18 to 49, but by only the thinnest of margins ahead of the last 30 minutes of NBC's ''Last Comic Standing'' (6.3 million). At 10 NBC's ''Dateline: To Catch a Predator'' (7.2 million) finished on top in the 18-to-49 set, but CBS's ''CSI: NY'' drew the most viewers in the hour (8 million). Over all CBS, ABC and NBC ended the night in a close race for second place behind Fox. In the 18-to-49 demographic, however, NBC earned a solid No. 2 ranking ahead of third-place ABC, whose ''American Inventor'' drew 6.1 million viewers from 9 to 11.

RODRIGUEZ--Mario B., of NYC, 60, passed in peace July 24, 2007. Law Librarian with White & Case. A gentle nature could not disguise his wry wit. We bid him a fond adieu as he journeys to Light. He is survived by his mother, two sisters, nieces, nephews and brother-in-law. Services 10:30am July 30, St. Bartholomew's Chapel, 51st St. and Park Ave., NYC. Family requests donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

HARLEM WEEK Now in its 33rd year, the month of festivities known as Harlem Week continues on Sunday with a full day of events. ''A Great Day in Harlem'' begins at noon in Ulysses S. Grant National Memorial Park, with performances from Broadway and Off Broadway plays; an excerpt from ''Lady Sings the Blues,'' featuring blues and jazz standards; a fashion show with clothing from local designers; a performance by the Ruth Williams Dance Studio, above; and music from the gospel greats Byron Cage and the Rev. Hezekiah Walker, who will also be the first gospel singer inducted into the National Black Sports and Entertainment Hall of Fame (the ceremony takes place later in the day). Traditionally, the evening is capped by a tribute concert honoring recently deceased artists, and this year, they are biggies: Ruth Brown, the queen of R&B, and James Brown. Harlem Week continues next month with ''Dancing in the Street'' on Aug. 18 (the neighborhood once made the Guinness World Records book for world's largest electric slide) and the Upper Manhattan Auto Show, beginning Aug. 19. Over the course of the month, more than three million people will attend Harlem Week: a testament, said Marko Nobles, a board member, to the success of what was originally a one-day event to promote the virtues of the area.

HUGHES--David H. November 8, 1918-June 18, 2007. Former Skidmore, Owings and Merrill partner David H. Hughes died on June 18, 2007 in Tucson, Arizona. The cause of death was heart failure. His almost 30 year career with the noted architectural firm began in 1948. He was involved in many projects in the U.S. as well as in Germany, South Africa and France. He retired from SOM in 1975 after establishing a Paris office for the firm. David Huey Hughes was born November 8, 1918, the son of David Ashford Hughes and Anne Wright Hughes. He grew up in Santa Fe, New Mexico and graduated from the Los Alamos Ranch School and from Yale University, class of 1941. The following year he married Ruth Noel Hurley, the daughter of Patrick J. Hurley and Ruth Wilson Hurley. During World War II he served as a Captain in the U.S. Air Force, Squadron 394. He then earned a degree in architecture from Yale before joining Skidmore Owings and Merrill. He was a member of the International Council of the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, and served on the boards of several schools and clubs in Greenwich, CT. After he retired, he and Ruth divided their time between New York and Santa Fe before moving to Tucson in 1999. His wife Ruth died in 2000. He is survived by his eight children, David Hughes of Chicago, Anne Hughes Kieve of San Francisco, Cecily Hughes of Telluride, CO, Ruth Hughes of The Plains, VA, Ian Hughes of Fairfield, CT, and Wilson, Peter and Graeme Hughes of Tucson, as well as 13 grandchildren.

WEIL--Walter. American Friends of Nishmat offers its profound condolences to Maria Finkle, our dear friend and Board member, on the loss of her brother Walter. We express our sorrow also to Walter's wife and to his son. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Chana Henkin, Dean Sharon Liberman Mintz, President Sondra H. Fisch, Exec. Dir.

CHAPNICK--Jeanette. The Board of Trustees of the W. Eugene Smith Fund is deeply saddened by the loss of a treasured member. She was an important and strong supporter of photojournalists and their work. We will miss her spirit and generosity.

In an interview with USA Today J. K. Rowling, the author of the blockbuster Harry Potter series, said she was working on two books, one for children and one for adults. She said she was unlikely to revisit Harry or the other characters in the monumentally successful series that concluded at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday with the official release of ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows,'' the seventh installment. Ms. Rowling, who with earnings of about $1 billion is probably the richest living author, lashed out at those who attempted to spoil the ending by uploading photos of every page of the book to Internet file-sharing sites the week before the book went on sale. ''I felt angry,'' she said. ''I knew it was about other people's egos.'' Nevertheless Ms. Rowling herself talked openly about the book's ending, less than a week after the novel went on sale and likely before millions of readers -- despite the quick-reading habits of the most ardent fans -- have finished it. (On its Web site USA Today cloaked her remarks behind a link clearly marked as a spoiler alert; in the print edition a spoiler alert caption marked the relevant paragraphs.) Although Ms. Rowling has said she had the entire series mapped out in her head from the first book, she said in the interview that there were two characters who die in ''Deathly Hallows'' that she at one point ''intended to keep alive.''

ELY--Clarence Geist, 76, Miami, FL, and Lakeville, CT, died June 22, 2007. Known as ''Geist'', he was born in Philadelphia, PA, on May 29, 1931 and was the son of Van Horn Ely, Jr. and Elizabeth Geist Ely, who was the daughter of Clarence Henry Geist, considered the largest private owner of utilities in the United States in the early 1990s. That grandfather, for whom he was named, built the Seaview Golf Club in Atlantic City, NJ, in 1914, developed The Boca Raton Hotel and Club in Florida in 1928, and built the controversial Geist Reservoir in Fall Creek Valley, PA. He is survived by his companion of 21 years, Margaret H. Douglas-Hamilton, four children, Van Horn Ely, III, Clarence Geist Ely, Jr., Melinda Ely Dubow, Center Marshall Ely, and five grandchildren. Three marriages ended in divorce. Mr. Ely was predeceased by his younger sister, Hope Ely Muzzarelli, who died young leaving a daughter, Elizabeth Gay Pollock whom he raised with his children. She and her four children also survive him.

SHARE PRICES DIVE Stock prices tumbled on Wall Street and across much of the rest of the world, driven sharply lower by worries over slowing economic growth in the United States and worsening borrowing conditions. Major stock market gauges -- including the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index -- were down more than 2 percent. The buyout bubble was finally pricked as the market for debt -- the jet fuel that had propelled it to dizzying heights -- slammed shut. [C1.]

NUNNALLE--Francoise, age 70, died July 23rd, 2007 in New York City ending her long vicious battle with complicated and overwhelming medical problems. She fought with fierce bravery and impeccable dignity during her life so she could live for what she loved-her friends and familyart, music, flowers and her cats. She resided in Manhattan and Lenox, MA. Francoise was an international fine arts dealer -antique textile, linen and lace collector, but was especially known for her exceptional collection of original Mariano Fortuny fabrics. She also handmade pillows from her textiles for private collectors and interior designers. She leaves her darling husband Jim, her third pair of oriental shorthairs, little Bonnie and Clyde, and all the friends who adored her and loved her greatly including her deeply spiritual sister Georgianna and four fine nephews; Philip, Ricky, Michael and Haleem. A celebration and memorial luncheon will be announced in the fall for all who knew her and appreciated her kind and generous spirit and extraordinary persona. She would prefer all memorial donations to be given to the ASPCA-or a tree planted somewhere in her name so the world may be a bit more beautiful, kinder, and greener.

CNN's Democratic presidential debate in South Carolina on Monday, featuring questions submitted by YouTube users, may have broken new ground as a format for political debate, but it proved less remarkable as a ratings draw. The debate, from 7 to 9 p.m. and moderated by Anderson Cooper, attracted fewer viewers (2.6 million), Nielsen Media Research reported, than CNN's more traditional Democratic debate in New Hampshire on June 3 (2.8 million). In the demographic of adults 18 to 34, the network did see a modest increase, averaging 407,000 viewers this round compared with 368,000 on June 3.

DUCEY--John Francis, Jr., 92, of Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida and Northeast Harbor, Maine died on June 22, 2007. He was born on November 2, 1914 to John Francis and Ethel Barroll Ducey in Detroit, MI. He graduated from St. George's School, Newport, RI in 1932 and from Harvard College in 1936. He had a distinguished career in the U.S. Naval Reserve during World War ll, serving on three destroyers, and as captain of the last. He retired from active service as Commander. He worked for American Brake Shoe Company between 1937-1973. He was predeceased by his first wife of 39 years, Katharine Munson, in 1977. He is survived by his wife of 28 years, Marion Schmidt of Buffalo, NY; three daughters, Katharine Hardy, Ethel Coggeshall and Georgina Field; nine grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. A funeral service is scheduled for June 30 at 2:00pm, St. Mary's Church, Northeast Harbor, Maine. In lieu of flowers, a contribution may be sent to the St. Mary's Church Building Fund, PO Box 105, Northeast Harbor, Maine 04662
