FARBER--Lillian. Beloved mother, cherished life-partner, devoted sister, aunt, sister - in - law, mother - in - law, grandmother and dear friend, Lillian Farber died on July 23rd, 2007, just two weeks shy of her 87th birthday. She possessed a world-class mind. A passionate lifelong reader, who absorbed the printed word at a speed frightening to anyone who saw her read a page, she was a mesmerizing conversationalist insightful, curious, perceptive, and devilish with a self-deprecating wit. She was also a beauty, and a dynamo. Social justice and politics energized her: in the mid-1950's, while raising four children, she spearheaded a campaign to strengthen the Democratic Party in Westchester County by running twice as the Democratic candidate for a seat on the town council of Greenburgh, then a heavily Republican enclave. She helped lead a successful fight to integrate the Hartsdale public schools, was an activist in the League of Women Voters, and a leader in the Brandeis National Women's Committee, a group dedicated to raising funds for the young university's libraries. Having graduated from NYU in three years, she went back to school in the mid-1960's, obtaining a Master's degree from Sarah Lawrence College in sociology in 1966, becoming director of the college's Upward Bound program (an intensive academic program for inner-city high school students), and then Dean of Student Services. In the mid-1970's, Lillian moved to Newfane, Vermont. There, she was vice president of Zone VI Studios, a manufacturer of photographic equipment. While helping to build and run the company, she found time to devote herself to local political campaigns in Vermont, to serve on the Vermont Council of the Arts, to chair the board of the Moore Free Library in Newfane, to officiate at civil unions and marriages as a justice of the peace, and, finally, to serve on the board of trustees of Marlboro College, an institution whose humanistic values she cherished. With a sense of adventure and mission, Lillian took on the role of chair of the Marlboro trustees' finance committee. She was fearless approaching potential donors, and unfailingly persuasive. Three Marlboro presidents, as well as members of the faculty and staff, counted on her for her counsel and foresight. She joined the board of trustees in 1982, served four years as chair in the 1990's, and became a member emeritus in May 2005. Lillian had an artists eye for photography: she built a distinguished collection that included works of Fred Picker, Paul Strand, Eugene Atget, Edward Weston, Alfred Steiglitz, Dorothea Lange, and Paul Caponigro, among others. In 2006, she donated the collection to Marlboro College. Her beloved son, Robert, who predeceased her, was a noted painter. Sister of the late Natalie Steinbock, she is survived by her life-partner, Bern Friedelson; children Lindy Linder, Peggy Farber, and Felicia and Charles Gervais; a sister, Florence Isbell; four grandchildren, Liza and Luke Linder and Benjamin and Samuel Jacoff; beloved nieces, nephew, and brothers-in-law; and dear ones, Susan Friedelson and Lori Schreiner. In lieu of flowers, donations to Marlboro College and the A.C.L.U.

WHITE--Timothy. Today is the fifth anniversary of Tim's untimely death at age 50. White, a renowned writer and editor of Billboard Magazine, was a passionate advocate for great music and artists' rights. He was also a devoted husband to Judy and father of twin boys Alexander and Christopher. White was taken all too soon, and we will truly miss him forever. His legacy is alive and well. As Tim himself would say, ''Rock heavily and without shame.'' Maureen

ABDULLAH IBRAHIM Last September the pianist Abdullah Ibrahim presided over the premiere of the Cape Town Jazz Orchestra, an ensemble officially sponsored by South Africa's Department of Arts and Culture. For Mr. Ibrahim, above, the event was personally as well as historically significant. Born in a Cape Town ghetto in 1934 -- and, before his conversion to Islam, widely known as Dollar Brand -- Mr. Ibrahim left home in the mid-1970s because of apartheid and other political pressures. (Another consideration was the safety and education of his two children with the jazz singer Sathima Bea Benjamin; their daughter, Tsidi Ibrahim, is the rapper known as Jean Grae.) Since Mr. Ibrahim's return to Cape Town in the early '90s, an act of reclamation as well as a sign of faith, he has been celebrated not only as a pioneer of South African jazz but also as a cultural eminence, precisely the sort of elder statesman to lead a national jazz orchestra. Thankfully his style hasn't puffed up or stiffened, judging by the most recent recorded evidence. ''African Magic'' is a generous-spirited trio album, by turns sprightly and serene, released in 2002 on the German label Enja. (Like Mr. Ibrahim's previous two albums, the live trio release ''Cape Town Revisited'' and the chamber-symphonic ''African Suite,'' it's available in North America through Justin Time Records.)

APRAHAMIAN--Vahe. Vahe was born in 1934 and left his family behind at the age of 14. He attended the Melkonian School in Nicosia, Cypress. Roberts College in Istanbul. MS in Structural Engineering at the University of Iowa in 1962, licensed in 14 states and he spoke four languages fluently and a 40-year member of the American Concrete Institute and committee 213. He founded Engineering Enterprises, a Des Moines, Iowa based company for 25 years. He was a pioneer in designing towers for the Titan Missile Program, Grain Silos, for the ports of Algeria and Egypt and he will also be recognized as the engineer who designed structures for the world-renowned artist ''Christo'', ''The Islands'' in Miami 1983, ''Pont Neuf'' in Paris 1985, and ''Umbrellas'' in California and Japan 1991. Married for 43 years to Donna Rees, they have two children Adrienne and Greg, two spouses Jack and Yoon-hee, and four grandchildren Sophia, Max, Aram and Sara. He has three brothers and two sisters surviving. He was a Philosopher-Engineer. Each day was a masterpiece for 72 years.

BEAR--Charles B. The board of the Time-Life Alumni Society is saddened by the recent death of a former board member, Charles Bear. A graduate of Grinnell College, he later received a Masters in international relations from Tufts' Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy. This lead to an executive career in Time Inc., with an early focus on the international expansion of the company. After World War II, as head of Time's international operations, he was based in Paris where he managed the distribution of magazines in 40 countries. When he was seized and held captive by the Russians for four days, he emerged unharmed, except, as he later reported, ''for an overexposure to sauerkraut soup.'' At age 45 he was named managing director of Time Life International, and later he was a key officer of Fortune and Architectural Forum Back in the United Stated. He capped his magazine career as a group vice-president and secretary of Time, Inc., and he became the company's chief administrative officer. He was a member of the U.S Olympic Committee, and he was a consultant to the Commissioner of Baseball. Charles' business wit was legendary. He was a man of few words or many words depending on the occasion. For example, when he recommended to the Time Inc board that a small chain of weeklies be divested, he cogently summarized his judgement with these words: ''...(This company) is something of an appendage to the corporation, a vestigial tail that the dog wouldn't bother to wag if he could.'' He will be missed by his former colleagues for his wit and charm, but he will also be remembered for his brilliant hard-nosed leadership in the world-wide expansion of Time Inc. Don Underwood, President, Time-Life Alumni Society

Millstein, Chairperson Board of Overseers Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean

KOSHLAND--Dr. Daniel E. Jr. The leadership and staff of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science mourn the passing of our dear friend, Dr. Daniel E. Koshland Jr. Dr. Koshland was an active member of the Weizmann Institute's Board of Governors and co-chaired the Scientific and Academic Advisory Committee. He funded two Career Development Chairs. Most significantly, Dr. Koshland established the Koshland Center for Basic Research, which supports the Koshland Scholars program, providing fellowships for extraordinary, international postdoctoral students at the Institute. Dr. Koshland was the founding Chairman of the American Committee's Bay Area Region, was a member of the President's Circle, and served on the Board of Directors. Dr. Koshland's warmth, wit, and wisdom will be deeply missed. We send heartfelt condolences to his wife, Yvonne, and to the entire family. As Dr. Koshland's life was for a blessing, so may his memory be. Robert B. Machinist, Chairman American Committee Pennie Abramson, President American Committee Martin S. Kraar, Exec. V.P. American Committee Mandy Moross, Chair Weizmann Institute Prof. Daniel Zajfman, President Weizmann Institute

COUNTDOWN TO DOWNTOWN: NEW MUSEUM FAMILY DAY ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE An old-fashioned way to welcome a new neighbor was with homemade cookies or a delicious pie. Something similar is happening tomorrow on the Lower East Side, but with a twist: The newcomer is involved in the giving, and since it's a museum, it won't offer baked goods, but freshly made art. The benefactor is the New Museum of Contemporary Art, which will hold its second annual ''Countdown to Downtown,'' an outdoor fair inspired by the theme ''Art in Our Neighborhood.'' And the museum is joining the neighborhood soon. Founded in Chelsea 30 years ago, it plans to open its new location -- 235 Bowery -- on Dec. 1. ''The idea is to introduce the community to what the New Museum is going to be, and let the people know that we're a friendly neighbor,'' said Cris Scorza, Family Day coordinator.

In her debut "On Foreign Policy" column today, Helene Cooper looks at Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr.'s soft partition plan for Iraq:

So much for the slow dog days of summer. From YouTube's laughs to Obama's gaffes, from Alberto Gonzales's stonewall to Robert Mueller's tell-all, it was a huge week for the blogosphere. But among all the mayhem, one story that readers outside New York may not have followed closely was the travails of our governor, Eliot Spitzer, whose aides, it turns out, attempted to strongarm the state police into helping them build a case against the State Senate leader, Joe Bruno, for unauthorized use of state aircraft.

DES MOINES - Senator Barack Obama has had the state of Iowa essentially to himself this weekend, at least among the Democratic presidential hopefuls. These days, a solo visit seems a rarity, with candidates often practically stepping over one another here.
Whenever I see my byline in The New York Times, I should give thanks to Tony Gwynn for making it happen.

In response to a reader's question about web sites that offer up-to-date information about London nightlife, here's one recommendation: A site called Urban Junkies. No, you don't have to be a drug addict to use it. But it does include useful information on new restaurants and bars, cultural events and shopping, as well as "insider" tips on getting into the hippest clubs.

Cancer rates may be falling, Denise Grady reports, but patients still find it difficult to obtain adequate treatment -- particularly for such difficult forms of the disease as colon cancer. How should patients take charge of their care? What can be done to improve the system?

The actress Alyssa Milano (you may know her as Samantha Miceli from Who's The Boss or as one of those witches from Charmed) is at Shea Stadium today to promote her MLB-related women's clothing line, but that's not how I know she's a huge baseball fan. Nor is it her season tickets at Dodger Stadium (she attended three of the Mets' four games there last weekend) or her blog, where she ruminates on baseball, or her past relationships with Carl Pavano, Brad Penny and Barry Zito. This is how I know: She is spending her Saturday watching the Mets play the Washington Nationals in a day-night doubleheader, and yes, she said, she plans on staying the whole time.

Magnus Carlsen of Norway neatly outplayed his co-leader, Alexander Onischuk of the United States, in Round 5 to take a commanding one point lead at the Biel International Chess Festival. The games can be replayed or followed live at the official Web site.

As he tests the waters for a presidential campaign, Fred D. Thompson is changing his floaties before wading all the way in. The Times's Susan Saulny reports that in addition to questions about his preparedness to run, this week's broad staff turnover "also ignited speculation in Republican circles about who is really in charge, and in particular about the extent of the role being played by Mr. Thompson's wife, Jeri Kehn Thompson, a former political operative."

All eyes were on Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton when she entered the crystal-chandeliered ballroom last night at the National Beauty Culturists' League Convention, with many no doubt casting a critical gaze on the candidate's latest waves.

Two invitation-only tournaments for women are being played on opposite sides of the world. One, the Monroi Women's Grand Prix, is being held in Montreal from July 21 to today. The Web site for the tournament, where games can be followed live or replayed, is here. The other tournament, the North Urals Cup, is taking place in Krasnoturinsk, Russia, from July 22 to 31. Its Web site, which also has all the games, can be found here.

What if Mrs. Haim and Mrs. Feldman had been offered a do-over back in 1971? Would one of them have taken the opportunity to rename her son Rory or Carl, thereby sparing us from a string of bad movies in the late 1980s-early ’90s and the spectacle of the new reality show “The Two Coreys”?

According to today's Your Money column, the number of people paying cash for cars and trucks is going up. There are two main reasons. With recent records on Wall Street, consumers are cashing in their stocks and using the proceeds; others are buying small cars, which are much cheaper than big sport utilities and sedans. Some experts say paying cash for a depreciating asset is a bad idea, and that consumers can make better use of their money by arranging a lease or getting a zero-interest loan. But many cash buyers simply want to be debt free.
Iraqis, particularly the poor, increasingly depend on ice to cool food. But delivering ice across sectarian lines is a risky job.
Pretentious and inane, “I Know Who Killed Me” arouses unexpected sympathy for its embattled star.
There’s probably more wit and pointed social commentary in the average four-minute OutKast song than in the entirety of “Who’s Your Caddy?”
A list of the winners of the Chicago Mixed Board-a-Match Teams at the American Contract Bridge League’s Summer North American Bridge Championships.
Up to 6,000 Palestinians stuck in Egypt for weeks may be allowed to return to Gaza starting Sunday, officials said.
Barry Bonds hit a solo shot in the first inning against the Florida Marlins to bring him within one home run of tying Hank Aaron’s all-time record.
Two men were arrested late last night, and one of them was injured, after leading police from New York and New Jersey on a car chase through both states.
Greg Winter discusses President Nicolas Sarkozy’s reinvention of French politics and his nation’s role in world affairs with Paris bureau chief Elaine Sciolino.
Ernie Tyler, the umpires’ attendant for the Orioles, will finally take a day off to see Cal Ripken inducted into the Hall of Fame.
A federal judge denied on Friday a request from a small Virginia company to stop eBay from using its “Buy It Now” feature, which allows shoppers to purchase items at a fixed price.
Moises Alou returned to the Mets lineup and had a decent game, but Jorge Sosa struggled, allowing nine hits and five runs in six innings.
Dominique de Villepin is at the center of an inquiry into whether he was involved in a campaign to smear Nicolas Sarkozy before Mr. Sarkozy won the presidency.

Sara Lee Corporation is recalling 27 brands of whole-wheat bread products because they could contain small metal pieces, the company said. A recent routine inspection of a bakery in Meridian, Miss., uncovered problems with a flour-sifting screen, said a company spokesman, Mark Goldman. The problem was isolated to the Meridian bakery, which continued production using bagged flour that did not require the sifting system, Mr. Goldman said. The recall involves EarthGrains, Publix, Sara Lee Delightful, Sara Lee Hearty & Delicious and several other brands that were stamped “best if purchased by” July 25, 2007, to Aug. 7, 2007, and included the code “222.” The products were sold in Alabama, Arkansas, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, Missouri and Tennessee. Consumers can return the bread to the store where it was purchased for a refund, said Sara Lee, based in Downers Grove, Ill.

United States Representative Ray LaHood, Republican of Illinois, said he would retire at the end of this, his seventh, term. Mr. LaHood, 61, said that leaving the House would allow him to spend more time with his family. He has served on appropriations and intelligence panels in the House and frequently crossed party lines to work with Democrats. Mr. LaHood, whose district includes Peoria and spans central and western parts of Illinois, is one of 11 House Republicans who told President Bush in May that lack of progress in the Iraq War was imperiling his party. He also presided over impeachment proceedings against President Bill Clinton in 1998.

Sajani Shakya, 10, has been reinstated to her role of “living goddess” in Nepal after a group of Hindu and Buddhist priests stripped her of the title earlier this month. Sajani is the Living Goddess of Baktapur, one of three such goddesses in the Katmandu Valley, young girls who are considered earthly manifestations of the Hindu goddess Kali. In June, Sajani visited Washington to help promote a British documentary about the living goddesses. But a group of priests in Baktapur claimed the trip overseas had rendered Sajani impure and dismissed her. The priests reinstated Sajani in mid-July, after the documentary’s director, Ishbel Whitaker, flew to Nepal and convinced them that Sajani had not been tainted by being overseas and that the trip was an important effort at cultural exchange.

A third person has died after an explosion Thursday at the test site of a pioneering company building commercial spaceships. The cause of the blast at the company, Scaled Composites, is under investigation. Scaled, based in Mojave and founded by Burt Rutan, a renowned aircraft designer, was working on a top-secret suborbital spaceship for the British tycoon Richard Branson. Mr. Rutan said the explosion occurred during a routine test of the propellent flow system for the craft, SpaceShipTwo. Three other people were injured in the blast. The dead were identified as Eric Blackwell, 38, Charles May, 45, and Todd Ivens, 33, all employees of Scaled.

A concrete supplier for the Big Dig in Boston has agreed to pay $50 million to end civil and criminal investigations into whether it supplied inferior concrete used in the massive highway project, the authorities said. The company, Aggregate Industries NE Inc., also agreed to plead guilty to a criminal charge of conspiracy to defraud the federal government. Six employees of Aggregate were indicted last year on charges that they falsified records to hide the substandard quality of concrete. The company was not charged, but prosecutors said their investigations continued. The deal will end the case against Aggregate, which has been bought by Holcim Ltd., a concrete company based in Switzerland. The employees are awaiting trial.
Rwanda’s decision to end capital punishment should allow suspects in the 1994 genocide to be extradited to stand trial in the country.

Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, accused the United States of having a “winner complex” after the end of the cold war, which, he said, led to recklessness in international relations, the Interfax news agency reported. “The U.S. is always anxious to win,” Mr. Gorbachev told a news conference in Moscow. “The fact that they suffer this disorder, the winner complex, is the main reason why things are so complicated in the world.” He criticized the “current U.S. administration” for trying to build a new empire in the world and said other countries would not accept that arrangement. He said that claims of victory after the cold war led the United States to feel its hands were untied in world affairs. “We all lost the cold war,” he said, “and we all benefited from its end.”.

A Russian nuclear submarine was damaged from an explosion caused by pressurized air while undergoing repairs at the Severodvinsk shipyard on the White Sea, the Russian news media reported. The authorities termed the accident minor and said no radiation had leaked. Russia has a history of accidents involving its nuclear submarine fleet, including an explosion onboard the Kursk in 2000 that sank the ship and killed 118 sailors.
Kenya has begun moving about 2,000 animals to a rebuilt game reserve devastated by rampant poaching in the 1970s and ’80s.

Plans for a 67-mile blacktop highway to a base camp on the Tibet side of Mount Everest to ease the Olympic torch’s journey to its peak have been put on hold, according to Ju Jianhua, the director of Tibet’s Foreign Affairs Department. He refused to give a reason. In April, organizers for the Beijing Summer Olympics announced plans for the longest torch relay in Olympic history, an 85,000-mile, 130-day route that would cross five continents and reach the top of Everest. Taking the torch to the summit — seen by some as a way for China to underscore its claims to Tibet — is expected to be one of the relay’s highlights.
The main runway at Congonhas Airport in São Paulo, Brazil, reopened 10 days after a passenger jet skidded off its rain-slicked surface and crashed, killing 199 people.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Tony Blair’s first day as the special envoy of the so-called quartet of Middle East peacemakers referred imprecisely to the population of Palestinian refugees and their descendants, whose fates are a core issue in the Arab-Israeli conflict. Although Palestinians and their descendants who are registered as refugees by the United Nations now number about 4.5 million, only about 700,000 Palestinians — not “millions” — fled or were forced to flee during the era when the state of Israel was created. Also because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to the time frame during which the first Palestinians left their homes. Most left before and during the 1948 war, not afterward.

Two days after Dale Earnhardt Inc. and Ginn Racing joined forces, Robert Yates Racing and the open-wheel powerhouse Newman/Haas/Lanigan announced their intention to form a Nascar partnership.The deal, which would rename the team Yates/Newman/Haas/Lanigan Racing, is expected to give the Yates team a big boost, particularly in engineering and marketing. Newman/Haas/Lanigan Racing, co-owned by Paul Newman, the racing entrepreneur Carl Haas and the businessman Michael Lanigan, is the most successful team in the Champ Car World Series.

An article on July 18 about a lawsuit by New York State seeking the cleanup of an oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the number of defendants. (The error was repeated in an article on July 19 about cleanup efforts at the site.) The suit names only one company — Exxon Mobil — not five. The state had previously signaled its intent to sue four other companies — BP, Chevron, KeySpan and Phelps Dodge — but did not do so.

The Chicago Bulls signed their first-round draft choice, Joakim Noah, along with their second-round selection, Aaron Gray. Noah, selected ninth over all, averaged 12.0 points, 8.4 rebounds and 1.8 blocks as a junior last season, when the Florida Gators became the first program to win back-to-back titles in 15 years.

Rutherienne continued a four-race winning streak, capturing yesterday’s $100,000-added Lake George for 3-year-old fillies at Saratoga Race Course. Ridden by Garrett Gomez, the bay filly ran the one-and-one-sixteenth mile on the turf in 1 minute 40.34 seconds.Rutherienne raced well behind the front-runners early, then found running room on the rail midstretch and came through under strong urging from Gomez to win by a head. Rutherienne held off a late push by Lady Attack, who was ridden by Calvin Borel. Sharp Susan was third.

Buffalo Sabres forward Derek Roy avoided N.H.L. arbitration yesterday by agreeing to a six-year, $24 million contract. Roy, a third-line center, had 63 points in 75 games. Roy made $627,000 last season.

A film review in Weekend yesterday about “The Simpsons Movie” misstated part of the title of an episode of the television show “The Simpsons” cited as among the best. It was “22 Short Films About Springfield,” not 32.

Diana D’Alessio of the United States and Jin-joo Hong of South Korea shared a three-stroke lead yesterday after the second round of the Evian Masters in France.Michelle Wie rebounded with a one-under-par 71 for a 144 total and made the cut. She had gone 24 consecutive rounds without breaking par.D’Alessio, who shot a 68, and Hong, who finished with a 70, were at seven-under 137. Annika Sorenstam (69) was a shot back. Juli Inkster, had five birdies in the first seven holes for a 68 to join a large group at 141.

The Knicks signed their first-round draft pick, Wilson Chandler, left, the No. 23 overall selection. The 6-foot-8 Chandler played two seasons at DePaul, averaging 12.9 points and 7.1 rebounds. He started all five games for the Knicks’ team in the Las Vegas summer league, averaging 13.4 points a game and shooting 51 percent from the field. Chandler will make a little less than $1 million in each of his first two seasons. The Knicks hold one-year options for his third and fourth years.

Hunter Mahan holed an 81-yard approach shot on No. 9 for his third eagle of the round yesterday — and second on a par 4 — at the Canadian Open in Markham, Ontario. Mahan also holed out from 189 yards on No. 18 and made a more routine eagle with a 10-foot putt on the par-5 No. 11. He finished with a nine-under 62 to match the tournament record and take a two-stroke lead over Steve Allan of Australia.

An article in Business Day on July 12 reported that the Food and Drug Administration rejected shipments of food and other products to the United States from Denmark, India, Mexico and the Dominican Republic because they violated sanitary, safety or labeling standards. But many of the statistics were incorrect because of a flawed analysis by The Times of inspection records that were in an online F.D.A. database.

Tom Watson missed a 5-foot putt at the last hole and tossed away a share of the lead at the Senior British Open yesterday, while the first-round leader, Nick Faldo, lost his putting touch and slipped to sixth. Watson finished with a par 71 and handed the lead to Des Smyth, who shot a 70 and held the lead at two-under-par 140 at windswept Muirfield in Gullane, Scotland. Watson was tied for second with Eduardo Romero (71), Gordon J. Brand (73) and Stewart Ginn (70) at one under. Faldo, who shot a 74, was two strokes behind after opening with a 68 on Thursday.
The New York Parks Department made life a little easier for the city’s surfers by opening a second surf-only beach in the Rockaways.
Pedro Martínez inched closer to throwing in a minor league game, tossing about 65 pitches against batters at the Mets’ training complex.
Pete Kendall is seeking to have the four-year deal he signed last season restructured so he will be paid $2.7 million this season.
A state panel recommended that troopers protecting the New Jersey governor work shorter shifts, receive more training and be given less freedom to ignore traffic laws.
The Yankees’ biggest weakness before the trading deadline is their bullpen, and they are open to the idea of dealing the setup men Kyle Farnsworth and Scott Proctor.
The U.S. military said a predawn raid captured what the Americans described as a high-level “rogue” member of the Mahdi Army and killed 17 other militants.
A tentative deal would require lawmakers to identify lobbyists who assemble multiple donations for candidates.
The latest questions about the security of electronic voting machines came on a day when House leaders reached an agreement on measures to revamp voting systems.

Days before a parliamentary election that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s party is expected to lose, fresh revelations about his scandal-ridden agriculture minister emerged.
Officials say they have asked NASA’s safety chief to interview astronauts, flight surgeons and others to determine whether the agency has an alcohol problem.
Nike announced that it had suspended Michael Vick’s endorsement contract without pay and would not sell any more Vick-branded products.
A suicide bomber killed at least 13 people as protesters clashed with the police when the government tried to reopen the Red Mosque in Islamabad, Pakistan, for prayers.

Jhonny Peralta homered twice and Kenny Lofton began his third stint with Cleveland by collecting three hits and playing left field for the first time as the host Indians beat the Minnesota Twins, 10-4, last night.
One former lawyer said morale under Attorney General Alberto Gonzales was worse than during Watergate, and another still working at the department said he was “ashamed.”

The good news is that there is a core group of influential farm state senators ready to break with the past and with the lobbyists for big agriculture.
A week of personnel turnover raised questions about whether the former senator is prepared to jump fully into the race for the Republican presidential nomination.
Quarterback JaMarcus Russell, the No. 1 overall draft pick, and the Oakland Raiders failed to agree on a contract before the start of training camp Friday.

Homeowners, renters and businesses affected by the steam pipe explosion that shook Midtown on July 18 will be eligible for low-interest federal loans to help them recover from losses caused by the disaster, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday.
As long as people like Mayor Louis J. Barletta persist in misusing the law to serve their prejudices, they will make the immigration system an ever more incoherent muddle.
Mitt Romney has turned down the invitation and aides to Rudolph Giuliani say he may do the same.

The Yankees held on to win a suspended game against the Orioles, 8-7,  but then dropped the regularly scheduled game against Baltimore, 4-2, with Jeremy Guthrie and four relievers holding them to seven hits.
The sale of its stake in the power company Dynegy also helped Chevron beat analysts’ expectations for second-quarter earnings.

This week all eyes were following the gyrating stock market, clues to the iPhone’s popularity were revealed, Barclays pursued ABN Amro, and the United States and China cracked down on software piracy.
Whitewater kayaking offers a high-risk adrenaline rush and  almost unlimited opportunities for adventure.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York said he was inclined to appear, if asked, as part of a review of the misuse of the State Police by his aides.

Some American Express card members have raised questions about one of the five finalists in a contest to select a philanthropic idea that will win up to $5 million.

A man claiming to speak for the Taliban said that some of the South Koreans were “not in good condition,” as local tribal elders and clerics continued telephone negotiations.
Coca-Cola named Joseph V. Tripodi its chief marketing and commercial officer yesterday, filling a post that has been vacant for months.

Landry’s Restaurants Inc. is facing early redemption demands from a creditor because it has failed to file quarterly reports.
Hand fishing, alternately known as noodling, hogging, tickling, grabbling or stumping, is a popular pastime on the lakes and rivers of the Southeast and Midwest.

In fantasy sports, men don’t hold an advantage over women and many women are enticed by this opportunity to compete against men on a level playing field.
A federal judge denied a motion to unseal the original version of a search warrant affidavit in which several major league baseball players were implicated in the use of performance-enhancing drugs.

CBS, the august home of the Masters and March Madness, will become the first broadcast network in the United States to cover a video game tournament as a sporting event.
Stores continue to sell recalled canned chili, stew, hash and other foods potentially contaminated with poisonous bacteria even after repeated warnings.
After a narrow defeat in the Preakness Stakes, the Kentucky Derby winner will return to action in the $500,000 Jim Dandy Stakes.
A suspected bookmaker whose lawyer says he is being investigated in the scandal involving the former N.B.A. referee Timothy Donaghy was convicted of criminal conspiracy and bookmaking in 1998.

President Bush plans to sign the bill, which he initially opposed, according to a White House spokesman.
A National Institutes of Health director spent $6 million of agency dollars for his laboratory after agreeing to a much lower limit, according to Senator Charles Grassley.
Political mavens have been waiting months for what seemed an inevitable explosion between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Attorney General Andrew Cuomo.
The latest venture trying to make money off America’s most popular professional sport is the A.A.F.L., short for the All American Football League.
Aitzaz Ahsan, one of Pakistan’s best known lawyer-politicians, led a campaign designed to bring maximum pressure on the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf.
Din Celaj, 23, has a breathtaking criminal past, including extortion, gun sales, drug sales, burglary, car theft, hostage taking, bank fraud and insurance fraud.
A federal investigation of State Senator Joseph Coniglio seems to focus on whether a consulting position he held at a hospital was a payback for grants he secured for it.

NEW HAVEN, July 27 — In more than 25 years as a prosecutor, Michael Dearington had sought the death penalty only once. This week, he did it twice, filing capital charges against the two suspects in the killings of a mother and her two daughters in a Cheshire home.
Dr. Koshland was a biochemist and philanthropist who brought an unexpectedly puckish tone to Science, the international weekly journal of research that he edited.

New technology would allow owners of videos to provide a digital fingerprint to automatically remove any video that infringes copyrights.

The re-enactment of a speech originally given by Paul Potter, the former president of Students for a Democratic Society, during the 1965 march on Washington fits into a growing subgenre of historical re-enactment as performance art.

Though ABC executives say no deal is yet in place, “The View” has apparently settled on Whoopi Goldberg and Sherri Shepherd as new panelists.

The Department of Defense has identified 3,636 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
The economy pulled out of a winter slump and grew at a quicker pace in the spring, lifted by an improvement in the trade deficit and stronger business spending.
The Australian government dropped a terrorism charge against an Indian doctor arising from the botched bombing plot last month.
WNBC in New York City will become the biggest television station in the country to end its 5 p.m. newscast.
The minor surgery, scheduled for Saturday, takes about an hour.
The Bancroft family’s deliberations on a sale of Dow Jones to the News Corporation took several bizarre turns Friday.

The Staten Island Museum has received $10 million in additional funds from the city for its expansion on the grounds of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center.

The decision of an Army private who has been writing anonymously for The New Republic to reveal his identity has not quieted critics at the rival Weekly Standard who continue to question the accuracy of the soldier’s deeply critical accounts from Iraq.

The novelist and critic Wilfrid Sheed begins “The House That George Built,” his impassioned history of American songwriting in the first half of the 20th century, with a grand assertion.
Ramón del Valle-Inclán's grotesque parody “Divinas Palabras” is being given a stark staging by the Centro Dramático Nacional of Madrid at the Lincoln Center Festival.
“Into the Little Hill,” which had its North American premiere on Thursday night at John Jay College, presented by the Lincoln Center Festival, is anything but a safe and modest work.

8 P.M. (HBO) INSIDE MAN (2006) Denzel Washington, Clive Owen and Jodie Foster play the holy trinity, as Manohla Dargis of The New York Times put it, in this psychological thriller from Spike Lee. The action begins when Mr. Owen, above right, gazes into the camera and declares that he’s going to pull off “the perfect bank robbery.” Oh, yeah? Mr. Washington, above left, plays the troubled veteran cop sent to take control when the Wall Street heist escalates into a hostage situation. Ms. Foster reveals some killer legs as a fixer hired by the bank, which doesn’t want some especially inconvenient secrets revealed. “ ‘Inside Man’ has a story to tell, but its most sustained pleasures come from its performances, especially the three leads,” Ms. Dargis wrote. “To watch Mr. Washington breeze into a scene smooth as silk, smooth as Bogart and Easy Rawlins combined, or to listen to Mr. Owen murmur sweet nothings into the camera, is to experience the ineffable pleasures that only big-screen stars can provide.”.
Michael Strahan didn’t show up to Giants camp Friday and is contemplating retirement, the team’s general manager said.
After nearly three weeks, numerous doping scandals, two team withdrawals and plenty of ill feelings, the Tour de France heads into the final time trial on Saturday as a still-undecided race.

In a concert featuring the pianist Eddie Palmieri and the trumpeter Brian Lynch, the tradition-minded series, Jazz in July,  made room for Latin jazz: the real thing, piquant and polished, with an urgent approach to propulsion.

At the American Contract Bridge League’s Summer North American Bridge Championships on Thursday night, the winners of the Wagar Women’s Knockout Teams were Phyllis Fireman of Chestnut Hill, Mass.; Mildred Breed and Tobi Sokolow of Austin, Tex.; Janice Seamon-Molson of Hollywood, Fla.; and Sabine Auken and Daniela von Arnim from Germany.

An article on July 18 about a lawsuit by New York State seeking the cleanup of an oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, misstated the number of defendants. (The error was repeated in an article on July 19 about cleanup efforts at the site.) The suit names only one company -- Exxon Mobil -- not five. The state had previously signaled its intent to sue four other companies -- BP, Chevron, KeySpan and Phelps Dodge -- but did not do so.
JEFFRIES--Seymour B., age 90, July 25. His many accomplishments include a successful law practice, the family he loved and who truly loved him. He will be missed.

SILBERT--Richard (Punch), passed away peacefully at home in Long Boat Key, FL, on July 26, 2007, at the age of 96, overlooking the beautiful Gulf of Mexico. Formerly of Great Neck, NY, a ''favored son'' of Chief Powhatan and Columbia Blue, Richard was a successful Attorney, Builder and an accomplished Artist and Sculptor. Punch was a devoted and caring husband for over 50 years to his beloved wife, Amy, who predeceased him; the most wonderful father to Michael, Jimmy and Betsy Tanjeloff and father-inlaw to Liz Horton and Jorge Tanjeloff; and the most cherished grandfather to Jasmin, Jordan, Sonia, and Zak. His captivating smile, until the very end, was just like the sunsets he loved over the Gulf, always brightening the darkest day, warming the coolest evening and soothing the saddest heart. A private burial will take place in Queens, NY and a Memorial Celebration of his life will be held on Long Boat Key, FL, at a later date. Shiva will be held at the home of James Silbert, July 29th and 30th, 2007, between 5:30pm and 9:00pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Florida Studio Theater, 1241 North Palm Avenue, Sarasota, Florida 34236; Circus of Sarasota, 8251 15th Street, East B, Sarasota, FL 34243; or Temple Beth Israel, 567 Bay Isles Road, Long Boat Key, FL 34228.

CAREY--Edward. Beloved husband of Roberta. Devoted stepfather of Steven Rosetti (Nancy) and Michael Rosetti (Victoria). Cherished grandfather of Hannah, Eve, Isaac and Samuel. Dear brother of Mary Carey. Services Sunday 11:15am ''Sinai Chapels'' 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

With a second consecutive night of singing and dancing reality shows, Fox finished No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday. The network began the night in the lead, as an hourlong ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' drew 8.5 million viewers at 8 p.m., Nielsen estimated. Following it at 9, Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance'' results edition (9.2 million) posted the night's highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, although a repeat of CBS's ''CSI'' edged ahead in total viewers (9.3 million). CBS ranked second over all, winning at 10 with ''Shark'' (8.2 million) and earning a solid second place at 8 with ''Big Brother'' (7.1 million). NBC finished third for the night. ABC trailed, in fourth place. Earlier in the week, two new cable series made notable debuts. On Tuesday at 10, FX's ''Damages,'' with Glenn Close, delivered 3.7 million viewers, making it the night's most watched program on basic cable. And on Monday, TNT's ''Saving Grace,'' with Holly Hunter, attracted 6.4 million total viewers, more than any other new series premiere on basic cable this year. Boosting the 10 p.m. show, TNT's 9 p.m. offering, ''The Closer,'' drew 7.3 million viewers.

The novelist and critic Wilfrid Sheed begins ''The House That George Built,'' his impassioned history of American songwriting in the first half of the 20th century, with a grand assertion. Irving Berlin, George Gershwin, Jerome Kern, Cole Porter and Richard Rodgers collectively more than doubled the world's supply of singable tunes, he declares. This work ''constitutes far and away our greatest contribution to the world's art supply in the so-called American century.'' Wow! That's laying it on the line. Then he pretends to demolish his own argument by admitting that a literature consisting ''entirely of epigrams and haiku, or at most sonnets,'' has obvious limitations. But he still refuses to take it back. ''What's wrong with being hungry again?'' he asks. Aren't Oscar Wilde's one-liners better than his plays?

Nicole Richie, right, will soon follow in the footsteps of Paris Hilton, her co-star on the reality show ''The Simple Life,'' by spending some time behind bars. Ms. Richie pleaded guilty yesterday in Superior Court in Glendale, Calif., to driving under the influence of drugs. She was sentenced to 90 hours in jail and fined $2,048, Reuters reported. CommissionerSteven K. Lubell of Superior Court told Ms. Richie, 25, that she was lucky nobody was killed when she drove the wrong way on a Burbank freeway on Dec. 11. ''If you continue to drive while under the influence of drugs or alcohol and someone gets killed, you can be charged with murder, not manslaughter,'' he told her. Ms. Richie must complete her sentence by Sept. 28 and will also have to enroll in a treatment program and prove that she has completed it when she returns to court on Feb. 20.

An obituary on Thursday about the cinematographer Laszlo Kovacs misspelled the surname of a fellow Hungarian cinematographer at two points. As noted elsewhere in the obituary, he is Vilmos Zsigmond, not Szigmond. The obituary also misstated the date of the Robert Altman film ''That Cold Day in the Park,'' on which Mr. Kovacs worked, and referred incorrectly to it. It was released in 1969, not 1970, and it was Mr. Altman's third feature as a director, not his ''first venture into longer narrative filmmaking.''

ZANKEL--Arthur. Husband, father, brother, grandfather. Your time ended too soon but we are blessed to have had you in our lives. We love you; you are with us in our hearts and minds forever. Judy; Kenny and Anna; Tommy; Mark and Susan; Jimmy and Pia

LEVKOFF--Yetta D., 91, of Charleston SC. Loving and beloved wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and friend, passed away in Charleston, SC July 26, 2007, surrounded by her three children: Jennie L. DeScherer (Richard K.), Michael S. Levkoff, Dr. Sue Levkoff (James Maxwell). Also survived by six grandchildren and two great-grandchildrn. Donations in her memory can be made to The Lupus Research Institute, 330 7th Ave. Suite 1701, NYC 10001.

NELKIN--Myron. You have been our inspiration, mentor and, most of all, the greatest father and grandfather a family could have ever been blessed with. Your generosity and tremendous heart will be remembered forever. You were larger than life to us all. You were a brilliant man, and the legacy you built will be carried on by the family you loved. We are surrounded by everything you accom plished, and your heart and soul will never leave us. You are our superhero, and we know superheroes live forever. Watch down on us, and continue to guide us through life. We love you, Dad. From your children, Henry, Mindy, Cathy and Charlie NELKIN--Myron. Grandpa, we miss you so much. You were the best grandfather in the whole world, and we are blessed for having known you, loved you, and for being loved by you. You taught us the meaning of hard work and integrity. Each of us hopes to be half the person you were and would consider that a wonderful life. To watch you lead others and help those who were in need has inspired us to do great things with our lives. Even though you had to leave us, we will think of you as we confront every decision and know you would be proud. Thank you for being so present in our lives. You were a force of strength, and we will strive to fulfill the expectations you had for us. The family was everything to you. Now its our turn to carry on your traditions. We love you. Love, your grandchildren, Rachel, Johnny, Jimmy, and Robbie NELKIN--Myron. A loving husband, father, and grandfather, a visionary real estate developer, a friend and mentor to his employees, a generous supporter of a variety of charitable causes, and an avid golfer in his spare time, Myron Nelkin passed away on Sunday, July 22, at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. Born in Brooklyn on January 5, 1925, Mr. Nelkin was a student at Boys High in Brooklyn and graduated from Columbia University with a degree in business in 1946. With his father, Harry L. Nelkin, DDS, he began his working life building homes in Queens and Long Island. He founded three companies, Fairhaven Properties, Nelkin Construction Corp., and Central Management, and built all of Long Island's Fairhaven apartment complexes and the Woodbury Gardens senior residence. What Mr. Nelkin considered his crowning achievement was the rebuilding of The Garden City Hotel on the site of the storied original, where Charles Lindbergh slept in 1927 on the night before his trans-Atlantic flight. The completely new construction opened in 1983 on 21 acres in the heart of Garden City. Lavishly landscaped and decorated, lively and bright, the acclaimed establishment maintains a sense of its place in the history of Long Island, as Mr. Nelkin wished. When in New York, he called the penthouse suite his home. Mr. Nelkin generously supported the Helen Keller Home for the Blind, the North ShoreLong Island Jewish Health System, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Family Services of Nassau County, Christa House, the Hart Foundation for Parkinson's Research, and the Tilles Center, as well as Jewish philanthropies and causes. He is survived by his wife, Barbara (nee Norinsberg); his children, Henry L. Nelkin, Mindy Nelkin, and Cathy Nelkin-Miller and her husband, Charles Miller; his grandchildren, Rachel, John, and James Schwartz and Robert Miller; and his brother and sister-inlaw, William and Trudi Nelkin. A private interment was held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont. NELKIN--Myron. My darling husband, I miss you already. The children and I are heartbroken. Thank you for providing us with a life full of wonderful, loving memories and for being our hero. Our love for you will live on, and you will live in our hearts and souls forever. Kisses and hugs, Barbara

PRIOR--Rev. Eugene. The Faculty of Loyola School is deeply grateful for the dedicated service of Fr. Eugene J. Prior, S.J. Teacher, Moderator, Student Counselor, and Assistant Headmaster. Gene epitomized the spirit of St. Ignatius' Prayer for Generosity in his selfless devotion to and inspiring enthusiasm for our students and our School. We are forever thankful for his wise counsel and unwavering support as our colleague and companion in the mission of Jesuit education. James F.X. Lyness, Headmaster, Stephen Katsouros, S.J., President. PRIOR--Rev. Eugene J., S.J., died on July 24, 2007. Fr. Prior, the son of the late Eugene and Elizabeth Prior and brother of the late Thomas ''Happy'' Prior, was born in the Bronx in 1924 and attended Fordham Prep and Fordham University. He entered the Society of Jesus in February, 1943, and was ordained a priest in June, 1955. Fr. Prior taught at Regis High School and The Loyola School. In 1962 he became a Spiritual Director for Students at The Loyola School and subsequently served as Assistant Headmaster, Dean of Students and, since 2001, Vice President for Alumni and External Affairs. Friends may call Sunday, July 29, 29pm and Monday, July 30, 25pm at The Loyola School Alumni Gymnasium at Park Ave and E. 83rd St. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday at 7pm, at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Park Ave at 84th. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Fr. Eugene Prior Scholarship Fund at The Loyola School will be gratefully accepted.

GELLER--Adele, July 26, 2007. Beloved wife of Stanley. Loving mother of George, Alice and her husband Scott Levine, much loved grandmother of Kate, Sarah, William and David. Devoted sister of Howard Robinson. She lived with grace, style and dignity and will be deeply missed. Service Monday, July 30, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Tony Blair's first day as the special envoy of the so-called quartet of Middle East peacemakers referred imprecisely to the population of Palestinian refugees and their descendants, whose fates are a core issue in the Arab-Israeli conflict. Although Palestinians and their descendants who are registered as refugees by the United Nations now number about 4.5 million, only about 700,000 Palestinians -- not ''millions'' -- fled or were forced to flee during the era when the state of Israel was created. Also because of an editing error, the article referred incorrectly to the time frame during which the first Palestinians left their homes. Most left before and during the 1948 war, not afterward.

GINSBURG--Rita M., died on her 89th birthday, July 20th, 2007. She was a highly respected book designer at Prentice Hall. She and her husband, the late Albert Ginsburg, were involved in integrating Stuyvesant Town. Survived by a daughter, son, brother and their families, grandchildren, nieces and nephews.

The Spice Girls have announced three more dates on their upcoming tour, adding shows in Shanghai; San Jose, Calif.; and Vancouver, British Columbia. Last month the group announced 11 dates, beginning with a concert in Los Angeles on Dec. 7. The six-continent tour will begin on Dec. 2 in Vancouver. There may be more dates to come: on the group's Web site, fans can vote for the Spice Girls to visit their city. With enough votes, new dates and locations will be added.

RODRIGUEZ--Mario B., of NYC, 60, passed in peace July 24, 2007. Law Librarian with White & Case. A gentle nature could not disguise his wry wit. We bid him a fond adieu as he journeys to Light. He is survived by his mother, two sisters, nieces, nephews and brother-in-law. Services 10:30am July 30, St. Bartholomew's Chapel, 51st St. and Park Ave., NYC. Family requests donations to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

David Hans Schmidt was arrested by F.B.I. agents in Los Angeles on Tuesday, accused of demanding more than $1 million in exchange for not publishing stolen photographs of Tom Cruise'swedding, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Schmidt, 47, who has made several other deals involving compromising celebrity pictures and videos in the past, approached representatives for the actor several weeks ago, asking for money.

To mark the 30th anniversary of Elvis Presley's death on Aug. 16, the cable channel TV Land commissioned a life-size statue of the King that made its first appearance on Thursday at the site of his 1973 ''Aloha From Hawaii'' concert, The Associated Press reported. The 1,100-pound bronze statue, above, shows Presley the way he looked during the concert, the first to be broadcast via satellite. It reached more than a billion television viewers worldwide.

FOGARTY--Dr. Thomas F., on July 26. Services by Lloyd Maxcy & Sons Beauchamp Chapel, (914) 632-2700. FOGARTY--Dr. Thomas F., 79, of Pelham, NY. One of the nations leading family psychiatrists passed away July 26th after a lengthy illness. Cofounder, Center for Family Learning, faculty, Albert Einstein Medical Center, St. John's University and Iona College. SCHLEIFMAN--George, 95, died July 26. He is survived by his two children, Noel and his wife Sandra, and Roslyn and her husband Donald, three grandchildren, Adam, Shari and Scott, two great-grandchildren, Ryan and Joshua. Funeral Services Sunday, July 29, 11am at the New Montefiore Cemetery.

A chart yesterday about hospital-acquired infections at a Veterans Affairs hospital in Pittsburgh omitted a label describing the data. The chart showed a substantial decline in the infection rate in a 40-bed surgical unit at the hospital -- not in the hospital as a whole.

Patrick Thomas, the elusive chief executive at Hermès -- elusive to reporters and analysts at least -- seemed downright expansive over lunch recently at his hotel only a few blocks from his new store in New York City's financial district. The company's Wall Street store opening was several days away, but the windows were already done: a motorcycle with a black leather outfit on one side ($5,700), and a deconstructed horse sculpture on the other, with a superb black saddle resting on the window ledge, safely behind glass. ($4,500).

Unless China adopts a tougher stance toward Sudan over the continuing conflict in Darfur, the 2008 Beijing Olympics may lose its artistic adviser. The director Steven Spielberg, above, is considering stepping down from his post, ABC News and Reuters reported, but his decision partly depends on a statement on Sudan by the Chinese government that is expected in the coming days. ''Steven will make a determination in the next few weeks,'' his spokesman Andy Spahn told abcnews.com. ''Our main interest is ending the genocide. No one is clear on the best way to do this.'' China, an investor in Sudan's oil industry, has so far resisted sending United Nations peacekeepers to the Darfur region, and Mr. Spielberg has been criticized -- most notably by the actress Mia Farrow-- for not using his position to prod the Chinese government into action.

NUNNALLE--Francoise, age 70, died July 23rd, 2007 in New York City ending her long vicious battle with complicated and overwhelming medical problems. She fought with fierce bravery and impeccable dignity during her life so she could live for what she loved-her friends and familyart, music, flowers and her cats. She resided in Manhattan and Lenox, MA. Francoise was an international fine arts dealer -antique textile, linen and lace collector, but was especially known for her exceptional collection of original Mariano Fortuny fabrics. She also handmade pillows from her textiles for private collectors and interior designers. She leaves her darling husband Jim, her third pair of oriental shorthairs, little Bonnie and Clyde, and all the friends who adored her and loved her greatly including her deeply spiritual sister Georgianna and four fine nephews; Philip, Ricky, Michael and Haleem. A celebration and memorial luncheon will be announced in the fall for all who knew her and appreciated her kind and generous spirit and extraordinary persona. She would prefer all memorial donations to be given to the ASPCA-or a tree planted somewhere in her name so the world may be a bit more beautiful, kinder, and greener.

ROSENBERG--Sally Greenbaum, passed away on July 26, 2007. Dearly loved by devoted husband Warren Rosenberg, four children: Jan, John, David and Dale Schroedel, eight grandchildren, two great-grandchildren, brother Eddie, and many friends. Strong, vibrant, passionate and loving, she will be greatly missed. Graveside gathering for family and friends on Sunday, July 29, 11:45am at Westchester Hills Cemetery, 400 Saw Mill River Road, Hastings on Hudson, NY, 914-478-1767. Donations may be made to Alzheimer's Association.

An obituary on June 30 about Rabbi Abraham J. Klausner, who aided Holocaust survivors, erroneously attributed a distinction to him. It was Rabbi Eli Bohnen -- not Rabbi Klausner -- who was the first Jewish chaplain in the United States Army to arrive at the Dachau concentration camp after its liberation in 1945. (Within a few days of Rabbi Bohnen's arrival, his unit moved on in pursuit of German troops, and Rabbi Klausner replaced him.)

JACOBSON--Dr. Burton R., on July 26, 2007. Loving husband to Harriet (Citrin). Devoted father of Elliot Jacobson (Eleanor Ostrow), Jonathan Jacobson, and Robin Jacobson (Kenn Rabin) and grandfather of Sam, Jack, Gil and Daniel. Funeral Service Sunday 11am, Scarsdale Synagogue/Tremont Temple. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery. Memorial donations to Democratic National Committee.

My Monday column will be about whether the electorate has built-in biases (suspicion of markets, suspicion of international exchanges, etc.) that lead to less than optimal outcomes from democracies. I argue that high schools could attempt to address the problem by teaching economics and statistics, as one small step in the right direction. I'd welcome your comments.

When Alex Rodriguez hit his 39th homer on Sept. 7, 1998, it put him one long ball shy of a milestone. He had already stolen 40 bases, and he badly wanted to join Jose Canseco and Barry Bonds as the only members of the 40/40 club.

Barry Bonds was warming up in left field before Saturday's game when he stopped to listen to a special message on the center-field scoreboard. It was Wayne Gretzky, who was known as the Great One, speaking to Bonds, who is close to becoming the greatest home run hitter ever.

Sam Querrey, a 19-year-old from California, defeated James Blake, 7-6 (10), 6-7 (7), 7-6 (7), to reach the semifinals of an ATP hardcourt tournament yesterday in Indianapolis. Querrey had 34 aces, including nine in a row over three games of the second set. Querrey advanced to play third-seeded Dmitry Tursunov of Russia. Top-seeded Andy Roddick and Frank Dancevic of Canada play in the other semifinal.

Freddy Adu was given permission by Real Salt Lake to travel to Portugal in an attempt to complete transfer negotiations with Benfica.Major League Soccer and Benfica have already agreed to a $2 million transfer fee for Adu, who was the captain of the United States team at this year’s FIFA Under-20 World Cup.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 28 (AP) — The Baseball Hall of Fame’s directors voted Saturday to cut the size of the veterans committee and the number of players it will consider for future enshrinement.

In an attempt to become eligible for the 2008 Beijing Olympics, the suspended United States sprinter Justin Gatlin will appeal a possible eight-year doping ban tomorrow. Lawyers for Gatlin will make the case behind closed doors in Atlanta. (AP).

Sania Mirza advanced to her first WTA Tour final in two years with a grueling three-set victory against Sybille Bammer at the Bank of the West Classic in Stanford, Calif. Mirza outlasted Bammer, 6-2, 5-7, 6-3. She will play the winner of a later match between top-seeded Anna Chakvetadze and third-seeded Daniela Hantuchova.

Frank Dancevic used 15 aces to eliminate an ailing Andy Roddick, 6-4, 7-6 (1), yesterday and advance to the final of the ATP harcourt tournament in Indianapolis, where he will face Dimitry Tursunov of Russia.Roddick, the top seed, said he began to feel ill in the first set, bothered by what he called “a stomach bug or something.”Tursunov, the No. 3 seed, reached the final by stopping James Querrey, 7-6 (5), 6-2.

Carlos Moyá of Spain and Andrei Pavel of Romania advanced to the final of the Croatia Open.Moyá has a chance to win the tournament for the fifth time after defeating Argentina’s Guillermo Cañas, 6-3, 6-2, in one semifinal. Pavel defeated the Serbian qualifier Viktor Troicki, 6-3, 6-3.

The Maggie Dixon Classic has found a home at Madison Square Garden.The second Maggie Dixon Classic will be played Dec. 8. It will be the first women’s basketball doubleheader at the Garden since 1981. Rutgers will play Army in one game, and Duke will face Pittsburgh. Dixon died April 6, 2006, of arrhythmia, probably caused by an enlarged heart. Her death came three weeks after the end of her first season as the coach at Army.

Upper Deck has removed all Michael Vick autographed memorabilia from its online store and will remove his trading card from N.F.L. sets that are scheduled to be released in October.Vick has pleaded not guilty to federal dogfighting charges in Richmond, Va.
Anthony Reyes ended a 12-game regular-season losing streak last night that began last September, helping the host St. Louis Cardinals defeat the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-2, to sweep a doubleheader.
The Yankees remain pessimistic about their chances of landing a reliever through a trade before Tuesday’s nonwaiver trading deadline.

India’s Sachin Tendulkar became only the third batsman in history to score 11,000 Test runs on the second day of the second test against England yesterday in Nottingham. Tendulkar, 34, was playing his 139th test. The others to reach 11,000 are the world record-holder Brian Lara (11,953) and the former Australia captain Allan Border (11,174).

Juli Inkster shot a three-under-par 69 yesterday to lead by two shots and Michelle Wie had an 84 after the third round of the Evian Masters in Evian-les-Bains, France. Inkster finished at six-under 210 on a tough day for scoring because of swirling winds, tricky flag positions and difficult greens. Only seven players broke par.Jang Jeong of South Korea is second after a 72. Tied for third, three strokes back, are Sophie Gustafson of Sweden (72), Shin Ji-yai of South Korea (70) and Diana D’Alessio of the United States (76).

Arizona infielder Donnie Sadler was suspended for 50 games yesterday after testing positive for a drug of abuse under baseball’s minor league program. Sadler, 32, has played for Boston, Cincinnati, Kansas City, Texas and Arizona in eight major league seasons. He is the 20th player suspended this year under the minor league program, the sixth for a drug of abuse.

Top-seeded Francesca Schiavone will play Yvonne Meusburger in today’s final of the Gastein Ladies tournament in Bad Gastein, Austria. Schiavone defeated Kaia Kanepi of Estonia, 6-4, 6-2, in one semifinal yesterday, while Meusburger defeated seventh-seeded Karin Knapp of Italy, 6-1, 3-6, 6-3, in the other.It will be Schiavone’s first final of the season and Meusburger’s first of her career.

A week after his surprising third-place finish in the British Open, Andrés Romero shot a nine-under-par 63 yesterday to take the third-round lead at the Deutsche Bank Players’ Championship in Alveslohe, Germany. Romero, who has never won on the European Tour, is at 17-under 199, two strokes ahead of Zane Scotland going into today’s final round. Romero, who squandered a late lead at the Open, collected two eagles and five birdies and went bogey free. “I try to birdie every single hole,” Romero said. “I’m going to go out and play as I did today.”.

Juan Monaco and Potito Starace advanced to the final of the Austrian Open yesterday in Kitzbühel. Monaco beat 11th-seeded Fernando Verdasco, 7-5, 7-5, while Starace upset the defending champion, Agustin Calleri, 6-4, 7-5, in the semifinals.The fifth-seeded Monaco is going for his third career title. The 10th-seeded Starace will be trying for his first tournament victory. “This is an unbelievable success for me,” Starace said. “I did not expect to beat Calleri, but my serve went really well and gave me a lot of confidence.”.

An article on July 15 about efforts by state and local governments to raise revenue without raising taxes, including such approaches as selling naming rights for stadiums, referred incorrectly to the San Francisco stadium once known as Candlestick Park. It is now called Monster Park, not AT&T Park. Also, the article attributed an erroneous distinction to Utah. It is one of two states — not the only one — without some form of legalized gambling, another way states raise revenue. (Hawaii is the other state.).

9 A.M. (Discovery) SHARK WEEK For the 20th year running, the Discovery Channel will devote a week’s worth of programming to stories intended to make you think twice before dipping a toe into that inviting surf. Among today’s highlights: “Ocean of Fear: Worst Shark Attack Ever,” a two-hour special at 9 p.m., narrated by Richard Dreyfuss, about the attack that occurred after the sinking of the U.S.S. Indianapolis during World War II. The tale, in which 800 injured sailors were menaced by hundreds of sharks in the Philippine Sea, is recreated using real sharks and some of the actual survivors, who may have had second thoughts about living through the experience again. Shark Week programming runs from 9 a.m. to 3 a.m. every day through Saturday. (Les Stroud, the host, is above.).

An article on the Collecting page last Sunday about the final years of Auburn, Cord and Duesenberg referred incorrectly to the use of the tooling for the Cord 810 and 812 after those cars ceased production. The Hupp Motor Car Corporation, which bought the tooling, agreed to let another automaker, Graham-Paige, use it for a car called the Graham Hollywood; Hupp did not introduce the Hollywood. (Hupp did sell a similar car called the Skylark, which was manufactured by Graham-Paige.) In addition, the article misspelled the name of the car line that sold the Skylark. FOGARTY--Dr. Thomas F., 79, of Pelham, NY. One of the nations leading family psychiatrists passed away July 26th after a lengthy illness. Teacher, author and clinical pioneer in the development of the theory and practice of family psychotherapy. Cofounder, Center for Family Learning, faculty, Albert Einstein Medical Center, St. John's University and Iona College. His clinical research on family systems had widespread influence in this country and abroad. On behalf of the thousands of Westchester families he helped, we mourn his passing. VANCOUVER ARTS SCENE To the Editor: Regarding ''36 Hours in Vancouver'' by Marc Weingarten (July 15): Anyone active in contemporary art could tell you that, contrary to Mr. Weingarten's assertion, Vancouver is very well-known for its art scene, whether one is thinking of artists of international fame (Jeff Wall, Rodney Graham, Stan Douglas, and Brian Jungen, to name a few), of prominent galleries such as Catriona Jeffries, Monte Clark and Tracey Lawrence, or of ambitious and lively nonprofit spaces including the Contemporary Art Gallery, the Western Front and Artspeak. That person could also tell you that the reason the ''terrific'' Vancouver Art Gallery (above) is ''more like a museum'' is that it is in fact a museum -- the city's main art museum at that.

SUMMERS RACE BY in a happy blur at Camp Half Moon in the Berkshire Hills of Western Massachusetts. From the 7:30 a.m. flag-raising to lights out, counselors guide sleep-over and day campers from the ages of 3 to 16 through a host of activities, including swimming, sailing, archery, basketball, singing and skits at weekly campfires, all designed to boost confidence without competitive overkill. Although the counselors, who hail from all over the world, spend their on-duty hours in a uniform of camp-issue T-shirts, shorts and jeans, off duty they let loose in, well, T-shirts, shorts and jeans. ''I own one suit,'' said Ross Hutcheson, 24, of Scotland, the head of the boys' camp, ''and I've worn it twice, to a wedding and a funeral.''

STEINFELD--Fay, formerly of Peekskill, NY and Hallandale, FL, died of natural causes in the Bronx, NY, on July 25th, 2007 at the age of 88. She was a music lover, amateur violinist, and reader. Born Feiga Tema Blei in New York City, she was the widow of Joseph Steinfeld. She is survived by her daughter Marcia Steinfeld and son-inlaw Mark Kalman of Albany, California, son, Dr. Alan Steinfeld and daughter-in-law Dr. Rena Sperber Steinfeld of Scarsdale, NY, and son, Dr. Harvey Steinfeld, and daughter-in-law Kay Peacock Steinfeld of Annapolis, Maryland. She is also survived by a sister, Betty Conlan, a niece Valerie Conlan and her husband Bela Horvath. She took great delight in her six grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Services were held graveside at Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, New York on July 27, 2007. She was deeply loved and will be remembered for her eternal optimism, humor, love and devotion to her family.

NELKIN--Myron. You have been our inspiration, mentor and, most of all, the greatest father and grandfather a family could have ever been blessed with. Your generosity and tremendous heart will be remembered forever. You were larger than life to us all. You were a brilliant man, and the legacy you built will be carried on by the family you loved. We are surrounded by everything you accom plished, and your heart and soul will never leave us. You are our superhero, and we know superheroes live forever. Watch down on us, and continue to guide us through life. We love you, Dad. From your children, Henry, Mindy, Cathy and Charlie NELKIN--Myron. Grandpa, we miss you so much. You were the best grandfather in the whole world, and we are blessed for having known you, loved you, and for being loved by you. You taught us the meaning of hard work and integrity. Each of us hopes to be half the person you were and would consider that a wonderful life. To watch you lead others and help those who were in need has inspired us to do great things with our lives. Even though you had to leave us, we will think of you as we confront every decision and know you would be proud. Thank you for being so present in our lives. You were a force of strength, and we will strive to fulfill the expectations you had for us. The family was everything to you. Now its our turn to carry on your traditions. We love you. Love, your grandchildren, Rachel, Johnny, Jimmy, and Robbie NELKIN--Myron. My darling husband, I miss you already. The children and I are heartbroken. Thank you for providing us with a life full of wonderful, loving memories and for being our hero. Our love for you will live on, and you will live in our hearts and souls forever. Kisses and hugs, Barbara NELKIN--Myron. A loving husband, father, and grandfather, a visionary real estate developer, a friend and mentor to his employees, a generous supporter of a variety of charitable causes, and an avid golfer in his spare time, Myron Nelkin passed away on Sunday, July 22, at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. Born in Brooklyn on January 5, 1925, Mr. Nelkin was a student at Boys High in Brooklyn and graduated from Columbia University with a degree in business in 1946. With his father, Harry L. Nelkin, DDS, he began his working life building homes in Queens and Long Island. He founded three companies, Fairhaven Properties, Nelkin Construction Corp., and Central Management, and built all of Long Island's Fairhaven apartment complexes and the Woodbury Gardens senior residence. What Mr. Nelkin considered his crowning achievement was the rebuilding of The Garden City Hotel on the site of the storied original, where Charles Lindbergh slept in 1927 on the night before his trans-Atlantic flight. The completely new construction opened in 1983 on 21 acres in the heart of Garden City. Lavishly landscaped and decorated, lively and bright, the acclaimed establishment maintains a sense of its place in the history of Long Island, as Mr. Nelkin wished. When in New York, he called the penthouse suite his home. Mr. Nelkin generously supported the Helen Keller Home for the Blind, the North ShoreLong Island Jewish Health System, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Family Services of Nassau County, Christa House, the Hart Foundation for Parkinson's Research, and the Tilles Center, as well as Jewish philanthropies and causes. He is survived by his wife, Barbara (nee Norinsberg); his children, Henry L. Nelkin, Mindy Nelkin, and Cathy Nelkin-Miller and her husband, Charles Miller; his grandchildren, Rachel, John, and James Schwartz and Robert Miller; and his brother and sister-inlaw, William and Trudi Nelkin. A private interment was held at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont.

An article last Sunday about Linda Troeller's photographs of Chelsea Hotel residents misstated Andy Warhol's involvement with the hotel. Though some of his associates lived there, and though he filmed the movie ''Chelsea Girls'' there, he never lived in the hotel.

After her much-honored work '' 'A Problem From Hell': America and the Age of Genocide'' appeared in 2002, Samantha Power was widely regarded as an expert on genocide. But as she explains in an e-mail message, she always saw her book as being more about American foreign policy, since ''it showed the U.S. government's systematic and deadly tendency to exclude considerations of human consequences in its decision making.'' Today, along with teaching at Harvard's Kennedy School, she writes for such publications as The New Yorker and The New York Review of Books. She also consulted for the Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama. Later this year she will become a foreign policy columnist for Time magazine, and she is completing work on a new book, ''Chasing the Flame: Sergio Vieira de Mello and the Fight to Save the World,'' about the United Nations peacemaker killed by a suicide bomb in Iraq. She views his death in August 2003 as a turning point in a war she calls ''the greatest strategic blunder in the history of U.S. foreign policy.'' Like Washington's history of ignoring genocide, Power says, the Iraq war is ''further proof'' of the need to overcome the United States government's ''systemic insensitivity to human consequences.'' The Editors

You can almost feel the jubilation in Albany these days, and hear the sighs of relief. Now that Gov. Eliot Spitzer has received his political comeuppance -- two aides caught trying to smear the governor's chief Republican opponent -- a lot of Mr. Spitzer's loftiest reforms are stalled, if not off the table. And instead of the much-needed new day the governor promised in January, the political rats are returning to the state ship.

BORCHARDT--Alice Allen O'Brien, born on the 6th of October 1939 and raised in New Orleans, LA, died on Tuesday, the 24th of July 2007 in Houston, TX. She was the beloved wife of Clifford Borchardt for 38 years. Daughter of the late Howard and Katherine O'Brien. Survived by her sisters, Anne O'Brien Rice, Rancho Mirage, CA; Tamara O'Brien Tinker, Daly City, CA; Karen O'Brien, Dallas, TX and Micki O'Brien Jenkins, Dallas, TX. Also survived by nephews Christopher T. Rice, Los Angeles, CA and Daniel Tinker, Oakland, CA. She lived for many years in Houston, TX and was a licensed vocational nurse. She fulfilled her dream of becoming a successful novelist with the publication of her first novel Devoted. It was published in 1995. She was also the author of six other books including The Silver Wolf and The Raven Warrior. Alice was, from an early childhood, a voracious reader. Largely self-educated, she took great pleasure in the historical background and details of her novels. She loved to write battle scenes. Her hobbies included raising orchids, and she loved her pet cats. A memorial service will be held at two o'clock in the afternoon on Saturday, the 4th of August 2007 in the Jasek Chapel of Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, 1010 Bering Drive, Houston, TX. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be directed to the American Cancer Society. Eternal rest grant unto them, 0 Lord. And let perpetual light shine upon them. May they rest in peace. Amen. May their souls and the souls of all the faithful departed, through the mercy of God, rest in peace. Geo. H. Lewis & Sons Houston 713.789.3005

AMERICANS have used the run-up in real estate values in recent years to build financial flexibility for themselves, and many homeowners reasonably believe they can use their home equity for last-minute emergencies. But if they wait until an emergency actually strikes to apply for a home-equity loan, they may be in for a painful shock, financial advisers and mortgage executives say. The very nature of some financial emergencies, like unemployment, may disqualify an applicant from a loan.
