MARILEE JONES, former dean of admissions at M.I.T., claimed three phantom degrees when applying for an entry-level job there 28 years ago, a disclosure that led to her messy departure last semester. Actually, the bachelor's she did have was all she needed to get a foot in the door at most admissions offices. It's those in the top jobs -- officers and deans who read and decide on applications -- who require advanced degrees. And most get them as they work their way up.

Suzanne Carole Lamm, the daughter of Dr. Carin Lamm and Dr. Steven Lamm, both of New York, is to be married today to Evan Michael Roberts, the son of Barbara and David Roberts of Boston. Rabbi David Lincoln is to officiate at the Central Park Boathouse. The bride, 27, is a fourth-year medical student at the New York College of Osteopathic Medicine, part of the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, N.Y. She is also completing work for a master's in public health at Boston University. She graduated magna cum laude from Colgate University.

New musicals, like New Yorkers, benefit from summers in the country, where the air is clean and the vultures are on vacation. Among the best places to find the neonate shows nesting is the Berkshires. The WILLIAMSTOWN THEATER FESTIVAL usually has one or two on the schedule; the current season's offerings started with B. D. Wong in ''Herringbone'' in June and continue with ''Party Come Here,'' which opened officially on Thursday. That comedy, about a mismatched young couple seeking enlightenment in Rio -- where they meet, among other unlikely characters, a 500-year-old Jewish caveman -- is stuffed in the Williamstown manner with Broadway talent, from the director (Christopher Ashley) and cast (Hunter Foster, Malcolm Gets, Kate Reinders) to the designers. One thing not of Broadway quality: the seats. They're much better. Through next Sunday, '62 Center for Theater and Dance, Williamstown, Mass., (413) 597-3400, wtfestival.org; $37 to $39.

To the Editor: ''Mandatory Fairness,'' by Dirk Olin (Op-Ed, July 22), raises legitimate concerns about the use of arbitration to resolve employment and consumer disputes. However, making it easier to sue arbitrators would not address those concerns.

THERE was a time, not so long ago, when everybody -- well, everybody but me -- knew which safety schools to apply to. Tufts was a fallback for Ivy League applicants. Washington University in St. Louis was a security blanket for Midwesterners like my brother, who wanted to go to Northwestern. And Grinnell, in Iowa, was a sure bet for my husband, a B student from a New England prep school.

EVERY institution of higher learning has a slogan -- something about truth or character strengthening. Then there are the unofficial slogans. The alumni association at Biola University in Southern California, for example, found ironic inspiration in football (it has none). The double entendre celebrating Smith's centennial -- the winner of a slogan contest -- is still quotable more than 30 years later. The mark of a successful saying: Is it T-shirt worthy?

LEVKOFF--Yetta D., 91, of Charleston SC. DeScherer (Richard K.), Michael S. Levkoff, Dr. Sue Levkoff (James Maxwell). Also survived by six grandchildren and two great-grandchildrn. von DRAN--Raymond F. Adoring husband and father, esteemed professor and dean emeritus of the Syracuse University School of Information Studies, pioneering leader in the field of information, innovative thinker and academic, beloved friend and mentor, nurturer of and believer in young talent, art and music aficionado, and bearer of a child-like spirit, Raymond F. von Dran passed away Monday, July 23 at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in New York City. He was 60. Born on July 31, 1946, in Elizabeth, New Jersey, Ray grew up a single child, learning from his father the value of an education. He instilled in Ray the love for reading, including his favorite book, Tootle. Ray presented copies of the book to May 2007 graduates of the iSchool at Syracuse as a reminder to lay down their own tracks in life. Throughout his career, Ray broke new ground to help bring library and information science schools into the Information Age. A founding member of the I-Schools Group -a national consortium of academic institutions focused on the relationship between information and people -Ray was among a core group of visionaries who helped define the newly emerging academic field of information studies, examining how information, in all its forms, expands human capabilities. He led the iSchool at Syracuse through a 12-year period of unprecedented productivity (1995-2007), during which the number of faculty and students nearly tripled, sponsored research in creased five-fold, and four of the school's programs earned top-four rankings from U.S. News and World Report, including the top-ranked master's in information systems. All seven of the school's research centers were launched under his leadership, and several academic degree programs were instituted. Ray was also instrumental in increasing the school's endowment, recently helping to secure the largest gift in its 110-year history. Among his most striking legacies at the school is the notion of a ''faculty of one'' that has no traditional departments or divisions between the various degree programs and that encourages faculty to teach across disciplines. This unique culture supports innovative collaboration and a family-like environment for school members to teach and learn from each other. Syracuse often served as a model for other schools to emulate, and Ray advised them on how to establish such a collegial and productive workplace. Prior to joining SU, Ray served as dean of the information schools at The Catholic University of America and the University of North Texas. He received a Ph.D. in information science and master's degrees in library science and French intellectual history from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and bachelor's degrees in foreign languages and history from Seton Hall University. One of his greatest skills and accomplishments in life was making every person he encountered feel special and like an invaluable contributor to whatever task was at hand. He was unabashedly devoted to his wife and daughter, whom he looked to for support and inspiration. He is survived by wife, Gisela von Dran, of Syracuse, NY, and daughter, Beth von Dran, of Austin, Texas. In lieu of flowers, a fund has been established in Ray's honor. Donations can be directed to the SU Raymond F. von Dran Fund, School of Information Studies, Syracuse University, 343 Hinds Hall, Syracuse, NY 13244. There will be no public calling hours. A memorial service will be held on the Syracuse University campus in September.

Even after 25 years of learning the basics, most adults are still playing catch-up when it comes to conversing in emoticon-ese. Luckily, a seemingly limitless supply of emoticon dictionaries have accumulated on the Internet (several of which supplied the following examples), meaning fluency in this graphical lexicon is only a Google search away. As with any language, one should start slowly and master the handful of basic emoticons before moving on to more sophisticated -- and cryptic -- symbols. And remember, should one stumble, that it's not considered cheating to tilt the computer monitor sideways. ALEX WILLIAMS

LOWY--Sherman J. 80 years old, beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, passed away on July 24th, 2007 after a courageous battle with cancer. Sherman was born in Bronx NY, attended DeWitt Clinton High School, served in the US Navy as an electrician's mate during WWII and was graduated from Columbia University with a degree in Electrical Engineering. He joined Lowy and Donnath, Inc. in 1949 and, with his partner Anthony Scala, led a firm which became known for lighting many of NYC's landmark buildings. Sherman is survived by Jacqueline, his devoted wife of 58 years, his children Ann Udis of Philadelphia, Linda Lowy, of Los Angeles, Steven Lowy of New York City, James Lowy of Tampa, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2pm Sunday July 29th at Temple Beth El, Boca Raton FL. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to the charity of your choice.

He is survived by his wife Pearl, son Ray, daughter-in-law Lynn and grandson Casey, all of San Rafael, CA. Family may be contacted at ray@thelentfamily.com

The college dorm is a pretty intimidating setup, when you think about it. You're sharing a house with a few hundred of your peers. You know that at least some of them are destined to be your friends. These future allies are rattling around out there somewhere in this gigantic building. But how will they find you? How will they know that you're you, fascinating and smart and ready to bond?

KREEK--Louis Francis, Jr., died on July 23 in Akron, OH, at age 78. He was born in Washington, DC, and graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Chemical Engineering and George Washington University Law School. For 30 years he was a patent attorney at Merck Pharmaceuticals, the patent firm of Kenyon and Kenyon in New York City, Exxon Company in Elizabeth, NJ, and ICI in Wilmington, DE. In 1985, he moved to Akron, OH, to join the patent firm of Oldham and Oldham, working there until retirement. His wife Gwendolyn Scheopfle Kreek died in 2006 after a long illness. He was active in local and national Alumni Association fund raising for MIT; President of the Delaware Valley MIT Club from 1978-1980, and was later President of the Akron area MIT Club. Active in the Kiwanis Club in Akron, he was Lieutenant General of his local chapter for two years. In July 2007, he received the Past International President's Award from the Kiwanis Club at a luncheon honoring his outstanding service to the organization. He is survived by his sister, Mary Jeanne Kreek, MD, Professor and Head of Laboratory at The Rockefeller University (and her husband Robert A. Schaefer, MD), his nephew, Robert A. Schaefer, Jr., JD (and his wife, Heather Fain Schaefer), all of New York City, and his niece, Esperance Anne Kreek Schaefer, MD, MPH, of Boston, MA. The funeral will be held Saturday, July 28 at the UCC Church-Kent, OH. Memorial gifts may be made to Akron City Hospital-Summa's Palliative Care and Hospice Fund or The United Church of Christ-Kent, OH.

Alberto Contador appeared to seal the victory in the 94th Tour de France on Saturday by finishing fifth in the final time trial. He has a 23-second lead over his closest rival, Cadel Evans, with a day to go. Levi Leipheimer, Contador's teammate on the Discovery Channel team, won the time trial, his first stage victory at the Tour. Leipheimer recorded the fourth-fastest speed for a long time trial in the Tour, at 32.98 miles an hour over the 34.5-mile course that started in Cognac and ended in this town in Central France.

CLYMER--Warren. Loving husband of Gail and caring father of Jonathan, Catherine and Jeffrey. Production designer for Broadway, television and film. Died July 16 at age 84 in Manhattan. After high school, he canoed the Mississippi River from his birthplace, Davenport, Iowa to New Orleans. Served as a B-17 tail gunner during World War II. Graduated from the University of Iowa and Indiana University. Started in scenic design for summer stock productions and worked on Broadway under Jo Mielziner. Designed sets for the play ''Write Me a Murder'' starting a long collaboration with director George Schaefer, including numerous Hallmark Hall of Fame television productions at NBC. Nominated for seven Emmy awards for scenic design of Hallmark shows, winning twice in 1965 and 1966. Film credits include ''Alice's Restaurant'', ''A New Leaf'', ''Where's Poppa'' and ''The Godfather''. In 2001, he helped establish the World Memorial charity and contributed designs that serve as icons for the 9/11 tragedy.

In addition to appreciating Paul Taylor's importance as a choreographer, it is always a particular pleasure to see the sheer physicality of the dancing of the PAUL TAYLOR DANCE COMPANY. This week that dancing can be enjoyed in open-air close quarters, at the LINCOLN CENTER OUT OF DOORS festival. The first program, on Friday night, offers two works from the 1970s, ''Book of Beasts'' and Mr. Taylor's celebrated ''Esplanade,'' alongside his most recent piece, this year's ''Lines of Loss.'' Even more interesting is the second program, on Saturday night, which shows -- alongside ''Airs,'' ''Black Tuesday'' and ''Troilus & Cressida (reduced)'' -- the recently revived ''Profiles,'' a double duet created in 1979. ''Profiles'' was an early study for Mr. Taylor's ''Sacre du Printemps (The Rehearsal), made two years later to great acclaim. At 8 p.m., Damrosch Park Band Shell, 62nd Street near Amsterdam Avenue, (212) 875-5766, lincolncenter.org.

It's one step beyond flipflops. Students at Occidental College, in Los Angeles, and Reed College, in Portland, Ore., pad around without shoes, and not just on grass but in classrooms, the gym and the cafeteria. And not just in summer but winter, too (that's into the 30s in Oregon). Nobody is quite sure how it started. But Pooja Bhaskar, below, who will be a junior at Reed in the fall, explains: ''I don't exactly see it as some sort of barefoot lifestyle or big statement against the man. It's like climbing trees. Tree-dwelling lifestyle? No. Fun? Yes.'' JAMIE WALLIS

SKROBEK--Gerhard. Master Sculptor 1922-2007. On Sunday, July 1, 2007, Gerhard Skrobek, a renowned Master Sculptor of Goebel Hummel Figurines at Roedental, passed away near Coburg, Germany. Mr. Skrobek passed as a result of complications from heart surgery and leukemia. Mr. Skrobek was born in Leobschutz, Upper Silesia, Germany on May 20, 1922 to Gunther and Edith Kornblum Skrobek. Gerhard is survived by his wife Sieglinde, sons Martin and Stephan, and daughters Suzanne and Victoria in Germany as well as his sister Ingeborg Larsen in Northern California. Gerhard became a roving ambassador for the Goebel Hummel Works shortly after erecting a seven foot high ''Merry Wanderer'' in Terrytown, New York in 1972. Following that notable piece of work Gerhard made several tours to the United States, demonstrating his sculpting methods and drawing large crowds of loyal fans throughout the country. In 1976, Gerhard sculpted a bicentennial Bald Eagle for formal presentation to President Ford and Vice President Rockefeller. Gerhard grew up in Berlin during World War II with his parents and sister, Ingeborg. Gerhard's mother, Edith, was of Jewish descent prompting the Gestapo to cause the family great suffering. In 1944 Gerhard's Catholic father, Gunther, was imprisoned for refusing to divorce his Jewish wife. Although Edith made an effort to protect her family from persecution by converting to Catholicism, the Gestapo showed no mercy. Gerhard was forced to work in a bomb factory in Coburg and his sister Ingeborg was forced to work in a parachute factory in Berlin. Fearing for his mother and sister during heavy Berlin bomb raids, Gerhard escaped from Coburg to rescue them. Thanks to Gerhard's heroic efforts, they all boarded one of the last trains out of Berlin prior to the Russians arrival in April 1945. Gerhard is deeply missed by his family and adoring collectors.

I was surprised that none of the letters (July 15) on David Holmberg's July 1 On Language column about student evaluations raised questions about the ethics of his ''carefully and compulsively analyzing'' students' responses for evidence of the identities of those whose words wounded him. While professors cannot avoid moments of idle speculation on who might have said something hurtful or inaccurate, I think most of us stop there. Actively trying to identify the source makes the promise of anonymity a lie. This looks like a good topic for the Ethicist.

THE NEWS An investigation found that aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York acted improperly by using the State Police to try to learn whether Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, had acted improperly when traveling around the state at taxpayers' expense. BEHIND THE NEWS No lawbreaking has yet been found on either side, but Mr. Spitzer's image as a new broom bent on cleaning up Albany has suffered, and may suffer more if Mr. Bruno goes through with plans to hold a Senate inquiry and issue subpoenas to the governor and his aides, which Mr. Spitzer's office vowed to fight.

AS THE ME-ME-ME GENERATION swarmed over the first iPhones this month, Louis Vuitton produced the first collection of luxury cases to protect the coveted high-tech, high-style accessories. In a spectrum of colors and materials, some are far pricier than the object they were designed to swathe. The structured cases are molded to the iPhone for easy slide-out access (now that's technology at its most dazzling). Look for the company's signature monogram canvas (the least expensive at $225, third from top); the chic Epi, leather in bright colors (second from top); and the Taiga, also leather, with a geek-worthy belt clip (bottom). There's also alligator leather (top), which rings in at a rather reptilian $1,120. At Louis Vuitton boutiques.

BERGE--David J., 92, of Roslyn, NY and Phoenix, AZ, died peacefully on July 23rd. Husband of the late Theresa Hollick and father of Ginette, Denise and Richard. He served in the Navy in WWII and graduated from CCNY after the war. David started work as a bartender for the Brass Rail restaurant chain in New York at the World's Fair of 1939, and retired as President of the Brass Rail Corporation. He was a major figure in the New York restaurant world during the 1950s and 1960s. An innovator in World Fairs, he was responsible for the food service at the American Pavilion at the 1958 Brussells World's Fair and the 1964 New York World's Fair. He also created the Golden Door restaurant at Idlewild Airport, the Jones Beach Dinner Theater, and was a pioneer in corporate dining services. His sweet spirit and cheerful optimism will be missed. A memorial service to be planned.

Robert Novak says, ''I don't see how you can have obstruction of justice when there is no underlying crime,'' which, of course, is exactly the point (Deborah Solomon, July 15). You can't ''see'' the underlying crime if justice is obstructed in uncovering it. Novak says Scooter Libby didn't lie, he just got ''mixed up'' and ''confused'': ''That's why you need lawyers -- to make sure you don't get confused.'' He fails to note, however, that Scooter Libby not only had lawyers, he was one himself. Novak then apparently contradicts himself, saying he was very careful, in his own testimony, not to fabricate anything, implying, of course, that he knows Libby did just that.

Robert De Niro has his own film festival. Why shouldn't Paul Giamatti? After all, it's been 15 years since Mr. De Niro was nominated for an Oscar; Mr. Giamatti made it to the big dance just last year (with a supporting actor nomination for ''Cinderella Man''). The Brooklyn Academy of Music agrees: Beginning Wednesday it presents ''PAUL GIAMATTI SELECTS,'' an eight-movie series, stretching over six weeks, chosen by Mr. Giamatti, the actor's actor and Brooklyn Heights resident. In keeping with the smart but less-than-sunny characters he is known for playing, these films share an -- anxious? clammy? all right, paranoid -- outlook and a tendency toward the darkest of dark comedy.

Patricia T. O'Conner's analysis of the ubiquitous four-letter word ''like'' (On Language, July 15) was most discerning, except that the examples she gives are unrealistically formal and reserved. Who would say, ''The band was, like, outrageous''? Outrageous is, like, a three-syllable word. The band was undoubtedly more, like, awesome. Similarly, we'd never hear, ''I was, like, exhausted.'' The habitual like-speaker is more likely to have said, ''I was, like, wasted.''

HATTERER--Lawrence J. M.D., age 82, died on July 13th. He was a graduate of Princeton University, The college of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia and the Payne Whitney Clinic of The New York Presbyterian Hospital where he was a member of the faculty for 55 years as an Associate Clinical Professor of Psychiatry and a Assistant Clinical Professor of Public Health. He was a Distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and Senior Fellow of the Academy of Psychoanalysis. He was a pioneer in the use of the media to study Psychotherapy and created television programs and video tapes to disseminate mental health information. A NIH funded researcher he authored three books and numerous articles. His life was defined by the love of humanity, creativity and beauty. He is survived and greatly missed by his wife Dr. Myra S. Hatterer, his daughters Dr. Julie Hatterer, Jane Hatterer Bohner Esq., Russell Bohner and four grandchildren.

THE first meaningful step that many Americans will take to combat global climate change will be to replace their incandescent light bulbs with far more efficient compact fluorescent bulbs. Switching just one bulb prevents about 100 pounds of carbon dioxide from entering the atmosphere. If every household replaced its five most frequently used bulbs, according to the Department of Energy, greenhouse gases would be curtailed as much as if nearly 10 million cars were taken off the road.

LEGISLATORS in New Jersey and six other states, including New York and Connecticut, are weighing whether to give thousands of accurate birth certificates to their rightful owners, adult adoptees who now have access only to falsified certificates. Most of America's six million adoptees are members of what one calls ''a witness protection program we didn't ask to be in.'' When their adoptions were made final, the birth certificates bearing their names and those of their parents were sealed by the state, and they were issued ''amended'' certificates portraying their adoptive parents as having borne them. In some cases, adoptees' dates and places of birth were also falsified.

MOYNIHAN--Ann. Fordham Law mourns the loss of Associate Dean and Clinical Professor Ann Moynihan. She was brilliant, creative, and warm; a great teacher, friend, and colleague. As a Legal Aid Lawyer and a clinical professor, Dean Moynihan devoted her life to helping those in need. She was vibrant, fun, and hope-filled; a true mentor who was gifted at discovering and developing potential in her students and staff alike. She viewed no problem as beyond solution and had the passion, drive, and skill to make her solutions become realities. There is no part of the Law School that was not edified by her brilliant guidance. She will be deeply missed. Our sympathies to her parents, Eugene and Mary and to her sister Nora. Services will be held in Greenville, NY. Detailed information will be posted at law.fordham.edu as it becomes available.

ABRAMOVSKY--Abe. Your generous spirit and enthusiasm animated young lives. We are thankful for what you gave us. We are heartbroken that you are no longer here. You were truly amazing. Joshua, Judy and Charley Gradinger

NUNNALLE--Francoise, age 70, died July 23rd, 2007 in New York City ending her long vicious battle with complicated and overwhelming medical problems. She fought with fierce bravery and impeccable dignity during her life so she could live for what she loved-her friends and familyart, music, flowers and her cats. She resided in Manhattan and Lenox, MA. Francoise was an international fine arts dealer -antique textile, linen and lace collector, but was especially known for her exceptional collection of original Mariano Fortuny fabrics. She also handmade pillows from her textiles for private collectors and interior designers. She leaves her darling husband Jim, her third pair of oriental shorthairs, little Bonnie and Clyde, and all the friends who adored her and loved her greatly including her deeply spiritual sister Georgianna and four fine nephews; Philip, Ricky, Michael and Haleem. A celebration and memorial luncheon will be announced in the fall for all who knew her and appreciated her kind and generous spirit and extraordinary persona. She would prefer all memorial donations to be given to the ASPCA-or a tree planted somewhere in her name so the world may be a bit more beautiful, kinder, and greener.

FOR BUTTONED-UP TYPES who find it hard to achieve sartorial ataraxia on the weekends, Thomas Pink has created Pink Casual -- because as tempting as it is, man and woman cannot live on Lacoste alone. A charmingly rumpled collection of woven shirts tailor-made for high-quality relaxation, the shirts are double-washed for extra softness and have an easy but not overly baggy fit. Fabrics include classic oxford cloth in solids like plain white, blue and pink, and poplin stripes in navy, cornflower blue and lilac. Women's shirts come with or without pockets and button-down collars. Apparently, when you're trying to let it all hang loose, you have to go one baby step at a time ($140 for women's shirts, $150 for men's, at Thomas Pink stores).

Gerhard Kaim, 46, an occupational therapist from Bamberg, Germany, with his girlfriend, Marita Hoefling, 25: ''I lived in Berlin more than 10 years ago, and I wanted to show Marita the place that I lived and the places I liked. We took an apartment in the middle of the city -- we wanted to be right in the middle, where everything happens. That day we rented bicycles and rode many, many kilometers, coming to the Reichstag in the evening. There's a spiral walkway, and as you go higher and higher the view is gorgeous. You can look all over Berlin. The city is a special place for us, because Marita comes from East Germany and I come from West Germany, and you always have the feeling that if the wall had not broken down we would never have met.'' As told to Seth Kugel

BERGER--Sue (Connie) Lindau, 77, on June 18, 2007. Sue Lindau Berger died on June 18 at her longtime Manhattan home, surrounded by loving family. Sue and her rich life will be celebrated by family and friends at a memorial service in September in New York City. Sue shared her many gifts generously with those lucky enough to have known her, and helped others from a young age and throughout her life through philanthropy and service. She loved to bake, read, compose music, spend time with family and friends, and cherished being around children. She was also an accomplished pianist. Sue was an extraordinary friend, always providing a ready ear, understanding, wisdom and support. Over the years Sue served in various positions at the Bergen County chapter of Planned Parenthood and at the midtown Ethical Culture School in Manhattan. In retirement, Sue counseled women with breast cancer in the innovative Women At Risk program at New York Presbyterian Hospital. She was a graduate of the Walden School in NYC and Sarah Lawrence College. Sue's family and many friends mourn her loss. She was the beloved mother of Chana Leah (Ellen) Lewis, John, Cathy and Wendy Berger; devoted grandmother to Sarah Elisheva, Yocheved, Yehudit, Nesanel, Devorah, Yisroel Meir, and Simcha of Jerusalem; Will, Chloe, Maya and Michaela of Hoboken; Isaac and Lena of Portland, Oregon; and great-grandmother to Moshe Aaron of Jerusalem. She was the beloved sister and sister-in-law of Jackie and David Marlin, and David and Josie Lindau; cherished cousin of Nancy Lindau Lewis; and much loved motherin-law of Gershon Lewis, Adriana Pacheco, Elizabeth Plapinger and Nicholas Sencer. Sue was beloved by her many nieces, nephews, cousins, colleagues, neighbors and friends. To honor Sue, and her lifetime of caring about children and others in need, contributions may be made in her name to the Fresh Air Fund, at 633 Third Avenue, 14th Floor, New York, New York, 10017.

My family and I are going to be at Walt Disney World for New Year's Eve. The group includes myself, my husband, our 19-year-old daughter, her 19-year-old boyfriend and our 17-year-old daughter. My question is this: What can our older teenage kids do at night and, more specifically, on New Year's Eve? While they are perfectly content to go on rides and pose with characters during the day, they would much rather go out at night. However, the dance clubs on Pleasure Island are 21 and older only. Any suggestions? -- Jan Miller, Long Island

Class size is one barometer of the academic experience; ratio of students to faculty is another. PRIOR--Rev. Eugene. The Parents Association of Loyola School expresses humble appreciation for the life and ministry of Fr. Eugene J. Prior, S.J. Generations of Loyola students have benefited from Fr. Prior's love for them, and their parents could count on his advice and affection through their children's high school years and beyond. Bridgett Lundy, President, Loyola Parents Association Stephen Katsouros, S.J., President, Loyola School PRIOR--Rev. Eugene J., S.J., died on July 24, 2007. Fr. Prior, the son of the late Eugene and Elizabeth Prior and brother of the late Thomas ''Happy'' Prior, was born in the Bronx in 1924 and attended Fordham Prep and Fordham University. He entered the Society of Jesus in February, 1943, and was ordained a priest in June, 1955. Fr. Prior taught at Regis High School and The Loyola School. In 1962 he became a Spiritual Director for Students at The Loyola School and subsequently served as Assistant Headmaster, Dean of Students and, since 2001, Vice President for Alumni and External Affairs. Friends may call Sunday, July 29, 29pm and Monday, July 30, 25pm at The Loyola School Alumni Gymnasium at Park Ave and E. 83rd St. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday at 7pm, at St. Ignatius Loyola R.C. Church, Park Ave at 84th. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Fr. Eugene Prior Scholarship Fund at The Loyola School will be gratefully accepted.

Jordana Spiro returns as a pretty tomboyish Chicago sportswriter in the second-season premiere of ''MY BOYS'' on TBS Monday at 10 p.m. Can her character balance dating, love, beer, chicken wings, fantasy baseball and her all-guy entourage? The question remains.

You can almost feel the jubilation in Albany these days, and hear the sighs of relief. Now that Gov. Eliot Spitzer has received his political comeuppance -- two aides caught trying to smear the governor's chief Republican opponent -- a lot of Mr. Spitzer's loftiest reforms are stalled, if not off the table. And instead of the much-needed new day the governor promised in January, the political rats are returning to the state ship. The earliest casualty may be real campaign finance reform -- one of Mr. Spitzer's biggest promises when he rode into office. New York's flagrantly lax campaign laws serve the Legislature. These laws allow incumbents to rake in the money while challengers have a hard time raising enough for bus fare. Without reform, the buying and selling of New York's Legislature will continue at its normal sky-high rates.

Cellos and clarinets and pianos and other instruments have their festivals, so why not the accordion? The AMERICAN ACCORDIONISTS' ASSOCIATION wraps up three days of concerts and master classes on Sunday. An afternoon seminar with casual performances will be followed by a concert featuring top accordionists playing pieces most of them wrote for the occasion. Some are former students of William Schimmel, a leading accordion guru who will also perform. Master class at 3 p.m., concert at 7 p.m., Tenri Cultural Institute, 43A West 13th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 876-0827, ameraccord.com; master class, $20; concert, $25; both, $40.

MOSES--Sigmund, of New York, Florida and Randolph, Vermont, loving husband, father and grandfather, passed away on July 21, 2007 at his home in Vermont. He was born on September 11, 1907, the son of Moritz and Gazela Moses. Mr. Moses grew up and attended public school in New York, graduating from Brooklyn Law School in 1930. He was admitted to the bar in 1931 and practiced law continuously in New York for the next 75 years. He retired at the age of 98. His loyalty, generosity and dedication were reciprocated by his clients, to whom he acted not only as attorney, but also confidante, advisor and friend. Growing up, Mr. Moses was an enthusiastic stickball player, and played in and coached a variety of local baseball teams. In later years, he became an avid golfer and fisherman, and was a longtime member of Dellwood Country Club. On April 20, 1943, Mr. Moses married Elizabeth, who predeceased him on April 20, 2007. Survivors include his sister, Esther Moses, his daughter and son-in-law, Karen and Karl Miller, his grandchildren, Caitlin Miller and Aaron Moses Miller, his nephew Martin Friedman and wife Marilyn, and numerous other nephews and nieces.
JEFFRIES--Seymour B., age 90, July 25. His many accomplishments include a successful law practice, the family he loved and who truly loved him. He will be missed.

LANVIN'S ELEGANT strings of pearls tied with tulle ribbon were just plain inspired. Now, Natalie Alabama Chanin, famous in her Project Alabama days for her hand-sewn clothing, has taken the idea in a more organic, handmade direction. Her new jewelry collection is shot through with cotton jersey cords, as embellishments or fastenings or both. The handsome new pieces range from rustic cuffs to citified charm bracelets loaded down with -- eek! -- giant beetles. The fabric, added by the company's army of local stitchers, is often culled from recycled T-shirts. ''I like the idea of something so common, so disposable, combined with precious metal,'' Ms. Chanin said. Available at www.alabamachanin.com, all pieces are custom. The necklace above, in your choice of gold vermeil or platinum sterling alloy, with cream, burgundy or black ties, is $625. SUSAN GUERRERO

Multibillion-dollar megabuyouts grab headlines, but smaller deals help pay the bills for many deal advisers. Consider the investment bank Lazard, which often advises on big-ticket transactions but recently created a unit devoted to middle-market work. So there could be a bit of good news in a recent survey, which found that many midsize companies have deal-making plans for the year to come, even though they are generally cautious about the economy as a whole.

Commissioner Bud Selig will probably attend Tuesday night's game, though Bonds may not start. He is two homers away from overtaking Hank Aaron's all-time home run record.

Several of the Democratic presidential contenders have been talking up their health care plans over the past few days. Senator Chris Dodd outlined his proposal last week, and former Senator John Edwards spent part of the weekend discussing his plan.

Prada announced last week that Azzedine Alaia will buy back 100 percent of his company from the Milan fashion group. Alaia will continue to work with Prada on bags and shoes. That makes sense, because Alaia has developed a very good relationship with the Prada folks in that area. I'm not inclined to read much into the announcement. Prada helped Alaia get his business on track, and that has been accomplished. He has always been independent.

Two years ago, a Deutsche Bank analyst predicted that the subprime mortgage market would suffer significant losses. Now the German firm is poised to reap at least $270 million and as much as $540 million from a strategy that enabled its traders to sell subprime mortgage loans with derivatives contracts that appreciated as the housing market in the United States suffered its worst slump in 16 years, Bloomberg News reported.

Hedge fund AQR Capital Management plans to file registration for an initial public offering on Monday to raise $500 million, The Wall Street Journal reported on its Web site on Friday, citing an unnamed source.

Ingersoll-Rand said it would sell its Bobcat machinery business and two other units to Doosan Infracore for $4.9 billion cash, the biggest ever overseas acquisition by a South Korean firm. Shares in Doosan, formerly known as Daewoo Heavy Industries & Machinery, surged 14.9 percent on the move, which the company said would nearly double its sales and make it the world's seventh largest construction equipment maker.

Cedar Fair Entertainment, the nation's third-largest theme-park operator, has entered talks with an investment firm, Destiny Capital Solutions, about a $4.1 billion takeover, The New York Post reported Monday. As part of the deal, Cedar Fair's management would remain in place for a period of time, and Destiny would commit between $500 million and $800 million to upgrade the company's 12 parks.

Verizon Wireless said it would buy the Rural Cellular Corporation in a deal it valued at $2.67 billion, including assumed debt. Verizon Wireless, a joint venture between Verizon Communications and Vodafone, will pay $45 a share for each share of Rural Cellular, or $757 million in cash.

The Blackstone Group and other big private equity firms could be forced to change their business models if the recent financing troubles at Alliance Boots and Chrysler signal a longer-term change, The Financial Times's Lex column writes.

John Malone, the American media mogul and chairman of Liberty Global, is considering entering a $23 billion auction for the cable operator Virgin Media, The Financial Times reported. Mr. Malone, who also chairs Liberty Media, told the F.T. that his interest in Virgin Media exploratory but said his company was "doing our homework."

In two separate columns published in The New York Times over the weekend, two writers --Alan S. Binder and Ben Stein -- take issue with the tax breaks currently enjoyed by private equity and hedge fund managers. In both columns the central argument revolves around the possible inequity of such breaks, which are currently under Congressional review and have stirred up a bucket of controversy.

Tom Cruise's United Artists movie studio and Merrill Lynch have essentially wrapped up negotiations over about $500 million in film financing, The New York Post reported. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, which owns UA, and Merrill are combing through final deal points and should be ready to go public with the financing by mid-August, according to the report.
Tata Motors, India's biggest car marker, has reportedly asked Ford Motor to let it take a look at its books for Jaguar and Land Rover, two companies Ford has put up for sale.

Lululemon Athletica's stock rallied as much as 50 percent Friday, despite an overall market sell-off, after the yoga-clothing maker increased the size of its initial public offering and raised the price.

A merger of the two major regulators for American stock markets has received final regulatory approval, the Securities and Exchange Commission said late Thursday. The S.E.C. approved rule changes allowing the consolidation of Nasdaq Stock Market cop NASD and the in-house watchdog for the New York Stock Exchange, NYSE Regulation, into the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority.

Congress heads today into a fast and furious finale before its August recess, with major changes in lobbying rules among the legislation House and Senate Democrats hope to complete this week to demonstrate they are delivering on their campaign promises.

KeyCorp, a regional bank based in Cleveland, said on Friday it had agreed to buy U.S.B. Holding, the parent of Union State Bank, for $575 million in cash and stock to expand in southern New York state.

An informal takeover approach by Apax Partners is in part responsible for Emap's decision to announce Friday that it is considering a sale or breakup of the company, The Guardian reported. The British private equity group has reportedly made an informal approach to buy Emap's business-to-business division for 1.3 billion pounds ($2.6 billion).

Terra Firma, the private equity group run by the British financier Guy Hands, has been given a last-minute extension by the Takeover Panel for its 2.4 billion pound ($4.9 billion) offer for the music group EMI. Before the deadline Sunday afternoon, Terra Firma had received less than 85 percent of acceptances, short of the 90 percent required to guarantee funding from its bank Citigroup.
Investors in defunct hedge fund Portus Alternative Asset Management will get some of their money back this fall, after a judge cleared the way Friday for the first payouts from the fund's receiver.

Conrad Black, the Canadian media magnate convicted in Chicago this month of obstruction of justice and defrauding the newspaper company he once headed, is apparently hoping for a Frank-Quattrone ending to his legal ordeal.
Homes on the market in Telluride Mountain Village, Colo., Dorset, Vt., and Newport Beach, Calif.

While Sumner Redstone, chairman and controlling shareholder of both Viacom and CBS, has shown little enthusiasm for Wall Street's belief that both companies would be good candidates for leveraged buyouts, in a July 23 interview with BusinessWeek, the 84-year-old media chieftain took a never-say-never approach to the question.

NowPublic.com, a "citizen journalism" Web site based in Vancouver, announced that it had closed a $10.6 million round of financing from venture capital groups in the United States and Canada after having turned down several offers to acquire the company outright.

Archer Daniels Midland said Friday morning that it has agreed to acquire Fasco Mills, a Mendota, Ill.-based grain and feed company. The Decatur, Ill. grain-processing concern did not disclose terms of its purchase of family-owned Fasco, which it characterized as the operator of one of the largest networks of grain elevators and rail shipping terminals in Illinois.

A private-equity group, Lee Equity Partners, founded by the buyout veteran Thomas H. Lee, is buying a junior-girl fashion retailer, Deb Shops, a Philadelphia company founded as a women's hosiery store, for $395 million, the company said Friday. The $27.25-per-share deal requires shareholder approval and represents a small premium over Thursday's closing price of $26.68.

The attorney for the former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Greg Reyes, who is on trial on charges of securities fraud associated with stock-option backdating, is filing a motion for mistrial alleging misconduct by the government in closing arguments Friday.
Nestle won approval Friday from European regulators to buy Gerber Products, giving the world's biggest food and drink company the largest share of the global baby food market.

EMC is selling a $150 million stake in its VMware software subsidiary to networking hardware maker Cisco Systems. The deal will give Cisco a 1.6 percent stake in VMware and comes about two weeks after Intel bought a 2.5 percent stake in the company for $218.5 million.

Imperial Chemical Industries, the British maker of Dulux and Glidden paints, rejected a sweetened 7.77 billion-pound ($16 billion) bid from Akzo Nobel of the Netherlands as too low. Akzo, the world's largest coatings company, raised its offer 8.3 percent to 650 pence a share.
HSBC, the world's fourth-biggest bank, said first-half profit rose 25 percent, beating analysts' estimates, on higher revenue from Asia. Costs for potential loan losses surged more than expected.

This little piggy's manure causes less pollution. This little piggy produces extra milk for her babies. And this little piggy makes fatty acids normally found in fish, so that eating its bacon might actually be good for you.

Despite an imminent deadline, the Bancroft family and even some of its advisers seem sharply split over whether to sell Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

The owners of Russneft, one of Russia's largest private oil companies, are in talks to sell their shares and are near a deal with Oleg V. Deripaska, an investor with close ties to the Kremlin, a Russian news agency reported on Sunday, citing an executive at a bank with ties to the company.

The board of ABN Amro, the Dutch lender at the center of the world's largest banking takeover battle, withdrew its support for a bid by Barclays, the British Bank, but it did not go so far as to support a rival bid from a banking consortium led by Royal Bank of Scotland.

Senator Charles E. Schumer has been reassuring private equity and hedge fund managers -- an important part of his constituency in New York -- that he will resist an effort led by members of his own party to single out the industry with a plan that would more than double the taxes on the enormous profits reaped by its executives.

Shares of the Kingdom Holding Company of the Saudi billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal rose as much as 41 percent in their openking on Sunday, making the company the fourth-largest publicly traded company in Saudi Arabia.

Monday, the day when Wall Street announces some if its biggest deals, may not be the same for a while. And that could cause more jitters in stock and bond markets, following their worst week in nearly five years.
A look at the New World of Coca-Cola museum in Atlanta.
“David Adjaye: Making Public Buildings,” an exhibition at the Studio Museum in Harlem, is the kind of measured, well-meaning endeavor that provokes reflection but yields few profound insights.
The Nickell team, the defending champions, claimed their ninth Spingold title in Nashville on Sunday.
Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. underwent “a thorough neurological evaluation, which revealed no cause for concern,” according to a statement by the court.
The computer server maker beat Wall Street’s estimates for its quarterly earnings, providing evidence that its turnaround plan was working and lifting shares in after-hours trading.
Mr. Walsh coached San Francisco to three Super Bowl titles and was one of pro football’s most influential figures.
If her mother manages to become the first female president of the United States, Chelsea Clinton could be in a historic position: the first first child twice over.
NBC will feature The Times’s political coverage on MSNBC.com, while The Times said it planned to use NBC video on NYTimes.com.
Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain indicated that he  mostly shared President Bush’s views on terrorism and the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.
Mr. Snyder introduced a highly personal style that would have a strong influence on other television interviewers.
The North American office of the Israel Ministry of Tourism is running an $11 million ad campaign — the ministry’s largest ever — that suggests visitors will “love Israel from the first ‘Shalom.’ ”.
The proposed arms sales package for Saudi Arabia and its neighbors could eventually total $20 billion.
A federal drug advisory committee voted 22 to 1 to keep Avandia, a diabetes drug that may raise the risks of heart attacks, on the market.
A one on one with Herminia Ibarra, the author of “Working Identity” and a professor at INSEAD Business School in France.
More than 1,700 civilians have been killed by Islamic extremists in the Philippines since 2000, according to a new report by Human Rights Watch.
Prime Minister Shinzo Abe insisted that Japanese voters still supported him despite a defeat in Sunday’s elections.
As many as four million Iraqis need immediate help getting food, a report from Oxfam International warns.
Widely considered one of history’s greatest directors, Ingmar Bergman found bleakness and despair as well as comedy and hope in his indelible explorations of the human condition.

A lightning bolt knocked down a power line and sparked a fire in a garage that spread to two homes yesterday, causing extensive damages and injuring several firefighters. The lightning struck a utility pole about 1 p.m., throwing a power line to the ground, an investigation by the Nassau County fire marshal’s office indicated. A woman and three children escaped the first home unharmed and no one was home at the other house, the police and neighbors said. The downed power line also caused several small explosions while firefighters tried to douse the flames. Two firefighters were shocked and taken to a hospital, the police said. Eight other firefighters were treated for minor injuries, including smoke inhalation and heat exhaustion.

A pregnant woman was fatally wounded when someone in a passing van fired several shots at a group of people standing on a street. The authorities said it was not yet known if the victim, Elisha Wordelman, 23, of Westwood, was the intended target. Ms. Wordelman and her friends were standing on Presidential Boulevard when the shooting occurred about 5 a.m. Saturday, Lt. Ron Humphrey said. She was taken to St. Joseph’s Regional Medical Center, and pronounced dead at 9:30 p.m. The investigation was continuing, the police said. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Four police officers were injured, one seriously, after they were hit by a car last night while responding to a call about a fight in New Cassel, the Nassau County Police said. The officers were investigating a call at 1001 Prospect Avenue about 9 p.m. when a passing driver, struck them as they were standing in the street, a police spokeswoman said. The officers were taken to Nassau University Medical Center in East Meadow. None of the injuries were life threatening, the police said.
The Bancroft family and even some of its advisers seem sharply split over whether to sell Dow Jones & Company to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.

Rio de Janeiro was ready for the Pan American Games after all. The event ended last night without major glitches. But it was not without problems, including questions about some of the temporary facilities and the lack of infrastructure.Rio has officially shown interest in bidding for the 2016 Olympics, and the Pan Ams were seen as a huge test for the city. “Good, but not perfect,” said Mario Vazquez Rana, president of the Pan American Sports Organization. The biggest star of the games was the Brazilian swimmer Thiago Pereira, who won six gold medals (and a silver and a bronze) to break the 40-year record held by Mark Spitz. The American swimmer Julia Smit won four golds and a silver, as did her countrywoman Shawn Johnson in gymnastics. Over all, the United States earned 12 Olympic berths for the 2008 Games in Beijing. Perhaps most significantly, the Pan Ams had no positive drug tests after more than 1,300 tests conducted through Saturday.
The mine was operating above its design capacity when a flash flood raced through an old shaft, trapping 69 miners on Sunday morning.
The Doosan Infracore Company agreed to buy the Bobcat unit and other divisions from the Ingersoll-Rand Company for $4.9 billion.

A 55-year-old man found bound and gagged in an apartment in the Rockaways on Saturday died of strangulation, according to an autopsy report released yesterday. A spokeswoman for the city medical examiner said the cause was ruled “homicidal violence, gagging and neck compression.”.
Gregory McCullough has been in a medically induced coma for nearly two weeks after suffering serious injuries in an explosion near Grand Central Terminal.

A picture caption on July 14 about preparations in Rawalpindi by Pakistani riot police for anti-government demonstrations included incorrect information from The Associated Press about the location. Rawalpindi is a separate city, not a suburb of Islamabad, the capital.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about the investigation into the cause of a fatal airplane crash last year in Lexington, Ky., misidentified the transportation official shown. He is Joseph Osterman, managing director of the National Transportation Safety Board — not Mark V. Rosenker, the board chairman.
The Army’s involvement in a concert series raises hackles about recruiting efforts in low-income and minority neighborhoods.

Cuauhtemoc Blanco quickly showed his ability yesterday in his Major League Soccer debut for the Chicago Fire. Blanco set up Ivan Guerrero for the game’s first goal, leading the visiting Fire past Toronto F.C., 3-0.The 34-year-old Blanco, twice Mexico’s most valuable player, found Guerrero slicing in toward the goal with a perfectly lofted pass. Chicago (5-8-4) had scored 13 goals in its previous 16 games.

Dmitry Tursunov beat Frank Dancevic, 6-4, 7-5, in the final of the Indianapolis Championships yesterday.Tursunov, ranked 27th in the world and seeded third, was competing in his first ATP final of the year. It was his second career title, the first coming at Mumbai in 2006. He did not face a seeded player on his way to the championship.
Top-seeded Francesca Schiavone won her first WTA Tour title, defeating Yvonne Meusburger, 6-1, 6-4, in the Gastein Ladies in Austria.

Vernon Forrest withstood a late rally by Carlos Baldomir to win the World Boxing Council superwelterweight championship in a unanimous decision in front of an estimated capacity crowd of 2,200 at the Emerald Queen Casino in Tacoma, Wash., on Saturday night.The 6-foot Forrest stood 5 inches taller than Baldomir and had a 6-inch reach advantage. Forrest (39-2) used left jabs to set up body and head shots with his right. Baldomir (43-11-6) took a number of tough punches but did not take shots to the body as well as he took the shots to his face. The judges scored it 118-109, 118-109 and 116-111 for Forrest.

Anna Chakvetadze won her second consecutive tournament, making quick work of the surprise finalist Sania Mirza, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday to win the Bank of the West Classic in Stanford, Calif. Chakvetadze improved to 6-0 in finals and will rise to No. 6 in the world rankings.

Carlos Moyá won his fifth Croatia Open title yesterday, defeating Andrei Pavel of Romania, 6-4, 6-2, in Umag.Moyá, who also won in 1996, 2001, 2002 and 2003, has a 43-8 record in the tournament. Moyá, seeded sixth, made several forehand errors in the first set, with Pavel serving well until 4-4. Then Moyá broke to 5-4, but needed to use his eighth set point to win the longest game of the match. In the second set, Moyá broke in the fifth game.

Mark Grieb completed 24 of 29 passes and threw four touchdown passes to lead the San Jose SaberCats to a 55-33 victory against the Columbus Destroyers in the ArenaBowl title game in New Orleans yesterday.The SaberCats (16-3), the most successful Arena Football League franchise this decade, capped a three-and-a-half-month winning streak with their third Arena League championship in six years. The Destroyers (10-10) won three consecutive road games to get to the final.

Juan Monaco won his third career ATP tour title by beating Potito Starace, 5-7, 6-3, 6-4, in the Austrian Open yesterday in Kitzbühel. Only Rafael Nadal (six titles) and Roger Federer (four) have won more tournaments in 2007 than Monaco, who won in Buenos Aires and Poertschach earlier this year. “I really can’t believe this is true,” the 31st-ranked Monaco said.
People throughout Iraq celebrated the country’s 1-0 victory over Saudi Arabia in soccer’s Asian Cup final.
As U.S. officials get serious about drafting rules for the industry, some scientists and executives say big investors may finally be willing to put up money.

The Suffolk County police yesterday were searching for robbers in two seemingly unrelated holdups on Long Island on Saturday. Three men with handguns held up a North Fork Bank in Deer Park about 9:40 a.m. on Saturday, clearing out three tellers’ stations as well as the bank vault, the police said. The men were in their 20s and 30s, and two wore fishing hats, the police said. Less than an hour later, in Mastic, a man, described by witnesses as about 40, handed a note demanding money to a teller at an HSBC Bank branch on Montauk Highway, the police said. In that case, the police on Saturday charged a man, George Jackson, 26, with attempting to conceal evidence, including cash, but did not charge him with taking part in the robbery, the police said.

A man trying to retrieve an item from a disabled vehicle, which had been damaged in a collision with a state police car, was killed on Saturday night after a third car smashed into the vehicle, the state police said. The man, John Robinson, 21, of Trenton, was a passenger in a Dodge Avenger that rear-ended a patrol car on the Atlantic City Expressway about 10:30 p.m., the state police said. Mr. Robinson was inside the Dodge, which was parked on the side of the road, when it was struck by the third vehicle, an Acura RL, and caught fire. State troopers pulled Mr. Robinson from the car, but were unable to save him, the state police said. The driver of the Acura, James Black, 32, of New Castle, Del., was charged with driving with a suspended license while being involved in an accident causing death or injury. He was being held yesterday at the Atlantic County jail in $10,000 bail.
Congressmen Anthony D. Weiner and Jerrold Nadler of New York announced that they would introduce legislation to block a proposal to sell advanced weapons to Saudi Arabia.

A Queens man, Michael Anthony, 26, was charged yesterday with murder and assault in the beating death of his mother on Saturday at their apartment in Fresh Meadows, the police said. Police officers answering a 911 call reporting an assault on a woman at 65-82 160th Street about 11:16 p.m. on Saturday found Maria Fischman, 61, with head injuries, the police said. She was pronounced dead at the scene, they said.

A small alligator was found Saturday morning on Overlook Beach in Babylon, the Suffolk County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said. An off-duty S.P.C.A. agent found the 2 ½-foot-long animal about 5:30 a.m., the S.P.C.A. said. Roy Gross, the organization’s chief, said the alligator would be sent to a reptile sanctuary. He added that it was the 107th reptile his organization had recovered this year. Mr. Gross estimated the animal, an American alligator, was about 2 years old and could inflict serious injury despite its size. “This is really not the kind of pet you want to have,” he said.

A Newark police officer who was dragged by a car during a traffic stop on Saturday was in stable condition last night, according to a spokesman for University Hospital in Newark. The officer, Cesar Estrella, 34, was treated for severe head trauma and facial lacerations after he was dragged for more than a block near Summer and Montclair Avenues. The police have charged Alisdair Archer Jr., 20, of Green Brook, N.J., with aggravated assault on a police officer, eluding arrest, resisting arrest and using a car as a weapon.
The opposition party seized control of the upper house, but Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said he would not step down.
Tony Stewart led 66 of 160 laps, grabbing the lead for good from Kevin Harvick with 10 laps left for his second consecutive Nextel Cup victory.
Federal regulators are supposed to make trucking safer, but lately they have been doing just the opposite.
By the end of last week, any lingering hope that the housing downturn would be contained had vanished. As this week begins, signs of contagion seem to be everywhere.

Congress’s Republican minority leaders are picking the wrong fight in suddenly attacking a notably bipartisan push to expand health insurance coverage to hundreds of thousands of children of the working poor.
After another poor outing from Kyle Farnsworth in Sunday’s victory, the Yankees have switched top minor league pitching prospect Joba Chamberlain to a relief role.
The induction of Cal Ripken and Tony Gwynn into the National Baseball Hall of Fame on Sunday was notable primarily because no one mentioned Barry Bonds’s race catch Hank Aaron.
The Giants leave Monday for a six-game trip to Los Angeles and San Diego, two of the last places Barry Bonds would like to hit 755 or 756.
Gordon Brown’s visit to Camp David is being closely watched for signs of how his relationship with President Bush will differ from that of his predecessor, Tony Blair.
Fort Worth and San Francisco are among the latest municipalities to sue gang members, asking courts for injunctions barring them from certain areas.
Neither rust nor a traffic jam could stop the Kentucky Derby winner Street Sense in his return to the races Sunday.
The governor’s press secretary says changes are possible, but that there is no shakeup planned.
At least eight states have let fighters enter the ring with fraudulent or insufficient medical examinations in recent years, a pattern of neglect nurtured by a patchwork system of safety.
Ryan Braun, the sensational Milwaukee Brewers rookie third baseman, revels in his connection to Hall of Fame slugger Hank Greenberg.
The Americans and the Iraqi government have erected a legal Green Zone to shelter judges and secure the trials of some of Iraq’s most dangerous suspects.
C. C. Sabathia’s defense deserted him — again.
Quarterback Tim Couch signed a two-year contract yesterday with the Jacksonville Jaguars, receiving a chance to revive his career as a backup to Byron Leftwich.
These are anxious days for abortion opponents, who are trying to adjust to a changed political landscape.
Barry Bonds’s teammate Mark Sweeney moved into second place on the career pinch-hit list on a night when most were watching for Bonds to make history.
Mohammed Haneef received a hero’s welcome in southern India on Sunday, returning after terrorism charges against him were dropped in Australia.
The population at a struggling youth detention facility is expected to grow because of a state law that will raise the age at which suspects are automatically tried as adults.
Alberto Contador, a 24-year-old from Madrid who rides for the Discovery Channel team, won the overall title, the youngest rider in a decade to win cycling’s biggest event.
Caddo Lake, often called Texas’s only honest lake, is under siege by a fast-spreading, Velcro-like aquatic fern.
From catching passes with the starting receivers to returning kickoffs to taking snaps under center, Brad Smith is the ever-evolving man on the Jets’ roster.
Because of the high prices that drugs can command, medicine — not food — might provide the earliest payoff from genetically engineered livestock.
At each stop, Mitt Romney, who nationally is less known than his Republican rivals, defended the role Iowa has traditionally played in the presidential process.
Researchers say they have identified new genetic variants that contribute to the neurological disease.
The owners of Russneft, one of Russia’s largest private oil companies, are in talks to sell their shares and are near a deal with Oleg V. Deripaska.

Mike Cameron and Adrian Gonzalez hit two-run homers during an 11-run first inning against Jason Jennings yesterday in an 18-11 victory against the Houston Astros. Visiting San Diego had a season-high 19 hits on the day the Padres’ career hits leader, Tony Gwynn, was inducted into the Hall of Fame.
When it reopens after a $12.5 million restoration, the legendary ballroom will be a newbie in a fiercely competitive market for event spaces.
Invoking Afghan and Islamic traditions of chivalry and hospitality, top Afghan political and religious leaders called on the Taliban to release 18 South Korean women being held captive.
A nearly singular spotlight has been on Eli Manning since he was chosen first over all in the 2004 N.F.L. draft and anointed the Giants’ franchise quarterback after he was acquired from San Diego.
Natalie Gulbis won her first L.P.G.A. Tour title Sunday, making a birdie on the first hole of a playoff with Jang Jeong at the Evian Masters in Evian-les-Bains, France.
A series of life-size sculptures of real people made over 25 years ago provide a link to a Bronx that has disappeared.
Katie Douglas scored 26 points to rally the Connecticut Sun to a victory against the Liberty in W.N.B.A. action on Sunday.
The soldier had fallen asleep during a rest break inside Gaza and was extricated only after his unit had returned to base.
A dance company in Cuba is breaking stereotypes of dance, redefining the aesthetics of beauty and raising the self-esteem of heavyset people.
A poet rides the bus, a musician is shouted down and a woman finds her mother.
Mrs. Crick’s  original illustration of the structure of DNA, discovered by her husband, Francis H. C. Crick and James D. Watson, became a symbol of modern molecular biology.
Outrage over the death of a teenager, killed by a driver whose blood alcohol content was three times over the legal limit, is finally compelling Italy to address drunken driving.
Sean Combs is looking for a helper to fill the shoes of his former assistant. But instead of résumés, Mr. Combs is accepting only video applications uploaded to YouTube.
Robert Ludlum died six years ago, but that has done nothing to slow the release of books published under the name of the actor-turned-novelist.

A new show is headed this way from the creators of De La Guarda’s “Villa Villa”: “Fuerzabruta” (“Brute Force”). Set to a dynamic soundtrack, it is described in publicity materials as a show in which “a man runs full throttle through a series of moving walls, individuals race to connect from opposite sides of a whirling sail, and performers frolic and interact in a watery world suspended just above the audience.” “Fuerzabruta” will play at the Daryl Roth Theater, near Union Square, where “Villa Villa” opened in 1998. Previews begin Oct. 11, and opening night is Oct. 24. The engagement runs through Feb. 17. ... Mel Brooks’s monster isn’t going to be the only one onstage this fall. “Frankenstein,” a new musical inspired by the 1818 Gothic novel by Mary Shelley, will begin performances off Broadway at 37 Arts on Oct. 10. The tale of a doctor who creates a living creature in his lab, only to be destroyed by his own invention, will feature music by Mark Baron and a book and lyrics by Jeffrey Jackson. Gary P. Cohen did the adaptation, and Bill Fennelly will direct.
On GSN, formerly the Game Show Network, a new program called “Without Prejudice?” stands out. It may be just what GSN needs in seeking an identity.
The decision by ABN Amro’s board is expected to be announced Monday when the company reports second-quarter results.
Bill Gates, who co-founded Microsoft, still intends to step away next year as planned. But so far, Mr. Gates, the company’s chairman, is showing no sign of fading away.

The slinky chanteuse and exotic cabaret kitten Meow Meow has temporarily replaced Paul Capsis in “Absinthe,” the acrobatic extravaganza at Spiegelworld at the South Street Seaport. Mr. Capsis left the show citing a family emergency but is expected to be back on Aug. 7. ... The songwriting and performing duo Ashford & Simpson will open the fall season at Feinstein’s at Loew’s Regency with an engagement from Sept. 11 through Sept. 29. The program will include hits like “Ain’t No Mountain High Enough” and “Reach Out and Touch Somebody’s Hand.” ... New York City Opera has announced the third annual “Afternoon Arias” season of free lunchtime concerts on the Bryant Park Stage, on Aug. 14, 16 and 17 at 12:30 p.m. ... Brian Stokes Mitchell will make his Carnegie Hall solo debut in an Actors Fund benefit performance on Oct. 15. Guests will include Reba McEntire and Phylicia Rashad. ... The 42-member a cappella choir of the Sretensky Monastery, founded in Moscow at the end of the 14th century, will make its United States debut on Sept. 4, singing at Avery Fisher Hall at the start of a world tour.
Frank Zappa, the Grammy Award-winning Rock and Roll Hall of Famer who died in 1993, is now a street in Berlin.
Beginning in November the Stratford Festival of Canada will be known as the Stratford Shakespeare Festival.

Mayor Francis Slay of St. Louis has rejected a request from organizers of the Big Muddy Blues Festival to proclaim Sept. 2 Ike Turner Day in honor of the 75-year-old Grammy Award winner and Rock and Roll Hall of Fame member who is scheduled to perform then. But Mr. Turner, right, said that he never asked for the accolade, that he already had a star on the St. Louis Walk of Fame, and that he didn’t worry about those honors, The Associated Press reported. “I just care about making people happy in the audience,” he said. The mayor turned down the request after his office received complaints that honoring Mr. Turner would send the wrong message, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported. Mr. Turner’s troubles include 17 months in jail on a 1990 drug conviction, and depiction as an abusive husband in “What’s Love Got to Do With It,” a 1993 movie about his ex-wife Tina Turner.

A performance by Arlo Guthrie at 7:30 p.m. Thursday will usher in this year’s Lincoln Center Out of Doors. Under the title “Summer of Love: Celebrating the Spirit of the ’60s,” the festival will offer more than 100 free performances of music, dance and street theater through Aug. 27.
A new outdoor installation in Queens pays tribute to New Orleans, a street in Berlin is named after Frank Zappa and more culture news.

“Social Dress New Orleans — 730 Days After,” an outdoor installation by Takashi Horisaki, a Japanese sculptor and performance artist based in New York, is on view in Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens, until the fall. (Above, a volunteer helping to assemble the work on Saturday.) Earlier this month in New Orleans, where he used to live, Mr. Horisaki applied layers of latex mixed with paint to create a textured 3-D print of a condemned Lower Ninth Ward house. The thin but strong rubber skin was transported to New York, where it was stretched over a frame that mimics the original structure.

Sudden acceleration of his heartbeat forced Paul Stanley, 55, lead singer and guitarist of Kiss, to bow out of a concert on Friday night at Soboba Casino, about 90 miles east of Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. His band mates, Gene Simmons, Tommy Thayer and Eric Singer, played the engagement while Mr. Stanley, right, was taken to a hospital. On his Web site, paulstanley.com, he wrote on Saturday, “During sound check yesterday, my heart rate spontaneously jumped to 190 plus beats per minute, where it stayed for over an hour, necessitating paramedics to start an IV and give me a shot to momentarily stop my heart and get it into a normal pattern.” Mr. Stanley added that consultations with the paramedics and a cardiologist at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center confirmed his worst fear: “They said I would put myself at risk if I tried to do the show.”.
Like MySpace before it, Facebook, the online social network, is being subjected to accusations that it does not do enough to keep sexual predators off its site.
Mets starter John Maine faced only 16 batters and allowed just one runner before the game ended prematurely because of rain after a delay of 90 minutes.
Shares of the Kingdom Holding Company of the billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia rose as much as 41 percent.
A year after the United States began a “strategic economic dialogue” with China, the word “dialogue” hardly seems to apply.
NEW HAVEN, July 29 (AP) — After five months of service, Pan Am Clipper Connection plans to end its service on Monday between Tweed New Haven Regional Airport and the Baltimore-Washington area.
The Today Sponge contraceptive is once again on sale and is the focus of a marketing campaign by its new owner, Synova Healthcare Group.
“The Simpsons Movie” sold a strong $71.9 million in tickets at United States theaters over the weekend and another $100 million overseas, making it No. 1 at the box office.
Two concerts at this venerable summer festival in the Berkshires made music, but were also opportunities to see how Kurt Masur and James Levine were getting along.
If you want to have a Coke and a smile, and you don’t mind being engulfed by an enormous commercial, this museum offers its own puzzles and pleasures.
New releases from Sean Kingston, Common, the Charlie Hunter Trio and Behemoth.
To the ardent pianophiles who flock to the International Keyboard Institute & Festival at Mannes College the New School for Music every summer, the Canadian virtuoso Marc-André Hamelin is royalty.
Jomar Mesquita and his Mimulus dance company ought to be bottled and sold as elixir.
Leon Botstein conducted the American Symphony Orchestra in new productions of “A Florentine Tragedy” and “Dwarf,” one-act operas both effectively directed by Olivier Tambosi.
Zack De La Rocha is the lead rapper and agitator and sermonizer of Rage Against the Machine, but on Saturday night at Randalls Island he barely talked between songs.
A column killed at The Los Angeles Times finds new life on a Web site called L.A. Observed.

10 P.M. (2) SIMON SCHAMA’S POWER OF ART Mark Rothko could be something of a crank. When he was asked to paint a series of large abstractions for the Four Seasons restaurant in Philip Johnson’s elegantly modernist Seagram Building, it rubbed him the wrong way. But he’d only recently begun to sell his abstractions, and he needed the money. So he accepted the commission by saying, “I hope to ruin the appetite” of everyone ”who eats in that room.” Eventually, in 1959, Rothko himself went to eat in that room, after which he returned the money and withdrew his paintings. In this series finale Mr. Schama, above, talks about how Rothko lost his own appetite.

de NAPOLI--Dr. Robert Anthony of Rye, New York on July 28, 2007. Loving and devoted husband of Joan (nee Ferreri). Beloved father of Joyce and Robert. Cherished grandfather of Christopher and Cara. Dear brother to Louis and his wife, Anne. Dear father-in-law to Michael. Admired brother-inlaw of Ellen and John Aversa and the late Dr. Carl Ferreri and loving uncle to many nieces and nephews. Dr. de Napoli graduated from Dartmouth College and Harvard Medical School. After completing his service in the US Army, he continued his residency at the Neurological Institute of Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City. Since 1960 until his retirement in 2004, he was an attending physician and clinical professor of Neurology at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology, A.M.A. Medical Society of New York and numerous other organizations and societies. Dr. de Napoli has also published numerous papers in the field of Neurology. Visiting hours will be held at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY on Tuesday, July 31st from 3-9pm. Funeral Mass will take place on Friday, August 3rd at 11:00 am at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, the de Napoli family requests that donations be made in his name to the Greenwich Woods Health Care Center, 1165 King Street, Greenwich, CT 06831.

CHARLIE HUNTER TRIO ''Mistico'' (Fantasy) Ruggedness suits Charlie Hunter, a groove-minded guitarist known for his distinctly ambidextrous technique. On ''Mistico,'' his first album for the Fantasy label, he rarely reaches for a dazzling run where a juicy riff will do the trick. His main pursuit seems to be the unpretentious logic of a working band and the freedom to do with it what he pleases.

BEHEMOTH ''The Apostasy'' (Century Media) The new album from the Polish metal band Behemoth is called ''The Apostasy,'' and it ends with a ferocious song called ''Christgrinding Avenue,'' inspired by Via Dolorosa in Jerusalem. In that track the band's vocalist and guitarist, known as Nergal, makes a plain-spoken vow: ''I shall complete the devil's work.'' Certainly that sounds pretty apostatic.

COMMON ''Finding Forever'' (Geffen) Common isn't a flashy rapper. His tone is forthright and matter of fact, and he rattles off his rhymes steadily in their chosen meters, without sudden emphases or bursts of speed. Yet Common's sheer straightforwardness lets him transcend hip-hop's factions. He has the social consciousness of a collegiate underground rapper, but he also has Top 10 sales figures; his previous album, ''Be,'' from 2005, entered the pop charts at No. 2. He's genuinely respectful toward women without denying his lust. And he's not the kind of hip-hop purist who would disdain a pop hook.

An article on Thursday about the arraignment of three men in the shooting of two New York police officers, one of whom died, misstated the schedule set by a judge for a trial in the case. The trial is expected to begin by February, not by ''Feb. 30.'' The error occurred when an editor saw the symbol ''-- 30 --'' typed at the bottom of the reporter's article and combined it with the last word, ''February.'' It is actually a notation that journalists have used through the years to denote the end of an article. Although many no longer use it or even know what it means, some journalists continue to debate its origin. A popular theory is that it was a sign-off code developed by telegraph operators. Another tale is that reporters began signing their articles with ''30'' to demand a living wage of $30 per week. Most dictionaries still include the symbol in the definition of thirty, noting that it means ''conclusion'' or ''end of a news story.'' -- 30 --

SEAN KINGSTON ''Sean Kingston'' (Beluga Heights/Epic) Sean Kingston is 17, and he already has a summer smash, ''Beautiful Girls'' in which he explains his romantic entanglements using a vocal processor and a sample from Ben E. King's ''Stand By Me.'' His girlfriend is ''too beautiful, girl, that's why it'll never work,'' though it seems the problem goes back a while: ''Back in '99, watching movies all the time/Oh, when I went away for doing my first crime/And I never thought that we was gonna see each other.'' (It's so hard to find a good woman, especially when you're a 9-year-old criminal.) The whole situation leaves him ''suicidal, suicidal,'' though some radio stations play the version that leaves him ''in denial, in denial,'' and still others just erase those eight semi-controversial syllables altogether.

WALSH--Nancy Sexauer, of Palm Beach, FL., died Sunday, July 22, 2007, at Good Samaritan Hospital, after a short illness. Mrs. Walsh was born in New York, NY on April 8, 1938, the daughter of James M. and Dorothy Sexauer. She was educated in schools in New York City and Westchester County, New York. Mrs. Walsh had been a resident of Palm Beach since 1983 and a member of Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, NY. Mrs. Walsh was an accomplished equestrian and rode in many successful shows, as evidenced by the myriad ribbons proudly displayed in her home. Prior to her recent illness, she owned and rode her horse in Wellington, FL. Mrs. Walsh was the President and Chairwoman of The Sexauer Foundation and served on the boards and committees of numerous charitable and philanthropic organizations and societies in the Palm Beach and surrounding areas. Her untiring efforts and the contribution of her many talents to the numerous functions of the societies earned her many awards and gratitude for her time and dedication to their worthy causes. Mrs. Walsh is survived by her son James R. Walsh and his wife Grayson Braun Walsh of Westport, CT, and many devoted and loving friends. The family received friends and a service was held at 11:00am on Wednesday July 25, 2007 at Quattlebaum - Holleman Burse Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, Florida. A memorial service will be held at the John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, NY at 11 am on Wednesday. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Nancy Sexauer Walsh may be made to The Sexauer Foundation, Bank of America, 396 Royal Palm Way, Palm Beach, Florida 33480.
