All of the immature egg cells (oocytes) a woman will ever produce are stored in the ovaries by the time she is born. The average age that girls begin to menstruate is 12 years old. Each menstrual cycle occurs approximately every 28 days. During each cycle, hormonal messages from the brain cause the ovaries to develop a single mature egg cell for potential fertilization, even as other hormones instruct the uterine lining to thicken in preparation for nourishing the fertilized egg cell.
This animation shows a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) procedure in which a portion of vein is grafted on the heart to reroute blood from a blocked section of a coronary artery.
This animation provides a general overview of the nervous system and shows the process in which nerve impulses are transmitted.
This animation illustrates the passage of air and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide within the lungs on both a gross and microscopic level.
This animation demonstrates how an ultrasound identifies the solid and hollow areas of structures within a fetus.

This animation shows an enlargement of a blood capillary with red blood cells traversing through it. A section of the artery is enlarged further to display the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide between a capillary and its surrounding tissue.

This animation shows a Directional Coronary Atherectomy (DCA) procedure performed to remove the blockage from the coronary arteries by a tiny spinning cutter that slices away plaque lesions and stores them to be withdrawn.

This animation illustrates the organization of skeletal muscle, enlarging from a muscle belly up to its myofibrils. Simultaneously in side and front views, the actions of a leg muscle and its myofibrils are shown while performing leg extension exercises.
This animation highlights the major parts of the digestive system and follows the breakdown of celery from consumption to excretion.
This animation enlarges a section of skin to illustrate melanocytes producing melanin in response to sun exposure. Also depicted on this enlarged section is sunburn and skin cancer.
This animation shows an enlargement of a section of skin to highlight an individual sweat gland. The gland then expels sweat onto the surface of skin.
This animation highlights the individual bones and groups of bones that comprise the skeletal system.
From a side view of the head, this animation shows the step-by-step process and mechanism of chewing and swallowing a piece of celery.
This animation illustrates and compares the severity of an ankle sprain (Type I, II, III).

This animation shows the mechanism of coughing caused by an irritant entering the windpipe (larynx), resulting in its dislodgement. The steps of the coughing reflex are shown from a side view of the body in tandem with a top view of the vocal cords.

This animation depicts the inhalation of air and scent molecules from a rose into an enlarged sagittal view of the nasal cavity. The smell receptors are magnified further to show their action of relaying a neural message of “scent” to the brain.

This animation begins with a top view of the tongue then magnifies and shows two individual taste buds detecting taste molecules. The various taste centers (bitter, sour, sweet, and salty) are highlighted on the tongue.

This animation shows the body’s response to a bee sting on the nose, giving a general description of the communication between the peripheral nervous system detecting the pain and the central nervous system issuing a reactive response.
This animation highlights the major sections of the brain and explains their primary functions.
This animation shows a vasectomy procedure.
A vibrating suction cannula is shown removing abdominal fat.
This animation shows a breast reduction (lift) procedure.
This animation describes a series of cosmetic surgeries, including forehead lift, eyelid lift, and facelift.

This animation shows a Percutaneous Transluminal Coronary Angioplasty (PTCA) procedure to open up blocked coronary arteries by inflating a tiny balloon to compress the plaque against the walls of the artery, flattening it out so that blood can once again flow through the blood vessel freely.
This animation shows the use of balloon angioplasty to open a narrowed coronary artery lumen caused by deposits of plaque.
This animation shows the procedure of a heart bypass surgery.

This animation describes and depicts the common reasons for having a cesarean section delivery. The location of an epideral application is shown in a side view followed by a Cesarean section delivery illustrated in both side and front views.
Normal, healthy lungs are compared to the lungs of a long-term smoker.
In an enlarged view of a cut section of a small artery, this animation shows a vaccine injection and follows the path of its antigens, initiating the body's development of antibodies.

This animation shows an enlarged view of femoral bone marrow containing immature specialized white blood cells (lymphocytes) and depicts their maturation and migration into either B cell or T cell lymphocytes.
This animation gives a general comparison between anaerobic exercise (lifting weights) and aerobic exercise (jogging).
This animation shows the affects of untreated glaucoma.

This animation highlights from a mid-sagittal view the structures of the male reproductive system and the pathway of ejaculate. A testicle is sectioned and enlarged to depict its internal anatomy, including a microscopic view of individual sperm.
This animation shows the neurological control of normal bladder function.
This animation shows the formation of a bunion.

This animation highlights the structures of the male reproductive system and the pathway of ejaculate. A testicle is sectioned and enlarged to depict its internal anatomy, including a microscopic view of individual sperm.
This animations shows the process of Intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), a procedure used to fertilize an egg cell outside of the body.
This animation shows a cerebral aneurysm growing and rupturing filling the brain with blood.
This animation shows an enlarged view of one lymph node filtering out micro-organisms from the fluid passing through.
From a top view of the voice box (larynx) and vocal cords, this animation shows the formation of a malignant tumor on the right vocal cord.
This animation shows corneal infections resulting from corneal injury.
This animation illustrates the various structures of the eye and how the shape of the eye affects vision (nearsightedness and farsightedness.
This animations depicts how a cataract is seen in the eye.
This animation shows the process of macular degeneration in the eye.
This animation discusses and depicts several aspects of the lymphatic system including a microscopic view of lymph formation, edema, breast lymphatics and the spread of breast cancer.
This animation depicts hypertension caused by pre-eclampsia that adversely affects the fetus by causing constriction of the placental arteries.

In a general overview, the formation and passage of urine through the various components of the urinary system is shown. Enlarged areas include the kidney, sectioned kidney, nephrons, renal corpuscle, and passage of particles and red blood cells within.
This animation illustrates some common skin conditions such as moles, birthmarks, age spots, and warts.
From a side view of the head and neck, this animation shows the structures involved in snoring. The common causes for snoring are also discussed.
This animation shows the brain and the changes that occur to it from Alzheimer's disease.
This animations shows sporatic brain activity and a twitching hand that occur with Parkinson's disease, followed by treatment with dopamine stimulation.
This animation illustrates the location of basal ganglia in the brain. Injury to the basal ganglia may result in athetosis (constant writhing movements of the body).
This animation shows a stroke resulting by an embolism traveling from an internal carotid artery and lodging within a cerebral artery in the brain.
This animations shows a piece of clot breaking away from the heart, travelling to the brain, resulting in a stroke.
This animation shows the various structures of the ear and the process of hearing.

Through a series of magnifications of the ear, this animation depicts the movement, amplification, translation, and interpretation of sound waves traveling through the ear’s three regions, ultimately becoming neural messages sent to the brain.

This animation begins with an front view of the urinary tract and continues with the formation of kidney stones shown in a cut-section of the kidney. Severities of kidney stones are depicted, demonstrating various degrees of urine obstruction.
This animation shows displacement of an intervertebral disk (disk between the vertebrae).
This animation shows the eye’s response to invading foreign substances, resulting in blinking and the lacrimal gland’s production of tears which then pass into the nose through tear ducts.
This animation compares a normal adult knee joint and a knee joint affected by osteoarthritis.
This animation shows uric acid crystals moving to the big toe joint causing pain.
This animation illustrates the prostate gland and its surrounding structures and shows the effects of benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH).

This animation illustrates the glands of the endocrine system, specifically enlarging the pituitary gland, thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, thymus, adrenal glands, and pancreas. A communication path within the neuroendocrine system is also shown.
This animation describes the regulation of the pituitary gland and the hormones it releases to regulate various organs and processes in the body.
This animations depicts changes to the retina resulting from diabetes mellitus.

This animation depicts how certain ingested foods can cause regurgitation of the stomach’s contents back into the esophagus resulting in the sensation of heartburn. The relationship between the location of the esophagus and heart is shown in a front view of the body.

This animation illustrates the cardiac conduction system, a group of specialized muscle cells that signal the rest of the heart to contract. An ECG tracing is shown in tandem with a normal heart beat.
This animation shows the cardiac conduction system and the arrhythmias of a fast and slow beating heart.
This animation shows a heart with tachycardia.
This animation shows atherosclerosis.
This animation shows a catheter being inserted into the heart where alcohol is injected causing the swollen ventricle wall to shrink.

This animation defines normal blood pressure and the measurement of systole and diastole. Structures shown include a front-view of the heart beating, a cut-view of the heart beating, and blood flowing through a small artery.
This animation shows the effects of hypertension on a cerebral artery.
This animation shows the process of red blood cell formation and the components that comprise blood.
This animation shows the cycle of blood circulation through the heart, arteries, veins, and lungs within the body.
This animation depicts the process of blood clotting in an enlarged view of a small artery. Cells shown include red blood cells, platelets, fibrin, and clotting factors.
This animations shows the head receiving two impacts. One on the front, and one on the side from a boxing glove.
This animation shows a dislocation of the shoulder joint.
This animation illustrates the major structures of the respiratory system and shows the mechanism of breathing (respiration.
This animation shows the passage of allergens (pollen) into the nasal cavity. The body response includes the release of histamine, a chemical that produces allergy symptoms in the body.
This animation begins by showing a hip fracture due to osteoporosis. The bone then dissolves into a frontal section to compare the bony interior of a normal femur to that of an osteoporotic femur.
This animation begins by showing a hip fracture due to osteoporosis. The bone then dissolves into a frontal section to compare the bony interior of a normal femur to that of an osteoporotic femur.
Commissioner Bud Selig was at Dodger Stadium to watch Barry Bonds pursue Hank Aaron's record again on Wednesday night, but Selig did not sound like someone who was thrilled to be in Los Angeles.

My Thursday column is from Yamhill, Oregon, my hometown, and is about the disgraceful new farm bill that House Democratic leaders have backed. We all know that our ag subsidies harm Africa and are hugely costly, but one of my points is that they are also bad for the family farm and rural America itself. I'd welcome your comments here.
A group of hecklers stood outside the visiting clubhouse at Dodger Stadium on Tuesday night, waiting for Barry Bonds.

In case you glide by The Times's home page on the Web tonight, we'd like to call your attention to an article by Russ Buettner on the long-longstanding relationship between former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani and Roger Ailes, of Fox News.
Former Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld testified about his knowledge of the death of Army Ranger Pat Tillman.

Enceladus is the coolest place in the solar system you've likely never heard of. And Enceladus, one of the moons of Saturn, is indeed cool - its surface temperature averages about minus-325 degrees Fahrenheit. It is also the shiniest object in the solar system, reflecting almost all of the light that hits it.
Zimbabweans try cope with the effect of 10,000-percent-a-year hyperinflation on their food supply.

For years developing nations like Brazil argued that they should play no role in cutting greenhouse gas emissions. After all, they said, the rich world has been responsible for putting most of the CO2 already there up in the atmosphere, and poor countries need to industrialize at top speed to alleviate grinding poverty.

Of the two great filmmakers who died this week, Ingmar Bergman lent images to the world of pop culture in a way that Michelangelo Antonioni did not -- mainly by virtue of the chess game with Death in "The Seventh Seal." (Of course, he was also referenced by Woody Allen, over and over and over.)
CNBC Advertisement with Julie Clark, Founder, The Baby Einstein Co.
CNBC Advertisement with Mel Karmazin, Chief Executive, Sirius Radio.
CNBC Advertisement with Bob Johnson, Founder, The RLJ Companies.
CNBC Advertisement with Herb Kelleher, President and Chief Executive, Southwest Airlines.

Barack Obama's declaration, during a foreign-policy address today, that he would be willing as president to use military force against Al Qaeda in Pakistan ("If we have actionable intelligence about high-value terrorist targets and President Musharraf won't act, we will") has provoked a blogburst. (Here's The New York Times news story on Obama's speech.)
The House of Mouse is about to its doors to flocks of virtual penguins.
A. O. Scott reviews "El Cantante," starring Marc Anthony and Jennifer Lopez.
The New York Times Co-Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Hot Rod" a film about an unintelligent, untalented, aspiring stuntman.

With permit in hand, our builder, Johnny, is ready to begin, but he can't start construction until Bank of America closes our loan. He thinks it's stupid, but it is bank policy. And since the bank is waiting for a couple of documents from the county, we've got to wait, too - but it looks like we can actually break ground in about a week!

The wheels continued to fall off for Magnus Carlsen of Norway as he lost a second consecutive game at the Biel International Chess Festival, this time to Loek Van Wely of the Netherlands. The tournament's leaders are now Alexander Onischuk of the United States, who today beat Boris Avrukh of Israel, and Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan, who decided to take the day off by playing a 10-move draw against Alexander Motylev of Russia. ("Playing" does not seem like the right verb to describe such a game.) The games can be followed live or replayed at the tourament's official Web site.

The Blackstone Group has been feeling a chill on many fronts lately -- from Capitol Hill, labor unions and the stock market, just to name a few. But the private equity giant got a big batch of love letters Wednesday from the research departments at investment banks, which initiated coverage on Blackstone en masse with droves of "buy" ratings.
The news that Bear Stearns has halted withdrawals from a third hedge fund -- one that sounds much less risky than the two that collapsed -- is a reminder what happens when people suspect lies.
Wow, that was a lot of fun!
David Pogue reviews trivial gadgets in his weekly video report.
An animation depicts the insertion of electrodes into the brain of a patient with severe brain injury. (Source: Cleveland Clinic) Eds note: No sound
The first 30 teams have been announced in the Automotive X Prize, and that brings up one question:
Some writers' Web sites are expansive and welcoming. Others are grudging and spartan.
In her web column today, Robin Toner tackles the newest incarnation of one of the nation's oldest debates:
A U.S. mortgage lender and two Australian funds became the latest victims of a credit crunch that has seen volatility spike and spreads on high-yield corporate debt explode.
Houston Dynamo Coach Dominic Kinnear discussed the SuperLiga, Major League Soccer and the quality of American soccer compared to international leagues.

This just in: Hedge fund managers like to drink expensive booze, Dan Dorfman revealed Wednesday in the New York Sun. He reports that six hedgies showed up at Tse Yang, a Chinese restaurant in New York, and spent $4,800 on a single round of a rare cognac.

Bull, a French computer services company, said on Wednesday that, contrary to a recent report, it was not in negotiations with Hewlett-Packard nor had it received an offer from the American computer giant. "There are no ongoing negotiations, and we have not received a formal offer," Bull's chief executive, Didier Lamouche, told a conference call when asked about Hewlett-Packard."

Don't count on Rupert Murdoch holding on to Dow Jones and the Wall Street Journal for the long term, warns Slate's Jack Shafer, the media critic who has written many scathing columns about Mr. Murdoch since the media baron's News Corporation made its bid in May. He'll keep it long enough to destroy it, then sell it off, Mr. Shafer predicts.
Does James Cayne still feel like hitting the greens?
It's not often that I use a post on this site to link to the editorial page of the newspaper, but today I felt I simply had to. Please read "In Praise of Tap Water."

On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the "celebrity playlists" on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.
Matt and his camping partner hike and skinny dip on the way to Hidden Lake, in the Absaroka-Beartooth Wilderness.

Quadrangle Group, a media- and communications-focused investment firm based in New York, said Wednesday it had hired Daniel Rosensweig, the former chief operating officer of Yahoo, to open an office in Silicon Valley in September.

On Monday Daniel Boulud settled a lawsuit filed by busboys and runners who said he didn't promote them to be waiters because they weren't white. Today, the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission weighed in, filing a lawsuit that backed the workers' complaints.
The Wall Street Journal editorial page wants its readers to know that it won't be changing its political perspective just because Rupert Murdoch bought Dow Jones, the company that owns The Journal:
Genstar Capital, a private equity firm based in San Francisco that focuses on midsize companies, added Kevin T. O'Leary to its strategic advisory board.
Subtle revisions (a decorator calls them the 50-year fix-up) in a town resistant to change.

On Tuesday night's episode of "The Charlie Rose Show," DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin sat down with Charlie Rose and The New Yorker's Ken Auletta to talk about the News Corporation's $5 billion deal for Dow Jones. You can watch the full video after the jump.

For the last few weeks, Republican candidate Mitt Romney has been accusing the Democrats of using "defeatist" language on terrorism and the war in Iraq. Rudolph W. Giuliani has arguably been even tougher, calling Democrats the "party of losers" who "refuse to admit the existence of Islamic terrorism."

While Rupert Murdoch finally won his long-coveted prize -- gaining enough support from the deeply divided Bancroft family to buy Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal -- closing the $5 billion deal was a marathon of conference calls and all-nighters for those involved in the deal-making process.

Villain, savior or just an ambitious businessman? In Manhattan's financial district Tuesday, core Wall Street Journal readers who had been following the drawn-out Dow Jones takeover events had no shortage of opinions about Rupert Murdoch.

Lazard said second-quarter earnings fell 2.2 percent, as the firm completed fewer merger and acquisition assignments, but the profit was higher than analysts had forecast. Profit declined to $61.5 million, or 53 cents a share, from $62.9 million, or 60 cents a share, a year earlier, the New York-based company said.

Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, said profit rose 31 percent, beating analysts' estimates, on record second-quarter trading revenue. Net income climbed to 1.78 billion euros ($2.43 billion), or 3.60 euros a share, from 1.35 billion euros, or 2.44 euros, a year earlier, the Frankfurt-based bank said on its Web site Wednesday.

Australia's Macquarie Bank warned on Wednesday that retail investors in two debt funds face losses of up to 25 percent as fallout from the global credit crunch widened, knocking 10 percent off its shares.
Discovery Communications has scooped up a companion Web site to its upcoming Planet Green cable network, agreeing to buy Treehugger.com for about $10 million, The New York Post reported.

After holding an emergency auction, the bankrupt wireless carrier Amp'd Mobile is seeking approval for "very discrete asset sales" in a Wednesday, Aug. 1, hearing, The Deal.com said, citing a court schedule.
The Jones Apparel Group said Wednesday it plans to accept a $900 million cash bid for Barneys New York from Fast Retailing of Japan.
Former investors in Enron called on the White House on Tuesday to support efforts to hold third parties accountable when their actions help a company defraud investors.

The turmoil in the debt markets has claimed another casualty, with a British private equity firm, 3i, pulling its auction of NCP Services, a company that supplies traffic wardens to many of Britain's local councils, according to The Telegraph.
Dow Chemical, the largest chemicals group in the United States, is considering making a rival offer for Imperial Chemical Industries, the British maker of Dulux paints, The Telegraph reported.
One of the enduring criticisms lobbed at hedge funds is their lack of transparency. Now, regulators and lawmakers may soon have a new target in their fight against opacity.
Since New Zealand's government drastically reduced subsidies to farmers in the 1980s, its agricultural community has never been the same.

Technology Partners, one of the first venture capital firms to get into clean technology, announced it has raised $300 million for its eighth fund. The firm will use the funds to invest in clean tech companies as well as life sciences and health/lifestyle companies.

Since the News Corporation's offer for Dow Jones & Company was made public three months ago, Rupert Murdoch's business career, character and motives have been dissected in an effort to predict what he might do as the owner of The Wall Street Journal. Based on his history, Mr. Murdoch is expected to try to broaden The Journal's influence beyond pure business readers.
Another Bear Stearns hedge fund has been hit by turmoil in the mortgage market.

EGL shareholders have approved the $2 billion buyout of the logistics provider by Ceva Group, the company said Tuesday. The buyout of Houston-based EGL by Ceva, which is owned by affiliates of Apollo Management, is expected to close Thursday.
Canada's Brookfield Asset Management plans to spin off a 60 percent stake in its infrastructure operations to its shareholders in a deal worth about $600 million, the company said Tuesday.

Aon said Tuesday that it is once again considering a sale or spinoff of its Combined Insurance Company of America unit, a move analysts applauded along with the parent's stronger-than-expected financial results in the second quarter.

Berardino Libonati, chairman of Alitalia, the Italian state-controlled airline, resigned Tuesday following the failure of the government's attempt to sell the carrier. Mr. Libonati, who had been appointed to guide the airline's privatization, resigned after all prospective buyers pulled out of the sale last month following a seven-month auction.
South Korea is encouraging state firms to go public, but investors and big banks will have to wait until next year at least before crown jewels like Incheon International Airport hit the market.

The New York Press, the city's second-largest free weekly newspaper after The Village Voice, was expected to be sold Wednesday to Manhattan Media, a publisher of weekly newspapers, according to The New York Times.

A former Merrill Lynch broker was sentenced Tuesday in federal court in Brooklyn to a year and a day in prison for witness tampering and making false statements in connection with an alleged scheme to misuse information broadcast over brokerage "squawk boxes."

Since the News Corporation's offer for Dow Jones & Company was made public three months ago, Rupert Murdoch's business career, character and motives have been dissected in an effort to predict what he might do as the owner of The Wall Street Journal.

The telecommunications equipment maker Alcatel-Lucent posted its second consecutive loss in the second quarter on costs related to its recent merger and an unfavorable product and geographic mix, the company said Tuesday.

Among the many sources of private equity's huge war chests has been cash from university endowments. Now buyout firms are pouring some of that money back into colleges -- and the companies that service them and their students.
A selection of poems by the new Poet Laureate.
“Respect Yourself: The Stax Records Story,” a “Great Performances” documentary tonight on PBS, provides an essential account of auteurism in one of American music’s greatest eras.
After 12 seasons with the Minnesota Timberwolves, Kevin Garnett will join fellow All-Stars Ray Allen and Paul Pierce in Boston, making the Celtics instant contenders in the Eastern Conference.
With the additions of Ray Allen and Kevin Garnett, faith has been restored in Boston by a Celtics team belly-up in image not two months ago.

The last time I remember hearing Hal Steinbrenner speak was at a news conference introducing José Contreras in 2003. He was representing his father, George, and he stood up and said one sentence: "I'll keep it brief, but we're expecting great things."
“Summer ’04” is so plainly the product of meticulous forethought that the shooting script might have been etched on marble slabs.
In their no-frills documentary, “Out of Status,” Pia Sawhney and Sanjna N. Singh examine the actions of the Immigration and Naturalization Service after 9/11.
A new campaign for Fage Total yogurt places magazine advertisements opposite ads for Tourneau watches and Honora jewelry, suggesting that the expensive goods have been sitting in the yogurt.
An engineer in search of decent wine in Seattle four decades ago decides to make his own. The result is a trim, handsome winery housing one of America’s greatest producers of cabernet sauvignon.
The federal Department of Education  still has no system to detect and uncover misconduct by lenders and protect student borrowers, a new government report says.
Rudolph W. Giuliani is facing increased scrutiny over his friendship with Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News.
The Republican candidates’ failure to embrace a Sept. 17 YouTube debate has prompted a public soul-searching in the blogosphere by some loyal supporters.
If Pakistan fails to eradicate terror operations, the U.S. should strike targets there itself, the senator said today.
American companies lost their leadership of the domestic car market for the first time ever in July, a dismal month for sales.
An Aphrodite statue, one of the Getty’s prized pieces, is among the works to be returned, but it will remain at the museum until 2010.
A man whose brain was stimulated with electric current is talking after spending years in a barely conscious state.
The grim discovery today in Ghazni province heightened concerns for the fate of a group of South Korean hostages.
Lazard said its asset management business kept growing  while its mergers and acquisitions advisory work dropped slightly.
More than seven decades after the New Deal, the charge of 'socialism' still dogs Democrats' health care proposals as millions remain uninsured.
Iraq’s largest Sunni political faction resigned from Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki’s cabinet on Wednesday and bombings in Baghdad killed at least 76 people.
The Dow reversed course from a slump yesterday that led to a sell-off in Asia and carried over into Europe.
The deaths, announced today, of four American soldiers in Baghdad on Tuesday brought the total American military death toll in July to 78, the lowest monthly figure so far this year.
Investors in Europe and Asia showed concerns about widening mortgage woes in the United States.
Saudi Arabia’s foreign minister today said his country was considering opening an embassy in Baghdad.
Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said today it had signed a merger agreement with Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.
In his first shot at baseball immortality, Tom Glavine pitched six masterly innings Tuesday. But Guillermo Mota gave up the tying run in the eighth to deny Glavine his personal milestone.

Mwadi Mabika scored 19 points to lead the Los Angeles Sparks to a 73-63 victory over the host Liberty, handing the Liberty its season-high seventh loss in a row. Janel McCarville scored 16 points and Loree Moore had 10 for the Liberty (10-15).

A man was sentenced yesterday to 21 years in prison for his role in a home invasion that led to a shootout and left a 9-year-old boy severely injured. The boy, John Henry Romano, now 10, attended the sentencing of Tyreek Williams, one of three men the police say led the home invasion. John Henry is blind in one eye and cannot run or move his left arm as a result of the shooting. He was visiting a home in Inwood on Sept. 23 when, the police said, three intruders held the occupants at gunpoint. The police say the intruders got into a gunfight with a resident at the home. That resident, a licensed gun owner, shot Mr. Williams, who was hospitalized. Mr. Williams, 22, was arrested and pleaded guilty in May to charges of assault, robbery and burglary. A second man, believed to have wounded John Henry, is set to be tried in September. The police are seeking the third suspect.
Seven Yankees slugged a total of eight homers in a rout of the Chicago White Sox, but Alex Rodriguez was not involved in the offensive explosion.

Paula Radcliffe of Britain will not defend her world marathon title in Japan next month, UK Athletics said. Radcliffe, who gave birth to a daughter in January, wanted to focus on preparing for the Beijing Olympics.

Marathon Oil said it had agreed to buy Western Oil Sands of Calgary, Alberta, for $5.5 billion in cash and stock, giving it a stake in Canada’s oil sands market. Shareholders of Western Oil will get $3.6 billion in cash and Marathon stock worth about $1.9 billion. Marathon will also assume $650 million of Western Oil’s debt, valuing the deal at about $6.2 billion. As part of the deal, Western has to spin off WesternZagros, a wholly owned subsidiary with interests in Kurdistan.

Fuji Heavy Industries, the maker of Subaru cars, posted a loss for the first time in eight quarters after sales declined in the United States and Japan. The net loss was 332 million yen ($2.8 million), or 0.46 yen a share, compared with a profit of 4.6 billion yen, or 6.42 yen, a year earlier, Fuji said. Sales fell 3.4 percent, to 318.2 billion yen from 329.5 billion yen. Separately, Suzuki Motor said first-quarter profit rose 20 percent, helped by increased sales of compact cars in Asia and Europe and a weaker yen. Net income climbed to 24.4 billion yen ($205.3 million), compared with 20.3 billion yen, a year earlier, the Tokyo-based company said. Sales rose 17 percent, to 894.5 billion yen. Mazda said first-quarter profit fell 63 percent as losses from currency hedging more than doubled. Net income fell to 2.48 billion yen ($21 million), from 6.61 billion yen, a year earlier. Sales rose 11 percent, to 814.3 billion yen. Mazda is based in Hiroshima.

Robert M. Godsell, the chief executive of AngloGold Ashanti, plans to retire after running the company since its creation in 1998 and helping it become the world’s third-biggest gold producer with operations in 10 countries. Mr. Godsell, left, who will step down on September 30, will be succeeded by Mark Cutifani, the chief operating officer of Companhia Vale do Rio Doce’s nickel unit, AngloGold said. Mr. Godsell, 54, was the chief executive of Anglo American’s gold and uranium division from 1995 before taking over as head of AngloGold, a company formed by a merger of Anglo American’s separately traded gold companies and the gold assets of Minorco. Other acquisitions included Ashanti Goldfields of Ghana.

Two people were killed and seven wounded by gunfire during a bloody four hours overnight in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. It did not appear that the four shootings were related, the police said, even though two of them occurred three blocks apart.

An article in some editions on Saturday about criticism of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales by some Justice Department lawyers misquoted an opinion article in The Denver Post that was written by one of those lawyers, John S. Koppel. He wrote that under the Bush administration the Justice Department had been “thoroughly politicized” — not thoroughly publicized — “in a manner that is inappropriate, unethical and indeed unlawful.” Also, a chart in some editions misidentified the forum for a May 23 hearing at which Monica M. Goodling, a former aide to Mr. Gonzales, testified. The hearing was in the House, not the Senate.

An article on July 17 about the NorthEast Two-Spirit Society, an organization for gay American Indians based in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to one member, Kevin VanWanseele, a Kumeyaay Indian. Before he moved to New York, he had been living in a suburb of San Diego — not on the nearby Barona Indian Reservation, where he had grown up.

An article on July 12 about bombings of natural gas pipelines in Mexico, and a correction in this space on July 23, referred incorrectly to the cause of minor bombings in Mexico City last year. A coalition of guerrilla groups claimed responsibility for the bombings — not the splinter group whose correct name is the Revolutionary Army of the Insurgent People.

The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about discounting in the book industry, misstated the location and history of the Barnes & Noble bookstore on Union Square. It is on 17th Street, not 18th Street, in the former Century Building, which was acquired by Barnes & Noble in the 1990s; it is not the original store. (The first Barnes & Noble was opened on Fifth Avenue at 18th Street during the Great Depression.).

A picture caption with an article in Business Day on Friday about plans by Goldman Sachs to start a hedge fund, which will be managed by Raanan A. Agus, the head of its equity proprietary trading desk, misidentified the man shown. He is Daniel H. Stern, founder of Reservoir Capital — not Eric Mindich, who had previously been a part of that trading desk at Goldman.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the restaurateur Daniel Boulud’s settlement of a discrimination lawsuit misidentified the plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed against the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York, an organization that had criticized Mr. Boulud. They are former employees of Windows on the World, the World Trade Center restaurant destroyed on 9/11 — not of Colors, a restaurant created after 9/11 by other former employees of Windows on the World.
An article on Sunday about lawsuits filed over proceeds from the sale of handmade quilts from Gee’s Bend, Ala., omitted the surname of one plaintiff. She is Lucinda Pettway Franklin.

An article on July 12 about bombings of natural gas pipelines in Mexico, and a correction in this space on July 23, referred incorrectly to the cause of minor bombings in Mexico City last year. A coalition of guerrilla groups claimed responsibility for the bombings — not the splinter group whose correct name is the Revolutionary Army of the Insurgent People.

An article and headline on July 19 about Exxon Mobil’s cleanup of an underground oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to the source of the 17 million gallons of oil and oil products that the state estimates has contaminated Newtown Creek and its banks. Although an explosion in 1950 contributed to the contamination, the area has been used by various petroleum companies for more than 140 years, and the 17 million gallons accumulated gradually over that time — not all at once after the explosion. (The error also appeared on Nov. 1, 2005; June 23, 2006; and on Feb. 9, July 16 and July 18 of this year.).

An article in some copies on Saturday about the complex relationship between Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York and Andrew M. Cuomo, the state attorney general, whose office released a report criticizing Mr. Spitzer’s aides for misusing the State Police to discredit a political rival, misidentified the division once headed by Mr. Spitzer in the Manhattan district attorney’s office, where Mr. Cuomo also once worked. It is the labor racketeering unit, not the rackets bureau. (The error appeared in an article in some copies on July 19, 2005, and in an article on May 22, 2002.).

An article last Wednesday about the death of a Staten Island teenager who was a passenger in a car that the police said was speeding before it crashed misspelled the name of a street where car racing was reported in April. It is Drumgoole Road, not Drumgould.
When Hank Aaron broke the career home-run record 33 years ago, Vin Scully made a call that evoked race, history and the American experience. Barry Bonds should not expect the same.

For many straphangers, encountering a broken elevator or escalator can be one of the more unpleasant surprises of travel in the subway system, requiring a long trek up a hot flight of stairs. For riders in wheelchairs, it can be far more than an inconvenience, requiring a lengthy detour to get out of the subway system.

At least 14,000 people have evacuated homes, hotels and campgrounds on the Canary Islands as firefighters struggled to extinguish fires in two popular tourist spots. About 8,800 people were displaced on Tenerife, where fires have burned 37,500 acres of forest and destroyed 900 homes. On Grand Canary, 2,000 acres of woodland were charred, 5,200 people evacuated and at least 60 homes engulfed by flames. The police said they had arrested a forest ranger who admitted starting the Grand Canary fire, saying his job contract was about to expire.

The Berlin Zoo is putting Knut the polar bear cub on a diet. Knut, whose legendary cuteness has doubled zoo attendance since his debut in March, is now 8 months old and weighs 132 pounds. More than his actual weight, it was his physical appearance that persuaded the staff to make the change, said the zoo’s veterinarian, Andreas Ochs. “If Knut would live outdoors, this wouldn’t be so bad,” Dr. Ochs said. “However, in captivity, the bear won’t need to fend off a grim winter.” Knut’s four daily meals will be reduced to three, he added, and “extras, like croissants, will need to be dropped.”.
President Umaru Yar’Adua reshuffled top officers in Nigeria’s powerful army, retiring about a dozen generals and shifting the commanders of several divisions.
An Ethiopian-American interpreter detained for more than two months without being charged was released over the weekend, American officials said.

The High Court delayed the demolition of Queen’s Pier, giving hope to activists working to preserve the former British colony’s architectural heritage. The 50-year-old pier, traditionally used by colonial governors and visiting royalty, was to be pulled down yesterday to make way for a highway. The court said it would review the case next Tuesday.
The new note is worth either $13 or $800 in United States money, depending on which of the government’s official exchange rates one uses.
The World Health Organization has warned that the region could face the worst outbreak of the mosquito-borne virus in nearly a decade.

The resolution will create the world’s largest peacekeeping operation, costing about $2 billion in its first year.
The Democratic strategy involves sending Republicans home to explain to voters why they have steadfastly backed President Bush on the war.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s commute is not your average straphanger’s ride.
Television, which was illegal under the Taliban, is off to a phenomenal start in a developing Afghanistan.
The director’s chilly depictions of alienation were cornerstones of international filmmaking in the 1960s.
Young girls who have been trafficked abroad into prostitution are emerging as an AIDS risk factor in their home countries, according to a new study.
The German rider Patrik Sinkewitz, who tested positive for elevated levels of testosterone in June, was fired by his T-Mobile team after refusing to have his backup sample tested.
More than 400 police officers and federal agents took part in predawn raids, arresting 43 people suspected of being members of a gang, officials said.

Khalid Khannouchi, the Moroccan-born American who has twice broken the world record for the marathon, withdrew from Sunday’s NYC Half-Marathon.“It’s not an injury,” said Sandra Khannouchi, his wife, coach and manager. “He has a mechanical problem. His foot lands flat, and he has a burning sensation.”.

The Rangers avoided a potentially contentious arbitration hearing by agreeing to terms with forward Marcel Hossa on a one-year contract worth $780,000. The only deal still unsettled is with forward Sean Avery.

Tony Stewart was fined $25,000 and docked 25 championship points by Nascar yesterday for using what Nascar called inappropriate language during an interview with ESPN after he won the Allstate 400 on Sunday in Indianapolis. Stewart held on to fifth place in the series standings but was 17 points ahead of Carl Edwards instead of 42.

Brendan Hansen, the world-record holder in the 200-meter breaststroke, won the event in 2 minutes 9.91 seconds at the United States Championships in Indianapolis. Michael Phelps, who rarely enters the 200 meters, was 11th. Other winners were Kathleen Hersey and Darvis Tarwater in the 200 butterfly, Rebecca Soni in the 200 breaststroke, Kate Ziegler in the 800 freestyle and Erik Vendt in the 1,500 freestyle.
auto racing.

Scott Speed, the only American driver in Formula One, was dropped by the Toro Rosso team and replaced with Sebastian Vettel of Germany. Speed, a 24-year-old from Manteca, Calif., has not finished in the top eight of any race in his two Formula One seasons.
South Korea on Tuesday urged the American and Afghan governments to show “flexibility” over Taliban demands for the release of imprisoned militants.
Rudolph W. Giuliani called for a voluntary move from an employer-based system to one that would grant tax benefits to people who buy their own insurance.

HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., July 31 — For centuries this village was the center of activity on Long Island, until modern suburbia exploded around it and decay set in.

A 62-year-old sculpture of the flag-raising on Iwo Jima is getting the heave-ho from the museum on the aircraft carrier Intrepid while the ship is docked in Staten Island for an overhaul.

The House approved sweeping ethics rules that would impose new restrictions on gifts and require lawmakers to disclose the names of certain lobbyists.

After months of growing tension with the Jordanian government, the opposition Islamic Action Front abruptly withdrew from nationwide municipal council elections on Tuesday.

The reaction of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe indicated strongly that the Japanese government would not offer surviving victims an official apology.
The New York Press, the city’s second-largest free weekly newspaper, is expected to be sold to Manhattan Media, a publisher of weekly newspapers.

A Somali man linked to a plot to blow up a shopping mall pleaded guilty to conspiring to provide material support to terrorists.
Voters will be required to show photo identification at the polls for a special election in September.
The lawyer for a surgeon charged with prescribing excessive drugs to a disabled patient to speed up his death says his client has been the subject of a “witch hunt.”
Investigators looking for human remains outside a home in Ocean City where a woman is accused of stashing four dead fetuses have finished their search without finding any more bodies.

Gay-rights groups and those who have obtained civil unions in New Jersey say the reality of the civil union law’s application is a hodgepodge.
For the fourth year in a row, Senator Byron Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, is seeking to implement legislation that would curb the shortcomings of boxing’s medical safeguards.
Adm. Michael G. Mullen said American military efforts in Iraq would fail unless Iraqi leaders did more.
When D’Brickashaw Ferguson, then a rookie with the Jets, began to lose weight last season, the worry was that the blocker protecting quarterback Chad Pennington’s blind side was wearing down.
Nelnet, a student loan company, agreed to pay into a fund to educate high school students about financing college, settling an inquiry into its business practices.
More than 60 dogs seized from Michael Vick’s property have been sheltered in Surry, Va., and in kennels across several counties in southeastern Virginia since April.
The reduction follows a record 331 fatalities from April to June during intensive military operations in Baghdad and Diyala Province.

Senator Lisa Murkowski has been drawn into ethics accusations that have brought F.B.I. scrutiny to the two other members of Alaska’s Congressional delegation.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,644 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
The nonwaiver trade deadline came and went Tuesday afternoon with the Mets looking exactly as they had when they arrived here Monday night: with a new second baseman, Luis Castillo.

ALBANY, July 31 — Senate Republicans said Tuesday that they would start hearings as early as next week that could become a public forum for investigating Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration. They did not rule out seeking to compel the governor’s testimony.
A small but recently growing number of Indian-American officeholders has been getting elected in communities across the nation where they are the tiniest of minorities.

The political message in Japan is clear: If Shinzo Abe is determined to stay as prime minister, he must change course.
Erik Bedard allowed two hits over six innings to win his seventh decision in a row, and the Baltimore Orioles beat the host Boston Red Sox, 5-3, last night despite two home runs by David Ortiz.
The Children’s Health Insurance Program has become a vehicle for an ideological struggle between President Bush and Congress over the future of the health care system.

New York State closed a deal yesterday to prevent most development on 51,590 acres of timberland in the northwest corner of the Adirondacks while allowing public access to the area for recreation. Conservation easements that cost the state $6.6 million will allow Rayonier Inc., a forestry company, to continue cutting timber from forests in the St. Lawrence County towns of Colton, Clifton and Clare. The easements will also allow recreational activities on the land and will provide access to branches of the Grasse River and its tributaries.
In Kingston, N.Y., a man recently celebrated the birthday of his car, a 1958 Edsel, the ugly duckling of its industry.

New York City’s 11 public hospitals will no longer offer free samples of baby formula in gift bags to new mothers, the city’s Health and Hospitals Corporation announced yesterday. The agency said the decision was meant to promote breast-feeding as part of the city’s campaign to improve infant health. The agency estimated that 24 percent of women who deliver at public hospitals breast-feed exclusively after they are discharged, up from fewer than 15 percent of such women a year ago. “Breast-feeding is a very important way to protect the health of babies and mothers,” said Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, the commissioner of the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene. Officials with the hospital agency said formula would be available for women who request it.

Four New Jersey cities — Atlantic City, Camden, Newark and Paterson — can begin giving clean needles to intravenous drug abusers under an experimental program approved yesterday to combat the spread of H.I.V. and AIDS. The pilot program, approved by the State Department of Health and Senior Services, will be a first for New Jersey, which had been the only state without a government-sanctioned way for drug addicts to exchange dirty syringes for clean ones. “Needle exchange is a proven public health intervention that will reduce the spread of H.I.V. and save lives,” said Fred M. Jacobs, the state health commissioner.

City Councilman James F. Gennaro, left, a Queens Democrat, has been fined $2,000 for asking a staff member to volunteer for his 2003 re-election campaign and for allowing city equipment to be used to write and print a campaign letter, both violations of the city ethics code, the Conflicts of Interest Board said yesterday. In a settlement with the board, Mr. Gennaro said he did not remember asking the staff member to volunteer for him and did not know that his city-supplied computer, printer and paper were used for a campaign letter, but he did not dispute either allegation. “Council member Gennaro accepts responsibility for any oversights that took place in his office in 2003,” his lawyer, Arnold N. Kriss, said in a statement. “Measures have been implemented to ensure that this will not happen again.”.

The State Department of Community Affairs announced yesterday that it would provide $17.7 million in extraordinary aid to local governments that say they will have to cut essential services without substantial property tax increases. The state provided $26 million in such aid last year. Gov. Jon S. Corzine said he knew that towns were struggling, but said the state had limited resources. William G. Dressel, the executive director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities, predicted the reduced aid would result in tax increases and service cuts, particularly in light of a recent announcement that local governments will owe substantially more in contributions for public worker pensions this year. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine did not waive his privacy rights to e-mail messages he exchanged with a state union leader who is a former companion when he asked his ethics advisers to review them, the administration argued in court papers filed yesterday. The filing was in response to a lawsuit filed by Tom Wilson, the state Republican Party chairman, seeking to make the messages public. Mr. Wilson has said he wants to see whether the messages between Mr. Corzine, a Democrat, and the union leader, Carla Katz, indicate that their relationship influenced recent contract talks. The governor and Ms. Katz are seeking to keep the messages confidential. Mr. Wilson has contended that Mr. Corzine waived privacy rights when he allowed the advisers to review them.

Two New York developers have signed an agreement to build a 1.2 million-square-foot office tower on the Far West Side that would serve as a hub for manufacturers of devices, diagnostics, computer systems and other equipment for the medical industry. The developers — Gary Barnett, the chief executive of the Extell Development Corporation, and Israel Green — said they planned to begin construction in early 2009. The tower would rise at 11th Avenue and 34th Street, on a site that is now home to the Copacabana nightclub. Mr. Green has spent five years developing the concept and pursuing a Manhattan location. He said it was an opportunity for New York City to become the principal center for the $260 billion global market for medical devices and diagnostics. The project may have to wait until the city completes part of an extension of the No. 7 subway line, which passes beneath the site.

New Jersey voters will decide in November whether to allow the state to borrow nearly $200 million to preserve open space under legislation signed yesterday by Gov. Jon S. Corzine. The proposal calls for spending $109 million to preserve open space and parkland, $73 million to preserve farmland, $12 million for antiflooding efforts and $6 million on historic preservation. Opponents say that New Jersey’s debt, which has grown to $30 billion since 2000, is too great to allow for more borrowing. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Laura Davies of England has been a professional golfer for more than 20 years and has won dozens of tournaments all over the world. But until Tuesday she had never played the Old Course.

A former Merrill Lynch broker was sentenced yesterday in federal court in Brooklyn to a year and a day in prison for witness tampering and making false statements in connection with an alleged scheme to misuse information broadcast over brokerage “squawk boxes.”.

The Yankees refused to trade the Class-AAA starter Ian Kennedy or Melky Cabrera for the Texas Rangers’ Eric Gagne, but did trade Scott Proctor to the Dodgers for infielder Wilson Betemit.

MIDNIGHT (IFC) INDIE SEX II: CENSORED The burlesque performer Dita Von Teese, at left with a friend, who knows that sometimes less obvious is more scintillating, is the host of this four-night festival, which explores how sexual fantasies have been played in independent films — and made it around production codes. First stop: “Indie Sex: Censored,” which moves from Eadweard Muybridge’s human-motion studies of naked men and women to the 1930s Hays Code to the Motion Picture Association of America’s institution of a formalized rating system in 1968 to its request at this year’s Sundance Film Festival that young filmmakers create more NC-17 movies. Peter Sarsgaard, Miranda July, Heather Matarazzo, John Cameron Mitchell, John Waters, Tatum O’Neal, Rosanna Arquette, Piper Perabo, Ally Sheedy, Guinevere Turner and Ms. Von Teese tell us what they think.

LEVINE--Selma, nee Kornhauser, 84, of Key Largo, FL and Livingston, NJ on July 29, 2007. Beloved wife of Herbert Levine, cherished mother of Vicki (Levine) Friedman and Janice Levine and sister of Charlotte Kornhauser. Devoted mother-in-law of Robert Friedman and grandmother of Jesse Friedman and Michael Friedman. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, August 1 at noon at Bernheim, Apter and Kreitzman Funeral Chapel in Livingston, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations may be made to The Ocean Reef Medical Center Foundation, 50 Barracuda Lane, Key Largo, FL 33037 (305.367.4224)

Stick to your old-fashioned roots and the market will eventually wake up. Take the Koeze Company's Cream-Nut peanut butter, for example. It has been made in Grand Rapids, Mich., from dark-roasted Virginia peanuts since 1925. Coarsely ground in small batches and lightly seasoned with sea salt, it is neither creamy nor chunky but totally irresistible. Jeff Koeze (pronounced COO-zee ) runs the company, and is the fourth generation of his family to do so. He uses vintage slow-grinding machines to produce exceptionally nutty-tasting peanut butter, which has been sold nationally for only the past year or so. When freshly made, it is well emulsified into a creamy consistency. The oil eventually floats to the top and has to be stirred back in. This does not affect quality, only convenience.

SALETAN--Lloyd, a good man, a friend, and a beloved cousin. Luv, Rhoda SALETAN--Lloyd. Lloyd Saletan died peacefully on July 29 after a brief illness. He was 83. A member of the Greatest Generation and a consummate New Yorker, Lloyd spent most of his life in Greenwich Village. He graduated from the Little Red School House and the High School of Music and Art. After serving as a bombardier in World War II, attaining the rank of Second Lieutenant, he graduated from Colgate University (B.A. magna cum laude, 1948) and studied at the London School of Economics (M.Sc., 1952). On retirement from a successful career in finance, Lloyd devoted himself to travel and the arts. He was a tireless theatre-, concert-, and museum-goer, with a special fondness for the opera. He combined profound appreciation with keen critical insight, which he readily shared with others. Lloyd was a generous and enthusiastic guide and host, endearing himself to his neighbors and welcoming visitors from the United States and abroad. He had a unique gift for bringing people together, and was cherished by a wide circle of friends and members of his extended family. Lloyd leaves behind his devoted friend Eddie; many cousins, especially Rhoda Goldberger and Stephen, Eugene, and Anthony Saletan; and a host of other friends.

BY an awful and uncanny coincidence -- the kind of occurrence that, in a movie, would have to be taken as symbolic lest it seem altogether preposterous -- Michelangelo Antonioni and Ingmar Bergman died on the same day. Since Mr. Bergman was 89 and Mr. Antonioni 94, neither man's death came as much of a shock, but the simultaneity was startling. Not only because they were both great filmmakers, but more because, in their prime, Mr. Antonioni and Mr. Bergman were seen as the twin embodiments of the idea that a filmmaker could be, without qualification or compromise, a great artist. Not that everyone agreed or saw them both in equally glowing light. There will always be those who scoff at the idea of cinema as a form of art. And those who do embrace the notion have always been notoriously prone to quarrel and dissension. In ''Anticipation of 'La Notte,' '' for instance, his touching, self-aware memoir of youthful cinephilia, Philip Lopate recalls being part of an undergraduate claque of film buffs in the early 1960s who worshiped Mr. Antonioni and disdained Mr. Bergman.

Nicole Richie and Paris Hilton, above, have lost their television gig. E!, the entertainment cable channel, said it had chosen not to renew their comedy reality series, ''The Simple Life.'' eonline.com said the final episode of the series, to be broadcast on Sunday, would feature the two at drama camp, ''enlisting the help of celebrity counselor Sally Kirkland.'' The Web site reported that 20th Century Fox, the producer, seemed to hold out hope another network would pick up the show, as E! did in 2005 after Fox dropped it. But, the site said, any new version would not star Ms. Hilton and Ms. Richie.

ABADIR--Akef R., ''Alex,'' 69, passed July 29, 2007. Noted author and scholar of Middle Eastern literature, his translation of ''God's World'' was cited by the Nobel Committee when it awarded Naguib Mahfouz its prize in 1988. Alex's profound passion for learning led to Ford Foundation and Penfield Scholarships which funded his studies in Egypt and American (at Cornell University and then NYU where he received his Ph.D.). Always one to ''pay it forward'' he gave tirelessly to help younger immigrants get started in America. Accordingly, contributions in his memory may be given to the Children of Nations organization at http://www.cotni.org. Alex is survived by his loving wife Cecilia, brother Adel, sisters Affef and Awatif, son Essam, and grandchildren Nile and Jolie -his last and greatest legacy. Relatives and friends are invited to services Friday 10:30am, St. Anastasia Church, Northern Blvd and 245th Street, Douglaston, NY 11362.

In steamy New Orleans, refreshment comes in the form of sno-balls: ice that has been shaved to a powder and drenched with bright syrup. The dense ice absorbs the syrup, making it more sorbet than slush, and more refined than the Italian ices known to New Yorkers. Eric Tilstra, right, who grew up in the Crescent City, thought it was time for beachgoers in Montauk, N.Y., where he was born, to experience sno-balls. It took him more than a year to get the equipment, the permits and a bright orange truck. Now, on Monday through Wednesday evenings from 6 to 10 p.m., and from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. the rest of the week, he dispenses Belly's Sno-Balls from his truck at the Kirk Park lot at the Montauk Village beach on Route 27.

Get your lit on outdoors tonight, at a reading series sponsored by Open City, the literary journal founded by Thomas Beller, of Mr. Beller's Neighborhood fame. Tonight's installment, in Tompkins Square Park, celebrates the 100th issue of Bomb Magazine, a Brooklyn quarterly that publishes indie writers, poets and artists. The readers include Ed Park, an editor of the magazine The Believer; Lore Segal, an octogenarian children's book writer and wit, and the author, most recently, of ''Shakespeare's Kitchen''; and Lynne Tillman. Her latest, ''American Genius,'' is ''a bold showcase of a novel,'' Lucy Ellmann wrote in her review, ''a cabinet of curiosity, a proposal for what fiction could be.'' Especially fiction in a park.

LIEF--Dr. Leonard, founding president, Lehman College, CUNY (1968-1990), World War II veteran, died July 30, 2007 in New Rochelle, age 83. Elizabethan scholar and life-long educator, he guided the expansion of academics and the arts at Lehman. He is survived by daughter, Madelon; stepchildren, Carol Irene ''Terry'' Rodgers and Scott Rodgers; five grandchildren; and two great-grandchildren. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Ruth Ann and Leonard Lief Scholarship Fund, Lehman College. LIEF--Leonard. Friends for 70 years, from Franklin K. Lane High freshmen to emeriti, we are finally separated. Leonard was a wonderful man, a scholar, a gentleman, a fellow Brooklyn Dodger and Mets fan and a mensch. The world is a lousier place without him and Suzanne and I, among many others, miss him. Ed Spingarn LIEF--Leonard. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Leonard Lief, President of Herbert H. Lehman College/ CUNY from its founding in 1968 as an independent senior college until 1990. It had earlier been the Bronx campus of Hunter College, where Dr. Lief began his CUNY career in 1955 as a professor of English and then Chairman of the English Department. He piloted Lehman College through the challenges of expanding student enrollments, the New York City fiscal crisis, imposition of tuition and times of budget austerity with unwavering commitment to high academic quality. Throughout his exemplary tenure, he expanded the college's facilities, hired outstanding faculty, set a tone of intellectual exploration, championed academic freedom, supported cultural activities and provided new opportunities to disabled students seeking higher education, particularly deaf and hearing-impaired students. We offer our deepest sympathies to his daughters Madelon Lief, and Carol Rodgers, and son Scott Rodgers. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr. Chairman Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein Chancellor

Good weather has blessed many crops in the New York region this year, and abundance at the Greenmarkets is a result. ''There has been enough rain, but not too much,'' said Fred Wilklow of Wilklow Orchards in Highland, N.Y. Tomatoes, top, and corn are in extremely good shape, as are zucchini. Squashes, including patty pans in various colors, sizes and patterns; herbs; a rainbow of peppers; four or five kinds of eggplant; five kinds of carrots; verdant okra; lettuces; cucumbers; green beans; and shell beans, which are just coming in, fill the vegetable stands. Velvety flat yellow Romano beans are $3 a pound from Berried Treasures in Cooks Falls, N.Y.

An article and headline on July 19 about Exxon Mobil's cleanup of an underground oil spill in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, referred imprecisely to the source of the 17 million gallons of oil and oil products that the state estimates has contaminated Newtown Creek and its banks. Although an explosion in 1950 contributed to the contamination, the area has been used by various petroleum companies for more than 140 years, and the 17 million gallons accumulated gradually over that time -- not all at once after the explosion. (The error also appeared on Nov. 1, 2005; June 23, 2006; and on Feb. 9, July 16 and July 18 of this year.) The article on July 19 also referred incorrectly to an agency, the Department of Environmental Conservation, that reviewed Exxon Mobil's water cleanup operation this year. It is a state agency, not a city one. The articles on July 18 and July 19 referred incompletely to soil tests taken to determine whether the spill has released toxic vapors into the neighborhood. Although previous tests, conducted by the Riverkeeper environmental group, showed the presence of such vapors, the most recent tests in residences in the area, conducted by the state, were negative.

New snack food alert: E-Mo's Kim Bab, in Koreatown, serves nothing but kim bap, seaweed rice rolls stuffed with fillings like beef, vegetables, tuna, kimchee, cheese, mushrooms -- or pickled jalapeño, ''the most palette tingling and enjoyable,'' says Nick Fox. ''It's a crunchy, chewy jumble of savory and sweet, crunchy and chewy, spicy and cool, familiar and surprising.'' Odds are, it'll be your favorite kim bap mom 'n' pop shop in no time.

Busy day in sunny Budapest it was. The sweltering heat of recent weeks has faded into a balmy 29 degree Celsius, blue skied afternoon. But it seems rain is predicted for at least part of the weekend. Today the center of Budapest was a mess of traffic as the police closed off portions of the city to allow Gerhard Berger to drive an old McLaren while Tonio Liuzzi drove a Toro Rosso on the chain bridge. Lewis Hamilton did an event for Hungarian go-karters. We don't know quite what his teammate Fernando Alonso did, since he was given permission by the FIA to skip the press conference but we were not told why.

The Russian mini-sub foray to the sea floor more than 14,000 feet beneath the crust of floating, shifting sea ice at the North Pole -- which left behind a titanium Russian flag, according to the official statements -- is just the latest in a decades-long chain of efforts aimed at making Russia the dominant power in the Arctic.

Magnus Carlsen of Norway has won the Biel International Chess Festival tournament after beating Alexander Onischuk of the United States in the fifth tie-breaker game. Carlsen trailed Onischuk and Teimour Radjabov of Azerbaijan by half a point going into the ninth round, but he smashed Radjabov while Onischuk could only manage a draw against Alexander Motylev of Russia. The games can be replayed at the tournament's official Web site.

Accredited Home Lenders, a subprime mortgage lender that agreed in June to be acquired by a private equity firm, said its survival is in doubt and that bankruptcy is possible, sending its shares down as much as 52.5 percent.

Updated: The Republican National Committee says it plans to go ahead with its summer meeting in Minneapolis over the next few days although with a revised schedule. Earlier today, Tracey Schmitt, a spokeswoman for the R.N.C., said the schedule was "in flux" after yesterday's highway bridge collapse.
