Jason Fagone argues in today's newsletter that golfers who use the new, weird putters strip the game of one of its inherent challenges. Take it a step further: Has modern equipment altered the game for better, or worse, and why?

Barack Obama's speech outlining a muscular antiterrorism policy wasn'this "Sister Souljah moment," says Thomas B. Edsall, political editor ofThe Huffington Post. But that's only because Obama has already had atleast two Sister Souljah moments, Edsall suggests.
I spotted Ben Harper, dynamite musician and devoted Dodgers' fan, in the concourse behind the first base box seats at Dodger Stadium on Wednesday night. I shook his hand and introduced myself.
Yahoo clearly wants a seat on the social-networking train. But how much should it spend for a ticket?

When the Democratic Leadership Council, a group made up of party moderates, wrapped up its annual meeting in Nashville earlier in the week having heard from none of the Democratic presidential candidates, many called it a "snub" -- especially since the entire field is jetting off to Chicago this weekend to address a convention of liberal bloggers.
Charles Simic is the new Poet Laureate of the United States - or PLOTUS, to borrow the jolly acronym his predecessor, Donald Hall, liked to employ.

Fiserv, an information manager for financial and insurance companies, said Thursday that it would buy CheckFree for $4.4 billion in cash. Fiserv will pay shareholders of the online banking and electronic payments company $48 a share.

Many say the outcome of Rupert Murdoch's $5 billion move on Dow Jones & Company was inevitable. But some unusual side transactions along the way to this week's agreement are raising questions about how the Bancroft family, which controls the company through a special class of shares, was persuaded to support the deal.

While market conditions have worsened, hedge funds may continue to feel prolonged pain, but private equity probably will not -- at least, not for some time. So while firms like Bear Stearns, Sowood Capital and Tudor Investment may see sudden losses in their profits, buyout firms should feel the pain only later on, Breakingviews argues.

Wall Street underwriters these days are probably wishing that buyout firms would abandon some of their announced leveraged buyouts, rather than force the banks to find financing in troubled markets. But according to The Financial Times' Lex column, there are lots of reasons why that won't happen.
NYSE Euronext reported Thursday a second-quarter profit that more than doubled, getting a boost from record trading on its European stock and derivatives markets.

Barclays, the British bank competing to buy ABN Amro, posted a 14 percent increase in first-half net income and said subprime mortgage defaults in the United States will not slow the investment bank this year.

Some hedge funds that have suffered losses on investments are closing the gate on clients who want to pull money out, a move that could further undermine confidence in already shaky financial markets. Hedge fund managers argue that by temporarily barring withdrawals, they are essentially protecting investors from themselves, by preventing sales of securities at deeply depressed prices.

Credit Suisse said second-quarter net income was up 48 percent from a year ago to 3.189 billion Swiss francs ($2.66 billion), well ahead of expectations, lifted by record earnings from investment banking and wealth management.
The pharmaceuticals maker Schering-Plough said Thursday it plans to sell 50 million common shares and $2.5 billion in mandatory convertible preferred stock in a public offering.
A new report from Dow Jones VentureOne reveals that venture firms in the United States have raised less capital during the first half of 2007 than in any other six-month period in almost four years.

Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia is joining forces with a private-equity partner GTCR Golder Rauner, to buy food-crafting company Wilton Industries and a paint-by-number specialist, Dimension Holdings, The New York Post reported.

Advanced Medical Optics on Wednesday withdrew its $4.23 billion unsolicited takeover bid for its rival eye-care company Bausch & Lomb, saying Bausch had put up unrealistic hurdles to a potential deal.

Houston-based Marathon Oil, which on Tuesday agreed to buy Western Oil Sands of Canada for about $5.56 billion, will pay a $1 million fine to settle allegations it tried to manipulate oil prices in 2003.

Cadbury Schweppes said Thursday morning it is prepared to spin off its North American soft drinks business if the proposed 7 billion pound ($14 billion) sale is scuppered by turmoil in credit markets. The group made the announcement as it unveiled a fall in first-half profits.

A day after two ailing Bear Stearns hedge funds filed for bankruptcy, the bank was slapped with a legal claim for allegedly misleading investors about the funds' exposure to subprime mortgages, a lawyer for an investor said Wednesday.
Landry's Restaurants says it is negotiating with its bankers to replace $400 million in bond debt with bank debt.
The Nasdaq Stock Market said late Wednesday that it supports the London Stock Exchange's plans to acquire an Italian rival, Borsa Italiana.

British Columbia Investment Management has struck a deal worth 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($1.1 billion) to acquire the Canadian Hotel Income Properties Real Estate Investment Trust, offering 19.10 Canadian dollars per unit.

Crescent Real Estate Equities said Wednesday that its shareholders overwhelmingly approved the sale of the company to Morgan Stanley Real Estate. At a morning shareholders meeting, 74 percent of the total shares outstanding voted in favor of the sale for $22.80 a share, Crescent said.

Canaan Partners said it led a $10 million financing for Associated Content, marking the second funding announcement for a community journalism Web site in one week. Canaan, a venture firm based in Menlo Park, Calif., also said it led a $15 million funding round for EzRez Software, which makes online travel-reservation software.

Investment banks that bundle and sell home mortgages often commissioned reports showing growing risks in subprime loans to less creditworthy borrowers but did not pass on much of the information to credit rating agencies or investors, according to some of those who prepared the reports.

The private equity firm Terra Firma Capital Partners, run by the British financier Guy Hands, said Wednesday it had succeeded in its 2.4 billion pound ($4.9 billion) takeover of the music company EMI Group, garnering the 90 percent of shares needed to let it force out minority shareholders.

The government's investigation of improperly dated stock options, which seemed quiet lately, is back in the headlines. The first chief executive caught up in the inquiry was sentenced Wednesday to five years of probation.

Just in case Rupert Murdoch is wondering who watches CNBC - the business network that he plans to compete with this fall when he introduces a competitor, the Fox Business Network - a series of commercials starting Thursday will tell him.

Hollinger, the Canadian company that Conrad M. Black used to control his newspaper empire, filed for bankruptcy Wednesday and said it would explore options for the Sun-Times Media Group while facing payments on debt and shareholder suits.
A look at some of the shows that are drawing audiences to London theaters.
Exchange-rate-rich Europeans are not the only foreign buyers gobbling up property in the United States, according to a first-of-its kind study by the National Association of Realtors.

For one Amsterdam mayor, the Netherlands’ famous tolerance has gone too far. Morrocan-born Ahmed Marcouch is taking the tough cop approach in a rough Amsterdam neighborhood, pushing his fellow immigrants to integrate. But some consider him a traitor.
The Lake Tahoe area is experiencing a rise in bear home invasions.
The entire span of a bridge in Minneapolis collapsed Wednesday, sending at least 50 cars and passengers into the Mississippi River.

An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River Wednesday night, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water and killing at least seven people.
The Chatpad for Microsoft’s Xbox attaches to the underside of the 360’s controller without interfering with the controller’s comfortable feel in the hands.
The Kinetik line of computer bags follows Logitech’s practice of jumping into a crowded field but adding some feature to set it apart from rivals.
If you’re on a budget and not afraid of working without telephone support, consider open-source software.
The iTunes program has an option to back up the library to CD or DVD. How can I back it up to a U.S.B. flash drive?
I have a boxful of 5.25-inch floppy disks that I used during college in the 1980s, and I’d like to extract the information from them. Where can I find a drive that supports these disks?
Hewlett-Packard has just released a “retro” version of its HP-35 hand-held scientific calculator to mark its 35th anniversary.
The WowWee Alive Elvis, an animatronic Elvis bust, has infrared eyes and lips that sync to music.
GrimGrimoire begins as Lilet arrives at the Magic Academy to be schooled in the art of Grimoires, which are books that allow magicians to call forth and control various fantastical creatures.
David Pogue explores the ins and outs of making free phone calls through the Internet.
When everyone in the household wants access to all the content at any time from any room, the data-engulfed consumer needs to go one step further, to network-attached storage.
The new TiVo HD recorder offers 20 hours of HD storage (or 180 hours of standard TV), an easy-to-use interface and the ability to record two channels at once.
Stocks staged their second consecutive late-afternoon rally today, recovering even more losses from the sharp sell-off last week.
The realization that scores of survivors were not going to be pulled from the water was setting in this afternoon.
If President Bush signs the bill into law members of Congress will be subject to a number of new restrictions, which have grown out of a series of scandals.
Moscow attempted to reinforce its longstanding — and disputed — claim to nearly half the Arctic Ocean.
Survivors from a school bus carrying 50 children recount struggle to escape trapped vehicle.
The defense secretary said today that the Bush administration might have misjudged the difficulty of achieving reconciliation among Iraq’s factions.
The judge said in a written order that prosecutors needed only show that the victim was chosen because of his sexual orientation to pursue charges.
The London police misinformed the British public about the identity of an innocent man shot dead by the police the day after an attempted terror in 2005, an investigation concluded today.
Senators today questioned J. Scott Jennings, a young White House aide,  about the firings of nine United States attorneys.
The Yankees hit five more home runs last night in a victory against the Chicago White Sox, but none were by Alex Rodriguez, who remained stalled at 499 for his career.
Starter Oliver Pérez prevented Manager Willie Randolph from turning to his bullpen earlier than he preferred, and the Mets capitalized on two three-run homers to hang on for a victory.
The death of an American priest who openly criticized the Kenyan government was homicide, not suicide as an earlier investigation had found, a Kenyan court ruled on Wednesday.
Barry Bonds has not had to deal with the kind of hate mail and death threats that followed Hank Aaron on the way to the home run record. But he is starting to get a taste of it.
The City of Chicago is not legally responsible for the 13 deaths and dozens of injuries that occurred when a porch collapsed in 2003, the Illinois Appellate Court ruled.
A Senate committee approved legislation that would allow federal regulation of cigarettes for the first time.
The five major private hospitals in and around New Orleans are going to lose more than $400 million by the end of 2009, executives told a Congressional committee.
The computer system used by the Homeland Security Department to monitor foreigners entering the United States is extremely vulnerable to manipulation by unauthorized users, a report concluded.
With a launching countdown looming, NASA scrambled to fix a cabin leak aboard the space shuttle Endeavour.
The chief executive of the Smithsonian Institution’s business unit has left the museum complex earlier than expected after a review of his spending.
Lawyers for one of Jose Padilla’s co-defendants rested their case, a day after Mr. Padilla’s lawyers said they would not put on a case.
The communications company said that it has been adding customers for its bundled packages of Internet, phone and TV services.
Video game-maker Electronic Arts managed to beat expectations despite an ongoing reorganization and continued losses.
Customs agents raided more than 30 businesses and homes Wednesday, looking for devices that allow pirated video games to play on Wiis, PlayStation 2s and Xboxes.

A front-page obituary on July 25 about Albert Ellis, a psychologist who pioneered a straightforward approach to psychotherapy, misstated the period during which he lived with a companion, Janet L. Wolfe, a former executive director of the Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan. It was 1965 to 2002, not 1966 to 2003. A picture caption with the continuation of the obituary referred incorrectly to the St. John’s University students he was shown lecturing to in a nursing home last December. They were graduate students in school counseling, not psychology.

A front-page obituary on July 25 about Albert Ellis, a psychologist who pioneered a straightforward approach to psychotherapy, misstated the period during which he lived with a companion, Janet L. Wolfe, a former executive director of the Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan. It was 1965 to 2002, not 1966 to 2003. A picture caption with the continuation of the obituary referred incorrectly to the St. John’s University students he was shown lecturing to in a nursing home last December. They were graduate students in school counseling, not psychology.

An article last Thursday about a government report that found many more cases of West Nile virus than at the same time a year ago misstated the extent of the virus’s spread since it first appeared in the United States in 1999. It has spread to every state but Alaska and Hawaii, not to every state.

Juan Pablo Montoya will race in his final Busch Series event next week at Watkins Glen, then the team will stop competing. Chip Ganassi Racing officials said the No. 42 Busch program was formed only to help Montoya adjust to Nascar after six seasons in Formula One. He drove the car to a victory in March on the road course in Mexico City, and will try for another one in Watkins Glen, N.Y., next Saturday. After that, Ganassi will stop operating the team because the rest of the schedule is not a good fit with Montoya’s Nextel Cup season.

Michael Phelps won two titles yesterday at the national swimming championships and barely missed a world record in the 200-meter backstroke.Phelps, who scheduled an ambitious 10-event program at the Indiana University Natatorium, failed to qualify for the final of the 200 breaststroke. But he won the 200 backstroke in 1 minute 54.65 seconds, just .33 seconds off the world record of 1:54.32 set by Ryan Lochte at the world championships in March. He later helped Michigan win the 4x100-freestyle relay.Dana Torres, a 40-year-old mother trying to qualify for her fifth Olympics, won the 100 women’s freestyle in 54.45 seconds, beating Amanda Weir. David Walters won the men’s 100 freestyle in 48.96 seconds.
pro basketball.

Craig Leipold, the owner of the N.H.L.’s Predators, said he has finally sold the franchise, this time to a group of local businessmen and one California venture capitalist who want to keep the team in Nashville. Leipold said yesterday he has signed a letter of intent to sell his team to the local group. The eight partners put down $10 million as a deposit toward the purchase price of $193 million. The only partner from outside the Nashville area is William Del Biaggio III, who will have to sell his minority share in the San Jose Sharks when this deal closes. Leipold said he is excited to pass ownership to a group he knows is committed to Nashville.The bid was less than the $220 million offered by the Canadian billionaire Jim Balsillie when Leipold announced May 24 that he had signed a letter of intent to sell his team. But Leipold said Balsillie ruined that deal by trying to move the Predators to Canada before money changed hands.

A celebration thrown by the ruler of Dubai for the Iraqi team after its Asian Cup victory was marred when Iraq’s Saddam Hussein-era national anthem was played, angering many players and prompting some to walk away. Confetti rained as the players arrived late Tuesday at the Dubai airport, where thousands of fans gathered to welcome the team and celebrate its victory. Emirates officials apologized for what was apparently a mistake, saying a technician responsible for the music was unaware there was a new anthem.

Tony Parker sprained his left ankle this week while working out with the French national team in preparation for the European championships next month, the San Antonio Spurs said yesterday. The team said Parker, who won the Most Valuable Player award in June when he led the Spurs to the N.B.A. championship over Cleveland, would return to San Antonio tomorrow. Parker, 25, will miss the Basketball Without Borders Europe event in his hometown of Paris as a result of the injury.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer vetoed legislation late Wednesday night that would have required social service agencies to train welfare recipients for better-paying jobs and train women for work in construction, computer sciences and other jobs traditionally held by men.

The Russian research ship Akademik Fyodorov, escorted by a nuclear icebreaker, has reached the North Pole on a mission to send two small piloted submarines to plant a Russian flag on the seabed of the Arctic Ocean, directly under the pole, the Interfax news agency reported. The Mir submarines will dive 15,400 feet, possibly tomorrow, and a member of Parliament will accompany the crew to the bottom. The mission is intended to support Russia’s claim that the Artic Ocean, including the North Pole, lies within Moscow’s exclusive economic zone. Russia maintains that a geological feature called the Lomonosov Ridge, directly under the pole, forms part of the Siberian continental shelf and thus belong to Russia. At issue are scientific projections that the ice cap will recede because of global warming, opening the Artic Ocean to offshore oil drilling. Canada and Denmark also claim the Lomonosov Ridge.

Sixty-nine coal miners trapped underground for more than three days emerged blindfolded, to protect their eyes against the light, and soaked to the skin, but safe. They became trapped Sunday morning when a flash flood from heavy rain surged through an old shaft at their mine in Henan Province. More than 500 colleagues worked around the clock to pump out water and remove mud and rocks blocking the passage between the trapped men and the pit entrance. A ventilation pipe and telephone line survived the accident, and rescuers sent down milk via a hose. China’s coal mining industry is the deadliest in the world, and this was “the most successful rescue effort in major mining accidents in our country in recent years,” the Henan governor, Li Chengyu, told the crowd at the scene through a loudspeaker, “one most worthy of celebration.”.

Sydney, Australia’s largest city, has installed dozens of loudspeakers to tell residents what to do in a terrorist attack, said the state police minister for New South Wales, David Campbell. He said that 40 speakers should be operational in time for next month’s meeting of 21 world leaders of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation. “If there were a terrorist event and there were people in the streets, this is a way of giving them information,” he said.

Israeli forces killed two armed Palestinians and wounded several others during an army incursion into northern Gaza. The dead men belonged to the military wings of Hamas and the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, according to statements from the groups. An army spokeswoman said a rocket-propelled grenade had been fired at soldiers but caused no casualties. Palestinian witnesses said that army bulldozers had razed large areas of farmland in the operation.

More Japanese want Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to resign than support his decision not to quit after his governing Liberal Democratic Party’s drubbing in Sunday’s election in the upper house of Parliament, according to polls conducted Monday and Tuesday by three major news organizations. In polls in the nation’s two largest newspapers, Yomiuri and Asahi, 45 percent and 47 percent, respectively, said Mr. Abe should step down; 44 percent and 40 percent said he should remain. In a poll by Kyodo, the largest news service, 50 percent said Mr. Abe should resign, while 44 percent backed him. Yomiuri said its poll was a telephone survey of 1,725 eligible voters. Asahi’s, also a telephone survey, included 1,094 voters. Kyodo did not state its sample size.

Israel began dismantling a low concrete barrier that ran for 25 miles along roads south of Hebron. Israel had claimed that the barrier, though just 32 inches high, was intended to provide additional security for Jewish settlers, but in February 2006 the High Court accepted the contention of the Association for Civil Rights in Israel that the wall violated the rights of Palestinian residents in 21 rural communities and prevented farmers from crossing the roads with their herds of livestock. The court gave Israel six months to remove the barrier. When it failed to do so, the civil rights group sought to have the state held in contempt of court. Last week, the court ordered the wall’s destruction within two weeks.

Bruce Trevorrow, an Aborigine removed from his family as a 13-month-old baby in 1957 and handed over to a white family, was awarded $450,000 in Australia’s first successful “Stolen Generation” court claim. The term refers to the legal and forcible removal of indigenous children from their families by government agencies and church missions in order to assimilate them. Mr. Trevorrow argued in South Australian Supreme Court that the state’s action had brought him a life marked by loss of identity, depression, alcoholism and erratic employment. His two brothers and two sisters stayed with their parents and led successful lives, he said.

The authorities in Turks and Caicos, a British territory in the West Indies, were ill equipped to handle the capsizing of a boat in May in which 61 Haitian migrants died, British maritime investigators said in a report. But they said it could not be determined if the territory’s marine police had caused the boat to capsize. Several survivors had accused a patrol boat of ramming their boat. The investigators concluded that the Haitian sloop, overloaded with at least 150 migrants, was nearing the territory’s coast when the patrol intercepted it and tried to tow it to shore. “It would appear that the sloop capsized while under tow, when the number of passengers on deck reached a critical number and stability was lost,” their report said. “However, the exact trigger for the capsize remains unknown.” It added that neither vessel showed signs of collision damage.
Two people in La Barge, Wyo., are buying the Moondance Diner, a Manhattan mainstay for about 75 years, to put it in their town.
Deutsche Bank said its second-quarter profit surged 31 percent as its investment banking business proved to be solid amid global market jitters over the subprime mortgage crisis in the United States.
The troubled Italian airline Alitalia named a new chairman and postponed a decision on a long-awaited business plan.
Japanese land prices rose 8.6 percent last year, more than nine times faster than in 2005, when a 16-year property slump ended as the country’s economy rebounded.

Arcelor Mittal, the world’s biggest steel maker, reported a 50 percent increase in second-quarter profit, more than analysts had estimated, after raising prices in Europe and the Americas and accelerating cost savings.
South Korea’s exports grew at the fastest rate in six months in July, as global demand was strong enough to counter the effects of a stronger won.
In the book business, few things are faster than the Espresso Book Machine, the product of a high-tech publishing venture that has nothing to do with caffeine.
An Interstate highway bridge in downtown Minneapolis loaded with rush-hour traffic dropped more than 60 feet into the Mississippi River, sending at least 50 vehicles and passengers into the water.

Federal prosecutors presenting the government’s case against six men accused of plotting an attack on Fort Dix have filed legal papers indicating that matters related to classified information are expected to arise during the trial. Prosecutors have asked to meet with the judge in private to discuss the matter, The Courier Post reported yesterday. Legal papers filed in Federal District Court do not disclose details, but say a federal law allowing for redaction of sensitive portions of documents should apply. The men, who are accused of planning to attack soldiers at the military base, have pleaded not guilty; the attack was never carried out and the men were arrested in May.
Hideki Matsui, who had two home runs Tuesday night in a 16-3 victory, led the majors in home runs in July and raised his batting average to .293 from .270.

A Manhattan lawyer pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to obtaining clients in personal injury cases from a go-between and lying to the state Office of Court Administration to hide the arrangement, prosecutors said. The lawyer, David Sheeger, 50, was charged with offering a false instrument for filing by paying the go-between to bribe hospital workers to obtain information about patients who had been treated for accidents, typically car accidents, said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney. The go-between, who was paid $500 per case, would contact the patients on behalf of Mr. Sheeger’s law firm, Mr. Morgenthau said. It is illegal in New York for lawyers to accept referrals from nonlawyers. Mr. Morgenthau said that Mr. Sheeger had obtained 67 cases using a go-between from April to November 2002. After his plea, Mr. Sheeger was disbarred, placed on probation and ordered to forfeit $110,000 obtained through the scheme, prosecutors said.

EnCap Golf Holdings, a developer that has faltered in its bid to transform garbage dumps in the Meadowlands into homes and an entertainment district, has been fined $1.054 million for allowing methane gas to escape from one of its construction sites, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday. According to agency documents, the gas was released from the Kingsland Landfill in Lyndhurst, where one of EnCap’s construction sites is located. The leaks were detected from October of last year through July 24. Methane gas is typically funneled through underground pipes underneath the landfill. EnCap, which is owned by Cherokee Investment Partners in North Carolina, was also fined for not obtaining permits to operate at the landfill. The company plans to appeal the fine, a spokesman said.
The Actors’ Playhouse, a 62-year-old Off Broadway theater, is closing.

City officials announced plans yesterday for a $40 million restoration of Dreier-Offerman Park in Bensonhurst. The 77-acre park, which overlooks Gravesend Bay, was acquired through a series of donations and purchases, starting with a gift of land from the Dreier-Offerman Home for Unwed Mothers in 1933. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said the development project called for the construction of three baseball fields, six soccer fields, kayak launches, nature trails, a playground and a recreation center. The work, scheduled for completion in 2011, is part of an effort to ensure that every New Yorker lives within a 10-minute walk of a park or open space, the mayor said.

A 22-year-old man was in custody in Massachusetts late yesterday in connection with robberies at two Manhattan hotels, the police said. Detective Kevin Czartoryski, a New York police spokesman, said the man, Ermal Qoshja of Revere, Mass., was being held by Massachusetts State Police, who had acted on information from detectives in New York. Mr. Qoshja had not been charged yesterday evening, he said. The police said Mr. Qoshja was located after he used a cellphone taken in one of the hotel robberies. In the first, on April 13, a couple and their 9-year-old daughter were held at gunpoint and robbed in their room at the Millenium Hilton downtown. In the second, on May 31, a woman was struck in the face with a pistol and robbed in her room at the Roosevelt, and another man was struck when he tried to prevent the assailant from fleeing.

The owners of a Jackson Heights trade school were charged yesterday with giving students the answers to tests for state asbestos-removal certificates and with allowing illegal immigrants to use false information to apply for the certificates, prosecutors said yesterday. The owners, Juan Herrera, 61, and Julia Herrera, 49, both of Clifton, N.J., were charged in Criminal Court on Tuesday night with falsifying business records and tampering with government records, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said detectives who went undercover as students at the Herreras’ school, Senagryph Training Facilities, were told to use fake Social Security numbers on certificate applications and given answers to questions on the certifying exam. Mr. Brown said the lapses allowed illegal immigrants to gain access to high-security work sites, including bridges, tunnels and airports.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer authorized a city program yesterday that will offer impoverished families tax credits to help offset child care costs. Under the program, part of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s broad effort to reduce the city’s high poverty rates, families earning $30,000 or less who use accredited child care services for children up to age 4 would be eligible for credits worth up to $1,700 per household, city officials said. The program is to cost the city $42 million a year and serve up to 49,000 families.
If the House version of an energy bill truly hopes to tackle the problems of global warming and energy independence, a few vital issues need to be addressed.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,645 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
Tweaking the tax bills of the richest 1 percent of Americans, an idea Charles Schumer has spoken of approvingly, simply won’t be enough.
The department still has no system to detect misconduct by lenders and protect student borrowers, a report says.
The Senate hold has been used to tie the chamber in knots by allowing senators to anonymously block legislation.
One month after the government tried to allay the effects of hyperinflation, Zimbabwe’s economy is at a halt.
An internal evaluation of the International Finance Corporation, the World Bank Group’s private-sector arm, found that projects in Africa had performed below average.
In Iraq, where battle lines are murky, the news emerging from the U.S. counterinsurgency campaign can seem particularly contradictory.
Jorge Sosa, who stabilized the back of the Mets’ rotation by winning six of his first seven starts, has been shifted to the bullpen as the team readies for the eventual return of Pedro Martínez.
An association of companies, including Google and Microsoft, allege that overstated copyright warnings may intimidate consumers from making legal use of copyrighted material.
All of us who care about journalism will be watching for any sign that news coverage at The Wall Street Journal is being slanted to curry political or economic favor.
August 1, 2007.

After charges of theft and money-laundering against officials with two major New York City heating oil delivery companies, federal prosecutors announced yesterday that deliveries by their trucks would be halted.
The bodies of four Afghan judges, kidnapped 10 days ago, were found Wednesday in the province where 21 South Korean hostages are being held.
Despite verbal provocations from committee members, former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld stuck to prepared answers regarding the death of Cpl. Pat Tillman.
Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales said he had been truthful in denying that there had been disagreements about a wiretapping program.
Five people were named to a committee intended to protect the editorial independence of the Wall Street Journal when it becomes part of News Corporation.
The maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars is recalling the toys because of lead paint.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 —District Attorney P. David Soares of Albany County is conducting a preliminary review to determine whether his office should investigate Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his staff, Mr. Soares said on Wednesday.
Iraq’s largest Sunni political faction resigned from the cabinet as a wave of bombings in Baghdad killed at least 76 people.
The cultural rise of the Persian Gulf is analogous to that of the American South in recent decades, as country singers and Southern ways have become part of pop culture.
Rudolph W. Giuliani is facing increased scrutiny over his friendship with Roger Ailes, the head of Fox News.
Major League Baseball has struck a revenue-sharing deal with StubHub to allow fans to resell or buy tickets online.

One man was killed and another wounded after being shot in Queens late Tuesday by a contractor who told investigators that the men had demanded $20,000 from him and threatened to harm his wife, law enforcement officials said.
Dodgers reliever Joe Beimel, who as a young baseball fan revered Barry Bonds, does not wither when he sees Bonds standing 60 feet 6 inches away from him.
Johnny Damon, a left-handed hitter who usually serves as the designated hitter and the leadoff batter, is 5 for 8 in his past two games, driving in three runs and scoring six.
The subway is fundamental to the experience of regular New Yorkers, and that is a truth city politicians rarely forget.
Flawed safety procedures and lax “organizational culture” led to the deaths of two workers in April, reports found.
Stopping large-scale traffickers who can source raw materials anywhere around the globe will make interdiction much more difficult for law enforcement.
Tom Glavine compared the atmosphere Tuesday to a playoff game, and he pitched as if the season was on the line, lasting into the seventh inning.
American companies lost their leadership of the domestic car market in July, a dismal month for sales.
The details suggest that mechanical failure or pilot error contributed to the accident last month where a jetliner skidded off a runway and exploded as it slammed into a building.
Buddy Bell announced the decision before Wednesday’s game against the Minnesota Twins and said that he would remain in that role for the rest of the season.
The Democratic Party will announce a state-by-state effort to identify potential problems in how elections are administered before the 2008 presidential election.
The Children’s Health Insurance Program would be  financed with increases in tobacco taxes and cuts in subsidies to private Medicare insurance plans.
Despite dire forecasts when the New Zealand government ended agricultural subsidies in the 1980s, the farming business there is now thriving.
CA Inc., which makes management software, said first-quarter profits were up sharply.
Sudan’s foreign minister said that the government supported the deployment of a United Nations peacekeeping force for Darfur.
While JaMarcus Russell remains home in Alabama without a contract, Daunte Culpepper practiced with the Oakland Raiders for the first time Wednesday after signing his one-year deal.
The colorful former mayor of Tijuana, Mexico, stands an even chance of being elected governor of the state of Baja California, despite allegations against him.
Ashraf al-Hazouz on Tuesday recounted his years of imprisonment and torture in Libya and aired his grievances.
The technology-services company Electronic Data Systems saw a rise in second-quarter profits but offered a tepid outlook for the third quarter.
If Saudi officials sit down with Israel, it will be the first time that both countries have attended public talks about Israeli-Palestinian peace since 1991.
The Los Angeles Sparks, a franchise that has been among the W.N.B.A.’s elite for most of the league’s 10-year history, is in danger of finishing the regular season with a losing record.

As the rush of fall road-running races nears, one challenge is to reach the starting line without first joining the large majority of runners -- as many as 80 percent -- who suffer a leg injury each year. A review of injury studies in the current issue of The British Journal of Sports Medicine provides some explanation for what causes so many injuries, and it might not be everything you’d expect. Those most likely to be injured, the review found, include people who’ve been injured before; are too obsessive (running for a year or more without a break); or are men taller than 5-foot-6. [what about tall women??] Runners with a relatively high body mass appear to somehow avoid foot injury[is she conflating leg injuries and foot injuries? does the review distinguish?] -- perhaps, the authors speculated, because Clydesdales, in general, run less. Surprisingly, some factors didn’t contribute to injury risk, including having legs of different length, using alcohol, or running after dark [why would running after dark make any difference??]. The one element that was foundto prevent running injuries most consistently was increasing mileage gradually, to a maximum of about 40 miles per week.

Anyone who watched the British Open this month had to notice Sergio Garcia’s new “belly putter”—an extra-long putter that stays anchored in the belly during the stroke. It helps keep the hands from shaking. In other words, it’s a putter for total wusses. Just ask Garcia’s colleague Ernie Els, who once said: “Nerves and the skill of putting are part of the game. Take a tablet if you can’t handle it.”.

Trying to get your teenager into the gym? You may be in luck. As The Times reports today, some smaller, independent gyms have started wooing teenagers instead of shooing them. In the last year, these centers have fitted themselves with foosball tables, juice bars, classes retrofitted for teens, and - of course - internet access. The goal: A places to work out and hang out.

7 P.M. (Cinemax) TWO HANDS In 1964, at the age of 36 and at the height of his career, the pianist Leon Fleisher, above, inexplicably lost the use of two fingers on his right hand. He didn’t regain it for some 30 years. This documentary from Nathaniel Kahn (“My Architect”) tells the story of Mr. Fleisher’s struggle, and of his rebirth as a two-handed performer. “There was a lot of despair and misery and unhappiness, but there were commensurate ecstasies,” he says in the film, adding that you can’t really expect to have one without the other. “Two Hands” is the second film in Cinemax’s presentation of this year’s Oscar-nominated short documentaries.

A news analysis article on Saturday about a civilian nuclear energy accord between the United States and India misstated the route of a proposed natural gas pipeline that India is negotiating with Iran, which has been criticized by the United States. The pipeline would run from Iran through Pakistan to India -- not from Iran through Pakistan and back to Iran.

SEIDEL--Esther. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Samuel Field YM & YWHA mourn the loss of of our extraordinary and beloved agency founder, Esther Seidel. A woman of keen intellect, passionate civic commitment and great vision, Esther was instrumental in the creation of our agency and served as the founding President. Since the time of the agency's inception in 1954, Esther consistently provided outstanding, visionary leadership as a twotime President, Chair of the Board of Trustees, Chair of the Executive Committee and then, as a Lifetime Trustee. She was a profoundly committed leader who was devoted to the agency's mission of improving the quality of individual, family and Jewish communal life with particular compassion and respect for our most vulnerable community members. Her courage, wisdom and deep love for her family, community and agency serve as an inspiration for all those who knew her. We will deeply miss her loving, enthusiastic and articulate presence, her strength and her generous spirit. Her devoted husband, Leo, and her beloved son, Dr. James Seidel, predeceased Esther. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her son Laurence, daughter - in - law Bobbie, granddaughters Amy and Debby, great-granddaughter, Jessica and to her sister, Rose Silverstein and niece Joanne Zuckerbrod. Richard Tanenbaum, President Steven Goodman, Executive Vice-President

Bolidt, a Dutch company known for its seamless polyurethane floors -- like the one in the Groninger Museum in the Netherlands, above -- is now selling the flooring for use in residential interiors. ''It's flexible, warm to the touch, and resists scratching much better than epoxy resin floors,'' said Walt Honer, the president of Fusion Floors, the company's American representative. The floors start at $15 a square foot and can be poured in ''any conceivable color,'' said Jacco van Overbeek, Bolidt's export manager, or in patterns like colored swirls or checkerboards. Or ''we can make prints of any type of picture,'' he added, ''a face, grass or children playing,'' and pour the floor on top. Information: (239)560-2588 or fusionfloors.com. ELAINE LOUIE

The computer system used by the Homeland Security Department to monitor foreigners entering the United States is extremely vulnerable to manipulation by unauthorized users, compromising the ability to intercept terrorists, a report by the Government Accountability Office found. It warns that someone could easily erase, modify, copy or simply gain access to records of millions of travelers. The computer system, which is set up at 285 air, sea and land ports, has cost $1.7 billion since 2002.

An article in Business Day on July 25 about AT&T's quarterly earnings report, which included a statement from an analyst, Eugene Munster, comparing the subscriber rate for the iPhone to iPod sales, misstated the period of iPod sales he was using for his comparison. It was the fourth quarter of 2004, not the first quarter after the iPod's introduction. (The iPod was introduced in July 2001.)

MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

BURNS--Dr. John J., the former Vice President of Research and Development at Hoffmann-La Roche, died on Sunday, July 29, 2007 in Bridgeport, CT. Born in Flushing, NY on October 8, 1920, he was a graduate of Queens College with a BS degree in 1942 and from Columbia University in 1950 with a Ph.D. degree. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army where he was assigned to a research group developing new anti-malaria drugs. During the fifties, while doing research at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, MD, Dr. Burns made an important observation, which explains why scurvy developed in humans on a Vitamin C free diet. He showed humans lack an enzyme in their liver required for making the vitamin, while almost all other animal species have this enzyme and thus do not develop scurvy on a Vitamin C deficient diet. Extensive pharmacological research conducted during his career on the metabolic fate and the mechanism of action of drugs gave a basis for discovering new drugs and improving their therapeutic use. In 1960, Dr. Burns moved to the Wellcome Research Laboratories, Tuckahoe, NY where he was Director of Research. From 1968 to 1984, he was Vice President of Research & Development at Hoffmann-La Roche. After Dr. Burns retired from Roche, he served as Adjunct Professor of Pharmacology at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University. He also was a scientific advisor to a number of new biotech companies. Dr. Burns was a member of the National Academy of Sciences, the Institute of Medicine, served as President of the American Society for Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics and as President of International Union of Pharmacology. In 1974, Dr. Burns was a member of the Herbal Pharmacology Delegation to the Peoples Republic of China and in 1973 was a member of the Panel on Chemistry & Health of President Nixon's Scientific Advisory Committee. Dr. Burns was a member of the Steering Committee of the National Academy of Sciences/Institute of Medicine that developed the National Strategy for AIDS. In 1987, he was awarded Honorary Membership in the Japanese Pharmacology Society. In 1987, he received an Honorary Doctor of Science degree from Queens College on the occasion of the Colleges 50th anniversary celebration. Dr. Burns was a resident of Fairfield and Westport since 1973. He had a strong interest in equestrian activities having served as President of the Fairfield County Hunt Club, as President of the Fairfield Bridle Trail Association and as Director of the Equus Foundation, Westport. Dr. Burns was predeceased by his sister, Mary B. Kalnins and his brother, Edward Burns. Friends are invited to attend a Memorial Service on Tuesday, August 7, 2007 at 11:00 a.m. at St. Luke's Church, 49 North Turkey Hill Road, Westport, CT. Interment is private. Donations in his memory to The Equus Foundation, Inc. 168 Long Lots Road, Westport, CT 06880. Shaughnessey-Banks Funeral Home, 50 Reef Road, Fairfield is entrusted with the services. To send an online condolence, www.shaughnesseyfuneralhome.com

RIFKIN--Beatrice (Bibi) Weiss, passed away on July 31, 2007 in her 88th year. Dearly loved by her late husband, Harold Rifkin M.D.; her children, Janet of Amherst, MA, Matthew of Old Field, NY and Phyllis of Rochester, NY; their spouses, David, Susan and Steve, and her grandsons, Adam, Alex (Jennifer), Jason (Allison), Nicholas, Jacob and Ethan. She was predeceased by her sisters, Helen Sunshine and Miriam Krosney. Bibi was born in Paterson, New Jersey on June 21, 1920. She lived her life in New York City, which she considered to be ''the best city in the world.'' She was the kind of woman who loved to laugh and made people around her feel good. She was bright, generous and thoughtful. She was a whiz at Scrabble, the New York Times crossword puzzles and enjoyed her daily Dewars before dinner until her last days. She adored her family and appreciated the support of her friends and caretakers. Above all, she appreciated all that life had given to her and considered herself to be a ''very lucky lady.'' Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Diabetes Association Rifkin Memorial Fund would be greatly appreciated.
LEIBOWITT--S. David. You left us too soon. Miss your sage advice. Love you always, Hazel and family

deNAPOLI--Robert A., M.D. The Department of Neurology notes with deep sadness the death of Dr. Robert deNapoli, longtime colleague and friend. MATTHEWS--Larry, 86, of Aventura, FL, died Monday of natural causes. He was a pioneer in the beauty business and an industry leader. Along with his late wife Norma, he opened the first 24 hour beauty salons, whose clientel included numerous showgirls and celebrities of the era. Both the famous and infamous passed through his salons' doors. Even in retirement, he continued to surround himself with what he loved best -people. He is survived by his daughter B. Ryan, grandchildren Sunshine, Jeremy, and Norma, and sons-in-law Patrick Ryan and Anthony Straiges. Memorial services Friday 10:30am at Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 20955 Biscayne Boulevard, Aventura, FL.

SALETAN--Lloyd. Lloyd Saletan died peacefully on July 29 after a brief illness. He was 83. A member of the Greatest Generation and a consummate New Yorker, Lloyd spent most of his life in Greenwich Village. He graduated from the Little Red School House and the High School of Music and Art. After serving as a bombardier in World War II, attaining the rank of Second Lieutenant, he graduated from Colgate University (B.A. magna cum laude, 1948) and studied at the London School of Economics (M.Sc., 1952). On retirement from a successful career in finance, Lloyd devoted himself to travel and the arts. He was a tireless theatre-, concert-, and museum-goer, with a special fondness for the opera. He combined profound appreciation with keen critical insight, which he readily shared with others. Lloyd was a generous and enthusiastic guide and host, endearing himself to his neighbors and welcoming visitorsfrom the United States and abroad. He had a unique gift for bringing people together, and was cherished by a wide circle of friends and members of his extended family. Lloyd leaves behind his devoted friend Eddie; many cousins, especially Rhoda Goldberger and Stephen, Eugene, and Anthony Saletan; and a host of other friends.
FEUERSTEIN--Sara, nee Gordon, 82, on July 29. Beloved wife of the late Joseph, loving mother of Kenneth, dear sister, aunt, cousin, and friend. She will be greatly missed. Services private.

Two boys were the sole survivors of an attack at a house in a peaceful middle-class suburb northwest of Atlanta that killed a mother and her two teenage daughters, investigators said. The boys, one of whom was at the house for a sleepover, were unconscious and gravely injured when the authorities found the triple homicide around 8 a.m. Investigators said it was unclear when or how the family and their guest were attacked. The police went to the house, in Powder Springs, after the visitor's mother could not reach anyone in the house on the phone.

It is ''In the Red Zone,'' not ''Inside the Red Zone.''

Just in time for corn season there's a new tool for taking kernels off a cob of cooked corn. The Oxo corn stripper ($12), created by Mark Naden, an industrial designer with TODA (the Office of Design and Architecture) in New York, is good news for people who are tired of getting corn stuck between their teeth. The tool removes the corn in strips as it is dragged down the cob, and holds the corn in an integrated collection basket. (Previous attempts to design such a device, Mr. Naden said, resulted in products that created a mess: ''Corn just went everywhere.'') There's also a comfortable grip for safety and control. At Sur La Table, 75 Spring Street (Crosby Street), (212) 966-3375; or (800) 545-4411 to order. TIM McKEOUGH

Bounce, a new baby linen pattern from Nurseryworks, offers an alternative for those who want something more sophisticated for their children than Winnie the Pooh sheets. ''We wanted the sheets to have a clean, modern, graphic look that a parent could embrace as much as a child might,'' said Kyra Hartnett of the Manhattan design firm twenty2, who created the 100-percent cotton sheets with her husband, Robertson. Bounce comes in two color combinations: Dreamsicle, below, and Blueberry Brownie. A five-piece set (two fitted sheets, a crib skirt, a bumper and a quilt) is $400; the fitted sheet can be purchased separately for $30. They will be available next month, but can be preordered from Yoya, 636 Hudson Street (Horatio Street), (646) 336-6844. Information: (888) 508-9540. ELAINE LOUIE

A picture on Friday with the Antiques column was published in error. The glass shown in the photograph was an Austrian marriage goblet from 1586, not an Austrian glass beaker with a view of Trieste from about 1825.

IT is impossible to anticipate what tricks bicycles thieves have up their sleeves these days. Even a locksmith knows that the best a cyclist can do is to buy a strong lock and learn how to use it properly. What constitutes a good lock has changed since September 2004, when it became common knowledge that a cheap pen could open many high-end locks. Redesigned lock cores have almost completely put an end to that. Additional advances in technology include beefier and more sophisticated locks that translate into the strongest units to date. Some have guarantees that provide replacement costs for your bike for as much as $5,000. Still, they're not impenetrable.

Donald Trump has just introduced a furniture collection at Macy's, and he may be suffering from first-timer anxiety. As he stretched out on a bed at the Herald Square store, he appeared to be concerned that the pictures might make his furnishings look fat. ''Can you keep me in the center?'' he said to the photographer. ''I hate those convex lenses. Do you find they're very distorted? I hate wide angles. They're a disaster for me.'' The collection, now at select Macy's stores, will be in independent stores this month. There are two lines: the sleek Central Park and the more traditional Westchester, both inspired by furniture in Mr. Trump's five homes and his business properties -- although his favorites, like a sofa at Mar-a-Lago, his $42 million Palm Beach estate, were impossible to reproduce. ''Mar-a-Lago is always tough,'' said Mr. Trump, whose hair these days is the color of a wheat field in an old MGM movie, which is to say, a gold that is better than real life. ''The furniture is extraordinarily opulent and large, like the house.''

An article in the special Education Life section on Sunday about residential colleges misstated the number of such colleges at Michigan State University. The residential college that is to open in the fall is Michigan State's third, not its first. Also, a chart showing large colleges and universities misstated the location of Grand Valley State University. It is in Michigan, not Missouri.

The voters in Iowa are finding things to like about the top three Democratic candidates, according to the latest ABC News/Washington Post Poll. Half the voters who said they were likely to participate in next year's Democratic caucuses described Hillary Clinton as having the best experience. John Edwards and Barak Obama were each seen as the most likeable candidate by a third of the voters. All three are seen as understanding people's problems.

Wood has had 11 stays on the disabled list and two major surgeries.

Starting a couple of years ago, many privacy-loving hedge funds started using "lockups" as a way to sidestep a new rule requiring them to register with regulators. Under lockup provisions, investors' capital cannot be withdrawn for some period, often one to two years. Funds with lockups of two years or longer were exempt from the fund-registration rule.

If you play the activist-investor game, be prepared to get burned. That is the lesson for Oppenheimer Funds, a mutual-fund manager that took the unusual step earlier this year of leading a campaign to take control of Take-Two Interactive, the maker of the wildly popular "Grand Theft Auto" video game series.

We know that Warren E. Buffett is on the prowl for a $40 billion to $60 billion deal. Now that the credit markets have sidelined potential private equity rivals, the Berkshire Hathaway chief may have an even easier go of it, Bloomberg News suggests.

On Sunday the Republican presidential candidates will gather for a live ABC News debate from Des Moines, Iowa. The war in Iraq will surely be one of the issues on the agenda, and a Bloomberg News story today notes subtle changes in the way some candidates are talking about the war.

In the Twin Cities today, a counselor at a day camp for small children may start to lead a circle of youngsters in "London Bridge is Falling Down" - and then stop short. A movie buff in the public library's video room may reach for "The Bridge on the River Kwai" - and then put it back on the shelf. Card players may wonder whether their weekly bridge game really feels right. Conversation in a dental office may stumble over a mention of bridgework, in a surgical supply store over trusses, in a writing workshop over concrete examples, at a poker table over going down to the river.

Warren E. Buffett once said when the tide goes out, you find out who is naked. There is suddenly a lot of skin showing on Wall Street, writes The New York Times' Jenny Anderson.
A late June move by Merrill Lynch to protect its clients from a struggling hedge fund run by Bear Stearns helped hasten the fund's ultimate collapse, Reuters reported Friday.

Union Investment Asset Management, Germany's third-largest mutual fund manager, halted redemptions from a fund holding subprime mortgages after clients withdrew 100 million euros ($137 million) in the last month, Bloomberg News reported.

The first purchase by the Chinese government's new overseas investment fund, a $3 billion stake in the Blackstone Group, has produced an unusual public reaction within China, The New York Times reports. Since Blackstone went public on June 22, the company's shares have fallen steeply, pushing down the value of the Chinese government's investment by more than $425 million in just six weeks.

The Royal Bank of Scotland, one of the banks in a takeover battle for ABN Amro, beat analysts' expectations with an 11 percent rise in profit and lifted its dividend by 25 percent.

It was probably only a matter of time before one of the most written-up deals of the summer -- Rupert Murdoch's $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company -- entered into the rhetoric of presidential hopefuls.

Investors who were licking their lips Thursday on the news that YES Network might be up for sale may be disappointed to learn that only a portion of the Yankees channel is being shopped. The New York Times reported that Goldman Sachs is evaluating whether possible new investors in the YES Network would pay enough to place a value of at least $3 billion on it - about four times what it was worth nearly six years ago when it was formed.

Anglo American put its Tarmac road-building business up for sale on Friday as it met forecasts with a 22 percent rise in first-half earnings and pledged to return a further $4 billion to shareholders. The chief executive, Cynthia Carroll, said the sale of Britain-based Tarmac, which analysts say could fetch at least $6 billion, was the mining group's last major piece of restructuring as it moves to focus on its metals and minerals businesses.

Evergreen Investments, Wachovia's asset management unit, said its chief investment officer was leaving after more than two decades with the firm. The executive, Christopher Conkey, will officially leave the firm, which has $281 billion under management, in a couple of weeks and will be temporarily succeeded by Evergreen's chief executive Dennis Ferro.

For Silicon Valley investors, there's new hot spot on Asian horizon: Vietnam. The San Jose Mercury News reports that a tech gathering in the Valley to discuss Asia's new roaring tiger drew drew an array of participants, from Google representatives to Ho Chi Minh City start-up executives.

Britain's Candover is considering revising the terms of its 1.5 billion euro ($2.1 billion) offer for Stork, the Dutch industrial conglomerate, after it emerged that Marel, an Icelandic company that opposes the deal, had built a blocking stake, The Financial Times reported.
As news that a stake in YES Network may be on the block sparked talk Thursday of a possible sale of the Yankees, another auction of a highly-prized baseball team has been heating up.

Dell's $340 million acquisition of ASAP Software could lead to similar, if smaller deals, by the struggling computer company, analysts told The Deal.com. The company is copying its rivals who are pushing deeper into the services business, which provides higher margins than computers and is in high demand from Dell's corporate buyers.

Tobira Therapeutics, a new company developing a pair of HIV drugs, raised $31 million in a first round of funding led by Domain Associates. Other investors who threw in included Frazier Healthcare Ventures, Montreux Equity Partners, and Canaan Partners.
Walt Disney's deal to buy Club Penguin for up to $700 million is causing tremors among the companies that have developed online digital communities, not least because of the price tag.
Delphi took a big step on its road to recovery Thursday when a bankruptcy court agreed to let Appaloosa Management and other investors inject up to $2.55 billion into the struggling auto-parts maker.
Royal Dutch Shell said Thursday it had agreed to sell three oil refineries in France and stakes in two Norwegian Sea fields worth $2.47 billion (1.8 billion euros).

ABN Amro's chief executive was back in court Thursday as a group of shareholders who lost a bid to halt the $21 billion sale of the company's United States division kept up their fight. This time, they are pushing for an investigation into alleged mismanagement.

Shares of a business service provider, Genpact, soared nearly 20 percent Thursday in their market debut, producing a 289 percent partially realized gain on investment for the company's two private equity backers, General Atlantic, and Oak Hill Capital Partners.
Tedeschi Realty, based in Rockland, Mass., on Thursday sold 25 shopping centers, most in the greater Boston area, to Dividend Capital Total Realty Trust of Denver for $377 million.

The Massachusetts state pension system lost $30 million with this week's collapse of Sowood Capital Management, the first evidence that public money also went down the drain when the $3 billion Boston hedge fund lost more than half its value in July.

The medical device maker Boston Scientific said Thursday that it had decided against selling a minority stake in its endosurgery group to the public, a move that it had explored to raise as much as $1 billion in cash and help pay off debt from a $27 billion acquisition.

Coming off four consecutive top-10 finishes that included his first PGA Tour victory, Hunter Mahan overcame a sloppy double bogey with a torrid stretch of birdies to shoot a three-under-par 67.
Steve Flesch shot a nine-under-par 63 to take a one-shot lead after the first round of the Reno-Tahoe Open.

A chart on Sunday with a front-page article about universities that charge different tuitions for different majors misstated the undergraduate division at Iowa State University that charges more than other programs. It is the College of Engineering, not the business school.

An article on July 18 about a wake for Russel Timoshenko, a New York police officer fatally shot when he and his partner stopped a suspicious vehicle in Brooklyn, misstated his age at the time he immigrated with his family from Belarus. (The error first appeared in articles in some copies on July 13 and 15.) He was 9, not 7.

A chart on Sunday with a front-page article about universities that charge different tuitions for different majors misstated the undergraduate division at Iowa State University that charges more than other programs. It is the College of Engineering, not the business school.
France Telecom reported first-half net profit was up 41 percent, with the group showing strength in its domestic business while pursuing rapid growth in emerging markets.
Assicurazioni Generali, Italy’s largest insurer, reported first-half profit that beat analysts’ estimates and agreed to sell its Nuova Tirrena unit for 1.25 billion euros ($1.71 billion).
The Lenovo Group, the personal computer maker, reported a twelvefold increase in quarterly profit, beating market expectations.
South Korea halted imports of beef from the United States after a shipment from Cargill was found to contain a bone part banned as a precaution against mad cow disease.

Belarus said it would pay $460 million it owes Russia for natural gas supplies within days, signaling a possible end to another conflict that has threatened gas deliveries to Europe. Belarus accepted gas rate increases that went into effect in January and it has paid 55 percent of the bill. A Russian threat to cut off gas for Belarus today raised fears that Belarus would siphon gas and that shortages in Europe would result. Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the Belarussian president, ordered the government to pay, although it was not immediately clear where it would find the money. Gazprom, the Russian gas monopoly, said that there was time for a settlement, although one had not yet been reached yesterday.

Two men convicted of shooting a judge to death in his car two years ago were publicly hanged from cranes on two pickup trucks in Tehran. The hangings were in front of the courthouse where the judge, Hassan Moghaddass, was killed. The executions took place a day after nine hangings in other parts of Iran.
The East African Submarine Cable System is to link sub-Saharan Africa to Internet and telecommunications services, giving development a boost.

Jorge Hank Rhon, the fabulously wealthy former mayor of Tijuana, faced new accusations of corruption in his city’s police force, just four days before voters are to decide whether he will be the new governor of Baja California. The newspaper Reforma reported that federal authorities had issued arrest warrants for two of Mr. Hank’s former police commanders, alleging the cover-up of a murder by police officers in 2005 and the killing of another police commander in 2006. Mr. Hank, 51, who operates a network of betting parlors, has been running on a promise to clean up crime in the drug-plagued state, while his political opponents have accused him of being involved in crimes ranging from money-laundering to murder. He denies any wrongdoing and has never been charged with a crime.

Sierra Leone’s United Nations-backed court convicted two former leaders of a pro-government militia, Moinina Fofana and Allieu Kondewa, of war crimes, including murder, cruel treatment, pillage and issuing collective punishment. They led a militia called the Civil Defense Forces, accused of torturing and mutilating civilians during the 1991-2002 war. Mr. Kondewa was also convicted of conscripting child soldiers. The head of the militia, Sam Hinga Norman, had also been named in the indictment, but died earlier this year. No date was set for sentencing. The first sentences were handed down two weeks ago in Sierra Leone’s long-running push to hold to account those bearing the “greatest responsibility” for atrocities that included the chopping off of limbs. The first convicted were members of a ruling junta who were sentenced to 45- to 50-year prison terms.

The District of Columbia has agreed to pay $1 million to about 120 protesters who were improperly rounded up by the police during demonstrations against the invasion of Iraq, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The settlement, reached Wednesday, is the largest payout to date by the city for police actions during the Sept. 27, 2002, protests. Charles Ramsey, who was police chief at the time, initially defended the arrests but later acknowledged they were improper.

In a note online, The New Republic said it had confirmed that all the anecdotes reported by the Baghdad Diarist, an American soldier in Iraq writing under a pseudonym for the magazine, had been investigated and confirmed. Conservatives writing at The Weekly Standard online and elsewhere had questioned whether the cruel incidents recounted by the diarist, Pvt. Scott T. Beauchamp, had occurred. “We spoke with five other members of Beauchamp’s company, and all corroborated Beauchamp’s anecdotes,” as did other sources contacted, the statement said. The one inaccuracy, it said, was that a conversation mocking a disfigured woman turned out to have occurred at Camp Buehring in Kuwait, before the unit’s arrival in Iraq.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency has stopped donating and selling disaster trailers while it studies reports that people living in them after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita have become sick because of formaldehyde exposure. FEMA said in a statement Wednesday that it was acting “out of an abundance of caution” until receiving the results of the studies, which will take into account relative humidity, the trailers’ design and how long they are lived in. Formaldehyde can cause respiratory problems in high doses or with prolonged exposure.

The ousted director of the National Hurricane Center wants to return to his job and told superiors in a letter that they illegally retaliated for his criticism of an aging weather satellite. The letter, sent Wednesday by lawyers for the former director, X. William Proenza, said his removal violated the Whistleblower Protection Act. In addition, the letter said, hurricane center employees were intimidated “into speaking adversely about Mr. Proenza.” Mr. Proenza’s lawyer said she had not heard from National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration officials in response. Mr. Proenza was placed on leave on July 7, after almost half his staff signed a statement urging his dismissal.

The White House has agreed to let Congressional investigators interview three former officials about what the administration knew about the friendly-fire death of Cpl. Pat Tillman in Afghanistan in 2004. The aides are Dan Bartlett, a former White House counselor; Scott McClellan, a former press secretary; and Michael Gerson, a former speechwriter. The House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform agreed to White House demands that initial interviews be conducted without a transcript and with White House lawyers present. If investigators determine the aides have relevant information, they will be asked to return for transcribed interviews.

Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger declared a state of emergency in three counties where people have died after being infected with the West Nile virus. There have been four deaths in the state attributed to the virus, he said. To try to stop the spread of the disease, which is mosquito-borne, the governor declared a state of emergency in Kern, Colusa and San Joaquin Counties, making financial assistance available to the local vector control districts and directing state agencies to take proactive measures to protect Californians from further spread of the virus. “I will continue to ensure our local agencies have whatever resources they need to fight the spread of this disease,” Mr. Schwarzenegger said in a statement.

A sports article on Monday about the failure of state boxing commissions to enforce their prefight medical standards misidentified the individual who drove the boxer Bradley A. Rone to the bout in July 2003 in which he collapsed and died in the ring from heart problems. Delivering a six-month high for NBC in the Wednesday 9 p.m. time slot, ''Last Comic Standing'' lifted the network to a strong second-place finish that night, behind Fox. According to Nielsen's estimates, this competition of comedians drew 6.8 million viewers and NBC's best numbers since late January for that hour among adults 18 to 49. It was not enough, however, to outpace the last 30 minutes of Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance,'' which averaged 8.2 million viewers from 8 to 9:30. During the rest of the hour, however, ''Last Comic Standing'' tied Fox's ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' (7.8 million) in the 18-to-49 demographic. NBC's ''Dateline'' (7.2 million) led in that demographic at 10, ahead of CBS's ''CSI: NY'' repeat (8.2 million). Although a distant third in the 18-to-49 set for the night, CBS finished close behind second-place NBC in total viewers. ABC, despite broadcasts of the ''American Inventor'' finale at 8 (5.3 million) and a new episode of ''The Nine'' at 10 (3.3 million), ranked fourth over all.

Southeast Missouri State University has a new addition to its Center for Faulkner Studies. It is ''Sorority,'' a six-paragraph, one-page manuscript handwritten by William Faulkner in 1933 as a favor for a friend of his stepdaughter's at a Mississippi junior college, The Associated Press reported. On a visit to Faulkner's home in Oxford, Miss., the friend asked Faulkner to copy her sorority pledge. Instead he composed his own pledge, which used imagery and analogy to list character traits that a sorority seeks to develop in its members. The young woman, who couldn't decipher Faulkner's script, never believed it was anything but the pledge she asked for. The pledge was donated to the university by Jane Isbell Haynes, 86, a Faulkner scholar who was given it by the woman in 1984.

TARGET FIRST SATURDAYS The Brooklyn Museum's lively free series, held on the first Saturday of every month, is one of those things New Yorkers always talk about attending, and when (or if, in this lazy city) they finally get around to it, they can't believe they waited so long. Will tomorrow be the day? It should be, as the museum offers a big celebration of Caribbean art and culture, including films, talks, live music and plenty of dance. From 3 to 7 p.m., the museum plaza will go carnival, as the West Indian-American Day Carnival Association presents stilt walkers and live steel-pan music -- a warm-up for the Charles Moore Dance Theater, which will perform a traditional Caribbean dance at 6. From 6:30 to 8:30 p.m., Brooklyn's own ReggaeLution band will perform, and at 9, D.J. Lumumba (a k a Revolution) will preside over an inclusive Caribbean dance party, from bachata to zouk and back again. If your feet need a rest, check out Marta Moreno Vega's 2003 film about Cuban spiritual traditions, ''When the Spirits Dance Mambo,'' and stick around for a question-and-answer session with the director. Also try your hand at decorating a fabric sash inspired by the collection in the African galleries; or listen to Yasmin Ramirez, an arts fellow at the Center for Puerto Rican Studies, discuss artists in Caribbean neighborhoods in New York. In addition, the museum's galleries, shop and cafe will be open, and a cash bar will offer wine and beer. All you need to take are your dancing shoes. (Tomorrow from 3 to 11 p.m., 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, 718-638-5000, brooklynmuseum.org; free, but some programs require tickets, with lines forming a half-hour in advance.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

'SUMMER SESSIONS' When Jeannie Hopper was taking her first spin on the turntables in the garden of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum a couple of years ago, and a pair of 70-something women sidled over to her D.J. booth, she had a pretty good idea of what was coming. ''I thought they were going to complain about the noise,'' Ms. Hopper said. Turned out that they had a question, not a complaint. ''The music is wonderful,'' Ms. Hopper recalls them saying. ''What do you call it?'' It was that sort of open, inviting reception that persuaded Ms. Hopper to return to Cooper-Hewitt, this year as curator of their weekly Summer Sessions series. The event, led each Friday evening by a different D.J. of her choosing, draws about 700 people to the museum in a three-hour period. And while Ms. Hopper is eager to expose D.J.'s to a museumgoing audience, the museum is equally eager to draw on the loyal audience that turns up to hear a specific D.J., no matter the setting. ''It's an opportunity for us to reach a wider demographic,'' said Laurie Olivieri, a spokeswoman for Cooper-Hewitt. ''They have their own fan base who come up to the museum.'' Last week the music fans, the museum's regulars and people simply drawn in by the consistent thud of the bassline all migrated to the center of the lawn to dance. Even those languishing on blankets or exploring the ''Design for the Other 90%'' exhibition in the garden betrayed their interest with a gentle nod of the head or tap of the foot. They had all become part of the same crowd. (Fridays through Sept. 7, 6 to 9 p.m., Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, Manhattan, 212-849-8400, cooperhewitt.org. Free with admission: $12; $9 for students and 62+.) MONICA DRAKE

MIHOK--Andrew F., Jr., who died a year ago, is mourned by his family, friends and colleagues. RIFKIN--Beatrice (Bibi) Weiss, passed away on July 31, 2007 in her 88th year. Dearly loved by her late husband, Harold Rifkin M.D.; her children, Janet of Amherst, MA, Matthew of Old Field, NY and Phyllis of Rochester, NY; their spouses, David, Susan and Steve, and her grandsons, Adam, Alex (Jennifer), Jason (Allison), Nicholas, Jacob and Ethan. She was predeceased by her sisters, Helen Sunshine and Miriam Krosney. Bibi was born in Paterson, New Jersey on June 21, 1920. She lived her life in New York City, which she considered to be ''the best city in the world.'' She was the kind of woman who loved to laugh and made people around her feel good. She was bright, generous and thoughtful. She was a whiz at Scrabble, the New York Times crossword puzzles and enjoyed her daily Dewars before dinner until her last days. She adored her family and appreciated the support of her friends and caretakers. Above all, she appreciated all that life had given to her and considered herself to be a ''very lucky lady.'' Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Diabetes Association Rifkin Memorial Fund would be greatly appreciated.

'THEATER OF CRUELTY' Antonin Artaud (1896-1948) was a Surrealist poet, mystic, drug addict and playwright who is said to have died sitting at the foot of his bed, holding a shoe. Rebellious young writers and artists have long admired him, especially his 1938 manifesto, ''The Theater and Its Double,'' which includes the essay ''The Theater of Cruelty,'' describing performances that try to shock, affect and unsettle the audience as much as they can. At White Box in Chelsea, the curator Raúl Zamudio has gathered a marvelously twisted assortment of artwork by two dozen artists from as many nations, all paying homage to Artaud; some of it will no doubt leave you scratching your head in wonder. Video dominates, including Daniel Joseph Martinez's ''Hollow Men'' (video image, above) and Sislej Xhafa's poignant, chilling close-up of a gun on muddy ground being pelted with rain. Something terrible has happened here. Marcos Lopez shows small but intriguingly staged photographs of autopsies, with the arrangement of the figures mirroring scenes from Western religious iconographic traditions. Teresa Margolles has a sound installation of a real autopsy guaranteed to give you goose bumps, especially when the pathologist pulls out the power tools. Then there is Martin Durazo's vibrant, chaotic installation in a cubbyholelike crevice in which strobe lights, sound, sculpture and psychedelic video projections, among other things, freely intermingle. The show's wider purpose can be hard to grasp, but the setup gives a clear nod to Artaud. (Through Aug. 11, White Box, 525 West 26th Street, Chelsea, 212-714-2347, whiteboxny.org.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO
