Citing illness, the German tenor Endrik Wottrich has withdrawn from the role of Siegmund in Sunday's performance of ''Die Walküre'' at the Bayreuth Festival in Germany, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Wottrich, who is the companion of Katharina Wagner, the daughter of Wolfgang Wagner, the festival's director, received unfavorable reviews for his performance on Sunday, when his voice nearly failed him toward the end of Act II. He will be replaced, at least on Sunday, by the American tenor Robert Dean Smith, a Bayreuth veteran who was to have sung the role of Walther in ''Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg,'' which opened this year's festival and was Ms. Wagner's debut there as a director. But citing artistic differences, he left that production.

Yesterday was a good day for Charles Simic. Besides being named the 15th poet laureate of the United States, an honor that carries a $35,000 annual stipend, he was awarded $100,000 by the American Academy of Poets, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Simic, 69, was chosen to receive the academy's Wallace Stevens Award for ''outstanding and proven mastery'' of the art of poetry. Reacting with good humor to the honors, he said: ''Now I just have to break a leg. It's just too much luck. I'm just overwhelmed by the amount of good luck, being a superstitious person.''

South Korea halted imports of beef from the United States after a shipment from Cargill was found to contain a bone part banned as a precaution against mad cow disease. South Korea's quarantine authority found a piece of the vertebral column of a cow in one of 1,176 boxes from a shipment imported on July 29 weighing 18.7 metric tons, the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry said. Cargill said it had packaged the beef. A Cargill spokesman, Mark Klein, said the company is investigating the incident and will work with United States and South Korean officials.

The Italian government said yesterday that it would withdraw civil claims against the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles related to 40 ancient artifacts that the Getty has agreed to return. The Italian authorities contend that those antiquities, including an Etruscan duck, right, were unearthed at archaeological sites and smuggled out of the country. Announcing the withdrawal of charges at a news conference in Rome, Italy's culture minister, Francesco Rutelli, called the agreement with the Getty a victory for ''cultural diplomacy.'' Yet Mr. Rutelli and Maurizio Fiorilli, a Culture Ministry lawyer, said the decision on the civil charges would have no direct impact on the criminal case against Marion True, the Getty's former antiquities curator. She has been on trial in Rome since November 2005 on charges of conspiring to traffic in stolen artifacts, but has maintained that she is innocent. After a year of on-and-off negotiations, the Italian government and the Getty announced on Wednesday that they had reached a pact providing for the return of the 40 antiquities. The accord calls for Italy to lend rare archaeological treasures to the Getty, whose antiquities collection is housed in a newly expanded museum villa in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

Assicurazioni Generali, Italy's largest insurer, reported first-half profit that beat analysts' estimates and agreed to sell its Nuova Tirrena unit for 1.25 billion euros ($1.71 billion). Net income advanced to 1.78 billion euros from 1.4 billion euros a year earlier, the company said. Generali's first-half operating result from its Italian life insurance business rose 14 percent, to 979 million euros, as the company made a greater proportion of its premiums from its proprietary sales network. Gross domestic life insurance premiums fell 10 percent, to 8.35 billion euros, as bank sales dropped 34 percent. Generali, based in Trieste, Italy, is considering acquisitions abroad as the Italian life insurance market contracts, and it will use funds from the sale of Nuova Tirrena, a car insurer, to expand internationally.

Despite protests, Gwen Stefani's show in Malaysia will go on, but it won't show all that much of Ms. Stefani (''Hollaback Girl''). Maxis Communications, the organizer of the concert in Kuala Lumpur on Aug. 21, said she would not wear revealing costumes and would follow the local code of ethics for foreign performers, which bans the unnecessary baring of skin, The Associated Press reported. The National Union of Malaysian Muslim Students, with about 10,000 members, had protested the concert. ''Her performance and her attire are not suitable for our culture,'' Abdul Muntaqim, the organization's vice president, told The Associated Press. ''It promotes a certain degree of obscenity and will encourage youth to emulate the Western lifestyle. The concert should be stopped.'' A senior official at the Culture, Arts and Heritage Ministry said enforcement officers would monitor the performance. The official guide to performing in Malaysia says a female artist must be covered from the top of the chest to her knees. Jumping, shouting or throwing objects onstage or at the audience is not allowed. Performers' clothes may not carry obscene or drug-related images or messages.

STEADMAN--Evan Thomas, M.D., died on August 1, 2007 after a short illness. Born in Passaic, NJ on November 14, 1926, he attended the Collegiate School and graduated from Deerfield Academy. He then served in the U.S. Naval Reserve from 1944 to 1946. After graduating from Amherst College and Cornell University Medical College, where he became a clinical professor in the Obstetrics and Gynecology Department at the NY Hospital, he practiced for many years with friends and colleagues in the firm of Martens, Ryan and Steadman. He was a former President of the NY Obstetrical Society and the NY Medical and Surgical Society and was a member of the Century Association. He is survived by his wife Marcia, and children E. TenBroeck, Tracy (Wise), Dirk T., R. Webb and A. Coe, and six grandchildren. He will be remembered by his many former patients, colleagues, friends and family alike for his quick wit, sense of humor and wide ranging, practical advice on all manner of subjects.

KOSINSKI--Katherina ''KiKi'', February 6, 1933-May 24, 2007. Widow of author Jerzy Kosinski. Born in New York City as Katherina Von Fraunhofer, a descendant of Bavarian Aristocracy, she was raised in England. KiKi was a pioneering account executive with advertising agency, J. Walter Thomson in the 1960s. In 1968 she married Jerzy Kosinski, a polish holocaust survivor and author of Best Selling Novels including ''The Painted Bird'' and ''Being There''. He died in 1991. KiKi and Jerzy were inseparable and active in the International Political Arena. They were among the founders of the first Polish-American Bank in Poland of which KiKi was C.E.O. A good writer herself, KiKi was preparing a book entitled ''It Was My Life Too''. Survived by sister Dita Brodin and brother John Lowell Von Fraunhofer and Joseph Anthony Von Fraunhofer. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

'CHILL OUT!' The Three Bears may have been preparing to dine on porridge when Goldilocks made her unannounced visit, but Gus and Ida will do nothing of the kind this weekend. They're polar bears, and they won't eat steaming bowls of gruel (or steaming anything) at the Central Park Zoo. They prefer their cereal cold -- Cheerios are a favorite, said Kate McIntyre, a zoo spokeswoman -- and they will also dig into concoctions made with trout, peanut butter, watermelon and whipped cream. (They're great together, at least if you're a bear.) ''The bears, like humans, need to watch what they eat, so this is a special treat,'' Ms. McIntyre said.

CHARLIE HADEN INVITATION SERIES Just over a decade ago, the bassist Charlie Haden played a drummerless New York nightclub engagement with the pianist Kenny Barron. The results were recorded for a sparkling album, ''Night and the City,'' that came on the heels of an exquisite effort with a different pianist: ''Steal Away,'' featuring the venerable Hank Jones. And those two releases, both on Verve, are hardly exceptions in the discography of Mr. Haden, above, who has always found comfort and inspiration in the intimate art of duologue. So when he settles in for a series of piano-bass duets next week at the Blue Note, Mr. Haden will be acknowledging his own history, as well as building a new bridge or two. The run begins on Tuesday with Mr. Barron, who has lately been delving deeply into Brazilian music; expect at least one sumptuous bossa nova. On Wednesday the bench belongs to Ethan Iverson, who has more than once used the blog of his band the Bad Plus -- thebadplus.typepad.com -- for ardent pro-Haden propaganda purposes. (He once appraised Mr. Haden's all-duet album ''The Golden Number,'' released on A&M in 1976 and now out of print, as ''one of the very greatest jazz records.'') Thursday's pianist is the drier-than-vermouth legend Paul Bley, an associate of Mr. Haden's for many years, as well as a direct influence on Mr. Iverson and many others. And finally, next weekend will involve three consecutive nights of the ever-lyrical Brad Mehldau, who shared billing with Mr. Haden and the alto saxophonist Lee Konitz on a scintillating pair of Blue Note albums recorded at the Jazz Bakery in 1996 (just a couple of months before Mr. Haden recorded ''Night and the City'' with Mr. Barron, in fact). Of course it's tempting to toss around other names that could have made the lineup -- Carla Bley and Gonzalo Rubalcaba have recently done fine work with Mr. Haden, and naturally there is Mr. Jones -- but that would be downright churlish. What's there will be plenty: more than enough elevated conversation for anyone to absorb fully, though a few hardy souls may try. (Tuesday through Aug. 12 at 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, 212-475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $30 to $45 at tables, $20 to $30 at the bar, with a $5 minimum.) NATE CHINEN

NEW CROWNED HOPE One of the most interesting cinema projects in recent memory has been the new work that came out of the New Crowned Hope Festival. Organized by Peter Sellars, among others, this 2006 festival was commissioned by the city of Vienna to commemorate the 250th birthday of one of Austria's favorite sons, Mozart. Among the offerings in this wildly, admirably ambitious event was a cycle of six feature-length movies from different points on the globe -- from Thailand to Paraguay -- that would somehow speak to Mozart or at least his admirers. Or, in the impressive words of Simon Field, a curator of the films, ''reflected to varying degrees on, or that continued the spirit of, the Mozartian themes of New Crowned Hope, and which will take these themes in new directions appropriate to our time.'' Whether the six movies say something truly Mozartian remains an open question (at least for me), though there's no doubt that all do say a great deal about their specific worlds and their radically distinct directors: Bahman Ghobadi from Iranian Kurdistan, Mahamat-Saleh Haroun from Chad, Tsai Ming-liang from Taiwan and Malaysia, Garin Nugroho from Indonesia (above, a scene from his film ''Opera Jawa''), Apichatpong Weerasethakul from Thailand and Paz Encina from Paraguay. Some of these films have received limited distribution, including Mr. Weerasethakul's critically beloved ''Syndromes and a Century,'' Mr. Haroun's touching ''Dry Season'' and Mr. Tsai's wonderful return to form, ''I Don't Want to Sleep Alone.'' Each is worth a revisit, while the others are worthy of new exploration. (Through Aug. 29, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, 718-636-4100, bam.org.) MANOHLA DARGIS

The Grammy Award-winning R&B singer R. Kelly, below, is to stand trial next month on child pornography charges, including participation in videotaped sex acts with an underage girl, The Associated Press reported. According to the state attorney's office in Chicago, Judge Vincent Gaughan has scheduled the start of a jury trial for Sept. 17, five years after the charges were brought against Mr. Kelly, 40, whose full name is Robert Sylvester Kelly. He has pleaded not guilty to 14 counts of child pornography. His lawyers, saying that his image might have been computer-generated, have not conceded that he is on the tape, and they have tried to raise doubt about the identity and age of the girl. The trial has been postponed repeatedly for various reasons.

LACHER--Lee. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel Lacher, devoted mother of Susan Alter Klaperman and the late Dr. Arthur Lacher, dear sister of Ruth, Evelyn and Betty, beloved grandmother of Beth, Rebecca, Shira and Jason, and cherished greatgrandmother of Nina, Arthur, Ryan, Ayelet, Aaron and Nava. Taken from us at the age of 90, she was a true woman of valor.

SCHMUTTER--Nat, the attorneys and staff of Krass, Snow & Schmutter, P.C. mourn the loss of Nat Schmutter, father of our partner, Steven Schmutter. Our heartfelt condolences to Steve, his mother, Elaine, and family.
The city's history is solidified in the mud of its buildings and that seems almost palpable. Yet around town, there is a sense of change. People are talking about a New Santa Fe.
Bahrain is ready to play host to the international crowds drawn by Formula One.

CHICAGO -- The founder of DailyKos, Markos Moulitsas Zuniga, took the stage tonight and reminded the 1,500 or so activists and liberal bloggers in the audience how far they had come in politics in so short a time.
Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below. - The Editors

CHICAGO -- One of the hottest moments of today's Democratic debate occurred when one of the moderators, Matt Bai (a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine), pressed the candidates about a challenge laid down by former North Carolina senator John Edwards.

CHICAGO -- New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson, always one with a joke, stayed a lot longer than his campaign aides wanted in the post-debate breakout session with liberal bloggers and activists here at the YearlyKos convention.
Dr. Robert Grober, a professor of applied physics, believes he has invented a teaching tool that could change the scope of golf instruction.
Hillary Rodham Clinton addressed Iraq and lobbying at the Yearly Kos convention and faced criticism from John Edwards and Barack Obama.

Given The Caucus's focus on presidential politics, the Republican debate on ABC's "This Week" with George Stephanopoulos is must-see TV for us, but the other Sunday talk shows are offering up some powerful competition with two of the administration's top foreign policy officials making the rounds.

CHICAGO -- Now we're up in a smaller, very packed room in the McCormick Place where Mr. Edwards is holding his break-out session with a few hundred people. They seem very pumped, feeling that Mr. Edwards had a very strong performance in the forum downstairs.

In his Web column today, Tom Redburn, a deputy business editor at The Times, who overseescoverage of economic issues, discusses the what could be the biggest issue no one wants to talk about:Just about everybody remembers Captain Louis Renault, in "Casablanca," declaring, "I'm shocked, shocked to find that gambling is going on here."

Yesterday our reader, Toof, asked a question for the virtual paddock. I decided that the best person to answer the question was not a team member, who might have a slanted point of view, but Gary Anderson, a former technical director at Jordan, and then Stewart Grand Prix and then Jaguar. Anderson is now working as a commentator for the Setanta Sports television channel in Ireland. Gary kindly accepted to answer Toof's question.

Debate Wrap We caught up with Joan McCarter, a contributing editor toDailyKos and one of the moderators of the panel. She was thrilled with the way it went, saying the candidates seemed to feed off the energy in the room.

ANKENY, Iowa - Senator John McCain said here Saturday that the Congress bears some responsibility for the Minneapolis bridge collapse because of the way it spends transportation aid on wasteful pork projects instead of inspections and maintenance.
CHICAGO -- We're still here, now moving on to the next stage at the YearlyKos convention with almost all of the Democratic candidates.
In a cafe in Amman, Jordan, more than 300 ecstatic Iraqis watched as Iraq defeated Saudi Arabia 1-0.
Many Iraqi fans found themselves left out as the national team returned in triumph to a celebration in Baghdad's Green Zone.

CHICAGO -- Hi everybody. We're at the YearlyKos convention in Chicago, where Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is about to speak in a small "intimate" setting with about 350 people. They'll get to ask her questions for half an hour or so.
Many Iraqi fans found themselves left out, as the national team returned in triumph to a celebration in Baghdad's Green Zone.

A clip of Republican Mitt Romney in a contentious exchange with a conservative Des Moines radio host over his Mormon beliefs is making the rounds today, offering something of a different critique about his religious faith.
Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online on Tuesday. Post a comment about it below. - The Editors

The role of candidates' wives was analyzed in the press in two very different ways today. The Times's Michael Cooper and Marc Santora bring you the Fred D. Thompson camp's internal debate about whether his wife, Jeri Kehn Thompson, is helping or hurting by getting involved in day-to-day operations. But looking back, it appears that whatever liability Hillary Rodham Clinton's assertive reputation posed for her husband's campaign in 1992, the way she conducted herself then is reaping major benefits now.

Things got a little bit tighter at the top of the U.S. Open as the leaders after the sixth round, Benjamin Finegold and Amon Simutowe, drew quickly with each other in Round 7 and were caught by Tegshsuren Enkhbat, a master, who won his seventh round game. The U.S. Open is being played in Cherry Hill, N.J. The games can be followed live or replayed at Monroi.com.
In recent months, British troops say they have been having increasing success in fighting the Taliban and winning local support in Afghanistan.

The inspiration for “Jekyll,” an odd and oddly addictive four-part mini-series that begins tonight on BBC America, is of course the Robert Louis Stevenson story, but somebody involved also seems to have been spending a lot of time watching “Un Chien Andalou.”
Into the season of “America’s Got Talent” and “So You Think You Can Dance,” ABC is dropping a series of four talky, philosophical dramas based on stories by well-known science-fiction writers.
On “Grand Slam,” a single-elimination tournament of game-show champions that will be broadcast on the Game Show Network starting tonight, the questions are often difficult.
A motherless boy, a graceless dog and a witless script propel “Underdog,” a live-action resurrection of the 1960s television series.
“Cash,” a Bollywood caper, provides abundant proof that Hollywood pictures have no monopoly on ostentatious wealth, or, to use a spent expression, bling.
Giants batting coach Joe Lefebvre, a man who hit 34 home runs in his own major league career, sees the irony in critiquing the form of Barry Bonds as he goes for 755.

The Dallas Mavericks agreed to a two-year, $4 million deal with guard-forward Eddie Jones, his agent said. Jones, 35, an unrestricted free agent, will receive about $1.87 million in the first year from the Mavericks’ biannual exception, the agent, Leon Rose, said. Jones, a three-time All-Star, has averaged 15.4 points in 13 N.B.A. seasons.
Detroit Tigers infielder Neifi Pérez’s season is over after it was announced that he tested positive for a banned stimulant for the third time.
The Yankees’ Alex Rodriguez drilled the first pitch he saw from the Royals’ Kyle Davies for his milestone homer.
As divers continued to search for bodies, the president promised today to make it a priority to rebuild the span.
Palestinian officials said that President Mahmoud Abbas and the prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, will meet in the West Bank city.
Officials moved today to try to contain the disease, which devastated the British livestock industry in 2001.
A strong performance on Friday showed that while Yankee Stadium is still a haven for the old and overpaid, the team is steadily getting younger and livelier.

Los Angeles Clippers forward Elton Brand ruptured his left Achilles’ tendon yesterday during his daily workout. Brand, 28, will have surgery, but plans for the operation had not been completed, the Clippers said. Last month, Brand withdrew from the United States national team because of nagging injuries. He averaged 20.5 points and 9.3 rebounds last season.

Michael Phelps won twice in about an hour at the United States national championships in Indianapolis, coming close to setting a world record in the 100-meter backstroke yesterday. Phelps’s backstroke time of 53.01 seconds was the second-fastest ever, .03 off Aaron Peirsol’s mark, set in March at the world championships. Phelps set a meet record in the 200 freestyle in 1:44.98, then regrouped and still had enough energy to swim what his coach, Bob Bowman, called his best closing 50 in the 100 back.
Greg Winter and Larry Rohter, chief of The Times’s Rio de Janeiro bureau, discuss Brazil’s global warming policies.
The practice of stopping people on city streets has caused occasional tension with some city residents.
State and local firefighters battled a fire late Friday that had burned through at least 3,000 acres of pinelands in Wharton State Forest in southern New Jersey, the authorities said.
A judge issued a statewide restraining order Friday prohibiting a self-described pedophile from coming closer than 10 yards to any minor in California.

Two Cuban boxers who disappeared during last month’s Pan American Games were found at a resort near Rio de Janeiro, where the police say they caroused and ran up an exorbitant tab. Now, a police inspector said, they want to go back to Cuba. The two-time Olympic champion Guillermo Rigondeaux and Erislandy Lara were found Thursday at an inn in the coastal resort city Cabo Frio.

Dale Earnhardt Jr. ended a stretch of nearly five years without qualifying in first thanks in part to a well-timed rain shower. Earnhardt won his first pole since September 2002 with a lap of 169.975 m.p.h. yesterday at Pocono Raceway. The top spot could be a huge benefit for Earnhardt, who is clinging to the final spot in the Chase. His lap after a 45-minute rain delay nudged Kurt Busch into second with a lap of 169.863. Kyle Busch was third at 169.782.

Tyson Gay warmed up for the world championships with a comfortable victory in the 100 meters at the London Grand Prix, but Jeremy Wariner had to work for his victory in the 400. Gay, the fastest man in the world this year, won the sprint in 10.02 seconds in a headwind, overcoming a poor start to take the lead at the halfway point. Wariner, the Olympic and world champion, passed his United States teammate LaShawn Merritt in the closing meters to win the 400 in 44.05.

Trent Hunter signed a one-year deal with the Islanders after an arbitrator awarded him a salary of $1.55 million for next season. Hunter, a 27-year-old right wing who was a restricted free agent, had 20 goals and 15 assists last season in 77 games.

The general director of the Rabobank cycling team resigned yesterday, 10 days after he dismissed Michael Rasmussen from the squad while he was leading the Tour de France. The director, Theo de Rooij, has “decided to step down, in consultation with Rabobank,” the team said in a statement. De Rooij dismissed Rasmussen, a Danish rider, saying he lied about his whereabouts to evade doping tests.

Officials yesterday were investigating suspicious betting patterns on a match involving Nikolay Davydenko of Russia, who retired with an injury against a low-ranked opponent at an ATP tournament in Poland. In an unprecedented move, the British online gambling company Betfair voided all bets placed on Thursday’s second-round match at the Prokom Open in Sopot between the No. 4-ranked Davydenko, the top seed, and No. 87-ranked Martin Vassallo Arguello of Argentina. Betfair said it received about $7 million in bets on the match — 10 times the usual amount — and most of the money was on Arguello to win, even after Davydenko won the first set, 6-2.
City Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher pleaded not guilty at the arraignment and was released on $200,000 bail.
Last summer, at age 29, Peter Gilmore made a career decision, quitting his job and putting all his energy into distance running.
The driver often parked in front of Intermediate School 8 in Queens, where he sold ice cream to children and drugs to longtime customers, the police said.
Alana Beard scored 24 points and Nakia Sanford added 16 to help the Washington Mystics beat the Liberty on Friday night.
Gazprom, the Russian natural gas monopoly that is controlled by the Kremlin, said it would not cut natural gas shipments to Belarus.
Nepal introduced a new national anthem to replace the one that praised the highly unpopular King Gyanendra and wished him a long life.
A survey of 32,000 men and women by researchers at the University of Göttingen found that more than 35 percent of those reporting unsatisfying sex lives tended to use work as a diversion.

An article on July 26 about the reopening of the north end of City Hall Park, which surrounds the Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan, included outdated information from a park advocacy group about park hours and access. A path from Broadway to Centre Street is open to the public from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. daily without interruption; it is not closed at certain times for exclusive use by a nearby charter school. Only one gate on Chambers Street — not two — is occasionally closed to the public, and those occasions are the times the school is in session, not just when students are arriving and being dismissed. The second gate, on the west side of the Tweed building, is open to the public without restriction during park hours.
The authorities detained as many as 200 ethnic Tibetans this week after a protest in the town of Lithang, in Sichuan Province, an area populated by Tibetans, Radio Free Asia reported.

President Evo Morales has suggested that along with the traditional salute of placing the right hand over the heart while listening to the national anthem, Bolivians should also raise their left fists, in solidarity with the country’s long-suffering indigenous majority.

A headline on Page 7 of the Travel section this weekend, with the Next Stop column, refers imprecisely to the relationship between the city of Nantes, France, and the region of Brittany. Although Nantes was long the capital of Brittany and remains strongly identified with it, France’s current administrative structure puts it in the Pays de la Loire region.
The Police Department has increasingly failed to prosecute police officers on charges of misconduct when those cases have been substantiated by an independent board, officials say.

An article on July 26 about the reopening of the north end of City Hall Park, which surrounds the Tweed Courthouse in Lower Manhattan, included outdated information from a park advocacy group about park hours and access. A path from Broadway to Centre Street is open to the public from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. daily without interruption; it is not closed at certain times for exclusive use by a nearby charter school. Only one gate on Chambers Street — not two — is occasionally closed to the public, and those occasions are the times the school is in session, not just when students are arriving and being dismissed. The second gate, on the west side of the Tweed building, is open to the public without restriction during park hours.
Congress stumbled toward a recess on a discordant note in the latest example of the ideological standoff that has slowed progress all year.

A Wisconsin company is voluntarily recalling 15,000 cases of green beans that federal officials say may not have been processed adequately to eliminate the potential for botulism toxin. No illnesses have been reported and no botulism has been found so far, but Lakeside Foods, based in Manitowoc, says it will continue to test cans of French style green beans. The company said it learned of the problem during routine internal monitoring. The 14.5-ounce cans were distributed in 20 states and Canada under various labels including Albertson’s, Happy Harvest, Best Choice, Food Club, H.E.B., Laura Lynn, Kroger, North Pride, Shop N Save, Shoppers Valu, Schnucks, Cub Foods, Dierbergs, I.G.A., Best Choice and Thrifty Maid. More information can be found at Lakeside Foods’ Web site at lakesidefoods.com.

Two mastiffs at the home of the actor Ving Rhames apparently mauled a 40-year-old man to death, the authorities said. The victim, whose name has not been released, had worked at the actor’s home for about two years and was responsible for caring for the dogs, said Officer Sandra Gonzalez of the Los Angeles Police Department. The authorities said the victim was found on the front lawn. Mr. Rhames was not home at the time of the attack, Ms. Gonzalez said.
A 16-year-old was sentenced to life in prison with the possibility of parole in the shooting death of his high school principal.

The State Supreme Court agreed to hear an appeal by a man sentenced to death in the killing of a Savannah police officer. In a 4-to-3 decision, the court granted the application of the man, Troy Davis, 38, who is appealing a lower court’s refusal to grant him a new trial. Last month, Mr. Davis was granted a stay of execution by the State Board of Pardons and Paroles the day before he was scheduled to be put to death. The stay was granted for up to 90 days. The stay was granted after Mr. Davis’s lawyers argued that several witnesses against him had recanted or changed their testimony about the 1989 shooting of the officer.

President Bush invited representatives of major industrialized and developing countries to a conference on climate changes this fall in Washington. “In recent years, science has deepened our understanding of climate change and opened new possibilities for confronting it,” Mr. Bush said in his invitation letter, asking other nations to take part in discussing a long-term strategy. The White House has set the meeting for Sept. 27-28. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice will be the host. Mr. Bush, who plans to address the conference, invited China, the European Union, the European Commission, France, Germany, India, Italy, Britain, Japan, Canada, South Korea, Mexico, Russia, Australia, Indonesia, South Africa and the United Nations.

President Bush signed legislation that intensifies the antiterrorism effort at home, shifting money to high-risk states and cities and expanding scrutiny of air and sea cargo. The bill requires screening of all cargo on passenger planes within three years and sets a five-year goal of scanning all container ships for nuclear devices before they leave foreign ports. It also elevates the importance of risk factors in determining which states and cities get federal security money.

A bribery case against a former San Jose mayor has been closed after prosecutors said they would not pursue an appeal or another grand jury indictment over the alleged corruption involving the city’s garbage contract. District Attorney Dolores Carr of Santa Clara County said winning an appeal seemed unlikely. A judge in June dismissed the criminal case against the former mayor, Ron Gonzales, his former budget director, and Norcal Waste Systems Inc., over what he found to be faulty grand jury instructions. Prosecutors alleged that Mr. Gonzales and his aide brokered a backroom deal with Norcal in 2000 that resulted in the hiring of Teamsters, instead of lower-paid union workers, and then passed off the extra labor expenses in a garbage rate increase that cost taxpayers an additional $11.25 million.

Mirthala Salinas, a broadcaster in Los Angeles who covered politics for Telemundo and became romantically involved with Mayor Antonio R. Villaraigosa, was suspended Thursday for two months without pay. Her suspension followed an investigation into whether the ethical standards of the station, KVEA-TV, had been violated because of her relationship with the mayor. The station’s news director was also suspended, its general manager reassigned and the station’s group president reprimanded.
Police officials said they suspected the men who were arrested were part of a group operating “a very violent criminal enterprise” out of a neighborhood bakery.
Most of the 1,400 or so people who lost their jobs at American Home Mortgage Investment Corporation said they were stunned to find themselves unemployed.
A prominent Italian priest who is close to some of Italy’s most powerful politicians has been accused by men who were once clients of his drug rehabilitation charity of sexually abusing them.
Brazilians are reconsidering their travel options after two major plane crashes in the past 10 months.
A measure to broaden the White House’s wiretapping authority was expected to be approved in the House.
Several investigations facing New York Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his staff can readily sidetrack everything else important going on in Albany.
The Yankees have been playing great baseball since the All-Star Game, and for all his talent as a hitter, Jason Giambi could disrupt the mix by returning from injury.
Twenty-six people have been killed in 61 attacks on candidates and activists as national elections approach.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has asked the S.E.C. to require that Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Och-Ziff Capital Management, both planning public stock offerings, be regulated as investment companies.
The present food aid system is a favorite of American farmers. But it is also cumbersome, slow, expensive and leaves people hungry who could easily be fed.
On a helicopter raid hunting Iraqi insurgents, U.S. troops avoided roadside bombs, established a presence and picked up intelligence.
Skateboarder Jake Brown’s five-story fall during competition raises a question: Who decides what is an acceptable level of risk in action sports?
Congress needs to clarify whether the messy affair surrounding Cpl. Pat Tillman’s death reflects astonishing incompetence or a conspiracy to exploit a famous soldier.
Anthony O’Reilly, former C.E.O. of H.J. Heinz and founder and chairman of Independent Media of Britain, discusses the newspaper business, editorial interference and expansion into Asia.
Some days I feel like a grave-rubbing — as if the terrain had been traced onto me. The tractor is the same, only dustier.
A Senate committee approved an amendment to the Coast Guard reauthorization bill that would restrict how private owners could use surplus ships obtained from the government.
Yovani Gallardo and the Milwaukee Brewers concentrated on taking on the visiting Philadelphia Phillies, not one another.
Steven J. Hayes, who was sanctioned on 23 occasions for misconduct while incarcerated, frequently and quickly relapsed into a life of crime.
Giants’ batting coach Joe Lefebvre, a man who hit 34 home runs in his own major league career, sees the irony in critiquing the form of Barry Bonds as he goes for 755.
Foot and mouth disease has been found in cattle on a farm in Britain, the government said as it shut down livestock movements.
Three Gulf Coast counties are spending millions of dollars in an effort to keep the mines from further expansion in a major watershed.
Sgt. Lawrence G. Hutchins III was sentenced to 15 years in prison for killing an Iraqi man near Hamdaniya last year.
Rupert Murdoch won ownership of Dow Jones, mortgage news went from bad to worse, M.L.B. and StubHub made a deal, Mattel recalled toys painted with lead, and more.
Returning to Iraq for the first time since they won the Asian Cup final, the Iraqi national soccer team celebrated far from the gaze of their disappointed fans.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel on Friday agreed to rethink a widely criticized plan to give Holocaust survivors a monthly stipend of about $20.
Overproduction and competition from New World wines has led the European Union to propose that farmers destroy 200,000 hectares of vines.
The holding company of the billionaire Warren E. Buffett, reported Friday that its net income jumped nearly 33 percent during the second quarter.
Pakistan’s Supreme Court ruled to free Javed Hashmi, one of the country’s main opposition leaders, who had been serving a sentence for treason.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who voted in 2002 to authorize the invasion of Iraq, has over the past year repositioned herself.
Fannie Hillsmith was a late-blooming Cubist painter.
Two Rider University officials and three fraternity members were charged in connection with the death of a freshman last March during a hazing ritual.
Haile Gebrselassie, the man universally regarded as the world’s greatest distance runner, will compete in New York for the first time this weekend.
William J. Tuttle was a Hollywood makeup artist whose work was so renowned that he won an Oscar years before there was an official Academy Award for makeup.
Little-known safety James Butler has been handed a starting job as the Giants make changes to their secondary.
Jeri Kehn Thompson is involved in everything, including her husband’s travel schedule, fund-raising focus and staffing decisions.
Rory Sabbatini shot a three-under-par 67 to take a two-shot lead over Zach Johnson in the second round of the Bridgestone Invitational at Akron, Ohio.
The job market lost some of its punch in July as employers added 92,000 jobs — the fewest in five months — and unemployment edged up to 4.6 percent.
Profits in Proctor & Gamble’s fiscal fourth quarter rose 19 percent and the company announced plans on Friday to increase its stock buyback.
A report by Congressional investigators says that the S.E.C. bungled a promising investigation two years ago into suspicious trading at Pequot Capital Management.
Using pomp and imagery to court public opinion at home and abroad, Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez has been escorting the actor Sean Penn on a tour around his country.
With Imax cameras filming, John Harlin III set out to complete a challenge that killed his father: climb perhaps the biggest, most notorious mountain wall in Europe.
Cellphone plans that encourage subscribers to talk mainly to people in the same network are having unintentional social effects.
In October, the federal government will begin enforcing new rules for highway bridge design meant to make new structures more efficient, more reliable, safer and longer lived.
The aide was being investigated on allegations that he threatened a Republican member of the Public Service Commission, which regulates utilities.
A New Jersey judge sought public disclosure of e-mail messages Gov. Jon S. Corzine exchanged with the state union official who is also a former companion.
U.S. officials said the airstrike had targeted two Taliban commanders during “a sizable meeting” of insurgents in Helmand Province on Thursday.
An influential Republican senator says he will propose legislation requiring a federal registry of payments made by drug makers to doctors.
Catriona Matthew is easily overlooked, despite being the best title prospect from Britain in the Women’s British Open.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 — The long, strange trip of Kerry Wood has again reached Wrigley Field. Before Friday’ 6-2 loss to the Mets, the Cubs activated Wood, who has not pitched in the major leagues since June 6, 2006, because of the shoulder problems that have bothered him since the start of 2005. Wood has had 11 stays on the disabled list and two major surgeries.

In a new book, Ellen Winner and Lois Hetland of Project Zero — an arts-education program at the Harvard Graduate School of Education — argue forcefully for the benefits of art education, while still defending their 2000 thesis.
Harness racing’s version of the Battle of the Sexes will be played out at the Meadowlands on Saturday.
Mr. Keeton was a former federal judge and Harvard law professor who wrote widely influential treatises on tort law, courtroom tactics and no-fault auto insurance.
Amtrak has insisted in recent meetings with developers and other transportation agencies that it has veto power over plans to build a new Pennsylvania Station.
Rahmat Abdhir was arrested at his workplace in Sunnyvale, Calif., on Thursday on terrorism charges related to the 2002 Bali bombings.
Chrysler became the only privately held Detroit automaker after the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management completed its $7.4 billion purchase of a majority stake on Friday.
The methods used to search evidence from Representative William J. Jefferson’s office were ruled unconstitutional.
Unlike a typical “Dateline” segment, “In the Shadow of Justice” feels highly personal, told without narration, mostly through the nearly 300 hours shot by Dan Slepian.
John August, one of Hollywood’s more hotly pursued studio writers,  moves into the directing chair with “The Nines.”
Twenty-five enlarged color prints arranged as diptychs, triptychs and multiple-panel works are included in “Emancipatory Action: Paula Trope and the Meninos.”
Mr. Boileau held leadership positions at Boeing, General Dynamics and Northrup Gruman and worked on projects ranging from the lunar rover to the B-2 stealth bomber.
E.A.D.S., Europe’s largest aerospace company, said that it was close to agreement with the government of Libya on arms contracts worth $405 million.
Mr. Roberto founded Angola’s first nationalist movement, which eventually helped win the country’s independence from the Portuguese in 1975.
Toyota reported a 32 percent rise in second-quarter profits and strong sales in North America as the company seeks to widen its lead over G.M. as the world’s largest automaker.
The search was continuing for potential survivors after a boat capsized in heavy rain at the mouth of the Great Scarcies River, while en route from Freetown to Rokupr.
The Mets had a huge ninth inning against Cubs closer Ryan Dempster on Friday night, scoring four runs.
At least 186 people have been killed in recent days and 19 million driven from their homes by monsoon rains in northern India and Bangladesh.

Nicholas  Kulish, the Berlin bureau chief for The New York Times, was embedded with the marines in 2003 while working for The Wall Street Journal, and he has brought home a story worthy of his literary idols.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton said she would attend an individual meeting with liberal bloggers this weekend.

This year at the Tanglewood Music Center’s Festival of Contemporary Music, the composer John Harbison, who directed the festival, assembled a program in the competing aesthetic ideas of a single generation.
Marines who work in White Plains have angered city officials by failing to address $94,000 in unpaid parking tickets since 2001.
WFAN, the AM radio station in New York City that served as a flagship for Don Imus’s show before he was fired, has apparently settled on a permanent successor.
Portfolio managers are seeking out companies that are less sensitive to changing economic conditions and the whims of investment fashion.
The hard fact is, Ingmar Bergman isn’t being taught in film courses or debated by film buffs with the same intensity as Alfred Hitchcock, Orson Welles and Jean-Luc Godard.
Valerie Plame Wilson loses C.I.A. lawsuit, the Van Gogh that wasn’t, Wonder returns to touring and more culture news.
The 2008 lineup of Lyrics & Lyricists, the series on the American Songbook at the 92nd Street Y, has been announced.

Experts have determined that “Head of a Man,” a painting attributed to van Gogh for more than 70 years, is a fake, probably painted by one of van Gogh’s peers, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

A federal judge has ruled in favor of the C.I.A. in its effort to prohibit the former agent Valerie Plame Wilson from disclosing the dates she worked for the agency in her coming book, Publishers Weekly reported yesterday.
I want an E-vote brokerage: Next election, I’m guessing battleground states will be very eager to pay for my hand on the lever.
While the nation’s airlines are starting to work their way back to profitability, conditions for passengers are worsening with not enough seats to go around.
James B. Stewart writes in Smart Money that the stock market bubble is about to burst.
The mini-festival of Beethoven at the Mostly Mozart Festival culminates today in a long two-part re-creation of one of Beethoven’s most famous concerts.

(ABC) MASTERS OF SCIENCE FICTION The physicist Stephen Hawking narrates this new four-part anthology series, featuring adaptations of some of the genre’s most famous short stories, performed by actors including Malcolm McDowell, Terry Quinn, Elizabeth Rohm, Brian Dennehy, John Hurt, James Denton and Anne Heche. First: “A Clean Escape,” based on John Kessel’s short story, set in a post-apocalyptic future, about Dr. Deanna Evans (played by Judy Davis, above), a psychiatrist charged with interrogating a distinguished if befuddled man (Sam Waterston) who appears to be having a memory lapse. A sports article on Tuesday about Lorena Ochoa's preparations for the Women's British Open on the Old Course at St. Andrews in Scotland rendered incorrectly the name of the famous bridge on the course. It is the Swilcan Bridge, not Swilken. (Other spellings, including Swilken and Swilkin, have been used in many publications, but Swilcan is the preferred spelling of the St. Andrews Links Trust.)

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the restaurateur Daniel Boulud's settlement of a discrimination lawsuit misidentified the plaintiffs in a lawsuit filed against the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York, an organization that had criticized Mr. Boulud. And a correction in this space on Wednesday also referred incorrectly to them. Among the plaintiffs are former employees of Windows on the World, the World Trade Center restaurant destroyed on 9/11; they are not all former employees of Colors, a restaurant created after 9/11 by other former employees of Windows on the World. Of the eight plaintiffs, four -- not all -- say they are former employees of Windows; the rest are former employees of other restaurants that closed after 9/11.

Duane Chapman, known as Dog, the star of the reality television show ''Dog the Bounty Hunter,'' is no longer wanted by the police in Mexico after a Mexican court dismissed a charge that he illegally detained an American fugitive, Reuters reported. A judge canceled an order for the arrest of Mr. Chapman, below, who for more than three years has faced the possibility of extradition to serve a jail sentence in Mexico, where bounty hunting is illegal. After spending two weeks in jail there, Mr. Chapman jumped bail and fled to the United States. EduardoAmerena, Mr. Chapman's lawyer, told Reuters, ''Chapman can now be in Mexico without any problem.'' Mexican prosecutors may appeal the decision. Mr. Chapman was arrested in 2003 after seizing Andrew Luster, heir to the Max Factor cosmetics fortune, on a street in Puerto Vallarta to take him back to the United States to serve a 124-year jail sentence for drugging and raping three women. Mr. Luster was flown to California shortly after the capture and is now in jail.

An article in The Arts on June 23 about ''David Macaulay: The Art of Drawing Architecture,'' an exhibition at the National Building Museum in Washington, misstated the nature of the show and attributed an erroneous distinction to it. The exhibition is a survey of Mr. Macaulay's drawing process, and is therefore not the first major retrospective of his work. (The first major retrospective opened in 2004 at the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., and is currently at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.)

The pop star Stevie Wonder, below,will make his first American tour in more than a decade, Reuters reported. Mr. Wonder, 57, said at a news conference in Los Angeles on Thursday that the tour would start on Aug. 23 in San Diego. The tour, ''A Wonder Summer's Night,'' will stop in 13 cities and end in Boston on Sept. 20, but Mr. Wonder said more dates might be added. In 2005, he released his first album in 10 years, ''A Time to Love.'' It has sold 469,000 copies so far, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In his career to date, Mr. Wonder has sold more than 70 million albums. He was just 11 when he signed his first recording contract with Motown Records.

POTTASCH--Alan Maxwell, 79 years young, died in his sleep on Friday, July 27. At the time of his death, he was doing what he loved best working on a Pepsi TV commercial in Los Angeles. Known as the father of the ''Pepsi Generation'', Alan joined Pepsi-Cola in 1957 and devoted his career to marketing and advertising. His Pepsi commercials won more than 60 major awards, including the advertising worlds highest honor, the Grand Prix at Cannes. Working with Pepsi's longtime agency partner, BBDO, he produced some of the industry's most famous celebrity commercials, including the groundbreaking musical ads starring Michael Jackson in the 1980s. In addition to his Pepsi duties, Alan served on the boards of the Association of National Advertisers, The Ad Council, Cayman Airways and the National Association of Underwater Instructors. He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in creative writing from Penn State University in 1949, which later honored him with its Alumni Fellow Award in 1993. A native of New York City, Alan lived in New Fairfield, Connecticut with his wife Lisa and their daughter Allison. He is survived by a son from a previous marriage, Alan Jr. of California, and two stepchildren, Gyongyi Plucer-Rossario of Guam, and Lorand Plucer of Amsterdam. He is also survived by a sister, Harriet Selig, of Florida. He is predeceased by two sisters, Audre and Muriel. Memorial services will be private, although a special tribute and celebration of Alan's life is planned at PepsiCo's world headquarters in Purchase, NY at a date to-bedetermined in September. Donations may be made in Alan's memory for a scholarship that is being established in his name at the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, NY, Office of Development, c/o Lenora Hallums, 219 North Hall, Pratt Institute, 200 Willoughby Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11205, or the Emergency Medical Technicians service of the New Fairfield Volunteer Fire Department, attention Ed McCue, PO Box 8307, New Fairfield, CT 06812.

The results may have been bad for Sara VonGillern and Dominic Sandoval, who were voted off ''So You Think You Can Dance'' on Thursday, but the ratings were a boon for Fox. According to Nielsen's estimates, the show drew 9.6 million viewers at 9 p.m., outperforming all other shows that night -- including a ''CSI'' repeat on CBS, also at 9 (9 million) -- in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. Fox's ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' (7.9 million) earned Thursday's second-highest ratings among adults in that demographic. It led the 8 o'clock hour, ahead of CBS's ''Big Brother'' (7.1 million). CBS ranked No. 2 for the night after Fox, winning at 10 with a rerun of ''Without a Trace'' (9 million), which easily outdrew ABC's ''Men in Trees'' (3.6 million) and NBC's ''ER'' repeat (2.8 million). ABC and NBC finished about even, in third place over all.

INTERNATIONAL A2-6 Guatemala's CampaigningIs Bloodiest in its History It is election time in Guatemala and that means rallies and banners -- and body bags. In the campaigning leading up to elections on Sept. 9, there have been at least 61 violent attacks on candidates and political activists, according to authorities. The death toll as of mid-July was 26, making this the bloodiest campaign in the country's history. A1

Federal authorities said a California man, Rahmat Abdhir, had been arrested on terrorism-related charges and indicted along with his Malaysian brother, a fugitive and suspected leader of Jemaah Islamiyah, the group blamed for killing 202 people in the 2002 bombing of a nightclub in Bali, Indonesia. Marcos Ambrose should have won the race. Robby Gordon insists he did. In the end, it was Kevin Harvick who celebrated the victory yesterday in Montreal in the inaugural Busch Series race in Canada. It was a controversial finish that thrilled the crowd, infuriated Nascar and probably jeopardized Gordon’s participation in today’s Nextel Cup race at Pocono Raceway.Gordon refused to forfeit his position on the track when ordered to by Nascar late in the race. Officials said he intentionally knocked Ambrose out of the race, then refused to pull off the track as ordered.“We are still determining what will happen at Pocono,” said Steve O’Donnell, vice president for Nascar’s racing operations.

Fernando Alonso was dropped from the pole position at the Hungarian Grand Prix in Budapest for delaying his McLaren teammate Lewis Hamilton during qualifying. Hamilton had questioned Alonso’s tactics during a lengthy pit stop, and officials from FIA, world racing’s governing body, changed the qualifying standings — which initially had Alonso on the pole and Hamilton second. Officials also said that McLaren, which led the team standings by 27 points over Ferrari, would not earn any points from the race. Officials from FIA said that Alonso, the two-time defending champion from Spain, and his McLaren crew delayed Hamilton, a rookie driver from England, for 20 seconds after the completion of a tire change. In a statement, FIA said the delay was “considered prejudicial to the interests of the competition and to the interests of motor sport generally.”.

Three lawyers accused of bilking their clients in a diet drug settlement must repay at least $62.1 million in settlement funds and interest, a judge in Louisville, Ky., ruled Friday.Special Judge William Wehr ordered William J. Gallion, 56, Shirley A. Cunningham Jr., 52, and Melbourne Mills Jr., 76, to repay $42 million taken from the settlement and $20.1 million in interest. The lawyers are being sued by about 400 former clients who claim they took too much money as part of a $200 million fen-phen settlement. Gallion and Cunningham own a 20 percent stake in Curlin, who won the second leg of the Triple Crown in May.

An article on July 1 about comparisons of America to ancient Rome referred imprecisely to a statue of George Washington once housed in the United States Capitol. The sculptor, Horatio Greenough, modeled his work after a Classical statue of the Greek god Zeus. Although Greenough’s unpopular statue had been nicknamed “George Jupiter Washington” — after Zeus’s Roman counterpart — it was not “Washington in the guise of a Roman god.”.

A film entry in the Week Ahead report on July 22 about the Museum of Modern Art’s retrospective of films released through Rialto Pictures misidentified Rialto’s national sales director. He is Eric Di Bernardo — not Mike Thomas, who once held the job. The entry also misstated Adrienne Halpern’s position at Rialto. She is co-president, not co-director for marketing and acquisitions.

A film entry in the Week Ahead report on July 15 about screenings of the digitally restored version of the 1927 film Fritz Lang film “Metropolis” included incorrect information from the film’s distributor about the amount of material that was restored. The restored version contains more than 1,200 rescued shots, not 1,200 rescued scenes.

The two houses also voted to increase financing significantly for a health insurance program for poor children that expires Sept. 30, but must still agree on how much more to spend. POSNER--Daniel B., 89, a lifelong resident of New York City, died at Flushing Hospital August 2. He was born in Crown Heights, Brooklyn and raised his family in Flushing, Queens. He graduated from Columbia University in 1937 and earned his LL.B. from Yale Law School in 1941. After serving in WWII, he worked for the Securities and Exchange Commission. He later practiced law with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, where he was a senior partner. For many years, he contributed a yearly review of securities legislation to The Business Lawyer. Dan was often seen sailing on Little Neck Bay, in good weather and bad. His love for the water was matched by his love of classical music, especially the violin concertos of Beethoven, Bruch, and Sibelius. Most of all, he loved his family and he loved the truth. Funeral service at 11am Monday, August 6; Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY 11365.

HIRSCH--Warren M., Professor Emeritus of Mathematics at the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences of New York University, former resident of NYC, Weston, CT, and Lyme, NH, died July 9, 2007 in Sarasota, FL at 88. Born in NYC, he was a graduate of City College and New York University where he earned his Ph.D. in 1952. The Swiss University of Fribourg awarded him an honorary degree in 1989. Best known for his work in mathematical biology, particularly the transmission of parasitic diseases, his research spanned the fields of optimization, operations research, mathematical cannibaliza tion, probability, statistics, biostatistics, and mathematical epidemiology. The HirschDantzig algorithm that emerged from his work on the ''fixed charge'' problem is widely recognized in economics and business. The famous ''Hirsch conjecture'' he posed in 1957 has intrigued researchers since and remains an open problem in the general case. In the late 1960s, he began mathematically modeling the transmission dynamics of a parasitic worm that causes the devastating tropical disease schistosomiasis. With I. Nasell, he developed a semi-stochastic model that suggested strategies for control of the disease and which became a foundational concept in mathematical epidemiology. Later models with J.-P. Gabriel and H. Hanisch provided new methods for the study of functional differential equations with delay. His superb teaching style reflected his enthusiasm for his subject and his reverence for mathematics. ''His classes were packed with students bearing witness to his reputation as a wonderfully clear teacher who really cared about his students.'' Appointed professor of mathematics at NYU in 1953, on retirement in 1988, he joined the Biomathematical Sciences faculty at the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine where, for the next 11 years, he taught future research physicians in the M.D./Ph.D. program. As a US Army Air Force major in WWII he attended Statistical Officers School at Harvard, served as Assistant Chief of the combat analysis branch, Headquarters Office of Statistical Control and on the AAF Evaluation Board in Europe analyzing the effects of bombing German targets. He is survived by his wife Gail Glavin Hirsch, his son, Adam Hirsch, his daughter Lisa Eisner, his nephew, Roger, his cousins, Enid, Carol, Burton, and George and his beloved granddaughter, Caitlin. A graveside funeral service will take place at Arlington National Cemetery on Friday, September 7, at 2pm. A memorial luncheon for friends and family will follow the service.

QIf a landlord starts an eviction proceeding against a rent-stabilized tenant for nonpayment, but then during the proceeding the landlord sends the tenant a renewal lease and ultimately accepts the signed lease and an additional security deposit, what impact would that have on the eviction? A ''The offer of a renewal lease is a statutory obligation imposed upon the landlord,'' said Jeffrey L. Goldman, a Manhattan lawyer who frequently represents landlords. Mr. Goldman said that by law, a landlord must provide a stabilized tenant with the offer of a renewal lease 90 to 150 days before to the expiration of the current lease.

MUNSON--Celia Deming, died on August 1st, 2007 at home on Jupiter Island, FL. Born July 9th, 1916 in Grosse Pointe, MI, Celia Bigelow Deming was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul H. Deming. She attended The Spence School in NYC and The Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, NY. She was presented to Detroit society as the ''daisy deb'' at her Grosse Pointe home ''Cherryhurst'' in 1935. She was an active member of the Detroit Junior League, and travelled extensively with her parents throughout Europe and South America. In 1940 she married William Wright Harts Jr., and remarried in 1953 to C. S. (''Sherry'') Munson Jr., residing in Southport, CT and Jupiter Island. An ardent animal lover, one of her greatest pleasures was her dog, Penny. She is survived by her three daughters, Deanne H. Mallory of HoHoKus, NJ, Sharon H. Wick and Marjorie S. Munson, both of San Francisco, CA, in addition to four grandchildren and one great-grandson. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Munson Foundation, No. 1134, NY Community Trust, 909 Third Ave., New York, NY 10022.

MOORE--A. Preston, 87, June 22nd, 2007, in Atlanta. Born in Washington, D.C., August 7, 1919. Preston attended Dartmouth College 1943. He served as LT. Officer in the Pacific on USS Dale during WWII. After the war he received a Master Architectural Decree at Harvard Grad School, 1949. He married Clair Hague in 1951 in NYC. During his distinguished architecture career he worked with Geo Ponti in Italy and with I. M. Pei as associate partner until retirement. He was directly involved in major projects including: US Embassy in Uruguay, apartment buildings in NYC, Boston, Kuwait and Tehran. Other projects included the IBM Armonk Pavilion, Portland Museum, and the Fragrant Hills Hotel in Beijing. He received the Bard Award in 1968 Architectural Consulting for Paley Park, NYC. He lived most of his life in NYC. He enjoyed summers in Wellfleet, Cape Cod, where he was former president and commodore of the Chequessett Yacht and Country Club. He is survived by his son, Matteo Moore in Atlanta, GA, his daughter, Wendy Hale in Duxbury, MA and his twin brother J. Clark Moore in Cashiers, NC. A memorial service to celebrate his life is planned in Wellfleet on September 22.

Feldman's article addressed a phenomenon that used to trouble me. No longer. Once I realized that the kind of small-mindedness he describes is not endemic to Judaism per se but to all forms of religious fundamentalism, I felt better. Fundamentalist Jews have more in common with fundamentalist Christians and fundamentalist Muslims than with the vast majority of Jews, Christians and Muslims who are not fundamentalists. The problem is not a Jewish one. It is rather a problem of all religions, which in these difficult times have seen a growing minority of adherents substitute xenophobia for honest faith.
THEATER Steven McElroy

Feldman's experience at the class reunion of his modern Orthodox yeshiva might be unsettling to some but not that surprising to anyone familiar with Judaism's position on intermarriage. In fairness, he should have noted that conversion to Judaism is an option for couples when one is not Jewish. But is it the official policy of the modern Orthodox community to exclude intermarried couples from photographs? Of course not. In all likelihood, it represents a somewhat zealous approach, probably by a few members of the school's administration, who believe they are protecting the yeshiva's reputation. It would be encouraging if Feldman's former classmates and friends, many of whom remain modern Orthodox but might not endorse deleting him and his wife from the school's publications, protested the policy of shunning a graduate who wishes to remain somehow connected to his roots.

IN decades past, borrowers who were turned away from traditional mortgage lenders turned to the private lending market, where wealthy individuals or small companies offered mortgages with much higher interest rates. Now, because of the subprime crisis, banks are again turning away borrowers with poor credit, and industry executives expect these borrowers will again turn to so-called ''hard money'' lenders. This time, though, borrowers will have more legal protection against unscrupulous lenders. ''Lenders aren't as interested now in lending to some individuals because they're going to have a harder time repaying,'' said Hugh Bromma, the chief executive of the Entrust Group Inc., a financial advisory company in Reno, Nev., that helps clients lend money on the private market, among other things. ''Those people will have to go to private lenders, where the standards are significantly different.''

BY an awful and uncanny coincidence -- the kind of occurrence that, in a movie, would have to be taken as symbolic lest it seem altogether preposterous -- Michelangelo Antonioni and Ingmar Bergman died on the same day. Since Mr. Bergman was 89 and Mr. Antonioni 94, neither man's death came as much of a shock, but the simultaneity was startling. Not only because they were both great filmmakers, but more because, in their prime, Mr. Antonioni and Mr. Bergman were seen as the twin embodiments of the idea that a filmmaker could be, without qualification or compromise, a great artist.

A Dilemma on Values To the Editor:

Michael BESCHLOSS, who not long ago was named the official ''presidential historian'' of NBC News, became interested in American presidents at the age of 8, when his parents took him to visit the Abraham Lincoln house in Springfield, Ill. ''From that moment on,'' he wrote in an e-mail message, ''Lincoln was the man for me.'' Soon after, ''it dawned on me that one could write history books on presidents as a profession.'' Beschloss has gone on to write about Franklin Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Dwight Eisenhower, John Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson. His latest book, ''Presidential Courage,'' recently spent nine weeks on the best-seller list. Asked how George W. Bush fits his idea of presidential courage, Beschloss observed: ''Bush partisans will insist that the president was brave to go to war in Iraq because the outcome of his presidency would depend on whether or not America won. But presidential courage -- as I define it in the book -- is when a president risks his popularity for an important cause for which Americans of the future are grateful. At the moment, it's sadly hard to imagine that future Americans will feel that way about the Iraq war.'' The Editors

What Feldman fails to recognize is what Sholem Aleichem's simple Tevye the Milkman had figured out : ''Normalizing the observance of traditional Jewish law'' does not include actions that dilute the religion or bring about its demise. While Tevye could accept certain of his daughters' modern behaviors, including choosing their own spouses, it was one daughter's decision to intermarry that he would not accept, as it is a definitive step toward the extinction of the faith.

Perhaps even more remarkable than the not-so-subtle exclusion of Noah Feldman and his future wife from the published version of his 10th high-school reunion photo and the yeshiva's subsequent newsletters is Feldman's uncommon restraint and reasoned effort in trying to understand the school's obvious prejudice. Such intolerance, even when it comes from a once-loved source, must be exposed for what it is -- a primitive, automatic evaluation of his (and his family's) character and a denunciation of one of his most profound personal choices -- and not some inscrutable Talmudic argument that trumps human decency and civilized behavior.

HOMEOWNERS may be dimly aware that their mortgage is held by someone other than the bank that lent them the money. But who is that someone? Possibly an institution other than last week's owner. The faculty of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center and Weill Cornell Medical College express their deep sorrow on the death of their esteemed colleague, Dr. E. Thomas Steadman. Dr. Steadman, who did his residency training at this Hospital, was influential in developing the first nurse-midwifery program in a private medical facility in the U.S., as well as the first teenage pregnancy clinic in New York City. A dedicated clinician and teacher for more than 40 years, Dr. Steadman was an important role model for medical students and house officers. His presence will be sorely missed. Frank A. Chervenak, M.D. Given Foundation Professor and Chairman, Dept. of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Weill Cornell Medical College Obstetrician and Gynecologist-in-Chief at NewYork Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center STEADMAN--Evan Thomas M.D. Our heart felt condolences to Marcia and family on your loss. He was an unparalleled and dedicated friend to many. Barbara and Stephen Phillips

JACOBSON--Irma Beit, of Rye, New York and West Palm Beach, much beloved Emeritus Trustee of National Jewish Medical and Research Center, died July 12, 2007. A committed supporter of respiratory research for many decades, Irma rallied friends in New York and Florida to our mission. She established the Westchester, New York Women's Division for National Jewish, which held many fundraisers and social events. On behalf of the faculty, staff, Board of Directors and Council of National Trustees, we would like to extend our sincerest condolences to her family and friends on our collective loss of a truly great woman. Stephen Arent, Chair, Board of Directors Michael Salem, M.D., FACS, President and CEO

KOSINSKI--Katherina ''KiKi,'' February 6, 1933-May 24, 2007. Widow of author Jerzy Kosinski. Born in NYC as Katherina von Fraunhofer, a descendant of Bavarian aristocracy, she was raised in England. KiKi was a pioneering account executive with advertising agency, J. Walter Thomson in the 1960s. In 1968 she married Jerzy Kosinski, a Polish Holocaust survivor and author of best selling novels including ''The Painted Bird'' and ''Being There.'' He died in 1991. KiKi and Jerzy were inseparable and active in the international political arena. They were among the founders of the first Polish-American Bank in Poland of which KiKi was C.E.O. A good writer herself, KiKi was preparing a book entitled ''It Was My Life Too.'' Survived by sister Dita Brodin and brothers John Lowell von Fraunhofer and Joseph Anthony von Fraunhofer. Memorial service held in the fall.

Beyond serving as a forum for graduates to keep up with one another, a school alumni newsletter is a powerful marketing tool that showcases for potential students the accomplishments of the school's graduates. For Noah Feldman to expect his Jewish day school to report on news of his marrying outside the Jewish faith is, effectively, asking his school to publish the following promotional ad: ''Come spend 12 years steeped in Jewish religious texts and Jewish identity-building, and you, too, may become successful and intermarry.''

Once again, you're bound for Guest Hampton or Give-Me-Shelter Island, and once again, you're pondering what to take your weekend hosts. Hostess gifts should convey the giver's wit, good taste and gratitude -- without kicking down the doors of ostentation. Below are a clutch of clever indie-shop choices for the well-behaved guest, all $55 or less. Accessorize them with a loaf of bread, a jug of wine and thou-washing-dishes, and odds are you'll be invited back at Thanksgiving. UPMARKET The price of Anya Hindmarch's famously nonplastic canvas shopping bag may have skyrocketed on eBay, but these cheery chintz-print oilcloth totes from Orange Lola in Wakefield, R.I., will set you back only $16 to $32 (at orangelola.com).

(TNT) THE COMPANYChris O'Donnell, Alfred Molina and Michael Keaton (left) head up the cast of this three-installment mini-series, which follows spies from the C.I.A. and the K.G.B. during the cold war -- from the early 1950s to the Hungarian Revolution in 1956 to the Bay of Pigs fiasco in the 1960s to the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. Mikael Salomon (''Band of Brothers'') directed this six-hour production, which will be shown in two-hour installments on three consecutive Sundays. Tonight, the agencies play cat-and-mouse on the streets of East and West Berlin. 8 P.M. The prank ends with a surprise performance by the All-American Rejects.

HAHN--Ilse (nee Meyer), age 93. Most revered, cherished and beloved mother of Frances H. Stewart and mother-inlaw of Gene Stewart. Loved by her late husband and parents. A member of the Leo Beck Lodge and Temple Emanuel of North Jersey. Every person who knew her loved her for her warmth, kindness and thoughtfulness. She will be deeply missed. She was a supporter of Weill Cornell Medical College and NY Hospital. Donations can be made in her memory.

GOLDSTEIN--David A., of Boynton Beach, FL. Passed away July 31, 2007. BOXBAUM--Edwin. Beloved husband of Harriet for 60 years and cherished father of Laura (Foti), Allen (Michele). Treasured grandfather of Sonia (Rob), Alex, Harrison and Brandon. Beloved brother of Marilyn, uncle and devoted friend to all who knew him. Former Commodore of Woodmere Bay Yacht Club. Died after a brief illness, July 30th in Delray Beach, Florida.

CASCIO--Erminia, on August 4, 2007. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Loving mother of Kimberly and Danis. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing. Mass Tuesday Ozanam Hall 10:30 am, Bayside. Interment Mt. St. Mary's. Visiting Monday 35 pm and 7-9 pm.

JONES--The Rt. Rev. Edward Witker, on July 28. Born in Toledo, Ohio, he graduated from Western Reserve Academy (1947), Williams College (1951), and Virginia Theological Seminary. Bishop Jones served as associate rector of Grace Episcopal Church, Sandusky, and as chaplain and rector of Christ Church, Oberlin, Ohio, as assistant to the Bishop of Ohio and as rector of St. James Episcopal Church, Lancaster, Pennsylvania, before his election as Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of Indianapolis, where he served as diocesan bishop from 1977-1997. Bishop Jones is survived by his beloved wife, Anne (Shelburne), his children, Martha Patricof, Caroline Hubbell, and David Jones and their spouses, Mark, Peter, and Elise, and their children; by his brother, Samuel M., and by many nieces, nephews, and godchildren. Memorial services to be held in Indiana in September.

Feldman's article could have inspired discussion of the issue of intermarriage in the modern Orthodox Jewish world, but his presentation precludes such discourse. Like any expert litigator, he has selectively emphasized certain facts to misrepresent the truth. He speaks of Baruch Goldstein at length, ignoring that the overwhelming majority of Orthodox Jews condemned his massacre of Palestinians as morally repugnant. Even Feldman's portrayal of Joe Lieberman seems like a backhanded jab at modern Orthodoxy. After ostensibly glorifying Lieberman's ''overt normalcy,'' why compare his phylacteries to the cilice of Opus Dei? Why encourage people to wonder what kind of backward, medieval man lurks within the senator's suit?

To the Editor: Rachel Donadio's summary of the trans-Atlantic response to Salman Rushdie's ''Satanic Verses'' (''Fighting Words,'' July 15) caught my attention because I happened to be president of the Authors Guild when that book was published in America.

I am a Korean-American who converted to Judaism (mikvah included) when I married my Jewish husband. We are active members of our conservative synagogue, and our children go to Jewish day schools. During the 17 years since my conversion, I have been fully accepted into the Jewish community as a Jew, including the ultra-Orthodox community. Judaism dictates that descendants are the religion of the mother. I believe that this tenet is crucial to the survival of the Jewish religion in the ever-increasing numbers of interracial marriages.

Albany is convulsed with concern about whether aides to Gov. Eliot Spitzer have done anything bad while another larger scandal is unfolding that is causing almost no political hyperventilation. An article in some copies on Wednesday about Congressional efforts to pass legislation to expand the government’s electronic wiretapping powers misspelled — yet again — the surname of the attorney general of the United States, in three of four references. He is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez. (The Times has misspelled Mr. Gonzales’s name in at least 14 articles dating to 2001 when he became White House counsel. This year alone Mr. Gonzales’s name has been misspelled in February and March, and in two articles in April.).
A credit for pictures last Monday with an article about a reunion of the comedy troupe the Kids in the Hall misspelled the given name of the photographer. He is Yannick Grandmont, not Jannick.

Manchester United won the Community Shield yesterday, capturing the traditional season opener by beating Chelsea, 3-0, in a shootout. Goalie Edwin van der Sar saved all three penalty kicks he faced.

Lewis Hamilton won the Hungarian Grand Prix yesterday in Budapest for his third Formula One victory of the year, extending his lead in the standings in a race in which his McLaren team was hit with a penalty.Hamilton was followed by Kimi Raikkonen of Ferrari and Nick Heidfeld of BMW-Sauber. The defending series champion, Fernando Alonso, was fourth.Hamilton’s team was penalized after it was deemed to have hindered his qualifying efforts. With six races to go, Hamilton leads Alonso, 80-73, in the points standings.

Texas’ 2007 season got off to a rough start yesterday with two players being suspended for the first three games.The Longhorns reported to training camp in Austin, and Coach Mack Brown announced that linebacker Sergio Kindle and defensive end Henry Melton, each charged with driving while intoxicated this summer, would miss three games.
Still bothered by a sore left ankle, David Beckham missed his scheduled Major League Soccer debut.

The Indianapolis 500 winner Dario Franchitti walked away from a spectacular and frightening six-car crash yesterday during the Firestone Indy 400 at Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn, Mich. Tony Kanaan held off Marco Andretti in the final 27 laps for the victory. The race began four and a half hours late because of rain. Franchitti was trying to hold off Dan Wheldon on Lap 144 when the two touched wheels on the backstretch at about 218 miles an hour.Franchitti’s car turned sideways and flipped over Wheldon’s car high into the air, at one point with its nose pointing straight toward the ground. As Franchitti’s open-cockpit car came down, upside down, Scott Dixon, who was seeking his fourth straight victory and is chasing Franchitti in the points race, drove into and under Franchitti’s car, nearly being hit in the helmet.

An article in some copies on Wednesday about Congressional efforts to pass legislation to expand the government's electronic wiretapping powers misspelled -- yet again -- the surname of the attorney general of the United States, in three of four references. He is Alberto R. Gonzales, not Gonzalez. (The Times has misspelled Mr. Gonzales's name in at least 14 articles dating to 2001 when he became White House counsel. This year alone Mr. Gonzales's name has been misspelled in February and March, and in two articles in April.)

An article on the Street Scene page in Business Day on Friday, about the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore's entry into bankruptcy law practice, misspelled the name of another law firm that recently lost a bankruptcy specialist. It is Willkie Farr & Gallagher, not Wilkie. (The Times has misspelled the firm's name in at least 50 articles since 1958. The ''Willkie'' comes from Wendell L. Willkie, who joined the firm shortly after losing the 1940 presidential election to Franklin D. Roosevelt and remained there until his death in October 1944.)
