An obituary on July 21 of Shirley Slesinger Lasswell, who marketed memorabilia and toys based on A. A. Milne's children's books about Winnie the Pooh, misspelled the name of the department store that agreed to let her set up Pooh Corners for children. It is Neiman Marcus, not Nieman Marcus. (The Times has misspelled the company's name in at least 195 articles since 1930.)

Capital One Financial, a credit card issuer and banking company, said on Tuesday it agreed to buy NetSpend Holdings, a marketer of prepaid debit cards, for $700 million in cash. The transaction is not expected to have a material impact on Capital One's earnings per share until 2009.

Regarding our recent blog post on the Automotive X Prize, Gary (#63) wrote: "Although I am interested in all of the technology that may come out of this, I think the mile per gallon equivalents should be raised to 150."

The subprime mortgage market gave rise to trouble of a different sort on Tuesday, as MGIC Investment said that it believes it is not obligated to close its deal with the Radian Group. The nation's largest mortgage insurer said in February that it would acquire its rival for $4.9 billion.

Hillary Clinton, Neocon? The blogosphere is atwitter today with the quote in the Washington Post from Bill Kristol, the editor of the Weekly Standard, that "Hillary Clinton is becoming the responsible Democrat who could become commander in chief in a post-9/11 world."
The closely watched criminal trial of Gregory Reyes, the former chief executive of Brocade Communications ended in a conviction today. He was accused of backdating option grants.

It's one more sign that former Senator Fred Thompson is dipping in more than just his toe as he "tests the waters" for a presidential bid. By the look of the slickly revamped Web site his committee rolled out today, we'd say he's in -- at least knee-deep.

Brian Hunter, whose ill-fated energy trades helped to bring down Amaranth Advisors, has offered a dire warning about his latest hedge-fund venture. Citing scrutiny from regulators, he said in court filings that the firm, called Solengo Capital Advisors, could flame out before it even gets up and running.

Since eBay acquired the Internet phone service Skype in 2005 -- a $2.6 billion deal widely believed to have been way too expensive, at least judging from the results thus far -- it has refrained from making billion-dollar acquisitions.

According to Crain's New York Business, officials at the bank are considering an initial public offering of the New York-based unit, after having rebuffed several suitors. The publication said Julius Baer is being advised by Goldman Sachs.

Chicago is getting a second dose of Democratic politics today as the presidential candidates return to the city to participate in an A.F.L.-C.I.O. debate at Solider Field just three days after they appeared at the YearlyKos convention. Tonight's forum, which the Chicago Tribune previews, will be moderated by MSNBC's Keith Olbermann and broadcast on the network starting at 7 p.m. Eastern.

Update, 4:13 PM Eastern The Fed statement that has been released is not going to please Jim Cramer. "The Fed sees the current situation less urgently than many on Wall Street do," writes Jeremy Peters of The Times.
According to NPR's Weekend Edition, "the newest status symbol for the nation's most affluent families is fast becoming a big brood of kids."

Evercore Partners said Tuesday its adjusted pro forma net income nearly doubled from a year ago to $15.5 million in the second quarter. Advisory fees rose, as the investment bank picked up more revenue-generating clients and larger success fees, Evercore said.
The day-to-day financial dealings of Oneida Limited, the dinnerware and flatware maker, are typically about as far removed from the mortgage loan business as they can be.

Amazon.com has led a first-round venture investment in AmieStreet.com, an online music store with a social-networking twist. AmieStreet, which is less than a year old, sets the price for downloads according to a song's popularity and allows users to rack up credits by recommending songs to their friends. The size of the funding round was not disclosed.
The giant apartment landlord Archstone-Smith said Monday that the closing date of its purchase by a group led by Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers could be pushed back to the fourth quarter.
Bear Stearns, in an effort to protect itself from shareholder lawsuits related to the collapse of two of its hedge funds, may establish a precedent for other failed hedge funds.
Venture capital investment has reached its highest level since 2001, according to a report scheduled to be released Tuesday.
Wipro is acquiring a United States outsourcing company, Infocrossing, in a deal valued at $600 million, the latest in a slew of overseas buys by Indian companies.

Cie. de Saint-Gobain, Europe's biggest supplier of building materials, agreed to buy the Maxit unit of HeidelbergCement for 2.13 billion euros ($2.94 billion) to double its production of industrial mortars.

The Weinstein Company/strong> has taken the wraps off a $285 million fund to fully finance the development, production, acquisition, marketing and distribution of a large slate of Asian-themed films over the next six years.

"Blogging about private equity is so easy, even a congressman can do it," writes Dan Primack on PEHub. He is referring to New York Republican Tom Reynolds, whom he describes as an opponent of raising taxes on carried interest, which makes up the bulk of income of private equity managers.

Morgan Stanley on Monday shrugged off the turmoil in leveraged debt markets by appointing Peter Bacon to a new position as chairman of European financial sponsors, signaling a desire to expand its undersized private equity business.

The British cable operator Virgin Media postponed its $23 billion (11.3 billion) sale of the company on Tuesday after it became apparent buyers would not have access to the debt needed to do a deal right away.
The billionaire Paul Allen is selling the majority of his stake in DreamWorks Animation SKG and stepping down from the board of the animation company he helped bankroll in its infancy.

In the aftermath of three major takeovers in Canada's broadcasting sector, the nation's regulators appear poised to consider revamping the rules on media consolidation, using a system pioneered last year by the Australian government, The Globe and Mail reported.

ICx Technologies, which develops sensing technologies used in the homeland security market, is seeking to raise as much as $184 million in an initial public offering, according to a regulatory filing Monday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Topps said Monday that rival Upper Deck is free to begin a $425 million bid for Topps, setting up a potential showdown for the maker of baseball cards and Bazooka bubble gum.
Talks between the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Mercantile Exchange may be heating up.

When Robert L. Nardelli was sent packing from Home Depot in January with a $210 million exit package and a reputation as an imperious chief executive who had made strategic blunders, he seemed tarnished forever.

Xstrata, which won a bidding war last year for Canadian nickel company Falconbridge, said Tuesday that it intends to offer 7.53 billion rand ($1.06 billion) for Eland Platinum Holdings of South Africa.

The forest products company Temple-Inland, which is under pressure from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, said Monday that it would sell 1.55 million acres of timberland to the Campbell Group for $2.38 billion and then issue a $1.1 billion special dividend.

A quick follow up to yesterday's item about the rapid worldwide expansion of Sotheby's International Realty, the real estate company bearing the name of the famous auction house. A Wall Street Journal story notes that Sotheby's is losing some of its high end luxury luster as it expands in the United States.

The night was supposed to be about Barry Bonds, but John Lannan made sure there would be no celebration in San Francisco. John Who? Lannan, a 22-year-old left-hander who was making his third major league start for the Washington Nationals, silenced one of the best hitters of all time and made sure the home run record would be shared for at least another day.

Robert L. Nardelli, who was just named chief executive at Chrysler, faces enormous challenges. Chrysler is in the midst of its fourth turnaround effort in three decades and Japanese companies like Toyota and Honda are surging. In July, foreign auto companies surpassed their American counterparts in monthly sales for the first time.

Barry Bonds returned to San Francisco on Monday to try to hit his 756th homer and break Hank Aaron's career home run record. Bonds was ready, the San Francisco Giants were ready and the fans were ready. Even Willie Mays, Bonds's godfather, was here for the potentially historic moment.
James Wood, a senior editor at The New Republic, where he has been the literary critic for the past 12 years, is leaving to become a staff writer at The New Yorker.
Ellyn A. McColgan, Fidelity Investments’ president for distribution and operations, said she was stepping down to pursue opportunities outside of the company.

The Indian outsourcing company Wipro said that it was buying Infocrossing, an outsourcing company based in New Jersey, in a deal that values Infocrossing at about $600 million. Wipro will pay $18.70 a share for Infocrossing, which provides information technology services to midsize companies in the United States and had sales of $229 million last year. The price represents a premium of about 6 percent over the closing price Friday for Infocrossing. The company operates five data centers and employs about 900 people. Wipro is based in Bangalore.

Because of a production error, the Bridge column’s diagramed deal yesterday misplaced some cards. The ace, king, queen, seven and five of clubs were part of East’s hand, not West’s; and the two shown in East’s hand was one of the diamonds, along with the queen, jack, ten and nine.

A listing of American military deaths yesterday misidentified the country in which Sgt. Taurean T. Harris was killed. It was Afghanistan, not Iraq. An updated Names of the Dead appears on Page A3 today.
Dozens of people revisited the facts and emotions surrounding the Son of Sam killings that took place thirty years ago.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday created a panel to study how best to integrate immigrants in New Jersey. The 27-member panel will have 15 months from its first meeting to make recommendations on education, citizenship status, civil rights, housing, health care, language proficiency and job training. The state public advocate, Ronald K. Chen, will serve as chairman. According to federal census figures, one in five of the state’s 8.7 million residents were born in other countries. Federal officials estimate that the state has 221,000 illegal immigrants.
Two men were found with several pipe bombs in their car near a Navy base, the authorities said, and were charged with possession of an explosive device.
While much of the nation worries about a slumping real estate market, people in Midwestern farm country are experiencing exactly the opposite.
The Federal Reserve today largely sidestepped the growing anxiety over how tightening credit standards will affect the economy.
The two men accused of the brutal murders of a Connecticut family last month appeared in court today under unusually high security.
Some 15 people were hurt in the operation today by Israeli riot police to remove Jewish settlers from houses they had been illegally occupying in Hebron.
Viruses that escaped from two veterinary laboratories may have led to an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Britain, a government report said.
Human rights groups today accused China of failing to live up to promises to improve its record on civil liberties.
Climate change could destroy vast swaths of farmland in this country, a U.N. official warned today.
A Bangkok police chief has begun punishing wayward police officers by forcing them to wear a pink insignia.
Georgian officials said that Russia violated Georgia’s air space by firing a guided missile, which did not detonate.
The company today announced a second-quarter loss of $13.5 million as gambling revenue fell, for a loss of 43 cents a share.
Efforts to reach six trapped coal miners slowed today as rescue teams pulled back for safety reasons.
The request, a major policy reversal for Britain, is likely to be welcomed by the Bush administration, which has been working to reduce the number of detainees.
Barry Bonds went 0 for 3 with a walk against John Lannan of the Washington Nationals, staying tied with Hank Aaron at 755 homers.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (AP) — Indiana Pacers forward Jermaine O’Neal is not demanding a trade to the Los Angeles Lakers, but he is open to the idea.

A van from a summer camp in Sullivan County overturned on a highway in Maine yesterday, killing a 15-year-old boy and injuring 12 other people, authorities said. Two people were in critical condition. The van, from Camp Serene Springs in Bethel, N.Y., towing a trailer with canoes, was carrying 11 campers and two counselors for a trip to Maine so campers could canoe the Penobscot River and hike Mount Katahdin. The campers were all boys, 14 to 18. It overturned on Interstate 95 in Artgyle Township about 7 a.m., Stephen McCausland, a spokesman for the Maine Department of Public Safety, said. The victim was identidied by camp officials as Gedalya Rosenblatt. (AP).

Houston Rockets center Yao Ming yesterday married his longtime girlfriend, Ye Li, a 6-foot-2 player on the Chinese women’s basketball team. The wedding was in his hometown, Shanghai, sina.com reported.
Chicago Cubs outfielder Alfonso Soriano went on the 15-day disabled list yesterday, a day after straining his right quadriceps while running the bases against the Mets.
The state attorney general’s office said that the settlement was the first of a series that could bring in more than $30 million in the coming months.

Japan’s broadest indicator of the outlook for growth signaled for the first time in eight months that the economy would expand. The leading index climbed to 80 percent in June, the Cabinet Office said, the first time it has been at or over 50 since October. A reading of 50 or more indicates the economy may expand in three to six months. The index is derived from as many as 12 monthly indicators. “The economy will probably accelerate in coming months as a pickup in U.S. exports brings a positive impact on the economy over all,” said Takeshi Minami, chief economist at the Norinchukin Research Institute in Tokyo. “As foreign demand remains robust, we can expect sustainable growth.”.

Infineon Technologies, the European semiconductor maker, dismissed its chief financial officer, Rüdiger A. Günther, left, after three months on the job because of disagreements between him and the company. Mr. Günther, 49, will leave immediately and Peter Fischl, who was finance chief until retiring in May, will take the post temporarily, according to the company. Mr. Günther declined to comment on the conflict, as did Guenter Gaugler, a spokesman for Infineon.

Wal-Mart Stores and the Bharti Group of India have agreed to set up wholesale stores and a supply chain in India, eight months after they signed an initial agreement. Their venture will open its first wholesale store by the end of 2008, according to Rajan Mittal, the joint managing director of Bharti Enterprises, who spoke at a news conference in New Delhi. Wal-Mart signed a tentative agreement to start a wholesaling business with the Bharti Group in November. The venture, a 50-50 partnership known as Bharti Wal-Mart Private, is planning to open 10 to 15 wholesale stores over the next seven years to sell to small retailers, hotels and restaurants. The proposed Bharti venture would supply the retail market with goods that come directly from producers like farmers, craftsmen and artisans, Mr. Mittal said.

Nobiz Like Shobiz won his turf debut by half a length over Marcavelly in the $150,000 National Museum of Racing Hall of Fame Stakes at Saratoga Race Course in New York. Running just behind Sahara Heat’s pace for most of the one-and-an-eighth-mile race, jockey Cornelio Velazquez launched a bid at the head of the stretch to take the Grade II race for 3-year-olds. Nobiz Like Shobiz was coming off a second-place effort in the Dwyer on July 4 at Belmont Park.

Indiana Pacers forward Jermaine O’Neal has not demanded a trade to the Los Angeles Lakers, but he remains open to the idea. While O’Neal has been the subject of trade talk since the Pacers missed the playoffs for the first time in 10 years, the discussion was stirred up yesterday when SI.com quoted O’Neal as saying he would “welcome a trade to the Lakers” and mentioned the Nets as another option.O’Neal, a six-time All-Star, played down the trade talk in a later interview.“I don’t think me saying I’d like to go with those teams is me saying I want to be traded,” he said.O’Neal, who averaged 19.4 points and 9.6 rebounds last season, said he recognized that the Pacers were rebuilding with young players and that he might not be part of their plans, but that he was happy to stay.

Amélie Mauresmo withdrew from the Pilot Pen and Rogers Cup tournaments yesterday, citing a need to fully recover from her appendectomy in March. “I rushed back too quickly because there was a lot at stake for me, especially on grass,” said Mauresmo, ranked No. 6. “Unfortunately, my body did not cooperate.”Francesca Schiavone, ranked 26th, will replace Mauresmo at the Pilot Pen event, which runs from Aug. 17-25 at Yale. The Rogers Cup is next week in Toronto.
pro basketball.

General Motors said it has decided not to renew its $1 billion sponsorship of the United States Olympic Committee when its contract ends after 2008. The company said the move was a result of changes in its marketing strategy and came after G.M. evaluated the return on its advertising investment. Chevrolet is still a sponsor of the United States Snowboarding Team, and G.M. of Canada is sponsoring the 2010 Winter Games in Vancouver, British Columbia.

The N.C.A.A. has asked Ball State officials to investigate new accusations of rules violations involving the men’s team, including an allegation that the women’s volleyball coach was fired for reporting suspected infractions. The allegations were outlined in a letter from the N.C.A.A. dated two days before Coach Ronny Thompson’s resignation July 13 after one season.
An article on Thursday about the Minneapolis bridge collapse rendered incorrectly the hometown of one victim. It is Mounds View, Minn., not Moundsview.

An article in Business Day on Friday about eye infections linked to the lens cleaner Complete MoisturePlus, produced by Advanced Medical Optics, misstated the manner in which the Centers for Disease Control learned that four contact lens users developed infections after the product was recalled on May 26, 2007. Those infections were reported individually to the C.D.C., not discovered as part of a survey that showed many contact lens users were unaware of the recall.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Kentucky governor’s race misstated the timing of Gov. Ernie Fletcher’s pardon of current and former aides who have been, or could be, charged in an inquiry into a hiring scandal. Mr. Fletcher pardoned them before, not after, his own indictment in the case.

A report in the World Briefing column on Friday about arrest warrants issued in Mexico for police commanders who worked for Jorge Hank Rhon, who is running for governor of Baja California, misidentified the government entity that issued the warrants. It is the State of Baja California, not Mexico’s federal government.

Because of an editing error, the “Most Popular” listing in the Most Wanted chart in Business Day yesterday, listing top sellers among re-released music CDs, misspelled the name of a singing duo. It is Simon and Garfunkel, not Simon and Garfunkle.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the coming release of boxed DVD sets of Playboy and Rolling Stone magazines, referred imprecisely to a Web site that will sell the DVDs. Although the site, covertocover.com, will take preorders, it will not do so until Sept. 1; it is not yet online.
Corrections

A 6-year-old girl was hit by a light-rail train in Hoboken yesterday, the authorities said. The girl, who was not identified by the authorities, was struck by a northbound Hudson-Bergen Light Rail train about 10:45 a.m., said Dan Stessel, a spokesman for New Jersey Transit, which operates the line. The girl and her mother had been trying to cross the street; the mother stopped at a crosswalk but the girl did not, Mr. Stessel said. He said the crosswalk’s lights and bells were operating at the time. The girl, who was critically injured, was taken to Jersey City Medical Center and later transferred to University Hospital in Newark.

A federal judge yesterday rejected a bid by Philip A. Giordano, the former mayor of Waterbury, for a reduced sentence, saying he deserved 37 years in prison for abusing two girls while he was mayor. Mr. Giordano, 44, was convicted in 2003 of violating the girls’ civil rights by paying a prostitute to bring her daughter and niece to him for sexual encounters in 2000 and 2001, when they were 8 and 10 years old. Mr. Giordano sought a reduction after federal sentencing guidelines were made advisory rather than mandatory. Yesterday, Judge Alan H. Nevas of Federal District Court ruled that the sentence was just.

Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed legislation yesterday abolishing the troubled State Schools Construction Corporation and replaced it with a new agency, the New Jersey Schools Development Authority. The Schools Construction Corporation, created five years ago to build schools in the state’s most troubled cities, was marred by waste, according to a 2005 report by the state inspector general. Governor Corzine said structural changes would allow the new agency to operate with greater efficiency and accountability. Many school projects were delayed because state lawmakers refused to finance the school building program until changes were made in its administration.

A malfunction in overhead power lines caused a 58-minute power failure yesterday afternoon that affected 968 residential and business customers in Flushing, a Consolidated Edison spokesman said. The spokesman, Chris Olert, said power went out at 1:32 p.m. and was restored at 2:30 p.m. Councilman John C. Liu, above, who represents the area, said about 5,000 people were affected. Mr. Liu said it was at least the fourth blackout in Flushing in the past nine weeks. “The frequency of these blackouts, albeit troubling, is not surprising,” he said in a statement.
An undercover Broward County sheriff’s deputy was shot in the head by a motorcyclist he had pulled over.
The government approved a new drug to help patients with AIDS, while acknowledging lingering questions about it long-term effects.

A 5-year-old boy was killed on Sunday night when he was struck in his driveway by his family’s minivan, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. His mother, Christine Schilling, told the police that after she moved her 1995 Chrysler minivan about 8:30 p.m., she discovered her son, Jacob Quinn, lying beneath a tire. The minivan was impounded for a safety check but no charges were filed, the police said.
Airline delays in the United States are at their highest level in at least 13 years.

Milberg Weiss, once the biggest United States investor class-action law firm, and a former partner, Steven Schulman, must go to trial to defend against charges that they illegally paid plaintiffs in securities lawsuits.
A medical plane carrying a young patient and her mother to a hospital crashed, killing all five on board, the authorities said.
Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, has taken down a video from a YouTube Web site, acknowledging that it should not have been posted.

The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to strip Councilman Dennis P. Gallagher of his leadership and committee posts after he was indicted last week on charges of rape and assault. The Queens councilman, a Republican, had volunteered to give up his positions as minority whip and on several committees at the suggestion of Speaker Christine C. Quinn, she said. “We are deeply, deeply troubled by the allegations and the charges that are pending against council member Gallagher,” Ms. Quinn said at a City Hall news conference. “That’s why we believe removing him from his leadership position and committees is an appropriate action.” The Council declined to take further steps, citing a request from Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney, to defer any investigation or proceedings until the criminal case is resolved.
The National Music Publishers’ Association said it would join a copyright infringement lawsuit against Google’s video-sharing site YouTube.

By counting prison inmates as residents when drawing districts, some New York counties dilute the political power of those who don’t live near prisons, a new study finds.

The giant apartment landlord Archstone-Smith said yesterday that the closing date of its purchase by a group led by Tishman Speyer and Lehman Brothers Holdings could be pushed back to the fourth quarter.
Mayor Michael Bloomberg was not chosen to sit on the jury for a civil suit involving a dead man in an asbestos case, but could be picked for a different trial on Tuesday.
The growing link between Argentina and Venezuela is making the largest group of Jews in Latin America increasingly nervous and could prove a thorny issue in October elections.

Even as the plunge continues in investments tied to dicey mortgages, government regulators remain skeptical of the need for new rules to cover these newfangled derivative products or the hedge funds that tend to buy them.

City officials have taken back control of Pier A in Battery Park from a private developer as part of a plan to pull together the city’s waterfront recreation areas.

A Moscow court sentenced Aleksei Pichugin, the former security chief of Yukos Oil, to life in prison as it upheld his conviction for involvement in at least three murders and four attempted murders.

Sallie Mae, the big student lender, said yesterday that its $25 billion deal to be acquired by a group of private equity firms and banks should be consummated in October.

LAW ON STRANDED PASSENGERS Airlines operating in New York would be required to provide fresh air, toilet-waste removal, drinking water and snacks to passengers on an airplane that has left the gate and remains parked on an airport apron under a new state law signed by Gov. Eliot Spitzer last week. The legislation, originally drafted by a state assemblyman from Queens, Michael N. Gianaris, would take effect Jan. 1, although the airline industry has said it is considering a legal challenge. The Airline Passengers Bill of Rights came in response to instances of passengers being stranded for hours on parked planes, with inadequate ventilation and food and deteriorating hygienic conditions. On Feb. 14, for example, thousands of JetBlue passengers sat on parked planes during a snow and ice storm for as long as 10 hours at Kennedy International Airport.
A Jewish émigré from Nazi-occupied Vienna, Raul Hilberg helped begin the field of Holocaust studies with his long, detailed 1961 study of the massacre of European Jews.

What issues do the voters expect to be most significant when they make their choice for president next year? It depends, at least in part, on their party identification. A New York Times/CBS News poll conducted last month asked the public which of seven issues would be most important in their decision. Among voters who expect to vote in a Democratic primary or caucus next year, the top three issues were the war in Iraq, health care and the economy and jobs. Those who plan to vote in a Republican primary or caucus have different priorities -- terrorism and national security was paramount, followed by immigration and Iraq.

WEISBERG--Moritz, on Friday August 3, of Coconut Creek, Florida. Dear husband of Shirley, deeply loved father of his only child, daughter Randy Genet and her husband, Jerry. Stepfather to sons Alan (Gail) Weinberg and Zev Weinberg and grandfather of Maxie and Freddie Weinberg. Predeceased by his late wife Shaynee Weisberg. Moritz was an esteemed expert in the garment industry over a 34 year career in New York before retiring in 1984. He traveled extensively sharing his knowledge of patternample making design and production. His skills provided a resource of heroic proportions as Production Manager for David Crystal, Inc and a subsidiary at the time -Chemise LaCoste. A survivor of five years in concentration camps including Auschwitz and Mauthausen, etc., he has participated in a film interview documenting his life for the Shoah Foundation. Several of the poems and short stories penned by Moritz are archived in Israel at Yad Vashem and in Washington, D.C. at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum. The writings are also included in the curricula of several colleges and universities throughout the U.S. His philosophy along with the literature he has written is powerful testimony to a very strong life force and the desire for Liberty! Services at Temple Emanu - El Fifth Avenue at 65th Street on Wednesday, August 8th at 12 noon.

COOPER--Beatrice. A loving wife, mother and grandmother died peacefully in her sleep August 6th, 2007. In June, she celebrated her 85th birthday. She will be remembered for her humor, wit, generosity and devotion to her family and friends. She is survived by her adoring husband of 62 years, Herman. A remarkable couple, they spent many wonderful years dividing their time between North Shore Towers, NY and Palmas del Mar, Puerto Rico. She will be remembered by her loving daughter Michele, son Brian, and son-in-law Dr. Kenneth Glassberg. She is also survived by five beautiful grandchildren, Chloe, Lola, Lauren, Larry, Andrew, and his fiance Mia. She was also a kind, loving sibling to her brother Albert and sister Diana (both deceased). BeaBea, as she was affectionately known, always had a joke to tell, often a risque one. She knew how to make people laugh, whether at the dinner table or while playing bingo with her newer friends at Waterford Towers in Edgewater, NJ. During the 1960s she was president of the Young Women's League of Cerebral Palsy In New York. During the 1980s and 1990s she was an avid golfer. BeaBea shared her heart and joy, and all who knew her are grateful for those gifts. Contributions may be made in her name to Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital of New York-Presbyterian, c Emily Taub, Office of Development, 654 West 170th Street, New York, NY 10032. Services will be held today, August 7th at 12:45pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY. Shiva will be observed at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth Glassberg through next Tuesday.

Have some of Senator Barack Obama's supporters figured out how to give more than the $2,300 legal maximum to back their candidate? In a report filed last week to the Federal Election Commission, Vote Hope, a political action committee formed by supporters independent of the Obama campaign, identified its first 27 donors. Thirteen of them, mostly wealthy Californians, had also given the maximum allowed, $2,300, to Mr. Obama for the Democratic primary, and three others had given lesser amounts.

SADIK - KHAN--Orhan, 78 years old, of Old Greenwich, CT died August 1, 2007 at Greenwich Hospital after years of bravely battling cancer and Parkinson's Disease. He is survived by his devoted family: Karen, his wife of 38 years, and their children, Karim (Lauren Dardick), Kadria and Altan; and from his first marriage Janette (Mark Geistfeld) and son Max; John (Cathy Ruckelshaus) and children Billy, Tommy, Eleanor. Orhan was born July 2, 1929 in Terihoki, Finland, son of Alimjan Idris, an Imam and Shemsulbenat Ashrat, a pediatrician. His brother, Ildar, and sister, Gulnar, predeceased him. He grew up in Berlin and on Feb. 13, l945, the family home in Dresden was destroyed by the infamous air raid. The family lived the remaining war years in Mittenwald then moved to Cairo where he graduated with a B.A. with Distinction in Economics from AUC. His mother's diamond ring paid for his passage to the U.S. where he received his MBA with Honors at Stanford University. Orhan's career began at Dean Witter in SF then he was head of research at F. Eberstadt and N.Y. Securities. l965-67 he was VP for the Business Equip. Group of Litton Industries; l969-81 served as Sr. VP at Norton Simon, Inc. Between l982 -84, he served as the first president of Millicom. He was a founding shareholder of Nextel. While a Managing Director of Paine Webber from l986-2000, he founded the Russian Partner's Company Fund and most recently he ran his own consulting firm, ADI. He was on the board of Firecom and Access Worldwide; had previously been a director of Near East Foundation and trustee of AUC. He was a member of Economics Club, Rocky Point and Innis Arden Golf Clubs, Old Greenwich. Karen and family thank GEMS, Dr. Michael Marino, ER & ICU staff of Greenwich Hospital for their compassionate care of Orhan. Contributions to Dr. Andrew Zelentetz for lymphoma research at MSKCC and Dr. Michael Marino, Pulmonary Service Fund, Greenwich Hospital. Services and burial are private.

CONNOR--Leo E. A well known educator of deaf children and Emeritus of the Lexington Center for the Hearing Impaired of New York City, died of cancer on August 2, 2007 at his home in Boca Raton, FL. He was 85. Dr. Connor headed the multi-purpose agency of the Lexington Center from 1968 to 1986. At his retirement the agency served 15,000 hearing impaired personas a year. Leo was Adjunct Professor of Education at Teacher's College, Columbia University from 1970-1986, conducting advanced seminars and supervising administrative interns and doctoral students. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania where he attended parochial schools. He graduated with a bachelor's degree from La Salle University in Philadelphia, earned a master's degree at the University of Pittsburgh and a doctorate in Educational Administration at Teacher's College, Columbia University. His teaching career began in the secondary schools in Pittsburgh, continued in Philadelphia and in 1951 advanced to the principalship of elementary schools in Rockland County, New York. In 1954, he became the Director of Elementary Education of the Clarkstown Central School District in New City, NY. In 1957, he became Educational Director of the Lexington School for the Deaf, subsequently was promoted to Assistant and Associate Superintendent and in 1958 he assumed the title of Executive Director of the school. His expansion into lifetime services for the hearing impaired began with the establishment of the Lexington Foundation in 1978, the Lexington Mental and Spiritual Health Center, in 1980, the Lexington Center for Mental Health in 1983, and overall parent corporation, The Lexington Center for Services for the Hearing and Speech Impaired in 1985. Dr. Connor retired in 1988. He wrote and had published numerous articles and professional books. His retirement activities included Chairman of the Zoning Board of Adjustment of Spring Lake, NJ (1986-1993) and Chairman of the Administration Committee of the Parish Council of Saint Catherine/Saint Margaret's churches in Spring Lake (1992-1996). He is survived by wife, Frances Partridge, whom he married in 1952, four sisters, Ellen Willard of Longwood, FL, Catherine Gilfillen of Alexandria, VA, Mary Brandt of Warrington, PA, and Margaret Peake of Berlin, MD and many relatives and friends who will cherish his memory always. Babione Funeral Home is in charge of services. 561-395-8787

SELIGMAN--Benjamin D. July 10, 1904 to August 3, 2007. After 103 happy and fulfilled years, Benjamin David Seligman passed away peacefully. Beloved by his wife Florence, his daughters Stephanie and Nicole, their spouses Robert and Joel, and the grandchildren of his twilight years, Chloe and Adam. Born in Keyport, NJ, the son of Nathan and Sophie Seligman, he was a graduate of Columbia Law School and with his late brother Edward founded the law firm Seligman & Seligman. He loved the law and practiced until past his 100th birthday. His wisdom, guidance, strength and devotion to family will be deeply missed by all of us. In deference to his wishes, funeral services will be private. SELIGMAN--Benjamin. We mourn the passing of Benjamin Seligman, our beloved brother-in-law and uncle. His devotion to his precious family, his brilliant mind, his dedication to Israel and his more than 75 years as a renowned attorney defined him as a man of the highest stature. We cherish our many happy memories and extend our love and deepest condolences to his wife, Florence, and his family. Ruth Rosenberg and family

“Daddy Day Camp” is a recruiting poster for kids, insisting that there’s no domestic problem that military values can’t solve.
Blanc de blancs Champagne, made only of chardonnay, are the lightest and most refreshing Champagnes of all, and just right for an August afternoon as for a midnight in December.
Open now: Flatiron Joes and Eighth Street Wine Cellar;  Caminito restaurant opens this week; John Fraser leaves Compass and Michael Bao Huynh to open a new spot.
Lesley Chamberlain brings some forgotten intellectuals back to life and argues that their banishment was a turning point in the road from revolution to Communist tyranny.
Culminating a smooth countdown, the space shuttle Endeavour lifted off into the humid skies this evening, carrying pieces of the International Space Station.
A decade and a half after a videotaped cocaine arrest that would have ended most political careers, former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has won yet another election.
The bidding war over Barneys New York, the luxury clothing retailer, escalated when a private equity firm from Dubai raised its offer to $942 million — $117 million more than it had originally bid.

The A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s executive council voted today against endorsing any presidential candidate, reflecting divisions over which Democrat to support and setting the stage for its 55 member unions to make individual endorsements.
The discovery raises the possibility that the bridge was structurally deficient from the day it opened.
The strike, the second mysterious raid with sophisticated, Russian-made weapons on Georgian soil this year, inflamed tensions anew between the two countries.
Rescue teams have drilled about one-third of the way down to where six coal miners have been trapped underground since early Monday, a mine official said.
President Bush described the economy as “thriving” and said lower taxes were the best way to guarantee prosperity.
U.S. officials described it as the latest assault on a network linking Iraqi militants with money and bombs from Iran.
The nation’s high school seniors received better scores than were expected on the first nationwide economics test.
Most of the New York City subway system was back in service this evening after a storm that included a rare and destructive tornado in southwestern Brooklyn.
Barry Bonds’s home run pushed him past Hank Aaron and pushed baseball’s sacred history into an awkward spot.
When Barry Bonds hit his record-breaking 756th home run, his former trainer, and a key figure in the steroids investigation about Bonds’s suspected steroid use, was in a prison cell 40 miles away.

Quarterback Brady Quinn signed a five-year contract with the Cleveland Browns, ending an 11-day holdout that essentially eliminated his chances to begin the season as the team’s starter. He missed 16 practices during his holdout.The deal, worth $20.2 million, with $7.75 million guaranteed, could reach $30 million over five years with incentives.

A New Jersey corrections officer fatally shot a man last night on a street after the man pulled a gun on him, the Newark police said. The corrections officer, whose name was not released, was shot in the foot during the confrontation and was in stable condition at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey Hospital. The officer was sitting on a porch on Grand Avenue about 9:30 p.m. when he was approached by the man, whom the police did not identify. The man then brandished a gun, the police said, and the officer fired. The state attorney general’s office is investigating, the police said.

NBC Universal Sports will stream 2,200 hours of live Summer Games coverage free from Beijing next year on its Web site, nbcolympics.com. It is the first time that NBC, or any network, has carried the Olympics on the Internet. . The broadband coverage will augment another 1,400 on NBC, USA, MSNBC, CNBC and Telemundo.

Billy Taylor, who led Lehigh’s men’s basketball team to the N.C.A.A. tournament in 2004, was hired by Ball State yesterday. He replaces Ronny Thompson, who resigned last month amid accusations that he broke N.C.A.A. rules and his claims that he faced a hostile racial environment. Ball State was 9-22 in Thompson’s only season as head coach and faces questions from the N.C.A.A., including an allegation that university officials fired the women’s volleyball coach for reporting suspected infractions by Thompson and his staff.
Loree Moore and Janel McCarville each scored 17 points Tuesday night to help the Liberty snap a four-game road losing streak with a victory over the Houston Comets.
After six shutout innings, Roger Clemens buried a fastball into Alex Rios’s back in the seventh, a delayed reaction to Alex Rodriguez being plunked with a pitch in the third inning.
If successful, the deal would help Lenovo quickly capture market share in a region where it is ranked sixth and is barely profitable.
Commissioner Bud Selig was not at AT&T Park on Tuesday night to witness Barry Bonds’s attempt to hit his record-breaking 756th home run.
Mets starter Oliver Pérez was rattled as the Braves raced to an early lead, scoring one run in the first inning, two in the second and three in the third.
LOTTERY NUMBERS.

An article in The Arts on Saturday about “In the Shadow of Justice,” a documentary on “Dateline NBC” about the murder of a bouncer at a Manhattan nightclub, included incorrect information from the maker of the film, Dan Slepian, about its editing. While Mr. Slepian shot and assembled most of the film, it was edited by Rob Allen, not by Mr. Slepian.

An article by The Associated Press on Thursday about flight recorder transcripts released after a fatal plane crash in São Paulo Brazil on July 17 reversed the identities of the pilot and the co-pilot, and their final comments. The pilot was Kleyber Lima, and he gave the first indication something was wrong when he said, “Only one reverser — spoiler nothing.” It was the co-pilot, Henrique Stephanini Di Sacco, who responded: “Look at that. Slow down. Slow down.” Then Mr. Lima responded: “I can’t. I can’t. Oh my God! Oh my God!” Then Mr. Di Sacco said: “Go! Go! Turn! Turn! Turn!”.

The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Tom Glavine’s milestone victory as the Mets beat the Cubs, referred incorrectly in some copies to the accomplishment. It was his 300th career victory, not his 500th.
A music review on Monday about a Beethoven program at the Mostly Mozart Festival misidentified the key of the Mass in which movements were played. It was C major, not C minor.

A report in the What’s Online column in Business Day on Saturday, about an Inc.com feature on young entrepreneurs, misspelled the surname of the owner of bestparking.com, which tracks parking garage rates in several cities. He is Benjamin Sann, not Samm.

An article by The Associated Press on Thursday about flight recorder transcripts released after a fatal plane crash in São Paulo Brazil on July 17 reversed the identities of the pilot and the co-pilot, and their final comments. The pilot was Kleyber Lima, and he gave the first indication something was wrong when he said, “Only one reverser — spoiler nothing.” It was the co-pilot, Henrique Stephanini Di Sacco, who responded: “Look at that. Slow down. Slow down.” Then Mr. Lima responded: “I can’t. I can’t. Oh my God! Oh my God!” Then Mr. Di Sacco said: “Go! Go! Turn! Turn! Turn!”.

A brief article in Science Times yesterday about the possibility that a person’s reading level might protect against neurological damage from lead exposure misspelled the given name of an author of the study. She is Dr. Margit L. Bleecker, not Margrit.

The Cheering Section article in sports on July 29, about the excitement among N.B.A. newcomers over posing for rookie trading-card photographs, referred incorrectly to Brandan Wright of the Golden State Warriors. He was chosen No. 8 in the draft by the Charlotte Bobcats and then traded to the Warriors; he was not drafted by the Warriors.

A picture caption with an article yesterday about a debate at some colleges over the installation of footbaths that Muslim students can use in ritual ablutions before prayers referred incorrectly to footbaths at the University of Michigan-Dearborn. The university is planning to install them, but has not yet done so.

Standard Chartered, a British bank operating mostly in Asia, beat expectations with a 30 percent increase in half-year profit and said it would consider more acquisitions to accelerate growth, including in South Africa. “South Africa is a country where we’d like to grow our business because we see it fitting well with the rest of our Africa franchise,” the chief executive, Peter A. Sands, left, said on a conference call. Standard Chartered, which makes three-quarters of its profit in Asia, said pretax profit in the six months through June was $1.98 billion, up from $1.53 billion a year earlier.

The Italian automaker Fiat announced a joint venture with Chery Automobile of China to produce Alfa Romeo and Fiat cars for the Chinese market. The deal came a day after Fiat said it would buy engines from Chery to expand its ties in China, which is viewed as a lucrative, fast-growing market as well as a low-cost base for production. Fiat, based in Turin, and Chery, based in Wuhu, intend to produce 175,000 Fiat and Alfa Romeo autos beginning in 2009. In the earlier deal, Chery will supply 100,000 engines a year for use in cars manufactured by Fiat in China and abroad. No financial terms were given.
The U.S. resumed its trade dispute over Canadian softwood lumber, just 13 months after signing an agreement intended to settle the decades-old issue.

Japan’s core private-sector machinery orders fell more than expected in June, signaling a slowdown in corporate capital spending ahead, but did little to alter market players’ views that the Bank of Japan would raise rates this month. Core orders, which exclude those for ships and machinery at electric power firms, fell 10.4 percent from May, their biggest monthly decline in nearly a year, government data showed. The consensus market forecast had been for a much more modest decline of 1.9 percent.

The drug maker Bayer said its second-quarter profit rose 46 percent, driven by a one-time gain on the sale of its Wolff Walsrode building materials unit. The company earned 660 million euros ($912 million) in the April-June period, compared with 452 million euros a year earlier. The result still fell short of the 687 million euros ($949.3 million) that analysts had expected, and Bayer’s stock fell nearly 2 percent. Bayer said it booked a one-time gain of 231 million euros ($319.2 million) from the sale of the Wolff Walsrode group for 540 million euros ($746.2 million) in July. Overall sales rose 22 percent, to 8.22 billion euros ($11.36 billion), from 6.74 billion euros a year earlier.
President Umaru Yar’Adua has suspended a multimillion-dollar plan to build 774 health clinics on the grounds that the contract was illegal.

The Supreme Court upheld the Moscow City Court’s ban of the National Bolshevik Party as an extremist organization. The small fringe party has gained notoriety for its vocal and theatrical antigovernment demonstrations. The group’s leader, the writer Eduard Limonov, said in a telephone interview that he did not expect the latest ruling to affect its activities, including participation in the Other Russia coalition, a loose movement of anti-Kremlin forces that includes the former chess champion Garry Kasparov. “They will not shut us up,” Mr. Limonov said. “We have no fear.” He said the party would appeal the ruling to the European Court of Human Rights.

Parliament’s upper house installed Satsuki Eda, left, a member of the main opposition Democratic Party, as its president, the first time an opposition lawmaker has held the post. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s Liberal Democratic Party suffered a crushing defeat in last month’s elections for the chamber, and the Democratic Party advanced to dominate it for the first time. While Mr. Abe’s coalition still controls the more powerful lower house, the upper chamber is expected to make it difficult for him to pass legislation, including a bill for the continuation of Japan’s logistical support of United States-led forces in Afghanistan.
Juan Carlos Ramirez-Abadia could be extradited to face United States charges that he smuggled billions of dollars worth of cocaine into the U.S.

Scientists have discovered a 780-year-old Scots pine, the oldest living forest pine known in Finland, the Finnish Forest Research Institute said. The tree was found last year in Lapland during a study mission on forest fires, the institute said, and scientists analyzed a section of the trunk to determine its age. “The pine is living, but it is not in the best shape,” said Tuomo Wallenius, a researcher. “It’s quite difficult to say how long it will survive.” The tree is inside the strip of land on the eastern border with Russia where access is strictly prohibited.

The authorities shut down Shargh, a leading reformist newspaper, after it published an interview with an Iranian poet who lives in exile and writes about female sexuality, Saghi Ghahraman. It was the third time the paper has been ordered closed, and it was unclear when it might be allowed to resume publishing. The closing was another sign of the increasing pressures on press freedom. In May, the authorities shut down the reformist newspaper Hammihan, and last week, a journalist and blogger, Soheil Assefi, was arrested.

A St. Petersburg court sentenced four young men to prison terms of up to 12 years for their roles in a stabbing attack in the city in 2005 that killed Timur Kacharava, left, a 20-year-old student who belonged to an antifascist group that campaigned against hate crimes. Three young men received suspended sentences. The harsh sentences are a victory for prosecutors and rights groups who complain that Russian courts have underplayed the extent of neo-fascist violence in the country by handing down light punishments for hate crimes.
Having already served suspensions totaling 14 games, Wally Backman resigned Tuesday as manager of the South Georgia Peanuts after leading them to the first-half title.
Senator Tim Johnson, Democrat of South Dakota, is returning to his home state for the first time since suffering a life-threatening brain hemorrhage eight months ago.
The space shuttle Endeavour and its seven-astronaut crew are scheduled to lift off on Wednesday night and head to the International Space Station.
After failing to meet its recruiting goal for two consecutive months, the Army is expected to announce that it met its target for July.
The number of United States beaches declared unsafe for swimming reached a record last year, the Natural Resources Defense Council reported.
A Utah polygamist was released from prison after serving six years on a child rape conviction for having sex with a 13-year-old girl who is now his only legal wife.
Eastern Michigan University said it would establish a warning system in its response to a report that found it had covered up the rape and killing of a student.

Over a three-day period in June, four New York traffic agents gave the impression they were busy by issuing a multitude of tickets. But as it turns out, they issued dozens of those tickets from the comfort of their cars or while enjoying a meal, according to police officials.
TRENTON, Aug. 7 — Gov. Jon S. Corzine opted for loyalty and familiarity on Tuesday, naming Bradley I. Abelow, the state treasurer and a former colleague at Goldman Sachs, to be his chief of staff.
The latest poor start for David Wells will not cost him a spot in the rotation with the San Diego Padres.
A former New York Times reporter who wrote an article about a teenager who operated a pornographic Web site may have sent more money to the young man than he had previously acknowledged.

WEST WINDSOR, N.J., Aug. 8 (AP) — Tyco International said Tuesday that it fell to a fiscal third-quarter loss because of hefty charges primarily related to a legal settlement, but its adjusted results exceeded Wall Street’s expectations.
Federal authorities are expected to announce rules that would require employers to fire workers who use false Social Security numbers.
Three senators seeking the presidency clashed over Iraq and Al Qaeda at a debate sponsored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
Michael A. Cordero was taken into custody in the killing of Boitumelo McCallum, the daughter of two New York University professors.
Attacks on American forces using a lethal type of bomb reached a new high in July, the U.S. military said.
A case in upstate New York illustrates the language difficulties of a new death benefit that pays relatives of emergency workers who die of strokes or heart attacks within a day of answering a call.
Prescription bottles bearing catchy brand names are being pushed aside by cheaper, tongue-twisting generics.
Mike McConnell, the nation’s top intelligence official, has brought criticism as the White House’s most visible advocate for changing a surveillance law.
Carlos Beltrán hit, ran and played catch Tuesday for the first time since straining his left oblique muscle July 25.
AFL-CIO DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES FORUM.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 7 — With roughly a dozen members of the Petit family sitting grimly in the front two rows, the two parolees accused of murdering three of their relatives during a brutal home invasion last month in Cheshire appeared in court on Tuesday under intense security.
No pitchers in major league history have had more success against Barry Bonds in as many confrontations as Washington relievers Kevin Ritz and Ray King.
The families have issued a joint statement addressed to President Bush and President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan.
A burn victim of last month’s steam pipe blast near Grand Central Terminal recalled her experience.
The leaders of North and South Korea will hold their second-ever summit meeting in Pyongyang this month.
The best strategy for dealing with a highly contagious disease is to enclose it within a moat of vaccinated animals — or dead ones.
The city of New York is waging a losing and ill-conceived battle for overzealous secrecy surrounding nearly 2,000 arrests during the 2004 Republican National Convention.
Of the mountain of individual plastic water bottles created by Americans each year, less than one-fourth are sent to the recycling industry for a second round.

Cincinnati will play the Big 12 Conference power Oklahoma in a home-and-home series. The Bearcats of the Big East will travel to Norman, Okla., for a game Sept. 6, 2008, then play host to the Sooners on Sept. 25, 2010, at Paul Brown Stadium. The two have never played in football.
colleges.

A federal appeals court ruled that a filly cannot be named Sally Hemings after Thomas Jefferson’s most famous slave and reputed lover. The Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati ruled that the Jockey Club can legally bar Garrett Redmond from naming his 4-year-old horse after Hemings. The Jockey Club forbids owners from using names of famous or notorious people without special permission. The club’s rules also say that “names considered in poor taste; or names that may be offensive to religious, political or ethnic groups” are not allowed.
Right wing Arron Asham, who appeared in a career-high 80 games with the Islanders last season, signed a one-year, $700,000 contract yesterday with the Devils.

Bud Collins, 78, joined ESPN’s tennis coverage a month after his final Wimbledon appearance for NBC. He will participate in ESPN2’s coverage of the Australian Open, the French Open and Wimbledon in 2008. He will report from the United States Open later this month.
The text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve after the Fed’s monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.
How did the Fed lose room to maneuver? The answer is rooted in the Bush administration’s misguided economic policies.
Relations between Russia and Georgia, already strained, have become even more tense because of the accusation.
A federal appeals court ruled that patients with terminal illnesses do not have a constitutional right to use medicines that have not won regulatory approval.
The deaths, which were attributed to roadside bombs, set the pace for a higher military toll in August than in July.
A recently discovered cache of nearly 100 records includes works by Tchaikovsky, Borodin and Rachmaninov.
The six-time W.N.B.A. All-Star Tina Thompson told a television station that she was seriously considering leaving the Comets, but then said that she was not close to making a decision.
Efforts to reach six trapped coal miners slowed on Tuesday as rescue teams pulled back for safety reasons.
A popular tax break for building developers is at the core of the agreement, which next goes to Gov. Eliot Spitzer.

Duke Energy, one of the largest electric power companies in the United States, said yesterday its second-quarter profit fell 17 percent after it spun off its natural gas business at the beginning of the year.

A front-page article on July 29 about the uneven quality of medical care for cancer gave an incomplete list of cancers that can be prevented or cured with surgery alone. Skin, cervical and colorectal cancer can be prevented if precancerous lesions are detected and removed. Melanoma and other skin cancers, along with cancers of the prostate, breast, colon, rectum and cervix, can sometimes be cured with surgery if diagnosed early and removed. Colorectal and cervical cancers are not the only ones preventable or curable by surgery alone.
Advocates said that the practice of serving breakfast in cafeterias failed to attract most of the children who need it.
Nascar fined the driver Robby Gordon $35,000 Tuesday for his vigilante-style antics at a Busch Series race Saturday in Montreal.

A large ceramic turtle containing the cremated remains of a woman has been recovered after being accidentally sold for 50 cents at a rummage sale. Anita Lewis, of Elmira, did not know the container held the ashes of her husband’s late wife when she sold the turtle on Saturday, The Star-Gazette reported. She realized her mistake, and a frantic search led to a Salvation Army Thrift Shop after a tip to the newspaper.

County officials said yesterday that the state must increase funds for local bridge repairs and urged the Legislature to dedicate nearly $3 billion over the next decade. The New Jersey Association of Counties said 4,164 bridges were either structurally deficient or obsolete, but based the estimate on 2003 data. Some of the bridges have since been repaired. The association said $2.68 billion was still needed. Gov. Jon S. Corzine ordered a report on the condition of state bridges last week after a deadly bridge collapse in Minneapolis. A spokeswoman for him said yesterday that no bridges in the state were considered unsafe.
Ryan Howard hit two home runs to help Jamie Moyer and the host Philadelphia Phillies beat the Florida Marlins, 11-1, last night.

New Jersey American Water advised customers in Warren Township and parts of Bridgewater, Watchung and Green Brook yesterday to boil water before drinking it. The water company said an electrical surge had knocked a pump station off line. The boil-water advisory is a precautionary measure, the company said, and no health threats were known to be in the water supply in those communities.

A group of airlines and public transportation agencies sued the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. yesterday, seeking permission to interview five special agents and two intelligence officers who may have knowledge helpful in their defense of wrongful death lawsuits arising from the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by American, United, Continental, US Airways and Delta Air Lines, and the public agencies that run the airports in Boston and Washington, after the bureau and the agency refused to grant access. Richard Kolko, an F.B.I. spokesman, declined to discuss the suit. The C.I.A. press office did not return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.

A man and his small spider monkey were detained yesterday after a flight crew alerted airport officials that they had a monkey aboard their aircraft en route to La Guardia Airport. The man boarded a Spirit Airlines flight on Monday night from Lima, Peru, to New York by way of South Florida, but did not report that he had a monkey with him, an airline spokeswoman said. It was only on the second leg of the flight, from Fort Lauderdale, that other passengers noticed the monkey. “It was clinging to his ponytail underneath his hat,” said Alison Russell, the airline’s spokeswoman. When the plane landed at 3:01 p.m. yesterday, the monkey was turned over to New York City Animal Care and Control, and the man, who was not named by airport officials, was turned over to federal officers for questioning, said Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs La Guardia Airport. “How the passenger got through security, I can’t begin to say,” Ms. Russell said.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the city had reached a tentative contract settlement with the Lieutenants Benevolent Association, the union representing police lieutenants. The agreement, for 26 months beginning on Sept. 1, calls for an 8.16 percent wage increase and applies to roughly 1,600 supervisors, the mayor said.

A principal at a Lower Manhattan high school who performed a Santeria religious ceremony at the school and coerced an assistant to help pay for it is likely to be fired, officials of the Department of Education said yesterday. The principal of Unity Center for Urban Technologies, Maritza Tamayo, paid a friend $1,800 to perform a ritual that involved sprinkling chicken blood on the floors to wipe out negative energy and as an antidote to students who misbehaved, according to a report released yesterday by the department’s special commissioner of investigation. During the school break in February 2006, Ms. Tamayo invited the friend to conduct the ceremony and urged an assistant principal to attend and pay $900, the report said.

Plans to put the Moondance Diner on a truck and take it to Wyoming were postponed yesterday after the city ordered work stopped until the owners could explain how the diner would be lifted off its foundation. The diner can be moved as soon as the city is assured that the procedure meets safety requirements, an official said. The Moondance, which has been a setting for films and television programs, was purchased online for $7,500 by Vincent Pierce, who plans to relocate the diner to Wyoming.
The request is a policy shift for Britain, as the Blair government insisted it had no obligation to help the detainees because they were not citizens.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined the city’s jury pool for a second day yesterday, but he was back to work at City Hall by early afternoon. The mayor was considered for a civil case involving a taxicab accident, but lawyers ultimately dismissed him. “I don’t take it personally,” Mr. Bloomberg said later. “I don’t take any pride in not being picked, or dissatisfaction either way.” Mr. Bloomberg, who spent his morning reading newspapers, postponed a jury duty call last summer because of the Queens blackout, a spokesman said.
A new book on Italy’s political class has become a phenomenon, catching the wave of a widespread national malaise.
The company said its fiscal fourth-quarter profit climbed to $1.9 billion, or 31 cents per share, from $1.5 billion, or 25 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier.
Lifted by high oil prices and a wave of foreign investment, the once humble ruble is showing its muscle, and fueling a consumer boom.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (Bloomberg News) — Borrowing by American households rose more than forecast in June, as consumers turned to credit cards and nonmortgage loans to maintain spending.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer criticized the Bush administration for failing to recognize its mistakes in Iraq while acknowledging that his own administration had “allowed our passion to get the best of us” in recent weeks.
Among the hardest hit in the bridge collapse was a group that survived war in its homeland, Somalia, and a move across the world to settle in Minneapolis.
The heavily promoted new business magazine that is about to publish its second issue, on Tuesday fired one of its top editors, James Impoco.
It is too early to know if he can lead the Steelers back to the playoffs. But veterans have learned one thing at camp about their youthful head coach: Mike Tomlin is still hungry.
The insurance broker Marsh & McLennan posted second-quarter earnings that missed analysts’ estimates and warned of continued weakness in its core brokerage unit, sending its shares down yesterday.
Recent American foreign policy setbacks can be traced partly to an American misunderstanding of how nomadic traditions shape attitudes in Central Asia.
Despite his brief but impressive résumé and his family ties, Steve Wallace, son of the 1989 Winston Cup champion Rusty Wallace, has had a miserable season.
Scientists, entrepreneurs and venture capitalists are becoming increasingly interested in making more than fuel out of the raw materials for biodiesel fuel and ethanol.
Officials estimate that there are 125,000 contractors working in Iraq, nearly the number of American troops. As of June 30, 1,001 have died there.
Sudan’s government is not enthusiastic about some elements of a joint Darfur rebel negotiating platform agreed to during talks on Monday.
Quarterback Brady Quinn has agreed to a five-year contract with the Cleveland Browns, ending an 11-day holdout that may have cost him the chance to begin the season as the team’s starter.
An American missing in Mexico for nearly three months after being wrongfully deported has been found and reunited with his family here.
Of the 156 players in the field at the P.G.A. Championship, few players have traveled the distances and depths that Steve Stricker has to rescue a sinking career.
Human rights groups accused China of failing to improve its record on civil liberties, despite official promises to make rights a centerpiece of the 2008 Olympics.
Ellyn A. McColgan, Fidelity Investments’ president for distribution and operations, said she was resigning to pursue opportunities outside of the company.
The spread of foot-and-mouth disease among livestock at two British farms was probably caused by human movement from nearby lab facilities, an investigation concluded.
Officials said the rules would be backed up by stepped-up raids on workplaces across the country that employ illegal immigrants.
F.C. Dallas’s Ray Burse Jr. will graduate from Ohio State later this month with a degree in American history after shuttling between Dallas and Columbus one day a week this past semester.
Skyrocketing farmland prices are stirring optimism, but for young and small-scale farmers, the news is grim.

Moody’s said yesterday that it would reorganize into two divisions, separating its credit ratings unit from sales, marketing and analytics to underscore the independence of its opinions on debt securities.
As the Yankees’ youngest reliever, Joba Chamberlain’s new role includes carrying an equipment bag to and from the bullpen. His impact on the rest of the team is expected to be far greater than that.
New York City is finally getting tough on delinquent ratepayers — but only on 11 of them.
Wall Street interpreted the Federal Reserve’s decision to maintain interest rates as a sign that the economy was not threatened by turmoil in the credit markets.
A certain canon of college-assigned summer reading is emerging: books that are readable, short, engaging, cheap.

The Countrywide Financial Corporation and the CIT Group said they would be able to ride out the mortgage industry’s credit squeeze as two more rivals, the HomeBanc Corporation and Impac Mortgage Holdings, curtailed new loans.
Climate change could ultimately affect food production and add to the woes of already desperate peasants in India, the official said.
With fullback Jim Finn out for the season after shoulder surgery, Robert Douglas is the only starter on the Giants without a backup on the depth chart.
After off-season pursuits that included parts in two movies and a magazine cover shoot, Jets safety Kerry Rhodes is immersing himself in football again.
The Federal Reserve Tuesday largely sidestepped the growing anxiety over how tightening credit standards will affect the economy.
Israeli riot police officers on Tuesday forcibly removed Jewish settlers from houses they had been occupying illegally for months in the West Bank city of Hebron.
The case of a former Brocade Communications executive was the first stock options backdating case to go to trial.
New York’s municipal native-plant nursery is part of a global project to collect and store seeds from 10 percent of the world’s flowering plant species in case of disaster.
An Army investigation into the “Baghdad Diarist” — a soldier in Iraq who wrote anonymous columns for The New Republic — has concluded that the reports were false.
WestLB Mellon Asset Management suspended redemptions of an asset-backed securities fund amid investor concern about the problems in the subprime mortgage market.
About a decade ago, Mikhail Gorbachev starred in a television ad for Pizza Hut. Now he is trading in fast food for fine leather.
Plucked from below 30 feet of sand last week was a mass that may be part of the remains of the Whydah, a pirate ship that sank off the coast  of Massachusetts in 1717.
Veikko Karvonen was a Finnish postal clerk who became one of the world’s best marathon runners in the 1950s.
A woman was charged Tuesday with interfering in the murder case against three men who have been accused in the shooting of two police officers during a traffic stop in Brooklyn last month.
In the last month, the continuing decline in Boston Scientific’s stock price has made some Wall Street analysts look bad.
The Warner Music Group posted a wider-than-expected quarterly loss , sending shares down roughly 10 percent.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 8 (AP) — The private-mortgage insurer MGIC Investment said on Tuesday that it did not believe that it had to complete its $4.9 billion purchase of the credit risk manager Radian Group after their joint interest in a mortgage investor became all but worthless.
The company announced a second-quarter loss of $13.5 million as gambling revenue fell, for a loss of 43 cents a share.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,668 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
NBC Universal Sports will stream 2,200 hours of live Summer Games coverage free from Beijing next year on its Web site, nbcolympics.com.
In front-loading the primary calendar, Florida and some other states have unintentionally damaged the presidential election process.
Disputes over maritime boundaries, particularly in the complex icy geography of the Arctic Ocean, require international solutions.
The power company said outside experts had been hired to analyze more than 500 pieces of debris that were pulled from the blast crater.
The city that never sleeps is also the city that never stops rebuilding. But lately, building projects have loomed even larger in New York.
Knicks forward Randolph Morris was arrested and charged with reckless driving early Tuesday morning in Lexington, Ky. Morris played sparingly for the Knicks last spring.
The increase in profits was driven by a tax benefit and stronger spending on marketing by clients like Microsoft and the United States Army.
Since 9/11, the Bush administration has sought to categorize members of Al Qaeda and other jihadists as “unlawful combatants” rather than treat them as criminals.
Mr. Schwarz, a freelance photographer, roamed the ancient heartland of Polish Jewry to record remnants of a disappeared people.
Wayward police officers in Bangkok will be punished by having to wear an embarrassing armband adorned with Hello Kitty and a pair of linked hearts.

CHAO--Ruth Mulan Chu 77, wife, mother, Asian scholar, and philanthropist passed away on Thursday, August 2, 2007 at New York Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital after a seven year battle with Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Precious wife of Dr. James S.C. Chao, Chairman of the Foremost Group of New York, cherished mother of United States Secretary of Labor Elaine L. Chao, Jeannette, May, Christine, Grace, and Angela Chao; treasured grandmother of Ben, Tyler, Alexia, Penelope, Miranda Mei and Jessica Ruth; and beloved mother-in-law of Republican Leader in the United Senate Mitch McConnell, Jeffrey Hwang, Jos Shaver and Gordon Hartogensis. A native of Anhui, China, she came to the United States as a young mother with three children in 1961, to join her husband who had arrived three years earlier. At the age of 51, she decided to return to school and earn a Master's degree in Asian literature and history from St. John's University. She has also established several foundations that provide scores of scholarships annually in her native land of China. A devout Christian and a lifelong church and community volunteer, she is deeply mourned by friends and family. CHAO--Ruth Mulan Chu. The Board of Trustees of St. John's University joins with the entire University community in mourning the passing of Ruth Mulan Chu Chao. An accomplished alumna who returned to the University at the age of 51 to attain a Master's degree in Asian Literature and History, she was an esteemed member of our University community. Along with her husband, alumnus and trustee emeritus James S.C. Chao, her daughter, honorary alumna and U.S. Secretary of Labor Elaine L. Chao, and her son-in-law, honorary alumnus United States Senator Mitch McConnell, she participated in a variety of University activities, where she touched us with her grace and dignity. She loved and was beloved by her husband and daughters. She and they are in our thoughts and prayers in this time of sorrow. Thomas E. McInerney, Chair, Board of Trustees Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President

In 1997 Adriana Kahane of Santa Monica, Calif., was studying blood oranges in business school and went to Italy, where she met Pino Modica, whose family grows blood oranges near Mount Etna in Sicily. She began shipping the oranges to a distributor in California (and married Mr. Modica in 1999). In 2003 Mount Etna had a major eruption that damaged the skins of the oranges, but not the flesh. The whole fruit could not be sold, so she went into the juice business and named her brand Italian Volcano.

Here's Eric Asimov's take on Champagne: it's not just for special occasions. ''Wouldn't it make sense to treat ourselves to a few bottles every now and then for no other reasons than that it's good?'' he asks. Um, yes. His tasting panel sampled 25 chardonnay-based blanc de blancs, ''the lightest and most refreshing Champagnes of all, just as right for an August afternoon as for a midnight in December.'' And hey, whaddya know -- it's August! So stock up on the panel's best value, ''the ripe yet dry and elegant Drappier Signature,'' a ''great buy at $27.'' Winter will be here before you know it, but you'll be a lot bubblier when it comes. ''Raise a Glass for the Taste, not the Toast'' by Eric Asimov.

MOORE--Jean Churchill Greensboro, NC. Jean Churchill Moore, 87, died peacefully at home on Sunday, August 5, 2007, supported by the love of family, friends, care-givers, and Hospice of Greensboro. After a heroic life weathering the effects of polio since 1951 with wisdom and grace, including fifty-six years in a wheelchair, along with lovingly raising her family and caring for multitudinous friends and her garden, she went to her well-deserved rest. A ceremony of remembrance will be held with family and friends at 4:00 PM on Wednesday, August 8, at Forbis & Dick, 1118 N. Elm Street. Attendees may wish to offer a brief anecdote about Jean. Urn burial will take place later in Massachusetts. Born July 9, 1920, in Northampton, MA, Jean was an intensely curious and caring person who touched everyone she met. She always took the time to ask about the lives of her visitors. Jean enjoyed education at the Williston - Northampton School, Smith College, and the Smith College School for Social Work. Despite her wheelchair, she was known to waltz, in her own way, while engaging her helpers in conversation. Her loving and well-loved husband William Walter Moore, a college professor, passed away in Greensboro on April 11, 1994. She is survived by three children, all teachers from the inspiration of their parents: William Churchill Moore of Greensboro, Margaret Isabell Moore of CA , and Terence Jordan Moore of MD along with seven grandchildren including Isabell Moore and Margaret Moore in town. Close relatives include Stephen Churchill of NY, Jordan Churchill of NC, and Robert Churchill of OR. Close friends are too numerous to list but Elizabeth Seymour, Nancy Walkowiak, Nego Crosson, Hermenia Milton, Lena Bembury, Midge Coston, and Honey Zimmer must be mentioned. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of Greensboro. On-line condolences may be offered at www.forbisanddick.com.

HILBERG--Raul. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the death of preeminent Holocaust scholar Raul Hilberg, whose monumental achievements defined the field of Holocaust studies. Through his devotion to teaching, his seminal work ''The Destruction of the European Jews,'' and his subsequent influential studies, he fostered a fundamental shift in the public's understanding of the Holocaust and inspired a generation of scholars. A pivotal leader in the creation of the Museum, he was a member of the President's Commission on the Holocaust, served on the Museum's governing Council and its Academic Committee, and was instrumental in the establishment of the Museum's Center for Advanced Holocaust Studies, which sponsors a fellowship in his honor. His singular legacy endures through the work of the Museum and the countless scholars whose lives he touched and work he influenced. The Museum extends its sincere condolences to his wife, Gwendolyn, and his children, David and Deborah. Fred S. Zeidman, Chairman Joel M. Geiderman, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director
