A group of airlines and public transportation agencies sued the F.B.I. and the C.I.A. yesterday, seeking permission to interview five special agents and two intelligence officers who may have knowledge helpful in their defense of wrongful death lawsuits arising from the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The lawsuit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan by American, United, Continental, US Airways and Delta Air Lines, and the public agencies that run the airports in Boston and Washington, after the bureau and the agency refused to grant access. Richard Kolko, an F.B.I. spokesman, declined to discuss the suit. The C.I.A. press office did not return phone calls seeking comment yesterday.

In some parts of the country, pride is taken in homemade pimento cheese; self-respecting Southerners would never buy the commercial kind to fill a sandwich or to top a canapé. And why would they? At its simplest, pimento cheese calls for shredded sharp Cheddar, minced jarred pimentos and mayonnaise. Variations include cream cheese, onion, pickles and hot sauce. Brooke Parkhurst, far left, a native of Pensacola, Fla., now living in New York, likes hers sharp and spicy, suitable to nibble with a martini at 5 p.m. or to use as an omelet filling for Sunday brunch. Tweaking her grandmother's recipe, she roasts red peppers in olive oil, uses sharp Irish Cheddar, Ben's cream cheese, mayonnaise and, for the kick, sriracha hot sauce. Her Belle's Southern Comforts pimento cheese is $6.99 for seven ounces at Murray's Cheese stores.

Pascal Goupil, a baker who owned the French Oven, now closed, in the Chelsea Market, has opened Madeleine, a charming French pâtisserie with a few tables. In spite of its name, it specializes in macaroons, not madeleines. ''In a week or so we'll have about 18 flavors,'' Mr. Goupil said, ''and I also plan to make cakes based on macaroons.'' The macaroons are big, filled and $2.50 each. Fresh fruit tartlets, like the elegant cherry variety, are $3.75 to $4.50, minitartlets are $1.50 each and small, rich chocolate croissants are 90 cents each.

MURRAY--William Edwards. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's Board of Trustees, faculty, administration are saddened at the passing of William Edwards Murray. Mr. Murray was a member of the Board of Trustees of the Labratory from 1995, serving as a Trustee until November 2001, and thereafter as an Honorary Trustee. CLARK--Duncan W., M.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Duncan W. Clark, M.D, professor emeritus of preventive medicine and community health. Dr. Clark helped pioneer the concepts and methods of family-based study, predating by four decades the case-based learning widely used at medical schools nationwide. The textbook he coedited, Preventive Medicine, is a classic in medical education. A teacher and mentor of thousands of physicians, he championed public health causes from water fluoridation to the importance of hand-washing in the prevention of disease transmission. A Class of 1936 alumnus of SUNY Downstate when it was known as The Long Island College of Medicine, he later served as dean of the college. In 1950, Dr. Clark was instrumental in merging the campus with the State University of New York, from which he received an honorary Doctor of Science degree in 2000. A past president of the New York Academy of Medicine, the Academy of Medicine of Brooklyn, and the Medical Society of the County of Kings, he served virtually his entire long and distinguished career at Downstate, including 35 years as chair of preventive medicine and community health. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, colleagues, and friends. John C. LaRosa, MD President Ian L. Taylor, MD, PhD Senior Vice President for Biomedical Education and Research and Dean of the College of Medicine Pascal James Imperato, MD, MPH&TM Distinguished Service Professor and Chair, Preventive Medicine and Community Health CLARK--Duncan. The New York Academy of Medicine acknowledges with profound sorrow the death of Duncan W. Clark, M.D., former Academy President from 1983 to 1984, trustee from 1985 to 1989, and chairman of the Committee on Medicine in Society from 1978 to 1982. Dr. Clark is remembered for his significant contributions to improving community health and for increasing the focus on preventive medicine in medical school education. Dr. Clark led a distinguished career at the SUNY Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn, that included 28 years as Chairman of the Department of Environmental Medicine and Community Health, where he emphasized the need to understand the social and environmental conditions under which diseases occur. Through extensive public service to dozens of local, state and national health organizations, Dr. Clark was dedicated to improving the health of all of the public. Dr. Clarks wisdom and drive made him an influential figure to generations of medical and public health students, residents and fellows. Dr. Clark will continue to be honored annually at the Academy with an endowed lecture in his name, as since 1986. The Academy Board, Fellows and staff extend the deepest condolences to his family. Jo Ivey Boufford, M.D., President Thomas Q. Morris, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees

First, the name. Cestropbeau deconstructs into three French words, c'est trop beau, which mean ''it's too beautiful,'' pronounced seh-troh-boh. The name is that of a company that makes uncommon granolas. The seasonings are sophisticated, the sweetening restrained. One granola mixes black currants, anise and pine nuts, another red tea, marcona marzipan and orange peel, left. Turkish apricots and sesame seeds combine in one, dried wild raspberries, cocoa, olive oil and sea salt in another. There are more than a dozen other flavors.

FISHMAN--Mosess (Moe). ALBA mourns the loss of the National Secretary of the Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade, who died on August 6 after a brief illness. Wounded during the Spanish Civil War, Moe returned to work on behalf of the wars refugees and served in the Merchant Marines during World War II. He was the public face of VALB for over 50 years representing US vets in public events around the world. An outspoken, respected activist, Moe will be remembered for his passion and dedication. We send our condolences to his partner Georgia Wever of Manhattan, sisters Lilly Litsky of Santa Cruz, CA and Pearl Fishman of Yonkers, and cousin Milt Okin of Rye, NY. A memorial will be held in the future. Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archives Peter Carroll, Board Chair Anne Taibleson, Executive Director

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that the city had reached a tentative contract settlement with the Lieutenants Benevolent Association, the union representing police lieutenants. The agreement, for 26 months beginning on Sept. 1, calls for an 8.16 percent wage increase and applies to roughly 1,600 supervisors, the mayor said.

CATINELLA--Nicholas. Suddenly and with out notice, Nicholas Alfonso Catinella, age 52, passed away in Las Vegas, Nevada on Saturday August 4, 2007. Mr. Catinella was born in Sicily on May 30, 1955. Nick, son of Virginia and the late Alfonso Catinella of Castrofilippo, Italy. He was a committed husband to his adoring wife Susanne; father of two beautiful children Matthew and Francesca; and loving brother to Salvatore Catinella. Nick also left behind a niece, nephew, two brother in-laws, and many devoted friends. Nick's passionate involvement with charitable foundations and civic organizations bestowed unlimited love and continuing support to countless children in New York and Connecticut. To have met Nick was to have been touched forever with humanity, kindness and everlasting hope. Services at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY at Noon on August 8, 2007. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations should made with grateful acknowledgement to: Myeloproliferative Disease Program, Division of Hematology-Oncology at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, 1 Gustave Levy Plaza, PO Box 1079, Attention Ronald Hoffman, NY, NY 10029, USA. CATINELLA--Nick. To my mentor and friend. I cannot express the deep sorrow I feel. I will miss your advice and the way that you were always there for me. Your dear friend Todd CATINELLA--Nick. To our dear friend. We will all miss you very much. Love Todd, Tom, Joe, Jerry and Randy

BELL--Philip Wilkes, economist, born in New York, NY on October 24, 1924, died on August 1, 2007 at Crosslands, Kennett Square, PA. He is survived by his wife, Jean Wyeth-Bell, his four children, stepchildren, and grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Friday, August 10, 2:30pm at Kendal-Crosslands. Kuzo & Grieco Funeral Home 610-444-4116.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer spoke on the tension between power and humility during a visit to the Chautauqua Institution yesterday, criticizing the Bush administration for failing to recognize its mistakes in Iraq while acknowledging that his own administration had ''allowed our passion to get the best of us'' in recent weeks. In his speech in the southwestern corner of the state, Mr. Spitzer drew on the theologian Reinhold Niebuhr. ''Only when we are willing to confront power with power,'' he said, according to his prepared remarks, ''can we even begin to address the injustices of our time.''

WEISBERG--Moritz, on Friday, August 3, of Coconut Creek, Florida. Dear husband of Shirley, deeply loved father of his only child, daughter Randy Genet and her husband, Jerry. Stepfather to sons Alan (Gail) Weinberg and Zev Weinberg and grandfather of Maxie and Freddie Weinberg. Predeceased by his late wife Shaynee Weisberg. Moritz was an esteemed expert in the garment industry over a 34 year career in New York before retiring in 1984. He traveled extensively sharing his knowledge of pattern/sample making, design and production. His skills provided a resource of heroic proportions as Production Manager for David Crystal, Inc. and a subsidiary at the time-Chemise Lacoste. A survivor of five years in concentration camps including Auschwitz and Mauthausen, etc., he has participated in a film interview documenting his life for The Shoah Foundation. Several of the poems and short stories penned by Moritz are archived in Israel at Yad Vashem and in Washington, D.C. at the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum. The writings are also included in the curricula of several colleges and universities throughout the U.S. His philosophy along with the literature he has written is powerful testimony to a very strong life force and the desire for Liberty! Services at Temple Emanu - El Fifth Avenue at 65th Street on Wednesday, August 8th at 12 noon.
We are tough and we are going to be even tougher. There are not going to be any more excuses for employers. RUSS KNOCKE,
A look at the career of Luciano Pavarotti.
There are plenty of opportunities to cut loose amid Old World grandeur in the Hungarian capital.
The Iraqi middle class who fled to other parts of the Middle East are now finding it difficult to make ends meet.
Zeinab Majid describes fleeing her war-torn homeland and her new life in Amman.
Zeinab Majid describes fleeing her war-torn homeland and her new life in Amman.
In today's column I note that health interventions seem to be among the more effective kinds of foreign aid. An interesting working paper from the IMF confirms that. It finds:

Last week I wrote about farm subsidies and noted that every year I get paid $588 not to grow crops in an Oregon forest. It's one more example of how ludicrous the agriculture subsidy system is. But when I complained about it, lots of you called me on it. You said, in effect, that if I objected to the system giving me the farm subsidy, I should reject it or at least give it to charity.

McLaren Mercedes today issued a statement that it says was done at the request of Lewis Hamilton, in order to set the record straight about how the two drivers are not enemies and how Hamilton did not swear at Ron Dennis after qualifying at the race in Budapest.
Debates seem to be taking on a new role in presidential politics. There is another one tonight, with most of the Democratic candidates scheduled to show up in Los Angeles to talk about gay issues.
Stocks on Wall Street suffered their biggest one-day decline  since February.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has criticized Senator Barack Obama for saying he would rule out using nuclear weapons to root out terrorists in Afghanistan or Pakistan, made a similar comment regarding Iran last year, before she became a presidential candidate.
From DealBook colleague Micheline Maynard, more on the surprise pick of Robert L. Nardelli as Chrysler's new chief executive:
This summer in Chelsea, the group shows have a more pronounced shift away from language and images and toward fairly raw materials.
The summer is ending and so is Matt's trip.  On his last and final week, he drives up the Pacific coast to Seattle, his final destination.
Images from "Desiderio" at the National Gallery of Art.
On the trail with the Republicans in the days before the Ames Straw Poll.
Movie Critic Stephen Holden reviews "2 Days in Paris,"  starring Adam Goldberg and Julie Delpy, who also directed.

LAS VEGAS - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just had an awfully testy exchange over universal health care with an audience member here at the National Association of Black Journalists conference - a lively moment that ended with an artful diss from Mrs. Clinton that had the audience hooting.

According to mediabistro.com's TVNewser, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Democratic forum televised Tuesday night on MSNBC "was the lowest rated-yet of the eight primary debates/forums held this election season. Based on live + same day data, Nielsen found the debate had 960,000 total viewers and 340,000 viewers in the 25-54 demo."
I'm familiar with the longstanding rule: no oysters in months that don't have an 'r' in them. And I continue to disobey it, for two reasons.
I woke up suddenly at 3 a.m. as if a phone was ringing or a child was calling. I listened for what had disturbed me, but everything was silent except for the sound of my heart pounding.

The recent wild swings of the stock market have wreaked havoc on yet more hedge funds. A publicly traded fund run by a unit of J.P. Morgan Chase has lost 5.3 percent of its value since the beginning of the month, while yet another fund run by Goldman Sachs suffered an 11 percent loss for July.

Manager Willie Randolph said today that he was not concerned about the negative statistics that Pedro Martinez posted Wednesday, his first minor league start since having rotator-cuff surgery last October.

News that Home Depot may receive less than $10.3 billion for the sale of its professional supply unit helped drive the home-improvement retailer's shares down more than 4.8 percent in afternoon trading Thursday. But despite the company's terse explanation that financing conditions prompted the move, we're still skeptical.
Will Japan eventually shed its pacifist constitution and develop a full-fledged military once again?

Updated, 5:02 PM Eastern The official death toll in the Minneapolis bridge collapse ticked up to seven today with the discovery of two bodies in the wreckage in the Mississippi River, the Hennepin Sherriff's Department announced.

Financial bigwigs continue to line up behind Hillary Clinton: The latest is Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein. The endorsements are only adding fuel to a debate about whether Wall Street's backing -- and its money -- are assets or liabilities for the Democratic presidential candidate.

Aura Estrada, 30, an essayist and the wife of the novelist Francisco Goldman, has died, apparently in a surfing accident while on vacation in Mexico in late July, according to Hunter College, where she was a second-year M.F.A. student. As part of the program, Estrada worked as a research assistant for Toni Morrison.

I do a lot of stuff for The Times: a weekly print column, a weekly e-column, a daily blog, a weekly audio podcast and a weekly video. As a result, I can never blame people who get these various efforts confused ("I got your podcast in my e-mail today!"), or who have no idea that the videos, for example, even exist.
Melena Ryzik of The Times attends the opening night party of the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival.

Another equity analyst has jumped into the buyout business. Joel Houck, formerly of Wachovia Capital Markets, has taken a job with American Capital Strategies, which said in a press release that he will oversee a new closed-end fund.
Fasten your seatbelts, as Bette Davis once advised, it's going to be a bumpy ride.

Charles Murphy, until recently a top European banker at Credit Suisse, is apparently doing well in his new gig with Fairfield Greenwich Group, a hedge fund that, despite its Connecticut-sounding name, is based in New York, according to its Web site.

Johnson & Johnson's trademark-rights suit against the Red Cross, covered in The New York Times today, has triggered a torrent of blog headlines filled with disbelief and outrage. Here are some examples:

Election '07? South Carolina's Republicans are going to move their presidential primaries to Jan. 16, 2008, which will likely set off a domino effect in New Hampshire, Iowa and elsewhere, "that could push the start of voting to New Year's Day or even to before Christmas," according to The Washington Post.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

We are planning to go to the Venice Biennale in October and would like to get an in-depth view of the exhibitions with a knowledgeable guide. I would appreciate suggestions on how to book one. Alternatively, are there tours that concentrate on the biennale?

With Dow Jones & Company set to become part of Rupert Murdoch's media empire, Gannett is sometimes touted as the next potential takeover target in the newspaper industry. But it is so huge -- with a market capitalization of nearly $11 billion -- that it is hard to imagine who the acquirer would be. Jon Morton, a newspaper analyst, told The New York Times in June that only a big, non-media buyer -- he mentioned General Electric or a buyout firm -- could possibly do such a deal, and even that's unlikely.

Carlos Beltran said this morning that he is still feeling discomfort from the right side the plate. He is ready to come off the 15-day disabled list today but still appears to be a few days away from playing in a game.

Even as Barry Bonds closed in on the home-run record, people were already predicting that Alex Rodriguez would someday overtake him. In the meantime, Tom Glavine gained his 300th victory, with seemingly fewer pitchers poised to ever reach that plateau. Which got us wondering: Is the 300-victory mark a more daunting, and impressive, achievement these days than reaching 755 home runs?
A recap of the handy little inventions David Pogue featured in his video piece from last week.
A mind-tingling conundrum, posed by email today by reader George D:

Suleiman Jamous, the confined Sudanese rebel leader who Mia Farrow offered to trade places with, will be freed when peace talks to end war and strife in Darfur begin, a top Sudanese official said today. The rebels would like the talks to start in two or three months.

In the unlikely event that someone decides to compile an online anthology called "Best American Blog Posts 2007" - please don't, by the way - I know one that ought to make it into the book's literary/academic section.

In a game of political one-upsmanship that is likely to shake up the 2008 election calendar, the South Carolina Republican party is expected to set a Jan. 19 date for its G.O.P. primary - moving its nominating contest ahead of Florida's by more than a week.
The Associated Press is reporting that some of the biggest critics of the Iraq war seems to be softening their stances, or at least hedging their bets:

It all started on Wednesday night in Pakistan, according to Reuters. Television stations started reporting that Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the embattled president, was about to declare emergency rule, which would increase the military's powers and postpone elections.

The ongoing troubles in the debt markets may have rocked yet another major buyout. On Thursday, Home Depot said it is in talks with the three private equity firms that agreed to buy its supply unit -- discussions that may lead to a lower price than the agreed-upon $10.325 billion. Home Depot also said it would cut the price it is offering in its share buyback.
Anyone know how to say "subprime" in French?

Wilbur Ross's $50 million investment in American Home Mortgage Investment during the lender's bankruptcy reorganization will apparently not be the last for the investor in distressed companies. In a Q&A with BusinessWeek, Mr. Ross said that he sees attractive targets in the subprime sector.

Campbell Soup said it may sell its Godiva Chocolatier luxury chocolate brand to focus on soups, snacks and drinks. "We are exploring strategic alternatives, which also includes the divestiture of Godiva," a Campbell spokesman, Anthony Sanzio, said to Bloomberg News.

The steel services company Ryerson on Wednesday defended its $1 billion deal to be bought by Platinum Equity, despite opposition from a hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, and said it had extensive discussions with potential buyers.
India's Tata Tea is interested in acquiring AriZona Beverages and the Tata Group could make a $2 billion buyout offer, The Economic Times said on Thursday, citing unnamed sources.

Australia's Wesfarmers, whose takeover of the Coles Group is in jeopardy because of a slide in its stock, said shareholders in the supermarket chain can opt for more cash as it seeks to make the offer more attractive.

The Royal Bank of Scotland has postponed the sale of a 1.1 billion-pound ($2.23 billion) British hotel portfolio because of spiraling costs in the wake of a global credit crunch, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source. It is not yet clear whether the deal has been permanently scrapped or simply delayed until the costs of borrowing and insuring debt have steadied, Reuters said.

Rosneft won another Yukos bankruptcy auction, buying key transport assets, including those used for exports to China, as it continued its drive to swallow up what was once Russia's biggest oil producer.

Dubai Borse on Thursday announced it is seeking to buy up to 25 percent of shares in OMX, the Nordic exchanges and technology group at 230 krona per share, threatening to derail an the Nasdaq Stock Market's agreed 25.1 billion-krona ($3.7 billion) bid for the Nordic exchanges and technology group.
Eurazeo, the French private equity firm, agreed Wednesday to buy a textile rental and cleaning service company, Elis GIE for 2.28 billion euros ($3.14 billion) from PAI Partners.

After resisting entreaties from would-be buyers and investors for years, an industrial design and engineering software maker, Coade, took the venture capital plunge, accepting $42 million in growth and liquidity funding from New York-based Insight Partners.
The former J.P. Morgan Chase salesman at the center of a Greek bond scandal is suing the bank, alleging he has been made a scapegoat.

The roiling credit markets and mediocre second-quarter results may be the push the Dolans, Cablevision System's founding family, need to persuade shareholders to green light their $36.26 a share offer to take the company private, The New York Post says.

The Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis, which is involved in a bidding war for the Dutch bank ABN Amro, reported a 16 percent year-on-year rise in second-quarter net profit on Thursday, beating analysts' expectations thanks to strong banking results.
A Dubai-based investment fund appeared to have won the bidding war for Barneys New York, the luxury clothing retailer, after a rival bidder pulled out of the race Thursday.

The trustee for Refco, a commodities brokerage firm that collapsed in fraud a few months after it went public in 2005, has sued Thomas H. Lee Partners, the private equity firm that controlled Refco, saying the firm should have known about the fraud before it sold stock.
Merger arbitrage hedge funds, which bet on the outcome of mergers and acquisitions, lost money in July over concern that turmoil in the credit market could derail some deals.

The deep freeze on corporate borrowing is showing signs of thawing, and that helped Wall Street post its third straight gain Wednesday. Although few analysts were willing to sound the all-clear for battered markets -- for one, the bonds that sold well Wednesday were corporate grade -- the mood has brightened significantly in the last few days.

Dell said in a regulatory filing Wednesday that once it finally files an annual report, it intends to pay $48.5 million to Kevin Rollins, who resigned as its chief executive early this year. The money comes in the form of a payment in lieu of stock options, the company said.

There are a lot of reasons why a man would give up his undercover status after 30 years with the C.I.A. For Jose Rodriguez, whose identity was revealed Wednesday, it was to participate in minority recruitment events, The Associated Press reported.

Shares of E-House, a Chinese real-estate services company, rallied more than 40 percent Wednesday as Wall Street dove into a play on the hot real estate sector in China. The Shanghai-based company bills itself as China's largest real estate agency and consulting services company.
American Public Education, a provider of online post-secondary education, filed Wednesday for an initial public offering of its common stock.

The resignation of Ellyn McColgan, a Fidelity executive who had been considered an heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Edward C. Johnson III, may have paved the way for Rodger Lawson, president of Fidelity to take the reins.

Who benefits from private equity? That was one of the questions kicked around by participants in a panel talk during the Academy of Management's annual conference this week. BusinessWeek framed the issue this way: "Do buyout firms like Blackstone Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts add value to companies or just collect a heaping wad of cash?"
All the hand-wringing lately over how hard the investment banks and the hedge fund industry will be hit by the current market turmoil may be for naught, according to one report.

The News Corporation reported strong quarterly earnings Wednesday, but the announcement was upstaged by Rupert Murdoch's comments on the company's recent deal to buy the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

The joint venture between NBC Universal and the News Corporation to bring their television shows and movies onto the Internet still lacks a Web site. It still has no name. It also has yet to announce a clear mission that convinces the large number of skeptical observers that real-world rivals can cooperate online.
The video rental chain Blockbuster said Wednesday that it had acquired the Internet movie provider Movielink to offer video downloading services to customers.

Take-Two Interactive Software's former general counsel, Kenneth I. Selterman, was sentenced Wednesday to three years of probation for falsifying a letter to regulators. He is the third former executive from the video game company, the maker of the Grand Theft Auto series, to be sentenced in a stock option backdating investigation.
The Universal Music Group said on Wednesday that it had acquired a stake in the operator of the urban social networking Web site Loud.com.
A comparison of several new portable radio consoles that can tune in to thousands of Internet radio stations.
A look at some of the dance performances at the 2007 New York International Fringe Festival.
How have female bounty hunters become a feature of the modern world?

Today's New York Times has an article about people who use the online community Second Life to live out their Architectural Digest-style fantasies. Second Life users "have built cities, created clothing lines and programmed their avatars - the characters that represent them in the three-dimensional space of Second Life - to ride horses, dance and have sex," Seth Kugel writes. People use online communities to network for their real-life careers, to stay in touch with friends, and to publicize their political campaigns.
When Donnie Andrews and Fran Boyd got married, it was the culmination of a lengthy courtship that was as much about turning their lives around as it was about finding each other.
The Pentax K100D shares several key features with its more expensive sibling, the K10D.
On Hasbro’s Power Tour Electric Guitar, your fingers glide on a glassy, lighted fret board that picks up the electrical charge of your fingers to sense the pitch.
A variety of digital tools, from cell phones to dedicated readers, are now available for cracking open  electronic books.
Motorola’s new Talkabout T9580RSAME two-way radios offers emergency alerts through the handset in additions to normal walkie-talkie features.
The TrackStick II looks like a U.S.B. thumb drive but picks up G.P.S. signals and stores the coordinates, which can be downloaded later to a PC.
Though VoIP providers are required to support 911 service, not all services work the same way and some providers may not be in full compliance.
Spam masquerading as greeting cards from unknown “friends” can might put your computer at risk if you click on a malicious link.
Keyspan’s USB 2.0 Server has two U.S.B. ports and an Ethernet port for connecting to a wired or wireless router, allowing U.S.B. devices to be shared on a network.
Two fossils could rearrange major branches thought to be in a straight ancestral line to Homo sapiens.
James Wood, a senior editor at The New Republic, is leaving to become a staff writer at The New Yorker.
A coping coach for renovators sees lessons in the sand.

When he wasn’t talking, B.B. King, who was headlining his own tour at the WaMu Theater at Madison Square Garden,  played tunes that have been lodged in his sets for quite a while and were worn but deep.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has criticized Senator Barack Obama for saying he would rule out using nuclear weapons to root out terrorists, made a similar comment regarding Iran last year.

The area of floating ice in the Arctic has shrunk more than in any summer since satellite tracking began in 1979, and it has reached that record point a month before the annual ice pullback typically peaks, experts said.
The United States Geological Survey estimated the magnitude of the quake, which caused no major damage, at 4.6.
A lawyer for Capt. Lisa Marie Nowak has filed papers arguing that the monitoring device is a hardship.
Searchers this afternoon found two bodies in the wreckage of the bridge as investigators looked at a potential design flaw.
Rescuers said they were within a few hours of possibly making contact with the trapped miners.
The Vatican worked to distance itself Thursday from a brief meeting between Pope Benedict XVI and a Polish priest accused of making anti-Semitic statements.
The decision today was a sign that the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease was coming under control.
President Bush lashed out at Democrats in Congress, questioning their priorities in spending tax revenues.
President Bush said today that he was confident that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq shared his view that Iran is a destabilizing force in the region.
The U.N. warned of “disastrous consequences” in Gaza unless the main border crossings into the territory are reopened.
Stocks dropped on Wall Street after the European Central Bank and the Fed took action to ease the tightening credit markets.
There were only a few signs of the violence that has marked previous year’s celebrations to honor an 8th-century Imam.
With the help of Moises Alou, the Mets’ lead over Atlanta in the division was restored to four and half games, which is where it was when the Braves came to town Tuesday.
Pedro Martínez toiled three innings in a 9-6 loss for the Port St. Lucie Mets and gave up five runs and six hits, including two home runs.
The Yankees’ Chien-Ming Wang suffered through the worst performance of his career, lasting just two and two-thirds innings in a rout by the Toronto Blue Jays.

Her legs draped in bandages and her fingers visibly pink and raw, Judith Bailey, a passenger in a tow truck at the center of a steam pipe explosion near Grand Central Terminal on July 18, was able to go home yesterday. “I thank God that I’m alive today,” Ms. Bailey said as she was wheeled out of NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital after three weeks there. Ms. Bailey was burned on more than 30 percent of her body, and the driver of the truck, Gregory McCullough, 21, suffered third-degree burns over 80 percent of his body. Mr. McCullough remains in the hospital’s burn unit, where he has been placed in a medically induced coma. Approximately 40 people were injured by the blast, and one woman, Lois Ellen Baumerich, 51, died of a heart attack while fleeing.

Golden Eagle Farm, a three-time Eclipse Award-winning thoroughbred breeding operation, plans to liquidate much of its inventory and relocate its San Diego County farmland. The owners Betty Mabee and her son Larry this week announced a six-month timeline to reduce Golden Eagle’s inventory from 282 horses to 25 by mid-2008.

Jeremy Mayfield will not return to Bill Davis Racing next season, the team said. Mayfield joined the team this year when it expanded to two cars, but he has struggled to qualify for races, making 8 of 21 events. His No. 36 Camry team was new for 2007 and did not have a guaranteed starting spot in the first five races of the season because it was outside the top 35 in owner points. After failing to qualify for the first four races of the year, Mayfield has not reached the top 35.

In the first 106 years of the United States Women’s Amateur, no preteen had reached match play. Now there are two, and they will face each other today. Alexis Thompson of Coral Springs, Fla., and Pearl Jin of San Gabriel, Calif., both 12, ousted older opponents to set up their second-round showdown at the Crooked Stick Golf Club in Carmel, Ind.

Susannah Aboff, a Princeton University junior, added a four-under-par 68 to her opening-round score of 72 to win the 20th Annual Lincoln Women’s Met Open Championship at Ridgewood Country Club yesterday. Aboff of Huntington Country Club became the fourth amateur to win the event. Her round included one bogey, on the par-5 17th hole, along with five birdies.

Peter Nowak will coach the United States Under-23 men’s team that will try to qualify for next year’s Olympics. Nowak, 43, who will remain an assistant coach for the national team, will take over the Under-23 team for Bob Bradley, now the national team coach.

Wake Forest promoted the assistant coach Dino Gaudio to succeed Skip Prosser, the head coach who died of an apparent heart attack July 26. Athletic Director Ron Wellman, who signed the 50-year-old Gaudio to a five-year contract, praised his strength during the two weeks of grieving after Prosser’s death. The speedy hiring appeared aimed at emphasizing stability and continuity to a recruiting class that was ranked as one of the nation’s best.

The Boston Celtics have spoken with the likely Hall of Famer Reggie Miller about coming out of retirement. ESPN.com was the first to report the talks. But both sides confirmed the possibility that Miller, who will turn 42 this month, would consider returning for the chance at a championship he never won during an 18-year career spent with the Indiana Pacers.

After Market, the winner of three consecutive races, including the Eddie Read, was chosen as the early 2-1 favorite for Saturday’s 25th running of the Arlington Million in Illinois. After Market, trained by John A. Shirreffs, drew the No. 4 post position. The field of eight 3-year-olds and up also includes the defending champion, The Tin Man, a 9-year-old gelding who will try to become the first back-to-back winner in race history.

James P. Molinaro, the Staten Island borough president, suffered a heart attack after a news conference yesterday and was hospitalized for surgery, his spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman, Pat Wilks, said that Mr. Molinaro, left, was resting comfortably at Staten Island University Hospital. He felt ill after a boardwalk news conference with Senator Charles E. Schumer and was driven to the hospital, she said. Mr. Molinaro, 76, a Conservative, began serving his first term as borough president in January 2002, succeeding Guy V. Molinari.

Cathay Pacific Airways, Hong Kong’s biggest airline, said its first-half profit rose 55 percent from a year earlier, helped by strong passenger demand and higher fares, particularly for first-class and business-class seats.

A picture caption on Friday with an article about a study contending that French fries at some fast-food restaurants in New York still have high amounts of trans fat, despite the city’s restrictions on its use, misidentified the Manhattan restaurant shown at lunchtime. It was a Wendy’s, not a Burger King. (The study found that fries at both chains were high in trans fat.).

A front-page article and picture caption on Tuesday about a surge of interest in the ancient books and texts stored in Timbuktu, Mali, misspelled the middle name of a Timbuktu resident whose family owns a 16th century Arabic text and whose ancestors ruled the city at its zenith. He is Ismaël Diadié Haïdara, not Diadé.

Adidas, the athletic shoe and apparel retailer, said its second-quarter net profit rose 27 percent as it began to realize gains from its takeover of Reebok, even though sales at the American unit were slipping.

An obituary on Friday about the Irish musician Tommy Makem misidentified the source of an account he gave of his arrival in Boston in 1955, including his description of being told by a customs agent, “Have a great life,” and his declaration more than a half century later, “I took him at his word.” It was an interview last year with The Boston Globe, not The Associated Press.
The Softbank Corporation, the Japanese mobile phone company, posted an eighteenfold increase in first-quarter profit after adding users at a pace twice that of the market leader, NTT DoCoMo.
Australia’s central bank raised its benchmark interest rate a quarter-point to 6.5 percent, the highest rate in almost 11 years.
The Universal Music Group said on Wednesday that it had acquired a stake in the operator of the urban social networking Web site Loud.com.
Britain eased a nationwide ban on moving livestock that it imposed last week after an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in southern England.
Austria will not extradite Rakhat M. Aliyev, the former son-in-law of the president, because there is no guarantee that he will get a fair trial in Kazakhstan.
Three Hamas militants were killed by Israeli troops in northern Gaza.
Leonid Stadnik, a 37-year-old former veterinarian, is the tallest person in the world, at 8 feet 5 inches.
A quake with a preliminary magnitude of 7.5 rattled Jakarta, violently shaking tall buildings and sending panicked residents into the streets.
A panel has taken a first step toward denying reappointment to a local administrative law judge who sued a dry cleaner for $54 million over a pair of lost pants, a government official said.

Two weeks after Fred D. Thompson shook up his political committee, he announced that he had hired a senior-level campaign-manager-in-waiting, William B. Lacy, a former strategist to Bob Dole and aide to President Ronald Reagan.
California’s $3 billion stem cell research program appointed an interim president, Richard A. Murphy, while it continued a longer-than-expected search for a permanent chief.
A man convicted of killing seven people at a suburban Chicago restaurant 14 years ago was sentenced to life in prison, after a judge denied his motion for a new trial.

A Cincinnati woman shot and killed a panhandler who asked her for 25 cents, the police say. “He asked her for a quarter,” Chief Tom Streicher said. “That’s apparently all there was to it.” The man, Donald Francis, who the police believe was homeless, stood outside a gasoline station Monday asking people for money. The woman, Geraldine Beasley, had complained about Mr. Francis to someone else, and when he approached her, she pulled out a gun and shot him, the police said. Mr. Francis, 44, died at the scene. Ms. Beasley, 62, was charged with murder and yesterday was ordered held in lieu of $500,000 bail.
The case in a plot to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport is working its way through Federal District Court in Brooklyn and the courts in Trinidad.

Two computers stolen from Yale University last month contained the Social Security numbers of about 10,000 current and former students and about 200 faculty and staff members, university officials said yesterday. Yale officials said they had notified those affected, but had not received any reports that the data on the machines had been misused. The officials said the computers were password-protected, one by multiple password levels, which “would require considerable computer savvy to bypass.” The machines were stolen from a dean’s office on July 17.
A survey of the nearly 1,000 readers comments that were posted throughout the day  on City Room, a news blog at nytimes.com.
If Carlos Beltrán’s left oblique muscle is still causing him problems when he bats from the right side, he will not play in the series finale against the Atlanta Braves.
In making public their suspicion about the flaw, officials were signaling a potentially crucial discovery and a safety concern for other bridges.
The effort to reduce the population at the detention center has been hampered by a number of diplomatic, legal and political challenges, officials say.
More than 500 hurricane survivors living in government-issued trailers and mobile homes are taking the manufacturers to court.
The federal government’s abandonment of comprehensive immigration reform has been matched by unprecedented crackdowns at the state and local level.
If ever there were a duo that needed a do-over, it’s the Chrysler-Nardelli team.
Health care giant Johnson & Johnson has filed a lawsuit against the American Red Cross over rights to use the iconic symbol they have both shared for more than 100 years.
President Bush described the economy as “thriving” and said lower taxes are the best way to guarantee prosperity.
Much of Utah’s coal is concentrated in one spot, and the resource has shaped that region’s ethnicity, culture and politics.
Putting one’s body in harm’s way to battle for prizes like the Barry Bonds ball is an extension of the tradition of fans bringing their gloves to ballparks to catch foul balls.
Civilian casualties caused by U.S. Special Forces make it hard to win over local people, a British commander said.
A tropical storm caused deadly landslides in the Philippines on Wednesday, before moving into southern Taiwan.

Though President Bush has had episodes of mild vertigo in recent weeks, they have not interfered with his work, the White House said.

James P. Molinaro, the Staten Island borough president, suffered a heart attack after a news conference yesterday and was hospitalized for surgery, his spokeswoman said. The spokeswoman, Pat Wilks, said that Mr. Molinaro, left, was resting comfortably at Staten Island University Hospital. He felt ill after a boardwalk news conference with Senator Charles E. Schumer and was driven to the hospital, she said. Mr. Molinaro, 76, a Conservative, began serving his first term as borough president in January 2002, succeeding Guy V. Molinari.

A Rider University student pleaded not guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to aggravated harassment in connection with the alcohol-related death of a college freshman in the spring. The student, Adriano DiDonato, 22, of Princeton, did not speak during his arraignment. Mr. DiDonato was charged after Gary DeVercelly, 18, of Long Beach, Calif., died after drinking at a fraternity party. The authorities said that Mr. DeVercelly had a blood alcohol level of 0.426 percent when he was pronounced dead on March 30. Mr. DiDonato was the residence director of the campus chapter of the Phi Kappa Tau fraternity, which has since been disbanded. Two school officials and two students have also been charged in connection with Mr. DeVercelly’s death.

Two computers stolen from Yale University last month contained the Social Security numbers of about 10,000 current and former students and about 200 faculty and staff members, university officials said yesterday. Yale officials said they had notified those affected, but had not received any reports that the data on the machines had been misused. The officials said the computers were password-protected, one by multiple password levels, which “would require considerable computer savvy to bypass.” The machines were stolen from the college dean’s office on July 17. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A North Bergen man was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to nearly 17 years in prison for robbing 10 banks in New York and New Jersey, prosecutors said. The man, Eduardo Quevedo, 44, was arrested on June 19, 2006, a day after robbing a Bank of America branch in North Bergen, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in New Jersey. When Mr. Quevedo was arrested, Mr. Christie said, federal agents seized an assault rifle, a handgun and ammunition. Mr. Quevedo admitted robbing 10 banks in 2005 and 2006 and was sentenced to 16 years and 8 months in prison. He was also ordered to repay more than $66,000, the amount taken in the robberies, prosecutors said. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A Jamaica man who fatally shot his father and his brother in 2002 was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to life in prison without parole, prosecutors said. The man, James Seecoomar, 38, was convicted of first-degree murder in February, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Seecoomar, a deli worker, shot his brother, Leonard, 35, in the back of the head with a revolver on March 27, 2002, as he watched television. When his father, James, 66, ran into the room, James Seecoomar shot him in the head and body, Mr. Brown said.

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo sued a magazine subscription company yesterday, claiming that it had illegally recruited and deceived young workers into selling door to door with little or no compensation. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Poughkeepsie, says the company, Jaguar Sales L.L.C. of Gig Harbor, Wash., transported workers to spots far from home, including New York. The workers were forced to endure terrible conditions and required to work six days a week for about 12 hours a day, the lawsuit says. Jaguar Sales had no comment on the lawsuit yesterday, according to a manager, Steve Barcel.

A driver who suffered a seizure just before a fatal car crash last year has been charged with falsely stating on his driver’s license renewal form that he did not have a medical condition that could cause unconsciousness, prosecutors said yesterday. The driver, Alexander Juwah, 44, a St. Albans psychiatrist, was charged yesterday in Criminal Court with offering a false instrument for filing, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Dr. Juwah suffered a blackout on Springfield Boulevard on Nov. 4, 2006, causing a multicar accident that killed three people and injured seven. Mr. Brown said Dr. Juwah knew that he suffered from a seizure disorder at the time he renewed his driver’s license.

A 22-year-old school aide has been arrested on charges of raping and sexually abusing an eighth-grade student, the office of the special commissioner of investigation said yesterday. The aide, Anthony Casey Jr., is accused of raping the student, a 13-year-old girl attending Lola Rodriguez de Tio Junior High School in the Bronx, twice in May, the commissioner’s office said, and at least one other time in June. Some of the rapes occurred at Mr. Casey’s Bronx apartment, the office said. Mr. Casey, who was suspended without pay, worked at the school for two years.
The massive failure to communicate by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday was not encouraging for New Yorkers.

Sometimes birdies and eagles aren’t enough. Occasionally, moose, bears, elk and wolves are necessary ingredients for a complete golf experience. It’s all part of the Big Sky allure. Situated midway between Bozeman and Yellowstone National Park in southern Montana, Big Sky Resort is best known for its uncrowded downhill ski facilities that were developed in part by native Montanan and legendary newsman Chet Huntley in the early 1970s. Perhaps the region’s biggest boost came via the 1992 film, “A River Runs Through It,” which featured a section of the Gallatin River near Big Sky. Fifteen years after its “I have to go there” moment, Big Sky is busting out again, this time as a golf destination. Among the new real estate communities are Yellowstone Club and the more accessible Spanish Peaks, which opened its private Tom Weiskopf-designed golf course on Aug. 3. With its mountain vistas and 7,000-foot elevation, this is breathtaking golf, indeed. Public players tee it up at Big Sky Golf Course, a flattish, if scenic early Arnold Palmer layout. If you like your golf on the wild side, walk this way.

Even as Barry Bonds closed in on the home-run record, people were already predicting that Alex Rodriguez would someday overtake him. In the meantime, Tom Glavine gained his 300th victory, with seemingly fewer pitchers poised to ever reach that plateau. Which got us wondering: Is the 300-victory mark a more daunting, and impressive, achievement these days than reaching 600 home runs?.

She arrived vibrant and upbeat despite jet lag from a trip back from Fiji, where she participated in a a charity swim in open water. A front-page picture caption in some copies yesterday with the Sports of The Times column about Barry Bonds's 756th home run misstated the year that Hank Aaron set the career record of 755. It was 1976, not 1974. (Aaron broke Babe Ruth's record of 714 in 1974.)
The Q&A column in Science Times on Tuesday misstated the location of blue lights used by airports for high visibility. The lights line taxiways, not runways.
DRECHSLER--Robert., The Board of Directors of 975 Park Avenue wishes to express its condolences on the passing of our friend and neighbor, Robert Drechsler.

A front-page article and picture caption on Tuesday about a surge of interest in the ancient books and texts stored in Timbuktu, Mali, misspelled the middle name of a Timbuktu resident whose family owns a 16th century Arabic text and whose ancestors ruled the city at its zenith. He is Ismaël Diadié Haïdara, not Diadé.

An article on Tuesday about the relationship between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama inaccurately described a moment involving them while they were doing television interviews after the State of the Union address. Mrs. Clinton took a circuitous route past Mr. Obama not to avoid him, but to accommodate a television producer.

MILES--Ruth., The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Ruth Miles, beloved mother of Vicki Weiner, member of UJA-Federation's board of directors. Vicki and her husband, Ronald are valued friends of the Jewish community who have, through their leadership, enabled us to care for those in need around the globe. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Vicki and Ronald; to Ruth's grandchildren, Jennie and Jeremiah, Maureen, Michelle and Zach, Stephanie and Arnie; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

CYCLISTS no longer have to take the road less traveled, thanks to miles of new bike paths paid for with federal money over the last two years. Because of these new routes, cycling is becoming more accessible and less intimidating for parents who are serious bicyclists looking to take their small children along for a ride, said Tim Blumenthal, the executive director of Bikes Belong, a coalition of bike suppliers and retailers.

THE trend toward modern design in nursery decoration has produced plenty of expensive furnishings. But now modernist babies with almost any budget can enjoy well-designed bedrooms. This season, stores like Wal-Mart are offering bedding and furnishings -- including cribs -- that bear a remarkable resemblance to higher-end merchandise. And most sets come with quilts and pillowcases that a child can continue to use even after the crib is converted to a toddler bed.

HILBERG--Raul, , Professor Emeritus of the University of Vermont passed away on August 4, 2007. University president Daniel Mark Fogel, the university community, and the Carolyn and Leonard Miller Center for Holocaust Studies at the University of Vermont would like to express their condolences to his wife Gwendolyn and his family, and their gratitude to this exemplary and pioneering scholar for his many years of service to the university. Professor Hilberg joined the faculty of the University of Vermont's department of political science in 1956, where he served for 35 years. Professor Hilberg took on a variety of administrative duties at the university, serving as chair of the political science department and chair of a presidential search committee, among other appointments. Professor Hilberg devoted his entire scholarly life to studying the Holocaust. In 1961 the first edition of his landmark work The Destruction of the European Jews was published. Regarded as the definitive study of the Holocaust, the book was described by the London Times Literary Supplement as ''one of the great historical works of our time.'' A revised version was published in 1985, and the Yale University Press published a third edition in 2003. It has been published in every major language. At the time of his retirement in 1991, the University of Vermont organized an international conference, ''The Hilberg Symposium: Perpetrators, Victims, and Bystanders.'' Presentations were delivered by Yehuda Bauer, Christopher Browning, Claude Lanzmann, Alvin Rosenfeld, Richard Rubenstein, George Steiner, and Herman Wouk. The proceedings were published as a collection of essays in honor of Professor Hilberg titled Perspectives on the Holocaust. That same year, the University of Vermont established a Center for Holocaust Studies, recently renamed the Carolyn and Leonard Miller Center for Holocaust Studies. Each year, the center honors Professor Hilberg with the annual Hilberg Lecture, attracting prominent Holocaust scholars from around the world. To further commemorate him, the center published a Festschrift for Raul Hilberg on His SeventyFifth Birthday in 2001. Professor Hilberg was and remains our constant companion and inspiration in our efforts to further the knowledge of the Shoah in the classroom, the community, and the world.

A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about the exhibition ''Invention: Merce Cunningham & Collaborators,'' at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, included outdated information about when the library is open. (The error also appeared on the previous three Fridays.) It is now open on Mondays, as well as Tuesday through Saturday. The hours are noon to 8 p.m. on Monday and Thursday; 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday (not noon to 6 p.m.) ; and 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Saturday (not noon to 6 p.m.).

If you are stuck in New York City on a hot August day, you might want to take an air-conditioned No. 7 subway to Queens, where you can peruse the merchandise at a 50-percent-off sale of African and Filipino furnishings at Tucker Robbins's studio and warehouse. Included in the sale are Dogan ladders, from six feet high ($975) to eight feet ($1,950); carved Nupe wood posts, some 10 feet tall and others that can be used as wall hangings ($1,200 to $1,800); and a hand-carved Human Chair from the Philippines ($1,650), above. The studio is on the fourth floor at 33-02 Skillman Avenue in Long Island City, near the 33rd Street-Rawson Street subway stop; (718) 764-0222. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

PRIVATE EQUITY INVESTOR SUED The trustee for Refco, a commodities brokerage firm that collapsed in fraud a few months after it went public in 2005, has sued Thomas H. Lee, the private equity firm that controlled Refco, saying the firm should have known about the fraud before it sold stock. BUSH SEES A STRONG ECONOMY President Bush, seeking to reassure Americans about the economy and combat Democratic criticism of his policies, said that recent financial market turbulence was not a cause for worry but a natural adjustment from the improvident lending of recent years. Mr. Bush said that his economic advisers would be ''paying close attention as the market begins to readjust its assessment of risk'' in housing and other sectors. [C1.]

SCHEIDT--Stephen S., The faculty, fellows and staff of the Division of Cardiology of Weill Cornell Medical College mourn the loss of our beloved colleague, Stephen S. Scheidt. A devoted physician and educator, Steve was Director of the Cardiology Fellowship Training Program for over30 years and inspired generations of cardiologists. Loved by all who knew him, his energy, spirit, and love for his work, and dedication to the well-being of patients and friends will live on in the hearts of all who were fortunate enough to know this unique and wonderful human being. Our hearts go out to his wife, Andrea, his daughters Leslie and Vivian and their families.

LEVY--Arthur., The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member, Arthur Levy. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his entire family. Seth Blumenfeld, President Hildy Wagenheim, Secretary LEVY--Arthur. My darling ... I will hold you in my heart always ... Thank you for the most wonderful life. Your Barb LEVY--Arthur. Our dear friend. We will miss you very much and mourn your passing. Our sincere condolences to his wife Barbara and the entire family. Ginger and Larry LEVY--Arthur. Arthur succumbed on Wednesday, August 8th after a valiant struggle with pancreatic cancer. He was 77 years old. Words cannot fully describe this truly elegant and handsome man, who was the foundation of our family. Beloved son of the late Betty and Lou. Adored husband and childhood sweetheart of Barbara. Cherished father of Richard and Lynn, Donald and Dawn and Lauren and John. Sweet and loving grandpa to Dana, Liz, Louis, Candice, Jenna, Ben, Julie and Jessie. Much loved brother of Jack and Marcia, Michael and Anne, Sandy and Phil Sherriton. Until his retirement, he was a real force in the apparel industry, but his interest in the family business remained constant. Taking the torch from his father and passing it to his sons, he continued to love the action and the creativity. Arthur's enjoyment came from spending hours with his sons discussing the direction the business was taking, and what new endeavors were to be in their future. Arthur was the most loyal of friends. His word was his bond. He will be sorely missed by his buddies in the card room at High Ridge and Brae Burn Country Clubs, all of whom he loved dearly. Arthur Levy genuinely loved his life. He took great pride and pleasure from his family, friends and from everything he did. We, his family, will love and miss him forever. Contributions can be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins. The funeral service will be held on Friday, August 10th at 11am at Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65th St. Entrance on 5th Avenue. LEVY--Arthur. My business partner for over 50 years, my brother for over 75 years, my friend for my lifetime, I will miss you forever. I love you. Jack LEVY--Arthur. Claude Bouchard is known for his porcelain and silver tabletop accessories, but occasionally he ventures into other sorts of objects -- as in Foglia Couture, a collection of leather trays, boxes and baskets he created for Oscar Maschera, an Italian leather company. The asymmetrical Robin baskets, above, are made of two pieces of leather, a light-colored one on the outside and a darker one inside, creased at the top, glued and then stitched together. The edges are burnished and smooth to the touch. ''I try to make the object as irregular as the drawing,'' said Mr. Bouchard, the artistic director of Puiforcat, a silver and porcelain company in Paris. ''So when you see an irregular object, you know it's designed by me, or a kid.'' The baskets come in three sizes, from left: 19 inches ($1,115), 7 1/2 inches ($345) and 14 1/2 inches ($805) tall. At Art et Maison, 31 North Moore Street (Hudson Street); (212) 226-3665. ELAINE LOUIE

An article on Friday about a Russian expedition that deposited a Russian flag on the seabed at the North Pole included an incomplete list of countries with Arctic Circle territory. The list includes Sweden, Iceland and Finland, in addition to the five named in the article -- Canada, Denmark, Norway, Russia and the United States.

Jackson, Chairman Daniel R. Allen, Exec. V.P.

A headline in some copies yesterday with the Extra Time soccer roundup, which began with a report about Ray Burse Jr.'s budding development as a professional goalkeeper for F. C. Dallas of Major League Soccer, referred incorrectly to his playing experience. He is a second-year player, not a rookie. Also, the report referred imprecisely to the nature of the Blue athletic honors awarded to Burse's father, Raymond Sr., while he attended Oxford. Blue status can be granted to those who compete on an elite Oxford sports team against rival Cambridge, not only to those who play four sports against Cambridge.

Lucienne and Robin Day, British Modernists, are often compared to Ray and Charles Eames, ''because they were a couple and we're a couple,'' said Ms. Day, 90, adding that she and her husband, 92, ''work absolutely separately.'' But if their aesthetic is reminiscent of the Eameses', the designs they are re-releasing are far less commonplace in the United States. An enlarged version of Mr. Day's 1955 Tricorne plywood tray, right, in birch ($150) or walnut ($174) veneer, and Ms. Day's 1950s linen tea towels (''Too Many Cooks'' and ''Night and Day,'' above, left and right; $40 each) are at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum shop, 2 East 91st Street; (212) 849-8355. CRAIG KELLOGG

A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about the exhibition ''Invention: Merce Cunningham & Collaborators,'' at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, included outdated information about when the library is open. (The error also appeared on the previous three Fridays.) It is now open on Mondays, as well as Tuesday through Saturday. The hours are noon to 8 p.m. on Monday and Thursday; 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday (not noon to 6 p.m.) ; and 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Saturday (not noon to 6 p.m.).

Claiming they are still owed profits, Tom Hanksand his wife, Rita Wilson, have joined Nia Vardalos in suing one of the producers of the 2002 sleeper hit ''My Big Fat Greek Wedding,'' The Associated Press reported. The lawsuit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, said the comedy cost $5 million to make; Box Office Mojo, a tracking company, has estimated its gross theatrical sales at $370 million. The plaintiffs maintain that the defendant, Gold Circle Films, puts the gross receipts at $287 million. The lawsuit seeks unspecified monetary damages and a full accounting of the profits. Scott Niemeyer, a principal at Gold Circle, said the lawsuit was ''frivolous'' and ''completely without merit.'' Mr. Hanks and Ms. Wilson were producers of the film; Ms. Vardalos wrote and starred in it.

Flake, a six-pointed star sold in multiples, can be turned into a curtain, a placemat or even a three-dimensional object. Simply slip the point of one star into the slit of another. Made by Woodnotes, a Finnish company, it is the latest version of an idea that Mia Cullin, a Swedish designer, came up with years ago while devising a user-friendly polycarbonate plastic lamp. ''The customer put it together the same way,'' she said, ''with slits and holes.'' This time she made the interlocking pieces out of Tyvek, a thermoplastic, because it is light, strong and easy to clean. A package of 160 pieces is $186 from Suite New York, 625 Madison Avenue (58th Street); (212)421-3300. ELAINE LOUIE

UBELE--Russell J., , of Brooklyn, NY, formerly of Philadelphia, PA, passed away Saturday, August 4, 2007, at Prospect Park Residence, Park Slope Brooklyn, NY. He was 80 years old. Born December 13, 1926, in Philadelphia, PA, he was the son of the late Russell and Jamesina Ubele. Mr. Ubele attended Central High School and Temple University in Philadelphia. He was an Accountant/Comptroller employed by Lauderback Moving and Storage in Philadelphia before moving to New York in 1960 and was Comptroller for Mayflower Moving and Storage and John Dorist Electrical Construction in Manhattan, NY. He was very fond of the performing arts, a collector and an avid gardener. He was also very fond of animals, having as many as five of his own Daschunds. He was also a generous supporter of animal rescue organizations as well as other charitable organizations. A brother Harry and his wife, Sandra, of Doylestown, PA, and a brother Robert and his wife, Patricia, of Wildwood Crest, NJ, nieces Robin, Karen, Jill, Margo, Trish, Tara, and nephews Douglas, David, Robert Jr., Tim and David, plus many great nieces and nephews, survive him. He will be remembered by his many good friends and neighbors in Park Slope, including Knight and Camela Vidal. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Augustine's Church, 116 6th Ave., Brooklyn, NY, at 10am, Saturday August 11, 2007. Visitors and friends may greet the family members prior to the service. Memorial contributions in his name may be made to a charity of the donor's choice.

Liza Sherman, whose Greenwich Village store carries items like iron saddle hooks and a 19th-century French glass gardening cloche refigured as a chandelier, has opened a new shop on Shelter Island. There you'll find a clown's head used in a carnival game ($1,600), bottom; horns that once adorned a truck ($1,800 for three), far right top; and the arms from an 18th-century carving of a saint ($900), below. There are also the ever-popular Portuguese eel traps ($1,200), which resemble large, wire-mesh doughnuts. When the light hits them, they cast intricate shadows on the wall, and if that's not enough for you, best you move along. ''We don't sell stuff that is considered useful,'' said Ms. Sherman, top, whose stock runs to Rust Belt industrial equipment that she describes as ''artistic stuff -- it's not the pair of things, the Ikea sofa, the sisal rug; that's the kiss of death.''

One of the last bits that I cut out of my latest Auto Ego article on Mike Tyrrell were his laments on the closing of Long Island Dragway three years ago. Once there were several drag strips and oval tracks spread all over Long Island. Today there's only Riverhead Raceway, which is a quarter-mile oval. There are no more drag strips. Long Island Dragway was the last.

The Bourdais watch is finally over. No need to talk at length on this site about how the sport can continue to ignore one of the great racing talents of the day. Bourdais has finally signed with an F1 team. All right, it's Toro Rosso - but that's an even greater sign of just how important this driver is. With all the Red Bull drivers around who might fill both seats at the team, Toro Rosso chose Bourdais.

The Mets' locker room was not exactly a festive place after yesterday's 7-6 loss to the Atlanta Braves, especially because the Mets staged a comeback that fell short by a few feet. You just thought you were sweating? Among global warming Cassandras, the fact that 1998 was the "hottest year on record" has always been an article of faith. Stephen McIntyre, who runs the Climateaudit blog was always puzzled by some gaps he saw in the raw data provided by NASA that supported the claim (data compiled in part by James Hansen, the climate scientist who has long accused the Bush administration of trying to "silence" him). McIntyre says he has "reverse engineered" the data to find NASA's algorithm, discovered that a Y2K bug played havoc with some of the numbers, and notified the space agency.
