Bear Stearns has managed, if only temporarily, to put some distance between itself and disgruntled investors in two of its now-bankrupt hedge funds.
Xtera Communications announced the closing of a $52 million second round that gives the optical networking company about $100 million in venture backing since its recapitalization in 2004.

The Nasdaq Stock Market pledged to press ahead with its 25.1 billion Swedish kronor ($3.7 billion) bid for OMX despite Borse Dubai of the United Arab Emirates encroaching on the offer with a bid for "at least" 25 percent of OMX, operator of the fifth largest exchange in Europe.
H&R Block, eager to sell its money-losing Option One mortgage unit to Cerberus Capital Management, said Thursday that it might not complete the deal until the end of December.

The war of words between Topps, the maker of baseball cards and Bazooka bubblegum, and Upper Deck, the rival that is trying to buy it, continued this week, as the two traded barbs over their deal negotiations.

Over the last few years, the Macquarie Bank of Australia has become something of a role model for the investment industry, but in recent months, markets and investors have posed some difficult questions for the relative newcomer.
Boston Scientific's tortured relationship with Advanced Bionics, the high-tech implant company it acquired in 2004, is about to end.

Roel C. Campos, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission who sparred with agency Republicans over how best to penalize companies for securities law violations, will depart in a month for the private sector, the commission said Thursday.

For a minimum of $10 million, golf fans can a buy a home on the sport's hallowed ground. The St. Andrews Grand, due for completion in 2009, offers 23 residences in a 120-year-old manor situated on the fabled 18th hole of St. Andrews' "Old Course" in Scotland, birthplace of the game.
The $26 billion-plus hedge fund managed by mathematician James Simons is down “in the order of 7 percent” for the year through Aug. 8, according to a letter the fund sent to investors.
A&E’s sick documentary series returns with four episodes, featuring new addicts with gruesome histories that are all uniquely fascinating to watch.
The Sci Fi Channel’s show, approximately the zillionth attempt to put Flash and his friends on the big or small screen, isn’t bad, particularly; it’s just not very, excuse me, flashy.
Nerissa Villamaria and Richard Villanova did not mind downsizing, as long as they still had sufficient space and could begin building equity.

According to an article in today's New York Times, consumer goods companies, which once saw packages largely as containers for shipping their products, are now using them more as 3-D ads to grab shoppers' attention.

I took advantage of the off-day to visit the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio, this afternoon. As I studied the play-by-play of "The Drive" - folks here in Cleveland need no further explanation - my cellphone rang. It was Scott Boras, calling me back.
“Stardust” is a sprawling, effects-laden fairy tale with the thundering stamina of a marathon horse race.
The junky, clunky, grimly unfunny “Rush Hour 3” isn’t the worst movie of the summer. But it’s an enervating bummer nonetheless.
Jeffrey Blitz’s tender but hardheaded “Rocket Science” plumbs the tormented consciousness of a fragile teenager with a paralyzing speech impediment.
In “2 Days in Paris,” Julie Delpy’s and Adam Goldberg’s performances are so assured and spontaneous that they don’t even seem to be acting.
“Crossing the Line” tells of four American servicemen who defected to North Korea, with a focus on Joseph Dresnok, who became a privileged North Korean citizen.
With “Descent,” first-time feature filmmaker Talia Lugacy explores the psychic aftershocks of a rape. The movie is hard to watch but essential to see.
Maneuvers by state lawmakers and political leaders upset with the presidential election process are adding unpredictability to the campaign.
At last count, 96 members of Mitt Romney’s clan have arrived to help out at Saturday’s Republican straw poll.
Rudolph W. Giuliani sought to clarify earlier comments in which he called himself “one of” the 9/11 cleanup workers and said he was “at ground zero as often, if not more, than most of the workers.”
Divers in Minneapolis found the remains of someone killed in the disaster, bringing the death toll in the collapse to as many as nine, with at least four others still missing.

Two days before a gunman killed 30 people and himself in a Virginia Tech classroom building, a suspicious man was seen in the building and at least one exterior door was found to be chained shut, the police said today.
A test of the cavity where the miners were originally believed to be trapped found insufficient oxygen levels.
The Army said that it was augmenting its number of recruiters in the field by pulling people from other jobs.
A gunfight erupted in Jerusalem’s Old City today when a young Arab man took a pistol from a security guard and attempted to flee.
Jose Carranza, who was charged in the slayings, had been out on bail. A third suspect was arrested today.
Divers in Minneapolis found the body of someone killed in the disaster, bringing the death toll in the collapse to eight, with at least five others still missing.
July’s rise in import prices exceeded the 1 percent increase that Wall Street economists were expecting.
After a sell-off early in the session, stocks recovered most of their losses. The ups and downs pointed to continued concerns over the credit squeeze.
U.S. stocks are likely to decline further today after most major Asian and European markets plunged over widening fears about the housing loan market.
Central banks around Asia joined efforts in the U.S. and Europe to stave off a credit crunch today, as stocks in Japan and Hong Kong fell by more than 2.5 percent.
The three leading Democratic candidates for president stopped short of supporting same-sex marriage.
A 2-year-old boy was killed and three members of his family were injured last night in a fire in their Queens apartment, the police said.
The Really? column in Science Times on Tuesday misstated one of the compounds that block UVA radiation and are frequently found in sunscreens. It is avobenzone, not avobenzene.
Magna International, an auto parts maker, reported a 36 percent rise in second-quarter profit as sales increased worldwide.

A front-page article yesterday about the relationship between President Bush and his father, George Herbert Walker Bush, misstated some dates in the history of the only other father and son elected to the presidency of the United States. John Quincy Adams was inaugurated on March 4, 1825, which was 24 years — not 28 — after his father, John Adams, left office. John Adams died in July 1826, which was 16 months — not 18 — after his son’s inauguration.
The Bank of Korea unexpectedly raised its benchmark interest rate for a second time in two months to curb lending that may fuel asset-price bubbles.
Deutsche Telekom, the largest phone company in Europe, reported a fifth consecutive decline in quarterly profit after a strike led to more fixed-line customer losses.

New Zealand’s jobless rate fell to a record low in the second quarter, adding to inflation pressure and increasing the prospect that the central bank would keep interest rates at a record high until at least June next year.

Puma said that its second-quarter profit slipped nearly 10 percent as rising sales in Europe were offset by a 15 percent sales decline in the Americas and a slide in orders for shoes in the United States.
Jon Fogarty won a record eighth straight Grand-Am Rolex Sports Car Series team pole position and set a track record.
The hourly chimes and quarter bells of the London landmark will fall silent during scheduled repairs for only the fourth time since the clock was installed in 1859.
Saif al-Islam, a son of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, has acknowledged that six medical workers who spent more than eight years in a Libyan prison were tortured.
Two bank guards who stole $6.7 million from a vault they were supposed to be protecting have been sentenced to death by a court n Hebei Province.
Long-range strategic bombers, once part of the Soviet Union’s nuclear forces, were used in new flight exercises that included passing by a United States naval base in Guam.
In his Major League Soccer debut, David Beckham played the final 21 minutes in the Los Angeles Galaxy’s 1-0 loss to D.C. United.
A French lawyer is defending the first member of the Khmer Rouge to be charged in connection with the deaths of 1.7 million people from 1975 to 1979.
One of five brown bears from Slovenia let loose in the French Pyrenees to increase the native bear population, was killed in a collision with a car.
A Ukrainian immigrant was convicted of murder for his role in two shootings dating to the heyday of Russian organized crime in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.
Jurors in the trial of Jose Padilla and two other men cannot consider whether the men’s actions were justified by Islamic law, a federal judge ruled.

Federal investigators said there were similarities between a fire this week at a suburban Houston manufacturing plant and the blasts last month at a Dallas gas facility that shot fiery debris in the city’s downtown area. The Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board said it would investigate an acetylene fire Tuesday at the Hughes Christensen Company, a manufacturer of oil drilling bits, that the agency said forced the evacuation of 800 employees. At Southwest Industrial Gases Inc. in Dallas on July 25, three people were hurt when a chain reaction of exploding acetylene tanks sent cylinders shooting like missiles into the sky. In both cases, the board said a delivery trailer from Western International Gas and Cylinders Inc. appeared to be involved. Bob Schubert, a spokesman for the company, based in Bellville, said the company was cooperating with the authorities.
Government forecasters minimally reduced their prediction for the Atlantic hurricane season, but said that up to nine hurricanes and up to 16 tropical storms were expected to form.

Cindy Sheehan, announced her candidacy for the House seat held by Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Ms. Sheehan, left, a peace advocate, said last month that she intended to run against Ms. Pelosi if Ms. Pelosi did not move to impeach President Bush by July 23. Ms. Sheehan said Ms. Pelosi, a Democrat from San Francisco, had “protected the status quo” of the corporate elite and lost touch with people in her district, most of whom want American troops out of Iraq. Ms. Sheehan cited her son, Specialist Casey A. Sheehan of the Army, as her inspiration for the bid. He was killed in Iraq in 2004. She said would run as an independent on a platform of universal health care and making college affordable.

The federal government has banned fishing in eight sites in the Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary, off Southern California, and has limited fishing in a ninth, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced. The action adds about 110 square nautical miles of protected areas to more than 100 square nautical miles already protected by the state and creates the nation’s second-largest network of marine protected areas, after reserves in the northwest Hawaiian Islands.
The change is part of a shift to put the Department of Homeland Security in charge of the terrorist watch-list screening for all commercial flights, foreign and domestic.
A voter-approved expansion of stem cell research in the state has run into political and financial roadblocks, putting the future of the research in doubt.
The decision for the access was the result of a compromise reached by the families and the mayor’s office on this year’s commemoration of the day.
On Thursday, stocks on Wall Street suffered their biggest one-day decline since February. Indexes fell more than 2 percent across Asia in early trading today.
Lawmakers must complete legislation to help states and localities provide the ever-increasing numbers of at-risk borrowers with assistance in modifying their loans.
One can only hope that the savagery of the latest crime will at last bring the city together in a new determination to end violence.
To the Editor:.
The president’s statement that Congress should “examine how they set priorities” prompted angry volleys from Democrats.
Numerous steps are being planned that would secure the border with Mexico, speed the expulsion of illegal immigrants and step up enforcement of immigration law.
Analysts said there could be many suitors for the well-known luxury brand, which could fetch more than $1 billion.
Officials played down worries surrounding the popular heartburn drugs Prilosec and Nexium after two disturbing studies.
Eastman Kodak said its second-quarter loss from continuing operations was wider than originally reported.
The Internet telephone company Vonage Holdings said second quarter losses dropped significantly, but so did the number of new subscribers.
Chrysler officials were planning to announce that Wolfgang Bernhard would become the chairman of Chrysler, before learning that the position would be filled by Robert L. Nardelli.
Veoh, an online video-sharing site, asked a judge for pre-emptive protection from a potential copyright infringement suit by Universal Music Group.
Graeme Storm, who vaulted to the front of the 89th P.G.A. Championship at Southern Hills,  has come a long way from his job at a cake factory, cleaning trays.
Roel C. Campos, a Democratic member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, will depart in a month for the private sector.
Mitt Romney is undergoing the stiffest test yet of his effort to win over conservatives wary of his ideological credentials in the days leading  up to the Iowa Straw Poll.
The Giants have been playing out the string for months, even though playing host to the All-Star Game and Barry Bonds’s home run chase made them strangely relevant.
A limited partner in a failed hedge fund run by Bear Stearns says that the investment bank took only “meager steps” to prevent the fund’s collapse.
The medical equipment maker said it will sell Advanced Bionics to avoid future payouts that could have amounted to $2.6 billion over the next six years.
The United Nations on Thursday issued a severe warning that Gaza could face an economic meltdown with “disastrous consequences” unless its main crossings were reopened.
In a painful new reality for an important part of Iraq’s population, professionals who fled elsewhere in the Middle East are finding it difficult to make ends meet.
Consumer goods companies are using their products’ packages as 3-D ads to grab shoppers’ fickle attention.
The death toll in the bridge collapse in Minneapolis is now seven, with others still missing.
Applied Digital Solutions, maker of radio identification tags, said Thursday that it intended to acquire complete ownership of a subsidiary.
The home improvement retailer Home Deport said it was renegotiating the sale of its supply unit, probably for a lower price.
At least three other suspects  were still being sought in the murder of three young people and the wounding of a fourth.

Canadian intelligence officials anticipated that Maher Arar, a Syrian-born Canadian who was detained in New York in 2002 on suspicion of terrorism, would be shipped to a third country to be tortured, an inquiry showed.
Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo could have gained subpoena power if the state inspector general had referred the matter to Mr. Cuomo’s office during the inquiry into the governor’s aides.
The government of Kazakhstan accused an Austrian court on Thursday of ignoring irrefutable evidence in the decision not to extradite Rakhat M. Aliyev.
Shares of Block, the largest tax-return preparation company in the United States, fell nearly 4 percent on the news.
South African anti-AIDS advocates called the firing of  Nozizwe Madlala-Routledge a setback to efforts to curb the spread of AIDS.
Gen. Pervez Musharraf backed away from declaring a state of emergency after a gathering storm of pressure.
What we may be witnessing is the beginning of the tragic moment in which the ownership of America’s farmland passes from the farmer to the industrial giants.
Behind what seemed like a well-orchestrated triumph in the apparent deal to sell Barneys New York was a bitter rift between the C.E.O. and board of its owner, Jones Apparel Group.
Germany’s prosecutors should drop their attempts to intimidate their nation’s journalists.
Analysts say that economic conditions cannot take all the blame for the disappointing July numbers reported by retailers on Thursday.
Hillary Clinton, who has criticized Barack Obama for saying he would not use nuclear weapons against terrorists, made a similar comment regarding Iran last year.
A report says that in some cases, the city’s child welfare agency received warnings that children were in danger but never fully acted on that information.
The Tampa Bay Devil Rays defeated the Detroit Tigers, 8-1, on Thursday to win consecutive road games for the first time in nearly two months.
As running back Thomas Jones prepares for his first big test with the Jets, his thoughts are with Big Stone Gap, Va., his coal-mining hometown.
The agency is asking for voluntary compliance with its proposed rules banning certain marketing practices by loan companies before the rules take effect next year.
The number of newly laid-off people signing up for jobless benefits rose more than expected last week, but employment conditions remained good.

A homeless man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 40 years in prison for raping one woman and trying to rape another last year, prosecutors said. The man, James Clark Brown, 45, was convicted of rape, attempted rape and robbery on July 23, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. He said that on the morning of June 13, 2006, Mr. Brown told a woman near the post office in Springfield Gardens that he had a gun and would kill her if she did not come with him. He ordered the woman to follow, but she escaped by pretending to tie her shoe before running away. About 15 minutes later, Mr. Brown forced another woman to accompany him to a nearby garage, where he raped and robbed her, the district attorney said.
Senator Ted Stevens and his son Ben are both under federal investigation for their ties to an Alaska businessman who has confessed to bribing public officials.

A New York state trooper was shot in the leg early yesterday when a man opened fire after troopers questioned him, the state police said. The trooper, Douglas Hoffman, was shot in the left calf and treated at a hospital and released. Trooper Hoffman was shot after he and another trooper found a Toyota Camry stopped on a dirt road outside Tupper Lake about 1:30 a.m., the state police said. The man in the car, Brent Bates, 48, of Plattsburgh, opened fire on the troopers, who shot him in the chest and neck, the state police said. Mr. Bates, who was in critical condition yesterday at the Adirondack Medical Center in Saranac Lake, is expected to be charged with attempted murder, said Derek Champagne, the Franklin County district attorney.

The rail company CSX Transportation has agreed to pay to clean up the site where one of its trains derailed in March, a company official said yesterday. CSX, based in Florida, will pay $114,000 to the City of Oneida, said Gary Sease, the spokesman. Mayor Leo Matzke said the company initially offered $90,000 to the city, but Mr. Sease said the company agreed to full restitution because of the severe disruption caused by the accident, which forced the evacuation of thousands of residents. The 80-car freight train derailed on March 12, and at least five tanker cars caught fire or exploded.

After some damage to the Throgs Neck Bridge was found during an inspection, access to the bridge by oversize trucks was restricted, transit authorities announced yesterday. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said the bridge, which connects the Bronx and Queens, is safe for drivers. But after some damage was found during a twice-yearly inspection, the authority rescinded a program started two years ago to allow some heavy trucks to travel the bridge. The maximum vehicle weight for the bridge is 80,000 pounds. With the canceling of the program, overweight vehicles must now apply for special permits and travel over the bridge only at night.

Rider University’s dean of students pleaded not guilty in State Superior Court yesterday to a criminal charge in connection with the death of a freshman who was binge-drinking at a fraternity house. The dean, Anthony Campbell, is one of two university officials and three students charged with aggravated hazing following the March 30 death of Gary De Vercelly Jr., 18, of Long Beach, Calif. Mr. De Vercelly died a day after drinking at a fraternity party on the college’s campus, prosecutors said. Prosecutors have said the party was a special event at which pledges, including Mr. De Vercelly, drank with fraternity members. Mr. Campbell’s lawyer, Rocco Cipparone Jr., said his client was not at the party and did not play a role in arranging it. “I’m not aware of any set of facts and circumstances that could remotely serve as a basis for a conviction of a crime,” he said.Compiled by John Sullivan.

A Queens man convicted of trying to pay someone to kill his mother so he could collect an inheritance was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 7 ½ to 15 years in state prison, prosecutors said. The man, Joseph Salvio, pleaded guilty on July 25 to conspiracy to commit murder. Mr. Salvio, 30, of Astoria, was jailed at Rikers Island on drug possession charges in April when he tried to hire someone he thought was a hit man to kill his mother, Susan Allogramento, the Queens district attorney’s office said. The man was actually an undercover police officer. According to a handwritten statement that was read during his sentencing yesterday, Ms. Allogramento fears that her son will continue to try to have her killed. “I will be subjected to looking over my shoulder or wondering if someone is waiting for me at home, or around the corner, to do me harm,” the statement said.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday vetoed a bill intended to chip away at his administration’s ban on cellphones in public schools. The bill would allow students to transport cellphones to and from school, putting the onus on school officials to give students a place to store phones during school hours. The Department of Education is exploring the possibility of installing lockers from private vendors for cellphone storage. Mr. Bloomberg has said that cellphones disrupt learning. The City Council, which voted 46 to 2 in favor of the bill last month, is expected to override the mayor’s veto.

A 26-year-old man and an 18-year-old woman, his former companion, were found dead in Tremont early yesterday in what is being investigated as a possible murder-suicide, the police said. Police officers responding to 911 calls at 12:30 a.m. found the body of the man, Lander Jones, lying on the sidewalk outside 325 East 176th Street, the police said. Later, inside Mr. Jones’s fifth-floor apartment in the building, the police found the body of the woman, Mabelyn Arriola, who lived on the second floor. Her throat was cut and she had been stabbed several times in the back, the police said. A knife was lying on top of her body. Investigators, relying in part on witness accounts, said they believed that Mr. Jones stabbed Ms. Arriola before slitting his wrists and jumping from his apartment window, the police said. He was pronounced dead at 1:10 a.m. at St. Barnabas Hospital. Ms. Arriola, who was pronounced dead at the scene, had obtained an order of protection against Mr. Jones but had visited him in his apartment before her death, the police said.
A paradox has frustrated U.S. attempts to bring countries in the Middle East closer to the West through democracy.
A new finding may provide a basis for devising new treatments for a leading cause of blindness.
The suspended Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones appeared on television to promote his foray into professional wrestling and to dispute how many times he had been arrested.
Little “i”s have proliferated in product names and commercial brands like the iPod and iVillage.
Prosecutors said that Mitch Cozad was so obsessed with becoming Northern Colorado’s starting punter that he plunged a 5-inch-long knife into his rival’s kicking leg.
Alexis Thompson became the youngest quarterfinalist in the 107-year history of the United States Women’s Amateur.
The Manhattan Beach Open started with qualifying, but it will be without Karch Kiraly, who is retiring after this season.
Penny Hardaway, who last played an N.B.A. game in November 2005, signed with the Miami Heat.
David Beckham started on the substitute’s bench for a game between Los Angeles and D.C. United but entered the match with 20 minutes left to make his debut in Major League Soccer.
The Boston Celtics started filling in their roster around their three all-stars with the signings of center Scot Pollard and guard Eddie House.
The British government’s relaxation of the ban on the movement of livestock was a first sign that the spread of foot-and-mouth disease was coming under control.
Mr. Rich was chairman and former president of the real estate development company that led the resurgence of downtown Stamford, Conn.
John H. Johnson will become C.E.O. of ImClone Systems, maker of the colon cancer drug Erbitux.
A program that has monitored sexual Web sites for illegal material over the last several years has not resulted in a single prosecution.
Capt. Lisa Nowak says that the electronic monitoring device she is wearing as a condition of her release from jail is a personal, physical and financial hardship.
The Indians’ explosive offense from last season has been missing for several weeks, and now it is scrapping, even sacrificing, for runs.
The Long Island fisherman who is widely recognized as the inspiration for the movie “Jaws,” and its shark hunter character, Quint, still has a taste for the monsters of the deep.

The riders on the Irish horse show circuit have recently been paying attention to more than riding and jumping and, oh, mucking out stalls. They have been paying attention to one another, judging by The Irish Independent of Dublin.
The death of the commander of Robert G. Mugabe’s security guard in late June is seen by some as a signal that threats to the president’s re-election will be crushed.
Steve Nash spends most of the year running the point for the Phoenix Suns, but in the off-season he can be found playing soccer in rec leagues in New York.
The Vatican worked Thursday to minimize the significance of a brief meeting between Pope Benedict XVI and a Polish priest accused of making anti-Semitic statements.
Pilgrims said that this year, security had improved, with a strict curfew in place and Iraqi and American forces guarding a well-defined route.
Mr. Johnson combined architectural training, a love of music and acute intuition to revolutionize the quality of sound in hundreds of the world’s concert halls.
A program intended to help Hurricane Katrina victims is too secretive and strict, say critics, and its money is too limited.
AT&T blamed a vendor for cutting two lines criticizing President Bush from a Webcast of a Pearl Jam concert last weekend.
After flopping in his attempt to rejoin the St. Louis Cardinals as a pitcher, Rick Ankiel rejoined the team as an outfielder before Thursday night’s game.
Macquarie Bank of Australia had become something of a model over the last few years, but now investors are questioning the bank’s debt-heavy approach.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,673 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.

Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s super-active president, will be crossing the Atlantic twice in the space of a day, to attend a funeral in Paris on Friday and still keep his Saturday lunch date with President Bush in Maine.
Foreign Tire Sales, a New Jersey importer, issued the recall after two deaths in a rollover accident involving the tires, saying that the tire treads or belts might separate.
The move is seen by many to be part of the industry’s wider push to increase competition to iTunes and shift leverage away from Apple.
New Jersey now grants gay couples the same state benefits that married heterosexual couples receive, but that does not mean they could file their tax returns jointly for the 2006 tax year.
The furor over a magnetic levitation rail line project is a sign of a new era in which the voice of China’s growing middle class can no longer be ignored.
Christopher Dunn, the associate legal director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, has a lot to be defensive about.
The earthquake, with a magnitude of 4.6, caused no major damage.
When he hit Alex Rios in the back with a fastball, it was clear that Roger Clemens was retaliating for the Blue Jays’ actions toward Alex Rodriguez.
Serena Williams, who has been out with a thumb injury, will return to action later this month in the Pilot Pen tournament in New Haven.
Harry has a painful time in his aunt’s house, as Dudley has met a belly-dancing girl.
Harry Potter learns that Mysterious Man (Voldemort) is going to China to persuade his rival Yandomort to attack Harry as well as the Western magic world.
I would ride on my favorite flying broom, together with Hedwig and my magic wand, go-go-go.
During their time with the Chinese students, Harry, Hermione and Ron gain the courage to beat Voldemort.
Harry barges into the Dragon Palace alone to have a showdown with the Dragon King.
Harry becomes a fat, hairy dwarf after being caught in a “sour and sweet rain.”
Now what will Harry do about his two girlfriends?
Here are excerpts from the various “Harry Potter” counterfeits that have been circulating in China in the last few years, translated by The Times from Chinese.
Harry becomes a blood-lust monster. He is finally beaten by his classmates.
The area of floating ice in the Arctic has shrunk more this summer than in any other summer since satellite tracking began in 1979.
T-Mobile will continue to sponsor its cycling team despite a spate of doping scandals, and will honor a contract that runs through 2010.
Fearing that Wal-Mart could eventually undermine small retailers, some Indians are protesting the company’s plans to open 15 large wholesale outlets.
Savers used to respond to financial panics with runs on banks. Now the targets are the securities that have replaced banks as the prime generators of credit.
Michael Jennings is trying to make the Giants again, and he is trying to kindle a customized car business, for which his own vehicle is advertising.
In a memo, Justice Charles J. Markey of State Supreme Court attempts to highlight the lack of skilled sign language interpreters in the courts.
People.
To the Editor:.
The Swedish Radio Choir was superb in its performance of Fauré‘s Requiem, as was Marc-André Hamelin’s rendition of Mozart’s Sonata, at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday.
To the Editor:.

Incensed Muslims assaulted Taslima Nasreen, above left, the exiled Bangladeshi author and feminist, at a publication party at the press club in Hyderabad, India, yesterday, Reuters reported. Lawmakers and members of the All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen party, outraged by her criticisms of Islam and religion in general for oppression of women, threatened Ms. Nasreen with a chair and hurled a leather case, bunches of flowers and other objects at her while some shouted for her death. With her forehead bruised, she described the attack as barbaric before the police moved her to safety. In 1994 thousands of radical Muslims demanded Ms. Nasreen’s death for blasphemy, and she fled into exile after a court declared that she had “deliberately and maliciously” injured the religious feelings of Muslims with her Bengali-language novel “Lajja,” or “Shame,” about riots between Muslims and Hindus. The European Parliament awarded her the Sakharov Prize for freedom of thought in 1994.
Muslims attack feminist writer, two Bushes in a book deal, Luciano Pavarotti  hospitalized and more culture news.

Laura Bush and her daughter Jenna will write a children’s book for HarperCollins. The book, as yet untitled, to be published in English and Spanish in the spring, is set in a school where a mischievous little boy learns the fun of reading with the help of his teacher. An announcement yesterday from HarperCollins said the story, with illustrations by Denise Brunkus, is loosely based on the authors’ experiences as teachers. Their net proceeds and a portion of the publisher’s proceeds are to go to two national teacher programs.

Luciano Pavarotti has been hospitalized in stable condition with a fever in Modena, Italy, his hometown, The Associated Press reported. The local daily, Il Resto del Carlino, reported that he was suffering from pneumonia. Officials and his manager said Mr. Pavarotti, 71, who underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer last year, was expected to be released in a few days.

Nilas Martins, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet and the son of Peter Martins, the company’s master in chief, pleaded guilty yesterday in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to a reduced charge of disorderly conduct stemming from his arrest there on July 3, when he was charged with felony possession of cocaine. City Court Judge Douglas Mills sentenced Mr. Martins, 40, to 40 hours of community service and ordered him to undergo a drug and alcohol test. Outside of court, his lawyer, E. Stewart Jones Jr., said Mr. Martins welcomed the test. “He does not use drugs,” Mr. Jones said. “He has not used drugs. He will never, ever use drugs.” He added that Mr. Martins took the plea to protect another, unidentified person who was with him in his car when he was arrested by a passing police officer in Saratoga Springs, where the company was in summer residence.
To the Editor:.

In his heyday in the 1990s, the money manager Dana Giacchetto charmed clients like Leonardo DiCaprio and Tobey Maguire, the band Phish and Michael Ovitz — until he was caught defrauding them, for which he served about three years of a nearly five-year prison sentence. Last year Robert L. Geltzer, the court-appointed trustee for Mr. Giacchetto’s bankrupt company, Cassandra Group, unearthed a book deal in which Mr. Giacchetto was to split the proceeds with Emily White, his biographer. Mr. Geltzer sued, and in a settlement to be filed with bankruptcy court today, Mr. Giacchetto, 44, has turned over his stake in her book, “You Will Make Money in Your Sleep: The Story of Dana Giacchetto, Financial Adviser to the Stars,” and the rights to his life story in any film or television production to satisfy claims against Cassandra Group. Whether the settlement will raise much money is doubtful. The book has sold only 300 copies since its June publication by Scribner, according to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks about 70 percent of retail sales. tvjobs.com.

The New York Philharmonic will admit the public free to Avery Fisher Hall at 9:45 a.m. on Sept. 18 for the dress rehearsal of its gala opening night concert. Lorin Maazel, the music director, will rehearse the ensemble in an all-Dvorak program, including the Cello Concerto, featuring Yo-Yo Ma; the “Carnival Overture”; and Symphony No. 7. Tickets will be distributed on a first-come-first-served basis, beginning at 8 a.m. in front of the hall.
To the Editor:.

Van Halen, re-formed around its original frontman, David Lee Roth, will embark on a 50-date North American tour in October, The Associated Press reported, citing Billboard Magazine’s Web site, www.billboard.com. Neither the band nor the touring company Live Nation would confirm the report, but the band sent out a news release promising “an announcement of monumental proportions” at a news conference on Monday in Los Angeles, The A.P. said. Van Halen has not toured with Mr. Roth in more than 20 years.

10 P.M. (ABC) PASTOR TO POWER: BILLY GRAHAM AND THE PRESIDENTS He has preached to more people than anyone in history and offered spiritual guidance to some of the world’s most powerful men. This “20/20” special explores the Rev. Billy Graham’s ties to 11 presidential administrations, both Republican and Democratic — from Harry S. Truman’s to George W. Bush’s — through interviews with former presidents and first ladies whom he served as a confidant, offering counsel on everything, from war to the existence of heaven. In a round-table discussion, from left above, Bill Clinton; Mr. Graham; Charles Gibson, the moderator; Jimmy Carter; and George H. W. Bush reflect on their friendships. Nancy Reagan, Barbara Bush and Hillary Rodham Clinton, who sought advice during the Monica Lewinsky scandal, also discuss their relationships with Mr. Graham, now 88. “I thought of them as just wonderful human beings who were wonderful personal friends as I knew them, each one,” he tells Mr. Gibson. “Pastor to Power” coincides with the publication of “The Preacher and the Presidents” by Nancy Gibbs and Michael Duffy of Time magazine.

BY and large musical Minimalists don't carry cards. But they do know something about guilt by association. Most composers commonly called Minimalists have disavowed the label at one point or another, suggesting that it mischaracterizes their music, which can be mind-bogglingly intricate -- and huge. And they certainly don't consider themselves part of a school. The designation arose mainly from the friendships of composers with Minimalist artists: Steve Reich and Philip Glass, for example, with the sculptor Richard Serra.

'RENT' In the 11 years since ''Rent'' opened on Broadway, much has changed in the world that its writer, Jonathan Larson, described. For one thing, many more medications than AZT are available for people with AIDS, and while too many people still die from its complications, a lot live with the disease as well. Plenty has changed in 11 years at the Nederlander Theater, too. ''Rent'' will surpass 4,700 performances this week, and 14 Rogers and 6 Marks (and scores of understudies) have come along since those roles were originated by Adam Pascal, above right, and Anthony Rapp, above left, who left the show within months of each other in late 1997 and early 1998. Though they went on to perform in the London production and revisited the roles in the 2005 film version, neither returned to the Broadway show.

HANSEN--William Prehn Jr. , of Chester, CT, died August 6, 2007. He was 68. Mr. Hansen was a municipal bond market pioneer who loyally served his firm, JPMorgan Chase, for over 44 years. He was instrumental in groundbreaking transactions that helped keep the State of California solvent during fiscal crises in the early 1980s, in 1994, and in 2001. Mr. Hansen began his career at Morgan Guaranty Trust in February 1963. After moving up the ranks in the bank's corporate side of the business and after being promoted to Vice President in 1974, he joined the firm's fledgling municipal credit group in 1977. There he was instrumental in establishing both the first variable-rate demand bonds via a put agreement and the first conditional liquidity facility for a tax-exempt bond that was not an irrevocable letter of credit (known today as the standby bond purchase agreement). He was named Executive Director in 2007, and retired in July 2007. Mr. Hansen took tremendous pride in working on financial transactions that supported the public sector. Mr. Hansen was born on March 6, 1939, in Port Chester, NY, to William Prehn Hansen and Jane Barbour Hansen. Nicknamed ''Wink'', he grew up in Greenwich, CT attending The Greenwich Country Day School, where his mother taught kindergarten. He graduated from The Choate School in 1957, and from Dartmouth College in 1961. He was a member of the Sigma Chi fraternity. Mr. Hansen found peace and happiness relaxing at his 19th century farmhouse in Chester, CT. He called his home Six Brothers Farm, a tribute to his six sons. He is survived by Nancy Cliggott Hansen, and by his six boys: Matthew, his wife Rasha and their children Leith and Lara; Geoffrey, his wife Linda and their daughter Skylar; Michael, his wife Jennifer and their son Nathan; William III and his wife Shannon; Richard; and Joseph. A funeral service will be held at 9:00 AM, August 10, 2007 at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich. Memorial gifts may be made to The Greenwich Country Day School in memory of William Hansen '53, c/o The Alumni Office, PO Box 623, Greenwich, CT 06836.

She was initially a volunteer and then full time vice president of The Women's American ORT which built vocational schools for Jews in Israel, Eastern Europe, and North Africa. She travelled extensively in support of its mission. She had a second career as an Associate Professor at New York University School of Education as a designer of the Head Start program and worked tirelessly to further its success. She was a vigorous supporter of the Arts in New York City. She is survived by David, her husband of 68 years, her children, Andrew Saxe and Elizabeth Andoh, grandchildren, Rena Andoh, and Adam, Benjamin and Sarah Saxe, nephews David and Michael Sculnick. We will miss this remarkable, loyal, loving woman. Kindly direct contributions to ORT America, 75 Maiden Lane, New York, NY 10038.

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the increasing strength of the Russian ruble misstated its appreciation against the American dollar in the last few years. It has appreciated by about 25.5 percent, not 20 percent. (The dollar has depreciated by 20 percent against the ruble.) The article also misstated the year the Soviet Union collapsed. It was 1991, not 1990.

An article on Sunday about energy legislation approved by the House of Representatives incorrectly described a provision involving light bulbs. The measure requires that by the year 2020 all bulbs be three times more efficient than current ordinary bulbs; it does not require them to be 300 times more efficient.

Fox's ''Don't Forget the Lyrics'' posted Wednesday's top ratings among adults 18 to 49, as the network led the night in that demographic. CBS won in total viewers, as its ''Criminal Minds'' rerun tied the lyrics game show with 8.8 million viewers in the 9 o'clock hour, according to Nielsen's estimates. At 8, Fox's ''So You Think You Can Dance'' (7.6 million) ranked No. 1 in the 18 to 49 set, while the official time-period premiere of CBS's ''Power of 10'' earned a slightly larger audience in the hour (7.8 million). NBC finished third for the night in total viewers but edged out CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49.

Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Tuesday about the events leading up to a home invasion robbery in Cheshire, Conn., that left a woman and her two daughters dead referred incorrectly to multiple sclerosis, which the woman, Jennifer Hawke-Petit, had been battling for eight years. It is a disease of the central nervous system, not the muscles.

DREW--George W. , 80, a member of America's first stage family, died July 8, 2007. A child actor/singer who later attended a Theatre Academy and graduated from Pratt Institute with a degree in fashion design. On Broadway he was in ''Kiss and Tell'' (followed by a USO tour of same in the South Pacific) and ''The Relapse'', transferred from the Brattle Theatre in Cambridge. He was part of a vaudeville trio that enjoyed three separate engagements at NY's Palace Theater. Off Broadway he designed productions of ''A Tenth of an Inch Makes A Difference'' and the musical ''My Old Friends.'' For live TV he codesigned ''Mayerling'' staring Audrey Hepburn. He designed costumes for many soap operas, most notably ''One Life to Live'' (for which he received an Emmy nomination), and TV series ''Patty Duke Show'', ''The Trials of O'Brien'' with Peter Falk, and the Peabody Award winning ''Go Show, USA.'' George chose wardrobe for Barbara Walters and later Lynn Redgrave for the daytime series ''Not For Women Only'' and ''Late Night with David Letterman.'' He appeared in and designed the costumes for ''An Evening of Highlights'' with Beatrice Lillie. With John and Mimi Mitchell and Robert Epstein, George formed the Institute for Advanced Studies in Theatre Arts, his most satisfying accomplishment. He is survived by his life partner of 43 years, Gary Gagnon.

RICH--Frank D., Jr. , 83, longtime chairman of the F. D. Rich Company, Stamford's primary urban redeveloper, and founder and current chairman of the Stamford Center for the Arts, passed away on August 7, 2007 at his home in Darien, CT. He was born in Stamford, CT on July 4, 1924, to the late Frank D. Rich and Mary C. Rich. Mr. Rich attended Stamford public schools, graduating from Stamford High School, Class of 1941, attended Cornell University, and graduated from Princeton University in 1945 with a B.S. in Engineering. He served as 1st Lieutenant in the Marine Corps during World War II and the Korean Conflict, with assignments which included the Mediterranean and China. Upon returning from the service, Mr. Rich began his business career with F. D. Rich Company, developing and building a broad range of construction projects spanning the U.S., including Alaska, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, including Stamford's urban renewal project. Mr. Rich's civic and philanthropic contributions were many. He was a trustee of the LowHeywood Thomas School from 1960-1969 and board president from 1968-1975, a director of the Stamford Museum and Nature Center from 1971-1984 and board president from 1973-1976, a director of Stamford State Opera and successor, Connecticut Grand Opera from 1973-1992 and board president from 1979-1992. He served as a trustee at the University of CT from 1974-1993, and vice chair from 1975-1992, and also a director of the University of CT Foundation from 1974-1980. He was a trustee of the Connecticut Public Expenditure Council in Hartford from 1976-1982. Mr. Rich was founder of Stamford Center for the Arts, served as president (1978-1999) and chairman from 1989 to the time of his death. From 1978-1996, he served as a director of St. Joseph Medical Center in Stamford. In 1979, Mr. Rich became a trustee of The Ferguson Library and later vice chairman and chairman from 1999-2000. In 1980, Mr. Rich became of member of the Governor's Heritage Task Force. Mr. Rich was a director of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association (SACIA) from 1981-1992. He also served as a director of Connecticut Public Broadcasting from 1982-1992. From 1985-1993, Mr. Rich was on the regional board of directors for the National Conference of Christians and Jews in Hartford, CT. Mr. Rich served as a director of the New England Foundation for the Arts in Cambridge, MA from 1986-1996. He also served at Yale New-Haven Hospital from 1989-1994. Mr. Rich became a director of New England Lyric Operetta in 1993. In 1999, the Rich Concourse at the UConn Stamford Campus was dedicated in his honor along with his father, F. D. Rich, Sr. and his brother, Robert. Mr. Rich and his brother established the Rich Fund for the CT Information Technology Institute at the Stamford campus and the Mary C. Rich Scholarship in honor of their mother. A born inventor, Frank Rich's foreign and domestic patents included a building employing prefabricated room-enclosed modules which were used in hotel and housing projects throughout the country. His professional affiliations included the American Assn. of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta, where he was ordained a Knight of Malta at St. Patrick's Cathedral in 1990, he was a life member of the American Society of Civil Engineers, the First Friday Group, Washington, DC from 1987-1994, the Economic Club of New York where he was a member from 1988-1992, and Chi Epsilon, the National Civil Engineering Honor Society. Mr. Rich was awarded numerous honors during his lifetime, including receiving the 1984 ''National Human Relations Award'' from the National Council of Christians and Jews, the ''Silver Hope Chest Award'' from the Multiple Sclerosis Society in 1985, the ''University Service Award'' from the UConn Alumni Association in 1986. He received the 1986 ''Stamford Citizen of the Year Award'' from the Jewish War Veterans, Fred Robbins Post No. 142, and the ''Building a Better Connecticut'' Association award from the Associated General Contractors of CT in 1988. In 1990, Mr. Rich received his honorary ''Doctorate of Humane Letters'' at Sacred Heart University, and with the Rich family received the American Heart Association's 2001 Gold Heart Award for southwestern CT. In 1991, Mr. Rich received the ''Angel Award'' at the International Society of Performing Arts Administrators Conference at the United Nations. Stamford Center for the Arts honored Mr. Rich and the Rich Family with the Star Award at the gala opening of Rich Forum in 1992. He was presented with the 1992 ''Connecticut Arts Award'' by the Connecticut Commission on the Arts. He was the recipient of the ''University Medal'' from the University of Connecticut in 1994. The March of Dimes honored Mr. Rich and the Rich Family with their 1997 ''Real Estate Award,'' and he was also the recipient of the 1998 Rotary Club of Stamford's ''Paul Harris Award.'' At commencement exercises at the University of CT in 1999, he was conferred the degree of Doctor of Laws, ''honoris causa.'' The Stamford Symphony Orchestra honored Mr. Rich at their Gala benefit in 2000. Along with his brother, Mr. Rich was inducted into the SHS Wall of Fame for exemplary accomplishments. In 2001, Mr. Rich received the ''Distinguished Advocate for the Arts Award'' from the Connecticut Commission on the Arts. He was married for 58 years to Jean Annabelle Hopkins, who survives him, along with his six children, Lisa Rich Coats of Palm City, Florida, Laura Rowland of Darien, Susan Rich Mailman of Stamford, F. D. Rich III of New Canaan, Robin Fulton of Hilton Head, SC, and Charles Rich of Suwanee, GA, and thirteen grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother, Robert N. Rich of Stamford, nephews Christopher Rich of Salem, VA, Thomas L. Rich of Stamford, and nieces Priscilla Rich of Boone, NC, and Martha Andrus of Boulder, CO. His niece, Amy L. Rich predeceased him. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Saturday, August 11, 2007 at 9:30am at Sacred Heart Church, 37 Schuyler Avenue, Stamford, CT. Burial will follow in Fairfield Memorial Park in Stamford. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made in the name of Frank D. Rich, Jr. to the Stamford Health Foundation, Nine West Broad St., Stamford, CT 06902 or to American Parkinsons Disease Association, CT Chapter, 27 Allendale Rd., North Haven, CT 06473.

MORTGAGE CRISIS SPREADING Turmoil in the home loan market ricocheted from the United States to Europe and back again as stocks on Wall Street suffered their biggest one-day decline since February, reflecting growing concerns about tightening credit worldwide. During the panics of J. P. Morgan's day, investors made runs on banks. Now the targets are the securities that have replaced banks as the prime generators of credit. News Analysis. [C1.]
The Really? column in Science Times on Tuesday misstated one of the compounds that block UVA radiation and are frequently found in sunscreens. It is avobenzone, not avobenzene.

'BOLLYWOOD IN BROOKLYN' The first time Rekha Malhotra, better known as DJ Rekha, saw the 1977 Bollywood movie ''Hum Kisi Se Kum Nahin'' (''We're Not Less Than Anyone,'' her translation), she was 7 and living in New Delhi. Even then she was struck by the main dance sequence, an 11-minute montage set up as a competition between two characters; they battle on the dance floor for the love of an heiress. ''The lead actor wears a one-piece feathered jumpsuit and has a big glowing heart around his neck,'' Ms. Malhotra, above, said, giggling. ''It's classic '70s Bollywood.''

TRISHA BROWN DANCE COMPANY In its effort to relive the Summer of Love, Lincoln Center Out of Doors has gathered a host of performers who made their marks in the 1960s. One is Trisha Brown, who, as a member of the performance nexus surrounding the Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village, fundamentally expanded and subverted our definitions of dance. Despite the wondrous sensuality of her movement, the rigor of Ms. Brown's choreographic sensibility hardly brings to mind the Swinging Sixties. Not to mention the fact that she has said that it took her years to free herself of the rigid new dictates that so often accompany revolutionary movements in order to create the kinds of dances she wanted to create rather than those that were expected of a Judson alumna. Some people have never forgiven her forays into opera: it's not easy being categorized as a ''postmodern dance icon.'' But never mind the adjectives (especially in dance, which can't seem to agree on its historical labels). Ms. Brown's essential artistic core remains as curious and restless as ever, and this free performance offers several decades' worth of proof, from ''Accumulation'' (1971) to ''Present Tense,'' left, created in 2003. (Tuesday at 8 p.m., Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, (212) 875-5766, lincolncenter.org.) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the increasing strength of the Russian ruble misstated its appreciation against the American dollar in the last few years. It has appreciated by about 25.5 percent, not 20 percent. (The dollar has depreciated by 20 percent against the ruble.) The article also misstated the year the Soviet Union collapsed. It was 1991, not 1990.

DORMAN--John (Jack) A., IV , of Ridgewood, NJ passed away at the age of 68 at Valley Hospital on August 9, 2007. Jack was born and raised in Rutherford, NJ. He was president of the Rutherford High School class of 1957. Following his graduation from Lafayette College in 1961, he rose through the ranks to become the president of Chemical Bank of New Jersey and retired as president of loans at Independence Bank of Newark, NJ. He retired in 2005 after a successful career of 44 years in banking. He was a trustee of the Northern New Jersey Chapter of the Leukemia Society of America, a member of the Montclair State College Advisory Board of the Friends of the School of Fine and Performing Arts, the Cooper's Ferry Development Association of Camden NJ, and the Bergen Council of Boy Scouts of America. Jack was an active member of the Lafayette College Alumni association and a longtime member of the Rutherford Elks BPOE 547. He was a parishioner at Mount Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood NJ. Jack is survived by his loving wife of 47 years Marylou (Burke) Dorman, his children John A. Dorman V. (Ridgewood, NJ), Kathleen A. Dorman (Denver, CO), Douglas A. Dorman and wife Roxanne D. Dorman (Kitty Hawk, NC), Elizabeth (Amy) A. Fralley and husband Drew G. Fralley and grandsons Kyle and Tyler Fralley (Waldwick NJ). He is also survived by his brothers Thomas (Ted) E. Dorman (Sanibel Island, Fl) , Jerry M. Dorman (Kitty Hawk, NC), and William J. Dorman and sister-in-law Susan Dorman (Landisville, PA) and sisterin-law Kathleen E. Dorman (Oneida, NY). He was preceded in death by his loving brother Richard P. Dorman and sister Barbara G. McCarty. Also surviving are 13 nieces and nephews and their spouses. Friends may visit with the family on Friday August 10th from 2 to 4 p.m. and 7 to 9 p.m. at Vander Plaat Funeral Home, 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ www.vpfh.com. Mass will be held on Saturday August 11th at 9:30 a.m. at Mount Carmel RC Church, 1 Passaic Street, Ridgewood, NJ. Interment will follow in the Redeemer Cemetery in Mahwah. In lieu of flowers, charitable contributions may be made to American Cancer Society, Bergen unit, 20 Mercer St., Hackensack, NJ 07601, or Lafayette College, Development Office, 307 Merkle Hall, Easton, PA 18042.

SCHEIDT--Dr. Stephen Slaton of New York City died of prostate cancer Tuesday August 7 surrounded by his family on Whidbey Island, WA. He was 67 years old. Adored husband and best friend of Andrea for 42 years. Remarkable irreplaceable father of Leslie and Vivian. Beloved grandfather and gifted storyteller to James, Andrew, Gabrielle and Sophie. Admired father-in-law of Tom and Ammi. Supportive brother of Peter Slaton. Cherished son of the late Egon and Lelo Slaton, dearly loved adopted son of the late Erna and Max Scheidt. Graduate of Princeton University and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Fullbright Fellow at the University of Wurzburg, Germany. An internationally recognized cardiologist and professor at New York-Weill Cornell Medical Center since 1970. An admired colleague, inspiring teacher, generous mentor and kind friend to many. He received the Elliott Hochstein Teaching Award from Cornell University Medical College in 1980. He is the co-director of the Salzburg-Cornell seminars and received the Silver Medal for Science and Technology from the Austrian Government. A memorial will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th & Amsterdam Ave at 1:15 pm, August 20. In his honor, contributions to support the Cardiology Fellowship program can be directed to Division of Cardiology, NYPHC, re: Dr. Stephen Scheidt, STARR 465, 520 E. 70th St., NY, NY 10021. A front-page article yesterday about the relationship between President Bush and his father, George Herbert Walker Bush, misstated some dates in the history of the only other father and son elected to the presidency of the United States. John Quincy Adams was inaugurated on March 4, 1825, which was 24 years -- not 28 -- after his father, John Adams, left office. John Adams died in July 1826, which was 16 months -- not 18 -- after his son's inauguration.

MILBANK--Jeremiah . The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of Mr. Jeremiah Milbank, our former Chairman, Life Member of our National Board of Governors, friend, advocate and a true champion for children. Mr. Milbank's half-century of involvement with Boys & Girls Clubs of America began with his father, Jeremiah Sr., a longtime leader of our cause, and President Herbert Hoover, who recruited a young Jerry Milbank to our national board. During Mr. Milbank's tenure as chairman, BGCA became one of the first youth organizations to serve children in public housing. Today we have more than 400 Clubs in these communities thanks to Mr. Milbank, a man of humility and humanity. Under his guidance we greatly expanded the size and scope of Club services and changed our name to reflect service to young women. In his honor, we established the Jeremiah Milbank Gold Medallion to recognize excellence among Boys & Girls Club volunteers. We will miss him greatly, but Mr. Milbank's positive influence will be felt for years to come. His legacy lives on through his sons Jeremiah III and Joseph, who continue a Milbank family tradition of service to Boys & Girls Clubs of America that spans three generations. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Rick Goings, Chairman Roxanne Spillett, President MILBANK--Jeremiah Jr. The Boards of Directors and staff of The JM Foundation and Milbank Foundation for Rehabilitation are deeply saddened by the loss of Jeremiah ''Jerry'' Milbank, Jr., formerly of Greenwich, CT, and more recently a resident of Charlottesville, VA, who died Tuesday, August 7, 2007. One of our nation's great civic leaders and philanthropists, he was beloved by family and friends and universally respected among colleagues in business and philanthropy. Voluntary service and a strong belief in limited government were guiding principles of Jerry's life. For over 35 years, he led The JM Foundation as President and President Emeritus and was a Founding Director of the Milbank Foundation for Rehabilitation. Among his other leadership roles were: Trustee, President, and Chairman of Boys & Girls Clubs of America; President of ICD-International Center for the Disabled; Chairman of Boy & Girls Clubs of Greenwich; and Trustee of the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace; the Herbert Hoover Foundation; the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation; the Advisory Committee on Presidential Libraries; the National Forum Foundation; Taft Institute for Government; the Dole Foundation for Employment of People with Disabilities; the National Council on Disability; Round Hill Community Church; and dozens of other local and national organizations. Jerry's kindness and generosity helped millions of Americans. His philanthropic spirit enabled him to serve many charitable organizations with great distinction, earning numerous awards and honors, such as President Ronald Reagan's Volunteer Action Award, the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award from Boys & Girls Clubs of America, the National Society of Fund Raising Executives Philanthropist of the Year Award, Rutgers University National Distinguished Service Award, the Harold Russell Award from the President's Committee on Employment of People with Disabilities, Kessler Institute's Human Dignity Award, the National Rehabilitation Institute Advocacy Award, the National Leadership Award of the Alcohol and Drug Problems Association of North America, the National Commission Against Drunk Driving Chairman's Award, the R. Brinkley Smithers Award of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence, and the Womens National Republican Award. Jerry Milbank graduated from Yale in 1942, served in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific during World War II, and earned his M.B.A. from Harvard after the war. In 1948, he began working in private finance and investments with his father. He served on a number of corporate Boards, including the Chase Manhattan Bank. He was awarded Honorary Doctorate Degrees by Sacred Heart University, Ithaca College, and Manhattan College. A lifelong Republican, he served as Chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee and founded the Republican Eagles. He is survived by the four children from his 35-year marriage to the late Andrea Hunter Milbank: Jeremiah Milbank III, Victoria Milbank Whitney, Elizabeth Milbank Archer, and Joseph Hunter Milbank, as well as ten grandchildren. He is also survived by his wife, Mary Rockefeller Milbank. We mourn Mr. Milbank's passing and pledge ourselves to the ideals he championed throughout his life. Contributions in Jeremiah Milbank's memory can be made to Boys & Girls Clubs of America c/o Roxanne Spillett, President, B&GCA National Headquarters, 1275 Peachtree Street, NE, Atlanta, GA 30309. MILBANK--Jeremiah Jr. The Board of Trustees, staff and clients of ICD-International Center for the Disabled are deeply saddened at the death of Jeremiah Milbank, Jr. He provided extraordinary vision and committed leadership to our organization for many decades, and was both a generous friend and benefactor. He will be greatly missed by everyone in the ICD family. We offer our deepest sympathy to all members of his family, and to his numerous good friends.

After hitting Toronto's Alex Rios in the back with a fastball on Tuesday, the Yankees' Roger Clemens did not try to claim innocence. It was clear that Clemens was retaliating for the Blue Jays' actions toward Alex Rodriguez, and Major League Baseball agreed Thursday. Bob Watson, baseball's vice president for on-field operations, suspended Clemens for five games and Manager Joe Torre for one. Torre will serve his suspension Friday, when the Yankees play the Indians at Jacobs Field.

'ELGAR AND HIS WORLD' Edward Elgar's music (like that of many composers) has fallen in and out of fashion over the years. One hundred and fifty years after his birth, Elgar, above, the English composer primarily known for works like his ''Pomp and Circumstance'' marches, ''Enigma'' Variations and haunting Cello Concerto, is being thoroughly revisited. One of the most in-depth explorations on either side of the Atlantic begins tonight at the Bard Music Festival, where three weekends will be devoted to ''Elgar and His World.'' There is nowhere better than the Bard Festival, which makes a practice of offering intense lineups of performances, pre-concert talks, panels and lectures, to re-examine misunderstood composers. Leon Botstein, the American Symphony Orchestra and a host of other musicians and scholars will play and discuss music by Elgar and a wide array of his predecessors and contemporaries, performing his well-known works as well as less frequently heard ones like the Symphony No. 2. The festival opens tonight with a program called ''Elgar: From Autodidact to 'Master of the King's Musick.' '' Tomorrow, performers including the Daedalus Quartet, the baritone Thomas Meglioranza and the pianist Simone Dinnerstein participate in ''Music in the Era of Queen Victoria,'' playing works by Johann Baptist Cramer, William Sterndale Bennett and Elgar. Later that day Mr. Botstein will lead the American Symphony in Elgar's ''Enigma'' Variations and his Funeral March from ''Grania and Diarmid,'' and Hubert Parry's Symphonic Variations. The opening weekend wraps up on Sunday afternoon with works for brass and strings by Elgar, Richard Strauss, Vaughan Williams and John Ireland. (Opens tonight at 8 at Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., 845-758-7900, fishercenter.bard.edu; $20 to $55.) VIVIEN SCHWEITZER

Less than half of the nation's teenagers aged 16 to 19 are working this summer. The percentage holding summer jobs, 42 percent, slid to its lowest level since World War II. Fifty-three percent of teenagers were working in 2000; a decade earlier, 60 percent were, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Experts see many explanations for this decline. For example, immigrants are taking many jobs, like mowing lawns, once held by teenagers. More Americans over age 60 are staying in the work force in part-time jobs. The nation has lost three million manufacturing jobs since 2000. Meanwhile, many students take summer courses. In light of these numbers and explanations, what is your take on teenagers and summer work? Go to Article

An article on Wednesday about the Israeli government’s eviction of Jewish settlers from houses they had been illegally occupying in the West Bank city of Hebron referred incorrectly to the ownership of the property. While Israel recognizes pre-1967 Palestinian leases to the property and does not allow Jews to violate those leases by living or squatting there, the property is considered by Israel to be owned by Jews who bought it before the nation was founded in 1948, and not owned by Palestinians.

Because of an editing error, a report from The Associated Press and a subheading in the baseball roundup in some copies on Thursday about Wednesday’s game between Baltimore and Seattle reversed the outcome. The Mariners won, 8-4 — not the Orioles.

A shootout at a hotel in the main square of Bastrop in northeastern Louisiana left two police officers and one suspect dead, and the authorities were searching for another suspect, officials said. Two paramedics were also hit by gunfire when they arrived at the scene, said Trooper Mark Dennis, a spokesman for the Louisiana State Police. One was in stable condition, and the other was not seriously hurt, Trooper Dennis said. It was not immediately clear what sparked the shooting, or whether the suspect was killed in the initial shootout or by officers who arrived later, Trooper Dennis said. Bastrop is about 100 miles east of Shreveport.

Minnesota will immediately receive $50 million in federal money to help pay for recovery and cleanup efforts and for design work on a bridge to replace the Interstate 35W span that collapsed on Aug. 1, Secretary of Transportation Mary E. Peters said. State officials say they are racing to build a bridge that can be open by the end of next year; the loss of the old bridge — the most heavily traveled in the state — has created traffic tie-ups in downtown Minneapolis and for thousands of commuters near the city. The $50 million in immediate financing is part of $250 million that Congress approved last week to replace the bridge. Divers recovered another body in the wreckage, bringing the death toll to at least eight.

The Illinois House is defying Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich and his call for another special session on the budget. Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat, does not like the budget that lawmakers sent him, so he ordered the legislature to pass a temporary budget this weekend. But Speaker Michael J. Madigan, a Democrat, told members to ignore the governor’s order and to go home indefinitely, even though the state budget has not been settled.

A Broward County sheriff’s deputy was killed in the second shooting of a Broward deputy in the line of duty this week, the authorities said. The deputy, identified as Sgt. Chris Reyka, 51, was on routine patrol when he became suspicious of two cars in a parking lot behind a drugstore in Pompano Beach. As Sergeant Reyka got out of his car to investigate, someone jumped out of one of the cars and shot him several times before fleeing, according to a statement issued by the sheriff’s office. The shooting of Sergeant Reyka, an 18-year veteran of the force, comes four days after Maury Hernandez, an undercover Broward County sheriff’s deputy, was critically injured when he was shot in the head by a motorcyclist he had pulled over for running several red lights.

Gov. Chet Culver said the state’s 2008 caucuses, which traditionally begin the presidential nominating process, would be held in January. As South Carolina and other states consider moving up their contests, the prospect was raised that the Iowa caucuses could take place before the end of this year. “We’re not going in December; it just doesn’t make sense,” said Mr. Culver, left. New Hampshire’s secretary of state, William M. Gardner, has yet to announce a date for his state’s primary. Iowa law calls for the caucuses to come seven days before the New Hampshire primary, but Iowa officials said they would consider changing that law to keep the traditional one-two punch of Iowa and New Hampshire alive. “In this state, we’re going to still have Christmas,” Mr. Culver said.

Three men being carried in a construction bucket fell out and plunged 500 feet to their death in an air shaft at a coal mine, the authorities said. No one else was injured, said George Zugel, director of safety and health for Frontier-Kemper Constructors, which is building the 550-foot vertical ventilation shaft at the Gibson County Coal mine in southern Indiana. The open-top bucket was somehow upset as it was descending in the shaft, and the three men fell out, Mr. Zugel said. The “sinking bucket” can hold 6 to 10 people and is about six feet high, said a worker, John Ervin. The mine is about 30 miles north of Evansville.
Mayor C. Ray Nagin said that he worried that killings in New Orleans make the city seem dangerous, but that news of such crimes “keeps the New Orleans brand out there.”

A federal appeals court again threw out the two-decades-old death sentence of a United States-British citizen convicted of killing a toddler in an apartment fire. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, which was ordered by the United States Supreme Court to reconsider its 2005 ruling in favor of Kenneth Richey, again found that he had received ineffective counsel in his murder trial. The court said Ohio had 90 days to give Mr. Richey a new trial or his freedom. Mr. Richey, 43, was convicted of aggravated murder and sentenced to die for setting the 1986 fire that killed 2-year-old Cynthia Collins in Columbus Grove in northwest Ohio. He has maintained his innocence and drawn support for years, including from members of the British Parliament and the late Pope John Paul II.
With quarterback Michael Vick gone indefinitely, the Falcons must plan for a future without his dazzling offensive skills and his burdensome personal issues.

A Kenyan judge acquitted four men accused of killing a British wildlife filmmaker and naturalist in her home, ruling that the investigation was “poorly done.”
South Africa’s former deputy health minister, fired this week by President Thabo Mbeki, said her ouster was unjustified.
At least 35 of the 226 people killed in this year’s monsoon have died of snake bites, the government of Bangladesh said.
Cuba released its longest-serving political prisoner, Francisco Chaviano González, who spent more than 13 years in jail, the country’s main human rights group said.

International nuclear inspectors said it would take up to a year for a nuclear power plant damaged during last month’s earthquake in Niigata Prefecture to restart operations, echoing an assessment by Japanese experts.
Two top Taliban leaders and four South Korean officials met face to face to negotiate over the fate of 21 members of a South Korean church group held hostage for three weeks, Afghan officials said.

Jeff Gordon started from the back of the field in Nascar’s first road race of the Nextel Cup season after his team was penalized for a technical violation. This time, he will start from the pole. Rain at Watkins Glen International became too heavy by midafternoon and forced Nascar to cancel qualifying for tomorrow’s Centurion Boats at The Glen. Qualifying has been rained out three times in the past four years at Watkins Glen. The top 35 cars in the 43-car field were set by points, so the points leader, Gordon, was placed up front.

Chicago Coach Denis Savard received a contract extension through the 2008-9 season. He has been the team’s coach since November, when Trent Yawney was fired. He finished the season with a 24-30-7 record. General Manager Dale Tallon said he was impressed with Savard, a Hall of Fame player who spent much of his career with the Blackhawks.

Laura Halldorson is stepping down as the women’s coach at the University of Minnesota after guiding the team to three national titles in 11 years. The university said she had been considering the move for some time because of the job’s demands. Halldorson’s teams won titles in 2000, 2004 and 2005. She was two years into a three-year contract extension. The Gophers finished 23-12-1 last season.

Donna Lopiano resigned as chief executive of the Women’s Sports Foundation, which she led for 15 years. The foundation, one of the foremost advocacy groups for women in athletics, was founded by the tennis great Billie Jean King in 1974, two years after the passage of Title IX. The foundation will be run by the senior officers Tuti Scott and Marjorie Snyder until a new C.E.O. is named.
Lawmakers were told in July that eavesdropping on certain communications had fallen by 75 percent, helping to set off a furious legislative rush.
A federal judge ruled that Novell, not the SCO Group, is the rightful owner of the copyrights covering the Unix operating system, removing a cloud over open-source software.

An article on Monday about how a case against a Brooklyn mother accused of leaving two small children unattended in a full bathtub illustrates the fine line prosecutors must walk in distinguishing between criminal neglect and irresponsible parenting referred incorrectly to one of the two charges against the woman, Jovanna Shiriver. The charge, endangering the welfare of a child, is a misdemeanor, not a felony. (The other charge against Ms. Shiriver, reckless endangerment, is a felony.)

SAPERSTEIN--Stanley, M.D. (a.k.a. Shep) , age 72, died August 8, 2007 in Southbury, CT. He is survived by his beloved wife, Eleanor, of 50 years, his devoted children, Mara Weissmann (Richard) and Aaron (Jane Margolis), his four grandsons, Gabriel, Asher, Jesse and Noah, and a brother, Michael of Manhattan. A man of small physical stature but large in everyway. He saved lives, enhanced people and loved his family and life. We lost a giant of a person. Funeral services will be held at United Jewish Center, 141 Deerhill Ave., Danbury, CT 06810 on Sunday, August 12 at 11:00am.

TOWAR--Barbara T. , 78, of Exmore, Virginia, formerly of New York passed away Wednesday, August 8th, 2007 from complications of multiple myeloma. Barbara was raised in Grosse Pointe, MI. A graduate of the University of Michigan, she moved to New York City and worked as an in-house and free-lance copy editor for several major publishers. She was a member of the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship of the Eastern Shore of Virginia. Barbara is survived by her life partner of 35 years, Lucille Stoffregen, and by several cousins. Honoring the wishes of Barbara, there will be no public service. Memorials in her memory may be made to Hospice of the Eastern Shore, PO Box 316, Parksley, VA 23421. Online condolences may be sent to the family at doughtyfuneralhome.com Services held by Doughty Funeral Home, Exmore.

SHAW--James T., Jr. James T. Shaw, Jr. , retired ABC Television Executive, passed away on August 5, 2007 in Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. Born in 1923 in Gary, Indiana, he graduated from the University of Indiana and served in the U.S. Army during World War II. His career was in television broadcasting, beginning as an independent producer of Saturday morning television shows. He rose to be Vice President of Sales for the ABC Television Network during its heyday era of the 70s and 80s, and went on to be President of the International Television Council. He and his loving wife Margaret lived in Sagaponack, Long Island until 1995, when they moved to Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida. Margaret passed away in 2005. James Shaw is survived by his three children, James III, Robin, and Rebecca, and three grandchildren, Nicholas, Margaret, and Michael. Memorial services are at Christ Episcopal Church in Ponte Vedra Beach on Saturday August 11. The world has lost one of its great wits.

F.D.A. REJECTS WYETH DRUG Wyeth's new schizophrenia drug was rejected by the Food and Drug Administration because it was not shown to be effective. Shares of Wyeth and its partner, Solvay of Belgium, dropped. Wyeth said the F.D.A. needed more data showing that the medicine, bifeprunox, works before the agency would consider approval. The F.D.A. also requested information on a patient who died while taking the drug. The drug does not cause weight gain, a safety concern with other schizophrenia remedies, but studies have also shown it is less effective than Zyprexa from Eli Lilly and Risperdal from Johnson & Johnson. ''Bifeprunox didn't work as well as Risperdal and Zyprexa in studies, and I can't see much reason to use this drug once generics of the others are available,'' said Michael Krensavage, an analyst with Raymond James in New York. Cheaper copies of Risperdal will be available next year, followed by generic Zyprexa in 2011. Shares of Wyeth, based in Madison, N.J., dropped $2.99, closing at $46.59. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

An article on Thursday about a storm that drenched the New York region, paralyzing the transit system, referred incorrectly in some copies to delays on morning Long Island Rail Road trains through Mineola, and misstated the total amount of rainfall recorded by the National Weather Service in Central Park. The delays averaged 30 minutes, not an hour, and the rainfall totaled 2.5 inches, not 2.8.
