On a recent visit to the new cafeteria of The New York Times, Julia A. Stewart, 52, complimented the gleaming hardwood floors and then suddenly stopped. ''I'm sorry,'' she said, as she stepped around a coffee spill to grab a few napkins and then proceeded to clean it up. Ms. Stewart, the chairwoman and chief executive of the IHOP Corporation of Glendale, Calif., knows a hazard when she sees one. She can also apparently spot a bargain.

A sports chart in some copies on Wednesday about active career home run leaders who could challenge Barry Bonds's new record omitted a leader and referred incorrectly to Alex Rodriguez's standing. Frank Thomas, who was not included in the chart, is in fourth place -- not Rodriguez, who is in fifth. (Thomas had 505 home runs entering yesterday's games, and Rodriguez had 500.)

An article on Wednesday about the Israeli government's eviction of Jewish settlers from houses they had been illegally occupying in the West Bank city of Hebron referred incorrectly to the ownership of the property. While Israel recognizes pre-1967 Palestinian leases to the property and does not allow Jews to violate those leases by living or squatting there, the property is considered by Israel to be owned by Jews who bought it before the nation was founded in 1948, and not owned by Palestinians.

HICKEY--Jean Hogan Died peacefully at her country home in Millerton, NY. Cherished wife of Lawrence F. Hickey, adored mother of Elizabeth Hickey Lavin of Pelham Manor, NY, Magee Hickey Salembier and Jane Hickey Sexton both of New York City and Frank Hickey of Los Angeles, and beloved mother-in-law of Tom Lavin, Rick Salembier, and Mason Speed Sexton. She was the devoted grandmother of 11 grandchildren: Tom, Kate, Meg, Jack, and Janie Lavin, Lily and Floy Salembier, Mason, Buckman, Keats, and Daisy Sexton. Former Copacabana girl, Johnny Weissmuller Water Show girl, and champion ballroom dancer, she went on to become an accomplished actress, performing on and off Broadway in more than 200 productions from 1944 to 2005. A graduate of Saint Saviours High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, she attended Brooklyn College and studied drama at Columbia University. She was a member of the Snarks, a drama group, as well as a featured performer at the Amateur Comedy Club. Deeply religious and a pacifist, she believed in the Pax Christi movement and in many teachings of Dorothy Day, as well as being a Dame of Malta and a Lady of the Holy Sepulchre. She was a Lector, a Eucharistic Minister, a longtime member of the Saint Vincent Ferrers choir, and a religion instructor at Saint Ignatius Loyola. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel located on 1076 Madison Avenue on Monday, August 13th from 6-9 pm. The funeral mass will be held at Saint Vincent Ferrers Church at 10:30am Tuesday August 14th, followed by a reception at the Colony Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, 4010 Dyre Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466.

An article and headline in Business Day on Thursday about a suit involving the collapse of the commodities firm Refco, and the High & Low Finance column on Friday about the same subject, referred incorrectly to both the defendants and the plaintiff in the suit. As the article described, the suit was filed by the trustee of the Refco Liquidation Trust, which represents creditors of Refco. He is not the Refco bankruptcy trustee, as the headline said, nor is he the trustee of the company, as the first paragraph said. The article and the column should have pointed out that the Thomas H. Lee Partners and partnerships run by that firm, which are defendants in the suit, are no longer controlled by Thomas H. Lee, who severed his ties with the firm in 2006. Mr. Lee is named as a defendant because of his role as a director of Refco, and the suit names several other former directors who were not identified in the article.

A federal judge found Friday that the Roman Catholic Diocese of San Diego had misrepresented its finances and ordered it to explain why its bankruptcy case should not be dismissed. The church undervalued real estate holdings and failed to disclose ''material facts'' to the court, the judge, Louise DeCarl Adler, of Federal Bankruptcy Court, found. She named federal statutes that would allow the case to be dismissed on grounds of the diocese's ''gross mismanagement'' and ''unexcused failure'' in its financial reporting.

Floyd Landis finished second in a mountain bike race in Colorado, the Leadville Trail 100, despite a crash that left him with a bloody right leg. Landis, who was unable to defend his 2006 Tour de France title because of a positive drug test, was runner-up to the five-time winner Dave Wiens.

The Phoenix Coyotes traded center Kevyn Adams to the Chicago Blackhawks for right winger Radim Vrbata. Vrbata, 26, was Chicago’s second-leading scorer last season and set career highs in points (41) and assists (27). Adams, 32, was acquired in January from the Hurricanes and played 33 games with Phoenix.

Tony Kanaan kept his outside shot at an IndyCar Series title alive, blistering the field to win the Meijer Indy 300 at Kentucky Speedway in Sparta, Ky. Kanaan passed A. J. Foyt IV with less than 10 laps to go for his second victory in a row.

Kerri Walsh and Misty May-Treanor rallied from a one-set deficit in the semifinals and final to win the Manhattan Beach Open for a record-tying fourth time. The event is considered the most prestigious in pro beach volleyball. In the final, they beat Elaine Youngs and Nicole Branagh, 15-21, 14-7 (forfeit), 15-12.

United on Thursday. He had planned to play at least one half against the Revolution.

The suspended Titans cornerback Pacman Jones can appear at a wrestling event today but cannot compete in the ring under an agreement approved by a judge.The Titans, Jones and the wrestling promoters worked out an arrangement Friday night in which the player would be part of the pay-per-view show “Hard Justice.” The deal was approved yesterday, including a temporary injunction that prohibits Jones from doing anything in which he could hurt himself.On Friday, the Tennessee Titans sought a restraining order barring Jones from participating in the show in any way. The Titans cited a contract that prevents him from engaging in activities in which he could be injured.Jones was suspended by the N.F.L. for a year because of repeated conduct violations since being drafted in 2005.

(TLC) DIANA: LAST DAYS OF A PRINCESS Ten years after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, this docudrama recreates the 12 weeks leading up to the car crash in a Paris tunnel that killed her and her companion, Dodi al-Fayed. Genevieve O’Reilly and Patrick Baladi, above, portray the couple in a work based on interviews with their close associates. The script also draws from the 832-page Paget Report issued by Britain’s Metropolitan Police Service, which examines the princess’s security arrangements, the scrutiny of Buckingham Palace and the news media, her relationship with the paparazzi, her thoughts on Mr. Fayed and her unrequited love for a British surgeon. Those weighing in include Mohamed al-Fayed, Dodi’s father, as well as his bodyguard Kez Wingfield. At 7, “Diana: Her Last 10 Days in Pictures” presents some of the final photographs taken of the princess.

Robin Marantz Henig’s article (July 29) conveys the excitement of how much the new robotic generation can do — or seem to do — such as “interact” with “civility.” But it falls short of solving the puzzle of why the gap between mechanical “understanding” on one hand and plain old human “consciousness” on the other is actually growing rather than shrinking as our machines get more advanced. Berkeley’s John Searle has said that figuring out what consciousness is, on its own undeniably subjective terms, is our No. 1 scientific challenge.

O'DEA--H. Patrick , 69, formerly of New York, died in Louisville, Kentucky, July 2007. Kind and loving father of Addison, Varick and Gannon. He will be sorely missed. Donations will be gratefully received by Wayside Christian Mission, Men's Shelter, P. O. Box 7249, Louisville, KY 40257-0249.

WHEN Cate Fahey applied for a summer job at the J. Crew store at The Westchester mall in April, she must have made a good impression. At age 19, she is outgoing, poised and hard-working. She landed the job and is now in the unusual position of holding not just one summer job, but two, at a time when fewer teenagers are working. From 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. she works as a counselor at the Larchmont Yacht Club's summer camp. Then, two or three days a week, after rushing to her home in Mamaroneck to shower and change, she drives to her J. Crew job in White Plains to work from 5 to 11 p.m. She helps shoppers find the sizes and styles they want and folds hundreds of slacks and blouses each day.

What happens when prodigies reach cruising altitude? That's one question facing NICKEL CREEK, the acoustic trio one month into what it pointedly calls the Farewell (for Now) Tour. Since forming in 1989 this group has fueled its ascent with precocity: two of its three members, the mandolin player Chris Thile and the fiddler Sara Watkins, were born in 1981, and Ms. Watkins's guitar-playing brother, Sean Watkins, was born in '77. As the musicians have come of age together, their sound has broadened, leaning away from bluegrass and toward a kind of emo-inflected indie-pop.

MANDL--David. David Mandl , noted New York architect and mensch, died at home in Manhattan August 4, 2007, at age 53. The cause of death was pancreatic cancer, diagnosed in January 2006. He is remembered and missed for his designs, mainly of NYC residential high rises, his business acumen, mentoring abilities and for an offbeat sensibility his friends called Planet David. He shared his home and world travels with his wife of 26 years, Anita Boggia Mandl. He is also survived by his parents, Otto and Ina Mandl of Baldwin, L.I., sister Susan Mandl of Rochester, NY, aunt and uncle Edith and Irving Hamberger, cousin Richard Hamberger (Carol), niece Renee Boggia and nephew Peter Boggia, both of New York, as well as brothers in law Richard and David Boggia of Branford, CT. The family is grateful to Hillel Tobias, MD, Mitchell Gaynor, MD, Continuum Hospice, home care aide Donna Gregg and numerous loyal friends who were supportive during his illness. Anita Mandl will receive visitors to share remembrances of David on Thursday August 9th at 280 Park Avenue South, NYC 5pm-10pm. Parents, Otto and Ina Mandl and sister Susan Mandl will be receiving on Friday August 10th at their home, 1419 Eva Court, Baldwin, LI from 3pm-8pm. Contributions in memory of David Mandl can be made to Pratt Institute, 200 Willoughby Street, #

WHEN THE ENGLISHMEN Marcus Wainwright and David Neville started their clothing line, Rag & Bone, they envisioned a fusion of British bespoke tailoring and American workers' clothing. Mr. Wainwright, 32, said: ''Every guy has a favorite pair of trousers, and in his closet there are 50 T-shirts in a pile, but he only ever wears four of them. The fabric is soft. The colors are good. That's the way we approached our line.''

LILLIAN HELLMAN's reputation as a playwright largely rests today on a single work, ''The Little Foxes,'' a magnolia-scented drama about a domineering Southern belle and her cowed family. It served as a great showcase for Tallulah Bankhead, the star of the debut production, and Bette Davis, who won the movie role. Since then it has been revived regularly as a durable vehicle for actresses of a certain age.

Maggie Jones's tragic stories of juvenile sex offenders are representative and are just a few of the multitude of similar tales of lives lost (July 22). There are individuals on sex-registry sites today who are married to the women with whom they had consensual sex as teenagers and who are still labeled as sex offenders. These men are monogamous, law-abiding citizens, but they can't even coach their children's teams because they are forever tattooed with the mark of a sex offender.

GOODFRIEND--Herbert J. , an attorney and member of the Corporate and Trust and Estates Departments of Phillips Nizer, passed away on August 10th, 2007 in New York City. Born in 1921, he was a graduate of NYU Law School and served in the U.S Army in World War II. Among his many accomplishments, Mr. Goodfriend was a columnist for ''Law Office Management'' and ''The New York Law Journal.'' He was the National President of Tau Delta Phi from 1956-1960. He was also a member of the New York University Club and served on its Board of Governors and as its Vice President. Mr. Goodfriend's professional accomplishments were extensive. He chaired several committees of the American and New York State Bar Associations. He was appointed by the Appellate Division as Master, Supreme Court, New York County (1977-1979), and he served as Associate Counsel and General Counsel for the New York Board of Trade (1980-1987). Mr. Goodfriend also served as Vice Chair and Director of Jones Apparel Group, Inc., and as Director of Halmode Apparel, Inc., Venice Industries, Inc., and Chesapeake Life Insurance Company. He and his loving wife Barbara lived in New York City, Barbara passed away in 2005. He is survived by his two daughters, Sandy Soriano and Pennelope Goodfriend and her husband Matthew Densen; his five grandchildren, Sasha and Shaun Goodfriend, Gregg, Amy and Charles Soriano; two greatgrandchildren, Charlie Soriano and Ellie Carter-Soriano; and his very special friend, Mickey Glass. Memorial services are at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC, on Tuesday, August 14th at 1 pm.

THE NEWSBarry Bonds blasted a fastball over the fence in right-center field in AT&T Park in San Francisco to surpass Hank Aaron's career home record. BEHIND THE NEWS Aaron's record of 755 home runs had stood for 31 years before Bonds, with what George Vecsey of The Times described as the ''measured, disciplined stroke of a martial-arts master,'' hit the full-count, 84 mile-per-hour pitch by Mike Bacsik of the Washington Nationals. Aaron congratulated Bonds in a videotaped message shown on the scoreboard. Bonds's chase of the record is over, but the debate will continue over its validity because of the suspicion that he used steroids.
Closing Time

I was entranced by Jim Holt's essay. Carl Sagan often said that when you look at the stars, you look back in time. The stars we see now first emitted light billions of years ago. And yet we see that light in the present, although many of those stars have since died. That means our sun, and the reflected light of its planets, are currently emitting light into the future, which means we do exist forever. Perhaps time and space are heaven. We're streaming through the night sky, where the ancients always said heaven would be.

AS SUMMER wanes, Jean Darc's runaway Ribbon Dress may be the perfect way to straddle the changing seasons. The centerpiece of a new clothing line based in Brooklyn, the structured black twill dress -- $345 at Gatsbys in Great Barrington, Mass.; (413) 528-9455 -- has the forgiving cut of the dresses of summer with less voluminous yardage. Look for it in ivory with navy trim and denim with ivory trim as well as the Epee, a version with military snap closures at the bodice (also at Gatsbys, Ron Herman and Steven Alan in New York). Equal parts ''Factory Girl'' and ''That Girl,'' the collection includes jeans, tops and little jackets for when the mercury finally, regrettably drops.

GOULD--Nadia, nee Balter . 78, died August 4, 2007 in New York surrounded by her family and friends: her husband Philip, her sons Gregory and Nicholas, her twin daughters Genia and Elka, and three grandchildren Isaac, Aaron and Rachel. The Hebrew prayer Kaddish was recited by Elka's friend. Two Tibetan monks Khyongla Rato Rinpoche and Ven. N. Vreeland, read passages from Buddhist sutras. Also present were Nicholas' wife Melanie and her mother Esther Lu Nan, her brother Frank Nan and his friend Mathew Waldman. Nadia grew up in France but fled the Nazi occupation in 1943 for the USA. She graduated from NYU in 1949 and later earned a MA from CCNY. She had several careers as teacher, painter, folk singer and author. She was married to art historian Philip Gould for 57 years and shared with him a love of art and artifacts from around the world. She was a long time volunteer French teacher at Marymount Manhattan College and a volunteer at the New York Folk Art Museum. She expressed a wish that her family, her many friends abroad and at home remember her as one who enjoyed the fullness of life. www.nadia gouldmemorial.blogspot.com

SCHEIDT--Stephen, M.D . The members of The Class of 1965 of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons mourn the loss of our dear classmate and esteemed colleague, Steven Scheidt. We will remember him best for adding his unique touch to our shared experiences in those wonderful years we studied and learned together. We send our condolences to his family. SCHEIDT--Stephen, M.D. We deeply mourn the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Stephen Scheidt, esteemed cardiologist at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center and professor of clinical medicine at Weill Cornell Medical College, where he served the entirety of his distinguished career of nearly 40 years. A brilliant clinician and advocate for medical education internationally, he was the longtime director of the College's cardiology training program, former vice president of the American Heart Association and co-director of the Salzburg-Cornell Seminars for Physicians. A prolific research scientist, his contributions ranged from pioneering early work in the development of coronary care units and the treatment of acute myocardial infarctions to exploring issues such as the link between mood and heart attack, and examining the relationship between cardiovascular disease and nutrition. Known for his quick wit and humor, and his kindness, warmth and generosity of spirit, Dr. Scheidt was greatly beloved by colleagues, students and patients alike. He will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his family. Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

Diana Vreeland's maxim ''Elegance is refusal'' referred to fashion, but it certainly applies to architecture. A shining (or shimmering) example is this Hudson Valley retreat. It was designed by the architect Thomas Phifer (with Greg Reaves, a partner in his firm) for Cristina Grajales, a gallerist and consultant in 20th-century and contemporary design and decorative arts, and Isabelle Kirshner, a criminal-defense attorney. The 2,200-square-foot, two-bedroom house may be small, but it's grand in all the ways that count: its elegant proportions, its skillful combination of lofty and intimate spaces and its clever use of inexpensive materials to maximum effect.

SARK--Ladislav B. (Fred) , 89, of Greenwich, CT died peacefully at home Sunday morning August 5th, 2007 with his wife and children at his side. Mr. Sark was born April 7, 1918 in Prague, Czechoslovakia. He graduated from Charles University in Prague, earning a Master's degree and later obtained the equivalent from the University of London, England. He entered the business world via the renowned Czech glass industry, and emigrated to England following the Second World War, where he met and married his beloved wife of 60 years, Estelle Green Sark. He built his career in import/export and came to the United States in 1955 where he founded his own import company, Verfrance, Inc., specializing in luxury lighting fixtures and crystal perfume bottles, and retired in 1988. A resident of Greenwich since 1957, Mr. Sark was an accomplished linguist, historian, avid chess player and gourmet. Most of all, he was a devoted husband, father and grandfather. In addition to his wife, Estelle, Mr. Sark is survived by his son, Adrian Sark, of Toronto, Canada, his daughter Andree Sark, of Stamford and four grandchildren. Services and interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Greenwich Hospital Hospice Program, c/o Development Office, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

GIOSCIA--Victor Joseph, Ph.D. , born June 13, 1930. Son of Joseph and Anna, respected and loving teacher, counselor and philosopher to those interested in living the Perennial Philosophy, died peacefully on August 5th, 2007 at home in San Francisco, California in the arms of his beloved Helene. Vic's lifelong exploration of Plato's insight into ''time as the moving image of Eternity'', his dedication to human transformation, his daily engagement with God, and his deep drive to integrate the three stood him in good stead for his twomonth long battle with an aggressive cancer. In his dying, as well as in his living, Vic updated Plato with a more Neapolitan flavor into a motto by which he lived: Practice dying and dance as often as you can! And dance and improvise with life he could and did do. Those of us who were touched by Vic's teaching, and he was always teaching, will likely not have his death end the dialogue with life that he fostered in his students. The tribute we are quite sure he would ask of us is to be more loving to those in our care, as well as to be more courageous with our gifts. He is survived by his mother Anna, sister Marie-Louise and Helene, his mate of 25 years. For those in the New York area, a gathering of family and friends to celebrate Vic's life will be held.

SCHWARTZ--Milton I. , passed away at the age of 85 on Thursday, August 9, 2007, 25 Av 5767. He is survived by his children, Eileen J. Zarin, Robin Sue (Bill) Landsburg, Samuel Schwartz, and A. Jonathan (Stacy) Schwartz and grandchildren, David (Jill), Jennifer, and Jonathan Zarin, Michael (Emily), Zachary, Joshua, and Benjamin Landsburg, Daniel Schwartz, and Ava Schwartz, and sister, Beatrice (Harry) Colter. Mr. Schwartz resided in Las Vegas, Nevada, where he was active in several synagogues and many charitable endeavors. He was born in Brooklyn, NY and grew up to manage his father's store fixture business, the first of over twenty businesses he successfully created and directed. He was a founder and former Chairman of the Board of Valley Hospital in Las Vegas and at the time of his death, he was a director of Nevada Yellow, Checker, and Star Cab Corporations in Las Vegas. He served in the Army during World War II as Staff Sergeant and was a lifelong member of the Masons Clermont Lodge of New York. His most cherished accomplishment in a long and exceedingly productive life was the establishment of the Milton I. Schwartz Hebrew Academy in Summerlin, Nevada. His commitment to Jewish education was in the forefront of his philanthropic activities. He truly believed in the Jewish value of ''Tikon Olam'' as he dedicated his life to repairing and improving the world around him. The funeral will take place on Sunday, August 12, 2007 at 2:00 PM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck, New York. A memorial service will take place in Las Vegas following Shiva in Great Neck, NY.

Earthy: applied to a man, the word conjures a lumbering, virile jack-of-all-trades with large, calloused hands, a homely but honest face, a big heart in a barrel chest and a life of emotional turbulence. That's GÉRARD DEPARDIEU. Like Jean Gabin, his most obvious forerunner in French cinema, Mr. Depardieu is a Gallic everyman, a flawed hero and a soulful roughneck. Cops, criminals, businessmen, farmers, even men in skirts -- almost all male types are within the grasp this astoundingly natural (and naturally likable) star.

CYNTHIA RODRIGUEZ, the wife of Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez, made a tempest-in-a-teapot fashion statement at Yankee Stadium last month when she wore a tank top with an obscene message on the back -- just a few weeks before her husband hit his 500th home run. Last week, after pitching his 300th victory, the Mets' Tom Glavine threw out a style change-up of his own: a retro-preppy necktie. In conjunction with Vineyard Vines, the Tom Glavine Rally 300 necktie is being issued to benefit the Rally Foundation, a nonprofit group that raises money for childhood cancer research. The 300 limited-edition ties are each signed by the pitcher and can be bought for a $1,000 donation at rallyfoundation.org. All proceeds will go toward childhood cancer research.

ROSENTHAL--Marilynn Mae , beloved mother of Helen, mother-in-law of Carmen Marino and grandmother of Madeleine and Alexandra, died peacefully Thursday. She spent the last few weeks of her life surrounded by friends and family in her own home. The cause was cancer, she was 77. Marilynn achieved much during her lifetime, including authoring books on various areas of health policy; teaching students at the University of Michigan; leading students on international health policy courses in England, Sweden and China; founding and editing a co-op nursery journal; and, most recently, initiating a rain barrel project in Ann Arbor. Marilynn earned her Ph.D. after raising her three children, writing her dissertation about rumor-control during the Detroit race riots in 1967. In short order, Marilynn won a Hopwood writing award and several years ago won a Fullbright Scholarship to study medical safety in England and Sweden. After ''retiring'' from teaching at the U of M Dearborn Campus, she continued lecturing at the U of M Medical School, teaching premedical and medical students about the importance of patient safety. She founded the Michigan Health Policy Forum, an ongoing seminar series for faculty and scholars focusing on Health Care Finance, Quality and Access to Care. According to her granddaughter, she ''...was not your typical grandmother. We made menorahs out of oranges, rode bikes together, and she lectured to us about history, current events and why we should drive hybrid cars. She had so many fun and interesting ideas for art projects.'' The family will be sitting shiva on Thursday and Friday, August 16 and 17 from 5-7:30pm. A celebration of her life will be held at the Michigan League in Ann Arbor on Sunday, August 19 at 9:30am. Services made by the Muehlig Funeral Chapel, Ann Arbor, MI.
A Former Firehouse That's Open to All

A miniature replica of Eric Fischl's artist studio -- along with that of his wife, the artist April Gornik -- was recently on view at the PARRISH ART MUSEUM in Southampton, N.Y. Now Mr. Fischl is one of the curators of a show at the Parrish that opens Sunday. (The other is Merrill Falkenberg.) Called ''All the More Real: Portrayals of Intimacy and Empathy,'' the exhibition considers the strategies artists use to generate emotions. Concentrating on themes like birth, childhood, intimacy and self-identity, ''All the More Real'' explores a range of responses to these experiences, from strong emotions to detachment. ''By creating images and objects that appear to be even more real than the actual thing they represent,'' the museum says, ''these artists reassert the ability of representational objects to convey authenticity, pathos and, in many cases, wonder and awe.'' Artists in the exhibition include Vito Acconci, Diane Arbus, Ross Bleckner and Louise Bourgeois. Through Oct. 14, Job's Lane, Southampton, N.Y., (631) 283-2118, parrishart.org.

There are no easy answers to how the law should make workplaces more family-friendly (Eyal Press, July 29). Paradoxically, accommodating parents could cause hiring discrimination against women. Accommodations can make parents more expensive to employ. This gives employers an incentive to avoid employees who might use them. Since mothers are more likely than fathers to request such accommodations, employers may seek to avoid hiring potential mothers. Such discrimination is prohibited by Title VII. But lawsuits challenging hiring discrimination are relatively rare. A disappointed applicant often does not know why she was passed over or who was hired in her place; therefore, she cannot easily allege discrimination. And, unlike in a firing case, a job applicant generally does not have a strong investment in the particular position; hence she is less likely to go through the cumbersome process of bringing suit. Thus, as a practical matter, employers often can get away with hiring discrimination.

Throughout his career the San Francisco choreographer Michael Smuin was an eclectic who created ballets in many styles on many themes. The versatility of Mr. Smuin, who died at 68 in April, is apparent in the program of New York premieres his SMUIN BALLET is bringing to New York. ''Schubert Scherzo'' reflects his classical training. ''Obrigado, Brazil'' makes use of Brazilian music from the Yo-Yo Ma album of that name, and ''Bells of Dublin'' is inspired by tap-dancing. ''Shinju'' derives from a Japanese play about star-crossed lovers. Monday and Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Wednesday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 and 8 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800, joyce.org; $44

INSIDE CHARTRES CATHEDRAL, JULY 5, 2007 ''At Chartres the cloudy splendour is shot through with such effulgence of color that its vision, evoked by memory, seems to beat with a fiery life of its own, as though red blood ran in its stone veins. It is this suffusion of heat and radiance that chiefly, to the untechnical, distinguishes it from the other great Gothic interiors. In all the rest, color, if it exists at all, burns in scattered unquiet patches, between wastes of shadowy grey stone and the wan pallor of later painted glass; but at Chartres those quivering waves of unearthly red and blue flow into and repeat each other in rivers of light, from their source in the great western rose, down the length of the vast aisles and clerestory, till they are gathered up at last into the mystical heart of the apse.'' Edith Wharton, in ''A Motor-Flight Through France,'' 1908
Chapter 19
A CD review of Nicole Cabell's ''Soprano'' last Sunday misstated the name of the composer of one selection, ''A Child of Our Time.'' He is Michael Tippett, not the composer Benjamin Britten.

Rarely have I seen a perspective in the magazine section that feels as intuitively false as Mary Bucholtz on nerds, as related by Benjamin Nugent (July 29). As a man in my 50s, who grew up as a nerd and still often feels like one, I believe that it is more a forced role and pejorative than a choice. Although it may be associated coincidentally with white stereotypes, those who embrace the role are usually trying to make the best of a bad situation.

To the Editor: The antismoking movement started to gain traction when in the 1980s the public began to fear exposure to the smoke of others. This perceptual change precipitated laws and social attitudes that turned smokers into pariahs. Millions gave up the habit if for no other reason than to regain social acceptance.

HICKEY--Jean Hogan Died peacefully at her country home in Millerton, NY. Cherished wife of Lawrence F. Hickey, adored mother of Elizabeth Hickey Lavin of Pelham Manor, NY, Magee Hickey Salembier and Jane Hickey Sexton both of New York City and Frank Hickey of Los Angeles, and beloved mother-in-law of Tom Lavin, Rick Salembier, and Mason Speed Sexton. She was the devoted grandmother of 11 grandchildren: Tom, Kate, Meg, Jack, and Janie Lavin, Lily and Floy Salembier, Mason, Buckman, Keats, and Daisy Sexton. Former Copacabana girl, Johnny Weissmuller Water Show girl, and champion ballroom dancer, she went on to become an accomplished actress, performing on and off Broadway in more than 200 productions from 1944 to 2005. A graduate of Saint Saviours High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, she attended Brooklyn College and studied drama at Columbia University. She was a member of the Snarks, a drama group, as well as a featured performer at the Amateur Comedy Club. Deeply religious and a pacifist, she believed in the Pax Christi movement and in many teachings of Dorothy Day, as well as being a Dame of Malta and a Lady of the Holy Sepulchre. She was a Lector, a Eucharistic Minister, a longtime member of the Saint Vincent Ferrers choir, and a religion instructor at Saint Ignatius Loyola. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel located on 1076 Madison Avenue on Monday, August 13th from 6-9 pm. The funeral mass will be held at Saint Vincent Ferrers Church at 10:30am Tuesday August 14th, followed by a reception at the Colony Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, 4010 Dyre Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466.

Tennessee Titans cornerback Pacman Jones can appear at a wrestling show Sunday, with a couple of provisions: He will not be allowed to touch or be touched, use or be hit by any object or do anything else that may injure him. But at least he can be in the building for the pay-per-view wrestling event. The arrangement was approved by a Tennessee judge yesterday after an agreement among the Titans, Jones's lawyer and lawyers for the wrestling promoters, Total Nonstop Action Wrestling.

HOW'S your summer going? Mine is just fine, thanks. We're summering at home, like we do every year (it's easier to get to work that way). Our 17-year-old daughter, on the other hand, is summering in Provence. She's in the place where all the cute soaps and placemats come from. Lavender fields, baguettes, Roman ruins and Mediterranean beaches. A few hours of language instruction in the morning for the group, nothing too taxing. Nothing to tire them out so they can't enjoy the scenery, the field trips, the late-night dance sessions in my daughter's room (I'm so proud).

Residents, commuters and visitors showed a tremendous amount of grace and forbearance last week when torrential rains closed much of the subway system. Despite uncomfortable heat and humidity, they piled into overburdened buses and found other ways to cope. Now that everyone has had a chance to cool off, officials need to work overtime to regain the public's confidence in mass transit. That's especially critical now. The federal Department of Transportation is expected to announce this week whether New York will get necessary funding to relieve traffic congestion. For months, the Bloomberg administration has been selling the benefits -- including cleaner air and less gridlock -- of charging a fee to use the city's busiest streets. But if people are to be persuaded to forget the car and use mass transportation, they'll need more than the financial disincentive of the proposed $8 fee for cars.
News that the Two Rivers Water Reclamation Authority has imposed a two-year ban on new sewer connections for some types of development in 12 towns should serve as a wake-up call for local officials.

SOLOMON--Lillian F . 19172007. Raised in Philadelphia by 1905 Russian Revolutionaries turned American dreamers. She moved to New York City in 1937 to study Yiddish literature and stayed forever. Delighted in cooking both plain and fancy, romantic comedies, the Times crossword puzzle, and her West Village neighborhood. Beloved wife of the late Lewis W. Solomon, cherished mother of Liz and specially devoted ''person'' to her cat Tux. Gathering in celebration of her life, August 9th, 4-8pm at the Solomon house. In lieu of flowers, consider a donation to the National Yiddish Book Center, Amherst, MA or to City Critters, NY.

Part of the charm -- and the power as well -- of OSVALDO GOLIJOV's music is its unusually expansive eclecticism. For most composers eclecticism means drawing on various contemporary styles, from Minimalism to Serialism to chance and improvisation, or mixing formal and pop styles, or even borrowing moves from composers of earlier eras. Mr. Golijov's purview includes all that and World Music as well, and his polystylistic, culture-spanning ''Pasión Según San Marcos'' is his grand postmodern treatise on the subject. It was the major offering of Lincoln Center's Golijov festival in 2006, and now it's back as part of the MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL, of all things. Robert Spano conducts, in his Mostly Mozart debut. Saturday at 8 p.m., the Rose Theater, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $40 to $90.

I went up to Saratoga Springs the other day, escaping any more office discussion about Fashion Week, which people keep saying is "just around the corner" with an eagerness that robs the best last days of summer. Here is some of the fashion I saw at the race track on Saturday: straw porkpie hats on old gentlemen, orchid-pink lipstick on old ladies, blue-striped shirts and Hermès horse ties, blue blazers, strings of pearls, floral sundresses, and stiffened tulle hats with petal brims that had a bridal cast. My favorite look was a generously cut seersucker suit worn with a bow tie and white Michael Jordan sneakers by a man who appeared to be 90.

The most difficult thing about taking Rome's 110 Open Bus, the city-run double-decker tourist line, is finding one of the stops where you can actually get on it. Paris has always been a city where a savvy traveler can see shows and spectacles on the cheap. Locals also rely on two weekly calender guides for shows, movies and cultural activities that can be purchased for less than one euro at any of the city's green newspaper kiosks.

Securities arbitration panels are supposed to offer a way to resolve disputes fairly, faster and more cheaply than the overtaxed court system. A three-member panel hears the case; one person represents the brokerage industry, and the other two are public representatives.

Cowboys linebacker Greg Ellis says he’s worried he may be forced to retire. He tore his left Achilles’ tendon last November and went through an aggressive rehabilitation to trim a few months off the usual 12-month recovery. But severe pain has not allowed him to practice.

Because of an editing error, an article Friday about newly released portions of an inquiry into the detention by the United States of a Syrian-born Canadian, Maher Arar, who was sent to a third country, where he was tortured, misstated in some copies the country where another Canadian, Ahmad Abou el-Maati, was tortured. It was Syria, not Kuwait. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the current value of a compensation package offered to Mr. Arar in January. The package was estimated to be 11.5 million Canadian dollars, including legal fees, although the exact amount of the fees was not disclosed. At current exchange rates, that would be about $10.9 million, not $9.75 million.

Because of an editing error, an article on July 26 about the family background of Joshua Komisarjevsky, one of two suspects in the home invasion slayings of a woman and her two daughters in Cheshire, Conn., referred incorrectly to “In Cold Blood,” which recounted the similar murders of a Kansas family in 1959. Although the author, Truman Capote, referred to the work in an interview as a “nonfiction novel” before its publication in 1966, it is not in fact a novel.

Because of an editing error, an article Friday about newly released portions of an inquiry into the detention by the United States of a Syrian-born Canadian, Maher Arar, who was sent to a third country, where he was tortured, misstated in some copies the country where another Canadian, Ahmad Abou el-Maati, was tortured. It was Syria, not Kuwait. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the current value of a compensation package offered to Mr. Arar in January. The package was estimated to be 11.5 million Canadian dollars, including legal fees, although the exact amount of the fees was not disclosed. At current exchange rates, that would be about $10.9 million, not $9.75 million.
To the Editor:.

Testament, a 4-year-old gelding who has won 3 of 20 career starts, appeared to be unharmed after collapsing from apparent heat exhaustion near the winners’ circle at Saratoga Race Course after running in yesterday’s first race.

Catriona Matthew won the Scandinavian T.P.C. yesterday, shooting a four-under-par 68 and beating Laura Diaz and Sophie Gustafson by three shots in Loddekopinge, Sweden. Matthew finished with a nine-under 279 for her fifth victory. Annika Sorenstam, the defending champion and tournament host, closed with a 68 for her best round of the tournament and moved to 9th from 21st.

Santiago Botero returned from the doping charges that sidelined him from European competition last year to win the Tour of Colombia yesterday in Bogotá. The 34-year-old Botero won the 15-stage race by 4 minutes 45 seconds over Hernán Buenahora. Botero was dropped by the Swiss-based Phonak team last year for his involvement in a Spanish doping investigation that implicated 56 cyclists. Botero was cleared by Colombia’s cycling federation in November.

Racing before a record-setting crowd of about 72,000, Classic Pack beat 13-1 odds to win yesterday’s $100,000 West Point Handicap at Saratoga Race Course in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Retribution opened a 10-length lead on the field until the head of the stretch, but Classic Pack, a 4-year-old son of Regal Classic, made his move under Cornelio Velásquez by coming up the outside. He won the mile-and-an-eighth event on the Mellon turf course by three quarters of a length in 1 minute 47.77 seconds.

The Belmont Stakes winner Rags to Riches will miss the Alabama Stakes on Saturday, and is now scheduled to run in the $300,000 Ruffian Stakes at Belmont Park on Sept. 8. The trainer Todd Pletcher said Rags to Riches, his star 3-year-old filly, missed too much training time while being examined for an illness.

Buffalo defensive end Anthony Hargrove is running out of second chances with the Bills, who are considering releasing him after he landed in trouble for the second time this summer. A week after being arrested following a scuffle with police officers outside a bar, he was suspended for the first four regular-season games for violating the league’s substance-abuse policy.

Phil Dalhausser and Todd Rogers won their second straight Manhattan Beach Open, beating eighth-seeded Sean Scott and Dax Holdren, 20-22, 21-16, 15-11. The third-seeded Dalhausser and Rogers had won just once in six previous A.V.P. Tour stops.

Sébastien Bourdais finally conquered Road America, and he took a big step toward a record fourth straight Champ Car title along the way in Elkhart Lake, Wis. Bourdais, who will move to Formula One in 2008, had failed to win on the 4.028-mile, 14-turn natural terrain road course in three previous tries, despite being dominant at times. But in yesterday’s Generac Grand Prix, he started from the pole and overpowered the rest of the 17-car field in picking up his fifth victory of the season.

The University of Pittsburgh receiver Derek Kinder, a first-team all-Big East player last season, will miss this season with a torn knee ligament. He was injured making a cut after catching a pass during a noncontact drill Saturday during the first day of full-squad workouts.

María José Uribe, a 17-year-old Colombian who will be a freshman at U.C.L.A. in the fall, took advantage of a late putting lapse by Amanda Blumenherst for a 1-up victory in the match-play final of the United States Women’s Amateur Championship at Crooked Stick Golf Club in Carmel, Ind.
A gunman opened fire in a church in Neosho, Mo., killing three people and wounding several others, the authorities said.
As technology enables people to work wherever they want, many are clustering in resort playgrounds.
As a former Home Depot chief heads Chrysler, Detroit has completed a new-model changeover of the executive suite.
It is stupefying that some Chinese officials have been talking of using China’s enormous cache of American Treasury bonds as an economic weapon.
To the Editor:.
Mike Huckabee, who placed second in the Iowa Straw Poll, has distinguished himself with his considerable humor.
What does it mean to go from a humanly ancient world in which only 17 percent of nature had been “tainted” to a world in which only 17 percent remains untainted?
The excesses in the financial markets are not in the traditional stocks and bonds where average Americans put their money.

If anyone outside the White House truly believes that the U.S. can stay in Iraq in reduced numbers, while ignoring the civil war and expecting Iraqi forces to impose order, the British experience demonstrates otherwise.
Without more visas to clear backlogs and a path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, illegality will remain chronic.
As overseas study has become a prized credential for undergraduates, a competitive  industry has emerged.
Emergency workers searching for six coal miners who have been trapped for a week in a deep underground shaft announced that they would begin drilling a third hole.
With a one-under-par 69 in the final round Sunday, Tiger Woods snared a two-shot victory over Woody Austin to claim his first major championship of the season and the 13th of his career.
On Sunday, Phil Mickelson shot a final-round 69 in the P.G.A. Championship, did not make a bogey and said the problems with his wrist were behind him.
Iraqi and American officials are in talks with major U.S. retailers to have clothing from Iraqi state-owned factories on sale in the U.S. by the holiday season.
It is the first written proof that border guards were told to shoot to kill at anyone trying to escape to West Germany.
Chinese companies are investing heavily in impoverished African countries like Chad, raising Western concerns.
Elizabeth Murray was a New York painter who reshaped Modernist abstraction into a high-spirited, cartoon-based language of form.
Hoping to forge a compromise among warring factions, Nuri al-Maliki said Sunday that he would meet as early as this week with leaders from Iraq’s major political parties.
Jeff Gordon screeched off the course at the first turn on the 11-turn, 2.45-mile road course at Watkins Glen International, allowing Tony Stewart to storm into the lead.
There is increasing pressure to install synthetic turf on athletic fields in New York City rather than grass so that the fields can be used year-round.
When the Buccaneers opened training camp at the end of July, they had seven quarterbacks on the roster. They are now down to four, with Jeff Garcia the likely starter to begin the season.
A 67-yard kickoff return and some impressive runs from scrimmage on Saturday night were the latest bright lights in the wavy glow-and-fade arc of Derrick Ward’s career.
A 9-month-old girl is recovering in an American military hospital after a death squad killed her mother and uncle.

Craig Biggio homered after he was honored by Houston, and Lance Berkman hit a tie-breaking shot leading off the eighth to start a four-run rally that sent the host Astros to a 6-4 victory against the Milwaukee Brewers yesterday.
Magglio Ordóñez was simply trying to get an opposite-field hit when he led off the second inning.
Jozy Altidore scored two goals and Juan Pablo Ángel added a goal and an assist on Sunday to lead the Red Bulls to a 3-0 victory against Toronto F.C.

A man was wounded in a shootout with police officers in East New York on Saturday night, the police said. The shooting occurred about 11:50 p.m., as the officers responded to a report of an assault at 247 Vermont Street. After the officers arrived, they saw two men, one of them armed. The gunman fired at three people, the police said, and when the officers ordered him to drop his weapon, he fired at them. The officers returned fire, hitting the gunman, the police said. The man, whose name was not released, was in stable condition yesterday at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said. The officers were not injured. A loaded .22-caliber pistol was found at the scene, and charges were pending, the police said.

The family of a college student found strangled and wrapped in a sheet have established a scholarship fund in her honor. The body of the student, Boitumelo McCallum, 20, was found on Aug. 5 in a Greenwich Village apartment. Her mother, Teboho Moja, a New York University professor, said a scholarship fund has been set up in the name of Ms. McCallum, left, at the school she attended, Mills College in Oakland, Calif. The fund would help a student from Africa, Ms. Moja was quoted as saying in The New York Post yesterday. Ms. McCallum’s ex-boyfriend, Michael Cordero, was charged in the killing.

Suffolk County police detectives yesterday were investigating a boating accident in which two boys were injured, one seriously, the police said. Two motorboats crashed about 10 p.m. on Saturday about a half mile south of the Bay Shore Marina. Three children, ages 11, 12 and 13, were thrown from a 22-foot boat driven by Brian Soltan, 45, of West Islip. The children, whose identities were not released, were rescued from the water and the boats were able to reach the marina, the police said. The 13-year-old boy suffered a head injury and was in serious condition yesterday at Stony Brook University Medical Center. The 11-year-old boy was in stable condition at Good Samaritan Hospital Medical Center. Mr. Soltan was in stable condition at Southside Hospital, the police said.

A Medford man was charged yesterday with driving while intoxicated after he apparently accidentally backed his car into his female companion’s mother, the Suffolk County police said. The man, Kenneth Gonzalez, 30, left a party at his companion’s house in West Islip after fighting with several of her family members, the police said. Several people had surrounded his Chevrolet Lumina, which was in the driveway, and when Mr. Gonzalez backed up, he struck the woman, Denise Stark, 49, the police said. Ms. Stark was taken to Stony Brook University Medical Center, where she was in critical condition yesterday with a broken neck and head injuries.

The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee and the city comptroller yesterday called on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to establish a commission to study the condition of the city’s infrastructure. The chairman, David I. Weprin, said the commission would examine city-owned assets and those owned by private entities like Consolidated Edison. Stu Loeser, a spokesman for the mayor, said yesterday that Mr. Bloomberg’s plan for managing future growth addresses the condition of infrastructure. “We don’t need another commission to study the problems, we need funding for the solutions,” Mr. Loeser said.
A man opened fire during an argument aboard a subway car in Eastchester, killing one and injuring three others.
Envisioned as a “Pittsburgh of the tropics,”  Ciudad Guayana, Venezuela, didn’t turn out quite as planned, and that’s casting doubts on President Hugo Chávez’s city-building ambitions.
In a reversal, Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan admitted that support for militants emanating from Pakistan has caused problems for Afghanistan.
The State Ethics Commission’s investigation of Gov. Eliot Spitzer may be the biggest test of its 20-year history, and  comes as the panel is poised to take a new, more prominent role in Albany.
Once considered a safe alternative to the overheated Bay Area real estate market, Stockton, Calif., is now filled with “For Sale” signs and evidence of foreclosures.
Envoys from the U.S., E.U. and Russia indicated on Sunday that partition of Kosovo could be an option if Serbs and Albanians agreed to it.
Irene Morgan Kirkaldy’s defiance of white supremacy in the summer of 1944 led to a Supreme Court decision outlawing segregated seating on interstate bus lines.
After beating Rafael Nadal in the semifinals of the Rogers Cup in Montreal, Novak Djokovic came up with an even bigger upset in the finals, defeating Roger Federer.
Jets defensive end Andre Wadsworth is 17 days into an uphill comeback attempt after six years out of the league.
A close-up laser inspection by astronauts on the space shuttle Endeavour revealed a three-and-a-half-inch gouge.
Kevin Millar hit a three-run homer in the 10th inning after Miguel Tejada tied the score with a shot against Eric Gagné in the eighth, leading the Baltimore Orioles past the Red Sox on Sunday.
With 40 employees and a $4.5 million annual budget, the  translation office for New York City’s public schools claims to be the largest of its kind in the country.
It looks as if the Republican presidential candidates, at least most of them, will be participating in a YouTube debate after all.
DENVER, Aug. 12 (AP) — Troy Tulowitzki is beginning to earn a satisfying reputationfor being fearless.
A senior Iranian judiciary official did not disclose the conclusions of the investigation into Haleh Esfandiari and Kian Tajbakhsh, two Iranian-American scholars who have been held since May.
Forecasters predicted that Hurricane Flossies would weaken before passing by Hawaii this week.
Paul Lo Duca said his hamstring felt great Sunday and said that he was incredibly disappointed about being placed on the 15-day disabled list.
After months of disagreements with two small, radical coalition partners, the ruling Law and Justice party has moved to hold early elections by November.
Erin Thorn made a jumper that banked in at the final buzzer Sunday to lift the Liberty to a victory against Detroit Shock, improving the Liberty’s chances for a playoff berth.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s big financing numbers might require an asterisk.
Drivers in two of the accidents were charged with driving while intoxicated.
Human remains were recovered Sunday from the site of the Mississippi River bridge collapse, but they were not identified.
A doorman trades in currency, a woman on the bus tells the future and a diner is misunderstood.
As tensions continue to simmer between Palestinian factions, Hamas claims to be in talks with Fatah, a claim that Fatah says has “no basis in truth.”
One of TV’s most popular talk-show hosts, Merv Griffin also created some of the most successful game shows.
The Japanese film “Ai No Yokan” (“The Rebirth”) won the Golden Leopard, the top prize, at the Locarno International Film Festival in Switzerland.
Thursday will mark the 30th anniversary of Elvis Presley’s death, and Elvis Week 2007 is all the rage in Memphis and elsewhere this week.
Twenty-eight dance companies from around the world will converge on New York City Center for the fourth annual Fall for Dance Festival, scheduled for Sept. 26 through Oct. 6.
Ms. Halston will be the host of the third annual New York Innovative Theater Awards.

David Cannon, a co-executor of the will of the soul singer James Brown, right, who has been accused of misappropriating $350,000 of Brown’s money, resigned on Friday after handing over a check for the full amount during a court hearing, The Augusta Chronicle reported.
Fighting continues over the James Brown estate, Aretha Franklin cancels a concert and more culture news.
Aretha Franklin canceled a hometown concert scheduled for last night at the DTE Energy Music Theater in suburban Detroit, because of the heat, The Associated Press reported.
Drew Carey injured his arm during a rehearsal of “The Price Is Right.”

The dance component of the 11th annual New York International Fringe Festival opened appropriately with “All Aboard,” an hourlong, multimedia work. But the trip ran out of steam well before its destination.
Google, whose Google News is among the largest news aggregators, is asking the people or companies mentioned in news articles to comment on those reports.
Short List, a new men’s magazine in Britain, will not follow the traditional industry formula of bare-breasted B-listers and bawdy jokes.
Patrick Makuakane’s Hawaiian dance and music company knows how to put on a good show.
Louis Hayes has been playing hard bop nonstop as a bandleader for more than 30 years. Last week at the Jazz Standard he led three groups.
As the credit markets have dried up, some quantitative funds could potentially have their worst year on record.
Four home runs, two of them by Moises Alou, propelled the Mets over the Florida Marlins on Sunday. The Mets had lost four of their previous five games and were in jeopardy of being swept by Florida.
Could any new ballet company have begun with more good will and eager applause than Christopher Wheeldon’s Morphoses?
The European Commission is weighing a plan that could force some former phone monopolies in Europe to open their networks to greater competition.
The last big-budget movie of the summer, “Rush Hour 3,” opened in United States theaters with a middling $50.2 million in ticket sales.

Non-city-owned institutions saw the most striking improvement in the city’s cultural budget.
Andy Pettitte worked seven and a third innings for the win, getting home runs from Jason Giambi and Melky Cabrera to lead the Yankees to their 11th victory in 13 games.

THE CREDIT SQUEEZE The main focus will be on the credit crisis and its effect on the markets. Wednesday will be the 45th day before the end of the quarter, the deadline by which most hedge fund investors must notify the funds if they want to redeem investments.
After it bought the Web site iVillage.com last year, NBC Universal bragged that it had landed a digital darling. But few people are boasting about iVillage now.
Ann Taylor, known for its prim clothing for career women in their 30s and 40s, is developing a new casual apparel chain for the older, baby-boomer generation.
Manhattan Media named former Village Voice editor David Blum as the editor in chief of the New York Press.
Owners of the Microsoft Xbox 360 have watched their machines break down. But the game Halo 3 could redeem the company going into the holiday selling season.
This Mostly Mozart program focused on teenage composers. Their names were Mozart and Schubert.
In April, the business magazine Portfolio arrived with breathless anticipation. Last week, the run-up to the second issue took a decidedly less reverent turn.
Manufacturers have realized that they can sell more aggressively online, which puts them in stronger financial positions and allows them to serve consumers more effectively.
The nation’s largest newspaper company filed papers that included a new change-of-control plan that would accelerate payments to top executives in the event of a corporate takeover.
TomTom, the world’s largest maker of car navigation devices, wants to build its United States presence and create a constantly updating digital map.
Last Thursday, inboxes around the world were flooded with crude PDF documents promoting the stock of the Prime Time Group.
The abundant doomsday plotlines in “The World Without Us” make it a useful conversation piece, if a grim one.
Accounts.
The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.
Time Warner Cable is about to offer its customers a free recording feature for their televisions — one that will not allow them to zap through the commercials.
The split, planned for the end of the year, will resonate particularly in the intense competition for the 9- to 14-year-olds and 12- to 17-year-olds.

10:30 P.M. (Showtime) CALIFORNICATION David Duchovny, left, stars as the novelist Hank Moody, a one-hit wonder who high-tails it from New York to Los Angeles when his acclaimed book is turned into a lousy romantic comedy starring TomKat. Natascha McElhone plays Karen, Hank’s longtime girlfriend, who dumps him when he proves to have raging hormones coupled with a maturity level somewhere below that of their 12-year-old daughter, Becca (Madeleine Martin). Madeline Zima is Mia, who’s out to sucker punch Hank in a way he never imagined. And Evan Handler is the sanctimonious if a tad envious Charlie, who wants his best friend to keep his pants on for once. Or else stop tempting Charlie with all that talk.
The diagramed deal was born great, achieved some greatness, but then exploded with disappointment.

“The Invasion,” one of many heirs to the 1956 science-fiction classic “Invasion of the Body Snatchers,” opens on Friday. Nicole Kidman (above) plays a psychiatrist trying to stay alive and find her son before the aliens get to her.
NBC said it was ready to stop showing reruns of the episodes former Senator Fred D. Thompson appears in because of federal equal time regulations for presidential candidates.

We must increase the frequency of bridge inspections and use and develop technologies that predict problems.

In an emotional appearance with President Bush today, Mr. Rove said he wanted to think about the “next chapter” in his family’s life.
Jon B. Eisenberg is suing the government on behalf of clients who say they were illegally wiretapped, but he was required to write an appellate brief under supervision.
For the bargain salary of $432,000 on a $200-plus-million roster, the Yankees’ Melky Cabrera stretched his hitting streak to 17 games on Sunday.
In the hours before Tiger Woods teed off with a three-stroke lead in the final round of the 89th P.G.A. Championship, even Yogi Berra might have thought it was over.
The river’s powerful tides have been wreaking havoc on six underwater turbines designed to turn its currents into electricity.
Htien Lin’s paintings and illustrations, smuggled from prison during his years as a political prisoner, offer a rare vision of prison life in Myanmar.
“August: Osage County” is a hugely entertaining (also just plain huge) new play by Tracy Letts at the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago.
New releases from Lori McKenna, Kate Nash and Luciana Souza, plus a new “High School Musical” soundtrack.
As we struggle to extricate ourselves from Iraq, it’s useful to look at how the Soviet Union handled a similar position in the 1980s. Then we should do the opposite.

FOLLOWERS OF THE PACK Hedge funds with computer-driven or quantitative investment strategies have been recording significant losses this month. Bankers and investors say these strategies tend not only to be duplicable but also broadly followed -- resulting in a pack-like tendency that has helped increase market volatility. [Page C1.] A NEW ROLE Now that former Senator Fred D. Thompson, below, seems poised to re-enter politics as a presidential candidate, NBC says it is ready to stop showing reruns of the ''Law & Order'' episodes in which he appears, because of federal equal time regulations. [C5.]

SCHATT--Michael , passed away in his sleep on Friday August 10th after an extended battle with cancer. A quiet gentle soul who's profound calming presence and dry wit touched many, Michael was passionate about both his family and his profession. His loyalty for those he love knew no bounds. Michael was 60 years old. He is survived by his loving wife and two sons. ''From time to time leaves let go, but the trunk of the oak...''

WHISONANT--Aida B. , on August 11, 2007. Loving wife of the late Lawrence Winters, beloved mother of Oliver and Frank. She was predeceased by her beloved sister Rousmaniere Wilson and brothers Charles and Wendell Alston. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st St) Wednesday 2-5pm.

O'DEA--H. Patrick, 69 , formerly of New York, died in Louisville, Kentucky, July 2007. Kind and loving father of Addison, Varick and Gannon. He will be sorely missed. Donations will be gratefully received by Wayside Christian Mission, Men's Shelter, P. O. Box 7249, Louisville, KY 40257-0249.

Because of an editing error, an article Friday about newly released portions of an inquiry into the detention by the United States of a Syrian-born Canadian, Maher Arar, who was sent to a third country, where he was tortured, misstated in some copies the country where another Canadian, Ahmad Abou el-Maati, was tortured. It was Syria, not Kuwait. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the current value of a compensation package offered to Mr. Arar in January. The package was estimated to be 11.5 million Canadian dollars, including legal fees, although the exact amount of the fees was not disclosed. At current exchange rates, that would be about $10.9 million, not $9.75 million.

An article in Science Times on July 17 about the widespread distribution of ''Atlas of Creation,'' a book with an Islamic creationist point of view, not only incorrectly identified a company involved in shipping some of the books but misstated its role and its responsiveness to questions. The company, SBS Worldwide Ltd. (not SDS Worldwide, as the article had it, and corrected in this space on July 21), says it cleared a shipment of the books through customs but had nothing to do with their further distribution in the United States. SBS Worldwide Ltd. did not return calls and e-mail messages asking about its role before the article was published because it never got any; The Times had sent the questions to the wrong company. This correction was delayed in the confusion.

LEVINE--Dr. Donald J. , on August 11th, 2007. Beloved husband of Jane, loving father of Laura and Andrew. Caring Ophthalmologist to his many devoted patients. For more than 30 years Attending Surgeon at the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital and Clinical Professor of Ophthalmology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Services private.

KATZ--Irving, 87 , died peacefully in his sleep. Loving husband of Helene, loving father of Joyce (Guy), Peter (Leslie), Harlan (Bonnie), Lauren (Richard), loving grandfather of Barbra (Ron), Nicole (Josh), Alexis, Stacey, Jason, Jodi, Justin, Brian, loving great-grandfather of Jack.
MINSKOFF--Henry H In our thoughts, our hearts and memories. All our love. Jim, Jean, Alan, grandchildren and great-grandchildren

BRODLIEB--Andrea, nee Lazan, Parks . Daughter of the late Dorothy Harris and the late Joseph Lazan. Born in Woodmere, NY and moved to Palm Beach in 1991. Most beloved wife to Bevan. Loving mother to Jon Parks and Jackie Scavone. Stepmother to Pamela Brodlieb and Jessica Winnick. Mother-in-law to Andrea Parks, niece to Lorraine Green. Loving grandmother to Arianna, Jake, Daniel, Nicky, Katie, Olivia, Max and Lauren. Services Monday, August 13, 11:30am, Riverside Nassau North, Great Neck.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 12 (AP) -- AirTran Holdings Inc. dropped its $431 million takeover bid for Midwest Air Group on Sunday night, and Midwest immediately announced it would pursue an all-cash offer from private equity firm TPG Capital. About two-thirds of the shareholders of Midwest, parent company of Midwest Airlines, had agreed to the latest cash-and-stock offer from AirTran, which was estimated at $389 million when it was announced. AirTran, based in Orlando, Fla., had offered $15.75 a share, which a spokesman, Tad Hutcheson, said made the equity value of the transaction in excess of $431 million based on Friday's closing price of $10.70 for AirTran shares.

GOLDBERG--Charles , 88 peacefully on July 15. Decorated WWII hero, dedicated social worker, community worker and beloved husband of Helen, father and grandfather. He was awarded the Purple Heart for his heroism in Saipan. He will be dearly missed and remembered.
Rows of flags flew in Karachi yesterday ahead of the 60th anniversary on Tuesday of Pakistan's founding, on Aug. 14, 1947. India celebrates its independence from Britain on Wednesday.

WOLMER--Bruce . Editor Emeritus of Art & Auction, died peacefully August 11. Survived by his beloved wife Colleen Babington and adoring mother Elaine Katz. Service 12:45pm August 15th at Riverside Memorial Chapel. No flowers please.

BREITBART--Ross Evan . The Breitbart, Rubinstein and Oshman families deeply mourn the sudden death of our beloved pride and joy, Ross Evan Breitbart. His time with us was too brief, but the love he created is infinite. We especially hold Dannah, his wife of one year, in our loving embrace.

SUGARMAN--Frances, 91 . Devoted wife of the late Eugene. Beloved mother of Robert and Surie, Douglas and Arleen, and Risa. Adored grandmother and greatgrandmother of Dana, Marc, Zachary, Jesse and Eli Zimmerman, Alison, Daniel, Kate and Jake Brown, Scott and Kristen Sugarman, Amanda and Jason Sugarman and Daniel Regino. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.
The same processes that led to the suburbanization of the United States after World War II are now producing a virtual suburbanization in places like Jackson or Steamboat Springs. JONATHAN SCHECHTER,

MAIORCA--Joseph E. , died peacefully on August 9, 2007. Joseph was the beloved husband of the late Vincenza Candela, and loving father of Lydia Driscoll (Edward) of Haverford, PA, Lucille Morgan (Stephen) of New York City, and Frank Maiorca of Sea Cliff, NY. He was the cherished grandfather of Daniel, Peter, Myles, Nicholas, and Elizabeth. Born in 1920, in Brooklyn, NY, he was a 45year resident of Garden City and Shelter Island, NY. He served in the Army during WWII. He graduated from CCNY School of Business in 1948. He was a CPA and worked for Merrill Lynch for 26 years, serving as Controller, Treasurer/VP, and an allied member of the New York Stock Exchange. He was an avid ballroom dancer, a longtime boater, and a volunteer member of the Coast Guard. He loved hosting family gatherings and spending time with his grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Whitting Funeral Home, 300 Glen Cove Ave., Glen Head, NY 11545, Wednesday, August 15, 2007, 11am-1pm. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. Contributions may be made to Alzheimer's Association, 225 N. Michigan Ave., Chicago, IL 60604-7633.
FISHMAN--Michael Alan . 19th 1963-Aug.13th 1995 Until we meet again. Lovingly remembered, Family and Friends.

ROSENTHAL--Richard L. , passed away peacefully August 5th, 2007 surrounded by family. Devoted husband of 60 years to Karolyn; loving father to Diane, Evelyn and son-in-law Mark; beloved grandfather to Joshua and Ariel; cherished uncle to Steven and John; proud veteran of World War II. We miss him so much. Memorial held August 6, Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills, NY.
BRAUNSTEIN--Laurence I. DPM . Dear husband of Florence, cherished father of Sharon and Elysa, devoted grandfather of Julianna and Emily. Great Doctor and friend. Master of puns.

An art review on Thursday about the ''NeoIntegrity'' show at the Derek Eller Gallery, in Chelsea, misstated the surname of the artist whose ''American Flag'' is in the show. He is Andrew Madrid, not Milan.

CREEDON--Scott on August 9, 2007 in Incline Village, Nevada. Beloved and treasured son of Valerie Doll (nee Dorman) and the late Michael Creedon. Proud and loving father of Brittany and Paige. Devoted grandson of the late Hetty and Joe Dorman. Loving stepson and buddy of Dick Doll. Former husband of Kim Creedon. Scott was deeply loved and respected by his family and friends. After a successful career in the securities business, Scott founded Creedon, Keller and Partners, a multi-billion dollar convertible bond arbritage hedge fund in New York. Eventually he relocated the firm to California and he and his family moved to Incline Village, Nevada (Lake Tahoe). Scott graduated from Poly Prep Country Day School in 1984 and Lafayette College in 1988. In 2002 he was awarded the Rising Star Award by the Alumni Board of Governors of Poly Prep in recognition of his distinguished and unique achievements. He was an outstanding athlete and was happiest outdoors in nature and the mountains he loved. He skied with skill and great passion which is how he lived his life. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday, August 15 and 16 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Memorial Service to be held on Friday, August 17 at 11am at The Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue at 29th Street, New York.

COHEN--Harris David . January 25, 1967-August 13, 1985. Not a day goes by that we don't think of you. Our memories are beautiful; our hearts are broken. Much Love, Mom, Dad, Jonathan, Lisa, Jake & Benjamin

HICKEY--Jean Hogan Died peacefully at her country home in Millerton, NY. Cherished wife of Lawrence F. Hickey, adored mother of Elizabeth Hickey Lavin of Pelham Manor, NY, Magee Hickey Salembier and Jane Hickey Sexton both of New York City and Frank Hickey of Los Angeles, and beloved mother-in-law of Tom Lavin, Rick Salembier, and Mason Speed Sexton. She was the devoted grandmother of 11 grandchildren: Tom, Kate, Meg, Jack, and Janie Lavin, Lily and Floy Salembier, Mason, Buckman, Keats, and Daisy Sexton. Former Copacabana girl, Johnny Weissmuller Water Show girl, and champion ballroom dancer, she went on to become an accomplished actress, performing on and off Broadway in more than 200 productions from 1944 to 2005. A graduate of Saint Saviours High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, she attended Brooklyn College and studied drama at Columbia University. She was a member of the Snarks, a drama group, as well as a featured performer at the Amateur Comedy Club. Deeply religious and a pacifist, she believed in the Pax Christi movement and in many teachings of Dorothy Day, as well as being a Dame of Malta and a Lady of the Holy Sepulchre. She was a Lector, a Eucharistic Minister, a longtime member of the Saint Vincent Ferrers choir, and a religion instructor at Saint Ignatius Loyola. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel located on 1076 Madison Avenue on Monday, August 13th from 6-9 pm. The funeral mass will be held at Saint Vincent Ferrers Church at 10:30am Tuesday August 14th, followed by a reception at the Colony Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, 4010 Dyre Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466.
KLEIN--Charles Joseph Happy 86th Birthday, dearest Charlie. Forever in my heart and thoughts. Love, Blanche

MARTIN--Suzanne Scott, 83 , August 4th. Survived by her daughter, Dr. Elizabeth Cooper-Martin, her husband, John, and their children, Laura and Luke; her son, Jeffrey Martin, his wife, Catherine, and their children, Peter and Nicholas; and her former husband, Ralph Martin. A reception in her memory will be held Tuesday, August 21st, at The Hartford Club in downtown Hartford from 5 to 6:30 pm.

RASKAS--Laeh Halpern , of St. Paul and Jerusalem, Israel. Born November 15, 1922, St. Louis, MO. The daughter of the late Rabbi Abraham E. and Bessie Halpern and sister to the late Rabbi Mordecai S. Halpern. Survived by loving husband of 62 years Rabbi Bernard S. Raskas; children, Hillel Raskas, Eve and Steve Kafitz, David Raskas and Milo Mortenson; five grandchildren; sister, Fayga H. Gordon. Laeh had a life long passion for the fine arts, politics and literature. She graduated with a B.F.A from Washington University, was a 20 year member of the Board of the World Joint Distribution Committee, dedicated several Jewish Social Service Facilities around the world, Past Chairperson of the UJFC Womens Division and a strong supporter and volunteer for Planned Parenthood. Funeral service Monday, St. Paul, MN. Interment at Mount of Olives Cemetery, Jerusalem, Israel. Hodroff-Epstein, 651-698-8311. Online guest book at: www. hodroffepstein.com

SIM--Lenore Overton , 91, of Garden City, New York passed away on August 11th peacefully at The Bristal of North Hills. She was the wife of the late William Henry Craig Sim and the mother of Craig Stephen Sim and Judith Sim Sartorius and the late David Craig Sim (infant). She is the grandmother of Brandon C.W. Sim, Stephanie B. Sim, John M. Sartorius III, Pamela Sim Sartorius and the late Melissa H. Sartorius. Visiting hours will be held at Fairchild Funeral Home in Garden City on Wednesday, August 15th from 7pm-9pm. Church service at The Garden City Community Church Chapel, Kensington Avenue side on Thursday, August 16th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to Columbia University at Harlem Hospital Art Program, Attention: Dr. Barbara Bar low, 506 Lenox Avenue, New York, NY 10037.
VERNAY--Jean-Pierre, 12/5/38-8/13/88. Remembered with love. Bill and Lenny

PINELES--Jacob, 86 , of Verona, NJ and Boca Raton, FL, passed away at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, NJ on August 12. He was the loving son of Max and Rose (nee: Welger) Pineles. He served his country proudly during WWII in the Army Air Force. He was born and raised in Hoboken, NJ then resided in North Bergen and then Clifton for 26 years and to Verona for the next 26 years, with the winters spent in Florida. He earned his B.S. in Mechanical Engineering at the Steven's Institute of Technology in Hoboken, NJ. He was a Self Employed Professional engineer and Builder in Construction. His business was based out of Hackensack, NJ. He was a Member of B'nai Brith, the Maplewood Country Club and the Clifton Jewish Center. He is survived by his loving wife of 56 years, Ann (nee Janowitz), his two daughters, Karen Mendelsohn of Fairfield, NJ and Jane Levine of NYC, NY and his son Richard of NYC, NY. He was the beloved grandfather of four grandchildren, Zachary Levine, Danielle Mendelsohn, Sydney Levine and Alissa Mendelsohn. He also had two sisters Betty (Robert) Simons of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, and Claire Gold of Easton, CT. He was predeceased by his sister Mollie Vidor. Chapel services Monday, August 13th, at 12 Noon at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, NJ. Interment to follow at the King Solomon Cemetery in Clifton, NJ. In lieu of Shiva gifts or flowers, the family kindly requests that donations be made to the Steven's Institute of Technology, Castle Point on Hudson, Hoboken, NJ 07030.

WAGNER--Kenneth . Kind, generous, bright, sweet, protective and fun to be with. A loving and true big brother. He will be lovingly remembered and sorely missed. Florrie and Artie, Toni and Bob, Casey, Eric, Paige, Samantha and Julie WAGNER--Kenneth. In memory of our generous, loving, bigger - than - life husband, father and grandfather. With everlasting love from Rhoda, Randy, Alissa, Jamie, Andrew, and Jim. Donations to The Kenneth Wagner Funds may be made at American Lung Association, 116 John St., NYC 10038 or Juvenile Diabetes Research, 432 Park Ave. South, NYC 10016.

DOUGLAS--Joanne S. (nee: Sangillo) , of Hawthorne, NJ, died August 11, 2007. Beloved wife of Harold C. Douglas. Loving mother of Michaela. Adoring sister of Ralph and wife Marcia Sangillo, and Carl Sangillo, and devoted aunt to five nieces and nephews. Joanne was a parishioner or Our Lady of Mt. Carmel R.C. Church, Ridgewood, NJ and was a Real Estate broker with Teri O'Connor Real Estate. Formerly, she was a CFO of Magnetic Post Production, NY, NY. Funeral Services Thursday 10:00am at Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave., followed by the 10:45am Funeral Mass in Our Lady of Mt. Carmel R.C. Church, both in Ridgewood, NJ. Cremation private. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Instead of flowers, donations to Hackensack Medical Center Foundation, 30 Prospect Ave., Hackensack, NJ 07601 would be appreciated. For condolences and information, feeneyfuneralhome .com

Dearest husband of Marilyn (Tenney), much loved father of Andrea Magder and William and Allison Nass, darling grandfather of Ethan, Abigail, Lexi, Alec and Katie, dear brother of Harold, Fritzi Roth and Glen Natkins. Services Monday August 13th, 10am, Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

Tom Vilsack, a Democrat and the former governor of Iowa, said to John McCain, the Republican presidential candidate as, looking a little wilted, he appeared at the Iowa State Fair today. Forests are carbon sinks: They absorb the emissions from other parts of the planet. If trees in forests are chopped down, that capacity is lost. There's more: Once the land under a forest becomes barren, more carbon dioxide emissions result.
