The United States will play Brazil on Sept. 9 in Chicago, the United States Soccer federation announced. The match is being billed as a "Clash of Champions," after the Americans won the Concacaf Gold Cup this summer and Brazil, the five-time world champion, brought home the Copa America from Venezuela.

Regular readers know that Champagne is one of my preoccupations, particularly Champagnes from independent growers who make their wines from their own grapes. These grower-producers occupy a minute segment of the market, yet interest in their Champagnes is clearly growing. In my recent column I was struck not only by the number of grower Champagnes we tasted but how well they did.

Back in 1943, American soldiers were given copies of a plainspoken book called "Instructions for American Servicemen in Iraq During World War II." Now the University of Chicago press has released a fascimile edition, and it's both a beautiful object and a fascinating document, one whose lessons seem more valuable than ever.

Last week was a brutal one for hedge funds. The rapid deterioration in the United States mortgage markets has created strange market conditions, to say the least, which have tripped up many a carefully calibrated computer-trading strategy. Just ask the folks at Goldman Sachs, where one multibillion-dollar quantitative fund lost more than 30 percent last week.

After a week of keeping Iowa mostly to themselves, the Republican presidential candidates will have to share the state with Democrats who are coming en masse this week to aggressively court voters. Polls there show a close race between the leading Democratic hopefuls, and despite all of the leap-frogging going on with early state primaries, a strong finish in the Iowa caucuses remains a coveted prize.

AirTran Holdings, the freshly rejected suitor for its rival Midwest Air Group, will not seek another merger partner simply for the sake of consolidating, AirTran's chief operating officer told Reuters Monday.
Edward Lampert, long ranked among the world's best-performing investors, may be enduring a rough patch, according to Reuters.

The rapidly growing software maker VMware priced its initial public offering at $29 a share Monday, setting the stage for one of Silicon Valley's most anticipated stock market debuts since Google mesmerized Wall Street three years ago.

Two of Wall Street's biggest investment banks have recently disclosed that several of their internal hedge funds have suffered major losses in recent weeks. Yet the difference in how the stocks and bonds of Bear Stearns and Goldman Sachs are faring could not be starker.

The Quadrangle Group is expected to complete its $245 million takeover of the American portion of Dennis Publishing Tuesday and plans to immediately fold the struggling magazine Stuff, The New York Post reported.
Citigroup could lose as much as $3 billion in the third quarter because of the credit crisis, according to analysts at Sanford C. Bernstein.
Web portal Batanga has closed a $30 million Series C financing round to continue developing social media and online content that serves Hispanic consumers.

Months after confirming it had received several unidentified approaches, a South African casino and theme park operator, Gold Reef Resorts, said Monday that it was in exclusive negotiations with a financial investor who was working to line up financing.

RF Micro Devices said Monday that it had agreed to buy Sirenza Microdevices for $900 million in cash and stock in a move by the company, a maker of wireless telecommunications chips, to enter more profitable markets.

PepsiCo is in talks to buy Russia's top juice maker Lebedyansky, which is being auctioned, Reuters reported. Russian business daily Kommersant said PepsiCo had agreed to buy more than 76 percent of Lebedyansky for $1.5-$2 billion.
Shares of the software maker BEA Systems rose more than 3 percent Monday following three upgrades from analysts, reviving speculation that the business-software maker may be an acquisition target.

CME Group, formed out of the $12 billion deal that united the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade, said Monday it would cut 380 positions "across all departments." Some of the positions being eliminated will be retained through June 2008 as transitional projects -- notably trading floor integration -- are completed, CME said.

UBS, the Swiss financial giant, reported a record profit in the second quarter but also warned about possible challenges ahead. The company, which is the world's largest wealth manager, said it would probably see a "very weak trading result" in its investment bank if turbulent market conditions continue, which could lead to a drop in profit in the second half of 2007.
When investors flinched in the face of credit-market worries, a consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland pounced.

By the time its fiscal year ends on Sept. 30, the Securities and Exchange Commission's San Francisco office plans to have civil charges against another Silicon Valley lawyer under its belt, according to The Recorder.

The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said on Monday it expects to report higher third-quarter profit than analysts had expected despite taking a hit on the subprime mortgage debacle in the United States.

The global credit crunch claimed a Canadian victim Monday, as the stock of a financing company, the Coventree Capital Group, plummetted on news that investors have turned their backs on its $15 billion portfolio of loans.
Microsoft has completed the largest purchase in its history, sealing its $6 billion takeover of the Internet advertising firm aQuantive.
Nanosphere, a nanotechnology firm that makes a genetic-testing system, Monday filed for an initial public stock offering, intending to raise up to $100 million.
After fighting one of the nation's largest corporate fraud cases, John and Timothy Rigas, former executives of Adelphia Communications reported Monday to a federal prison in North Carolina.
The European Union cleared the way Monday for Intel and STMicroelectronics of Switzerland to combine troubled units that make a type of flash memory used primarily in cellphones.

FoldRx Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology firm based in Cambridge, Mass., has received $22 million from the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation to develop and commercialize drugs aimed at treating the fatal genetic disease, a disorder of the lungs and digestive system that afflicts 70,000 people worldwide.
Qualcomm, the mobile phone chip maker, announced Monday that its general counsel had resigned on the eve of a crucial hearing in its patent dispute against a rival, Broadcom.
Qwest Communications named Edward A. Mueller, a telecommunications industry veteran and a former chief executive of the retailer Williams-Sonoma, as its new chief executive Monday.

The Dutch insurer Aegon said Monday it had agreed to buy the Merrill Lynch Life Insurance Company and the ML Life Insurance Company of New York for $1.3 billion to increase its sales of variable annuities and distribution in the United States.

H&R Block, facing a proxy battle from the activist investor Richard C. Breeden, said Monday that its board had voted to require all directors to stand for election annually rather than every three years.
The bombs tore through the districts near Qahataniya, 75 miles west of Mosul, Iraq’s third-largest city, officials said.

The poor state of medical care in California’s prisons was evident in the West Block clinic at San Quentin, the first penitentiary to be visited by Robert Sillen before he began to overhaul the system.
Do enough people care about the stories behind viral videos to make “i-Caught,” which had its premiere last week on ABC, a viable prime-time television concept?
Like a lot of documentaries, “Gaza E.R.,” tonight on PBS’s “Wide Angle” series, makes a grim subject a little more palatable by occasionally tossing in some humanism via a likable character.
Images from the exhibit "Artempo: Where Time Becomes Art" at the Fortuny Museum in Venice.
A European buyer recently paid $4.6 million (€3.8 million) for a three-story suite in Sky Las Vegas, billed as the "the only luxury, high-rise condominium located on the Las Vegas Strip."
Photos of a house overlooking San Miguel de Allende in central Mexico.
When Joba Chamberlain pitched at Class AA Trenton, his entrance music was the song "Indian Outlaw" by Tim McGraw, a nod to his Native American heritage.

The World Chess Federation has published a list of the qualifiers for the 2007 World Cup tournament to be held in Khanty-Mansiysk, Russia. The tournament is part of the cycle for selecting the world champion. Altogether, 128 players will be part of the World Cup, but so far only 93 have been determined, according to the Federation's release. How the 128 are selected is explained in the release, but be forewarned, it is a bit arcane.
The First Chapter from On the Road.

The drivers who appear to have berths locked in Nascar’s Chase for the Nextel Cup may as well try to do everything they can to win a race now, because second place will not be worth much when the Chase begins.
The owner of a mine where six men have been trapped without contact for eight days admitted for the first time  that hopes for their rescue may be fading.
The cellphone maker was offering to replace the batteries, which were made in China, at no cost to consumers.
Don Imus and CBS announced that they had settled the remaining differences surrounding his firing in April.
Shares in the software company VMware surged nearly 75 percent early in their first day of trading, closing at $51, or $22 above the initial offering price of $29.
The nation’s largest retailer and a bellwether for the  economy warned that profits would be lower than expected for the year, citing higher energy costs and interest rates.
The U.S. Department of Transportation provided significantly less money than the mayor had sought as part of his sweeping proposal.
The sure-handed Hall of Fame shortstop, nicknamed the Scooter, went on to become a beloved broadcaster.
From exile in London, Thaksin Shinawatra is watching and, perhaps, waiting for his moment to return.
Severe flooding has left hundreds dead or missing and inflicted widespread damage, North Korean officials acknowledged on Tuesday.
A jump in energy prices caused prices paid at the producer level to rise more than expected last month despite falling food prices and small price increases for many other goods.
A suicide attack on a bridge north of Baghdad killed 10 people today while disrupting an American supply route, as American and Iraqi forces began a big push north of the capital.
The world’s largest toy company announced its second major recall of toys from China contaminated with lead paint.
It would be Mattel’s second major recall in a month because of defective toys that were made in China.
A bomb set along railroad tracks exploded and derailed a passenger train between Moscow and St. Petersburg, injuring scores of passengers.
Jason Giambi’s pinch-hit single moved Melky Cabrera from first to third in the bottom of the ninth inning and Derek Jeter’s chopper off the pitcher’s glove drove in the winning run.
A 58-year-old Brooklyn woman who ran a halfway house in her brownstone was found dead in her bedroom early yesterday, her apartment in disarray, the police said.
A court acquitted Ma Ying-jeou, the Nationalist Party candidate for president, on Tuesday.

A 34-year-old Brooklyn man working in an industrial warehouse was crushed by a freight elevator last evening, the police said. The man, Arturo Gil, was declared dead shortly after 5 p.m. at the site, the Whale Industrial Terminal Building at 14B 53rd Street in Sunset Park, the police said. The elevator had become stuck between the second and third floors and Mr. Gil was trying to move it, according to relatives, who said his body was caught as the elevator began to move. The Buildings Department said that the accident was under investigation but the police said that no criminal charges were expected. The building, which is owned by Whale Realty LLC, had received an “unsatisfactory” rating during elevator inspections on July 10, according to Buildings Department records. It is unclear if the rating included the elevator where Mr. Gil was killed. Mr. Gil, who came here from Mexico and lived in Sunset Park, had been working in the United States for about a decade, his cousin Rodolfo Veroles said. His wife was also in New York, and Mr. Gil sent money to Mexico to support his relatives, including his children.

A Queens principal could not account for the whereabouts of more than $30,000 collected for lunches, snacks and graduation festivities at Intermediate School 109 in Queens Village, investigators said yesterday. In a separate matter, the principal, Shango Blake, punched and choked a 13-year-old student he thought had made disparaging remarks about his son, said Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the New York City school system, in a report released yesterday. The Department of Education responded by saying that the principal would be punished. “We are moving to terminate Mr. Blake,” Dina Paul Parks, a department spokeswoman, said in a statement. No one answered the telephone at the school yesterday afternoon.

The president of Rider University is defending two school officials charged with hazing in connection with the binge-drinking death of a freshman in the spring. The president, Mordechai Rozanski, said in a letter posted on the university’s Web site yesterday that the school was “surprised by the charges” against two school officials, Anthony Campbell, 51, Rider’s dean of students, and Ada Badgley, 31, the university’s director of Greek life. The two officials and three students have been charged with aggravated hazing in relation to the death of Gary DeVercelly Jr., 18, of Long Beach, Calif. Mr. Campbell and the students have pleaded not guilty; Ms. Badgley is expected to enter a plea when she appears in court this week. Mr. DeVercelly died in March after a party at the Phi Kappa Tau fraternity house, the authorities have said.

More than 200 paroled burglars in Connecticut will be fitted with global tracking devices as part of the state’s response to a home invasion in Cheshire last month that claimed the lives of a woman and her two daughters. The state fitted parolees with convictions for first-degree and second-degree burglary with radio frequency devices on Aug. 2, and state officials said they planned to upgrade the devices to more accurate G.P.S. tracking by the end of September. Gov. M. Jodi Rell ordered the tracking devices after Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her daughters, Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11, were found dead in their home on July 23. Two paroled burglars have been charged.

The authorities seized nearly 600,000 packs of cigarettes with brand names like Marlboro. They lacked tax stamps and half of them are suspected of being counterfeits from China, prosecutors said yesterday. Three men arrested in a raid last week at a warehouse in Corona were charged with forgery and trademark counterfeiting in the case, said Kathleen Rice, the Nassau County district attorney. The cigarettes are worth more than $3.4 million, she said. Also seized were counterfeit sneakers and $350,000 in cash. Prosecutors said the potential lost tax revenue from the cigarettes was more than $1 million. State and Queens law enforcement authorities took part in the investigation.

The police released a description yesterday of a man they are seeking in connection with the fatal stabbing of a British tourist in Margate early Sunday. The tourist, Lavern Paul Ritch, 37, of Penarth, Wales, was visiting friends in Cherry Hill and had traveled to the beach for the weekend, the police said. Police officers found Mr. Ritch stabbed in the heart when they responded to an emergency call about 2 a.m., the police said. Mr. Ritch, who worked as a fitness instructor, was listed in a 2002 survey by Company magazine as one of Britain’s 50 most eligible bachelors. Prosecutors said yesterday that the person they were seeking was a white man about 35 to 40 years old, about 5 feet 10 inches tall, with a medium to heavy build, wearing a green hat with a flat top and a short brim.

A Bronx teenager was arrested yesterday and charged with a fatal shooting in the subway early Sunday in the Bronx, the police said. They said that Robert Denis, left, 16, killed Rayquon Story, 19, and injured three other passengers on the No. 5 train some time after 2 a.m. Sunday between the 180th Street and Eastchester-Dyre Avenue stations. A tip led investigators to Mr. Denis. He was charged as an adult with murder, attempted murder, manslaughter and criminal possession of a weapon.
Federal officials are expected to announce that they will help finance Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan if it is ultimately approved.
The move comes after the bank pumped money into the system for two days to ease fears of a liquidity crisis.

Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technology who is fighting extradition from Namibia to face options-related fraud charges in the United States, won another delay in the proceedings. An extradition hearing was delayed until Nov. 12 as a result of a challenge filed by Mr. Alexander to the selection of the magistrate who will hear the case. Lawyers for Mr. Alexander, who is known as Kobi, argued that Petrus Unengu, who was appointed by Namibia’s justice minister to hear the extradition, be removed from the case and that it be assigned to Uaatjo Uanivi, the magistrate who ordered the release of Mr. Alexander on bail of $1.4 million.

An article yesterday about the search effort in Utah for six trapped coal miners misstated the amount of time that nine miners in Pennsylvania survived underground in 2002. It was about 3 days, not 11.

The “Popular Demand” listing in the Most Wanted chart in Business Day yesterday about Nicole Kidman movies misidentified the actor who starred opposite her in “Batman Forever.” It was Val Kilmer, not Michael Keaton.

An article on Friday about a Democratic presidential forum on gay issues incorrectly described the history of such events. The Human Rights Campaign, the sponsor of the event, held a similar forum in July 2003; the event was not the first televised Democratic presidential forum on gay issues.

A challenge to the Nasdaq Stock Market’s bid for the OMX exchange of Sweden appeared to be developing as representatives of the Borse Dubai stock exchange, which bought a stake in the OMX last week, were in Stockholm to meet with OMX officials. An OMX spokeswoman, Heidi Wendt, said representatives of OMX, including its chief executive, Magnus K. Böcker, and its chairman, Urban Bäckström, were meeting with officials of Borse Dubai, but declined to give details on what would be discussed. Borse Dubai, owner of the Dubai stock exchange, said on Thursday it had bought a 4.9 percent stake in OMX for 230 kronor ($34) a share, and that it had entered option agreements to raise its stake in OMX to 27.4 percent at the same price. Nasdaq bid 208.1 kronor ($30.90) a share, to be paid in cash and shares.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about the revival of the Fiat 500 misattributed a quotation. The statement, “Don’t forget the original 500 sold four million cars,” was spoken by Marco Zurro, who works for the Roland Berger consulting firm, not by Mr. Berger.

A front-page article on Sunday about how security and rebuilding efforts in Afghanistan have faltered referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of a trip to Afghanistan by NATO representatives. The trip occurred two years after the fall of the Taliban, not one year. A front-page chart with the article gave an incorrect total in some copies for the amount spent on aid and reconstruction in Afghanistan by the United States from 2003 to 2007. It is $19 billion, not $22 billion.

Motorola said it had received orders worth $394 million to supply network equipment to the China Mobile Communications Corporation next year in the first half. Motorola will supply equipment based on technology known as global system mobile communications, the companies said. China Mobile will use the equipment to expand its network, which spans 16 Chinese provinces and municipalities.

The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about Time Warner Cable’s plan to offer customers free digital recording without fast-forwarding, misidentified another cable company that offers some video-on-demand clips with fast-forward turned off. It is Cox Communications, not Charter Communications.

A front-page article on Saturday about the Federal Reserve’s decision to inject capital into the financial system mischaracterized the central bank’s action. The Fed lent $19 billion against mortgage-backed securities, it did not purchase the securities. In a second action, the Fed lent $19 billion through reverse repurchase agreements.
Corrections: For the Record

A chart on Saturday with an article about new federal wiretapping rules misstated Harry Reid’s title and misspelled the surname of the White House chief of staff. Mr. Reid is the Senate majority leader, not the Senate minority leader, and the chief of staff is Joshua B. Bolten, not Bolton.

The Bush administration asked the World Trade Organization to rule in a complaint against China over piracy of copyrighted movies, music, software and books, escalating a dispute that has strained commercial relations between the two trading giants. After consultations failed to resolve differences over what the United States argues are weak Chinese laws to safeguard patents and copyrights, the Trade Representative’s office took the formal step of asking the trade organization, which is based in Geneva, to decree that China’s laws fall short of international agreements.
Jets receiver Justin McCareins had to refocus after a humbling 2006 season in which he lost his starting job to Jerricho Cotchery and finished with only 23 receptions.

PHOENIX, Aug. 13 (AP) — The Arizona Diamondbacks start four rookies, sometimes five or six. They have been outscored by 21 runs this season. They are at the bottom of the National League in hitting with runners in scoring position.
Danielle Salzberg, an education official experienced in starting new schools but not in speaking Arabic, will take over as principal at the Khalil Gibran International Academy.
New Jersey has asked the operators of a dozen social networking Web sites to determine whether sex offenders are participating in online chats and meeting groups.
The American Civil Liberties Union and the A.C.L.U. of Louisiana filed a lawsuit in federal court against the governor and the state treasurer regarding payments the state made to two churches.
The state’s attorney general has reversed a decision relieving Nelnet, a student lender, from paying $1 million.
The mayor of Minneapolis cautioned that Minnesota transportation officials’ swift timetable to replace a collapsed Interstate bridge could overlook the elements necessary to make it a memorial.
A man charged with dragging the Holocaust scholar Elie Wiesel from a hotel elevator in San Francisco apologized to him in court.
Twenty military members asked National Football League Commissioner Roger Goodell to help secure the release of all documents related to the death of Pat Tillman.
The University of California president, Robert C. Dynes, will step down from his position in June, the university said.
A fatal shooting put a chilling end to a youth football tournament intended to promote nonviolence in Cincinnati neighborhoods.
The Rocky Mountain director of the National Outdoor Leadership School, Pete Absolon, died in a climbing accident.
An entrance to Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming was closed because of a wildfire, and crews in Montana worked to contain flames near a residential area.
The city’s method of returning items lost in taxis is confusing, disorganized and frequently a dead end, according to a report by City Councilwoman Gale Brewer.
Roger Clemens is serving a five-game suspension for throwing at Alex Rios in Toronto last Tuesday, and he will not return to the team until Thursday.
Turkey’s governing party has chosen Abdullah Gul as its candidate for president, placing the party on a collision course with the country’s secular elite.
Goldman Sachs and a group of investors are injecting $3 billion of capital into one of its flailing hedge funds.

Pat Riley has ended months of speculation about his immediate future by announcing that he will be on the Miami Heat bench for three more seasons.Riley, 62, gave up coaching in 2003, then returned two years later and led the Heat to the 2006 N.B.A. title. The Heat was eliminated from the first round of the 2007 playoffs and Riley was noncommittal about whether he would return.Riley trails only Lenny Wilkens and Don Nelson in regular-season victories, with 1,195.
pro basketball.

Kirk Hinrich is the latest player to withdraw from the United States basketball roster for personal reasons. Shane Battier did so earlier this summer. This year’s No. 1 draft pick, Greg Oden, pulled out last month after having his tonsils removed.Seattle forward Nick Collison has been added to the squad, leaving the Americans with 16 players as they return to Las Vegas for practice starting tomorrow.

Marat Safin, a former United States Open and Australian Open champion, was eliminated in the first round of the Cincinnati Masters, losing, 6-3, 7-6, to Nicolas Kiefer.Eleventh-seeded Ivan Ljubicic recovered from a poor start to beat Amer Delic, 1-6, 7-6, 6-3, and No. 13 Mikhail Youzhny crushed Dominik Hrbaty, 6-3, 6-1. Carlos Moyá, the winner in 2002, defeated David Nalbandian, 7-6, 7-6.

Ten world champions will defend their titles for the United States at the world championships in Osaka, Japan, beginning Aug. 25.American athletes won a record 14 gold medals at the 2005 worlds in Helsinki, Finland, their overall medal haul of 25 matching their total from the 2004 Olympics.Headlining the American team are Jeremy Wariner, the defending champion in the 400 meters who has the world’s fastest time this year, and Allyson Felix, who won the 200 title in 2005 and has the world’s best time in the event this year.Also on the team are Tyson Gay (100 and 200) and Lauryn Williams (100); Breaux Greer, who has the world’s best javelin throw in 2007; Alan Webb, who set the American record in the mile last month and will run the 1,500; Adam Nelson, who won gold in the shot-put at the 2005 worlds and has top throw this year; Michelle Perry, the reigning world champion in the 100 hurdles; Brad Walker in the pole vault; and Reese Hoffa in the shot-put.

Patty Schnyder defeated Anabel Medina Garrigues, 6-3, 6-2, in the first round of the Rogers Cup in Toronto.The 10th-seeded Schnyder was making her fifth appearance in the event, but her first since 2002, when she lost in the second round to Daniela Hantuchova.

The United States soccer team will play Brazil, the South American champion, in an exhibition game Sept. 9 in Chicago, replacing a match against Mexico that was called off because of financial problems.This will be the first game between Brazil and the United States since 2003, when the Brazilians won, 2-1, in overtime in the Gold Cup semifinals in Miami.
The American public needs to understand the full story of how this White House — with Karl Rove pulling many of the strings — has been improperly and dangerously politicizing the federal government.
Groups want to make neighborhoods comfortable places for elderly people not interested in assisted living.
Joe O’Donnell took some of the first disturbing pictures after the nuclear bombing of Japan and captured famous scenes as a White House photographer.
A brutal triple murder has provoked a level of outrage not seen since the riots of 40 years ago.
Ed Limato, a longtime agent for stars like Steve Martin and Mel Gibson, will be able to leave International Creative Management for a rival and take his clients with him.
As credit markets seized up and stocks gyrated last week, the White House appeared weirdly disconnected if not in outright denial.
Two more people indicted with Michael Vick in connection with a suspected dogfighting ring are expected to plead guilty in the case later this week.
Two candidates for Web supremacy are working up their plans to improve the nation’s health care.
A son of Philadelphia Eagles Coach Andy Reid pleaded guilty yesterday to gun and drug charges stemming from a road-rage dispute.
Concerns about the mortgage market have caused many mutual fund investors to move into the safety of money market funds and Treasuries.
Damage in the shuttle would not be catastrophic upon re-entry into the atmosphere, according to the space agency.
What is it about South Africa’s devastating AIDS epidemic that President Thabo Mbeki just doesn’t want to understand?
Hundreds of federal police troops have reinforced Russian forces in the southern region of Ingushetia in recent days.
Fidel Castro turned 81 and spent his second consecutive birthday convalescing at an unknown location.
Aleksandr Pichushkin, an accused serial killer, appeared in a Moscow courtroom and requested a jury trial.
North Korea said hundreds of people were dead or missing and thousands of homes destroyed in torrential rains.
Five family members fell 65 feet to their deaths from a Ferris wheel after the car they were in unexpectedly overturned at a traveling carnival.
An explosion derailed 12 cars of a passenger train on the country’s busiest line, injuring dozens and suspending rail service between Moscow and St. Petersburg.
The coach for the 6-year-old slum boy whose long-distance running set off an outcry last year, was arrested and charged with regularly beating and torturing him.
Deforestation of the Amazon rainforest from August 2005 to July 2006 decreased by 25 percent since the previous 12 months.
Brands are trying to break away from their reliance on 30-second television spots, which some marketers fear have lost their effectiveness.
The Sears Holdings Corporation, the biggest United States department store company, said yesterday that it planned to buy back $1.5 billion in stock.
The death comes just days after the city’s Department of Investigation issued a report faulting the city’s handling of 10 previous child fatality cases in 2005 and 2006.
Magazine circulation continues to hold steady this year, in contrast to declining sales of newspapers, with big increases among celebrity-oriented magazines.
Eliot Spitzer, the Ivy League Upper East Sider with the reputation for a hyperkinetic braininess, indulged his other side at a Nascar race Sunday.
Zhang Shuhong’s company was behind the recall earlier this month of more than a million Mattel toys.
Water levels in the three upper Great Lakes are wavering far below normal, and experts expect Lake Superior to reach a record low in the next two months.
Cultural institutions in New York paid tribute to Brooke Astor, who Mayor Michael Bloomberg described as “one of the great philanthropists of our time.”
Cécilia Sarkozy is under scrutiny for ducking out of public appearances where a presidential spouse would be expected.
For those of us who celebrated the life and work of Elizabeth Murray, who died of cancer on Sunday, we mourn our separation from both.
A Methodist organization says the state of New Jersey is violating its constitutional rights by pushing it to allow a civil union ceremony for a lesbian couple on its property.
Many Americans say Michael Vick’s high profile has led to preferential treatment from the authorities, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

ORLANDO, Fla., Aug. 13 (AP) — AirTran Holdings will refocus on slow expansion around the country after abandoning its bid to buy a rival air carrier, the Midwest Air Group, company officials said Monday.
In interviews, Gen. David H. Petraeus stresses the downside, and the upside, of the military effort in Iraq.
Hamas rulers have imposed a security crackdown in the Gaza Strip in an effort to maintain public order and control.
The Dutch insurer Aegon said agreed to buy the Merrill Lynch Life Insurance Company and the ML Life Insurance Company of New York for $1.3 billion in cash.
Candidate Mitt Romney filed a financial disclosure form showing that his family received over $8 million last year from his former firm Bain Capital.
Human Rights Watch said that Ethiopian troops had shelled hospitals, that Somali officials had blocked aid convoys and that both forces had shown wanton indifference toward civilians.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he would direct additional financing to about 50 of the city’s lowest-performing middle schools.
A bioterrorism expert has accused the government of violating his privacy by revealing information about him in the F.B.I.’s investigation of the 2001 anthrax mailings.
The craftsman at Vintage Canoeworks work hard to restore old boats to seafaring condition.
If this was Barry Bonds’s farewell to Pittsburgh, he went out rather quietly — quite the change for one of the most successful, and most talked-about, athletes in the city’s history.
The former U.S. Federal Reserve chairman has been hired as an adviser to Deutsche Bank’s corporate and investment banking unit.

Wall Street gave up a moderate gain in late trading and closed marginally lower yesterday after the Federal Reserve and other central banks added more cash to their banking systems, helping investors set aside some concerns about credit tightness.
The former professional wrestling champion Brian Adams, best known as Crush, died Monday after he was found unconscious in his home.
Prosecutors had barely mentioned Jose Padilla for long stretches of his three-month terrorism trial, focusing instead on his two co-defendants.
The grainy black and white video drawn from the Crandall Canyon Mine showed signs of activity, but there were no coal miners in the images.
The Travers Stakes, a race that once promised a rematch among this year’s winners of the three Triple Crown events, has been whittled to Street Sense and a handful of second-tier horses.
New owners are leading a gentrification of Amsterdam’s houseboats, many of which are relics of the flower power era.
A scandal has left President Néstor Kirchner of Argentina and his wife scrambling to contain any potential damage to her bid to succeed him as president.
DALLAS, Aug. 13 (AP) — The TXU Corporation said Monday that it would probably break into three separate companies if it cannot complete a $32 billion sale to private investors.
Edward A. Mueller, the incoming chief executive, said he is not planning large changes at the company, which has overcome important debt issues in recent years.
The resignation of Lou Lupin comes as Qualcomm faces multiple legal battles with rivals such as Broadcom and a U.S. government ban on importing some wireless phones using its chips.
After Sunday’s victory at the P.G.A. Championship, Tiger Woods is five behind Jack Nicklaus’s record of 18 major titles, and future sites could aid him in his chase.
Gardenia, established in 1977 and one of the oldest restaurants on the Upper East Side, will yield to that supreme leveler, the New York real estate market.
Mike Leary, an assistant managing editor at The Baltimore Sun, and Sandra Long, deputy managing editor at The Inquirer, will jointly rank  as No. 2 editors.
A European civil aviation authority said that it was reviewing security conditions at airports in northern Iraq after the pilots said their passenger airliner had been attacked.
The Accredited Home Lenders Holding Company has sued the private equity firm Lone Star Funds to force it to complete its $400 million takeover of Accredited, a money-losing subprime mortgage lender.
Steeply rising food prices pushed inflation in China to 5.6 percent last month, the fastest pace in a decade, government figures showed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) — Consumers went shopping for clothes, furniture and electronics products last month, giving a modest boost to retail sales despite continued weakness in the demand for new cars.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton began running the first television commercial of her presidential campaign on Tuesday.
Prosecutors filed three murder charges against a Micronesian man accused of opening fire inside a church in Neosho, Mo., on Sunday, killing three people.
With defensive end Michael Strahan still contemplating retirement, the Giants have obvious concerns about what his departure could mean for their run defense.
Forced from his job last summer, Dr. Richard H. Carmona, the former surgeon general, testified in July that the Bush administration had made him trumpet administration priorities.
Politicians from the right and left pounced on the government for its landmark nuclear accord with Washington, heckling the prime minister.
Take a look around any airport and the business travelers are easy to spot — not so much by their wardrobe and gadgets - but by their luggage.
Is the G.O.P. going the way of L.B.J.?
Karl Rove didn’t practice wedge politics, but he did cleave his own party.
The aid is said to include money and training for the Mexican police, as well as advanced eavesdropping, surveillance and other spying technology.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,676 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the past week:.
The tax preparer said it would change the terms of its directors from three years to one, barring shareholder approval.
The Aegis Mortgage Corporation joined a growing list of companies hurt by investors’ unwillingness to finance home loans for borrowers with poor repayment histories.
I’m seeing the world about three weeks at a time. Brazil had been on my radar for a while, but once I decided to go recently, it was a very last-minute trip.
Luis A. Ubiñas, who has worked for McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, for 18 years, will lead the organization.
The musical group that serenaded  Ebbets Field with off-key choruses hailing the Brooklyn Dodgers recently marked the 50th anniversary of the team’s departure.

VERY LATE TO THE GATE As domestic air traffic continues to be plagued this summer by the worst delays on record, FlightStats.com compiled data on individual airlines’ performances in July compared with those in the month a year earlier. American Airlines had by far the largest number of flights arriving 45 or more minutes late: 12,302 (17.9 percent of its 68,366 flights in July). Next among major carriers in “excessive arrival delays” were Continental (15.9 percent of 37,386 flights); Delta (15.3 percent of 50,842 flights); US Airways (15.3 percent of 29,476 flights); United (14.2 percent of 52,097 flights); and Northwest (10.1 percent of 42,931 flights). But Northwest had by far the highest flight-cancellation rate: 1,895, or 4.4 percent of its flights.
The private equity firm reported strong second quarter results, but acknowledged that the freeze in the credit markets could drag on its future earnings.
On Monday, the European Central Bank  provided the financial system with another 47.7 billion euros ($65 billion) to keep European money markets from drying up.
The British company that makes Dulux paints said it accepted a $16 billion takeover bid from Akzo Nobel.
The New York Philharmonic is considering an invitation from the North Korean government to perform in Pyongyang, the orchestra said.
The Bangladeshi author Taslima Nasreen will face criminal charges for what the authorities called her anti-Islamic views.
The French publisher of the Harry Potter books will not sue the teenager who was arrested for publishing his own complete French translation of the final Potter book.
NBC said in January that it would eventually add a fourth hour to the “Today” program.
Football’s return to NBC’s Sunday prime-time schedule gave the network only a moderate boost; it earned second place on the night behind CBS.
Tanz im August, Germany’s biggest dance festival, opens in Berlin on Friday.

The Bowery Presents, an independent concert promoter, is expected to announce today that a new rock club is coming to New York, and it’s a big one: Terminal 5, with room for 3,000, at 610 West 56th Street in Clinton.
New York Philharmonic is invited to North Korea,  attacked and charged in India, NBC confirms its plans for a fourth hour of “Today” and more culture news.
An amateur video of a northern Nigerian film actress in a sex scene has caused a scandal in the Muslim north of the country.

By the mid-20th century, even among many British composers and critics, Edward Elgar was patronized as a product of the Victorian era, an unquestionably skilled but ponderous composer, given to lofty pathos.

10:30 P.M. (Oxygen) I AM MANDY MOORE One of the few bubblegum-pop singers cum actresses of her generation not to fizzle, the normally private Ms. Moore, above, allowed cameras to follow her as she promoted her new album, “Wild Hope” (released in June after a four-year hiatus) and prepared for a televised concert. This hourlong special is “a raw look at a six-month promotional run,” Ms. Moore wrote in a letter on the Oxygen Web site (oxygen.com), “with no sweetening.” This from a woman with a hit titled “Candy.”.

MURRAY--Elizabeth . The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. Her loss will be deeply felt. MURRAY--Elizabeth. The Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with deep sorrow the passing of Elizabeth Murray. Her superb talents brought a new vigor to painting in this country, blurring the traditional boundaries of painting and sculpture. Murray was first included in the Whitney Museum's 1972 Annual, and she was a staunch and valued friend of the Museum. We honor her legacy as an outspoken advocate for the art and the artists of this country and we hope to emulate her joy in life. We join her many friends in expressing our deepest sympathies to Bob Holman and her children. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Robert J. Hurst, President Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director , Whitney Museum of American Art, New York. MURRAY--Elizabeth. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the loss of Elizabeth Murray. Her retrospective exhibition at The Museum in 2006 brought to a wide public the extraordinary pleasure of her maverick and exuberant paintings. Murray's courage in dedicating herself in the 1970s to the then-unfashionable pursuit of painting, and her ingenious exploration of the medium over the course of more than three decades resulted in a body of work that never ceased to surprise and enlighten. We will remember Murray not only for the beauty, humor, and wisdom of her work, but also as an enormously generous friend, mentor, and colleague of inspiring warmth and vitality whose courage in fighting cancer was an inspiration for all of us. We extend our deepest sympathy to her husband Bob Holman, their daughters Daisy and Sophia, and her son Dakota. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Ronald S. Lauder, Honorary Chairman Robert B. Menschel, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, President Emerita Donald B. Marron, President Emeritus Jerry I. Speyer, Chairman Marie-Josee Kravis, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director

HICKEY--Jean Hogan . The Board and staff of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter offer our heartfelt sympathy to former President and longtime Board member Larry Hickey and his family on the death of his beloved wife Jean. Stephanie Guest, President Anne R. Teicher, CEO HICKEY--Jean Hogan Died peacefully at her country home in Millerton, NY. Cherished wife of Lawrence F. Hickey, adored mother of Elizabeth Hickey Lavin of Pelham Manor, NY, Magee Hickey Salembier and Jane Hickey Sexton both of New York City and Frank Hickey of Los Angeles, and beloved mother-in-law of Tom Lavin, Rick Salembier, and Mason Speed Sexton. She was the devoted grandmother of 11 grandchildren: Tom, Kate, Meg, Jack, and Janie Lavin, Lily and Floy Salembier, Mason, Buckman, Keats, and Daisy Sexton. Former Copacabana girl, Johnny Weissmuller Water Show girl, and champion ballroom dancer, she went on to become an accomplished actress, performing on and off Broadway in more than 200 productions from 1944 to 2005. A graduate of Saint Saviours High School in Park Slope, Brooklyn, she attended Brooklyn College and studied drama at Columbia University. She was a member of the Snarks, a drama group, as well as a featured performer at the Amateur Comedy Club. Deeply religious and a pacifist, she believed in the Pax Christi movement and in many teachings of Dorothy Day, as well as being a Dame of Malta and a Lady of the Holy Sepulchre. She was a Lector, a Eucharistic Minister, a longtime member of the Saint Vincent Ferrers choir, and a religion instructor at Saint Ignatius Loyola. The wake will be held at Frank E. Campbell's Funeral Chapel located on 1076 Madison Avenue on Monday, August 13th from 6-9 pm. The funeral mass will be held at Saint Vincent Ferrers Church at 10:30am Tuesday August 14th, followed by a reception at the Colony Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Lawrence F. Hickey Center for Child Development, 4010 Dyre Avenue, Bronx, NY 10466. HICKEY--Jean. In the words of Robert Frost, Jean, you, of course, are a rose but were always a rose. Joan DiBlasi, Ph. D.

While Mitt Romney won Saturday's Republican straw poll in Iowa with 32 percent of the 14,302 votes cast, the political significance of the event has not always been consistent. The straw poll did predict the eventual party nominee in the last two presidential races in which there was not a Republican incumbent. But the poll was off the mark in the two no-incumbent votes before those. Below are results from 1999, when the poll was accurate, and from 1987, when it was off.

ASTOR--Brooke Russell (Mrs. Vincent) . The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of our beloved Trustee and Honorary Chairman, Brooke Russell Astor. No one in the modern history of the Library played a more pivotal role in promoting, and supporting, the welfare of the Library than Brooke Astor. As an engaged Trustee of the Library for nearly five decades, Mrs. Astor understood clearly how vital the Library is to the people of our City. She worked with passion, generosity, and immense style to strengthen the Library on every level. Her many substantial benefactions, made through the Vincent Astor Foundation, supported collections, programs, staff, and facilities throughout the Library system. They also inspired, directly and indirectly, the supremely generous gifts that many individuals made to the Library in her honor or made as a consequence of the example she set. Mrs. Astor's love of the Library stemmed in large part from her own passion for both reading and writing. An accomplished writer herself of memoirs, novels, and poetry she believed that all New Yorkers, regardless of circumstance, should have access to the Library and experience the enlightenment and pleasure to be found in reading. Mrs. Astor therefore enriched the lives of countless fellow citizens through her support of the Library's work. Brooke Astor was our patroness and our symbol. She transformed the Library in lasting ways, increasing its quality, its prestige, and its centrality in the life of our City. She was a great philanthropist, a great leader, and the best and most beloved of friends. We extend our condolences to all members of her family. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn & Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Trustees and staff mourn with deep sadness the passing of Brooke Astor, who was a beloved Trustee and generous donor to The Metropolitan Museum of Art for more than 40 years, both personally and through the Vincent Astor Foundation. Her philanthropic touch was administered with wisdom, generosity, and great human warmth, and her versatility and degree of involvement easily qualified her as one of the most generous benefactors in the Museum's history. But she was so much more than that. Brooke understood the special mission of the Museum and was always eager to find creative ways to support its changing needs. Her generosity helped launch The Michael C. Rockefeller Wing, and The Temple of Dendur in The Sackler Wing came to the Metropolitan in part through her efforts. Her interest in China, going back to her childhood, was fundamental to the Museum's determination to become a major center for Asian art, and caused her to become the guiding force behind the creation of the Astor Court, the spiritual heart of the Museum's Asian galleries. Her support also led to extraordinary acquisitions - even after her 100th birthday-and she helped present many important exhibitions, including the 1986 showing of the treasures of the Princes of Liechtenstein. As Co-Chairman of the Chairman's Council with Annette de la Renta, and as Co-Chairman of the Visiting Committee of the Department of Asian Art, she inspired many others to become involved with the Metropolitan. And as a caring Trustee and friend, she endowed an annual holiday party for the Museum's staff and volunteers, personally greeting employees until the age of 101. Wherever there was a need, she stepped forward, often selflessly refusing to be acknowledged for her generosity. She engendered goodwill in all who came in contact with her, and was regarded with respect and affection by every member of the staff. There is a Chinese saying: ''A thousand people drink from a well dug by one man.'' Brooke dug such a well at the Metropolitan Museum, with her benefactions large and small. We treasure the time this great New Yorker spent with us, and the public will long benefit from a spirit of generosity that was remarkable beyond measure. James R. Houghton, Chrman Philippe de Montebello, Dir Emily K. Rafferty, President

A 2008 presidential nominating caucus scheduled in 2007? In addition to testing the patience of the electorate, such an event could open a loophole in the 1974 campaign finance laws, potentially allowing for a flood of new donations to the campaigns. The laws cap an individual's contributions to a presidential candidate at $2,300 for the primaries and $2,300 for the general election. But a technicality would allow a third $2,300 contribution for use in nominating contests held before the calendar year of the election, a possibility this year as states move up their nominating contests earlier in 2008.

HOMOLA--Ivan , M.D. The Department of Psychiatry and the Staff of The Zucker Hillside Hospital, North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, mourn the sudden passing of our long term colleague, Ivan Homola, M.D. Dr. Homola was a highly regarded psychiatrist at The Zucker Hillside Hospital for the past 33 years, as well as maintaining a private practice in the community. In 1974, he was hired as Physician-InCharge of the newly formed Walk-In Clinic, and became the Associate Director of the Adult Outpatient Psychiatry Department. He also directed a program for the psychiatric aspects of human sexuality. An active traveler, he documented his worldwide travels with spectacular photographs of his journeys which he would share with his colleagues. Our sincere condolences are extended to his two daughters; Susan Ruggiero and Louise Marasco, two granddaughters, and his loving companion and travel mate, Shannon Kelly, and the rest of his family, colleagues and friends. John M. Kane, M.D., Chairman and Chief of Staff

ROSENBLOOM--Rabbi Dr. Noah . For more than five decades, our esteemed spiritual leader Rabbi Rosenbloom guided us with his comprehensive wisdom, unfailing integrity, sharp humor and deep compassion. Separated from his parents in his teens, Rabbi Rosenbloom came to this country penniless and without any knowledge of English. His brilliance overcame all obstacles and he quickly became renowned for his scholarship in all facets of our Tradition, earning semikha at Yeshiva University-REITS, a masters at Columbia, a doctorate from NYU, and then serving as a Professor at Stern College. His love for his congregants and students was matched by his passion for the State of Israel and the well-being of its inhabitants, for whom he dedicated his life work. We mourn our loss as our hearts go out to Leah, Michy and his many grandchildren and great-grandchildren that he merited to nurture and guide in his lifetime. B'Nai Israel Jewish Centre Frieda Nack, Chair of the Board ROSENBLOOM--Rabbi Dr. Noah. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and supporter Rabbi Dr. Noah Rosenbloom. A scholar in Torah and a master of secular knowledge, Rabbi Rosenbloom's support of our Yeshiva and Even Shmuel serves as an exemplar of dedication for the State of Israel, her People and our Torah. Rabbi Rosenbloom's lifelong friendship with our Chairman, Moshe Moskovitz, was a model of shared vision, deep mutual admiration, and abiding respect. We extend our solidarity to Leah, Michy and their children and grandchildren whom he merited to see grow in the tradition of our People. Yeshivat Har Etzion Rabbi Dr. Aharon Lichtenstein and Rabbi Yehuda Amital, Roshei Yeshiva Moshe Moskovitz, Chairman

Fred D. Thompson has yet to announce his presidential candidacy formally. But his first campaign trip to Iowa this week should resolve questions -- if any remain -- about his intentions. On Friday, Mr. Thompson, below, is scheduled to appear at the Iowa State Fair, where he will deliver a speech at the Soap Box, a patch of high-profile real estate where several presidential hopefuls of both parties are stopping by this week. Senator John McCain of Arizona is set to arrive today, followed by Rudolph W. Giuliani tomorrow. Their appearances come on the heels of the Iowa Straw Poll, which all three skipped last weekend.

MILBANK--Jeremiah Jr . The Boards of Directors and staff of The JM Foundation and Milbank Foundation for Rehabilitation are deeply saddened by the loss of Jeremiah ''Jerry'' Milbank, Jr., formerly of Greenwich, CT, and more recently a resident of Charlottesville, VA, who died Tuesday, August 7, 2007. One of our nation's great civic leaders and philanthropists, he was beloved by family and friends and universally respected among colleagues in business and philanthropy. Voluntary service and a strong belief in limited government were guiding principles of Jerry's life. For over 35 years, he led The JM Foundation as President and President Emeritus and was a Founding Director of the Milbank Foundation for Rehabilitation. Among his other leadership roles were: Trustee, President, and Chairman of Boys & Girls Clubs of America; President of ICD-International Center for the Disabled; Chairman of Boy & Girls Clubs of Greenwich; and Trustee of the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace; the Herbert Hoover Foundation; the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation; the Advisory Committee on Presidential Libraries; the National Forum Foundation; Taft Institute for Government; the Dole Foundation for Employment of People with Disabilities; the National Council on Disability; Round Hill Community Church; and dozens of other local and national organizations. Jerry's kindness and generosity helped millions of Americans. His philanthropic spirit enabled him to serve many charitable organizations with great distinction, earning numerous awards and honors, such as President Ronald Reagan's Volunteer Action Award, the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award from Boys & Girls Clubs of America, the National Society of Fund Raising Executives Philanthropist of the Year Award, Rutgers University National Distinguished Service Award, the Harold Russell Award from the President's Committee on Employment of People with Disabilities, Kessler Institute's Human Dignity Award, the National Rehabilitation Institute Advocacy Award, the National Leadership Award of the Alcohol and Drug Problems Association of North America, the National Commission Against Drunk Driving Chairman's Award, the R. Brinkley Smithers Award of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence, and the Womens National Republican Award. Jerry Milbank graduated from Yale in 1942, served in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific during World War II, and earned his M.B.A. from Harvard after the war. In 1948, he began working in private finance and investments with his father. He served on a number of corporate Boards, including the Chase Manhattan Bank. He was awarded Honorary Doctorate Degrees by Sacred Heart University, Ithaca College, and Manhattan College. A lifelong Republican, he served as Chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee and founded the Republican Eagles. He is survived by the four children from his 35-year marriage to the late Andrea Hunter Milbank: Jeremiah Milbank III, Victoria Milbank Whitney, Elizabeth Milbank Archer, and Joseph Hunter Milbank, as well as ten grandchildren. He is also survived by his wife, Mary Rockefeller Milbank. We mourn Mr. Milbank's passing and pledge ourselves to the ideals he championed throughout his life. Contributions in Jeremiah Milbank's memory can be made to Boys & Girls Clubs of America c/o Roxanne Spillett, President, B&GCA National Headquarters, 1275 Peachtree Street, NE, Atlanta, GA 30309. A Memorial Service is scheduled for Saturday, September 29, 2007 at 11am, at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, CT.
