SCHOTTENSTEIN--Saul . The Western Wall Heritage Foundation mourns the passing of Saul Schottenstein. The Schottenstein family donated the Jerome and Saul Schottenstein Hasmonean Water Tunnel in Jerusalem in Saul's honor and in memory of his late brother Jerome Z'L. Our sincere condolences to his wife Sonia and his sister-inlaw Geraldine Schottenstein Hoffman and his entire family. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ingeborg Rennert, Chairperson Yogi Loshinsky, Exec. VP

McGOVERN--Mary M. , on August 12, 2007. Beloved sister of Patrick Connolly, loving aunt to the four McGovern brothers, the Connolly family and 13 great-nieces and nephews. Reposing Leahy-McDonald Funeral Home, Atlantic Ave. at 111 St., Richmond Hill. Funeral mass Thursday 9:45 AM, Church of the Holy Child Jesus. Visiting Tuesday 7-9 PM, Wednesday 2-4 and 79 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the John McGovern Scholarship at Archbishop Molloy High School, 83-53 Manton St., Briarwood, NY.

Mitt Romney has based much of his presidential run — both its image and its financing — on his experience with and investments in private equity and other alternative assets. It now seems that the former Massachusetts governor has gained even more from those investments — and lost, too.
One of the world's biggest charities said that the American food aid system may hurt the people it aims to help.

In Thursday's column I focus on a wave of new research showing that climate change is already happening faster than scientists had anticipated. Most predictions about rising seas are based on computer models, but a series of new scientific studies have shown that actual measurements are worse than the models predicted. For example, the north polar ice cap is melting at three times the rate the models anticipated.
By Andreas Tzortzis

I touched on this briefly in my game story in this morning's paper, but I devoted a little more space to it in the notebook that will run in the early editions tomorrow: Was anyone else surprised to see Willie Randolph summon Scott Schoeneweis - and not the left-handed specialist Pedro Feliciano - with the tying run on third base and two outs in the eighth inning Tuesday?

By March, Representative Dennis J. Kucinich of Ohio will probably know the fate of his presidential bid. At that point, he might have to worry about his party's nomination for his own Cleveland-based House seat. The race is already heating up, as his challenger for the Democratic nomination in the 10th Congressional District today accepted the endorsement of Paul Hackett, the Iraq vet and bitter war foe who himself sought a seat in Congress.
I'm headed for vacation, although my Friday and Saturday columns will appear this week. Comments will continue to be posted, but I probably won't write new items until Aug. 27.

A hedge fund manager sent me a copy of a report from Goldman Sachs entitled "The Quant Liquidity Crunch." What follows are Goldman's conclusion, and his dissection of that conclusion. (The manager prefers not to have his name used here. The people he mentions, if anyone needs to be told, are Warren Buffett and Charles Munger of Berkshire Hathaway.)
It's been one year since an old man named Peter Oakley posted his first video on YouTube.

Every human being has his own particular web of associations for identifying and interpreting reality, which, most often, instinctively and unthinkingly, he superimposes on every set of circumstances. Frequently, however, those external circumstances do not conform with, or fit, the structure of our webs, and then we can misread the unfamiliar reality, and interpret its elements incorrectly... - Ryszard Kapuscinski, "Travels with Herodotus" (2007)

Just two days after announcing he would be stepping down as a top adviser to President Bush, Karl Rove is ramping up his attacks on Democrats and, in particular, one of the party's leading presidential contenders, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

Is Hillary Clinton Slytherin's heir? Mark Kleiman, a U.C.L.A. public policy professor who writes at the academic group blog The Reality-Based Community, says Clinton's campaign is "Rove's disciple" for its attacks on Barack Obama.
WATERLOO, Iowa - If Senator Chris Dodd of Connecticut were elected president, sleepovers might become more popular than state dinners at the White House.
RSS feeds are a great tool, and nytimes.com has quite a few. They are a bit scattered around the site, but here is a quick roundup of feeds with OPML files.
CARSON,Iowa -- Rudolph W. Giuliani was nowhere to be seen in Iowa last weekend during the Iowa Straw Poll in Ames, the non-binding, pay-to-play poll for Iowa Republicans.

The Dow has managed to lose more than 1,000 points in the 19 trading sessions since it first closed over 14,000. It seems like every time stock buyers manage to get a rally together, as they did earlier today, there is another piece of bad news on the credit front. Today it is KKR Finance, which can't sell enough mortgage loans, and Countrywide Financial, where a Merrill Lynch analyst named Kenneth Bruce is warning the company could go broke if it can't sell assets for high enough prices.
If only the walls could talk. The building that once housed The Halcyon, the hangout hotel for London's sophisticated cool set, has been converted into luxury apartments.
Want to feel old?
What makes Roy Keane tick?
For more than a decade, tango in Central Park has been the emblem of one of the city's most obsessed subcultures.
Former referee Tim Donaghy admitted to gambling on N.B.A. games while working for the league.
The coordinated attack on members of the Yazidi sect in two Iraqi towns near the Syrian border was the single deadliest bombing of the war.

DES MOINES - Hillary Rodham Clinton may have been the coolest person at the Iowa State Fair today. According to The Des Moines Register, the heat index is 103, and everyone else here at the fairgrounds looked it. Makeup slid off women's faces. Thousands of hands wiped brows and beat the still air with cardboard fans.

You can almost count the hours between the time that a White House official says something, a Democratic candidate responds, and then ... a fund-raising appeal drops into everyone's inbox. In the 2008 campaign season, it's already a familiar routine.
From a reader:
Breaking news from the Maple Inn Café in Osage, Iowa: Elizabeth Edwards is angling to be her husband's vice president.

Foreign Affairs has published Rudy Giuliani's foreign policy manifesto, "Toward a Realistic Peace." (The magazine has published similar essays by Barack Obama, Mitt Romney, and John Edwards, with more to come from "the top U.S. presidential candidates.")

The SLM Corporation, commonly known as Sallie Mae, said on Wednesday its shareholders had approved the $25 billion acquisition of the student lender by a group of private equity firms and banks. The company in April accepted the cash leveraged buyout proposal, worth $60 per share, from J.C. Flowers, Friedman Fleischer & Lowe, Bank of America and J.P. Morgan Chase.
In Washington, as in Wall Street, money talks. And during the first half of this year, it seems private equity firms were trying to say a lot.

The nautical news goes farther and wider than world leaders are willing to roam this vacation season. From the North Sea to the South Atlantic, a trio of oddities on the high seas have carried on in their own odd way since we last wrote about them on July 3. Here's a progress report.

José Offerman's bat landed him in trouble Tuesday. Or rather, it's what he did with his bat: Offerman was charged with two counts of second-degree assault after hitting the pitcher and catcher with his bat during an independent minor league game in Bridgeport, Conn.

When things turn bad, hedge fund managers can't get away with telling investors that the dog ate their returns. But they have an array of other, far more technical-sounding explanations for losing billions of dollars of other people's money. And those explanations have been getting quite a workout in the last few weeks, as some well-known funds are facing double-digit losses or shutting their funds down altogether.
I've never actually laid my hands on a copy of Ralph Ginzburg's literary-cultural magazine Avant-Garde, which existed from 1968 through 1971.

This week in Florence Fabricant's "Off the Menu" column, she reports that Lidia Bastianich will be the first chef to serve as grand marshal of the Columbus Day Parade. She joins an esteemed grand marshal lineage that includes Frank Sinatra, Sophia Loren and Tommy Lasorda.

Marcus Hahnemann is now in his eighth year playing in England. Last season, the Reading keeper helped his team finish eighth in the Premiere League, their first season in the top flight. He recorded 22 shutouts in 38 league games.
No liquidity problems here.
Mitt Romney is up with yet another new ad in Iowa, this time an effort to extend his victory lap after the state's Republican straw poll with a "Thanks, Iowa" commercial.
The Harry Potter craze has begun to fade in the United States, but the boy wizard has plenty of Russian fans eagerly anticipating the September 1 release of the official Russian translation.
Not even Elvis Presley is immune from the recent credit crunch.

Ten years ago, Garry Kasparov lost a match to Deep Blue, a chess computer developed by I.B.M. Anyone who wants to relive the match can go to the Web site which is still up. Although the result was a bit of shock at the time, it was also inevitable. With improvements in computer speed and programming, everyone, even Kasparov, knew that eventually computers would surpass humans at playing chess. (In 1995, Kasparov had predicted that he would not lose until about 2005, but programming and computer hardware development were not exactly his area of expertise.)

For years, the name Jacob H. Zamansky provoked headaches on Wall Street. The plaintiff's lawyer best known for suing Merrill Lynch over an infamous research report by Henry Blodget, Mr. Zamansky has long been known as a gadfly who represented small investors -- and squeezed big settlements out of major firms in the process.

Writing in The Financial Times, former Clinton strategist James Carville analyzes Karl Rove's career: "There is no doubt that Mr Rove won elections. He has perhaps one of the most remarkable win-percentages in modern American politics." At the same time, however, "He has lost an entire generation for the Republican party," Carville writes. He continues:

Out on the campaign trail, candidates are carefully detailing their Iran policies, with Rudolph W. Giuliani being the latest. In two paragraphs of an essay in Foreign Affairs, he describes a broad strategy with the goal of proving to "the theocrats ruling Iran" that "we can wield the stick as well as the carrot."

Pentala Harikrishna of India and Peter Acs of Hungary tied for first in the Fifth Marx Gyorgy Memorial Tournament in Paks, Hungary. (In an odd coincidence, the two share the same birthday: May 10, although Acs is five years older than Harikrishna.) The tournament, which was sponsored by a nuclear power plant in honor of Gyorgy, a nuclear physicist, ran from Aug. 4-15. The games and profiles of the players are on the tournament's official Web site.

A lot of readers don't want to believe they're living in a computer simulation. The last post prompted a virtual avalanche of comments from people insisting it would be impossible for any computer to create a virtual world with virtual people with virtual nervous systems.

On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage. Why? Because books and music, on good days, just seem to go together. And because the "celebrity playlists" on iTunes never get around to asking writers to pitch in.

Australia's Basis Capital Fund Management told investors losses at one of its hedge funds may exceed 80 percent as the United States subprime mortgage rout prompted creditors to force the Sydney-based company to sell assets, Bloomberg News reported.

Cadbury Schweppes, concluding that private equity firms will be unable to raise funds to buy its United States beverage business, is moving ahead with a demerger of the unit instead of a sale, The Times of London reported, citing undisclosed sources.

All summer, the rumors have flown about when former Senator Fred D. Thompson would officially announce his candidacy for president. Would he jump in on July 4 or perhaps later in the month? Now we're hearing that it's likely he'll get into the race around Labor Day.

The auction of Mirant is suffering from a brownout as the credit markets continue to take their toll on deal making. The Financial Times' Deal Reporter site said Wednesday that buyers are waiting out the recent storm in the debt market and that the auction is merely on hold for now.
A place built to nurture both young and elderly people.
Goldman Sachs waived fees to draw investors to its Global Equity Opportunities hedge fund after stock-market losses wiped out $1.4 billion of assets this month.

Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market spread again Tuesday - this time to a type of short-term security held by money market mutual funds. These funds have become the investment of choice for many people seeking a safe haven.

Kaupthing Bank, the biggest bank in Iceland, agreed to buy NIBC Holding for 3 billion euros ($4 billion), less than a week after the Dutch investment bank disclosed losses on United States subprime-mortgage bets.
Tribune said its $8.2 billion sale to a group led by the billionaire Samuel Zell is still on, disputing an analyst who said the odds of the deal closing as scheduled are no better than 50-50.
Bear Stearns plans to enter India by acquiring the financial arm of Ford Motor, The Economic Times newspaper said in an unsourced story on Wednesday.

Aegis Mortgage, which is owned by an affiliate of Cerberus Capital Management , became the third mortgage lender to file for bankruptcy protection in a week as the weak housing market and rapidly deteriorating secondary one for mortgage loans continues to devastate the entire industry.
As Integra Telecom works to close an acquisition that will greatly increase its heft, the Western operator said Tuesday that Warburg Pincus has paid $245 million for a stake in the company.
Doppelganger, a music-focused virtual realm operator, announced Tuesday that it had received an $11 million infusion of venture capital.
Janney Montgomery Scott, the 175-year-old Philadelphia brokerage, will pay $2.5 million to settle allegations that it inflated borrowing costs and fees on stock loans.

Tully's Coffee, once eager to jump into the stock market's roiling waters, now waits nervously on the shore. The Seattle-based coffee retailer has indefinitely postponed its initial public offering, citing turmoil in the stock market.

In what The New York Law Journal regards as a cautionary tale, two former managers of a collapsed hedge fund, Veras Investment Partners, are suing Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld, claiming that the law firm advised them that the late trading that led to the fund's collapse was legal.
For hedge fund bosses, today could be a nail-biter.

A Dutch company, Basell Holdings, has received a commitment for $21 billion in loans for its acquisition of Houston-based Lyondell Chemical in a signal that banks are still willing to finance some leveraged buyouts.

Senator Christopher Dodd, who heads the Senate Banking Committee, joined a number of lawmakers and officials of both parties Tuesday in calling on the Bush administration not to side with defendant companies in a Supreme Court case that could determine the fate of a separate Enron lawsuit.

The banks arranging the 6 billion pounds ($11.9 billion) of debt finance for the Qatari-backed bid for Britain's J Sainsbury's supermarket chain have asked lenders for the money to be made available for longer as talks between the two sides drag on.

Venture capital investment across Canada fell by nearly one-third in the second quarter of 2007 with Ontario taking the hardest hit, as investment levels in the province fell to less than half their totals from the previous quarter.

The Behringer Harvard Real Estate Investment Trust of Dallas is proposing to buy Canada's IPC US Real Estate Investment Trust in an all-cash deal valued at about 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion).

Berkshire Hathaway, the investment firm run by Warren Buffett, bought stakes in Dow Jones and Bank of America and more than quadrupled its holdings of the health insurers UnitedHealth Group and WellPoint.

Confirming recent rumors, the activist investor Carl C. Icahn disclosed Tuesday in a regulatory filing that his investment firm had acquired 3.92 million shares of Kraft Foods, a holding valued at about $138.2 million as of June 30.
Sentinel Management Group on Tuesday froze a $1.5 billion fund, saying too many investors are trying to withdraw their money.

Shares of VMware, the fast-growing Silicon Valley software maker, jumped 76 percent in their first day of trading Tuesday as investors bet that the company would continue to fend off competitors like Microsoft for years to come.

Trading was halted Tuesday in shares of the lender Thornburg Mortgage Asset after they fell 47 percent, the most since their 1993 initial public offering. Earlier, five brokerage firms downgraded the stock and Moody's Investors Service cut its debt rating amid turmoil in the home loan market.
The Fortress Investment Corporation posted a wider quarterly loss on Tuesday, sending its shares down 6.6 percent.
AirTran Holdings reversed course Tuesday and raised its offer for the Midwest Air Group to $445 million, topping a $424 million bid from the buyout firm TPG Capital and Northwest Airlines.

Federal regulators filed court documents on Tuesday outlining concerns that stores in competitive markets will close and consumers will face higher prices if Whole Foods Market's $565 million purchase of Wild Oats Markets is completed.

A former finance vice president at Morgan Stanley and her husband, a former hedge fund analyst at ING Investment Management, are expected to plead guilty to insider-trading charges, according to a prosecutor.
The hedge fund manager William A. Ackman dropped his opposition to the sale of Ceridian, the payroll processor, after tangling with the company for months.
Sanjay Kumar, the former chief executive of Computer Associates, now known as CA, began serving a 12-year prison term Tuesday for his role in a $2.2 billion accounting fraud at the software company.

The first episode of the five-part series “Nascar in Primetime” offers nothing new about Nascar, which raises questions about ABC News’s motivation in producing a documentary about a sport that its Disney cousins, ESPN and ABC Sports, began carrying last month under a contract worth $560 million a year.

With all the talk of how baby names switch around in America, it’s as pleasing as the bygone scent of suntan oil to discover tonight, on the premiere episode of “Newport Harbor: The Real Orange County” on MTV, that some things never change: Southern California parents still name their daughters Chrissy.
If nothing else, “Power of 10,” the new sort-of quiz show on CBS, is an opportunity to ponder the question of why Drew Carey has become America’s go-to game-show host.

I've always felt sorry for food purveyors who want their products to shine at a conference but are at the mercy of the kitchen where the meeting is being held. Woe to the organization trying to promote any red meat under these circumstances, especially bison, which is a goner once it has been overcooked.

Anybody who reads my column in Wednesday's newspaper, on the wonderful eaux de vie from Clear Creek Distillery, is likely to come away with this question: How do they get the pear into the bottle of pear eau de vie?

I mentioned recently in this blog that I'll be going on book leave soon to work with my wife, Sheryl WuDunn, on a book about women in the developing world. That provoked some interesting comments, and it reminded me that we still need a good title.
A downtrodden schoolteacher, a disabled boy and a government agent suffering from an embarrassing itch are the unlikely heroes of “Zebraman.”

“Love for Sale” has a deep sympathy for sexual free
spirits in a rigid macho society.
Tom DiCillo’s angry comedy “Delirious” subjects modern celebrity culture to a microscopic examination that shows the toxic virus of fame squirming under its lens.

Eaux de vie wait
for diners to fall in
love with them.
A one-bedroom condo in Philadelphia, a 2,293-square-foot condo in Dallas and a one-bedroom house in Santa Cruz, Calif.
Many would-be entrepreneurs (baby boomers, especially), stretch out their searches for the perfect business opportunity.
Officials said that cough medicine should never be given to children under the age of 2 unless approved by a doctor.
Families of the victims will receive more compensation and benefits than was originally planned, university officials announced today.
The study by the New York Police Department concluded that there is some danger from unassimilated Muslims, but less so than in some European countries.
Experiments indicate that temperatures inside a gouge on the underside of Endeavour were not likely to become dangerously hot during reentry.
A White House spokeswoman today deflected questions about the designation for Iran’s Revolutionary Guard.
China today disclosed a crackdown on “false news reports” two months before the Communist Party congress begins.
The disquiet on Wall Street showed no signs of letting up as the Dow industrials closed below 13,000 for the first time since April and the S.&P. 500 erased its gains for the year.
Stocks suffered further reversals today on Wall Street as the turmoil in the American mortgage market continued to cast a pall.
Tim Donaghy, a former N.B.A. referee, pleaded guilty today to two felony counts related to gambling.
Financial stocks led a broad retreat in Asia today, amid more signs that the turmoil in the American mortgage market was spreading.

A Bronx man was convicted yesterday of killing a Middletown salon owner on the floor of her shop last year. The jury found Melvin Green, 37, guilty of first-degree murder in the death of Fermina Nunez on Dec. 30, 2006. He was the gunman in a murder-for-hire plot that prosecutors said was orchestrated by Ms. Nunez’s former companion, Patrick Bowie. Mr. Bowie is scheduled for trial on Aug. 20. Mr. Green faces life in prison when he is sentenced on Sept 18. Ms. Nunez, 36, a single mother of four, was fatally shot in front of her customers. The salon was also robbed.
Mets starter Orlando Hernández tied the mark for most pitches thrown in a game this season and his teammates made sure his effort did not go unrewarded.

Jia Perkins scored 24 points to lead the Chicago Sky to a 77-65 victory over the visiting Liberty, snapping a five-game losing streak. Chicago (13-19) was eliminated from playoff contention when Washington beat Connecticut earlier in the night.The Sky lost Chasity Melvin to an eye injury in the first quarter. Preliminary tests showed no loss of vision. Jessica Davenport scored 14 points for the Liberty (13-18), which is a game and a half behind the Mystics for the East’s fourth and final playoff berth.
The Baltimore Orioles punished the Yankees on Tuesday night, taking advantage of four walks in three innings by the fill-in starter Jeff Karstens.

A New York City housing court fined a landlord $50,000 for serious elevator violations on Monday, one of the largest such civil penalties to date, a Department of Buildings spokeswoman said yesterday.
Tim Donaghy, a former N.B.A. referee accused of betting on games he officiated, is expected to plead guilty in federal court in Brooklyn on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) — Federal regulators filed court documents on Tuesday outlining concerns that stores in competitive markets will close and consumers will face higher prices if Whole Foods Market’s $565 million purchase of Wild Oats Markets is completed.

MIAMI, Aug. 14 (AP) — A jury on Tuesday ordered the accounting firm BDO Seidman to pay more than $351 million in punitive damages in a negligence case, bringing BDO’s potential liability in the case to roughly $521 million, an amount the chief executive said threatens its operations.

A picture caption yesterday about a guilty plea by Oliver M. Thomas Jr., a New Orleans official, in a federal bribery case misstated his status on the city council. He is a former president of the council, not its current president.

The Back of the Envelope chart in Street Scene on Friday, about the value and number of mergers and acquisitions this year, referred incorrectly to the deals covered by the data. They were private-equity-related deals in the United States, not all merger and acquisitions.

An article in Business Day on Saturday about the revival of the Fiat 500 misstated the horsepower of the Citroën 2CV, a French economy car that was made from 1948 to 1990. Engines in the earliest models had nine horsepower, not two.
A picture caption with an article yesterday about falling water levels in the Great Lakes misspelled the photographer’s surname. It is John Flesher, not Fleisher.
A Sports of The Times column on Monday, about Tiger Woods’s ability to hold a lead in the final round of major golf tournaments, misstated his career victory total on the PGA Tour. It is 59, not 52.

Because of an editing error, a sports article on Aug. 3 about Mike Nugent, the Jets’ place-kicker, incorrectly described an achievement. In 2006, he had the most accurate season in team history, not the most accurate season since Pat Leahy in 1990.

An obituary on Thursday about Frank E. Rosenfelt, a former top executive of MGM, rendered incorrectly a line from the MGM movie “Network,” which disappointed him when it failed to win the Academy Award for best picture in 1976. It is “I’m as mad as hell, and I’m not going to take this anymore,” not “I’m mad as hell, and I’m not going to take it anymore.”.

The Saturday Interview column in Business Day, with Julia A. Stewart, chairwoman and chief executive of the IHOP Corporation, referred imprecisely to the premium IHOP will pay to shareholders of Applebee’s International in its $1.9 billion acquisition for the company. The premium is 5.2 percent over Applebee’s share price in February at the time the company announced that it was considering selling itself — not 20 percent, which refers to the premium over Applebee’s share price late last year, before an activist investor started pressing the company to improve its stock performance.

A picture caption yesterday about a guilty plea by Oliver M. Thomas Jr., a New Orleans official, in a federal bribery case misstated his status on the city council. He is a former president of the council, not its current president.

China’s retail sales grew at the fastest rate in more than three years, helped by a stock market rally and higher wages and prices. Spending climbed 16.4 percent, to 699.8 billion yuan ($92 billion) in July from a year earlier, after gaining 16 percent in June, the National Bureau of Statistics said. The figures are not adjusted for inflation. The biggest increase in consumer prices in a decade contributed to the acceleration. Stock market gains and a 14 percent jump in urban incomes underpinned demand. “Inflation played an important role in gains for food sales,” said Paul Tang, chief economist at Bank of East Asia in Hong Kong. “But in other categories, there’s genuine continued gains, and overall growth is steady.”.

Economic growth slowed in the second quarter as business investment faltered, with the economy expanding 1.3 percent from the previous year, the national statistics agency Insee said. The economy grew 0.3 percent from the previous quarter, after an expansion of 0.5 percent in the first three months of the year. That fell short of analysts’ expectations and followed soft second-quarter industrial output figures published last week. Exports of goods rose 1.1 percent, while imports rose 2.1 percent in the second quarter, Insee said.

Swatch reported an increase of almost 40 percent in first-half net profit amid booming sales of luxury watches and warned that strong demand in the second half could outstrip production. Swatch said it earned 460 million Swiss francs ($385.3 million) for the first six months of this year. The company has benefited from rising demand for its high-end watches as part of a worldwide boom for luxury goods, including new consumers in China. Sales rose 16.4 percent when adjusted for exchange rate fluctuations, to 2.739 billion francs. In actual currencies, sales were up 16.7 percent, helped by the strength of the euro.

The Citic Securities Company, the Asian brokerage firm, said first-half profit rose more than fivefold as a surging Chinese stock market fueled share trading and underwriting fees. Net income rose to 4.2 billion yuan ($554 million), from last year’s 775.8 million yuan, Citic said. Brokerage commissions at Citic, which is based in Beijing, rose sixfold, to 6.6 billion yuan, in the first half. Citic Securities made 473 million yuan, or 4.4 percent of its revenue, from arranging share sales in the first half. Its investment banking division is the leading underwriter this year, with 20.1 percent of the market. Citic and its units have 165 branches and more than 5,000 employees.

The inflation rate in Britain unexpectedly fell last month below the Bank of England’s 2 percent target for the first time since March 2006, weakening the case for another interest rate increase. Consumer prices rose 1.9 percent in July from a year earlier, down from 2.4 percent in June, the Office for National Statistics said. Economists had expected inflation, which accelerated to a decade high of 3.1 percent in March, to slow to 2.3 percent last month. So-called core inflation, which excludes energy, food, tobacco and alcohol, slowed to 1.7 percent in July, down from a decade high of 2 percent in June.

The operators of the social networking Internet site Facebook have agreed to cooperate with a request from New Jersey officials to help identify convicted sex offenders who might be participating in online chats. The Web site’s owners issued a statement yesterday saying that the company would work with New Jersey’s attorney general, Anne Milgram, above, to identify sex offenders online. Last week, Ms. Milgram sent a letter to Facebook and 11 other meeting sites asking for their help finding sex offenders online. Although it is not illegal for sex offenders to visit such Web sites, Ms. Milgram wants to determine whether such sites are being used to find potential victims.Compiled by John Sullivan.

A Deer Park man was charged yesterday with robbing and sexually abusing a cabdriver at knifepoint, the Suffolk County police said. A driver for Comfort Taxi was at the Deer Park railroad station about 4 a.m. yesterday when a man got in the cab and held a knife to her throat, the police said. The man stole money from the driver and ordered her to drive away from the station, the police said. At Dunton Avenue and South Second Street, a second man ran up and entered the cab, and “subjected the victim to unlawful sexual contact,” the police said. The driver leapt out after the men ordered her to turn around in a parking lot, causing the cab to crash into a parked car, the police said. A Suffolk County police officer arrested one suspect, Robert King, 20, walking on Commack Road after the crash. He has been charged with first-degree robbery and sexual abuse, the police said.

A member of the Rutgers women’s basketball team sued Don Imus and CBS yesterday, claiming the radio personality’s sexist and racist comments about the team damaged her reputation. The team member, Kia Vaughn, filed the lawsuit in State Supreme Court in the Bronx the same day Mr. Imus settled with CBS Radio in a deal that pre-empts his threatened $120 million breach-of-contract lawsuit against CBS. Ms. Vaughn’s lawsuit, believed to be the first by a player in the case, says Mr. Imus and his former co-host Bernard McGuirk, along with CBS and CBS Radio, are responsible for damage done to her character and reputation. The suit does not list a dollar amount.

Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced yesterday that he had named Wilbur L. Chapman, who spent nearly three decades in the New York Police Department, to direct the way the department trains its officers for the multiple jobs of conventional crime-fighting, counterterrorism and community relations. Mr. Chapman, who retired in 1989 as the department’s chief of patrol, served in the interim as New York City’s transportation commissioner and then as the chief of police in Bridgeport, Conn. He succeeds Charles D. De Rienzo, who retired last month, as the deputy commissioner for training and will earn $170,310 annually.

Two drivers were charged yesterday after a crash on the Cross Island Parkway killed one man and injured seven other people, the police said. The crash occurred shortly after midnight near the Whitestone Expressway when a Chevrolet Blazer driven by Bolivar Comacho, 18, of Queens and a Honda Civic driven by Milton Flores, 20, of Queens, collided, the police said. John Reyes, 19, a passenger in Mr. Comacho’s vehicle, was killed and five other occupants of the Blazer and two of the Civic were injured, the police said. Both drivers were among the injured. Mr. Comacho was charged with manslaughter and reckless driving, and Mr. Flores with driving while intoxicated, the police said.

Federal agents arrested 626 people yesterday as part of a sweep seeking sexual offenders, violent criminals and gang members, the federal marshal’s office said. The operation arrested 35 people wanted on sex offenses, 244 on drug charges and 36 on weapons violations, officials said. Officials said 118 suspected gang members were also arrested. Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney, said the investigation had lasted about a month.

Garbage is now being shipped out of the Bronx entirely by rail instead of by trucks, part of a city plan to reduce the number of trucks traveling on the streets, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The Bronx is the second borough to use trains to ship the garbage; Staten Island began shipping household waste in May after the city reactivated the Staten Island Railroad. The Bronx ships about 2,100 tons of garbage each day for disposal outside the city, the mayor said.

Edwin Garcia, 30, the Staten Island man law enforcement officials say smashed the head of his companion’s 21-month-old daughter, was arraigned yesterday in Staten Island Criminal Court and charged with second-degree murder. Marlene Medina, 24, the mother of the girl, Hailey Gonzalez, was charged with second-degree manslaughter. Mr. Garcia and Ms. Medina pleaded not guilty. Neither of their lawyers returned calls for comment. Prosecutors said that “in an attempt to discipline” Hailey on Aug. 7, Mr. Garcia “slammed her onto a playpen containing hard toys causing severe trauma” to her head. Despite obvious signs of distress, the couple waited five hours to get medical attention, prosecutors said. Hailey died on Monday after being taken off life support.

With the starting forward Elton Brand sidelined with a ruptured left Achilles’ tendon, the Los Angeles Clippers added frontcourt depth yesterday by signing the former North Carolina State forward Josh Powell. Powell, 23, averaged 10.8 points and 9.8 rebounds in five games last month for Golden State’s team in the N.B.A. Summer League in Las Vegas.

Tiger Woods revealed plans yesterday to design his first course in the United States. Woods, 31, said that his company, Tiger Woods Design, was planning a private course at about 4,000 feet in the Blue Ridge Mountains near Asheville, N.C. He had no timetable for its completion.

Florida A&M fired men’s basketball coach Mike Gillespie Sr. yesterday after six seasons, less than three months after he was charged with misdemeanor stalking. Gillespie has been on administrative leave with pay since late May and will continue to be paid through Nov. 2.

A member of the Rutgers women’s basketball team sued the radio personality Don Imus and CBS yesterday, claiming that Imus’s sexist and racist comments about the team damaged her reputation.Kia Vaughn filed the defamation of character lawsuit in state Supreme Court in the Bronx. Vaughn’s suit, believed to be the first by a player in the case, says that Imus; his former co-host Bernard McGuirk; CBS Corporation; and CBS Radio are legally responsible for damage done to her character and reputation. No dollar amount was listed in the suit.Imus referred to the players as “nappy-headed hos” on his nationally syndicated radio program in April. He was fired shortly after.A spokeswoman for CBS Radio declined to comment.

10 P.M. (ABC) NASCAR IN PRIMETIME With roots in Prohibition-era bootlegging, stock-car racing used to be a sport known primarily for its appeal to Southern white men. But these days, women make up more than 40 percent of Nascar’s 75 million fans, and drivers like Juan Pablo Montoya attract a growing Hispanic audience. So for the first time, Nascar has opened up its doors, and hoods and pits, to a news organization. For six months ABC News was granted uncensored access to drivers, fans and officials, both on and off the racetrack. Among the speed demons waxing poetic about life in the very, very fast lane: Jimmie Johnson, above, Tony Stewart, David Stremme, Stanton Barrett, Mark Martin, Johnny Sauter, Jeff Burton, Marc Davis and Mr. Montoya.

ASTOR--Brooke Russell (Mrs. Vincent). The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of our beloved Trustee and Honorary Chairman, Brooke Russell Astor. No one in the modern history of the Library played a more pivotal role in promoting, and supporting, the welfare of the Library than Brooke Astor. As an engaged Trustee of the Library for nearly five decades, Mrs. Astor understood clearly how vital the Library is to the people of our City. She worked with passion, generosity, and immense style to strengthen the Library on every level. Her many substantial benefactions, made through the Vincent Astor Foundation, supported collections, programs, staff, and facilities throughout the Library system. They also inspired, directly and indirectly, the supremely generous gifts that many individuals made to the Library in her honor or made as a consequence of the example she set. Mrs. Astor's love of the Library stemmed in large part from her own passion for both reading and writing. An accomplished writer herself of memoirs, novels, and poetry she believed that all New Yorkers, regardless of circumstance, should have access to the Library and experience the enlightenment and pleasure to be found in reading. Mrs. Astor therefore enriched the lives of countless fellow citizens through her support of the Library's work. Brooke Astor was our patroness and our symbol. She transformed the Library in lasting ways, increasing its quality, its prestige, and its centrality in the life of our City. She was a great philanthropist, a great leader, and the best and most beloved of friends. We extend our condolences to all members of her family. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn & Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President ASTOR--Brooke. The NYU community deeply mourns the loss of our long-time friend and life trustee, Mrs. Brooke Astor. Mrs. Astor has left an indelible mark not only on the University but on the entire city, where her grace, charm, and generous philanthropy made her a legendary and beloved figure. In 1965, Mrs. Astor and Mrs. Albert D. Lasker became the first women to serve as NYU trustees. Mrs. Astor was appointed a life trustee in 1993. Additionally, she served as a trustee of NYU's Institute of Fine Arts from 1970 to 1974. Mrs. Astor was awarded the Albert Gallatin medal in 1972 in recognition of her outstanding contribution to society, and received an honorary doctorate of letters from NYU in 1986. NYU is grateful for her generous gifts, both personally and through the Astor Foundation, to the libraries and the Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development. On behalf of the entire NYU community, we extend our condolences to Mrs. Astor's family, friends and loved ones; our thoughts are with them during this sad time. Martin Lipton, Chair NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU ASTOR--Brooke. The New York Regional Association of Grantmakers community mourns the loss of our beloved friend and esteemed partner in grantmaking Brooke Astor, a philanthropic icon without equal. Her dedication to the city of New York inspired us all. With our deepest sympathies to her family and to all who have been touched by her generosity and spirit. Tamara Kreinin Interim Executive Director, NYRAG Vincent Stehle Chair, NYRAG ASTOR--Brooke. The Board and Staff of The New York Botanical Garden are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and Distinguished Counsellor to the Board Brooke Astor. Mrs. Astor's philanthropy here focused on the education of New York City children, as she believed all children should learn about nature. As will so many New Yorker's, we will long remember this remarkable woman. Our sincere condolences to her son Anthony Marshall and her family. Wilson Nolen, Chairman of the Board Gregory Long, President ASTOR--Brooke. The Overseers, Trustees, Physicians, Faculty and Staff of Weill Cornell Medical College and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Brooke Astor. Mrs. Astor was a founding member of the Board of Overseers of Weill Cornell Medical College and was named its first Life Overseer in 1983. A spirited advocate for the health and wellbeing of all throughout her extraordinary lifetime of service and philanthropy, she generously supported the Hospital's commitment to providing the highest quality patient care, and the Medical College's education and research mission, establishing the Vincent Astor Fund for Medical and Graduate Student Scholarships and funding construction of the Dr. Connie Guion Building for outpatient care. She endowed professorships in medicine and neuroscience and was a founding chairman of the Medical Center's ''Cabaret!'' gala fundraiser. She also enjoyed singing Christmas carols with the Medical College student chorus. Mrs. Astor leaves an outstanding legacy of stewardship and benevolence. We are honored to have enjoyed both her friendship and wise guidance over many years, and we join with all those who knew her in mourning her loss. Our deepest condolences are extended to Mrs. Astor's family and friends. Sanford I. Weill Chairman Board of Overseers Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College John Mack Chairman Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D. President & CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital ASTOR--Brooke. The trustees, staff and volunteers of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation (EBC), licensee of Thirteen/WNET and WLIW New York, mourn the passing of Brooke Astor, a woman who stood for all that is sublime and uplifting in our lives. Everywhere we turn in this great city, we see her generous touch. The institutions that speak to the heights of our human potential were endlessly dear to her, and for that, all who dwell in this vibrant metropolis are eternally grateful to her. We are deeply honored that she counted Thirteen/ WNET among the cultural and educational pillars that edify our society. Mrs. Astor, who served as an EBC Trustee from 1976 to 1981, once told us ''Thirteen is a vast educational institution. But instead of visiting a great edifice, you need only turn your television dial to discover its wonders. Every day, Thirteen fulfills the promise that I supported . . . when the station first began.'' That support was indeed beneficent. She created The Astor Endowment for Literacy, (which most recently helped fund the unprecedented series, ''Novel Reflections on the American Dream'') and the George Page Science Endowment for Science and Nature Programming. She also provided major support for ''Charlie Rose'' and essential unrestricted support to help keep EBC strong and vital. Through her visionary commitment to Thirteen/WNET and public television, Mrs. Astor has left a lasting legacy that will continue to benefit public television viewers throughout our region and across our nation, today and for many years to come. We extend our most profound sympathies to Mrs. Astor's family, including her son Anthony, who is a Life Trustee of EBC, and her grandsons, Philip and Alec. And we join all of New York in remembering and celebrating the life of a living landmark, a great humanitarian, and a wonderful woman. James S. Tisch, Chairman William F. Baker, Chief Executive Neal Shapiro, President ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The staff and fellows of the Dorothy and Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers of The New York Public Library wish to express their great sorrow at the death of Brooke Russell Astor. The Center for Scholars and Writers was created by a generous benefaction from Dorothy and Lewis Cullman in 1999 specifically in honor of Mrs. Astor as a writer. The Cullmans had the deepest respect for and admiration of Mrs. Astor not only as a philanthropist but also as a writer of memoirs, fiction, and poetry. The 15 writers and scholars who are invited to the Center each year therefore work in an environment that reflects one of Mrs. Astor's central values: that writing good books is a key element in our culture. We are all deeply indebted to her for having inspired this Center. Jean Strouse, Sue Ann andJohn Weinberg Director of the Dorothy & Lewis B. Cullman Center for Scholars & Writers The New York Public Library ASTOR--Brooke. The staff and Trustees of Historic Hudson Valley remember with joy the varied gifts of Brooke Astor, a Trustee from 1975 to 2000 and there after Trustee Emerita, and 1996 recipient of the John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Founder's Award. She graced our board meetings and our historic sites near to Holly Hill, her Westchester home. Waddell Stillman, President Michael Hegarty, Chairman ASTOR--Brooke. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Mrs. Vincent Astor, a luminous benefactor to all of New York City and a special friend to Juilliard. Through the Vincent Astor Foundation, she supported important educational outreach programs at the School for the past two decades. We send our condolences to her son, Anthony and his wife Charlene, and all of her family. She will be deeply missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi, President ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Board and Staff of The New York Landmarks Conservancy salute the legacy of Brooke Russell Astor. Her support was instrumental in our efforts to prevent the demolition of the early 19th century Fraunces Tavern Block in Lower Manhattan, preserve homes on landmark Astor Row in Harlem, and assist in numerable historic houses of worship throughout the City. She was indeed a ''Living Landmark'', leaving an indelible mark on the City she loved. Frank J. Sciame, Jr., Chair Peg Breen, President ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society are deeply saddened by the death of our celebrated friend, generous benefactor and Life Trustee, Brooke Astor. For half a century, Brooke played an important role in the Wildlife Conservation Society. She became a Trustee in 1969 and served on several important com mittees including the Development, Conservation and Executive Committees, and was Honorary Chair of the Women's Committee. Through her support, the Vincent Astor Foundation provided significant funding for several WCS projects. Brooke's willingness to explore new opportunities combined with her enthusiasm and vision were responsible for the development of the Bronx Zoo's Wild Asia complex. Her Wild Asia Monorail, her World of Darkness and exhibits at the NY Aquarium continue to be enjoyed by generations of visitors. In 1978, Brooke received WCS's distinguished Gold Medal for extraordinary service and subsequently, the Bronx Zoo's recently restored historic Astor Court was named in her honor. She will be remembered fondly for her kindness and dedication to the conservation of animals and their habitats. Brooke embodied the spirit of giving and showed us all the power of one individual to make a lasting difference in the lives of countless people. She set a standard for caring and contributing to the quality of life in New York City and elsewhere. She will be profoundly missed. We extend out deepest sympathies to her son, WCS Honorary Trustee Anthony Marshall, and her entire family. Ward W. Woods Chairman David T. Schiff Chairman Emeritus Steven E. Sanderson President and CEO Wildlife Conservation Society ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Trustees and staff mourn with deep sadness the passing of Brooke Astor, who was a beloved Trustee and generous donor to The Metropolitan Museum of Art for more than 40 years, both personally and through the Vincent Astor Foundation. Her philanthropic touch was administered with wisdom, generosity, and great human warmth, and her versatility and degree of involvement easily qualified her as one of the most generous benefactors in the Museum's history. But she was so much more than that. Brooke understood the special mission of the Museum and was always eager to find creative ways to support its changing needs. Her generosity helped launch The Michael C. Rockefeller Wing, and The Temple of Dendur in The Sackler Wing came to the Metropolitan in part through her efforts. Her interest in China, going back to her childhood, was fundamental to the Museum's determination to become a major center for Asian art, and caused her to become the guiding force behind the creation of the Astor Court, the spiritual heart of the Museum's Asian galleries. Her support also led to extraordinary acquisitions - even after her 100th birthday-and she helped present many important exhibitions, including the 1986 showing of the treasures of the Princes of Liechtenstein. As Co-Chairman of the Chairman's Council with Annette de la Renta, and as Co-Chairman of the Visiting Committee of the Department of Asian Art, she inspired many others to become involved with the Metropolitan. And as a caring Trustee and friend, she endowed an annual holiday party for the Museum's staff and volunteers, personally greeting employees until the age of 101. Wherever there was a need, she stepped forward, often selflessly refusing to be acknowledged for her generosity. She engendered goodwill in all who came in contact with her, and was regarded with respect and affection by every member of the staff. There is a Chinese saying: ''A thousand people drink from a well dug by one man.'' Brooke dug such a well at the Metropolitan Museum, with her benefactions large and small. We treasure the time this great New Yorker spent with us, and the public will long benefit from a spirit of generosity that was remarkable beyond measure. James R. Houghton, Chrman Philippe de Montebello, Dir Emily K. Rafferty, President ASTOR--Brooke. The Board and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our Honorary Trustee, Brooke Astor, who died on August 13th, 2007, at the age of 105. Mrs. Astor played a very important role in the history of Carnegie Hall, providing a leadership gift that inspired the philanthropic community to come to Carnegie Hall's aid and help restore its landmark building in the 1980s. For her generosity--and the myriad other ways Mrs. Astor showed Carnegie Hall her benevolence, compassion, and graciousness--we are eternally grateful. All of us at Carnegie Hall have greatly valued Mrs. Astor's presence in our lives, and we are saddened by this loss. We express our heartfelt condolences to her extended family and to the many who, like us, considered her a deeply cherished friend. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman, Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Trustees and staff of MorrisJumel Mansion Museum record with sorrow the passing of Mrs. Astor, whose kindness and support will long be remembered. James L. Kerr, Esq., President Kenneth Moss, Exec. Director ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Board of Trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the passing of our cherished friend, Life Trustee, and honorary alumna Brooke Russell Astor. A woman of remarkable generosity and dedicated service to humanity, Brooke Astor was a beacon of light for all New Yorkers. No one did more to make this city a better place to live. Brooke Astor joined our Board of Trustees in 1972 and was elected the University's first Life Trustee in 1983. Throughout her trusteeship, she took a warm personal interest in the accomplishments of our scientists, from investigators in the prime of their careers to graduate students taking their first steps in independent research. Her philanthropy touched every aspect of the University, from the endowment of three faculty chairs and the establishment of a fund to support research on the brain, to the expansion of the Child and Family Center and the creation of the Brooke Astor Student Life Center. She also helped to put our Women & Science initiative on the map, by serving as honorary chair since the program's 1997 inception. Her contributions to the University were but a single facet of one of the world's most remarkable philanthropic careers. It was our great privilege to award her an honorary degree in 1984 and the David Rockefeller Award for Extraordinary Service in 1996. In her honor we created the Brooke Astor Award for Outstanding Contributions to Science, of which she was the inaugural recipient in 1998. Brooke's progressive ideals, keen intelligence, creativity, and boundless energy defied conventional notions about the effect of time's passage on the human mind and spirit. She taught us all what it means to be young at heart. We extend condolences to her son, Anthony Marshall, and all members of her family; to her great friend Annette de la Renta; and to everyone who loved her. ''And if you should survive to 105, Look at all you'll derive out of being alive. Then here is the best part. You have a head start, If you are among the very young at heart.'' Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Joshua Lederberg, President Emeritus Frederick Seitz, President Emeritus Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus and Vincent and Brooke Astor Professor James Darnell and Paul Greengard, Vincent Astor Professors, The Rockefeller University ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Citizens' Committee for New York City salutes Brooke Astor, our founding funder, whose vision, enthusiasm and generosity have been constant over the years. New York and its neighborhoods loved her--just as she loved New York. Osborn Elliott Founding Chairman Henry Cornell Chairman Peter H. Kostmayer President ASTOR--Vincent, Mrs.; It is with deepest sorrow that the Board of Trustees and staff of The Animal Medical Center mark the passing of our devoted friend and Trustee, Mrs. Vincent Astor. Mrs. Astor's generosity and compassion toward New York institutions influenced many lives, including those of our animal companions. The Animal Medical Center was a very fortunate witness to Mrs. Astor's largesse, most especially in the creation of two programs. In 1982 The Vincent Astor Foundation changed the course of veterinary research through the integration of AMC's work with that of other great medical institutions with the establishment of the Astor Chair of Comparative Medicine. In 1995 the Foundation acted as a generous source of funding for the Senior Assistance Veterinary Effort (SAVE), providing medical care to the companion animals of indigent elderly persons. In acknowledgment of Mrs. Astor's kindness to AMC, the Brooke Astor Award was created to stand in everlasting commemoration of Mrs. Astor's lifelong care and concern for, and generosity toward, the people of New York City. We extend our most sincere sympathies to the overwhelming number of fortunate friends and family members of Mrs. Astor, a woman whose vision, joy and strength will forever remain woven into the cloth of The Animal Medical Center. ASTOR--Brooke. The Board of Directors, Advisory Board, staff and volunteers of the Merchant's House Museum are deeply saddened by the loss of Mrs. Vincent W. Astor. We will always remember with appreciation the love she expressed for the Merchant's House on her many visits here. And we will be forever grateful for her extraordinary generosity, through the Vincent Astor Foundation, in creating the Museum's permanent endowment fund, thus ensuring the survival of the Merchant's House for generations to come. BARNES--Sheila, on August 13, 2007 in Greenport, NY. Born Sheila O'Brien in NYC on July 14, 1923 she was a lifelong Democrat, avid reader and Times crossword puzzle solver to the end. A pioneer newswoman, she dropped out of Syracuse University after being ''bitten by the bug'' during a stint as copy girl at the NY World Telegram. She was hired by the Roswell Daily Record then returned to NY where she worked for the Daily News, Standard News Association, the East Hampton Star and Newsday. In her ''retirement'' she was an editor/writer for True Detective magazine. Her work on behalf of children for the Guardian Ad Litem program in Florida won her prestigious awards but her first and abiding love was Bellevue Hospital where she began volunteering in the sixties as a ''book lady'' eventually becoming president of the Bellevue Auxiliary. Her proudest achievement was the cocreation of a support group for prison inmate patients. She leaves behind her daughter Nancy Williams Watt, sonin-law Stephen Watt of Greenport; son Edward Dillon Williams, daughter - in - law Joyce, grandchildren Michael B. Williams, Donna Williams Strickland and great-granchildren Alyx, Jesi and Owen Matthew, all of Florida. Donations may be sent to Auxiliary for Bellevue Hospital, Prison Health Fund, Room A100, 462 1st Ave, NYC 10016.

French mountain honey made from lime blossoms (also called tilleul or linden, but not true citrus) has a distinctively citric flavor. It is one of several new honeys from the Pyrenees that carry the label of Mille Envies de Miel. A darker, nuttier chestnut honey and a floral acacia are two others in the line, which also includes a whipped spreadable honey. But the lime blossom variety is the clear winner, to spread on morning toast or fold into thick yogurt, or to use to sweeten fruit or tea. The honeys, in 9.17-ounce jars, are $7.99 at Fairway markets and Barzini Market (2451 Broadway, near 91st Street) and $12.99 at Eli's Manhattan.

Shiso is typically used in Japanese restaurants as a garnish for sushi. But the plant, also called perilla or beefsteak plant, has other delightful uses, as in a brightly herbaceous refresher served at Tori Shin, a restaurant at 1193 First Avenue (64th Street), where it is topped with raspberry. The dish, a shiso granita, is so simple you can make it at home: all you need are fresh shiso leaves, which are sold in packages of 10 for $1.49 at Sunrise Mart stores in the East Village and SoHo.

MILBANK--Jeremiah Jr. The Boards of Directors and staff of The JM Foundation and Milbank Foundation for Rehabilitation are deeply saddened by the loss of Jeremiah ''Jerry'' Milbank, Jr., formerly of Greenwich, CT, and more recently a resident of Charlottesville, VA, who died Tuesday, August 7, 2007. One of our nation's great civic leaders and philanthropists, he was beloved by family and friends and universally respected among colleagues in business and philanthropy. Voluntary service and a strong belief in limited government were guiding principles of Jerry's life. For over 35 years, he led The JM Foundation as President and President Emeritus and was a Founding Director of the Milbank Foundation for Rehabilitation. Among his other leadership roles were: Trustee, President, and Chairman of Boys & Girls Clubs of America; President of ICD-International Center for the Disabled; Chairman of Boy & Girls Clubs of Greenwich; and Trustee of the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace; the Herbert Hoover Foundation; the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation; the Advisory Committee on Presidential Libraries; the National Forum Foundation; Taft Institute for Government; the Dole Foundation for Employment of People with Disabilities; the National Council on Disability; Round Hill Community Church; and dozens of other local and national organizations. Jerry's kindness and generosity helped millions of Americans. His philanthropic spirit enabled him to serve many charitable organizations with great distinction, earning numerous awards and honors, such as President Ronald Reagan's Volunteer Action Award, the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award from Boys & Girls Clubs of America, the National Society of Fund Raising Executives Philanthropist of the Year Award, Rutgers University National Distinguished Service Award, the Harold Russell Award from the President's Committee on Employment of People with Disabilities, Kessler Institute's Human Dignity Award, the National Rehabilitation Institute Advocacy Award, the National Leadership Award of the Alcohol and Drug Problems Association of North America, the National Commission Against Drunk Driving Chairman's Award, the R. Brinkley Smithers Award of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence, and the Womens National Republican Award. Jerry Milbank graduated from Yale in 1942, served in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific during World War II, and earned his M.B.A. from Harvard after the war. In 1948, he began working in private finance and investments with his father. He served on a number of corporate Boards, including the Chase Manhattan Bank. He was awarded Honorary Doctorate Degrees by Sacred Heart University, Ithaca College, and Manhattan College. A lifelong Republican, he served as Chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee and founded the Republican Eagles. He is survived by the four children from his 35-year marriage to the late Andrea Hunter Milbank: Jeremiah Milbank III, Victoria Milbank Whitney, Elizabeth Milbank Archer, and Joseph Hunter Milbank, as well as ten grandchildren. He is also survived by his wife, Mary Rockefeller Milbank. We mourn Mr. Milbank's passing and pledge ourselves to the ideals he championed throughout his life. Contributions in Jeremiah Milbank's memory can be made to Boys & Girls Clubs of America c/o Roxanne Spillett, President, B&GCA National Headquarters, 1275 Peachtree Street, NE, Atlanta, GA 30309. A Memorial Service is scheduled for Saturday, September 29, 2007 at 11am, at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, CT.

Stonehouse California Olive Oil, which has two shops in its namesake state, opened a store in the East Village last year and quickly outgrew it. So a few months ago it moved to larger quarters in the South Street Seaport, where it holds tastings of its oils, made mainly from mission and manzanilla olives grown organically on 100 acres in Oroville, north of Sacramento. The house blend ($16 for 25.4 ounces, $12 for 17 ounces) is warm and fruity, with lightly grassy notes. The estate blend ($16 for 17 ounces) has more bite. Olive oils blended with blood oranges and sharper Persian limes (both $16 for 17 ounces, $12 for 7.6 ounces) are also available.

MARSH--Theron Ludlow. Theron ''Curly'' Marsh, 95, died July 30th in Naples, FL. He graduated from Phillips Andover Academy and Princeton University (1933), he served as a Major in the U.S. Army during WWII. He was CEO of Midlantic Banks, Inc., retiring in 1977 and served on various boards including Kidde & Co. An avid golfer and yachtsman, he was a member of Somerset Hills and Hole-In-The-Wall country clubs, and New York, Norwalk and Corinthians yacht clubs. He is survived by his loving wife Minsi Marsh, adoring children Judy, Cindy and Rock Marsh (Cathy), grandkids Rusty and Kim Wutkiewicz, Katie and Eric Marsh and devoted stepchildren. Private service in Chatham, NJ.

Upon the death of Brooke Astor, New Yorkers of all backgrounds turned to a medium that was unimagined when she was born in 1902. On Web sites and blogs, they recounted chance encounters with Mrs. Astor on the streets, lamented the end of an era for philanthropic socialites, or simply offered their condolences. On the City Room blog of The New York Times, a reader identifying himself as Stewart Rapoport remembered updating her phones and how well he was treated by Mrs. Astor, who died on Monday afternoon at the age of 105. This, he said, was at a time when many of her neighbors on Park Avenue considered him to be merely ''the hired help.'' He was one of several service workers who recalled pleasant encounters with her.

If scientists somehow proved that there was absolutely nothing more to say about Elvis Presley, it wouldn't matter a bit. Just one look at the Elvis Sighting Bulletin Board proves that point: News is being generated beyond all reason. Of course, Elvis worship is not about reason; it's about love. And in the year 2007, that love is being spread in the great snow globe that is the Web. And yes, it's all shook up today, the 30th anniversary of his death.
The collapse of the mortgage market has impacted the stock market and driven Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage company, into survival mode.
Harold Levy, the chancellor of New York City's school system from 2000 to 2002, is getting into the hedge-fund business.
Updated: Potential suitors of first daughter Jenna Bush take note: She's taken.

A Republican recession? If the mortgage crisis leads to a recession, it could be "the whammy of political death" for the eventual Republican nominee for president, suggests James Pethokoukis, the assistant managing editor for the Money & Business section at U.S. News & World Report, at his Capital Commerce blog. There are plenty of people hoping Countrywide Financial will not be forced to seek bankruptcy protection. Not least of these are Countrywide's shareholders, including Barclays and Legg Mason, who would most likely lose their entire stakes. And then there are the 40 banks providing an $11.5 billion credit line to Countrywide, which the company said Thursday it had completely drawn down.

The Midwest's Fifth Third Bancorp said on Thursday it would buy First Charter for about $1.1 billion, adding nearly 60 bank branches in North Carolina and Georgia. Cincinnati-based Fifth Third said it would pay $31 in cash and stock per First Charter share, a healthy 53 percent premium over the target's closing stock price Wednesday.

Ever the jokester, former Arkansas Gov. Mike Huckabee told a group of reporters in Washington this morning that it's still possible for him to walk into a coffee shop, declare he's running for president and get a puzzled look in return.
Are there bed-and-breakfasts in Beijing? Has The Times done an article on that topic?
Since my last posting on Hong Kong mobile audio tours, I've gotten several emails about MP3 travel guides, as well as their flesh and bone counterparts. Here's some feedback:
Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore will contribute items for The New York Times Goal blog dealing with his life, soccer and his dreams for the future. This is his first post.
Representative Deborah Pryce announced today that she would not seek re-election to Congress.
COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa - Senator Barack Obama opened a three-day bus tour here today in this Missouri River town, located on Iowa's western edge in Pottawattamie County.
I'd fallen way, way behind on "Top Chef," which I wrote about several times last year and again at the start of its current season, but I recently caught up.

The Blackstone Group has gotten a lot of unsolicited advice lately about improving its public image. There has also been plenty of speculation about the private equity firm's relationship with Goldman Sachs, with some suggesting that competition for buyout deals, as well as Blackstone's recent initial public offering, had created a rift between the two firms.
The publish-or-perish mentality that pervades academia has taken many forms over the years, but a new threshold seems to be on the horizon: the Digg breakthrough.

David Beckham not only started for the L.A. Galaxy last night, he also wore the captain's arm band and scored his first goal for the club, curling in a signature direct kick into the left side netting, cleanly beating D.C. United keeper Troy Perkins. Video highlights are available on MLSnet.com or the SupeLiga Web site.

Amid fears of a spreading crisis in Canada's debt market, 10 firms, including Quebec's pension fund, said Thursday that they had agreed to bail out the 40 billion Canadian dollars ($37.4 billion) market for third-party asset-backed commercial paper. All told, the group, led by Caisse de Depot et Placement, will hold about two-thirds of the Canadian market for such commercial paper.

Two of Britain's best-known (and most gifted) crime writers, Ian Rankin and Val McDermid, are battling, the Times of London reports, over this comment, which Rankin made in an interview last year: "The people writing the most graphic novels today are women. They are mostly lesbians as well, which I find interesting."
The number of New Jersey schools that failed to meet the standards of the federal No Child Left Behind law fell in 2007,  state education officials will announce today.

After an off-season of bad news about concussions in football, the N.F.L. this week approved guidelines to help monitor and manage concussions among active players. What should the league's responsibility be for the health of former players?
Did you know it was possible to hold, at Oxford University's Worcester College, the title of "Rupert Murdoch Professor of Language and Communication"? I didn't.
The recent pain in the hedge-fund industry has inspired all kinds of headlines, not to mention a few jokes. Now, it has inspired a country song.

Steven Stark, the presidential campaign columnist for The Boston Phoenix, thinks the grueling debate schedule is "slowly destroying the candidacies of John Edwards and Barack Obama - much to the delight of Hillary Clinton supporters." Stark adds:
"We just went 207 m.p.h."

The September Vogue landed on my desk, or rather, on the floor. It came in a freight box. It's very fat: 840 pages. Sienna Miller is on the cover of this super-duper issue, photographed by Mario Testino in Rome during the Valentino festivities. Though I can't comprehend her appeal, apart from an American pixy-sportiness, she looks great in the clothes, mostly feathered things. My favorite fashion piece is Grace Coddington's revisit with Kiki de Montparnasse and French café society in the '20s and '30s, photographed by Meisel. The clothes are right this season for a Jazz Age revue, especially Galliano's and Chanel's. (And perfect timing for "Making It New: The Art and Style of Sara and Gerald Murphy," a great collection of essays and photographs of the period from University of California Press.)
What was the New York base of Deutsche Bank on Sept. 11, 2001, when it was badly damaged by debris from the World Trade Center, is now being painstakingly dismantled.

Mayhem is always in the mix in the morning news, but today it's downright dominating. The lede story on many major news sites is the 7.9-magnitude earthquake centered near the capital of Peru. Initial reports from the region signal a death toll measured in the hundreds, such as this account from the mayor of Pisco reported by The Associated Press:

Charles Schumer, the Democratic senator from New York, is preparing legislation that would raise tax rates for partnerships in all industries, and not just in the private equity business. A spokesman said this approach would be "fairer" than current proposals being considered in Congress.
Kraft Foods is in the early stages of looking for a buyer for its Post cereals business, maker of the Grape Nuts and Shredded Wheat brands, according to The Wall Street Journal.

Sal Oppenheim said on Wednesday that it has raised its stake in IKB, the German bank beset by subprime-related woes, to 5 percent. In a statement, Sal Oppenheim, a private bank, said its purchase would reinforce its "strategic partnership" with IKB.
David Pogue is baffled by Apple’s latest version of its iMovie video-editing software.
The crash of the debt markets is now hitting the silver screen, in a way.

Credit Suisse's chief executive, Brady Dougan, weighed in on several issues in a video interview this week with The Financial Times, including the recent turmoil in the credit markets that has rattled stocks and hurt investment banks' profits.

The Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Japan's largest bank, would consider buying a commercial bank in the United States or Europe to expand its international operations, a senior executive said on Thursday.

Metrolight, a maker of energy-saving lighting equipment, said it received a $9 million investment from a group led by Virgin Fuels, an investment vehicle of Sir Richard Branson, and Gemini Israel Funds.
Rimrock Energy, a private oil and gas company, said on Wednesday that it had received financing commitments worth $250 million from Bear Stearns Merchant Banking and Natural Gas Partners.

Two major Democratic presidential candidates - Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama - have vied for their party's nomination by trying to draw contrasts over experience and taking the country in a new direction. A new CBS News poll indicates that the distinction they are trying to make is sticking in the minds of voters. The Times's Katharine Q. Seelye takes a look at the results:
HelioVolt, which specializes in copper-indium-germanium-selenide solar cells, has raised $77 million in a second round of financing,
Seattle-based Calidora Skin Clinic, which operates stores that offer skin care treatments and products, said it raised $4 million to expand into Southern California.
The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday it had reached settlements with two prominent hedge fund firms, Schultze Asset Management and Quattro Global Capital.
Thomas & Betts, which makes electrical connectors and components, said late Wednesday it is buying a Cleveland-based supplier, Lamson & Sessions, for about $426.6 million.

The organic grocer Whole Foods Market is investigating how federal antitrust authorities botched a release of electronic documents involving sensitive Whole Foods information, a spokeswoman said on Wednesday.
Entrepreneurs are banding together on a new Silicon Valley-based website to alter the power structure between those hunting for cash and the venture capitalists who hold the keys to the coffer.

Stocks fell sharply Wednesday in the United States, set off by worries that Countrywide Financial, the largest mortgage lender in the nation, could face bankruptcy if liquidity worsens after a Merrill Lynch analyst flagged that possibility. The mood grew even more grim Thursday morning, when the lender said it tapped its entire $11.5 billion credit line to boost cash on hand.
Those plotting an insider-trading ring, beware.

The Bush administration on Wednesday took the side of defendant companies in a Supreme Court case that could determine the fate of other investor lawsuits including one stemming from the Enron scandal.
Home Depot and a group of private-equity firms that are in talks to buy the retailer's supply business have agreed to delay the closing date by a week to Aug. 23, the company said Wednesday.
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is apparently hoping to get its profit coming and going.
Reliant Technologies, a venture-backed maker of medical devices, filed with regulators Thursday to raise up to $95 million in an initial public offering.

Midwest Air Group's board of directors will meet Thursday to consider options for a sale, including a sweetened offer by AirTran Holdings, which revived its bid just as Midwest was about to finalize another deal.

From the executive suite to showroom lots, Chrysler is wasting no time in trying to convince customers that it has come out from under the wing of its former German owners.
First Premier Bank has agreed to pay $4.5 million to settle a claim by the New York State attorney general that it deceptively marketed credit cards to people with bad credit ratings.
The video game maker Take-Two Interactive said Wednesday that it might face civil charges and fines from the Securities and Exchange Commission for backdating stock options.
Three reporters for CNET Networks sued the computer and printer maker Hewlett-Packard on Wednesday, accusing the company of violating their privacy in its hunt for the source of boardroom leaks.

The aluminum company Alcoa named Klaus Kleinfeld, the former chief executive of Siemens, president and chief operating officer Wednesday, and said he would most likely take over as chief executive when Alain J. P. Belda retired.
The billionaire Paul G. Allen may try to buy or recapitalize Charter Communications, the cable company he controls, according to a regulatory filing Wednesday.
Stuff, one of the biggest of the "lad" magazines that took off in the 1990s, is being stuffed into its bigger sibling, Maxim, the publications' new owners confirmed Wednesday.
The Russian court-appointed managers of Yukos sold its contested overseas assets at a bankruptcy auction for $306 million, taking another step toward the final dismantling of the oil company.

For months, one of the most popular tourist attractions in Bangkok has been on the brink of closure. In February officials announced that the Suan Lum Night Bazaar, a warren of small shops spanning over 20 hectares in central Bangkok, would be ploughed under to make way for, alas, a shopping mall. April 30 was the ultimate deadline for shopkeepers to clear out.
Toyota has a television commercial running now that brags the company makes nine vehicles that get 30 miles per gallon of fuel, or better.
