The annual rate of building permits issued last month was 22.6 percent lower than the rate last July. The rate of construction on new homes fell 20.9 percent compared with a year earlier.
Today’s discovery brings to 11 the number of people known to have died in the Minneapolis disaster.
Max Roach rewrote the rules of drumming in the 1940’s and spent the rest of his career breaking musical barriers.
Countrywide Financial said it had tapped $11.5 billion in emergency financing from 40 of the world’s largest banks amid difficulties in selling its home loans.
Stocks staged a late rally today on Wall Street after a day of wild swings  as investors weighed the impact of the crunch in the American credit market.
A powerful earthquake shook Peru last night, killing at least 437 people, Civil Defense authorities said today.

A man who had been shot died about 8:30 last night after the car he was driving crashed into a fence at Clinton and Seymour Avenues in Newark, the Newark police said. His car also hit two pedestrians, whose conditions were not released. The man, whose identity was not released, was dead when the police arrived. His cause of death had yet to be determined.
Law enforcement, emergency response and border control agencies have won greater access to the nation’s spy satellites to monitor United States territory.

Sam Pollock, who built a dynasty as vice president and general manager of the Montreal Canadiens in the 1960s and 1970s, has died. He was 81.A moment of silence was held before the Toronto Blue Jays’ game at Rogers Centre last night in honor of Pollock, who was an executive with the team after leaving Montreal. Pollock set the standard by which other N.H.L. general managers have been measured. As the architect of the dynasties, Pollock was considered the shrewdest evaluator and dealer of talent of his era.
The Mets scored five runs in the first, then not another one until a five-run outburst in the ninth in a game that offered glimpses into how maddeningly frustrating this team can be.

A federal judge ruled yesterday against more than a dozen out-of-state gun dealers who had argued they could not be sued in a New York court because they did not do business in the city. The judge, Jack B. Weinstein of United States District Court in Brooklyn, said the city had demonstrated “with a high degree of probability” that the shops’ behavior had been “responsible for the funneling into New York of large quantities of handguns used by local criminals.” That “knowing” conduct brought the out-of-state dealers under New York jurisdiction, he said. The city has accused the shops named in the lawsuit of allowing so-called “straw purchases” by private investigators. Investigators focused on shops that had been linked to hundreds of guns used in New York killings, muggings and other crimes. The city has sued more than 25 shops from Georgia, Ohio, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Virginia. Some of the dealers have settled their suits and agreed to work with a court-appointed monitor.

An article on Tuesday about financial disclosures filed with the Federal Election Commission by Mitt Romney, a Republican presidential candidate, misstated the year he ran successfully for governor of Massachusetts. It was 2002, not 1999.
The Russian court-appointed managers of Yukos, the oil company, sold its contested overseas assets at a bankruptcy auction for $306 million, taking another step toward the final dismantling of Yukos.

The Kaupthing Bank of Iceland agreed to buy a Dutch merchant bank, NIBC, for about 3 billion euros ($4.1 billion) in cash and shares, but left out the bank’s money-losing portfolio of subprime loans in the United States.
Embraer, the Brazilian airplane maker, said its second-quarter net profit fell 49 percent as production costs rose sharply with the hiring of thousands of new employees.
Indonesia’s economy grew the fastest in more than two years in the second quarter as exports rose and lower interest rates fueled spending and investment.
China’s industrial production rose 18 percent in July, slowing for the first time in three months after reductions in export incentives.

David Beckham scored his first goal for Los Angeles on a free kick in the 27th minute of the Galaxy’s SuperLiga semifinal game against D.C. United in Carson, Calif. Beckham, nursing an ankle injury, played 63 minutes before heading to the bench.

Dale Earnhardt Jr. will not be taking his familiar No. 8 with him to Hendrick Motorsports next season. Earnhardt, who is leaving Dale Earnhardt Inc., has used the No. 8 since he entered the Cup Series in 1999. His late grandfather Ralph also used the number. D.E.I. had the right of first refusal on the No. 8, and Hendrick was unable to reach an agreement with D.E.I. for the number.
Amélie Mauresmo has pulled out of the United States Open because of a groin injury and the need to recover fully from the appendectomy she had in March.

Top-ranked Roger Federer beat the qualifier Julien Benneteau, 6-3, 6-3, last night at the Western & Southern Financial Group Masters in Mason, Ohio, in a match devoid of surprises. Earlier, Rafael Nadal, the No. 2 player in the world, and Novak Djokovic were ousted from the tournament. Nadal — his right knee wrapped and his left wrist aching — retired in the second set of his match against Juan Mónaco. Fourth-seeded Djokovic lost to Carlos Moyá, 6-4, 6-1.

Justine Henin dispatched Andreja Klepac, 6-3, 6-1, but Ana Ivanovic’s title defense ended yesterday when she lost to Zi Yan, the 169th-ranked player in the world, in the second round of the Rogers Cup in Toronto. No. 5 Anna Chakvetadze and No. 8 Elena Dementieva were eliminated.

The former San Jose forward Mark Bell has pleaded no contest to drunken driving and hit-and-run charges and will serve six months in a Santa Clara County, Calif., jail, a prosecutor said. Bell, who was traded to Toronto in June, had faced nearly four years in state prison if convicted of the original charges.

In 35 games at Pittsburgh, Darrelle Revis recorded 129 tackles and 8 interceptions. Revis has missed 19 practices, 2 scrimmages, 1 walkthrough and 1 game.
A powerful earthquake shook Peru’s southern coast on Wednesday, toppling some houses in Lima and generating a tsunami warning.

CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 15 — Cheshire residents, angered by revelations that the men suspected of killing three members of a prominent family in a home invasion robbery last month had been paroled after convictions for burglary, rallied in a town park on Wednesday to demand stricter laws to keep repeat offenders behind bars.
The Yankees and their first-round pick in this year’s draft, the right-hander Andrew Brackman, reached agreement on a contract, hours before the Yankees would have lost his rights.
Three reporters for CNET Networks sued Hewlett-Packard on Wednesday, accusing the computer maker of violating thier privacy during its search for boardroom leaks.
South Texas braced for Tropical Storm Erin to bring torrential rain to a state that has already had one of its wettest summers on record.
Nassau and Suffolk Counties have chosen e-Path Communications of Tampa, Fla., for a $150 million plan to make wireless broadband available to the public.
The Food and Drug Administration issued an advisory against giving cough and cold medicines to children under the age of 2.
Astronauts aboard the Endeavour will spend Thursday studying plans for conducting the first in-flight repair of the shuttle’s thermal tiles.
U.S. officials are quietly urging Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to share power with Benazir Bhutto, a longtime rival.
The governing military junta imposed a surprise 100 percent price increase on rationed fuel.
Russia restored full rail service on the line between Moscow and St. Petersburg, which had been suspended after a bomb derailed a passenger train on Monday.
Frederick Chiluba is accused of stealing $500,000 from the state coffers between 1991 to 2001, while he was president.
At least 3,000 Central American migrants remained stranded along railroad lines in southern Mexico after an American train operator shut down its operations there.
The police arrested a student they said had confessed to posting on the Internet a grisly video of two young men apparently being executed in front of a Nazi flag.
The foreign ministers of Japan, Israel and Jordan and senior Palestinian officials met to discuss the possibility of building a joint agricultural-industrial park.
The police arrested a 63-year-old man they said had practiced dentistry for 29 years although he had no training.
A consultation of coca leaves by Aymara Indian shamans presages the recovery of Fidel Castro, according to Cuba’s ambassador to Bolivia.

New York and northern New Jersey will get more than $50 million in the latest round of federal antiterror grants to protect mass transit systems and ports, officials said yesterday. The Department of Homeland Security is expected to make the announcement today. The area will share about $37 million in transit security money and slightly less than $15 million for port security.

A Rhode Island man was arrested yesterday and accused of throwing liquid into a whale tank at the Mystic Aquarium and Institute for Exploration. The man, Paul Watkins, 54, of East Providence, was charged with disorderly conduct and criminal trespass, the Stonington police said. He is accused of tossing a mixture of baking soda and a substance used in soldering into a 750,000-gallon tank that is home to three whales, the police said. The whales were not harmed, and tests showed that the water was fine, an aquarium spokesman said. The police said Mr. Watkins told them he threw the liquid into the tank “to keep the fish warm and protect them from Agent Orange,” a chemical defoliant used in the Vietnam War.

A new emergency medical station will replace an old firehouse in Woodlawn that was closed last year because of structural problems, city officials said yesterday. Firefighters from Ladder Company 39 moved from their station at 243 East 233rd Street in June 2006 because of the building’s poor condition, city officials said. The ladder company is now based about a mile away, sharing quarters with Engine Company 63. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city would begin construction of a new station for emergency medical workers on the site in the fall of 2008. The new $12.4 million station will allow ambulances that are now based at three stations to operate out of one.

Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, left, a Westchester County Democrat, said yesterday that the terms of an aid package that federal officials offered this week for broad traffic reduction measures in New York City fall short of what is required under state law. Mr. Brodsky, who wrote an Assembly report critical of the plan, wrote a letter to Transportation Secretary Mary E. Peters yesterday asking for a clarification of the terms of the $354 million package. The aid is contingent on the state’s approval of a pilot program to carry out Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s most controversial proposal, which would charge drivers for entering the most congested parts of Manhattan on weekdays. Mr. Brodsky said a new state law that sets up a commission to study the mayor’s plan required a firm commitment of $200 million from federal officials by October. His comments and letter underscored continuing opposition in the Democrat-led Assembly. A spokesman for Speaker Sheldon Silver, who has expressed concerns about the plan, had no comment.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 167.45 points after having stayed in positive territory for most of the day.

Fifteen people have been indicted on federal charges of running a crime ring that specialized in producing fake identification to obtain loans and credit card accounts, state officials said yesterday. Investigators said the group produced fake drivers’ licenses, resident cards and Social Security cards. They were used to establish credit to get bank loans and mortgages totaling at least $10 million.

Police departments in New Jersey will be able to trace gun ownership almost instantly through a federal-state agreement announced yesterday. The agreement provides the New Jersey State Police with round-the-clock access to e-Trace, a nationwide computer database of firearms purchases operated by the United States Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives. The agreement, which is meant to help the police identify sources of illegal weapons, calls for each police department in the state to send gun-tracing information to the database. Just under a third of the state’s police departments had submitted tracing information to e-Trace, and it was not readily available to the authorities in other jurisdictions. Last year, nearly 5,000 people in New Jersey were arrested for possessing illegal firearms.

A lawyer representing one of the most severely injured victims of last month’s steam pipe explosion in Manhattan said yesterday that an independent monitor should oversee the testing of evidence. In a hearing on a motion filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the lawyer, Kenneth P. Thompson, said that Consolidated Edison, which runs the city’s steam network, could not be trusted to perform destructive testing on equipment found at the site of the July 18 explosion. Mr. Thompson represents Gregory McCullough, 21, who suffered third-degree burns. The lawyer obtained a temporary restraining order last week to stop the testing until a judge could review the motion. Henry G. Miller, a lawyer for Con Edison, said that an independent company, Evidence Security Inc., had been hired to secure evidence found at the scene. Arguments in Mr. Thompson’s motion are expected to resume this morning.
Three judges hearing challenges to the National Security Agency’s surveillance programs appeared skeptical of the Bush administration’s argument.
CARE, one of the world’s biggest charities, said that American food aid may hurt the people it aims to help.
Alpha Media Group will turn Stuff magazine into a section of Maxim, while keeping Stuff.com as a stand-alone Web site.
Engineers are grappling with the broader implications of the Crandall Canyon Mine accident in Utah.
A tractor-trailer crashed and exploded in flames, killing at least one person and snapping off an overpass support column near Grand Junction.
A federal appeals court ruled that Royal Dutch Shell must further postpone plans for exploratory drilling off the northern coast of Alaska.
An illegal immigrant who took refuge in a church a year ago to escape deportation said she planned to leave her sanctuary to lobby Congress for immigration changes.
A sheriff’s deputy killed on Wednesday was the third law enforcement officer shot in Florida in 10 days.
Representative Deborah Pryce of Ohio, an eight-term Republican, will not seek re-election, party officials said.
It took all of two weeks for the political unity brought on by a deadly bridge collapse in Minneapolis to unravel.
A Democratic senator said he would indefinitely block President Bush’s nominee to become the C.I.A.’s top lawyer.
Donald H. Rumsfeld resigned as defense secretary before last November’s election, according to his resignation letter, but his decision was not announced until after the voting.
Biotechnology giant Amgen said Wednesday that it would cut its workforce by at least 2,200 as it sought to cope with sliding sales of the anemia drug Aranesp, its biggest selling product.
To his fans, Phil Rizzuto was a warm-hearted personality who charmed them during chance encounters and elicited smiles with his idiosyncratic one-liners.
If the United States is to reap the rewards of globalization, the government must provide a more robust safety net to protect vulnerable workers.

If nothing else, the rainstorm last week that left millions of commuters in the dark about the whereabouts of their trains and buses reinforced the idea that riders can never have too much information.

The court-appointed guardians of Brooke Astor have filed legal papers saying that the will she signed in 1997 should be the valid one. They argue that she was not mentally competent or was unduly influenced when she signed her last will in 2002 and several amendments to it over the following two years, according to people who have been briefed on the situation.
A new federal push to promote traffic-busting policies like congestion pricing appears to contradict other tax breaks.
The Empire Hotel, opposite Lincoln Center, quietly reopened for business this month, and not as a luxury condominium as had once been planned.
Two prominent Muslim American organizations took steps to reverse what they called a Justice Department effort to smear the entire Muslim community.
I was totally not prepared for instant messaging - the idea that two people on opposite sides of the planet can type messages back and forth in nearly real time.
For too long, the Republican-controlled Congress allowed mine operators to put off making needed investments to ensure their workers’ safety.
Tim Donaghy left the basketball court as a disgraced former N.B.A. referee in July and left a federal court room Wednesday as an admitted criminal, a conspirator and a gambling addict.
With a new chief marketing officer, Chrysler is wasting no time in trying to persuade customers that it has come out from under the wing of its former German owners.
The top deputy to Gov. Eliot Spitzer said that he could remain effective in his job, even as some Democrats quietly question whether his continued role in the administration is hurting the governor.
America needs to respond to real and alleged facets of Iran’s many dangerous behaviors with serious policies, not more theatrics.
The rate of core inflation remained stalled at 2.2 percent, suggesting that it was unlikely that the Federal Reserve would lower interest rates soon.

New York’s attorney general is opening an inquiry into the relationships between universities and providers of study abroad.
Days after Phil Rizzuto’s death, stories are being recalled in his childhood neighborhood in Queens.
North Korea detailed a picture of widespread devastation on Wednesday after heavy rains wiped out more than a tenth of the impoverished country’s farmland.
The uproar began in July, when Mayor Jim Naugle said that installing a single-occupancy restroom on a local beach could deter “homosexual activity.”
Shunning low-cost call centers and e-mail-based service, Netflix is hoping to use customer service as a strategic weapon against Blockbuster’s rival DVD-mailing service.
WakeUpWalMart.com is introducing a fresh round of ads in addition to naming several Democratic political strategists to leadership positions.
Several Christian faiths have joined an effort to create a common code of conduct for religious conversions.
The deadliest coordinated attack since the invasion of Iraq in 2003 left at least 250 dead and 350 wounded, and the toll could still rise significantly, officials said.
Sierra Leone’s main opposition party vowed to mount a legal challenge if official results, still trickling in, did not show that it had won a parliamentary majority.
A series of killings in Germany apparently stemmed from a vendetta between rival southern Italian crime families.
Families of the Virginia Tech students and faculty members shot to death in April will receive more compensation than originally planned.

PREGNANCY is no time to abandon fitness. Sure it's ridiculous (not to mention ill advised) to try to develop steely buns or defined abs in the next nine months. But Kegel exercises may help strengthen pelvic muscles to avoid postpartum incontinence, and modified core workouts can diminish back pain common in pregnancy. ''The key is to modify exercise to the pregnant body,'' said Liz Neporent, who has a master's in exercise physiology. Changes to keep in mind include looser ligaments that can be prone to overstretching, and the shifting center of gravity as the stomach grows.

If you like tropical fish but not the bulky aquariums that go with them, consider the AquaVista 500 ($299.99), below, which hangs on the wall like a picture. The 4.3-inch-thick, 26-inch-square aquarium is made of shatterproof acrylic and injection-molded plastic, and the pump and filtration system are concealed inside. All you see are the fish in their environment, against a background chosen from eight options, including midnight black and deep blue. The aquarium comes with a black or silver frame; a wood frame is available for an additional $60. ''It's a living art piece,'' said Scott Yen, the president of AquaVista Enterprise Inc., the Menlo Park, Calif., company that makes the aquarium. ''We're giving you the canvas, and your fish are the art.'' To order: aquavistainc.com; information: (888) 627-8284.STEPHEN MILIOTI

MILBANK--Jeremiah Jr. The Boards of Directors and staff of The JM Foundation and Milbank Foundation for Rehabilitation are deeply saddened by the loss of Jeremiah ''Jerry'' Milbank, Jr., formerly of Greenwich, CT, and more recently a resident of Charlottesville, VA, who died Tuesday, August 7, 2007. One of our nation's great civic leaders and philanthropists, he was beloved by family and friends and universally respected among colleagues in business and philanthropy. Voluntary service and a strong belief in limited government were guiding principles of Jerry's life. For over 35 years, he led The JM Foundation as President and President Emeritus and was a Founding Director of the Milbank Foundation for Rehabilitation. Among his other leadership roles were: Trustee, President, and Chairman of Boys & Girls Clubs of America; President of ICD-International Center for the Disabled; Chairman of Boy & Girls Clubs of Greenwich; and Trustee of the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace; the Herbert Hoover Foundation; the Ronald Reagan Presidential Foundation; the Advisory Committee on Presidential Libraries; the National Forum Foundation; Taft Institute for Government; the Dole Foundation for Employment of People with Disabilities; the National Council on Disability; Round Hill Community Church; and dozens of other local and national organizations. Jerry's kindness and generosity helped millions of Americans. His philanthropic spirit enabled him to serve many charitable organizations with great distinction, earning numerous awards and honors, such as President Ronald Reagan's Volunteer Action Award, the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award from Boys & Girls Clubs of America, the National Society of Fund Raising Executives Philanthropist of the Year Award, Rutgers University National Distinguished Service Award, the Harold Russell Award from the President's Committee on Employment of People with Disabilities, Kessler Institute's Human Dignity Award, the National Rehabilitation Institute Advocacy Award, the National Leadership Award of the Alcohol and Drug Problems Association of North America, the National Commission Against Drunk Driving Chairman's Award, the R. Brinkley Smithers Award of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence, and the Womens National Republican Award. Jerry Milbank graduated from Yale in 1942, served in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific during World War II, and earned his M.B.A. from Harvard after the war. In 1948, he began working in private finance and investments with his father. He served on a number of corporate Boards, including the Chase Manhattan Bank. He was awarded Honorary Doctorate Degrees by Sacred Heart University, Ithaca College, and Manhattan College. A lifelong Republican, he served as Chairman of the Republican National Finance Committee and founded the Republican Eagles. He is survived by the four children from his 35-year marriage to the late Andrea Hunter Milbank: Jeremiah Milbank III, Victoria Milbank Whitney, Elizabeth Milbank Archer, and Joseph Hunter Milbank, as well as ten grandchildren. He is also survived by his wife, Mary Rockefeller Milbank. We mourn Mr. Milbank's passing and pledge ourselves to the ideals he championed throughout his life. Contributions in Jeremiah Milbank's memory can be made to Boys & Girls Clubs of America c/o Roxanne Spillett, President, B&GCA National Headquarters, 1275 Peachtree Street, NE, Atlanta, GA 30309. A Memorial Service is scheduled for Saturday, September 29, 2007 at 11am, at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, CT.

An obituary on Aug. 7 by The New York Times Regional Newspaper Group about the indoor-tennis promoter Jerry Schneider erroneously credited him with a distinction. Fred Malina -- and not Schneider -- established the first modern tennis club with permanent indoor courts, in 1958 in New York. It is called the Armonk Tennis Club. As the obituary noted, Schneider built his club in a Chicago suburb in 1961.

BIRD--Etta G., M.D., November 22, 1916-August 13, 2007. Distinguished research psychiatrist and psychotherapist. Her seminal research study on chlorpromazine (thorazine) in the treatment of mental illness, published in the American Journal of Psychiatry, May 1957, freed millions of schizophrenic patients from lifetime confinement in mental institutions by proving for the first time that their disease could effectively be treated with medication. Her only regret was that illness forced her to cancel seeing patients two weeks before death. Predeceased by brothers Sidney and Joseph Gerstein, sister-in-law Chana Gerstein, parents Lena and Solomon Gerstein, and longtime companion, Peter Mande. A brief marriage to Rubin Bird ended in divorce. Survived by daughter Beth Bird Pocker and son-in-law Richard Pocker of Pound Ridge, NY, grandson Sam Pocker of Queens, NY, nephews Steven and Michael Gerstein, nieces Helene Morris and Sabine Cavanaugh, and grandniece Holly Katz.

A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup yesterday about Marcus Hahnemann, a 35-year-old American goalkeeper in the English Premier League, misspelled the surname of another goalie in the league who is a friend of Mr. Hahnemann's. It is Edwin van der Sar, not van der Saar. Also, because of an editing error, a report in the Notes section of the roundup about a semifinal match in the inaugural SuperLiga tournament reversed the result and misstated the final score in some copies. Pachuca, the reigning Mexican league champion, defeated the Houston Dynamo of Major League Soccer in a penalty kick shootout, 4-3. Houston did not win, 3-2.

A lawyer representing one of the most severely injured victims of last month's steam pipe explosion in Manhattan said yesterday that an independent monitor should oversee the testing of evidence. In a hearing on a motion filed in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the lawyer, Kenneth P. Thompson, said that Consolidated Edison, which runs the city's steam network, could not be trusted to perform destructive testing on equipment found at the site of the July 18 explosion. Mr. Thompson represents Gregory McCullough, 21, who suffered third-degree burns. The lawyer obtained a temporary restraining order last week to stop the testing until a judge could review the motion. Henry G. Miller, a lawyer for Con Edison, said that an independent company, Evidence Security Inc., had been hired to secure evidence found at the scene. Arguments in Mr. Thompson's motion are expected to resume this morning.

ASTOR--Brooke. The trustees and staff of The Library of America express deep sorrow on the death of Brooke Astor. Mrs. Astor gave encouragement and support to The Library of America and believed in the power of books to change lives. D. Ronald Daniel, Chairman Cheryl Hurley, President ASTOR--Brooke Russell./d The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library mourn the death of Brooke Russell Astor. Brooke was a valued Trustee and became a Trustee Emerita. A Fellow since 1955, she was also a founding member of the Director's Roundtable. Brooke was greatly loved here. Her generosity advanced our programs and growth. And her presence at meetings and receptions and dinners illuminated the Morgan. She inspired many others to follow her splendid example. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends and all those who knew and miss her. Charles E. Pierce, Jr. Dir. S. Parker Gilbert, Pres., Board of Trustees ASTOR--Brooke. The staff and Trustees of Historic Hudson Valley remember with joy the varied gifts of Brooke Astor, a Trustee from 1975 to 2000 and there after Trustee Emerita, and 1996 recipient of the John D. Rockefeller, Jr. Founder's Award. She graced our board meetings and our historic sites near to Holly Hill, her Westchester home. Waddell Stillman, President Michael Hegarty, Chairman ASTOR--Brooke. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Mrs. Vincent Astor, a luminous benefactor to all of New York City and a special friend to Juilliard. Through the Vincent Astor Foundation, she supported important educational outreach programs at the School for the past two decades. We send our condolences to her son, Anthony and his wife Charlene, and all of her family. She will be deeply missed by us all. Bruce Kovner, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi, President ASTOR--Brooke. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Brooke Astor, and send condolences to her family. ASTOR--Brooke Russell. Born Portsmouth, NH, March 30, 1902, died August 13, 2007, Philanthropist, Author. Awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, 1998, by President Clinton. Presidential Citizen's Medal, 1988, by President Reagan. Dame of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem. Beloved mother of Anthony D. Marshall. She led a full life. In her own words, to be read at her funeral, she stated, ''I want to leave my fellow man more sure there's a divinity that shapes his end. I want to leave him with the knowledge that death is nothing and life is everything.'' Funeral services Friday, August 17 at 2:30pm, St. Thomas Church, 5th Ave. at 53rd St. Anthony and Charlene Marshall. ASTOR--Brooke Russell. Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, the oldest and largest social services and educational organization on the Upper East Side, has greatly appreciated the generosity of our benefactor, Brooke Russell Astor. For more than three decades, through the Vincent Astor Foundation and her personal support, our programs have been greatly enhanced. One of our fondest memories of Mrs. Astor is when she braved a blizzard to attend a fund raiser to support our many services for people in need. Elizabeth Rohatyn, Honorary Chair Sydney Roberts Shuman, Honorary Chair Diana Ronan Quasha, Chair Thomas J. Edelman, President Warren B. Scharf, Executive Director ASTOR--Vincent, Mrs.; It is with deepest sorrow that the Board of Trustees and staff of The Animal Medical Center mark the passing of our devoted friend and Trustee, Mrs. Vincent Astor. Mrs. Astor's generosity and compassion toward New York institutions influenced many lives, including those of our animal companions. The Animal Medical Center was a very fortunate witness to Mrs. Astor's largesse, most especially in the creation of two programs. In 1982 The Vincent Astor Foundation changed the course of veterinary research through the integration of AMC's work with that of other great medical institutions with the establishment of the Astor Chair of Comparative Medicine. In 1995 the Foundation acted as a generous source of funding for the Senior Assistance Veterinary Effort (SAVE), providing medical care to the companion animals of indigent elderly persons. In acknowledgment of Mrs. Astor's kindness to AMC, the Brooke Astor Award was created to stand in everlasting commemoration of Mrs. Astor's lifelong care and concern for, and generosity toward, the people of New York City. We extend our most sincere sympathies to the overwhelming number of fortunate friends and family members of Mrs. Astor, a woman whose vision, joy and strength will forever remain woven into the cloth of The Animal Medical Center. ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Board of Trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the passing of our cherished friend, Life Trustee, and honorary alumna Brooke Russell Astor. A woman of remarkable generosity and dedicated service to humanity, Brooke Astor was a beacon of light for all New Yorkers. No one did more to make this city a better place to live. Brooke Astor joined our Board of Trustees in 1972 and was elected the University's first Life Trustee in 1983. Throughout her trusteeship, she took a warm personal interest in the accomplishments of our scientists, from investigators in the prime of their careers to graduate students taking their first steps in independent research. Her philanthropy touched every aspect of the University, from the endowment of three faculty chairs and the establishment of a fund to support research on the brain, to the expansion of the Child and Family Center and the creation of the Brooke Astor Student Life Center. She also helped to put our Women & Science initiative on the map, by serving as honorary chair since the program's 1997 inception. Her contributions to the University were but a single facet of one of the world's most remarkable philanthropic careers. It was our great privilege to award her an honorary degree in 1984 and the David Rockefeller Award for Extraordinary Service in 1996. In her honor we created the Brooke Astor Award for Outstanding Contributions to Science, of which she was the inaugural recipient in 1998. Brooke's progressive ideals, keen intelligence, creativity, and boundless energy defied conventional notions about the effect of time's passage on the human mind and spirit. She taught us all what it means to be young at heart. We extend condolences to her son, Anthony Marshall, and all members of her family; to her great friend Annette de la Renta; and to everyone who loved her. ''And if you should survive to 105, Look at all you'll derive out of being alive. Then here is the best part. You have a head start, If you are among the very young at heart.'' Paul Nurse, President Russell Carson, Chairman David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Joshua Lederberg, President Emeritus Frederick Seitz, President Emeritus Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus and Vincent and Brooke Astor Professor James Darnell and Paul Greengard, Vincent Astor Professors, The Rockefeller University ASTOR--Brooke Russell (Mrs. Vincent). The Trustees and staff of The New York Public Library deeply mourn the passing of our beloved Trustee and Honorary Chairman, Brooke Russell Astor. No one in the modern history of the Library played a more pivotal role in promoting, and supporting, the welfare of the Library than Brooke Astor. As an engaged Trustee of the Library for nearly five decades, Mrs. Astor understood clearly how vital the Library is to the people of our City. She worked with passion, generosity, and immense style to strengthen the Library on every level. Her many substantial benefactions, made through the Vincent Astor Foundation, supported collections, programs, staff, and facilities throughout the Library system. They also inspired, directly and indirectly, the supremely generous gifts that many individuals made to the Library in her honor or made as a consequence of the example she set. Mrs. Astor's love of the Library stemmed in large part from her own passion for both reading and writing. An accomplished writer herself of memoirs, novels, and poetry she believed that all New Yorkers, regardless of circumstance, should have access to the Library and experience the enlightenment and pleasure to be found in reading. Mrs. Astor therefore enriched the lives of countless fellow citizens through her support of the Library's work. Brooke Astor was our patroness and our symbol. She transformed the Library in lasting ways, increasing its quality, its prestige, and its centrality in the life of our City. She was a great philanthropist, a great leader, and the best and most beloved of friends. We extend our condolences to all members of her family. Catherine C. Marron, Chairman Samuel C. Butler, Elizabeth Rohatyn & Marshall Rose, Chairmen Emeriti Paul LeClerc, President ASTOR--Brooke. My dear Mrs. Astor, alas no more chance dances. I will miss you terribly, but take you in my heart each day. David Wren, Philadelphia

FRETWORK, the open geometric ornamentation found on Chinese antiques, has influenced Western furniture design for centuries; now its influence can be seen on rugs and carpets. Simple and graphic, the motif -- which is being used on pile as well as flat-weave rugs -- complements many furniture styles and works in both traditional and modern interiors.

Scott Hill, a self-described singer-songwriter, painter and set builder who owns two stores in upstate New York, was also, until a few months ago, the director of creative resourcing and design at Ralph Lauren. Recently, though, Mr. Hill, 46, above right, has taken on a new challenge: textile design. Mr. Hill's latest venture involves upholstering antiques in toile, mattress ticking and Belgian linen that he has silk-screened with historical images and text. ''I've always been fascinated by creating provocative environments in whatever medium I work in,'' he said. ''The fabric and furniture express that, too.''

An article in Business Day yesterday about jitters in the market for commercial paper backed by residential mortgages misstated the number of issuers in that market who were warned of possible downgrades on Tuesday by Standard & Poor's, a ratings agency. It warned three commercial paper issuers, not four. (It put a fourth issuer, Broadhollow Funding, on watch on Aug. 6.)

Philip Nimmo, a Los Angeles interior designer, has been making wrought-iron fire screens with colored glass and semiprecious stones like rose quartz, clear quartz and agate since 2003. The Primo room divider ($20,000), left, introduced this year, resembles the first fire screen he made using colored glass, when he was ''trying to create interesting shapes'' that, he said, would ''glisten and glow'' in the firelight. The Goccia screen ($7,000), top right, is named after the Italian word for ''drops, like raindrops.'' And the Mattonella screen ($8,670), bottom right, was Moroccan-inspired. Available to the trade at Profiles, 200 Lexington Avenue (32nd Street), (212) 689-6903; information: www.philipnimmoironworks.com. ELAINE LOUIE

The New York Freudian Society mourns the lost of Frieda Plotkin; an esteemed colleague and caring friend, a devout clinician who contributed to our understanding of the elderly.

Sometimes failure gives rise to the best ideas: Edouard Larmaraud's Cage Lamp, for example. Three years ago, the 28-year-old French industrial designer tried to build a nine-foot-tall lampshade, but the Paris factory he worked with did not have the technology or machinery to make it. Hervé Matejewski, a home furnishings designer and manufacturer Mr. Larmaraud met by chance, suggested an easier-to-build alternative -- ''a lamp where you see the structure before you see the shade,'' Mr. Matejewski said. The Cage Lamp, now available in the United States, has a small light shade encased in a five-foot-tall cage ($547, plus shipping); it is also available as a hanging lamp ($410, plus shipping). For information: www.larmaraud.com; to order: www.matejewski.com. ELAINE LOUIE

An article on Tuesday about financial disclosures filed with the Federal Election Commission by Mitt Romney, a Republican presidential candidate, misstated the year he ran successfully for governor of Massachusetts. It was 2002, not 1999.

SAYLES--Paula, August 15, 2007, age 101. Born on January 1, 1906 in Brooklyn, she lived in the Park Slope section until she was 98, when she moved to Abington, PA to be close to family. She was a benefactor of Congregation B'Nai Jacob of Park Slope and the building is named after her. She is survived by her son Leonard, her daughter-inlaw Alice and her grandchildren Heather, Wendy, Daniel and Rebecca.

MATHIEU--Barbara Bedford, 73, died peacefully on August 14, 2007 in Southhampton. Survived by her beloved daughter Jessica Tuthill and grandchildren Christina Martin and Hunter Tuthill. Services at St. Andrew's Church at 5:00pm on August 25, reception to follow at Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.

CORNWALL--Joseph Clift, 89, died peacefully at home Tuesday, August 14, four weeks after celebrating his twenty-first wedding anniversary with Elizabeth Hillard Eddy Cornwall on July 19. He is predeceased by his wife of forty-four years, Barbara Wallace Cornwall, and son Timothy C. Cornwall, and survived by two daughters, Elizabeth Cornwall and Pamela Duncan, two sons, John W. Cornwall and Joseph F. Cornwall, a stepdaughter, Ellen Eddy Thorndike, a stepson Charles B. Eddy III and twelve grandchildren. In recent years he completed his tenure as a founding board member and chair of The Fund for New Jersey-a private foundation committed to public policy initiatives in the state of New Jersey. In 2001 the Newark campus of Rutgers University opened the Joseph Cornwall Metropolitan Center for research, analysis and formulation of data on the New Jersey urban environment. A graduate of Princeton, class of 1939, in 1942 he received his LL.B. from Yale Law School and later that year was commissioned an ensign in the Navy, and served the durations of World War II. He was a corporate secretary for Wallace & Tiernan, Inc. the manufacturing company begun by his father-in-law, Charles Wallace, and a lifelong generous supporter of nonprofit institutions. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm on Wednesday, September 5, 2007 at Christ Church, 66 Highland Avenue, Short Hills, NJ. Services by Bradley - Brough Funeral Home, Summit NJ.

Memorial Service to be held at Christ Church, Riverdale on September 15th at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to: Riverdale Neighborhood House.

In fact, I get too many to answer all or even most of them --- it's a sad fact of limited time --- and that frustrates me, because I'd like to help. So this post is the first in what I hope is a partial, imperfect solution.

China plays a central role underwriting the Sudanese military and hence the genocide in Darfur. With all the troubles facing the newspaper business model, I'm a big believer that the best hope for reviving the model is to take newspaper websites and turn them into bases for social networks. You look at what happened to newspaper valuations over the last decade, and then what happened to the valuations of social networks like Facebook, Youtube, Myspace and so on, and you wish we could learn some of their techniques for creating communities and monetizing them. The upshot would be more eyeballs, longer time on the site, more free (reader-generated) content, and thus more advertising revenue.

The Federal Reserve unexpectedly announced Friday that it has approved a half-percentage point cut in its discount rate on loans to banks, a move that many on Wall Street had been clamoring for. The decision came as stock markets have been whipsawed by speculation about which mortgage company or hedge fund could be the next to fall victim to the recent credit crunch.

Lazard chairman Bruce Wasserstein opened his wallet this week to buy his firm's beaten-down shares, which hit a 52-week low Thursday. Mike Reid and Mark McNulty shot six-under-par 66s to shared the first-round lead in The Tradition, the Champion Tour’s fourth major of the year. David Edwards was a stroke back at the Crosswater Golf Club in Sunriver, Ore.
Canada — like other countries — seemed ill at ease with taking on refugees to remedy a public-relations headache for the United States.

A cousin of the late Minnesota Vikings tackle Korey Stringer was among two Connecticut players suspended indefinitely yesterday for an unspecified violation of team rules.The freshman linebacker Corey Stringer and the sophomore tailback Andre Dixon were suspended by Coach Randy Edsall. The university said there was no police involvement. Stringer is the nephew of Rutgers women’s basketball Coach C. Vivian Stringer.

A Little Leaguer from Japan was found to have measles yesterday, the eve of the World Series. Little League officials did not release his name, citing privacy guidelines. The boy was being treated in isolation on the Little League complex, the spokesman Lance Van Auken said.

A truck driven by a man with a suspended license struck and killed a 13-year-old Queens girl riding a bicycle yesterday afternoon, the police said. The man, Carlos Noriega-Olivia, 36, was driving a 2006 Chevy truck on Junction Boulevard in Corona when he turned right onto 57th Avenue and hit the girl, Carolina Hernandez, who was crossing the intersection on her bike around 4:15 p.m., the police said. The girl was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center, where she was pronounced dead. Mr. Noriega-Olivia was arrested and charged with driving with a suspended license.

Two more sets of human remains were discovered amid the wreckage of the Interstate bridge collapse in Minneapolis, raising the known death toll to 11. The remains were found in cars that divers got to only after cranes moved debris out of the way, said Randy Mitchell, spokesman for the diving operation at the site. They were identified as those of Vera Peck, 50, of St. Anthony, and Christina Sacorafas, 45, of White Bear Lake, the Hennepin County medical examiner’s office said.
The collaboration, which will enable Sun’s Solaris operating system to run on I.B.M. servers, will likely put pressure on competitor Hewlett-Packard.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 — The state inspector general is investigating Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s recent nominee for chairwoman of the Public Service Commission, according to a former aide to Mr. Spitzer who met with investigators.
Consolidated Edison won its legal fight yesterday to test a piece of equipment that may not have been working properly shortly before last month’s steam pipe explosion in Midtown Manhattan.
The mercury hit 105.6 degrees in the city of Tajimi, Japan on Thursday.
The government of North Korea granted the World Food Program permission to send four emergency teams to flood-stricken areas.
About 500 people trying to reach Europe aboard boats from Africa were found by the Italian Coast Guard over a 24-hour period.
Greece’s governing conservatives moved to hold parliamentary elections on Sept. 16, six months ahead of schedule.
The police questioned a couple after their 24-year-old Indonesian maid was found dead in their house in Kuala Lumpur.
A new priest in Tilburg was fined $6,800 for ringing his church bells too loudly at just after 7 in the morning.
Janel McCarville scored 18 points and Shameka Christon added 12, including the go-ahead free throws with 9.8 seconds remaining as the Liberty beat the Mystics.
Gary Sheffield retreated from his accusations of racism against Yankees manager Joe Torre by saying “a lot of people took it and ran with it and made it bigger than what it is.”
Qantas Airways, Australia’s biggest airline, said second-half profit almost tripled and announced plans to buy back 10 percent of its stock.
The Swiss insurer Zurich Financial Services said its second quarter was reduced by payouts for the June floods in Britain but still rose 8 percent.
Retail sales in Britain unexpectedly rose in July by the most in five months as price cuts by stores lured shoppers.
Russian industrial production growth slowed in July after expanding at the fastest annual rate in two and a half years in June, the Federal Statistics Service said.
One Red Sox fan said that “the tone of the city changes daily.”

An article on Tuesday about the governing party of Turkey’s presidential nomination of Abdullah Gul, an economist and practicing Muslim, misstated the number of votes he would need to win confirmation in the 500-seat Parliament if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, when a two-thirds majority, or 367 votes, is required. In a third round, he would need 276 votes, not 267.
Australia and India have agreed to negotiate a uranium trade pact to help meet the growing demand for power in India.

An article yesterday about Karl Rove’s criticism of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated when he made remarks to Reuters that were critical of Ms. Clinton. Those comments were on Tuesday, not Wednesday.

An article on Tuesday about the governing party of Turkey’s presidential nomination of Abdullah Gul, an economist and practicing Muslim, misstated the number of votes he would need to win confirmation in the 500-seat Parliament if he failed in the first two rounds of voting, when a two-thirds majority, or 367 votes, is required. In a third round, he would need 276 votes, not 267.

A 26-year-old Queens woman accused of killing and mutilating her father last month in her Arverne apartment was arrested last night and charged with murder, the Queens district attorney’s office said. For the past few weeks, the woman, Brigitte Harris, a security guard at Kennedy International Airport, has been in a Staten Island psychiatric hospital. She admitted herself there after the bound and gagged body of her father, Eric Goodridge, 55, of Staten Island, was discovered in her third-floor apartment on July 28. She was charged with second-degree murder and first-degree manslaughter. If convicted, she faces up to 25 years to life in prison.

An article on Monday about Htein Lin, a Burmese artist and former political prisoner whose paintings depicting incarceration in Myanmar, formerly Burma, are on display in London, misidentified Myanmar’s capital. It is Naypyidaw, not Yangon, formerly Rangoon. (The military government relocated the capital from Yangon to Naypyidaw, a remote jungle city about 200 miles north of Yangon, in 2006.).

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo sent letters yesterday to two insurance companies raising questions about the ranking systems they use for doctors, his office said. In letters to the companies, Aetna and Cigna HealthCare, Mr. Cuomo said the rankings were confusing for consumers, and he asked for information that would justify the ranking systems. Both companies said they would cooperate with the attorney general. Aetna said its system had a process for doctors to raise concerns and to correct errors in rankings. A spokesman for Cigna said it was reviewing the attorney general’s letter and could not directly comment on it, other than to say that Cigna would respond to the request for information.

A police officer was dragged by a car in Williamsbridge early yesterday after he tried to question the driver, whom he suspected of using drugs, the police said. The officer, who was not identified by the police, then shot the driver in the left leg, the police said. The officer had approached the car, at East 228th Street and White Plains Road, on foot about 1 a.m., believing two men in it were smoking marijuana. The car was driven off, and the officer was caught and briefly dragged, the police said. Investigators said the two men were seen throwing marijuana and cocaine from the moving vehicle, which police officers stopped after it had gone about two blocks. The officer was treated for minor injuries at St. Barnabas Hospital, and the driver was in stable condition at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said. Charges against the two men in the car, whose identities were not disclosed, were pending late yesterday, the police said.

A 54-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed by a hit-and-run driver early yesterday in East New York, the police said. The woman, Eunice Washington of Brownsville, was with her adult son and daughter at Eldert Lane and Linden Boulevard when one of the three hailed a burgundy four-door sedan for a ride. What followed was unclear, but investigators said the family members got into a dispute with the driver. He then reversed over the curb, striking Ms. Washington, and fled, the police said. The police said the man may have been working as a livery car driver. The car also struck the son, who is 28, but he was not seriously injured, the police said.

A Bloomfield man was sentenced to death yesterday in State Superior Court for killing two women in Hartford in 2000. The man, Jessie Campbell III, 27, was convicted in May 2004 of killing his estranged girlfriend, LaTaysha Logan, 20, and her friend Desiree Privette, 18. Ms. Privette’s aunt, Carolyn Privette, was shot in the head but survived. The jurors who convicted Mr. Campbell could not decide whether he should be executed, so in December 2004, Edward J. Mullarkey, the presiding judge, declared a mistrial and ordered a new penalty phase. A new jury was impaneled, and last October it recommended death. The sentence yesterday, imposed by Judge Mullarkey, will automatically be reviewed by the State Supreme Court. Mr. Campbell is the eighth person on Connecticut’s death row.

A teenager fatally stabbed his stepfather, who was assaulting the boy’s mother, on Wednesday night, the police said yesterday. After consulting with the district attorney, the police said yesterday that no charges had been filed. The police said the stepfather, Arturo Moreno, 33, began arguing with his wife about 9:30 p.m. at their Ozone Park home. The dispute became physical, and the woman’s 14-year-old son, who was not identified, stepped in. During the altercation, the teenager stabbed Mr. Moreno in the chest, the police said. Mr. Moreno was pronounced dead at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center, they said.

A Queens man has been charged with killing one man and wounding another in a shooting last week in Laurelton, prosecutors said yesterday. The man, Rhian Taylor, 21, of 229th Street in Laurelton, was charged with murder and assault, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Taylor fired repeatedly into a car after an argument outside a party just before 2 a.m. last Friday. Darion Brown, 22, of 127th Avenue in Laurelton, was hit several times and died, prosecutors said. Another man was shot in the leg, they said.

The Washington Wizards traded the rights to the Spanish guard Juan Carlos Navarro to the Memphis Grizzlies yesterday for a future first-round draft pick.The Wizards drafted Navarro in the second round, 40th over all, in 2002. Last month, FC Barcelona and Navarro agreed to a buyout that allowed him to head to the N.B.A. In Memphis, Navarro will play with the Spanish star Pau Gasol.
The free-agent guard Robert Hite signed with the Nets yesterday. Hite appeared in 12 games for the Miami Heat last season, averaging 4.3 points and 1.3 rebounds in 11.3 minutes a game.

Kirsten Honeycutt hit a run-scoring single in the top of the sixth inning to lead the South team from Morristown, Tenn., to a 3-2 victory over the Southwest team from Elgin, Tex., in the championship game of the Little League Softball World Series in Portland, Ore.

The Devils kept a major piece of their defense, signing Paul Martin to a multiyear contract yesterday. Contract terms were not immediately available. Martin, 26, had 3 goals and 23 assists last season while playing in all 82 regular-season games.

Emmanuel Moody, the second-leading rusher for Southern California last season as a freshman, has decided to transfer. Moody, a 6-foot-1, 205-pound sophomore from Texas who is caught in a glut of highly regarded tailbacks, gained 458 yards on 79 carries last season before missing the final four games because of a sprained ankle. He entered camp as one of 10 players competing for playing time at tailback.

Will MacKenzie shot an eight-under-par 64 to take a one-shot lead over Lucas Glover, Steve Marino, Brian Davis and Jeff Overton after the first round of the Wyndham Championship in Greensboro, N.C. MacKenzie nearly made a hole in one and had nine birdies to offset a bogey.

Secret Gypsy did not want to load into the starting gate, but once the race was on she blazed through five and a half furlongs to set a track record at Saratoga Race Course yesterday.Secret Gypsy won the first start of her career impressively, besting a field of 10 by six and a quarter lengths as she cruised home under jockey Kent Desormeaux in 1:03.26, breaking the track record of 1:03.32 set by Mayakovsky on July 25, 2001. Secret Gypsy, a chestnut daughter of Sea of Secrets, paid $29.20 for a $2 bet to win.
Gary M. Osen is a lawyer on a personal and professional campaign to sue banks that he believes bankroll terrorist activities.

A federal judge in Detroit dismissed a lawsuit brought by a coalition of shipping interests challenging a Michigan law intended to curb the introduction of invasive species into the Great Lakes. The law, enacted earlier this year, requires all oceangoing ships sailing into Michigan ports to obtain permits showing that the vessels will not discharge ballast water, which is held in the ballast tanks or cargo holds of ships to provide stability, into Michigan waters, or, if they do plan to discharge the water, that it will first be treated to remove any non-native species. On Wednesday, the judge, John Feikens of Federal District Court, rejected the shipping coalition’s claim that the law was unconstitutional. Judge Feikens wrote that invasive species posed a “serious threat” to the state’s environment.

The remnants of Tropical Storm Erin soaked rain-weary Texas, snarling rush-hour traffic and killing at least one person.Thunderstorms brought seven inches of rain to parts of San Antonio and Houston, where a person was killed when the waterlogged roof of a storage unit collapsed.

The Herndon Town Council voted 6 to 1 Wednesday to keep its day laborer center open but to find a new operator that will check the immigration status of the workers who use it. The current operator, Project Hope and Harmony, a nonprofit group, has refused to check workers’ documents. The center has been the focus of debate since it opened two years ago to provide a more organized alternative for workers who used to flag down potential employers on the town’s main street. Six months after the center opened, voters elected a new mayor and two new council members who opposed it.

The Los Angeles City Council approved building 10 new gates at Los Angeles International Airport to handle international flights. The Council gave unanimous approval Wednesday to the $1.2 billion project, which will be financed by the fees airlines pay to use the airport. It should be completed by 2012.

An owner of a small South Carolina parts supplier pleaded guilty to fraud after collecting about $20.5 million over six years from the Pentagon for fraudulent costs, including $998,798 for sending two 19-cent washers to an Army base in Texas. Cynthia Stroot, a Pentagon investigator, said the supplier, C&D Distributors in Lexington, S.C., exploited a flaw in an automated Defense Department purchasing system: bills for shipping to combat areas or American bases that were labeled “priority” were usually paid automatically. A federal judge in Columbia, S.C., accepted the guilty plea of the owner, Charlene Corley, to one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and one count of conspiracy to launder money.
The funeral is to take place at St. Thomas Church. It will be open to the public, with as many as 500 seats reserved for Mrs. Astor’s friends and family.

A member of the Texas National Guard accused of helping transport illegal immigrants pleaded guilty to a federal felony conspiracy charge. The man, Jose Rodrigo Torres, 26, was one of three guardsmen accused of helping illegal immigrants pass a checkpoint on Interstate 35. The other two, Sgt. Julio Cesar Pacheco and Sgt. Clarence Hodge Jr., have pleaded not guilty. Mr. Torres could face 10 years in prison and up to $250,000 in fines.

The former chief of staff to former Representative Bob Ney was ordered to serve two years’ probation for his role in the corruption scandal surrounding the lobbyist Jack Abramoff. The man, William Heaton, 29, left, who often served as Mr. Ney’s contact with Mr. Abramoff, must also perform 100 hours of community service and pay a $5,000 fine, Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle said in Federal District Court. Mr. Heaton pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy in February. Prosecutors did not seek a prison term for Mr. Heaton, who cooperated with them by taping conversations with his boss. Mr. Ney, an Ohio Republican, is serving a prison term of two and a half years.
A former Marine sergeant has been charged with voluntary manslaughter in the killings of two captured Iraqi insurgents in Falluja in 2004.
Public telephones are one of New York City’s stranger cash cows, generating $62 million in ad revenue annually.
Jose Padilla, an American who was designated an “enemy combatant,” now faces life in prison.
While parts of the city are now substantially safer from possible floodwaters, others have changed little.
NASA managers decided on Thursday night not to send astronauts on a spacewalk to repair a gouge on the bottom of the space shuttle Endeavour.
Rudolph W. Giuliani has raised the hackles of 9/11 rescue and recovery workers by likening his experience to theirs.
A day after an earthquake struck Peru’s southern coast, officials put the toll at 437 and said it was sure to rise.
The parent company of Interboro Institute, a commercial college in New York City, has been ordered to repay the federal government about $2.5 million.
What’s most important now is for markets and businesses to have confidence that the Federal Reserve chief will make the right calls at the right time.
Skype’s 220 million users, some of them small businesses that had given up their landlines, were left without a way to call colleagues, customers and friends.
Prior to the agreement, some nonbank holders of asset-backed commercial paper were unable to roll over their debt and get their banks to provide emergency financing.
The earthquake that struck off Peru’s southern coast on Wednesday occurred in one of the world’s most active geological areas.
Pitcher Andrew Brackman does not need surgery on his elbow — not yet, at least.
An investigation found that a distributor in China was the source of about a million fake blood sugar test strips that have turned up in at least 35 states and eight countries.
The new policy calls for local laws that would require the registration of all firearms in Newark and the reporting of lost or stolen guns.
Iraq’s prime minister, a Shiite, and president, a Kurd, announced a new alliance of moderates in Parliament that could revive government activity.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,692 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
A panel tightened rules Thursday on the use of state aircraft by public officials, the first concrete change to emerge after a scathing report issued by the attorney general’s office last month.
Off-season surgery means that special teams coordinator Mike Westhoff has no choice but to take it easier — on himself, if not his players.
European officials are concerned that ratings agencies like Moody’s and Standard & Poor’s are paid by the very issuers they are supposed to be rating.
Prosecutors said the owners had been criminally negligent in not removing residents as Hurricane Katrina approached.
U.S. News & World Report releases its rankings of America’s top colleges, under attack as never before by college officials who accuse it of using dubious statistics.
Beijing urgently needs to grasp that when it comes to public safety, secrecy is never the right policy and there is no benefit in trying to go it alone.
The F.B.I. director’s notes provide another eyewitness account of the confrontation over the secret N.S.A. surveillance program.
Hoping to reduce debt and focus on its core businesses, the medical equipment maker said it is looking to sell its cardiac and vascular surgery units.
A federal investigation is generating information about referees that could lead to disciplinary action short of criminal charges, said those involved.
Senator Barack Obama has moved in recent weeks to sharpen his tone noticeably as he fights for the Democratic presidential nomination.
It would be a mistake to see the guilty verdict against Jose Padilla as a vindication for the Bush administration’s serial abuse of the American legal system.
Roger Federer survived a scare and advanced to the quarterfinals of the Western & Southern Financial Group Masters, which had been unkind to seeded players this week.
Queens, America’s most ethnically diverse county, has just been awarded the top prize as the nation’s busiest library system.
Standard & Poor’s Ratings Services raised its credit and financial strength ratings for the New York Life Insurance Company on Thursday from AA+ to AAA.

He was a young man with a big plan: taking aim at rich Americans, with the help of the Forbes 400 list, and robbing their financial accounts by trolling the Internet for information all the way from his base in Moscow, prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday.
A new plan would allow emergency response, border control and, eventually, law enforcement agencies greater access to satellites and other sensors that monitor American territory.
After the Carolina Panthers’ running game shredded the Giants’ defensive line last week, the Giants decided to find two of the biggest free-agent tackles still available.
The 84,000-seat stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. will be the most expensive ever built in the United States.
A report by a panel of international military experts stopped short of directly implicating Russia in the matter.
Three rescue workers are dead and six others were injured during an attempt to reach six men trapped at Crandall Canyon Mine, officials said.
The deal would most likely come with a recommendation that the star quarterback be sentenced to one to two years in prison on dogfighting charges.
The youth baseball organization run by Cal Ripken Jr. and his brother, Billy, is increasing in popularity after switching to larger fields resembling Major League diamonds.

Adam Wainwright (11-9) gave up two hits in seven scoreless innings and Yadier Molina put on a rare power display with two homers as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the host Milwaukee Brewers, 8-0, yesterday to complete a crucial three-game sweep.
Sales at J. C. Penney, Kohl’s and Nordstrom were up in the second quarter, beating Wall Street estimates.
The worst forest fire to close in on Athens in a month destroyed homes and caused power failures across the Greek capital.
The William Morris Agency completed an expensive deal to hire Ed Limato, the longtime agent to A-list actors like Denzel Washington and Mel Gibson, after Mr. Limato won the right to leave I.C.M.
The first flight with paying customers aboard Singapore Airlines’ new Airbus A380 aircraft will depart on Oct. 25 from Singapore to Sydney.
Fifth Third Bancorp said Thursday that it would acquire the First Charter Corporation in a deal valued at $1.09 billion.
The parent of Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurant chains said Thursday that it would buy Rare Hospitality, owner of the LongHorn Steakhouse and Capital Grille chains.
Computer and printer maker Hewlett-Packard saw its fiscal third-quarter net income jump 29 percent on strong sales of laptop computers and printer ink.
Cosmetics maker Estée Lauder Lauder reported a lower-than-expected quarterly profit, despite nearly doubling net income in the company’s fiscal fourth quarter.
After seven years of violence and terrorism, stagnation and unilateralism, the U.S. has finally decided to push the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to talk about peace.
The PC maker said it would reduce net income for the period by as much as $150 million and revenue by 1 percent or less per year.
The country’s largest Lutheran denomination is urging bishops to refrain from disciplining gay and lesbian clergy members who are in committed same-sex relationships.
Seemingly internal documents suggest that Kazakhstan conducted intelligence operations against international monitors during the presidential election in 2005.
Dr. Selberg’s theoretical work on the properties of numbers was recognized with the Fields Medal and other major prizes.
More than one-quarter of New Jersey’s 2,430 public schools were cited for failing to meet federal education standards after too few of their students passed state reading and math tests this spring.
The Toronto Stock Exchange has lost many of its biggest listings to foreign takeovers and private equity moves, now it is facing the emergence of several new local rivals.
Senator Ted Stevens has long played on state worries that, without his loud, powerful voice in the Senate, Alaska would be an afterthought in Washington.
East Hampton’s official town crier dispenses a little local history.
Even while consumers seek to avoid advertising on TV and the Web, a growing number Web sites are presenting advertisements as entertainment.
Mr. Rector was a well-regarded poet and educator whose work appeared in many distinguished publications.
Officials insisted that the deal was not dependent on a simultaneous American plan for $20 billion in sales of sophisticated arms to its Arab allies.
Southern African political leaders appear unlikely to press President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe to change any of the policies that have caused a crisis in his nation.
The primordial rocks in Hyderabad, India, have become the focus of one of India’s many emerging citizens movements.
Plácido Polanco recently played his 144th consecutive game at second base without an error, snapping the record held by his friend, the Mets’ Luis Castillo.
Last month, the pace of new residential construction and the rate of building permits issued fell to their lowest points in more than a decade.
As the Montreal Canadiens’ general manager, Mr. Pollock  built nine Stanley Cup championship teams in the 1960s and ’70s.

The F.B.I. is investigating whether Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska had a role in arranging a 1999 government contract worth as much as $70 million for a company that later oversaw renovations of his house.
The turmoil in the mortgage market is starting to make it harder for New Yorkers to get the large loans that are typical in a city where the average apartment in Manhattan costs $1.3 million.
Senior figures in Pakistan’s governing party have warned that the Supreme Court will almost certainly block Pervez Musharraf’s nomination for president.
Iran lashed out at American plans for a missile defense shield, while Russia took an indirect swipe at what it called Washington’s unilateral foreign policy.

The U.S. used to be able to pick up the slack when growth stalled in the rest of the world.  Now that dynamic has reversed, but many countries are still worried that the U.S. could drag them down as well.

A federal judge rejected a bid by government antitrust authorities to temporarily block Whole Foods Market’s planned acquisition of a rival, Wild Oats Markets.
Ninety-nine soldiers killed themselves last year, the highest suicide rate in the Army in 26 years of record keeping, a new report says.
Hundreds of Italian police officers have deployed to head off a full-scale mob war after six Italian men were killed Wednesday in Germany.

Two more sets of human remains were discovered amid the wreckage of the Interstate bridge collapse in Minneapolis.
The Op-Ed page asked seven people with experience in both new media and old to answer the question: What would a real new-media debate look like?
I propose a full day of live one-on-one debates on unannounced issues, with no aides to help the presidential candidates.
The Web isn’t just a one-way “suggestion box.” It offers our democracy an entirely new participatory ecology.

“Mozart Dances” is a rich theatrical experience, one that often pulled me outside Mozart’s music as often as it drew me into it.

On Oct. 2 Bruce Springsteen will release “Magic,” an album on which he reunites with the E Street Band for the first time since the 2002 album “The Rising,” The Associated Press reported yesterday. The album, which is billed as Mr. Springsteen’s return to rock ’n’ roll, was recorded with the producer Brendan O’Brien in Atlanta and includes the guitarists Steve Van Zandt and Nils Lofgren, the bassist Garry Tallent, the drummer Max Weinberg, the keyboardists Danny Federici and Roy Bittan, the saxophonist Clarence Clemons, the violinist Soozie Tyrell and the vocalist Patti Scialfa.

Former Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, who stepped down in June, plans to write a book, The Associated Press reported yesterday, citing a Blair representative who would not speak on the record because no deal has been made. The representative said that the book, probably a memoir, hasn’t been started and is at least a few years from publication. There have been no negotiations with publishers, the representative said, but Mr. Blair has retained Robert Barnett, a Washington lawyer who has acted as book agent for Bill Clinton and Alan Greenspan,. A spokesman for Mr. Blair, Matthew Doyle, declined to comment.

An article yesterday about a federal investigation of the lawyer Roderick M. Hills over his representation of Chiquita Brands International misidentified one institution where Mr. Hills taught. It was the Yale School of Organization and Management, not Yale Business School, and is now called the Yale School of Management.

An owner of a small South Carolina parts supplier pleaded guilty to fraud after collecting about $20.5 million over six years from the Pentagon for fraudulent costs, including $998,798 for sending two 19-cent washers to an Army base in Texas. Cynthia Stroot, a Pentagon investigator, said the supplier, C&D Distributors in Lexington, S.C., exploited a flaw in an automated Defense Department purchasing system: bills for shipping to combat areas or American bases that were labeled ''priority'' were usually paid automatically. A federal judge in Columbia, S.C., accepted the guilty plea of the owner, Charlene Corley, to one count of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and one count of conspiracy to launder money.

ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library mourn the death of Brooke Russell Astor. Brooke was a valued Trustee and became a Trustee Emerita. A Fellow since 1955, she was also a founding member of the Director's Roundtable. Brooke was greatly loved here. Her generosity advanced our programs and growth. And her presence at meetings and receptions and dinners illuminated the Morgan. She inspired many others to follow her splendid example. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends and all those who knew and miss her. Charles E. Pierce, Jr. Dir. S. Parker Gilbert, Pres., Board of Trustees ASTOR--Brooke Russell. The Trustees and staff of the Brooklyn Stained Glass Conservation Center mourn with great sadness the passing of our friend and benefactor, Brooke Russell Astor. Mrs. Astor's dedication to preserving New York City's architectural history inspired her to rescue one of the city's treasured national historic monuments, the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights. Along with her dear friend Brendan Gill and the New York Landmarks Conservancy, Mrs. Astor, through the Vincent Astor Foundation, generously contributed to the restoration of the Church, the establishment of the stained glass studio at St. Ann's and the restoration of its greatest window, the Ascension of Christ. Originally charged with the restoration of the church's magnificent Bolton windows, the Brooklyn Stained Glass Conservation Center has evolved into a premium center for stained glass conservation, design and education. We are truly grateful for her many years of support. As a philanthropist, Mrs. Astor ran the Astor Foundation with integrity, responsibility, and a strong commitment to serve New York City. Always curious to learn more, she greeted each project with compassion and respect, never distancing herself from those she helped. We will remember her always as a remarkable, gracious lady who loved her town. Valerie Lynch, Chairman Dr. Robert Vadheim M.D., Treasurer David Goltl, Board Member David Fraser, Executive Director ASTOR--Vincent, Mrs.; It is with deepest sorrow that the Board of Trustees and staff of The Animal Medical Center mark the passing of our devoted friend and Trustee, Mrs. Vincent Astor. Mrs. Astor's generosity and compassion toward New York institutions influenced many lives, including those of our animal companions. The Animal Medical Center was a very fortunate witness to Mrs. Astor's largesse, most especially in the creation of two programs. In 1982 The Vincent Astor Foundation changed the course of veterinary research through the integration of AMC's work with that of other great medical institutions with the establishment of the Astor Chair of Comparative Medicine. In 1995 the Foundation acted as a generous source of funding for the Senior Assistance Veterinary Effort (SAVE), providing medical care to the companion animals of indigent elderly persons. In acknowledgment of Mrs. Astor's kindness to AMC, the Brooke Astor Award was created to stand in everlasting commemoration of Mrs. Astor's lifelong care and concern for, and generosity toward, the people of New York City. We extend our most sincere sympathies to the overwhelming number of fortunate friends and family members of Mrs. Astor, a woman whose vision, joy and strength will forever remain woven into the cloth of The Animal Medical Center. ASTOR--Brooke Russell. Born Portsmouth, NH, March 30, 1902, died August 13, 2007, Philanthropist, Author. Awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom, 1998, by President Clinton. 'AUTOMATIC UPDATE' Artists forgo more traditional image-making materials for a taste of recent technologies -- LCD screens, DVD players, digital video and computers -- in this buoyant survey of media installations at the Museum of Modern Art. The show begins in a black-box gallery on the second floor, with an interactive installation of 21 LCD screens on a wall connected to a laptop computer, a work by Rafael Lozano-Hemmer, a young Mexican artist. Viewers can enter random words and ideas into the computer, which are then generated into questions and displayed on the screens; viewed in passing, the questions are like subliminal messages. Nearby is an installation by Jennifer and Kevin McCoy, an American husband-and-wife artist team, consisting of a tabletop model recreating the famous car accident scene from Jean-Luc Godard's 1967 film ''Weekend.'' Video cameras film the scene, the tabletop rotating to create the impression of movement, with the footage computer-processed and then played back live in a projection on an adjacent wall. It may be the coolest thing you've ever seen. But also likable are Xu Bing's interactive computer installation, above, in which viewers are invited to communicate using popular symbols, and Paul Pfeiffer's tiny LCD monitor showing a digital loop of spinning and hovering basketballs, the artist having digitally removed the players from video of NBA games. Mr. Pfeiffer's piece is pretty fabulous, both as a contemplative, abstract aesthetic experience and as a meditation on beauty in sport. (Through Sept. 3, 212-708-9400, moma.org.) BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO
