Claudio Monteverdi has been called the creator of modern music, and performances of his operas and songs this summer at Glimmerglass Opera, the Lincoln Center Festival and the Mostly Mozart Festival support that claim. But Anthony Tommasini points out another way in which Monteverdi anticipated the world of modern orchestras and opera companies: he was a pragmatic and politically astute musical professional with a gift for public relations. 'THE WORLD IS MY CANVAS' Many young people leave their childhoods before they ever leave their countries. But in SoHo, the Children's Museum of the Arts is now offering its visitors an opportunity to view other lands through eyes that are still very young: those of their peers in nations ranging from the Netherlands to North Korea. These visions make up ''The World Is My Canvas: Images From the Permanent Collection,'' 26 works by artists ages 4 to 15. Displayed with a large map, the pictures are part of the museum's holdings of more than 2,000 pieces of children's art from 50 countries. Although the museum began soliciting the work in 1990, much of it languished in storage until recently, when Elizabeth Fearon Pepperman and Jodi Richard, board members, cataloged it and organized this exhibition. ''The big push right now is to really assert ourselves as an art organization with a permanent collection that's available for people to study,'' said Lucy Ofiesh, the museum's manager of visitor services and marketing.

Paintings and drawings by the poet Sylvia Plath, many never seen before, will be published in Britain this October by Oxford University Press to mark the 75th anniversary of her birth, The Guardian newspaper in England reported. The book ''Eye Rhymes: Sylvia Plath's Art of the Visual,'' edited by Kathleen Connors and Sally Bayley, includes illustrated childhood letters, found in the Plath family attic in 1996, that Plath wrote when she was 7. There are also schoolbook sketches, portraits, photographs and paintings, including a self-portrait, that Plath made while an art student at Smith College. The works were all completed by the time she was 20, when she decided to concentrate on writing. Oxford plans to publish ''Eye Rhymes'' in the United States in January.

Twenty of the Chinese terra-cotta warriors, above, from the tomb of Qin Shi Huang (259-210 B.C.), China's first emperor, will be on view in the United States starting in May 2008. ''Terra Cotta Warriors: Guardians of China's First Emperor,'' as the exhibition is called, will travel from the British Museum in London to the Bowers Museum in Santa Ana, Calif., where it will be shown from May until mid-September. It then moves to the Houston Museum of Natural Science, the National Geographic Museum in Washington and, under a different name, the High Museum of Art in Atlanta before returning to China in 2009. The exhibition, drawn from 11 different collections in Shaanxi Province, includes two recently discovered half-size bronze chariots and life-size bronze animals that were found in what would have been gardens within the tomb complex.

Fox rode the ''So You Think You Can Dance'' finale to victory Wednesday night. According to Nielsen's estimates, the two-hour show delivered an average of 8.5 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., outpacing all other programming. NBC's ''Last Comic Standing'' at 9 (5.7 million) was the runner-up among adults 18 to 49, as NBC ranked No. 2 for the night in that demographic. CBS finished No. 2 in total viewers. Its repeat of ''CSI: NY'' at 10 earned the second-largest audience of the night (8.1 million), and its new game show, ''Power of 10,'' fared well at 8 (7.7 million). ABC came in fourth over all; the debut of its five-part ''Nascar in Primetime'' drew just 3.2 million viewers in the 10 p.m. hour.

Max Roach, who died yesterday at 83, was in on the ground floor of aesthetic change for much of his working life: zeroing in on particular regions of his drum kit and reshuffling rhythms, inventing percussive patterns that helped move jazz away from typical swing. An appraisal and discography by Ben Ratliff are on Page 3.

ALPHABET CITY IV The Metropolitan Playhouse is quintessentially East Village. It occupies a small space on the second floor of a walk-up that it shares with another theater and a school on an artist-rich block just above the Lower East Side. The playhouse, under its artistic director, Alex Roe, explores America and American literature by producing old American plays, new ones based on old literary sources, and plays specifically about the city and the neighborhood. Metropolitan is currently presenting the fourth installment of a series that features the stories of local residents. Each of the nine solo performances, divided among three separate evenings (titled ''Avenue A,'' ''Avenue B'' and ''Avenue C''), represents a collaboration between an actor and a subject. Each performer was responsible for finding his own subject, who might be an artist, activist or entrepreneur. ''Sometimes they just walk up to interesting people on the street,'' Mr. Roe said. ''Actors are willing to do that.'' Performers conducted interviews and amassed several hours of material, which became fodder for monologues of about 20 minutes, consisting entirely of the interviewees' real (but edited) words. Derek Jamison, the show's director, helped pare down the text and shape each performance, but the actor's desire to play the person and the subject's allure drive each piece.
Correction Appended MARIGOLD

For the first time, four summer movies -- ''Spider-Man 3'' ($336.4 million), ''Shrek the Third'' ($321 million), ''Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End'' ($307.6 million) and ''Transformers'' ($303.7 million) -- have broken the $300 million barrier at the domestic box office, Variety reported yesterday. Nine other titles have also exceeded the $100 million mark, helping 2007 set a summer box office record, running 6 percent ahead of 2004, the previous record summer, according to Nielsen EDI. Hollywood has been equally successful overseas, where four films have topped the $400 million mark. The third ''Pirates of the Caribbean'' movie has earned $650 million, ''Spider-Man 3'' and ''Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix'' have each earned $550 million, and ''Shrek the Third'' has brought in $412 million.

WATSON ADVENTURES In a city with no shortage of attractions, a few details can get lost in the shuffle. Bret Watson sees that as something of a challenge. ''I was walking in the Met by myself one evening and noticed some funny details in various works of art and thinking, 'How can I get my friends to see what I'm seeing?' '' Mr. Watson said. He found a way to make often overlooked details a bit more compelling. Mr. Watson's company, Watson Adventures, has gone through the museum and 18 other locations in New York City with a fine-toothed comb and found enough trivia to produce 45 different scavenger hunts, including ''Wax Attacks'' at Madame Tussaud's, ''Skyline at Sunset'' in Brooklyn Heights and ''Secrets of Greenwich Village,'' which stops in Washington Square Park, above. The most popular is ''Murder at the Met,'' which received a considerable boost from books like ''The Da Vinci Code,'' said Tracey Henry, a spokeswoman for Watson Adventures. Clues lead visitors -- who include tourists, locals, couples and singles hoping to become couples -- on a two-hour trail through the museum. By the end of the evening the hunters will not only uncover a culprit, chances are they will also discover the true goal of the search, an ''accidental education'' on the museum's treasures. ''They may or may not know about art,'' Mr. Watson said, ''but they will have a new appreciation of it.'' (''Murder at the Met'' tomorrow at 5:30 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, 877-946-4868, watsonadventures.com; $41.50, $33.50 for college students. A full schedule is on the Web site.) MONICA DRAKE

WILD MARKET SWINGS During a day of intense volatility, fed by rumors and fears over the credit squeeze, markets swooned before a late-afternoon rally. The Dow industrials were down as many as 340 points before ending at just 15 points under. The New York Stock Exchange said a record 5.73 billion shares were traded. A CREDIT CRISIS LIKE NO OTHER Financial markets react with lightning speed to events halfway around the world. So why is the credit panic of 2007 being played out in slow motion? Information may arrive instantly, but insight takes longer. High & Low Finance: Floyd Norris. [A1.]

Foxy Brown, below, has been charged with felony assault, misdemeanor assault and criminal possession of a weapon, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Ms. Brown, the 27-year-old rapper, whose real name is Inga Marchand, was released on $50,000 bail after being arraigned Tuesday. The authorities allege that she hit a neighbor; her manager, Chaz Williams, said the charges were false. She was charged with assaulting Arlene Raymond, 25, who lives near Ms. Brown in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, on July 30. The police said Ms. Raymond had complained to Ms. Brown about the volume of her car stereo. A few days later, Ms. Raymond alleged, Ms. Brown hurled a BlackBerry at her as they passed on the street, cutting her lip and knocking a tooth loose. Ms. Brown is on probation after pleading guilty to assault in a 2004 dispute over payment for a manicure at a nail salon. The latest arrest could lead to revocation of her probation. ''We have filed a violation of probation with the court,'' said Jack Ryan of the city Department of Probation. Earlier this year Ms. Brown was accused of violating probation after she threw hair glue at a beauty shop employee in Florida. She was threatened with jail in that incident but was restored to probation in good standing in June by a Manhattan judge, who said she had kept appointments with her probation officer, passed drug tests and attended required anger management classes.

CATCH 25 The eclectic series Catch is back tomorrow for its latest installment, and it's hard to justify seeking any other form of entertainment on your Saturday night when, for a measly $10, you have access not only to some of today's most interesting performers, but also to $2 beers. Formerly held in Galapagos Art Space, Catch now makes its home at Starr Street Projects, a big, raw space in Bushwick, Brooklyn, that suits the adventuresome, rowdy mood cultivated by Catch's curators and hosts, Jeff Larson and Andrew Dinwiddie. These gentlemen take their fun as seriously as they take their art. The lineup for Catch 25 includes the choreographer Chris Yon, another delightfully brainy funny man, and the duo Asubtout, whose members Katy Pyle and Eleanor Hullihan have impeccable dancing résumés: Ms. Hullihan performs with John Jasperse, and Ms. Pyle used to dance with Jennifer Monson and Mr. Jasperse. But wait, there's more. For its 25th edition, and for the first time, Catch is featuring artists from outside New York, including the Minneapolis performing artist Megan Mayer and the Performance Thanatology Research Society from Baltimore. ''Huh?'' you might ask. Well, ''they do these -- I guess they're multimedia performance lectures,'' Mr. Dinwiddie explained in an e-mail message. A video collage by the Brooklyn Underground Film Festival co-founder Myles Kane and choreography by Larissa Velez round out the evening. (Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Starr Street Space, 108 Starr Street, at Knickerbocker Street, Bushwick, Brooklyn, catchseries.org; $10) CLAUDIA LA ROCCO

KNOWLTON--Perry H. Renowned literary agent and the former Chairman and CEO of Curtis Brown, Ltd., one of the world's oldest literary agencies, died on July 6, 2007 at the New York State Veterans' Home at Montrose in Westchester County, after a long and valiant battle with Alzheimer's disease. He was 80 years old. Born at Miss Lippincott's Lying-In Hospital in New York City on March 25, 1927, he grew up in Rye, New York. Among his childhood cohort was a young Barbara Pierce, later Barbara Bush. Upon graduating from Phillips Exeter Academy, he served in the army from 1945 to 1946. Adventurous from a young age, at 19 Knowlton and a friend crossed the Atlantic from New York to England in a 21-foot sailboat. He returned to the United States to a comparatively more settled existence as a member of Princeton's class of 1949, but his continued peripatetic nature is apparent from his roundabout journey to the center of the New York literary world. After a stint as an English teacher at the Lawrenceville School in New Jersey, he took a job in regional sales for the college textbook division of Charles Scribner's Publishers, initially in Cincinnati and then in Tucson. Knowlton married Louisa C. Tripp in 1954 and finally reached Gotham in 1956. He took a job as an editor at Scribner's, where he stayed for several years before moving into the world of agenting in 1959, when he was hired by Alan Collins, the president of Curtis Brown, Ltd. Knowlton ran the agency's book department and in 1968, following Collins's death, became President and owner of the firm. He personally represented dozens of authors and their estates, a veritable Who's-Who of 20th Century literature, including W.H. Auden, Daphne DuMaurier, Robertson Davies, Ogden Nash, Ayn Rand, Diana Gabaldon, Tony Hillerman, Frank Robinson, Jean Craighead George, Betty Friedan, Nicholas Monsarrat, Samuel Eliot Morison, A.A. Milne, Frederik Pohl, Harrison Salisbury, Frederick Forsythe, Brian Moore, Pauline Kael, Louis Auchincloss, John Knowles, C. S. Lewis, and Alvin and Heidi Toffler. He also represented Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Joseph Stalin, after her defection in 1967. He worked fiercely to protect author's rights and interests, and served on the executive board of the Society of Authors' Representatives for more than 20 years. He was one of the principal engineers in bringing about the merger of the SAR with the Independent Literary Agents Association to form the Association of Author's Representatives in 1991 and served as its President from 1993 to 1995. Perry Knowlton was known for his keen intellect, courtly manners, and good looks. He was a handsome man-more than a man of letters ever needed to be. As a sideline in the late 1950's and early 1960's, while still practicing as an agent, he modeled for print and TV advertising for Xerox and Budweiser, among others. Most notably, he was one of the original ''Marlboro Men''. He was also one of the founding members of the Friends of the Earth in 1969, along with former Sierra Club president David Brower. In 1995, several years before fully retiring from his agency practice at Curtis Brown, he returned to his boyhood interest in falconry, describing himself, at the age of 68, as ''the world's oldest apprentice to a falconer.'' After becoming a fully-licensed falconer he also became a wildlife rehabilitator, and eventually provided a home to 28 birds of prey. In addition to literary agent, teacher, falconer, editor, actor and model, his other occupations and hobbies included life - long sailor, horseman, athlete, licensed airplane pilot, navigator, certified scuba diver, beekeeper, farmer and chef. Divorced in 1961, he is survived by his three children, Timothy Knowlton, Elizabeth Knowlton McNamara and Virginia Knowlton Canfield, along with three grandchildren, Heather, Perry and Alexis, many nieces and nephews, and innumerable friends, clients and colleagues who will miss him forever. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

NEW YORK KOREAN FILM FESTIVAL The Korean movies that Americans are most familiar with are the baroque revenge fantasies of Park Chan-wook (''Lady Vengeance,'' et al.) and the slow-moving erotic melodramas of Kim Ki-duk (''Time,'' ''Samaritan Girl''). That probably says more about us than it does about a wildly eclectic film industry whose domestic audience eats up historical costume dramas, war stories, slapstick comedies, maudlin contemporary soap operas, teen sex farces, Hong Kong-like cop stories, imitation-Japanese horror films and much more. Some idea of the breadth of the output can be gained from this sprawling 28-film, two-week festival, which opens Tuesday and includes screenings at Cinema Village, the IFC Center and BAMcinématek. It begins at the Brooklyn Academy of Music with a four-film retrospective of the veteran director Im Kwon-taek, including ''Festival'' (1996), above, with Oh Jeong-hae, left, and Ahn Sung-ki. After that comes a wide sampling of recent Korean films, including three of the country's top 10 all-time box-office hits: the plastic-surgery comedy ''200 Pound Beauty,'' the gambling drama/love story ''Tazza: The High Rollers'' and the controversial and hugely successful period piece ''The King and the Clown,'' with its hints of homosexuality. (Tuesday through Sept. 2 at various locations, koreanfilmfestival.org.) MIKE HALE

Vicktor Bologan, a grandmaster from Moldova, has won a Chess960 tournament at the Chess Classic in Mainz. The tournament used the rules of Chess960, also known as Fischer Random Chess, where all the pieces, except for the pawns, are shuffled before the first move. The idea is that players cannot use the openings that they have learned for regular chess and must instead rely on their wits from the beginning of the game. A good explanation of the rules and the history of Chess960 can be found here. The home page for the Mainz event, with all the results and some of the games, is here.

Mr. Snow earns $168,000 a year as an assistant to the president; he made much more than that as a conservative pundit and syndicated talk-show host on Fox News Radio. Neas is stepping down as the president of People for the American Way, a liberal organization that has fought President Bush’s conservative judicial nominations. “I just feel this is the time to make a move,” said Mr. Neas, 61. He has led the organization for eight years, and he said he would stay on as president emeritus while the group looked for a new leader. He said he did not have any immediate plans. Mr. Neas was a major figure in Robert H. Bork’s unsuccessful nomination for the Supreme Court, serving as chairman of the 300-organization Block Bork Coalition in 1987.

A law enacted this year allows Arkansans of any age — even infants — to marry if their parents give approval, and the governor may call a special session of the legislature to fix the mistake, lawmakers said. The legislation was intended to establish 18 as the minimum age to marry but also allow younger pregnant teenagers to marry with parental consent, said Representative Will Bond, a Democrat, who sponsored the bill. The bill contains an extraneous “not”: “In order for a person who is younger than 18 years of age and who is not pregnant to obtain a marriage license, the person must provide the county clerk with evidence of parental consent to the marriage.” Several lawmakers said a special session might be necessary to fix the error. Senator Sue Madison, a Democrat, said, “I am concerned about pedophiles coming to Arkansas to find parents who are willing to sign a very young child’s consent.”.

Nursing mothers who take codeine should watch their infants for increased sleepiness or other signs of overdose, federal health officials warned. The Food and Drug Administration warning of the rare but serious side effect was prompted by a 2006 report of the death of a nursing infant whose mother was given codeine for episiotomy pain. Genetic testing later showed that the woman’s body converted the codeine to morphine more rapidly and completely than in other people. That led to higher-than-expected morphine levels in her breast milk. Given the risk, the F.D.A. said, doctors should prescribe nursing mothers the smallest dose of codeine for the shortest period of time, and should closely monitor both mother and child.

The former Miami Heat swingman James Posey has agreed to plead guilty to reckless driving in connection with an incident in April in Miami Beach, prosecutors said yesterday. As part of his plea agreement, he must perform 50 hours of community service, complete six months of probation, and pay court costs and a $250 fine. Posey was arrested for drunken driving April 9 after the Miami Beach police pulled him over for stopping in the middle of a road. The police said that he was unsteady on his feet, that he had slurred speech and that his breath smelled of alcohol. Posey refused to take a breath test.Posey, a free agent, has played two seasons with Miami, and the Heat is among the teams pursuing him.

(Cinemax) PAN’S LABYRINTH (2006) The Mexican-born Guillermo del Toro directed this political fable cum fairy tale, set in a dark forest in 1944 Spain, about a young girl whose fantasies are trampled by her stepfather’s fascist politics. The film, in Spanish with English subtitles, received Academy Awards for cinematography, art direction and makeup, but lost the Oscar for best foreign-language film to “The Lives of Others,” from Germany. Ivana Baquero plays the film’s heroine, Ofelia, who longs to believe in fairies, princesses and magic lands; Doug Jones, above, plays the woodland creature (a couple of them, actually) who charges her with three tasks. “Fairy tales (and scary movies) are designed to console as well as terrify,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “What distinguishes ‘Pan’s Labyrinth,’ what makes it art, is that it balances its own magical thinking with the knowledge that not everyone lives happily ever after.”.

ZATZKIS--Henry, died peacefully at Saint John's Hospital in Santa Monica on August 15, 2007 at the age of 92. Beloved husband of Natalie and devoted father of Dr. Mark and the late David. Loving fatherin-law of Melissa. Born on April 7, 1915 in Holzminden, Germany, the son of Lifscha and Mordecai Zatzkis. He was a Holocaust survivor who narrowly escaped from Germany in 1939. He lived in London for a year before emigrating to New York in 1940. He received a degree from Ohio State University and Indiana University. He then taught at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill before receiving a Ph.D. in Physics from Syracuse University in 1950. On July 1, 1951 he married Natalie Serlin in Syracuse. Subsequently he taught mathematics at the University of Connecticut before joining the mathematics faculty at New Jersey Institute of Technology. There he was the Chairman of the Mathematics Department for 32 years before retiring in 1985. In 2000 he and his wife moved to Los Angeles where they have been residing for the past seven years. In addition to his wife and son Henry leaves three grandchildren whom he loved very much: Elliot, Hayley and Gregory Zatzkis . He is survived by his sister Rosel Goldbaum of San Diego. He will be fondly remembered and sorely missed by all of his family. Graveside services will be conducted Sunday 3:00pm August 19 at Hillside Memorial Park (800) 576-1994. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Hillel Foundation of Ohio Sate University, Columbus, Ohio or to St. John's Hospital and Health Center, Santa Monica, California would be appreciated.

A map with a foreign journal yesterday about citizen efforts to save the huge boulders of Hyderabad, India, from destruction during a development boom mislabeled in some copies a city in the southeast. It is Chennai, not Mumbai.

MANDL--David. Dear Dave, I just heard the news. I don't want to believe it. I'm thinking of all the times, of your great success at 688 and beyond. So many of us miss you, Dave. All the best Dave, all the best. Your pal, Peter Minthorn

TOUMEY--Dorothy Agnes Henry, of New Canaan, CT passed away August 16, 2007 with her family at her side. Beloved wife of the late Hugh J. Toumey, father of Donald J. and Kenneth D. Toumey, sister of Ethel H. White, and grandmother of Meghan E., Paul D. and Kerry A. Toumey. A mass of Christian burial will be celebrated on Monday, August 20, 2007, at 10am at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Connecticut. Interment will follow at Lakeview Cemetery in New Canaan. The family will receive friends at the Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main Street, New Canaan, Connecticut on Sunday, August 19, 2007, from 4-8pm.

A theater column on Thursday about the Edinburgh Fringe festival erroneously included a new adaptation of ''The Bacchae'' among its productions. ''The Bacchae'' is in the Edinburgh International Festival, not the Fringe festival.

An article on Aug. 2 about the Espresso Book Machine, a device that can produce a paperback from digital code in less than 15 minutes, referred imprecisely to Johannes Gutenberg, the 15th-century German inventor. He invented a method of printing from movable type that sped up book production in Europe considerably, but he did not invent movable type itself. (It originated in Asia centuries earlier.)
CHRISTMAN--Henry M. Rest, rest in peace noble Henry. You're still giving me life. Abraham

An article on Tuesday about Vintage Canoeworks, a Buffalo business that restores old canoes and boats and recently won a prize at a show in upstate New York, misstated part of the name of the museum that held the show. It is the Antique Boat Museum, not the Adirondack Boat Museum. A picture caption referred incorrectly to a boat being worked on by Wendy Valint, one of Vintage Canoeworks' owners. It is a canoe, not a guide boat, and it was built in 1920 by Old Town, not circa 1888 by E.G. Ricketson, as misstated in some copies.

DENNISON--Ethan Allen. The Board of Directors and staff of Riverdale Neighborhood House mourn the loss of our dear friend, E. Allen Dennison. We extend our deepest sympathy to his loving wife, Franny, and to his children and grandchildren. Denny's four decades of work as RNH President, Board member, and Honorary Board member made a remarkable, lasting impact in our community. He was a gracious colleague who will be greatly missed. Daniel Eudene, Executive Director Alison Pavia, Board President

DHITAL--Binod Prasad, Famous Nepali poet and novelist, our ''baba'' & ''dai'', took leave on Thursday morning the 16th of August 2007, at his home in Kathmandu, Nepal. Baba/Dai, you were our spiritual rock and guardian. We miss you and LOVE you. May you bless us, always. Sai Ram. Om Shanti Shanti Shanti (In our hearts always the Dhital, Gautam, Adhikary, Tiwari, Belbase, Koirala, & Sapkota families)
PALEY--Warren. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to his family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Howard A. Stecker, Senior Rabbi Hon. Richard Kestenbaum, President

MURRAY--Elizabeth. The world feels a lot more gray today without Elizabeth in it. She brought light and color to every thing and every life she touched. Her art is a vibrant and pulsing reminder of the woman, the mother, the generous and benevolent spirit, and most of all, the artist whom we lost. Not only will Elizabeth live on through the work she created, but she can also be seen in so many of New York's other artists, by whom she is beloved. We extend our love and sympathies to her entire family, and especially to Bob, Dakota, Sophia, and Daisy. Agnes Gund and Daniel Shapiro

Professional wrestling has been making headlines recently, mostly involving Chris Benoit, the wrestler who murdered his wife and 7-year-old son before killing himself in the family's suburban Atlanta home in June. World Wrestling Entertainment, the company that had Mr. Benoit under contract, said it was cooperating with investigators in Georgia and had received a Congressional request for any information it had on steroid and drug use in professional wrestling.

MICHELMAN--James, 77, beloved husband of Enid, died August 17 at Brigham & Women's, Boston. Raised in New Rochelle NY, an MIT graduate, he became CEO of Mainzer Minton, Inc., NY. After retiring from the textile industry, he began a Renaissance life in the Berkshires reading, writing, mentoring, and volunteering in diverse activities including founding the Emergency Services Fund, work as an EMT, tutoring, and serving on the Board of Shakespeare & Co. as Treasurer for many years. A son of Mike and Starr Michelman, Jim was a devoted husband and loving father of Lise Breen and Bill, Doug and Michelle, Tom and Mary. Jim also leaves behind his dear brother Frank I. Michelman. His twin brother Charles (Chuck) predeceased him. Their wives, Ellen and Peg, will miss him also. He was the proud grandfather of Leah and Aidan Breen, Sam, Caroline, Julie and Valerie Michelman, each so special to him. Jim saved lives and enhanced many others; he will be remembered for his sharp mind and his dedication to his family, friends and community. A celebration of his life for family and friends will be held on Monday, August 20 at 3:00 at the Meeting House, New Marlborough, followed by a gathering at Mepal Manor. Donations may be in Jim's name to the Literacy Network of South Berkshire, Lee, MA; Shakespeare & Co., Lenox, MA; or Doctors Without Borders.

A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with a dance review of the Mark Morris Dance Group, at the Mostly Mozart Festival, misidentified the work in which the dancers shown were performing. It was ''Double,'' not ''Twenty-seven.''

A music review on July 19 about Os Mutantes, at the Lincoln Center Festival, referred incorrectly to a song they performed, ''Top Top.'' It was from approximately the middle of their career; it was not among the earliest in the band's repertory.

Because of errors in a report by the National Conference of State Legislatures, an article on Aug. 6 about new immigration laws inaccurately described laws in three states. In Tennessee, a law provided for administrative, not criminal, procedures against employers who knowingly hire illegal immigrants, including temporary suspension of their business licenses. The bill did not create a new criminal offense of recklessly employing illegal immigrants or any new fines for prohibited hiring. Louisiana required drivers license applicants presenting foreign passports as proof of identity to provide documents showing they are authorized to be in the United States for at least 180 days, or 60 days for agricultural workers. It did not require applicants' names to be checked against federal immigration or terror lists. Minnesota's ban on illegal immigrants receiving its general assistance medical care has not changed.

It's time to start thinking seriously about Hillary Clinton's running mate. I know that the first primary is six months away (although the date keeps creeping backwards) and the conventions more than a year away, but this one is over before it's over. Clinton's national poll numbers are very high and if they hit 50 percent fence-sitters will climb down and join her ranks. John Edwards isn't going to catch fire, and Barack Obama has already caught all the fire he is able to ignite. With every day, the small possibility that Al Gore will join the race gets smaller. As for the other candidates, they are either running for vice president or just having a good time. To be sure, polls in Iowa and New Hampshire show a close contest, but I predict that as the time for actually voting gets closer, Clinton will pull away in those states, too, and the landslide will begin.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) — David Ortiz’s grand slam capped a six-run fifth inning, Curt Schilling earned his first victory since a one-hitter two months ago and the Boston Red Sox defeated the Anaheim Angels, 10-5, on Saturday night in a matchup of the teams with the best records in the majors.

Shawn Johnson won the United States gymnastics championships handily last night in San Jose, Calif. Her score of 123.650 was 3.450 points ahead of the runner-up, Shayla Worley. Johnson is sure to be a favorite at next month’s world championships in Stuttgart, Germany. The world team also includes Nastia Liukin, Alicia Sacramone, Samantha Peszek, Ivana Hong and Bridget Sloan. Jana Bieger, the world silver medalist, had difficulties and was left off the squad.

Denny Hamlin fought off a challenge from Matt Kenseth midway through the race yesterday, then drove away for a dominating victory in the Carfax 250 Nascar Busch Series race at Michigan International Speedway. Kevin Harvick, winner of the previous two Busch races, was third. Carl Edwards, who finished 28th after being hit from behind and spinning, still leads the series by 700 points over Harvick.

Nets forward Richard Jefferson announced Friday that he was donating $3.5 million to his alma mater, the University of Arizona, to help build a multisport practice facility. The planned $20 million project is expected to be completed by September 2008. Jefferson played at Arizona from 1999 to 2001.

For the third time in four years, Southern California will begin the season ranked No. 1 in the Associated Press top 25 poll. U.S.C. received 62 of 65 first-place votes and 1,622 points from a panel of news media members in the poll released yesterday. No. 2 Louisiana State, with two, and West Virginia had the other first-place votes. Texas, Michigan, the defending national champion Florida, Wisconsin, Oklahoma, Virginia Tech and Louisville round out the top 10. Ohio State, last year’s preseason No. 1, is at No. 11. Rutgers, ranked 16th, and No. 23 Hawaii are in the preseason poll for the first time.

Striker Brian McBride, who retired last year from the United States national team, dislocated his left kneecap while scoring for Fulham in a 2-1 victory over Middlesbrough yesterday in the English Premier League. The 35-year-old McBride, Fulham’s captain, will be sidelined several months.

High-flying Everton came crashing back to earth yesterday with a 1-0 defeat at Reading in the English Premier League. Stephen Hunt scored for Reading before halftime. Everton had won its first two games. In other games, Tottenham Hotspur beat newly promoted Derby County, 4-0; Wigan Athletic handed Roy Keane’s Sunderland its first loss with a 3-0 victory; and Portsmouth kept Bolton winless with a 3-1 victory.

Jens Voigt successfully defended his title in the Tour of Germany, finishing 1 minute 57 seconds ahead of Levi Leipheimer of Discovery Channel. Voigt, a German who rides for CSC, won Friday’s time trial, making yesterday’s 89-mile stage a formality.

The president of badminton’s world governing body yesterday lashed out at the group’s top council after it passed a vote of no confidence in him in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Kang Young Joong, the president of the Badminton World Federation, said the federation had become “mired in darkness.” The controversy revolves around the move of the federation’s headquarters to Kuala Lumpur from Cheltenham in England. The federation is investigating pledges of money and airline tickets that were reportedly made by Kang’s deputy, the former Malaysian shuttler Datuk Gunalan.

AFTER nearly nine years of study and more than a hundred public meetings, Federal Aviation Administration officials say they are weeks away from issuing a final decision on how to reroute airline flights over the region to ease bottlenecks in the sky. As Alex Kotlowitz reports, the contradictions and complexities of the immigration influx encourage cultural clashes and the accompanying fear and resentment (Aug. 5). Carpentersville, Ill., is a perfect microcosm of the national situation. People are inherently leery of the unknown. Just as the primary force spurring the illegal immigration explosion is economics, the impetus behind the backlash is fear. The result is that threatened Americans strike out at threatened immigrants, driving them farther underground and away from assimilation. Kotlowitz, with his probing look into circumstances and opinions of all sides involved, attempts to answer many questions, but one remains unresolved. When does fear and animus turn into bigotry? There is no conclusive evidence that Judy Sigwalt or Paul Humpfer are bigots, but many of their policies foster bigotry and are self-defeating. Compassion and compromise, not truculence and intimidation, will resolve the current immigration stalemate.

Jack Kerouac once said of the many foreign editions of his novels: ''When I'm old, you know what I'm going to do? I'm going to study languages reading these.'' Kerouac didn't get to grow old -- he died in 1969 at 47. But foreign editions of his books, especially ''On the Road,'' continue to multiply. The covers of ''On the Road'' shown below are taken from a fascinating Web page -- find it by Googling ''Jack Kerouac Book Covers'' -- maintained by Dave Moore, a Kerouac scholar. (He edited ''Neal Cassady: Collected Letters, 1944-1967,'' the correspondence of Kerouac's friend and muse, who died in 1968.) Moore began buying these editions in the 1960s, often swapping copies with other collectors. The covers range from the eerily evocative to the deeply silly: see the 2000 cover from China, in which Kerouac's characters seem to be reimagined as the cast from ''St. Elmo's Fire.'' The one at the top left, by the way, is from the first edition of ''On the Road,'' issued by Viking in 1957. 1. United States, 1957

In terms of seasonal art pleasures, few outings in the Hudson River Valley match a visit to the Hammond Museum and Japanese Stroll Garden in North Salem. You can stop at the museum, then at your leisure putter around the Japanese-inspired gardens stretching over about three and a half acres. Now and through the fall is a terrific time to visit, not only because of the changing foliage but also because the museum is host to a small but worthy exhibition highlighting the work of about a dozen contemporary Korean artists. It dovetails nicely with the museum's focus on Asian art and culture.

KNOWLTON--Perry H. Renowned literary agent and the former Chairman and CEO of Curtis Brown, Ltd., one of the world's oldest literary agencies, died on July 6, 2007 at the New York State Veterans' Home at Montrose in Westchester County, after a long and valiant battle with Alzheimer's disease. He was 80 years old. Born at Miss Lippincott's Lying-In Hospital in New York City on March 25, 1927, he grew up in Rye, New York. Among his childhood cohort was a young Barbara Pierce, later Barbara Bush. Upon graduating from Phillips Exeter Academy, he served in the army from 1945 to 1946. Adventurous from a young age, at 19 Knowlton and a friend crossed the Atlantic from New York to England in a 21-foot sailboat. He returned to the United States to a comparatively more settled existence as a member of Princeton's class of 1949, but his continued peripatetic nature is apparent from his roundabout journey to the center of the New York literary world. After a stint as an English teacher at the Lawrenceville School in New Jersey, he took a job in regional sales for the college textbook division of Charles Scribner's Publishers, initially in Cincinnati and then in Tucson. Knowlton married Louisa C. Tripp in 1954 and finally reached Gotham in 1956. He took a job as an editor at Scribner's, where he stayed for several years before moving into the world of agenting in 1959, when he was hired by Alan Collins, the president of Curtis Brown, Ltd. Knowlton ran the agency's book department and in 1968, following Collins's death, became President and owner of the firm. He personally represented dozens of authors and their estates, a veritable Who's-Who of 20th Century literature, including W.H. Auden, Daphne DuMaurier, Robertson Davies, Ogden Nash, Ayn Rand, Diana Gabaldon, Tony Hillerman, Frank Robinson, Jean Craighead George, Betty Friedan, Nicholas Monsarrat, Samuel Eliot Morison, A.A. Milne, Frederik Pohl, Harrison Salisbury, Frederick Forsythe, Brian Moore, Pauline Kael, Louis Auchincloss, John Knowles, C. S. Lewis, and Alvin and Heidi Toffler. He also represented Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Joseph Stalin, after her defection in 1967. He worked fiercely to protect author's rights and interests, and served on the executive board of the Society of Authors' Representatives for more than 20 years. He was one of the principal engineers in bringing about the merger of the SAR with the Independent Literary Agents Association to form the Association of Author's Representatives in 1991 and served as its President from 1993 to 1995. Perry Knowlton was known for his keen intellect, courtly manners, and good looks. He was a handsome man-more than a man of letters ever needed to be. As a sideline in the late 1950's and early 1960's, while still practicing as an agent, he modeled for print and TV advertising for Xerox and Budweiser, among others. Most notably, he was one of the original ''Marlboro Men''. He was also one of the founding members of the Friends of the Earth in 1969, along with former Sierra Club president David Brower. In 1995, several years before fully retiring from his agency practice at Curtis Brown, he returned to his boyhood interest in falconry, describing himself, at the age of 68, as ''the world's oldest apprentice to a falconer.'' After becoming a fully-licensed falconer he also became a wildlife rehabilitator, and eventually provided a home to 28 birds of prey. In addition to literary agent, teacher, falconer, editor, actor and model, his other occupations and hobbies included life - long sailor, horseman, athlete, licensed airplane pilot, navigator, certified scuba diver, beekeeper, farmer and chef. Divorced in 1961, he is survived by his three children, Timothy Knowlton, Elizabeth Knowlton McNamara and Virginia Knowlton Canfield, along with three grandchildren, Heather, Perry and Alexis, many nieces and nephews, and innumerable friends, clients and colleagues who will miss him forever. A memorial service will be held in the fall.

ANSLINGER--Patricia L., Global Head of M&A and Corporate Strategy at Accenture, age 47, died at her home in Manhattan. Prior to Accenture, Ms. Anslinger was a partner with McKinsey & Co., where she founded McKinseys private equity practice. She served on the board of directors of The Children's Law Center and worked tirelessly to help people afflicted with lung cancer, particularly non-smoker's lung cancer, which took her life. Ms. Anslinger earned an engineering degree from Purdue University and an MBA from UCLA, having turned down an acceptance to Harvard Business School. She received Purdue's 2007 Outstanding Engineer award for leadership. She is survived by her husband Victor J. Geraci, and their children, Olivia, V. Maximilian and Isabella. A service will be held on August 27 at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY. ANSLINGER--Patricia. An exceptional woman, exemplified strength and courage for all of us who had the privilege of being her friend, we will miss her. Vicky, Angus and family

CORNWALL--Joseph Clift. Beloved and Widely Respected Philanthropic Leader. While an undergraduate at Princeton University, Joseph Clift Cornwall married his senior prom date, Barbara Wallace, just before graduating in 1939. Thus began a wonderful union and an association with the Wallace family that led to the founding of what later became The Fund for New Jersey. As chairman of the board of The Fund for New Jersey for its first twentyseven years, Joe Cornwall shaped a philanthropic mission to promote a more equitable and open society, and attracted to its board thoughtful statesmen, scholars and community leaders. A mentor to so many in the field, he fostered informed and intelligent deliberation in examining pressing social issues and evaluating public policy intended to address them. From its founding in 1969, Mr. Cornwall's wise leadership proved crucial to every Fund for New Jersey initiative and grant we have made in our thirty-eight year history. The cause of equal access to quality education led him to urge early support for the legal rights of urban school children. Equitable school financing became a commitment that The Fund has supported for over thirty years. What perhaps most guided Joe Cornwall was his conviction that in our democracy, an informed citizenry holds ultimate authority. So he kept an eye on the role of government to remove artificial barriers, adapt policy to meet social changes, and always to keep government accountable to the people governed. Mr. Cornwall actively supported the founding of New Jersey's public broadcasting television station, NJN, and numerous projects like the public affairs journal New Jersey Reporter to bring to the public information on the issues and opportunities before them. Joe Cornwall's search for underlying causes of social injustice was a lifelong pursuit. In 1999, The Fund for New Jersey honored our beloved founding chairman by establishing and endowing the Joseph C. Cornwall Center for Metropolitan Studies at Rutgers University, which today carries on applied policy research to better address urban issues. Genuinely humble, more intent on hearing what others could contribute than on being heard himself, affirming and optimistic in outlook; our dear friend, mentor, colleague, and leader, continues to provide us the example by which we strive to live. Leonard Lieberman Chairman of the Board The Fund for New Jersey Mark M. Murphy President The Fund for New Jersey

SERETEAN--M.B. (Bud), carpet industry pioneer, successful entrepreneur, philanthropist, author and wellness proponent, died Monday, August 13, 2007, in London, England. He was 83. The cause of death was a brain hemorrhage. A native New Yorker and long-time resident of Chattanooga, TN, Seretean lived for the past 25 years in Boca Raton, FL. He served as a field artillery officer in the Mediterranean theater during World War II before getting a B.S. degree in marketing from Oklahoma State University and an M.S. degree in retailing from New York University. He began his career as an assistant floor coverings buyer for Allied Stores in New York. Seretean co-founded Coronet Industries Inc. in Dalton, GA, in 1956, and served as its Chairman and Chief Executive Officer for 30 years. The carpet, furniture and wall coverings manufacturer quickly grew to $400 million in sales and 4000 employees and was purchased in 1971 by RCA Corporation. Seretean recently received a Lifetime Achievement Award from the Floor Coverings Industry Foundation. Seretean's entrepreneurial spirit continued after his decades at Coronet. His other successful business ventures included co-founding Opti World in Atlanta, GA, which was ultimately sold to Lens Crafters; and co-founding ABC-TV affiliate WGXA in Macon, GA. His lifelong love of sports led him to the NBA in the 1970s when he coowned the Atlanta Hawks and served as President and General Manager of the franchise until it was later sold to Ted Turner. Seretean then became a member of the Board of Directors for Turner Broadcasting Systems (TBS), the Atlanta Hawks and the Atlanta Braves and served on all three Boards for 20 years. Seretean was known not only for his business acumen but also for his dedication to and tireless efforts on behalf of the various charitable organizations with which he was affiliated. He was an ardent supporter of his alma mater, Oklahoma State University. He served as President of OSU's Board of Governors and received an honorary doctorate from OSU in 1999, on the 50th anniversary of his graduation, for his professional achievements and philanthropic activities. It was during a visit to a Pritikin Longevity Center 25 years ago that Seretean realized the importance of wellness in his own life and committed himself to promoting its benefits to others. He founded and financed The Seretean Wellness Center at OSU and served as the driving force for the Seretean Center for Health Promotion at Emory University in Atlanta, GA, which promote healthy lifestyles by providing members of the university and the surrounding community access to the state-ofthe-art facilities and educational programs. Seretean served for 12 years on The President's Council for Physical Fitness and Sports. At 80, he was inspired by teachers Nathan Pritikin and Dean Ornish to write and publish ''Living Healthy to 100''. His dedication to practicing and promoting wellness culminated in his being awarded one of the first Lifetime Achievement Awards from The President's Council for Fitness and Sports. Seretean served as President of the Jewish Welfare Federation while living in Chattanooga and has for decades supported Israel. In recent years, he found a way to marry his commitments to Israel and wellness. Through Friends of the Israel Defense Forces, Seretean funded multiple facilities serving the soldiers of Israel, including a state-of-the-art wellness center located on a military base in the Negev. Recognizing his Romanian heritage, Seretean built a Holocaust memorial to the Jews of Dorohoi, Romania. It is located in the Judean Hills outside Jerusalem. He also planted a grove of trees honoring Romanian Jewry through the Jewish National Fund. Seretean believed in expanding access to the arts and to education as well and provided primary funding for the M.B. Seretean Center for the Performing Arts at OSU and endowed numerous scholarships at several universities. He was a member of the Board of Directors at Rhodes College in Memphis, TN, and served on the Board of the UC (University of Chattanooga) Foundation. Seretean was a member of the National Board of Directors and Chairman of Government Relations Committee for the Boys and Girls Clubs of America. Seretean's survivors include his fiance, Judy Murata; daughters Tracy Seretean, Amanda Grossman and Patricia Seretean; son, Scott Seretean; stepson, Mark Warner; sisters Zella Witt and Rhoda Naidus; grandchildren Farol, Arden and Derek Seretean; three nieces; four nephews; extended family and many friends. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made either to Friends of the Israel Defense Forces (8177 West Glades Road, Suite 208, Boca Raton, FL 33434), the OSU Foundation (P.O. Box 1749, Stillwater, OK 74076) or the charity of your choice. Funeral services for M.B. Seretean will be held Monday, August 20, 2007, at 10:00am at Temple Beth El, 333 SW 4th Avenue, Boca Raton, FL 33432. Services are by Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, 7240 North Federal Highway, Boca Raton, FL 33487.

FLOWERMAN--Marvin S. International entrepreneur, sportsman, artist, and public servant, died August 12, 2007, at his home in Far Hills, NJ at age 82. Born in NYC to Joseph and Bessie A. Flowerman, Marvin graduated Brooklyn College at age eighteen to join the army. Just before departing, he married Leonora (Libby) Rosenberg, to whom he was married for 62 years. He fought in the Battle of the Bulge as a platoon sergeant and translator, and served in military government. Marvin parlayed his language proficiency to secure work in foreign trade and capitalized on opportunities he observed to establish in 1952 a business which more effectively served remote suppliers and their clientele. He traveled extensively, building decades-long friendships. He began a twenty-seven year partnership with Paul Greene in 1955, establishing PL Thomas Inc., a sister paper trading company, and several manufacturing companies. He also earned a Masters degree in international economics from the New School. He was joined in 1976 by his son Paul and guided him for nine years before moving on to pottery making, elected office and philanthropy in Far Hills. Building upon his previous studies of sculpting with John Terkin, drawing with Edwin Lanning, and ceramics at Raritan Valley Community College, Marvin set up a ceramics studio in his home with three kilns. After back problems forced him to give up his beloved competitive tennis (he served for many years as the tennis chairman for Roxiticus Golf Club) he also led the fund raising and construction of the greatly expanded Bedminster/Far Hills Library. He served six years as an elected Far Hills councilman, a position he resumed this past year to work very actively with the mayor and the police department. He was preparing for reelection as well as an art show. Mr. Flowerman is survived by his widow, Libby Flowerman, whose mutual love of piano playing brought them together, his brother Ted Flowerman, his daughter, Dr. Amy Cades and her husband Lonny Cades, son Paul Flowerman and his wife, Margot Jackler, and six grandchildren: Lisa and David Cades, Aviva Flowerman Vikstrom, and Josh, Seth, and Zac Flowerman. He was courageous in many facets of his life, and his accounts of his exotic adventures captivated multiple generations. He will be cherished for his devotion and generosity to his extended family, friends, and community. A funeral service was held Wednesday, August 15. at Temple B'nai Or, Overlook Road, Morristown, NJ. Donations may be made to Metrowest Jewish Foundation, Chromosome 18 Registry, or Memorial Sloan Kettering. For more info, Bernheim Apter Kreitzman 800-938-6372.

HARVEY--Larry D., 69, died peacefully at home in East Hampton, NY, on Wednesday August 15th, after a valiant struggle with cancer. He was the beloved husband of Donna, loving father of Pamela and Susan, father-in-law of Jay and Darin, and adoring grandfather of Jason, Hunter, Courtney, Zach, Sam and Lily. Born in Mexico, Missouri, he was a graduate of Westminster College in Fulton, Missouri, and received an advanced degree in Hotel Management from the University of Denver. Larry was for many years a highly respected member of the hotel community in New York City; serving as the Executive Director of Catering at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for eleven years and then as the Executive Director of Catering at The Plaza for 15 years. He was a member of the University Club in New York City and served on the Board of Directors of the Jeffrey Modell Foundation. He was a member of the Waldorf-Astoria Distinguished Alumni Association and a recipient of the Westminster College Alumni Award, as well as a Churchill Fellow of Westminster College. Larry was a recipient of the Cardinal's Award for Humanitarian Efforts, Hospitality & Tourism Division, awarded by the Archdiocese of New York and, also, a recipient of the Jerusalem Founders Man of the Year Award, presented by Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem. One of his proudest accomplishments was in being the author of ''A Plaza Wedding'', published by Villard Books, a division of Random House, in 1996. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, August 25th, at 3:00pm at the Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 94 Pantigo Road, East Hampton, New York, to be followed by a reception to celebrate Larry's life at the Maidstone Arms on Main Street, East Hampton, New York. Larry's family and friends will cherish all the good memories he leaves behind. Memorial contributions in Larry's name may be made to the Jeffrey Modell Foundation, 747 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017.

MICHELMAN--James, 77, beloved husband of Enid, died August 17 at Brigham & Women's, Boston. Raised in New Rochelle NY, an MIT graduate, he became CEO of Mainzer Minton, Inc., NY. After retiring from the textile industry, he began a Renaissance life in the Berkshires reading, writing, mentoring, and volunteering in diverse activities including founding the Emergency Services Fund, work as an EMT, tutoring, and serving on the Board of Shakespeare & Co. as Treasurer for many years. A son of Mike and Starr Michelman, Jim was a devoted husband and loving father of Lise Breen and Bill, Doug and Michelle, Tom and Mary. Jim also leaves behind his dear brother Frank I. Michelman. His twin brother Charles (Chuck) predeceased him. Their wives, Ellen and Peg, will miss him also. He was the proud grandfather of Leah and Aidan Breen, Sam, Caroline, Julie and Valerie Michelman, each so special to him. Jim saved lives and enhanced many others; he will be remembered for his sharp mind and his dedication to his family, friends and community. A celebration of his life for family and friends will be held on Monday, August 20 at 3:00 at the Meeting House, New Marlborough, followed by a gathering at Mepal Manor. Donations may be in Jim's name to the Literacy Network of South Berkshire, Lee, MA; Shakespeare & Co., Lenox, MA; or Doctors Without Borders.

HOMEOWNERS who have seen the value of their houses drop below the amount left on their mortgages and who are struggling to make their monthly payments often believe their only option is to walk away from the loans and accept a foreclosure. Not so, lenders say. Borrowers can both avoid foreclosure and escape their mortgage debt, provided they are willing to give up their homes and accept at least some collateral damage to their credit ratings.

All of the old-timers knew that subprime mortgages were what we called neutron loans -- they killed the people and left the houses. The deals made in 2005 and 2006 were going to run into trouble because the credit pendulum at the time was stuck at easy. LOUIS S. BARNES, a partner at Boulder West, a mortgage banking firm. [17]

JODY--Alexander, M.D., 85, died on August 15, 2007. A most dedicated physician for more than 50 years, he continued to treat patients until his health prevented him from doing so, well into his 84th year. Loving and beloved husband of Sarah Jody, father of Nina Jody and Michael Jody, stepfather of Marcy Miller and Jerry Askin. Adoring grandfather of Sophia and Luke and step-grandfather of Douglas, Elizabeth, Joshua, Amy and Jeffrey. He also leaves behind his brother Boris Jody, his son and daughters-in-law, Robert Soloway, Jamie Lerner and Bonnie Askin. Besides being a gifted and caring doctor, he spoke many languages, travelled widely, read broadly and had a great sense of humor. He will be remembered for his intelligence, gentleness, wit and the compassion he showed to others.

WILSON--Ruth. Born January 22, 1919, in Salt Lake City, Utah. Her friends and extended family mourn Ruth's death at the Mary Manning Walsh Home on August 13, 2007. She lived as Mother Mildred at the Benedictine Abbey of Regina Laudis, in Bethlehem, CT, from March 1949 until October 1969. Dispensed from her vows, she moved to New York City, where she taught reading in the public schools and later worked as an editor for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. In 1972 her book for young adults, ''Our Blood and Tears: Black Freedom Fighters,'' was published by Putnam's. Ruth made prayer, study, and work a part of every day. Her last project (uncompleted) was a concordance of the ideas of Dutch theologian Edward Schillebeeckx. Just predeceased by her sister Rebecca Wilson Hodge, Ruth leaves her brother Grant Wilson, nieces, nephews, cousins, greatnieces, great-nephews, and many friends. We will miss her erudition, unshakably clear thinking, and deep capacity for friendship. Family and friends will be advised of the date of a Mass to be celebrated for Ruth at St. Francis Xavier Church, NYC.

The original concept of congestion pricing, which was held up in Albany, didn't make stuck-up Manhattan smartypants suffer enough, rural New York politicos explain -- so they've added new hindrances, extra confusion and more tolls to make Gothamites squirm. Midtown pedestrian congestion is the excuse for stiff tolls on foot traffic below 86th Street; a new E-ZPass-like ''FOOTZIP'' electronic name tag lets impatient ambulators bypass turnstiles. Cyclists pay for being so annoying with a $4 toll of their own.

ZATZKIS--Henry, died peacefully at Saint John's Hospital in Santa Monica on August 15, 2007 at the age of 92. Beloved husband of Natalie and devoted father of Dr. Mark and the late David. Loving fatherin-law of Melissa. Born on April 7, 1915 in Holzminden, Germany, the son of Lifscha and Mordecai Zatzkis. He was a Holocaust survivor who narrowly escaped from Germany in 1939. He lived in London for a year before emigrating to New York in 1940. He received a degree from Ohio State University and Indiana University. He then taught at the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill before receiving a Ph.D. in Physics from Syracuse University in 1950. On July 1, 1951 he married Natalie Serlin in Syracuse. Subsequently he taught mathematics at the University of Connecticut before joining the mathematics faculty at New Jersey Institute of Technology. There he was the Chairman of the Mathematics Department for 32 years before retiring in 1985. In 2000 he and his wife moved to Los Angeles where they have been residing for the past seven years. In addition to his wife and son Henry leaves three grandchildren whom he loved very much: Elliot, Hayley and Gregory Zatzkis . He is survived by his sister Rosel Goldbaum of San Diego. He will be fondly remembered and sorely missed by all of his family. Graveside services will be conducted Sunday 3:00pm August 19 at Hillside Memorial Park (800) 576-1994. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Hillel Foundation of Ohio Sate University, Columbus, Ohio or to St. John's Hospital and Health Center, Santa Monica, California would be appreciated.

TRIFFON--George, 74, passed away on August 7th at Cabrini Hospice Care due to complications from a stroke. He was the only son of Penelope and George Triffon of Port Jefferson, New York. He graduated from Point Jefferson High School. He acquired a commercial pilot's license in the early 1960's and in 1999 graduated ''Cum Laude'' with a B.A. degree from John Jay College of the City of NY. George was born in New York City on July 2nd, 1933. After receiving an Honorable Discharge from the US Army in 1953, he moved to Miami Beach and began an illustrious career as the lead trumpet player for Tito Puente. While there, he played with the touring Count Basie Orchestra. In 1955 he returned to New York and secured a three year stint at the Copacabana, playing for Frank Sinatra, Peggy Lee, Paul Anka, Tony Bennett, Nat Cole and Pearl Bailey. He was a member of the studio orchestra on The Merv Griffin Show. In addition to playing in many successful Broadway shows, Mr. Triffon was on the jazz scene where he played with the Duke Ellington and Benny Goodman bands at Basin Street East. Eventually he joined Goodman's band to tour in the summer of 1962, where he met his wife (singer Sandy Stewart). He also toured with Les Brown and Lionel Hampton. He was quoted in a recent interview; ''Playing for pianist Bill Evans on his album, 'From Left to Right,' was one of the biggest thrills of my career.'' He made several recordings with trombonist Bill Watrous' big band as well. Aside from his musical career, Mr. Triffon was an accomplished athlete. He worked as a lifeguard at Riis Park and Delray Beach for 20 years. At the age of 54, he won eight gold medals in swimming events in the seniors' masters competition. He is survived by his wife, Sandy Stewart and seven children; daughter Lori Elgazzar, Wendy Taylor, mother of George and Christine Triffon, cousins Denos and Lavalle Marvin; step children: Anne, Tom, Katherine and Bill Charlap and six grandchildren. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on August 22nd at 7 pm at St. Peter's Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, NYC.

COLLIER--Chester F. The Board of Governors, the officers and members of The Westminster Kennel Club deeply mourn the passing of their friend and colleague, former president and show chairman Chester F. Collier. Mr. Collier won seven Emmys and helped build Fox News into a world media power during a lifetime in television production, but he will also be well-remembered as the man who made the annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show into the world's most famous dog show, with millions of viewers on live television and the Internet, a sold-out Madison Square Garden, and the object of worldwide media attention. Mr. Collier died Wednesday, August 15 at his home in Wellington, FL, from complications of diabetes. He was 80. ''Chet's knowledge of the sport and his television background created a vision that helped to enhance and grow a unique event that continues to be the very best our sport has to offer'', said Westminster President Peter R. Van Brunt. ''He will live on in this wonderful legacy he has left for the club, its members, the sport, and the dog-loving public''. This past February, Mr. Collier, past president (1989-2001), show chairman (1978-1989) and long-time member (since 1973) of the Westminster Kennel Club, was honored as the first recipient of the club's Sensation Award, in recognition of his contribution to the club, to purebred dogs, and the sport of showing dogs. ''No individual in modern times has had a more positive influence on our sport than Chet Collier'', said Westminster Show Chairman Thomas H. Bradley, 3d. ''He single-handedly created live televised dog shows, embodied by his very own world-famous Westminster. Because of him, millions of people share in this annual celebration of the dog in our lives. Fortunately, he has left behind a number of proteges to carry on his vision. All of us at Westminster and indeed, all of us in the sport of dogs, are most sincerely in his debt''. Mr. Collier was a long time network television producer and executive with Group W Productions, Westinghouse Broadcasting, CNBC and Fox News. He was president of Group W and Westinghouse Broadcasting, where he oversaw the development and production of the Mike Douglas Show, the Regis Philbin Show, The Steve Allen Show, the Merv Griffin Show and the David Frost Talk Show. In the mid-1990s, he assisted Rupert Murdoch and Roger Ailes in launching the Fox News Channel, which today is the top-rated cable news channel (Mr. Ailes had worked for him on the Mike Douglas Show). In addition to his Emmy awards, Mr. Collier also won the George Foster Peabody Award and the Robert F. Kennedy Journalism Award. He was a past president of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences/New England. A native of Boston, Mr. Collier became involved with purebred dogs in the 1960s, showing Bouviers des Flandres and enjoying great competitive success, with more than 50 Bests In Show. In addition to his Westminster roles, he served as an AKC delegate for a number of years and sat on the AKC's board of directors from 1986 to 1990. ''His influence, wisdom and devotion to the sport are without comparison and many of the modern, positive changes at AKC can be traced directly to Chet Collier'', said Dog News in 2000. That was the year that Westminster accorded him the honor of judging Best In Show. He was also a past president of the American Bouvier des Flandres Club, and a member of the Westchester Kennel Club and Eastern Dog Club. Mr. Collier is survived by his wife, Dorothy; three children: Ruth, Greg and Rich; and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Florida at 6pm on Saturday evening, August 18, at Palms West Funeral Home, 110 Business Parkway in Royal Palm Beach. Another service will be held in New York in September on a date and location to be announced. The family requests that in lieu of flowers a donation in his name be made to: Take The Lead, PO Box 6353, Watertown, NY 13601.

Babys First Diet Pill ''Remaking the age-old survival mechanisms of the human body'' is, in the case of infant feeding, completely unnecessary (Annie Murphy Paul, Aug. 5). The age-old survival mechanism is still in place and still works. Human milk contains the appetite-regulating hormone leptin, and the act of breast-feeding allows a baby to be in control of how much he eats. These factors help explain why babies who are breast-fed are less likely to become obese as children and adults. Furthermore, breast-feeding is free, unlike specialty formulas. Mother Nature has it right.

Some would say that Brooke Astor's hats were her signature, but in fact it was her white kid gloves. She put on a fresh pair each night, sending her worn ones to Paris to be cleaned. The dictator of her look was not a particular designer, but her French maid, Raymonde Tissot-Bellin. Every day, Madame Tissot-Bellin laid out her clothes and selected the jewels she was to wear. Mrs. Astor always dressed appropriately, and she always dressed to be attractive to men.

AFTER nearly nine years of study and more than a hundred public meetings, Federal Aviation Administration officials say they are weeks away from issuing a final decision on how to reroute airline flights over the region to ease bottlenecks in the sky. Communities that fear a sharp increase in the number of flights rumbling overhead are now turning to what they say is their only chance to stave off noise pollution: the courts. ''A lawsuit is a near certainty,'' said Jerome Feder of the New Jersey Coalition Against Aircraft Noise, based in Scotch Plains. ''There are so many legal bases to litigate on, and I believe we can defeat it.''

My last column before beginning a book leave is about energy conservation. Dick Cheney once dismissed it as a sign of personal virtue, but no basis for an energy policy -- but I argue that in fact conservation is the low-hanging fruit in the effort to address carbon emissions and climate change. There wasn't space in the column to go into this, but there's also a major national security argument for conservation: The more we reduce our oil dependency, the less vulnerable we are to the whims of Iran and Venezuela. What's more, if we curb demand, that tends to dampen the oil price -- which means less revenue for Iran to invest in nuclear weapons.

Barely a week after being purchased, Student Council made his first trip to the West Coast and stunned the defending champion Lava Man yesterday to win the $1 million Pacific Classic by a half-length at Del Mar in California.Sent off as the even-money favorite, Lava Man faded to sixth.“I thought he ran a great race,” Lava Man’s trainer, Doug O’Neill, said. “He just wasn’t good enough.”Eager to win the Pacific Classic after his horse Super Frolic finished third last year and fifth in 2005, the owner Ro Parra bought Student Council on Aug. 10 from Will Farish, who bred Student Council.The horse was shipped from Saratoga to Del Mar, where the trainer Vladimir Cerin gave him a few workouts on the new synthetic Polytrack surface.At 23-1 odds, Student Council and the jockey Richard Migliore covered one and a quarter miles in 2 minutes 7.29 seconds and paid $48.80 on a $2 bet to win. The horse’s time was the slowest in race history, although the Classic was being run on Polytrack for the first time.
